                "html": "<blockquote><p>Deep in the heart of London, a young photographer named Tom Argent walks the streets and captures whatever catches his eye: an old man drinking coffee; a striking woman sipping champagne in St. Pancras station; a cloud of moths taking flight across the sky. He’s orphaned, lonely, and lost in his work. He certainly has no intention of falling in love.</p>\n<p>And yet, love finds him in the shape of beautiful Vanessa, who lives a dangerous double life in the heart of the city. Tom’s pursuit of Vanessa leads him to discover an alternate world, hiding in plain sight among the streets and rooftops of London. A world unseen by common folk and inhabited by strange and colorful beings, in which two warring factions—one nocturnal, one in the light—wage war for the sake of a long-lost love, which can only end with one side’s total annihilation.</p></blockquote>\n<hr>\n<p><strong>Dabney</strong>: I have been a Harris fan for decades. <strong>The Moonlight Market</strong> utterly enchanting and I adored it. Marian, how did you feel about it?</p>\n<p><strong>Marian</strong>: It&#8217;s certainly different from <strong>Chocolat</strong> and <strong>Five Quarters of the Orange</strong>, just as deliciously atmospheric but with more of a fairytale feel to it. It wasn&#8217;t a perfect read for me, but it was very close.The gradually revealed story of the war and its consequences was like myth meeting reality, and this book made me want three things : 1. a pair of wings 2. a visit to the Moonlight Market 3. a sequel.</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney</strong>: SO, in the world of this book, humans exist side by side with fairies. The fairies, due to a romance that turned sour ages ago, have split into two kingdoms, that of the Moths and the Butterflies, and are at war with one another. Tom, a man who lives a quiet, rather empty life as a photographer in London, falls, he thinks, in love with a Butterfly, the gorgeous Vanessa. As he pursues her, he becomes ensnared in the fairy world and its war. And, slowly, he realizes his connection with the fairies runs far deeper than he would have ever expected.</p>\n<p>I loved this set up. I love fairy tales and this is an intricate one, with heroes and villains on all sides. What did you think of the world building?</p>\n<p><strong>Marian</strong>: Detailed and evocative. You can almost smell the incense and gingerbread and dried flowers in the market. Even the way the fairies speak is different. There are daylight names and midnight names, and I like the nickname for Tom &#8211; &#8220;chrysalis&#8221;, something that could produce either a moth or a butterfly.</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney</strong>: This is, wonderfully, a love story with both a main couple and an usual secondary one. What did you think&#8211;no spoilers!&#8211;of the romances here?</p>\n<p><strong>Marian</strong>: Unfortunately I didn&#8217;t enjoy the main romance as much as I did the rest of the book. For a large chunk of the story, I was thinking, &#8220;Don&#8217;t! Don&#8217;t do that! Don&#8217;t be taken in!&#8221; only to sigh in frustration as the character did exactly what they shouldn&#8217;t have done. Plus, there&#8217;s glamour and temptation, but I felt these worked their spell for so long that the actual romance got a little shortchanged in the process &#8211; in the end, there simply wasn&#8217;t enough space remaining in the book to convince me of true love. I liked the individual characters. I just wish they&#8217;d had more screen time together to develop their relationship.</p>\n<p>When I first read the book, I thought the secondary romance could also have used more development, but looking back, I think this was foreshadowed with the recounting of the myth at the start of each part of the book. It tied up some loose ends as well. I wasn&#8217;t as emotionally invested in this one because, to be honest, I disliked one of the characters involved and felt more of a redemption arc was needed here.</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney</strong>: Tom is irksomely clueless for too long. But I felt that was realistic given how the magic worked on him. So I was frustrated but I accepted it.</p>\n<p>Harris has always written leads that aren&#8217;t necessarily likeable. My favorite of hers is possibly <strong>Runemarks</strong>&#8211;I have a profound weakness for retelling of Norse mythology&#8211;and, in that novel, several of the main characters do things that made me crazy. I suspect I am a reader who doesn&#8217;t need to like a character as much as I need to believe they are improving.</p>\n<p>So, we&#8217;ll agree we see the romances differently!</p>\n<p>What else struck you?</p>\n<p><strong>Marian</strong>: I don&#8217;t usually mind unlikeable protagonists outside of romance, but I think with this book, the romantic aspect started early enough that I began expecting Tom to be more like a romance hero rather than &#8220;irksomely clueless&#8221; (great turn of phrase!). And with other flaws, the character and I can still be on the same page, whereas if a character is intensely naive when it comes to the villain, I&#8217;m far ahead and waiting for the character to catch up. But as you said, we see the romances differently!</p>\n<p>Another plus point was the time travel aspect. I&#8217;m fascinated by alternate versions of cities, and I enjoyed London Before/London Beyond. It&#8217;s a great example of the way the story unfolds, beginning with Tom&#8217;s small, mundane life but expanding into the secrets of the Market and spreading from there to encompass another world and a different time entirely. I like the plotting here as well, and the twist of how the battle started (if that&#8217;s not too spoilery).</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney</strong>: We&#8217;re both agreed that the world building alone in this book justifies the read. I loved the Londons and how they overlapped. <strong>The Midnight Market</strong> is a stand alone which, in terms of this story, is good. There are no cliffhangers. But I so loved this world, I kinda wish for more stories set in it.</p>\n<p>Other than Tom&#8217;s cluelessness, was there anything else you didn&#8217;t love?</p>\n<p><strong>Marian</strong>: The worldbuilding was an absolute delight. So much so that I&#8217;m disappointed there&#8217;s no sequel &#8211; imagine a story that&#8217;s about how the Moths and the Butterflies rebuild their society in their own world, or a return to the Land of the Sightless Folk, or a mystery set in the Market.</p>\n<p>But as for anything else I didn&#8217;t love, potential spoilers again, towards the end of the book, the revelation of a familial relationship made me raise an eyebrow about the completely different direction this relationship had taken earlier. Can&#8217;t say much more than that. I think that&#8217;s one reason I felt the happy ending was a bit rushed &#8211; there&#8217;s a lot to unpack, and I felt that after such a long and bitter war, reconciliation and peace would not come easy. But that would have made the book twice as long and might be a tiresome anti-climax as well. And I did enjoy the ending for the fairytale it is; suspend disbelief and it works just fine. It&#8217;s only when I step back and think critically that I start being picky!</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney</strong>: I think I just surrendered to the spell of the book&#8211;it is, after all, a fairy tale! If I have a complaint, it is that I too would have liked just a bit more of the story at the end&#8211;we learn the what happened but I wished for more how: What does the world look like in the wake of the resolution.</p>\n<p>This, thought, is a small quibble. For me, this book is a DIK. How about for you?</p>\n<p><strong>Marian</strong> : It wasn&#8217;t perfect, but it was a very enjoyable read for me. I&#8217;d give it a B+.</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney</strong>: I&#8217;d give it an A-. It&#8217;s a lovely, lovely read.</p>\n",
                "text": "Deep in the heart of London, a young photographer named Tom Argent walks the streets and captures whatever catches his eye: an old man drinking coffee; a striking woman sipping champagne in St. Pancras station; a cloud of moths taking flight across the sky. He’s orphaned, lonely, and lost in his work. He certainly has no intention of falling in love. And yet, love finds him in the shape of beautiful Vanessa, who lives a dangerous double life in the heart of the city. Tom’s pursuit of Vanessa leads him to discover an alternate world, hiding in plain sight among the streets and rooftops of London. A world unseen by common folk and inhabited by strange and colorful beings, in which two warring factions—one nocturnal, one in the light—wage war for the sake of a long-lost love, which can only end with one side’s total annihilation. Dabney: I have been a Harris fan for decades. The Moonlight Market utterly enchanting and I adored it. Marian, how did you feel about it? Marian: It&#8217;s certainly different from Chocolat and Five Quarters of the Orange, just as deliciously atmospheric but with more of a fairytale feel to it. It wasn&#8217;t a perfect read for me, but it was very close.The gradually revealed story of the war and its consequences was like myth meeting reality, and this book made me want three things : 1. a pair of wings 2. a visit to the Moonlight Market 3. a sequel. Dabney: SO, in the world of this book, humans exist side by side with fairies. The fairies, due to a romance that turned sour ages ago, have split into two kingdoms, that of the Moths and the Butterflies, and are at war with one another. Tom, a man who lives a quiet, rather empty life as a photographer in London, falls, he thinks, in love with a Butterfly, the gorgeous Vanessa. As he pursues her, he becomes ensnared in the fairy world and its war. And, slowly, he realizes his connection with the fairies runs far deeper than he would have ever expected. I loved this set up. I love fairy tales and this is an intricate one, with heroes and villains on all sides. What did you think of the world building? Marian: Detailed and evocative. You can almost smell the incense and gingerbread and dried flowers in the market. Even the way the fairies speak is different. There are daylight names and midnight names, and I like the nickname for Tom &#8211; &#8220;chrysalis&#8221;, something that could produce either a moth or a butterfly. Dabney: This is, wonderfully, a love story with both a main couple and an usual secondary one. What did you think&#8211;no spoilers!&#8211;of the romances here? Marian: Unfortunately I didn&#8217;t enjoy the main romance as much as I did the rest of the book. For a large chunk of the story, I was thinking, &#8220;Don&#8217;t! Don&#8217;t do that! Don&#8217;t be taken in!&#8221; only to sigh in frustration as the character did exactly what they shouldn&#8217;t have done. Plus, there&#8217;s glamour and temptation, but I felt these worked their spell for so long that the actual romance got a little shortchanged in the process &#8211; in the end, there simply wasn&#8217;t enough space remaining in the book to convince me of true love. I liked the individual characters. I just wish they&#8217;d had more screen time together to develop their relationship. When I first read the book, I thought the secondary romance could also have used more development, but looking back, I think this was foreshadowed with the recounting of the myth at the start of each part of the book. It tied up some loose ends as well. I wasn&#8217;t as emotionally invested in this one because, to be honest, I disliked one of the characters involved and felt more of a redemption arc was needed here. Dabney: Tom is irksomely clueless for too long. But I felt that was realistic given how the magic worked on him. So I was frustrated but I accepted it. Harris has always written leads that aren&#8217;t necessarily likeable. My favorite of hers is possibly Runemarks&#8211;I have a profound weakness for retelling of Norse mythology&#8211;and, in that novel, several of the main characters do things that made me crazy. I suspect I am a reader who doesn&#8217;t need to like a character as much as I need to believe they are improving. So, we&#8217;ll agree we see the romances differently! What else struck you? Marian: I don&#8217;t usually mind unlikeable protagonists outside of romance, but I think with this book, the romantic aspect started early enough that I began expecting Tom to be more like a romance hero rather than &#8220;irksomely clueless&#8221; (great turn of phrase!). And with other flaws, the character and I can still be on the same page, whereas if a character is intensely naive when it comes to the villain, I&#8217;m far ahead and waiting for the character to catch up. But as you said, we see the romances differently! Another plus point was the time travel aspect. I&#8217;m fascinated by alternate versions of cities, and I enjoyed London Before/London Beyond. It&#8217;s a great example of the way the story unfolds, beginning with Tom&#8217;s small, mundane life but expanding into the secrets of the Market and spreading from there to encompass another world and a different time entirely. I like the plotting here as well, and the twist of how the battle started (if that&#8217;s not too spoilery). Dabney: We&#8217;re both agreed that the world building alone in this book justifies the read. I loved the Londons and how they overlapped. The Midnight Market is a stand alone which, in terms of this story, is good. There are no cliffhangers. But I so loved this world, I kinda wish for more stories set in it. Other than Tom&#8217;s cluelessness, was there anything else you didn&#8217;t love? Marian: The worldbuilding was an absolute delight. So much so that I&#8217;m disappointed there&#8217;s no sequel &#8211; imagine a story that&#8217;s about how the Moths and the Butterflies rebuild their society in their own world, or a return to the Land of the Sightless Folk, or a mystery set in the Market. But as for anything else I didn&#8217;t love, potential spoilers again, towards the end of the book, the revelation of a familial relationship made me raise an eyebrow about the completely different direction this relationship had taken earlier. Can&#8217;t say much more than that. I think that&#8217;s one reason I felt the happy ending was a bit rushed &#8211; there&#8217;s a lot to unpack, and I felt that after such a long and bitter war, reconciliation and peace would not come easy. But that would have made the book twice as long and might be a tiresome anti-climax as well. And I did enjoy the ending for the fairytale it is; suspend disbelief and it works just fine. It&#8217;s only when I step back and think critically that I start being picky! Dabney: I think I just surrendered to the spell of the book&#8211;it is, after all, a fairy tale! If I have a complaint, it is that I too would have liked just a bit more of the story at the end&#8211;we learn the what happened but I wished for more how: What does the world look like in the wake of the resolution. This, thought, is a small quibble. For me, this book is a DIK. How about for you? Marian : It wasn&#8217;t perfect, but it was a very enjoyable read for me. I&#8217;d give it a B+. Dabney: I&#8217;d give it an A-. It&#8217;s a lovely, lovely read."

                "title": "The Summer We Fell",
                "author_first": "Elizabeth",

                "publisher": "self",

                "pages": "318",

            "content": {
                "html": "<p>In this dual timeline contemporary romance, we follow the lives of Luke, the world’s hottest surfer, and Juliet, a beautiful woman ostensibly characterized as a musician. This label feels tenuous at best, as the narrative divulges virtually nothing about her career, her music, or her perception of fame. Juliet&#8217;s primary role seems to be that of the romantic heroine, her identity revolving around her love for the hero. (I think this is the current take on hero centric romance: the heroine exists just to bask in the excellence of the object of her love/lust.) Their love story is complicated by an insurmountable barrier related to the death of Danny, Luke’s best friend from college. Which is frustrating because the friendship between Danny and Luke is puzzling: Danny is depicted as a self-absorbed man-child, while Luke is a hyper-masculine figure capable of seeing Juliet&#8217;s true self. I couldn&#8217;t see the problem.</p>\n<p>But I&#8217;m getting ahead of myself.</p>\n<p>The story kicks off in the present day, where Juliet and Luke have returned to the small town Juliet and Danny hailed from. They’re collaborating with Danny’s mother to open a home for foster kids, a project funded by all the money Juliet and Luke have earned from their very successful careers. We quickly learn the two haven’t seen each other since Danny&#8217;s death seven years prior and, whoa, is there a bunch of unresolved sh*t between them.&nbsp;</p>\n<p>Why? Well, ten years ago, after his first year in college, Danny brought his best bud&#8211;again, no clue why they are friends&#8211;Luke home for the summer to stay with his very Christian parents, and Juliet, whom they took in after she ran away from her abusive family. Danny’s father, a pastor, is a judgmental figure who tolerates Juliet’s presence but constantly reminds her that she’s there on sufferance. His mother, Donna, is a misguided gem. Danny and Juliet are dating, and Danny, his parents, and all the townsfolk assume that Danny will someday be the pastor, with Juliet his subservient wife.</p>\n<p>Juliet is not enthusiastic about this life. She dreams of being a singer-songwriter, a passion she can&#8217;t pursue in the constraining environment Danny’s family offers. (But she&#8217;s so grateful to them for taking her in that she can&#8217;t rebel because it would be hurtful. Sigh.) Plus, she loves Danny or so she thinks she does&#8230; until the moment she meets Luke.</p>\n<p>Luke, who is big, tall, strong, gorgeous, given to five words sentences and few smiles, makes her lady parts hum and her stomach flip. This makes sense, given that Danny doesn&#8217;t believe in any pre-marital hanky panky. He is a virgin. Juliet is not&#8211;she was forced into sex with her much older step-brother when she was a teen. This abuse complicates matters; she’s experienced sex as both a pleasurable and painful act. O&#8217;Roark writes Juliet’s ambivalence and trauma with nuance and, in doing so, makes Juliet&#8217;s often self-destructive behavior understandable but she still drove me crazy.</p>\n<p>We know almost nothing about how Luke feels&#8211;I mean, obviously he&#8217;s been in love with Juliet since day one&#8211;because the book is all told from Juliet&#8217;s point of view. This isn&#8217;t great&#8211;she&#8217;s a giant martyr and isn&#8217;t one to share anything non-Danny or non-Luke related. I still have no idea how successful she is as a musician, what she thinks about her work, or what her favorite song is. I do know that Luke is a world famous surfer who beats up anyone who is or has been a threat to Juliet. He also looks amazing naked.</p>\n<p><span style=\"font-family: var(--global-body-font-family);\">The narrative oscillates between the present, where Juliet and Luke’s unspoken history brims with tension, and the past, where readers anticipate their inevitable affair. The predictable plot structure becomes frustrating as not much happens. In both timelines, Luke and Juliet are stupid in lust with one another&#8211;this book has some serious sexual tension&#8211;and most readers will be flipping the pages ready for the two to finally jump each other&#8217;s bones. We do know that Juliet feels guilty about Danny&#8217;s death and Luke does not. Why that is, the reader must wait until the very end to find out. (It was not worth the wait.)&nbsp;</span></p>\n<p>Despite these criticisms, I enjoyed reading this book. O’Rourke’s talent for crafting voices and memorable characters shines through. Their circle of friends, Danny&#8217;s complex relationship with his parents, and the awful childhoods Luke and Juliet experienced are all believable and compelling. The love scenes are intensely passionate&#8211;O’Rourke writes steamy sex fabulously. The angst in the book isn&#8217;t super deep but it&#8217;s real enough to make <strong>The Summer We Fell</strong> more than just fun froth.</p>\n<p>The book <strong>is</strong> sexy and fun and O’Rourke’s skill with dialogue and character creation is evident&#8211;I get why her work is popular. However, this particular book feels like a missed opportunity, with an underdeveloped heroine and a plot that doesn’t surprise. This makes it a B/B- read.</p>\n",
                "text": "In this dual timeline contemporary romance, we follow the lives of Luke, the world’s hottest surfer, and Juliet, a beautiful woman ostensibly characterized as a musician. This label feels tenuous at best, as the narrative divulges virtually nothing about her career, her music, or her perception of fame. Juliet&#8217;s primary role seems to be that of the romantic heroine, her identity revolving around her love for the hero. (I think this is the current take on hero centric romance: the heroine exists just to bask in the excellence of the object of her love/lust.) Their love story is complicated by an insurmountable barrier related to the death of Danny, Luke’s best friend from college. Which is frustrating because the friendship between Danny and Luke is puzzling: Danny is depicted as a self-absorbed man-child, while Luke is a hyper-masculine figure capable of seeing Juliet&#8217;s true self. I couldn&#8217;t see the problem. But I&#8217;m getting ahead of myself. The story kicks off in the present day, where Juliet and Luke have returned to the small town Juliet and Danny hailed from. They’re collaborating with Danny’s mother to open a home for foster kids, a project funded by all the money Juliet and Luke have earned from their very successful careers. We quickly learn the two haven’t seen each other since Danny&#8217;s death seven years prior and, whoa, is there a bunch of unresolved sh*t between them.&nbsp; Why? Well, ten years ago, after his first year in college, Danny brought his best bud&#8211;again, no clue why they are friends&#8211;Luke home for the summer to stay with his very Christian parents, and Juliet, whom they took in after she ran away from her abusive family. Danny’s father, a pastor, is a judgmental figure who tolerates Juliet’s presence but constantly reminds her that she’s there on sufferance. His mother, Donna, is a misguided gem. Danny and Juliet are dating, and Danny, his parents, and all the townsfolk assume that Danny will someday be the pastor, with Juliet his subservient wife. Juliet is not enthusiastic about this life. She dreams of being a singer-songwriter, a passion she can&#8217;t pursue in the constraining environment Danny’s family offers. (But she&#8217;s so grateful to them for taking her in that she can&#8217;t rebel because it would be hurtful. Sigh.) Plus, she loves Danny or so she thinks she does&#8230; until the moment she meets Luke. Luke, who is big, tall, strong, gorgeous, given to five words sentences and few smiles, makes her lady parts hum and her stomach flip. This makes sense, given that Danny doesn&#8217;t believe in any pre-marital hanky panky. He is a virgin. Juliet is not&#8211;she was forced into sex with her much older step-brother when she was a teen. This abuse complicates matters; she’s experienced sex as both a pleasurable and painful act. O&#8217;Roark writes Juliet’s ambivalence and trauma with nuance and, in doing so, makes Juliet&#8217;s often self-destructive behavior understandable but she still drove me crazy. We know almost nothing about how Luke feels&#8211;I mean, obviously he&#8217;s been in love with Juliet since day one&#8211;because the book is all told from Juliet&#8217;s point of view. This isn&#8217;t great&#8211;she&#8217;s a giant martyr and isn&#8217;t one to share anything non-Danny or non-Luke related. I still have no idea how successful she is as a musician, what she thinks about her work, or what her favorite song is. I do know that Luke is a world famous surfer who beats up anyone who is or has been a threat to Juliet. He also looks amazing naked. The narrative oscillates between the present, where Juliet and Luke’s unspoken history brims with tension, and the past, where readers anticipate their inevitable affair. The predictable plot structure becomes frustrating as not much happens. In both timelines, Luke and Juliet are stupid in lust with one another&#8211;this book has some serious sexual tension&#8211;and most readers will be flipping the pages ready for the two to finally jump each other&#8217;s bones. We do know that Juliet feels guilty about Danny&#8217;s death and Luke does not. Why that is, the reader must wait until the very end to find out. (It was not worth the wait.)&nbsp; Despite these criticisms, I enjoyed reading this book. O’Rourke’s talent for crafting voices and memorable characters shines through. Their circle of friends, Danny&#8217;s complex relationship with his parents, and the awful childhoods Luke and Juliet experienced are all believable and compelling. The love scenes are intensely passionate&#8211;O’Rourke writes steamy sex fabulously. The angst in the book isn&#8217;t super deep but it&#8217;s real enough to make The Summer We Fell more than just fun froth. The book is sexy and fun and O’Rourke’s skill with dialogue and character creation is evident&#8211;I get why her work is popular. However, this particular book feels like a missed opportunity, with an underdeveloped heroine and a plot that doesn’t surprise. This makes it a B/B- read."

It&#8217;s the sort of book MFA students dream of publishing&#8211;literary, adored by critics, socially incisive. Moore&#8217;s latest, <strong>The God of the Woods,</strong> is&#8211;and this is a good thing&#8211;just a mystery, the sort of story one picks up on a Saturday afternoon and by midnight on Sunday, finally, reluctantly finishes. It will, I suspect, be one of my favorite reads of 2024.</p>\n<p>The novel begins in August of 1975 at Camp Emerson, a naturalist camp for kids set deep in the Adirondacks. One morning, during the end of a summer session, twelve year old Barbara Van Laar is, alarmingly, not in her bunk. Her counselor, Louise Donnadieu, is immediately panicked. Not only was Louise <strong>not</strong> in the cabin last night&#8211;she thought the junior counselor was looking after their charges. Barbara is not just any camper. She is the daughter of the wealthy Van Laars who own the camp and whose son Bear also went missing back in the summer of 1961. Soon, the whole camp and the local police are searching the mountains for Barbara.</p>\n<p>The second narrative, set in the summer of 1961, tells the story of young Bear Van Laar and the complicated adults who surround him.</p>\n<p><span style=\"font-family: var(--global-body-font-family);\">Moore&#8217;s narration skitters between these two times, in ways that, at first, confused me. The novel&#8217;s structure, however, slowly becomes a boon&#8211;the reader, in each new chapter, must use not just time and place but character development to understand where she is in the story. And though the plot unspools more slowly than many a modern mystery, the pace gives space to the people in these pages. We watch them change, learn, and adapt and, as we do so, what happened to the two Van Laar children becomes ineluctably clear.</span></p>\n<p>Like all good genre fiction, <strong>The God of the Woods </strong>isn&#8217;t merely a mystery. Moore has things to say about friendships, especially those that can mold or fracture its inhabitants. For those in this story, a devoted friend may be the greatest gift and a family who loves its reputation more than its members may be the biggest threat. Or not. You&#8217;ll have to read the book to see what really happened to the Van Lear children and why.&nbsp;</p>\n<p>I&#8217;ve never spent time in the Adirondacks but, after reading this book, I think if I did, their beauty and their dangers would feel familiar. Moore vividly shows how nature can be both soothing and terrifying and how an awareness the physical world can mean the literal difference between life and death.&nbsp;</p>\n<p><strong>The God of the Woods</strong> is a riveting read&#8211;its dual mysteries are both page turners. The hidden truths about the Van Laar family and the local community intertwine with the intricate web of friendships at the camp. The connections formed during that pivotal past summer resonate in the eerie present. The denouement is shocking and believable.</p>\n<p>It isn&#8217;t perfect&#8211;I found parts of the resolution to be moderately unbelievable and, as is too often the case in current fiction, the villains of the story are villainous because of what they have rather than integrally who they are. But, these are small quibbles. Overall, this is a gripping mystery and one I recommend.&nbsp;</p>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"w-full pt-2 md:pt-0 dark:border-white/20 md:border-transparent md:dark:border-transparent md:w-[calc(100%-.5rem)]\">\n<form class=\"stretch mx-2 flex flex-row gap-3 last:mb-2 md:mx-4 md:last:mb-6 lg:mx-auto lg:max-w-2xl xl:max-w-3xl\" data-dashlane-rid=\"f99731cef54db417\" data-form-type=\"\">\n<div class=\"relative flex h-full flex-1 items-stretch md:flex-col\">\n<div class=\"flex w-full items-center\">&nbsp;</div>\n</div>\n</form>\n</div>\n",
                "text": "Liz Moore&#8217;s best selling Long Bright River (2020) is both a very good thriller and a brutal examination of a community and a family destroyed by addiction. It&#8217;s the sort of book MFA students dream of publishing&#8211;literary, adored by critics, socially incisive. Moore&#8217;s latest, The God of the Woods, is&#8211;and this is a good thing&#8211;just a mystery, the sort of story one picks up on a Saturday afternoon and by midnight on Sunday, finally, reluctantly finishes. It will, I suspect, be one of my favorite reads of 2024. The novel begins in August of 1975 at Camp Emerson, a naturalist camp for kids set deep in the Adirondacks. One morning, during the end of a summer session, twelve year old Barbara Van Laar is, alarmingly, not in her bunk. Her counselor, Louise Donnadieu, is immediately panicked. Not only was Louise not in the cabin last night&#8211;she thought the junior counselor was looking after their charges. Barbara is not just any camper. She is the daughter of the wealthy Van Laars who own the camp and whose son Bear also went missing back in the summer of 1961. Soon, the whole camp and the local police are searching the mountains for Barbara. The second narrative, set in the summer of 1961, tells the story of young Bear Van Laar and the complicated adults who surround him. Moore&#8217;s narration skitters between these two times, in ways that, at first, confused me. The novel&#8217;s structure, however, slowly becomes a boon&#8211;the reader, in each new chapter, must use not just time and place but character development to understand where she is in the story. And though the plot unspools more slowly than many a modern mystery, the pace gives space to the people in these pages. We watch them change, learn, and adapt and, as we do so, what happened to the two Van Laar children becomes ineluctably clear. Like all good genre fiction, The God of the Woods isn&#8217;t merely a mystery. Moore has things to say about friendships, especially those that can mold or fracture its inhabitants. For those in this story, a devoted friend may be the greatest gift and a family who loves its reputation more than its members may be the biggest threat. Or not. You&#8217;ll have to read the book to see what really happened to the Van Lear children and why.&nbsp; I&#8217;ve never spent time in the Adirondacks but, after reading this book, I think if I did, their beauty and their dangers would feel familiar. Moore vividly shows how nature can be both soothing and terrifying and how an awareness the physical world can mean the literal difference between life and death.&nbsp; The God of the Woods is a riveting read&#8211;its dual mysteries are both page turners. The hidden truths about the Van Laar family and the local community intertwine with the intricate web of friendships at the camp. The connections formed during that pivotal past summer resonate in the eerie present. The denouement is shocking and believable. It isn&#8217;t perfect&#8211;I found parts of the resolution to be moderately unbelievable and, as is too often the case in current fiction, the villains of the story are villainous because of what they have rather than integrally who they are. But, these are small quibbles. Overall, this is a gripping mystery and one I recommend.&nbsp; &nbsp;"

            "content": {
                "html": "<p>I had no idea what to expect when I picked up this debut mystery. When I finished it, I thought, Crouch is gunning for Harlan Coben&#8217;s audience and she&#8217;s done a very good job. Like many of Coben&#8217;s stand alone thrillers, Middletide is, at its dark(ish) heart, a love story. Crouch&#8217;s prose is more literary than Coben&#8217;s but she&#8217;s yet to hit his level of fiendish suspense. That said, <strong>Middletide</strong> is a worthwhile read.</p>\n<p>The book opens on a cold morning in 1994 with two fishermen finding a hanging body on the shores of Puget Sound. The corpse is that of the preternaturally beautiful Erin Landy, the main doctor in the small town of Point Orchards. What looks like a suicide is determined by local sheriff, Jim Godbout, to be a murder, a murder that has far too much in common with a book, written 13 years earlier, by Elijah Leith, a reclusive author on whose land the body swings.</p>\n<p>From there, we cut immediately to 1973 where we see Elijah, at 18, pledge his life long love to a Native American girl, Nakita, who lives on the nearby reservation. Then we are in 1977, then 1992, then 1994, then 1992 again&#8211;the book zigs back and forth through time, slowly setting out the context of the relationships between Nakita, Elijah, and Erin.</p>\n<p>This is a novel that lays its conceits out slowly. Early on, we know that Elijah, despite promising to return to Nakita in 1977, did not. He spent ten years in California, writing <strong>Middletide</strong>, his first great novel. The novel was a flop due to a single negative review from the ubiquitous <em>New York</em> <em>Times</em> and Elijah, out of money and ashamed, slunk home in 1992. He began rehabbing the cabin he&#8217;d grown up in while earning a living working in his dead father&#8217;s best friend&#8217;s&#8211;Chitto&#8211;garage. He longs to connect again with Nakita who is in mourning for her husband of five years who was killed in a hunting accident. For her part, Erin is still devastated from the loss of her young daughter who was recently killed in a car accident.</p>\n<p>Crouch leisurely takes us through Elijah&#8217;s life in Point Orchards. When he is not learning how to live off his land, he is trying to get Nakita back and, I must confess, for much of the book, his thoughts about her veered towards the borderline obsessive. We spend a lot of time sharing Elijah&#8217;s thoughts, as well as those of Erin and Nakita. We get hints about what their lives look like when the murder occurs but stlll, at well the novel&#8217;s midpoint, I had no idea how the three were, in 1994, connected.</p>\n<p>Then, a discovery is made and it is suddenly blindingly clear who killed Erin but only to the reader. The cops are remarkably credulous until they are not and I found their behavior to be frustrating. The last quarter of the novel moves at breakneck speed and the story&#8217;s resolution is more or less satisfying.</p>\n<p>Crouch is a strong writer, especially about the land and her unusual timeline gives the book an intellectual interest the plot doesn&#8217;t quite match. The characterizations of Nakita and Erin aren&#8217;t especially nuanced and, though Elijah is clearly limned, I wasn&#8217;t crazy about him as a person. He&#8217;s one of those leads that&#8217;s interesting to read about but not especially endearing.</p>\n<p>But I did, overall, enjoy the book. The mystery, for much of the novel, is slippery and the story doesn&#8217;t feel any need to demonize any of its characters. This is, oddly enough, a feel good story, with a resolution Coben would cheer. I&#8217;ll definitely be reading whatever Crouch writes next and, if you like unusually plotted literary mysteries, you&#8217;ll enjoy the time you spend reading <strong>Middletide</strong>.</p>\n",
                "text": "I had no idea what to expect when I picked up this debut mystery. When I finished it, I thought, Crouch is gunning for Harlan Coben&#8217;s audience and she&#8217;s done a very good job. Like many of Coben&#8217;s stand alone thrillers, Middletide is, at its dark(ish) heart, a love story. Crouch&#8217;s prose is more literary than Coben&#8217;s but she&#8217;s yet to hit his level of fiendish suspense. That said, Middletide is a worthwhile read. The book opens on a cold morning in 1994 with two fishermen finding a hanging body on the shores of Puget Sound. The corpse is that of the preternaturally beautiful Erin Landy, the main doctor in the small town of Point Orchards. What looks like a suicide is determined by local sheriff, Jim Godbout, to be a murder, a murder that has far too much in common with a book, written 13 years earlier, by Elijah Leith, a reclusive author on whose land the body swings. From there, we cut immediately to 1973 where we see Elijah, at 18, pledge his life long love to a Native American girl, Nakita, who lives on the nearby reservation. Then we are in 1977, then 1992, then 1994, then 1992 again&#8211;the book zigs back and forth through time, slowly setting out the context of the relationships between Nakita, Elijah, and Erin. This is a novel that lays its conceits out slowly. Early on, we know that Elijah, despite promising to return to Nakita in 1977, did not. He spent ten years in California, writing Middletide, his first great novel. The novel was a flop due to a single negative review from the ubiquitous New York Times and Elijah, out of money and ashamed, slunk home in 1992. He began rehabbing the cabin he&#8217;d grown up in while earning a living working in his dead father&#8217;s best friend&#8217;s&#8211;Chitto&#8211;garage. He longs to connect again with Nakita who is in mourning for her husband of five years who was killed in a hunting accident. For her part, Erin is still devastated from the loss of her young daughter who was recently killed in a car accident. Crouch leisurely takes us through Elijah&#8217;s life in Point Orchards. When he is not learning how to live off his land, he is trying to get Nakita back and, I must confess, for much of the book, his thoughts about her veered towards the borderline obsessive. We spend a lot of time sharing Elijah&#8217;s thoughts, as well as those of Erin and Nakita. We get hints about what their lives look like when the murder occurs but stlll, at well the novel&#8217;s midpoint, I had no idea how the three were, in 1994, connected. Then, a discovery is made and it is suddenly blindingly clear who killed Erin but only to the reader. The cops are remarkably credulous until they are not and I found their behavior to be frustrating. The last quarter of the novel moves at breakneck speed and the story&#8217;s resolution is more or less satisfying. Crouch is a strong writer, especially about the land and her unusual timeline gives the book an intellectual interest the plot doesn&#8217;t quite match. The characterizations of Nakita and Erin aren&#8217;t especially nuanced and, though Elijah is clearly limned, I wasn&#8217;t crazy about him as a person. He&#8217;s one of those leads that&#8217;s interesting to read about but not especially endearing. But I did, overall, enjoy the book. The mystery, for much of the novel, is slippery and the story doesn&#8217;t feel any need to demonize any of its characters. This is, oddly enough, a feel good story, with a resolution Coben would cheer. I&#8217;ll definitely be reading whatever Crouch writes next and, if you like unusually plotted literary mysteries, you&#8217;ll enjoy the time you spend reading Middletide."

                "html": "<div class=\"flex-1 overflow-hidden\">\n<div class=\"react-scroll-to-bottom--css-frqeg-79elbk h-full\">\n<div class=\"react-scroll-to-bottom--css-frqeg-1n7m0yu\">\n<div class=\"flex flex-col pb-9 text-sm\">\n<div class=\"w-full text-token-text-primary\" data-testid=\"conversation-turn-11\">\n<div class=\"px-4 py-2 justify-center text-base md:gap-6 m-auto\">\n<div class=\"flex flex-1 text-base mx-auto gap-3 md:px-5 lg:px-1 xl:px-5 md:max-w-3xl lg:max-w-[40rem] xl:max-w-[48rem] group final-completion\">\n<div class=\"relative flex w-full flex-col lg:w-[calc(100%-115px)] agent-turn\">\n<div class=\"flex-col gap-1 md:gap-3\">\n<div class=\"flex flex-grow flex-col max-w-full\">\n<div class=\"min-h-[20px] text-message flex flex-col items-start gap-3 whitespace-pre-wrap break-words [.text-message+&amp;]:mt-5 overflow-x-auto\" data-message-author-role=\"assistant\" data-message-id=\"b5c11d3f-a6cb-4eeb-9370-4d14299a2fcb\">\n<div class=\"markdown prose w-full break-words dark:prose-invert light\">\n<p>I am new to Candice Fox&#8217;s writing, but after inhaling <strong>Devil&#8217;s Kitchen</strong>, I&#8217;ll be reading more of her work. I know this sounds like hyperbole but, truly, I could NOT put this one down.</p>\n<p>The setup is irresistible: New York City&#8217;s fire department, especially after 9/11, is known for their heroism and skill and one team, Ladder 51, is no exception. But the crew, Ben, Jakey, Engo and their leader Matt, are <strong>also</strong> a ruthless group of brilliant thieves who use their intimate knowledge of the city&#8217;s architecture and their willingness to do whatever it takes to steal millions from banks, jewelry stores, and art galleries. Their city&#8217;s trust in them as well as their very jobs have made them some of the most successful criminals on the East Coast.</p>\n<p><strong>Devil&#8217;s Kitchen</strong> kicks off with the tension cranked up to eleven and never lets up. As the book begins, a woman named Andy, a new member of the team, kneels on the ground, as does Ben. Engo, Matt, and Jakey have accused her of being a cop and Ben of knowing that. Guns have been drawn, and Andy thinks <em>It would look like an accident</em>.&nbsp;</p>\n<p>The story then jumps three months in the past. Ben is sitting at his local diner, thinking about how everything has gone to shit. He&#8217;s been part of Ladder 51 since he was young&#8211;Matt is a father figure to him. Their loyalty to one another must be absolute. But Ben’s girlfriend and son have disappeared. Desperate, and convinced Matt knows something about this, Ben&#8217;s sent the cops a letter ratting out his friends which results in Andy appearing at his local diner.&nbsp; She is a freelance investigator whose jobs involve going deep undercover to solve crimes&#8211;in this one, she&#8217;s loosely partnered with the FBI. Andy is keen to help Ben find his missing family but her handler Tony&#8211;not a great guy&#8211;is much more interested in putting the crew away for the robberies.</p>\n<p>Andy has a plan, one that makes Ben very very nervous. She&#8217;ll get herself on the crew and, once the guys accept her, she and Ben will document their next big heist. Whether or not this will work, what it will mean to Ben if it does, well, Fox spools out this story of secrets and betrayals brilliantly.&nbsp;</p>\n<p>All of the lead characters, with the possible exception of Tony whose true nature remains a bit too elusive, are fascinating. Some are outright evil, others have their reasons for why they do the morally iffy things they do. I genuinely had no idea how the novel would end or whether and how those who sinned would pay.The fire scenes are, well, fire. Fox, who is Australian, gets New York down pat&#8211;one has the sense she spent months there following some hopefully non-criminally inclined fire company as they worked.</p>\n<p>As I devoured the pages, I kept thinking, <em>Whoa,&nbsp; this needs to be a movie</em>. With its audacious plot, intense fire fighting scenes, and darkly accurate portrayal of New York City, <strong>Devil&#8217;s Kitchen</strong> is a wild ride of a read.</p>\n<p>If you&#8217;re a fan of smart, fast-paced, adrenaline-fueled thrillers, <strong>Devil&#8217;s Kitchen</strong> is your jam.&nbsp;</p>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n",
                "text": "I am new to Candice Fox&#8217;s writing, but after inhaling Devil&#8217;s Kitchen, I&#8217;ll be reading more of her work. I know this sounds like hyperbole but, truly, I could NOT put this one down. The setup is irresistible: New York City&#8217;s fire department, especially after 9/11, is known for their heroism and skill and one team, Ladder 51, is no exception. But the crew, Ben, Jakey, Engo and their leader Matt, are also a ruthless group of brilliant thieves who use their intimate knowledge of the city&#8217;s architecture and their willingness to do whatever it takes to steal millions from banks, jewelry stores, and art galleries. Their city&#8217;s trust in them as well as their very jobs have made them some of the most successful criminals on the East Coast. Devil&#8217;s Kitchen kicks off with the tension cranked up to eleven and never lets up. As the book begins, a woman named Andy, a new member of the team, kneels on the ground, as does Ben. Engo, Matt, and Jakey have accused her of being a cop and Ben of knowing that. Guns have been drawn, and Andy thinks It would look like an accident.&nbsp; The story then jumps three months in the past. Ben is sitting at his local diner, thinking about how everything has gone to shit. He&#8217;s been part of Ladder 51 since he was young&#8211;Matt is a father figure to him. Their loyalty to one another must be absolute. But Ben’s girlfriend and son have disappeared. Desperate, and convinced Matt knows something about this, Ben&#8217;s sent the cops a letter ratting out his friends which results in Andy appearing at his local diner.&nbsp; She is a freelance investigator whose jobs involve going deep undercover to solve crimes&#8211;in this one, she&#8217;s loosely partnered with the FBI. Andy is keen to help Ben find his missing family but her handler Tony&#8211;not a great guy&#8211;is much more interested in putting the crew away for the robberies. Andy has a plan, one that makes Ben very very nervous. She&#8217;ll get herself on the crew and, once the guys accept her, she and Ben will document their next big heist. Whether or not this will work, what it will mean to Ben if it does, well, Fox spools out this story of secrets and betrayals brilliantly.&nbsp; All of the lead characters, with the possible exception of Tony whose true nature remains a bit too elusive, are fascinating. Some are outright evil, others have their reasons for why they do the morally iffy things they do. I genuinely had no idea how the novel would end or whether and how those who sinned would pay.The fire scenes are, well, fire. Fox, who is Australian, gets New York down pat&#8211;one has the sense she spent months there following some hopefully non-criminally inclined fire company as they worked. As I devoured the pages, I kept thinking, Whoa,&nbsp; this needs to be a movie. With its audacious plot, intense fire fighting scenes, and darkly accurate portrayal of New York City, Devil&#8217;s Kitchen is a wild ride of a read. If you&#8217;re a fan of smart, fast-paced, adrenaline-fueled thrillers, Devil&#8217;s Kitchen is your jam.&nbsp;"

                "html": "<div>\n<p><strong>Dabney: </strong>Look on the Bright Side is the third book Higgins has set in the Cape Cod town of Wellfleet&#8211;the others are <a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/book-review/a-little-ray-of-sunshine-by-kristan-higgins/\"><strong>A Little Ray of Sunshine</strong></a>&nbsp;and <a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/book-review/out-of-the-clear-blue-sky-by-kristan-higgins/\"><strong>Out of the Clear Blue Sky</strong></a>&#8211;and it is my favorite of the series.</p>\n<p>The main lead&#8211;although there are three women whose lives we follow&#8211;is Lark Smith, the younger sister of the Harlow, whose story was told in <strong>A Little Ray of Sunshine</strong>. In the early pages of the book, Lark didn&#8217;t wow me&#8211;she is initially sunshiny to the point of treacle and that rarely works for me.</p>\n<p>Lark, however, like this book, grew on me.</p>\n<p>As the story begins, Lark&#8217;s boss in Oncology is booting her down to the ER because she keeps crying around patients. This is NOT what Lark wants because, for many years, she has believed she is destined become an oncologist. But he is adamant, and Lark is sent to work in the ER for six weeks. (This is not how residencies work but it doesn&#8217;t really matter so I&#8217;ve decided to let it go.)</p>\n<p>That same day, she gets a text from one of the hospital&#8217;s most famous surgeons, Lorenzo Santini whom everyone calls Dr. Satan&#8211;he is known as an interpersonal nightmare. She has no idea what he wants but agrees to meet him as he asks. For reasons&#8211;and again, I just decided to go with this even though it is impossible to believe this would happen in the real medical world&#8211;he wants her to be his date for the summer because his grandmother, who is dying, wants to know he is happily partnered. In exchange, he’ll put in a good word for Lark with some high-flying cancer docs he knows. Even though she thinks it&#8217;s a bit scuzzy&#8211;me too, Lark, me too&#8211;she agrees.</p>\n<p>Honestly, the first few chapters of this book had me shaking my head. Lark is a manic pixie girl, Lorenzo is a caricature of a brilliant asshole surgeon, and I struggled to feel OK about the fact that Lark&#8217;s true love, Justin, has been dead for seven years&#8211;she&#8217;s 33&#8211;and she&#8217;s never come close to getting over him. I thought about DNF-ing the book.</p>\n<p>I am so happy I didn&#8217;t. <strong>Look on the Bright Side</strong> is&#8211;and this is saying something&#8211;one of Higgin&#8217;s bests.</p>\n<p>Kayne, what are your thoughts?</p>\n<p><strong>Kayne:</strong> I really liked Lark! She has a sense of humor and is so kind to everyone. She is funny on her first date with Lorenzo when we see her thinking how stuffy and arrogant he is yet she’s trying to be polite but is a little snarky and orders all the most expensive things on the menu. I wondered if this was going to be a grumpy/sunshine trope and it became even more interesting when Lark meets Dante, Lorenzo’s hot, firefighter brother. I couldn’t wait to find out who she would end up with. Was Lorenzo as big of a jerk as he first appeared, or would he redeem himself? Is Dante as nice of a guy as he seems and if so, what will he think of Lark after he finds out she’s been fake dating Lorenzo?</p>\n<p>I agree Lark was over the top when she kept crying in Oncology and while it didn’t bother me as much that she was still grieving for Justin, I wasn’t interested in hearing about their courtship and how much she missed him – I wanted to skip to the part where she falls in love again. I wanted to know how her dates were going with Lorenzo’s family and if she could make it in ER.</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney:</strong> I get the whole love of my life thing, I do. But I also felt as though it was past time for Lark to move on. It was fun to watch her with both Dante and Lorenzo&#8211;and I liked the way both storylines played out. But I was very ready to get out of Lark&#8217;s head and thus was thrilled when, in chapter four, the narration shifts from Lark to her mom Ellie. From that point, the book began to soar.</p>\n<p>Unlike her daughter, Ellie is not a ball of sweetness and light, especially not after she discovers her devoted husband of 38 years, has done something she finds almost unforgivable. This comes as a shock to her and to everyone in their town because she and Gerald have what just about everyone would describe as the best marriage ever. They&#8217;re madly in love, have a hot sex life, adore their five kids and three grandkids, have their health, and Ellie has a very successful career as a painter and gallery owner. But now, now Ellie suddenly sees her life through the lens of anger. She&#8217;s supporting their family while Gerald faffs about starting and never finishing projects at home AND HE&#8217;S RETIRED! She is so angry she, rather randomly, moves out of the home they&#8217;ve lived in forever and in with Joy, a wealthy, lonely woman who moved to Wellfleet several years ago and is still mourning the death of her best friend and brother.</p>\n<p>What did you think about Ellie and her story?</p>\n<p><strong>Kayne:</strong> I couldn&#8217;t wait to find out if Ellie would go back to Gerald. I was glad to see her take the summer off for herself, not just because of what happened with Gerald but because she had worked so many years without a break and she deserved one. I admired Ellie and her relationships with her family. It was interesting to see how her paintings changed over the summer.</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney:</strong> Ellie is my jam. I was less interested in Joy. What are your thoughts about her?</p>\n<p><strong>Kayne:</strong> I loved Joy &#8211; her name fit her so well because she brought joy to everyone she meets. She was such a good friend to Lark and her mom, Ellie, the way she took them in and how they all helped each other heal. It was special when she started working at the Bayview Senior Living Community in the Memory Care Unit and her classes were such a big hit, everyone started taking them, not just the memory residents. Hearing about her classes, like Joyful Movement, made me smile &#8211; I wanted to take them too.</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney:</strong> Though&nbsp;Joy&#8217;s story didn&#8217;t do much for me, I loved Ellie&#8217;s and, after the first quarter of the book, I fell for Lark&#8217;s as well. But what I love most about this book&#8211;which moved me to tears more than once&#8211;is that Higgins writes gorgeously about the startling joy life offers when we have made our peace with death.</p>\n<p>Lark, as part of trying to get back to oncology, becomes a hospice volunteer and the parts of the story where she sits with those who are dying are phenomenal. Higgins&#8217; greatest gift in all her books is her risible love for humanity paired with her determination to give her readers genuine hope about life, love, and the world. The key word there, and why this book ended up being so lovely, is genuine.</p>\n<p><strong>In Look on the Bright Side</strong>, Higgins leans into death. Her descriptions of patients going through cancer treatments are hard to read and, although one has the sense that she believes we, in our culture of treatment no matter what, need to consider if that is always the best option, she gracefully supports the choices patients make. In the scenes where patients in hospice opt to go gently into that good night, her prose soars. If you can read chapter 18 without sobbing, you&#8217;re made of sterner stuff than am I.</p>\n<p><strong>Kayne:</strong> Chapter 18 was so heartbreaking. It brings tears to my eyes just thinking about it now and I rarely cry over books. It was so well done. I do agree with you about how hard it was to get through the part dealing with cancer treatments, but it made me appreciate the incredible ending even more. I did wonder how Lark had time to work in ER, volunteer for hospice and fake date Lorenzo.</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney:</strong> Yeah&#8211;there is no way Lark would have had all that free time. But, this is a feel good fiction and, again, I just decided to go with it.</p>\n<p><strong>Kayne:</strong> Feel good is right. I so enjoyed reading this novel!</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney:</strong> Me too. And I need to stress, even though parts are heartbreaking, <strong>Look On The Bright Side</strong> is a joyful, funny, hug of a book. Lark, Ellie, and Joy all find the happy endings they deserve. The Santini family and the Smith family are peopled by those I&#8217;d love to hang out with&#8211;there&#8217;s not a loser in the bunch. I adored all the sibling teasing, the witty retorts, and the unbounded love these lucky families share. I am now wishing I could spend some time in Wellfleet&#8211;for starters, Ellie and I have a lot to talk about!</p>\n<p><strong>Kayne:</strong> What stood out for me was how the story managed to be upbeat and hopeful, even during the hardest of times and the different ways that friends were there for each other.</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney:</strong> Yes. <strong>Look on the Bright Side</strong> makes it clear that living and loving are just so damn worth it. In a world where we focus relentlessly on the costs of opening ourselves to others, this book celebrates connection in lovely ways.</p>\n<p><strong>Kayne:</strong> Both families were wonderful. The party Joy threw for Lark and Lorenzo so the families could meet was a hoot. They were all so funny and quick witted with each other and even with Noni, Lorenzo’s nasty grandmother &#8211; they made me laugh. This is my favorite book I’ve read by this author and one of my favorite books so far this year. My grade is an A.</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney:</strong> This is a DIK for me too. I’ve read thousands of books in my life and have decided that good endings are the hardest thing to do well. The end of this book, especially the last page, is a gem. And the novel’s last line? It’s perfect.</p>\n<p>My advice to readers is grab this wonderful book. Though it takes a bit to hit its stride, when it does, it’s magical. It gets an A- from me.</p>\n</div>\n",
                "text": "Dabney: Look on the Bright Side is the third book Higgins has set in the Cape Cod town of Wellfleet&#8211;the others are A Little Ray of Sunshine&nbsp;and Out of the Clear Blue Sky&#8211;and it is my favorite of the series. The main lead&#8211;although there are three women whose lives we follow&#8211;is Lark Smith, the younger sister of the Harlow, whose story was told in A Little Ray of Sunshine. In the early pages of the book, Lark didn&#8217;t wow me&#8211;she is initially sunshiny to the point of treacle and that rarely works for me. Lark, however, like this book, grew on me. As the story begins, Lark&#8217;s boss in Oncology is booting her down to the ER because she keeps crying around patients. This is NOT what Lark wants because, for many years, she has believed she is destined become an oncologist. But he is adamant, and Lark is sent to work in the ER for six weeks. (This is not how residencies work but it doesn&#8217;t really matter so I&#8217;ve decided to let it go.) That same day, she gets a text from one of the hospital&#8217;s most famous surgeons, Lorenzo Santini whom everyone calls Dr. Satan&#8211;he is known as an interpersonal nightmare. She has no idea what he wants but agrees to meet him as he asks. For reasons&#8211;and again, I just decided to go with this even though it is impossible to believe this would happen in the real medical world&#8211;he wants her to be his date for the summer because his grandmother, who is dying, wants to know he is happily partnered. In exchange, he’ll put in a good word for Lark with some high-flying cancer docs he knows. Even though she thinks it&#8217;s a bit scuzzy&#8211;me too, Lark, me too&#8211;she agrees. Honestly, the first few chapters of this book had me shaking my head. Lark is a manic pixie girl, Lorenzo is a caricature of a brilliant asshole surgeon, and I struggled to feel OK about the fact that Lark&#8217;s true love, Justin, has been dead for seven years&#8211;she&#8217;s 33&#8211;and she&#8217;s never come close to getting over him. I thought about DNF-ing the book. I am so happy I didn&#8217;t. Look on the Bright Side is&#8211;and this is saying something&#8211;one of Higgin&#8217;s bests. Kayne, what are your thoughts? Kayne: I really liked Lark! She has a sense of humor and is so kind to everyone. She is funny on her first date with Lorenzo when we see her thinking how stuffy and arrogant he is yet she’s trying to be polite but is a little snarky and orders all the most expensive things on the menu. I wondered if this was going to be a grumpy/sunshine trope and it became even more interesting when Lark meets Dante, Lorenzo’s hot, firefighter brother. I couldn’t wait to find out who she would end up with. Was Lorenzo as big of a jerk as he first appeared, or would he redeem himself? Is Dante as nice of a guy as he seems and if so, what will he think of Lark after he finds out she’s been fake dating Lorenzo? I agree Lark was over the top when she kept crying in Oncology and while it didn’t bother me as much that she was still grieving for Justin, I wasn’t interested in hearing about their courtship and how much she missed him – I wanted to skip to the part where she falls in love again. I wanted to know how her dates were going with Lorenzo’s family and if she could make it in ER. Dabney: I get the whole love of my life thing, I do. But I also felt as though it was past time for Lark to move on. It was fun to watch her with both Dante and Lorenzo&#8211;and I liked the way both storylines played out. But I was very ready to get out of Lark&#8217;s head and thus was thrilled when, in chapter four, the narration shifts from Lark to her mom Ellie. From that point, the book began to soar. Unlike her daughter, Ellie is not a ball of sweetness and light, especially not after she discovers her devoted husband of 38 years, has done something she finds almost unforgivable. This comes as a shock to her and to everyone in their town because she and Gerald have what just about everyone would describe as the best marriage ever. They&#8217;re madly in love, have a hot sex life, adore their five kids and three grandkids, have their health, and Ellie has a very successful career as a painter and gallery owner. But now, now Ellie suddenly sees her life through the lens of anger. She&#8217;s supporting their family while Gerald faffs about starting and never finishing projects at home AND HE&#8217;S RETIRED! She is so angry she, rather randomly, moves out of the home they&#8217;ve lived in forever and in with Joy, a wealthy, lonely woman who moved to Wellfleet several years ago and is still mourning the death of her best friend and brother. What did you think about Ellie and her story? Kayne: I couldn&#8217;t wait to find out if Ellie would go back to Gerald. I was glad to see her take the summer off for herself, not just because of what happened with Gerald but because she had worked so many years without a break and she deserved one. I admired Ellie and her relationships with her family. It was interesting to see how her paintings changed over the summer. Dabney: Ellie is my jam. I was less interested in Joy. What are your thoughts about her? Kayne: I loved Joy &#8211; her name fit her so well because she brought joy to everyone she meets. She was such a good friend to Lark and her mom, Ellie, the way she took them in and how they all helped each other heal. It was special when she started working at the Bayview Senior Living Community in the Memory Care Unit and her classes were such a big hit, everyone started taking them, not just the memory residents. Hearing about her classes, like Joyful Movement, made me smile &#8211; I wanted to take them too. Dabney: Though&nbsp;Joy&#8217;s story didn&#8217;t do much for me, I loved Ellie&#8217;s and, after the first quarter of the book, I fell for Lark&#8217;s as well. But what I love most about this book&#8211;which moved me to tears more than once&#8211;is that Higgins writes gorgeously about the startling joy life offers when we have made our peace with death. Lark, as part of trying to get back to oncology, becomes a hospice volunteer and the parts of the story where she sits with those who are dying are phenomenal. Higgins&#8217; greatest gift in all her books is her risible love for humanity paired with her determination to give her readers genuine hope about life, love, and the world. The key word there, and why this book ended up being so lovely, is genuine. In Look on the Bright Side, Higgins leans into death. Her descriptions of patients going through cancer treatments are hard to read and, although one has the sense that she believes we, in our culture of treatment no matter what, need to consider if that is always the best option, she gracefully supports the choices patients make. In the scenes where patients in hospice opt to go gently into that good night, her prose soars. If you can read chapter 18 without sobbing, you&#8217;re made of sterner stuff than am I. Kayne: Chapter 18 was so heartbreaking. It brings tears to my eyes just thinking about it now and I rarely cry over books. It was so well done. I do agree with you about how hard it was to get through the part dealing with cancer treatments, but it made me appreciate the incredible ending even more. I did wonder how Lark had time to work in ER, volunteer for hospice and fake date Lorenzo. Dabney: Yeah&#8211;there is no way Lark would have had all that free time. But, this is a feel good fiction and, again, I just decided to go with it. Kayne: Feel good is right. I so enjoyed reading this novel! Dabney: Me too. And I need to stress, even though parts are heartbreaking, Look On The Bright Side is a joyful, funny, hug of a book. Lark, Ellie, and Joy all find the happy endings they deserve. The Santini family and the Smith family are peopled by those I&#8217;d love to hang out with&#8211;there&#8217;s not a loser in the bunch. I adored all the sibling teasing, the witty retorts, and the unbounded love these lucky families share. I am now wishing I could spend some time in Wellfleet&#8211;for starters, Ellie and I have a lot to talk about! Kayne: What stood out for me was how the story managed to be upbeat and hopeful, even during the hardest of times and the different ways that friends were there for each other. Dabney: Yes. Look on the Bright Side makes it clear that living and loving are just so damn worth it. In a world where we focus relentlessly on the costs of opening ourselves to others, this book celebrates connection in lovely ways. Kayne: Both families were wonderful. The party Joy threw for Lark and Lorenzo so the families could meet was a hoot. They were all so funny and quick witted with each other and even with Noni, Lorenzo’s nasty grandmother &#8211; they made me laugh. This is my favorite book I’ve read by this author and one of my favorite books so far this year. My grade is an A. Dabney: This is a DIK for me too. I’ve read thousands of books in my life and have decided that good endings are the hardest thing to do well. The end of this book, especially the last page, is a gem. And the novel’s last line? It’s perfect. My advice to readers is grab this wonderful book. Though it takes a bit to hit its stride, when it does, it’s magical. It gets an A- from me."

                "html": "<p>What was Maria Vale, she of the incredible shifter series <strong><a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/review-tag/the-legend-of-all-wolves-series/\">The Legend of All Wolves</a></strong>, thinking? Who decides to make <a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/review-tag/the-legend-of-all-wolves-series/\">Azrael, the angel of death,</a> an awkward and surprisingly, given his immortality, clueless romance hero? And to have him fall for his second (since the beginning of time) mistake, a mouthy, part-time stripper who struggles to pay the bills? It&#8217;s a mystery but whatever inspired Vale to write this gem of a story, all I can say is I&#8217;m damn glad she did.&nbsp;</p>\n<p>As our story begins, Azrael has spent the past two hundred thousand years ushering the dead into the next stage which, somewhat off puttingly, involves their souls put through Mangles and being transformed into more or less nothingness. And lest you wonder&#8211;and I think Santa should use this trick&#8211;how one angel has managed to process the 108.234 billion people who have died since the beginning of time, Death has the ability to stop time.&nbsp;</p>\n<p>In all the eons Death (the supernatural set calls him Ragpicker) has been at his job&#8211;he doesn&#8217;t really like it or the supernatural beings he reports to&#8211;he&#8217;s never been seen by a human. But, on the day he goes to collect the Rag or soul of a human with the last name of Molloy, he errs. Not only does he take the wrong one, the human whose soul he was supposed to (literally) pocket can see him&#8211;he&#8217;s inadvertently saved her from death by flaming hot chicken wing&#8211;and chats him up.&nbsp;</p>\n<p>Death now has a problem. Molly, he explains to her, is supposed to be dead. Molly, understandably, would prefer to remain in the land of the living. And though Death knows he&#8217;s supposed to send Molly&#8217;s soul to be Mangled, he just can&#8217;t quite bring himself to. Initially, she&#8217;s just so entertaining&#8211;his life is one of solitude interspersed with angry lectures from his superiors. However, given time which Death has in spades (In the supernatural world, there is no such thing as time&#8211;in fact, there is a running well done joke about his peers inability to understand tense that anyone who&#8217;s ever struggled with high school Latin will love.) he, like the reader, finds himself falling head over immortal form for Molly Molloy.</p>\n<p>Both Molly and Death, whom Molly calls Dee, are wonderfully unexpectedly leads. Death, in his marginally human form, is skinny, awkward, and absurdly enamored of cold pizza and trashy men&#8217;s magazines. He&#8217;s not especially sexy or wise and yet he is exactly what it turns out Molly (and we all) need. Molly&#8217;s morality errs on the side of pragmatic; she&#8217;s sarcastic and a better waitress than stripper. But she sees all creatures as having inherent value and her heart is big enough for two. Which is a good thing because Azrael doesn&#8217;t have one&#8211;organs are for humans not for angels.&nbsp;</p>\n<p>Over the course of this fable, Molly and Dee fall in love and create a life together. They navigate both his immortality and her insistence that the rent be paid with honestly earned money with equal effort. As they live together, we readers suspect that Molly&#8217;s time will, some day, end. Will Azrael&#8217;s? And, if Molly does die, will her soul be Mangled? And does it matter? Is the point of living just to be and be grateful for the gift of human existence? Or are our souls and loves destined to be timeless?&nbsp;</p>\n<p>You&#8217;ll have to read the book to see how Vale deftly answers these questions. All I&#8217;ll say is that, for me, the book has a believable, heart-breaking and remaking, joyful ending.</p>\n<p>I loved this book. It is true that, once I&#8217;d finished it, I wasn&#8217;t sure its metaphysics held up to intense scrutiny. But who cares? There are no easy answers about what love, life, and death really mean or even are. And though this book will make you think in all the best ways, its real gift is its richly imaginative storytelling, hilariously vivid characters, and its unwavering conviction that, really, all you need is love. And maybe some very spicy chicken wings.&nbsp;</p>\n",
                "text": "What was Maria Vale, she of the incredible shifter series The Legend of All Wolves, thinking? Who decides to make Azrael, the angel of death, an awkward and surprisingly, given his immortality, clueless romance hero? And to have him fall for his second (since the beginning of time) mistake, a mouthy, part-time stripper who struggles to pay the bills? It&#8217;s a mystery but whatever inspired Vale to write this gem of a story, all I can say is I&#8217;m damn glad she did.&nbsp; As our story begins, Azrael has spent the past two hundred thousand years ushering the dead into the next stage which, somewhat off puttingly, involves their souls put through Mangles and being transformed into more or less nothingness. And lest you wonder&#8211;and I think Santa should use this trick&#8211;how one angel has managed to process the 108.234 billion people who have died since the beginning of time, Death has the ability to stop time.&nbsp; In all the eons Death (the supernatural set calls him Ragpicker) has been at his job&#8211;he doesn&#8217;t really like it or the supernatural beings he reports to&#8211;he&#8217;s never been seen by a human. But, on the day he goes to collect the Rag or soul of a human with the last name of Molloy, he errs. Not only does he take the wrong one, the human whose soul he was supposed to (literally) pocket can see him&#8211;he&#8217;s inadvertently saved her from death by flaming hot chicken wing&#8211;and chats him up.&nbsp; Death now has a problem. Molly, he explains to her, is supposed to be dead. Molly, understandably, would prefer to remain in the land of the living. And though Death knows he&#8217;s supposed to send Molly&#8217;s soul to be Mangled, he just can&#8217;t quite bring himself to. Initially, she&#8217;s just so entertaining&#8211;his life is one of solitude interspersed with angry lectures from his superiors. However, given time which Death has in spades (In the supernatural world, there is no such thing as time&#8211;in fact, there is a running well done joke about his peers inability to understand tense that anyone who&#8217;s ever struggled with high school Latin will love.) he, like the reader, finds himself falling head over immortal form for Molly Molloy. Both Molly and Death, whom Molly calls Dee, are wonderfully unexpectedly leads. Death, in his marginally human form, is skinny, awkward, and absurdly enamored of cold pizza and trashy men&#8217;s magazines. He&#8217;s not especially sexy or wise and yet he is exactly what it turns out Molly (and we all) need. Molly&#8217;s morality errs on the side of pragmatic; she&#8217;s sarcastic and a better waitress than stripper. But she sees all creatures as having inherent value and her heart is big enough for two. Which is a good thing because Azrael doesn&#8217;t have one&#8211;organs are for humans not for angels.&nbsp; Over the course of this fable, Molly and Dee fall in love and create a life together. They navigate both his immortality and her insistence that the rent be paid with honestly earned money with equal effort. As they live together, we readers suspect that Molly&#8217;s time will, some day, end. Will Azrael&#8217;s? And, if Molly does die, will her soul be Mangled? And does it matter? Is the point of living just to be and be grateful for the gift of human existence? Or are our souls and loves destined to be timeless?&nbsp; You&#8217;ll have to read the book to see how Vale deftly answers these questions. All I&#8217;ll say is that, for me, the book has a believable, heart-breaking and remaking, joyful ending. I loved this book. It is true that, once I&#8217;d finished it, I wasn&#8217;t sure its metaphysics held up to intense scrutiny. But who cares? There are no easy answers about what love, life, and death really mean or even are. And though this book will make you think in all the best ways, its real gift is its richly imaginative storytelling, hilariously vivid characters, and its unwavering conviction that, really, all you need is love. And maybe some very spicy chicken wings.&nbsp;"
