                "html": "<p>Prior to reading the ridiculously entertaining <strong>The Deer and the Dragon</strong>, the last time I&#8217;d thought about the <a href=\"https://www.metmuseum.org/toah/hd/phoe/hd_phoe.htm\">Phoenicians</a> was in ninth grade in our study of the world&#8217;s early civilizations. Nor had I given much thought to <a href=\"https://www.pewresearch.org/short-reads/2021/08/17/6-facts-about-jains-in-india/#:~:text=Jainism%20is%20one%20of%20the,all%2Dknowing%20state%20called%20moksha.\">Jainism</a> or <a href=\"https://www.worldhistory.org/baal/\">Ba&#8217;al</a> and his consort <a href=\"https://www.worldhistory.org/astarte/\">Astarte</a>. Not so Piper CJ&#8211;thank the gods. Fluent in <a href=\"https://www.britannica.com/browse/Ancient-Religions-Mythology\">myriad ancient religions</a>, she also has a firm grasp on Christian theology. All are marvelously jumbled up in this novel, the first of her <em>No Other Gods</em> series.</p>\n<p>I really don&#8217;t want to tell you anything about this tale&#8211;just read it. But since this is a <em>review</em>, I&#8217;ll try to give you a sense of the book without spoiling any of its fun.&nbsp;</p>\n<p>Our narrator, Marlow, a wildly successful author of a series based on differing mythological pantheons, misses her lover terribly. Why has he left her?</p>\n<p>Well, Marlow grew up in a super religious home with a nutso mother. (Bear with me.) The women in her family have what the church calls the gift of sight, the ability to see gods, angels, demons, or whatever we call those beings that exist outside of the realm of human perception. Her mother, for REASONS, spent her life convincing Marlow that the visions weren&#8217;t real but rather a symptom of severe mental illness. So, after years of being involved with one such being, Marlow, never sure whether or not she&#8217;s crazy, has told him she never wants to see him again. Even though he is absolutely the best boyfriend in any realm ever.</p>\n<p>So, now she&#8217;s miserable and self-medicating dangerously. Then, if her severe depression isn&#8217;t enough, someone breaks into her impenetrable condo and tries to kill her. If it were not for Caliban, said fabulous boyfriend, plus an unbelievably handsome Nordic god both of whom apparate into her living room and save her, she&#8217;d be dead. But for REASONS, Marlow gets even madder at Caliban and banishes him. Bad idea. Hottie Nordic man tells her, honey, you screwed up. Your boyfriend is actually THE PRINCE OF HELL and, <em>yes, of course gods are real.</em> Now he&#8217;s gone and the balance between heaven and hell, who have been at war for eons, is tipping dangerously in heaven&#8217;s favor which is <strong>not</strong> a good thing.&nbsp;</p>\n<p>Marlow, after taking several beats to accept this, listens to hottie warrior dude explain that the real world is stuffed with gods of all kinds&#8211;pretty much every pantheon ever believed in still exists. Most of them are pretty minor in terms of their universal&#8211;and I use that term loosely&#8211;impact, although, there&#8217;s a town out West run by the Phoenicians one should avoid at all costs. But Heaven and Hell are heavy hitters and virtually every other god/demon/angel does not want Heaven to get the upper hand. (As a devotee of <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/His_Dark_Materials\"><strong>His Dark Materials</strong></a>, this made perfect sense to me.)</p>\n<p>Thus Marlow, with the help of a grouchy fallen angel and an extremely snarky Nordic goddess, sets out to unbanish Caliban which involves, well, I&#8217;m not going to get into it. But it is a DAMN good time.</p>\n<p>Marlow is a riot of a narrator. She&#8217;s a bit of a brat, with a background one rarely sees in heroines of any kind, let alone in romantasy. As she and her literally supernatural new pals try to outsmart Heaven, the Phoenicians, and a&#8211;haha&#8211;host of other hallowed beings, she comments on everything and, really, I could listen to her all day long. Equally entertaining are just about every deity she encounters&#8211;if, like me, you grew up snarfing down every mythology you could find, you&#8217;ll love her take on the stories you read about&#8211;Piper&#8217;s writing is inventive, smart, and intricately true to the original stories.&nbsp;</p>\n<p>This book is also wonderfully sex, queer, you-be-you positive. The author is adamant that any religion that doesn&#8217;t want you to think for yourself, shames you for your desires, tells you who you can canoodle with, or forces its denizens into subservient roles is unequivocally, morally wrong. If you&#8217;ve been looking for a progressive read that celebrates all kinds of relationships, cis, het, or poly, you&#8217;ll enjoy the hell out of this book.</p>\n<p>It does end on a cliffhanger and I&#8217;ve no idea how long it will be before book two graces our lives. But, even with that, I recommend it big time. It&#8217;s&#8211;wait for it&#8211;divine.</p>\n",
                "text": "Prior to reading the ridiculously entertaining The Deer and the Dragon, the last time I&#8217;d thought about the Phoenicians was in ninth grade in our study of the world&#8217;s early civilizations. Nor had I given much thought to Jainism or Ba&#8217;al and his consort Astarte. Not so Piper CJ&#8211;thank the gods. Fluent in myriad ancient religions, she also has a firm grasp on Christian theology. All are marvelously jumbled up in this novel, the first of her No Other Gods series. I really don&#8217;t want to tell you anything about this tale&#8211;just read it. But since this is a review, I&#8217;ll try to give you a sense of the book without spoiling any of its fun.&nbsp; Our narrator, Marlow, a wildly successful author of a series based on differing mythological pantheons, misses her lover terribly. Why has he left her? Well, Marlow grew up in a super religious home with a nutso mother. (Bear with me.) The women in her family have what the church calls the gift of sight, the ability to see gods, angels, demons, or whatever we call those beings that exist outside of the realm of human perception. Her mother, for REASONS, spent her life convincing Marlow that the visions weren&#8217;t real but rather a symptom of severe mental illness. So, after years of being involved with one such being, Marlow, never sure whether or not she&#8217;s crazy, has told him she never wants to see him again. Even though he is absolutely the best boyfriend in any realm ever. So, now she&#8217;s miserable and self-medicating dangerously. Then, if her severe depression isn&#8217;t enough, someone breaks into her impenetrable condo and tries to kill her. If it were not for Caliban, said fabulous boyfriend, plus an unbelievably handsome Nordic god both of whom apparate into her living room and save her, she&#8217;d be dead. But for REASONS, Marlow gets even madder at Caliban and banishes him. Bad idea. Hottie Nordic man tells her, honey, you screwed up. Your boyfriend is actually THE PRINCE OF HELL and, yes, of course gods are real. Now he&#8217;s gone and the balance between heaven and hell, who have been at war for eons, is tipping dangerously in heaven&#8217;s favor which is not a good thing.&nbsp; Marlow, after taking several beats to accept this, listens to hottie warrior dude explain that the real world is stuffed with gods of all kinds&#8211;pretty much every pantheon ever believed in still exists. Most of them are pretty minor in terms of their universal&#8211;and I use that term loosely&#8211;impact, although, there&#8217;s a town out West run by the Phoenicians one should avoid at all costs. But Heaven and Hell are heavy hitters and virtually every other god/demon/angel does not want Heaven to get the upper hand. (As a devotee of His Dark Materials, this made perfect sense to me.) Thus Marlow, with the help of a grouchy fallen angel and an extremely snarky Nordic goddess, sets out to unbanish Caliban which involves, well, I&#8217;m not going to get into it. But it is a DAMN good time. Marlow is a riot of a narrator. She&#8217;s a bit of a brat, with a background one rarely sees in heroines of any kind, let alone in romantasy. As she and her literally supernatural new pals try to outsmart Heaven, the Phoenicians, and a&#8211;haha&#8211;host of other hallowed beings, she comments on everything and, really, I could listen to her all day long. The author is adamant that any religion that doesn&#8217;t want you to think for yourself, shames you for your desires, tells you who you can canoodle with, or forces its denizens into subservient roles is unequivocally, morally wrong. If you&#8217;ve been looking for a progressive read that celebrates all kinds of relationships, cis, het, or poly, you&#8217;ll enjoy the hell out of this book. It does end on a cliffhanger and I&#8217;ve no idea how long it will be before book two graces our lives. But, even with that, I recommend it big time. It&#8217;s&#8211;wait for it&#8211;divine."

                "html": "<p>If you love smart hockey romances with leads that act like grownups and writing that shows a commitment to excellence, you, like me, will <strong>not</strong> enjoy this book.</p>\n<p>Our heroine, Astrid, is yet another romance heroine with zero interest in romance. Five years ago, she was left at the altar by a hockey star and now she&#8217;s the poster child for commitment-phobia. She&#8217;s a one-night stands only type&#8211;she even has rules against eating food with the guys she screws. Whatever.</p>\n<p>Her food resolution, however, is tested when Cal, the very hot and very unsmiley hockey-coach-with-a-heart-of-gold walks into the bar she&#8217;s working at. Not only can she not stop staring at his thighs (he&#8217;s equally obsessed with her deliciously thick ass), he wins her <em>let me bang you as soon as possible</em> favors when he physically puts down a guy who is arguing aggressively with Astrid about her rule that no one in the bar is allowed to discuss hockey. (This ban, in a bar in a hockey city, seemed absurd to me.) After a tiny bit of trite banter, the two agree to meet later in Cal&#8217;s apartment (this breaks another Astrid rule&#8211;don&#8217;t bang anyone in her building) for JUST SEX.</p>\n<p>Astrid shows up, Cal talks extremely dirty, the two have sex and, shocker, it&#8217;s the best they&#8217;ve ever had, and now they want MOAR. But it&#8217;s complicated because Cal is in town to work with Astrid&#8217;s asshat ex who now plays for Astrid&#8217;s dad and Astrid is against love and hockey. What on earth will they do? I couldn&#8217;t have cared less.</p>\n<p>Astrid and Cal are less like fully-fleshed characters and more like cardboard cutouts. Astrid&#8217;s whole &#8220;I hate hockey because my ex played it&#8221; shtick gets old real fast, and Cal&#8217;s relentless pursuit of her feels more cringeworthy than swoon-worthy. Both leads feel like early 20-somethings bumbling through life&#8211;it&#8217;s hard to take either of them or their manufactured angst at all seriously. I was especially irked that, though Astrid has a job, we learn nothing about her life outside her relationships. Oh, and the endless dampness of her panties.</p>\n<p>And don&#8217;t even get me started on the writing. The plot&#8217;s predictable and the dialogue as subtle as a <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MI7Tq6sRxE4&amp;t=1s\">Chevy truck ad</a>. And while the sex is copious and detailed, it&#8217;s not sexy nor does it reveal anything about the leads. Flynn has crammed in as much steaminess as possible without bothering with those little things like an interesting plot or believable character development.</p>\n<p><strong>Walk of Shame</strong> is less of a romantic journey and more of a stumble through a minefield of tired tropes and lackluster writing. To be honest, I skimmed the last half because I was so bored. I&#8217;ve not read Flynn before but we&#8217;ve given her<a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/book-review/butterface-by-avery-flynn/\"> Bs on two other books</a>. So, either this one is much worse than her earlier stuff, she&#8217;s just not for me, or this book just sucks. Whatever the issue, this is gets a low C.</p>\n",
                "text": "If you love smart hockey romances with leads that act like grownups and writing that shows a commitment to excellence, you, like me, will not enjoy this book. Our heroine, Astrid, is yet another romance heroine with zero interest in romance. Five years ago, she was left at the altar by a hockey star and now she&#8217;s the poster child for commitment-phobia. She&#8217;s a one-night stands only type&#8211;she even has rules against eating food with the guys she screws. Whatever. Her food resolution, however, is tested when Cal, the very hot and very unsmiley hockey-coach-with-a-heart-of-gold walks into the bar she&#8217;s working at. Not only can she not stop staring at his thighs (he&#8217;s equally obsessed with her deliciously thick ass), he wins her let me bang you as soon as possible favors when he physically puts down a guy who is arguing aggressively with Astrid about her rule that no one in the bar is allowed to discuss hockey. (This ban, in a bar in a hockey city, seemed absurd to me.) After a tiny bit of trite banter, the two agree to meet later in Cal&#8217;s apartment (this breaks another Astrid rule&#8211;don&#8217;t bang anyone in her building) for JUST SEX. Astrid shows up, Cal talks extremely dirty, the two have sex and, shocker, it&#8217;s the best they&#8217;ve ever had, and now they want MOAR. But it&#8217;s complicated because Cal is in town to work with Astrid&#8217;s asshat ex who now plays for Astrid&#8217;s dad and Astrid is against love and hockey. What on earth will they do? I couldn&#8217;t have cared less. Astrid and Cal are less like fully-fleshed characters and more like cardboard cutouts. Astrid&#8217;s whole &#8220;I hate hockey because my ex played it&#8221; shtick gets old real fast, and Cal&#8217;s relentless pursuit of her feels more cringeworthy than swoon-worthy. Both leads feel like early 20-somethings bumbling through life&#8211;it&#8217;s hard to take either of them or their manufactured angst at all seriously. I was especially irked that, though Astrid has a job, we learn nothing about her life outside her relationships. Oh, and the endless dampness of her panties. And don&#8217;t even get me started on the writing. The plot&#8217;s predictable and the dialogue as subtle as a Chevy truck ad. And while the sex is copious and detailed, it&#8217;s not sexy nor does it reveal anything about the leads. Flynn has crammed in as much steaminess as possible without bothering with those little things like an interesting plot or believable character development. Walk of Shame is less of a romantic journey and more of a stumble through a minefield of tired tropes and lackluster writing. To be honest, I skimmed the last half because I was so bored. I&#8217;ve not read Flynn before but we&#8217;ve given her Bs on two other books. So, either this one is much worse than her earlier stuff, she&#8217;s just not for me, or this book just sucks. Whatever the issue, this is gets a low C."

                "html": "<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><em>(warning: This book, while not having any spoilers, does sketch out the parts of the novel. If you want to experience the true glory of this novel, go and read it and then come back to this review.)</em></p>\n<hr>\n<p>In 1977, my family moved to South Florida, to an ocean front town an hour north of Miami. We bought a house on a spit of land in between the <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intracoastal_Waterway\">Intracoastal</a> and the Atlantic Ocean, both of which were a few blocks walk away. Even then,<a href=\"https://www.google.com/maps/@26.3309411,-80.0731758,740m/data=!3m1!1e3?entry=ttu\"> the expensive high rises that lined the shore lost beachfront every year</a>.</p>\n<p>The coasts of Florida, and indeed much of the American Southeast, are meant to shift and change as the ocean&#8217;s currents ebb and flow. As Lily Brooks-Dalton writes in the mesmerizing <strong>The Light Pirate</strong>, the buildings we place on these lands are:</p>\n<blockquote><p><em>Structures that belonged to an old paradigm. A series of rooms built upon a series of ideas, none of which had withstood the test of time: the idea that what was here would always be here; the idea that the limestone beneath their feet would go on holding them forever; the idea that the coast was a faithful, unmoving line in the sand. None of this was true anymore. The thing was, it never had been.</em></p></blockquote>\n<p><strong>The Light Pirate </strong>is set further up the coast from where I grew up but the landscape, ravaged by ever stronger hurricanes, tropical storms, overdevelopment, and feckless politicians, is the same. The novel, begins on the eve of an immense hurricane named Wanda. Many leave the state, headed North where, perhaps, nature is less punishing, but one family&#8211;a lineman named Kirby, his pregnant wife Frida, his sons Lucas and Flip&#8211;stays in the fictional town of Rudder, sure that this storm, like the many that have come before it, is the safest place for them. Their faith, like that of those who believe we can master the natural world, betrays them and, after Wanda, their lives as well as those of all who live in Florida, are cataclysmically changed.</p>\n<p>The novel is split into four parts—<em><strong>Power</strong></em>, <em><strong>Water</strong></em>, <em><strong>Light</strong></em>, and <em><strong>Time</strong></em>&#8211;and each segment moves the narrative forward in time. In the second, <em><strong>Water</strong></em>, the novel narrows its focus on, Wanda, a girl named for the storm in which she was born. It&#8217;s ten years after the events in <em><strong>Power</strong></em> and Wanda and her family now live in a state slowly being abandoned by the government. Kirby and Lucas spend their days repairing faults in a power grid that constantly breaks while Wanda attends an elementary school whose population drops every month. Wanda spends her afternoons with their neighbor Phyllis, an ecology professor who is also a survivalist. It is Phyllis who sees the truth of the world they live in and the skills she imparts to Wanda insure that Wanda, as Florida and indeed the world is remade to Nature&#8217;s will, navigates a path to the future.</p>\n<p>This future, one in which whole nations have vanished and where climate refugees must move constantly, is grim. But the life that Wanda and Phyllis make for themselves is not. Life, even in a dystopian world, is bettered by love and connections with others. As the story moves through the years of Wanda&#8217;s life, she endures although the world in which she lives is a harsh one, where one mistake can mean death and where trusting others is an risk.</p>\n<p>I read this book in a day. When I turned the last page, I found myself in tears, not because the ending is tragic but because it is not. For though <strong>The Light Pirate </strong>limns a not-so-removed world, one we rightly fear, it is a story of hope and resilience. Woven through its warnings is the belief that we can survive, even thrive, if we have one another. Wanda, mysteriously, causes the water she touches to glow&#8211;hence the title of the book. Brooks-Dalton&#8217;s prose is commensurately dazzling. Yes, she tells us, it is too late to go back to the world we imagined with its power grids, mega dams, and concrete lands. But, if we open ourselves to the world as it is, to others as they are, our future mayhap still gleam.</p>\n<p>&nbsp;</p>\n",
                "text": "(warning: This book, while not having any spoilers, does sketch out the parts of the novel. If you want to experience the true glory of this novel, go and read it and then come back to this review.) In 1977, my family moved to South Florida, to an ocean front town an hour north of Miami. We bought a house on a spit of land in between the Intracoastal and the Atlantic Ocean, both of which were a few blocks walk away. Even then, the expensive high rises that lined the shore lost beachfront every year. The coasts of Florida, and indeed much of the American Southeast, are meant to shift and change as the ocean&#8217;s currents ebb and flow. As Lily Brooks-Dalton writes in the mesmerizing The Light Pirate, the buildings we place on these lands are: Structures that belonged to an old paradigm. A series of rooms built upon a series of ideas, none of which had withstood the test of time: the idea that what was here would always be here; the idea that the limestone beneath their feet would go on holding them forever; the idea that the coast was a faithful, unmoving line in the sand. None of this was true anymore. The thing was, it never had been. The Light Pirate is set further up the coast from where I grew up but the landscape, ravaged by ever stronger hurricanes, tropical storms, overdevelopment, and feckless politicians, is the same. The novel, begins on the eve of an immense hurricane named Wanda. Many leave the state, headed North where, perhaps, nature is less punishing, but one family&#8211;a lineman named Kirby, his pregnant wife Frida, his sons Lucas and Flip&#8211;stays in the fictional town of Rudder, sure that this storm, like the many that have come before it, is the safest place for them. Their faith, like that of those who believe we can master the natural world, betrays them and, after Wanda, their lives as well as those of all who live in Florida, are cataclysmically changed. The novel is split into four parts—Power, Water, Light, and Time&#8211;and each segment moves the narrative forward in time. In the second, Water, the novel narrows its focus on, Wanda, a girl named for the storm in which she was born. It&#8217;s ten years after the events in Power and Wanda and her family now live in a state slowly being abandoned by the government. Kirby and Lucas spend their days repairing faults in a power grid that constantly breaks while Wanda attends an elementary school whose population drops every month. Wanda spends her afternoons with their neighbor Phyllis, an ecology professor who is also a survivalist. It is Phyllis who sees the truth of the world they live in and the skills she imparts to Wanda insure that Wanda, as Florida and indeed the world is remade to Nature&#8217;s will, navigates a path to the future. This future, one in which whole nations have vanished and where climate refugees must move constantly, is grim. But the life that Wanda and Phyllis make for themselves is not. Life, even in a dystopian world, is bettered by love and connections with others. As the story moves through the years of Wanda&#8217;s life, she endures although the world in which she lives is a harsh one, where one mistake can mean death and where trusting others is an risk. I read this book in a day. When I turned the last page, I found myself in tears, not because the ending is tragic but because it is not. For though The Light Pirate limns a not-so-removed world, one we rightly fear, it is a story of hope and resilience. Woven through its warnings is the belief that we can survive, even thrive, if we have one another. Wanda, mysteriously, causes the water she touches to glow&#8211;hence the title of the book. Brooks-Dalton&#8217;s prose is commensurately dazzling. Yes, she tells us, it is too late to go back to the world we imagined with its power grids, mega dams, and concrete lands. But, if we open ourselves to the world as it is, to others as they are, our future mayhap still gleam. &nbsp;"

He meets the woman of his dreams but HE STILL JUST CAN&#8217;T TRUST, so, even though she&#8217;s clearly the one and she HAZ FEELINGS, he continues his rakish ways until&#8211;SNAP!&#8211;love finally becomes the thing he realizes he truly deserves and wants. Except, here, it&#8217;s a she. Not a plot we see much in romance. Lisa, what did you think about the story of Roxie? Lisa: Roxie absolutely reminded me of Dee from It&#8217;s Always Sunny in Philadelphia, only way more confident and MUCH less of a hot mess.  I love seeing role reveals like this &#8211; I loved seeing Roxie hook up with other dudes to wash the feeling of TRUE LOVE out of her mouth &#8211; only to feel bad about ignoring Chris. Dabney: I can&#8217;t decide if she&#8217;s a mite too self-destructive for me. Like, WHY run from true love? is it only her conviction that men just dig her for sex? (This is a plot I&#8217;m seeing more in contemporary romance and, in some ways, it seems very retro to me.) And I have to say I found the whole men like to bang Roxie but not seriously date her because she isn&#8217;t small and blonde a bit much. I&#8217;d hazard that the same men who seek Sydney Sweeney look alikes to be their OTP are equally DTF same. I had a hard time buying that Roxie, just because she&#8217;s tall and brunette, could only find men interested in only hooking up. But I&#8217;m ancient. Lisa, am I missing something here? Lisa: Well, they&#8217;d gladly do the same thing to Ms. Sweeney &#8211; trust me, I know of men who are the types of dudes who would do what they do with Roxie but ply their wares upon young blondes.  Yeah, that&#8217;s a small blemish on the books&#8217; credibility. Dabney: The thing is, except when she was being an idiot, I really liked Roxie. She&#8217;s smart, very good at her job, has a wickedly sharp sense of humor, and, in general, is one of those people you meet in a book that you&#8217;d totally like to grab a drink with. What did you think of her? Lisa: Honestly, she&#8217;s probably my favorite romance heroine of the year so far because of all of those things. Dabney: I also liked Chris. I&#8217;d be happy if my kid brought him home as a friend or a date. He&#8217;s smart, full of zingy quips, and is cleary deeply loyal to those he cares for. I liked him so much that, when Roxie refused to cut him slack for any of his missteps, I thought she was being overly extra. Lisa: Chris is smart, normal and super fun &#8211; definitely an excellent hero. Dabney: This is certainly, for a book that is less than 225 pages long, chockablock full of sex, all of which involves Roxie. She has sex with four different guys and all of the scenes are detailed. Which is fine because Ember writes excellent sex scenes. And, props to her given her dedication to writing Roxie the rake&#8217;s many hookups judgement free, she manages to show that, when it&#8217;s sex and love, it&#8217;s a different and better kind of sex. Lisa: Oh yeah, this one borders on a hot rating for a reason. And I liked the detached fondness of all the hookup sex versus what happens with Chris, which feels more real, so to speak. Dabney: My biggest complaint is, especially given how short this book is, Roxie&#8217;s insistence on HAVING THINGS HER WAY ONLY. Chris was clearly deserving of her trust, love, and great blow jobs&#8211;I got a bit bored of the endless stream of NO Roxie defaulted to. Lisa: I found it more psychologically complex; she was clearly punishing herself here. Dabney: I think I needed more words to understand that Roxie was complex as opposed to unnecessarily self-destructive. That said, I suspect she&#8217;s a heroine that will resonate with many. This is a very modern romance and I liked that about it. I&#8217;m here for a romance novel&#8217;s casual sex enthusiast being female. Once Roxie opened up her heart a bit, the power dynamic in the book seemed fab and fair. The sex scenes are focused on female and male pleasure in erotic and realistic ways. Those who are willing to forgo traditional assumptions about women looking for some good D rather than love will find Roxie and Chris&#8217; story appealing. Lisa: If it breaks down the walls surrounding stigma attached to romancelandia slut shaming, I&#8217;m all for it. Dabney: It&#8217;s a B read for me. Roxie took too long to let herself fall for very kind Chris and the book seemed padded with more sex than plot. But, overall, it&#8217;s a fun, sexy read. Lisa: Going a little higher with a B+ because I really liked hero and Heroine alike &#8211; the sex was enjoyable and I can&#8217;t complain that too much was enough."

                "html": "<div class=\"flex-1 overflow-hidden\">\n<div class=\"react-scroll-to-bottom--css-znqjm-79elbk h-full\">\n<div class=\"react-scroll-to-bottom--css-znqjm-1n7m0yu\">\n<div class=\"flex flex-col text-sm pb-9\">\n<div class=\"w-full text-token-text-primary\" data-testid=\"conversation-turn-17\">\n<div class=\"px-4 py-2 justify-center text-base md:gap-6 m-auto\">\n<div class=\"flex flex-1 text-base mx-auto gap-3 md:px-5 lg:px-1 xl:px-5 md:max-w-3xl lg:max-w-[40rem] xl:max-w-[48rem] group final-completion\">\n<div class=\"relative flex w-full flex-col agent-turn\">\n<div class=\"flex-col gap-1 md:gap-3\">\n<div class=\"flex flex-grow flex-col max-w-full\">\n<div class=\"min-h-[20px] text-message flex flex-col items-start gap-3 whitespace-pre-wrap break-words [.text-message+&amp;]:mt-5 overflow-x-auto\" data-message-author-role=\"assistant\" data-message-id=\"e0759604-57a3-425a-882a-0edda5c2cc78\">\n<div class=\"markdown prose w-full break-words dark:prose-invert light\">\n<p>Tana French&#8217;s latest work, <strong>The Hunter</strong>, yet again solidifies her reign as the queen of literary mysteries. Set in the west of Ireland, it&#8217;s the story of <a href=\"https://www.writingforums.com/threads/there-are-only-two-plots-or-how-to-have-an-existential-crisis-in-writing.174038/\">a (somewhat) stranger who comes to town</a> and the havoc his return creates.</p>\n<p><span style=\"font-family: var(--global-body-font-family);\">Taking this in are Cal Hooper and Trey Reddy. Cal is the retired Chicago detective whom readers met in </span><a style=\"font-family: var(--global-body-font-family);\" href=\"https://amzn.to/4bXw6pq\"><strong>The Searcher</strong></a><span style=\"font-family: var(--global-body-font-family);\">. (You don&#8217;t have to have read that book to enjoy this one, but it will give this story more depth.) A couple of years ago, Cal moved to the tiny hamlet of Ardnakelty seeking solace amidst the tranquility of rural life. There, he found the nosiest neighbors in the UK, and, of course, crimes he simply can&#8217;t help but work to decipher.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-family: var(--global-body-font-family);\">Trey Reddy is a rebel of a girl whom Cal has been attempting to mentor and protect. The Reddys live on the lowest rungs on the town, and are very poor, troubled, and are disdained by the town. Much of this is due to Trey&#8217;s feckless father, Johnny, who abandoned his family and, distressingly, has now returned. Why Johnny has come home, what he (really) wants, and what it means for Trey, the Reddys, and the denizens of Ardnakelty, well, therein lies a fabulous tale.</span></p>\n<p>French&#8217;s mysteries are never just mysteries&#8211;they are, as has been famously said by others, stellar novels that happen to have crime in them. Here, she slowly unwraps the complex relationship between Cal and Trey, a bond that is tested by the return of Johnny and the depredation he brings. As these three lives become intertwined, French explores the depths of human emotion, delving into the intricacies of love, loss, vengeance, and redemption.</p>\n<p>And though I used the word <em>slow</em>, don&#8217;t misunderstand me: This <strong>is</strong> a riveting plot. The cascade of disasters caused by Johnny&#8217;s return are myriad and the threat to Trey, a character readers will adore, is risible. Furthermore, French&#8217;s mastery lies not only in her ability to craft a gripping plot but also in her skill in painting vivid, atmospheric settings. Through her prose, the village comes alive, its every nook and cranny pulsating with life and intrigue.</p>\n<p><strong>The Hunter</strong> transcends the usual confines of genre, using glorious language to limn the precarious experience we call living. Her character development is meticulous and Cal, Trey, and the residents of the village are all indelible. Many of the latter are, wonderfully, slippery, especially Cal&#8217;s pain in the ass next door neighbor Mart who steals every scene he&#8217;s in. You won&#8217;t know until the end&#8211;and perhaps not even then&#8211;whom Cal and Trey can trust&#8211;although I&#8217;d put my money on Lena, Cal&#8217;s no nonsense girlfriend every time. But you&#8217;ll wish you&#8217;d been there to listen to the village elders plot in the bar or watch Trey risk everything for her pride simply because the way French writes is mesmerising.</p>\n<p>Whether you&#8217;re a longtime fan of Tana French or new to her world, <strong>The Hunter</strong> is a must-read for anyone who appreciates masterful storytelling. It&#8217;s a novel that&#8217;s lingered in your mind long after I turned the final page and is a testament to French&#8217;s undeniable talent as a storyteller. When it comes to writing mysteries, as Carly Simon once sang, <strong>nobody</strong> does it better.</p>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"mt-1 flex justify-start gap-3 empty:hidden\">\n<div class=\"text-gray-400 flex self-end lg:self-center justify-center lg:justify-start mt-0 -ml-1 h-7 visible\">\n<p>&nbsp;</p>\n<div class=\"flex\">&nbsp;</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"pr-2 lg:pr-0\">&nbsp;</div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"absolute\">\n<div class=\"flex w-full gap-2 items-center justify-center\">&nbsp;</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"w-full pt-2 md:pt-0 dark:border-white/20 md:border-transparent md:dark:border-transparent md:w-[calc(100%-.5rem)]\">\n<form class=\"stretch mx-2 flex flex-row gap-3 last:mb-2 md:mx-4 md:last:mb-6 lg:mx-auto lg:max-w-2xl xl:max-w-3xl\" data-dashlane-rid=\"e2504a62c9807bc0\" data-form-type=\"\">\n<div class=\"relative flex h-full flex-1 flex-col\">\n<div class=\"flex w-full items-center\">&nbsp;</div>\n</div>\n</form>\n</div>\n",
                "text": "Tana French&#8217;s latest work, The Hunter, yet again solidifies her reign as the queen of literary mysteries. Set in the west of Ireland, it&#8217;s the story of a (somewhat) stranger who comes to town and the havoc his return creates. Taking this in are Cal Hooper and Trey Reddy. Cal is the retired Chicago detective whom readers met in The Searcher. (You don&#8217;t have to have read that book to enjoy this one, but it will give this story more depth.) A couple of years ago, Cal moved to the tiny hamlet of Ardnakelty seeking solace amidst the tranquility of rural life. There, he found the nosiest neighbors in the UK, and, of course, crimes he simply can&#8217;t help but work to decipher. Trey Reddy is a rebel of a girl whom Cal has been attempting to mentor and protect. The Reddys live on the lowest rungs on the town, and are very poor, troubled, and are disdained by the town. Much of this is due to Trey&#8217;s feckless father, Johnny, who abandoned his family and, distressingly, has now returned. Why Johnny has come home, what he (really) wants, and what it means for Trey, the Reddys, and the denizens of Ardnakelty, well, therein lies a fabulous tale. French&#8217;s mysteries are never just mysteries&#8211;they are, as has been famously said by others, stellar novels that happen to have crime in them. Here, she slowly unwraps the complex relationship between Cal and Trey, a bond that is tested by the return of Johnny and the depredation he brings. As these three lives become intertwined, French explores the depths of human emotion, delving into the intricacies of love, loss, vengeance, and redemption. And though I used the word slow, don&#8217;t misunderstand me: This is a riveting plot. The cascade of disasters caused by Johnny&#8217;s return are myriad and the threat to Trey, a character readers will adore, is risible. Furthermore, French&#8217;s mastery lies not only in her ability to craft a gripping plot but also in her skill in painting vivid, atmospheric settings. Through her prose, the village comes alive, its every nook and cranny pulsating with life and intrigue. The Hunter transcends the usual confines of genre, using glorious language to limn the precarious experience we call living. Her character development is meticulous and Cal, Trey, and the residents of the village are all indelible. Many of the latter are, wonderfully, slippery, especially Cal&#8217;s pain in the ass next door neighbor Mart who steals every scene he&#8217;s in. You won&#8217;t know until the end&#8211;and perhaps not even then&#8211;whom Cal and Trey can trust&#8211;although I&#8217;d put my money on Lena, Cal&#8217;s no nonsense girlfriend every time. But you&#8217;ll wish you&#8217;d been there to listen to the village elders plot in the bar or watch Trey risk everything for her pride simply because the way French writes is mesmerising. Whether you&#8217;re a longtime fan of Tana French or new to her world, The Hunter is a must-read for anyone who appreciates masterful storytelling. It&#8217;s a novel that&#8217;s lingered in your mind long after I turned the final page and is a testament to French&#8217;s undeniable talent as a storyteller. When it comes to writing mysteries, as Carly Simon once sang, nobody does it better. &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;"

py-2 justify-center text-base md:gap-6 m-auto\">\n<div class=\"flex flex-1 text-base mx-auto gap-3 md:px-5 lg:px-1 xl:px-5 md:max-w-3xl lg:max-w-[40rem] xl:max-w-[48rem] group final-completion\">\n<div class=\"relative flex w-full flex-col lg:w-[calc(100%-115px)] agent-turn\">\n<div class=\"flex-col gap-1 md:gap-3\">\n<div class=\"flex flex-grow flex-col max-w-full\">\n<div data-message-id=\"3138f569-1a99-4087-b06f-2cf53a28a680\">\n<div class=\"markdown prose w-full break-words dark:prose-invert light\">\n<p>Five years ago, in the gleefully gossipy small town of Plumpton, Texas, Lucy Chase wandered out of the woods, covered in blood, unable to recall who killed her best friend Savannah. After first being seen as a victim, Lucy slowly became the town&#8217;s prime suspect&#8211;even her parents seem to think she might be a murderess. There wasn&#8217;t enough evidence to convict Lucy or, for that matter, anyone, and Savannah&#8217;s murder remains unsolved. Lucy bolted to Los Angeles, rebooted her identity, and, under a pen name, became a successful romance writer. Now, she&#8217;s living under the radar with with a stodgy boyfriend when her anonymity suddenly vanishes thanks to a new viral podcast called <em>Listen for the Lie</em> featuring investigative fame seeker Ben Owens. Ben&#8217;s latest subject? Savanah&#8217;s unsolved murder.</p>\n<p><span style=\"font-family: var(--global-body-font-family);\">Even though she thinks it&#8217;s probably a very bad idea, Lucy returns, reluctantly, to Plumpton to celebrate her grandmother&#8217;s Beverley&#8217;s 80th birthday. She&#8217;s not been back since Savanah&#8217;s death and now, being there, faced with the fallout of the podcast and the endless Plumpton gossip, she finds herself trying to figure out who really killed Savanah. At the very least, she&#8217;d like to be 100% sure it wasn&#8217;t her. (I&#8217;m not a fan of plots that rely on localized amnesia, but Tintera&#8217;s tale is so fun, I rolled with it.)</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-family: var(--global-body-font-family);\">It&#8217;s safe to say, it&#8217;s not easy being home. The town is sure Lucy&#8217;s the killer. Plus, now that everyone is tuning into Ben&#8217;s podcast, Lucy and Savannah are all anyone wants to talk about. Ben too is in town and he really wants Lucy, her parents, her friends, and the cops to tell him their stories. The actual podcasts episodes are part of the narrative&#8211;they&#8217;re excellent-and Tintera uses them to break up Lucy&#8217;s snarky first person narration and to reveal a series of genuine surprises.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-family: var(--global-body-font-family);\">I do love me some will-they-or-won&#8217;t-they and Lucy and Ben have the sexual tension of, oh, </span><a style=\"font-family: var(--global-body-font-family);\" href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nMkbmtPlP-g\">Logan and Veronica</a><span style=\"font-family: var(--global-body-font-family);\">. (Please tell me you&#8217;ve watched </span><strong style=\"font-family: var(--global-body-font-family);\">Veronica Mars</strong><span style=\"font-family: var(--global-body-font-family);\">.) Readers will be wondering about the two until the book&#8217;s end, wondering if trust is on the table along with possible hot sex. Neither character is especially moral&#8211;those who like some grey in their novels will find </span><strong style=\"font-family: var(--global-body-font-family);\">Listen for the Lie</strong><span style=\"font-family: var(--global-body-font-family);\"> to be their jam&#8211;and whether it&#8217;s watching the two spar over how much Lucy wishes to tell Ben (or vice versa) or watching them flirt in Plumpton&#8217;s deadbeat diner, the two are always a very good time.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-family: var(--global-body-font-family);\">The supporting characters are excellent as well. Dead Savannah is hilarious and helpful. Lucy&#8217;s saucy grandmother, Lucy&#8217;s exhusband and his new girlfriend, as well as Lucy&#8217;s complicated parents, all add to the story in startling ways. Everyone has a story, not one of which is 100% true, and finding out what really happened to Savannah is seemingly impossible. Unless, of course, you, very carefully, listen for the lie&#8230;.</span></p>\n<p><strong style=\"font-family: var(--global-body-font-family);\">Listen for the Lie</strong><span style=\"font-family: var(--global-body-font-family);\"> has it all: a crackling plot, snarky humor, sexy banter, characters you care for, just enough well-placed female power, all combined with a tough to parse crime. This reader&#8211;along with Lucy and Ben&#8211;didn&#8217;t figure out what happened five years ago until the novel&#8217;s last chapters. <strong>Listen for the Lie</strong> is Tintera&#8217;s first novel for adults. Let&#8217;s hope it&#8217;s not her last. </span></p>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n",
                "text": "Five years ago, in the gleefully gossipy small town of Plumpton, Texas, Lucy Chase wandered out of the woods, covered in blood, unable to recall who killed her best friend Savannah. After first being seen as a victim, Lucy slowly became the town&#8217;s prime suspect&#8211;even her parents seem to think she might be a murderess. There wasn&#8217;t enough evidence to convict Lucy or, for that matter, anyone, and Savannah&#8217;s murder remains unsolved. Lucy bolted to Los Angeles, rebooted her identity, and, under a pen name, became a successful romance writer. Now, she&#8217;s living under the radar with with a stodgy boyfriend when her anonymity suddenly vanishes thanks to a new viral podcast called Listen for the Lie featuring investigative fame seeker Ben Owens. Ben&#8217;s latest subject? Savanah&#8217;s unsolved murder. Even though she thinks it&#8217;s probably a very bad idea, Lucy returns, reluctantly, to Plumpton to celebrate her grandmother&#8217;s Beverley&#8217;s 80th birthday. She&#8217;s not been back since Savanah&#8217;s death and now, being there, faced with the fallout of the podcast and the endless Plumpton gossip, she finds herself trying to figure out who really killed Savanah. At the very least, she&#8217;d like to be 100% sure it wasn&#8217;t her. (I&#8217;m not a fan of plots that rely on localized amnesia, but Tintera&#8217;s tale is so fun, I rolled with it.) It&#8217;s safe to say, it&#8217;s not easy being home. The town is sure Lucy&#8217;s the killer. Plus, now that everyone is tuning into Ben&#8217;s podcast, Lucy and Savannah are all anyone wants to talk about. Ben too is in town and he really wants Lucy, her parents, her friends, and the cops to tell him their stories. The actual podcasts episodes are part of the narrative&#8211;they&#8217;re excellent-and Tintera uses them to break up Lucy&#8217;s snarky first person narration and to reveal a series of genuine surprises. I do love me some will-they-or-won&#8217;t-they and Lucy and Ben have the sexual tension of, oh, Logan and Veronica. (Please tell me you&#8217;ve watched Veronica Mars.) Readers will be wondering about the two until the book&#8217;s end, wondering if trust is on the table along with possible hot sex. Neither character is especially moral&#8211;those who like some grey in their novels will find Listen for the Lie to be their jam&#8211;and whether it&#8217;s watching the two spar over how much Lucy wishes to tell Ben (or vice versa) or watching them flirt in Plumpton&#8217;s deadbeat diner, the two are always a very good time. The supporting characters are excellent as well. Dead Savannah is hilarious and helpful. Lucy&#8217;s saucy grandmother, Lucy&#8217;s exhusband and his new girlfriend, as well as Lucy&#8217;s complicated parents, all add to the story in startling ways. Everyone has a story, not one of which is 100% true, and finding out what really happened to Savannah is seemingly impossible. Unless, of course, you, very carefully, listen for the lie&#8230;. Listen for the Lie has it all: a crackling plot, snarky humor, sexy banter, characters you care for, just enough well-placed female power, all combined with a tough to parse crime. This reader&#8211;along with Lucy and Ben&#8211;didn&#8217;t figure out what happened five years ago until the novel&#8217;s last chapters. Listen for the Lie is Tintera&#8217;s first novel for adults. Let&#8217;s hope it&#8217;s not her last. "
            }

Mira’s job is to rescue survivors, if there are any. After all, she never feels the cold of the frigid ocean waters and the waves seem to sing to her soul. But the people of Rosevear never admit the that they set the beacons themselves to lure ships into the rocks.</p>\n<p>When the Council watch lays a trap to put an end to the wrecking, they arrest Mira’s father. Desperate to save him from the noose, Mira strikes a deal with an enigmatic wreck survivor guarding layers of secrets behind his captivating eyes, and sets off to find something her mother has left her, a family secret buried deep in the sea.</p>\n<p>With just nine days to find what she needs to rescue her father, all Mira knows for certain is The sea gives. The sea takes. And it’s up to her to do what she must to save the ones she loves.</p></blockquote>\n<hr>\n<p><strong>Dabney:</strong> This is the third first entry in a new YA/NA fantasy trilogy I read in 2023&#8211;the other two were <a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/book-review/fourth-wing-by-rebecca-yarros/\"><strong>The Fourth Wing</strong></a> and <a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/book-review/the-hurricane-wars-by-thea-guanzon/\"><strong>The Hurricane Wars</strong></a>&#8211;and it was the best of a very good bunch.</p>\n<p>I loved <em>everything</em> about it: the sublime prose and the unexpected character arcs and plot. Greenlaw&#8217;s storytelling relies not on dragons or complicated magic but rather on Mira, her riveting heroine, and those on whom she must rely. Lisa, was it a gem for you too?</p>\n<p><strong>Lisa:</strong> This was my first encounter with this author and I was mightily impressed by it. Mira is a stunner of a character; and she happens to be one of the best of 2024. She’s something special and unique in the field.</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney:</strong> Agreed. The very best leads in magical fiction are those whose magic is a plus not a necessity. I’d have happily read about Mira if she hadn’t an enchanted bone in her body–she’s smart, a bit snarky, determined, loyal, and witty. I loved her.</p>\n<p>Mira, as we learn in the first pages of the novel, lives in a small, coastal town that relies on the illegal goods they get from being wreckers. She has a preternatural ability to stay in the water and the villagers use her to swim out to the wrecked ships and bring back treasures. She is both ambivalent and determined about her work–she is a marvelously pragmatic woman. When the wrecking goes terribly wrong and her father is imprisoned by the draconian British Guard, she sets out on a quest and, oh, I was so there to watch her in all her adventures.</p>\n<p><strong>Lisa:</strong> The piratical worldbuilding here is fantastic; it reminded me of several different real-life subcultures, like people who scavenge wrecks for cash, or pearl divers working in the deep sea to support their villages. It felt very real and lived-in. And Mira’s love of the ocean is gorgeous and well-defined. It’s, in a great way, a definite part of who she is.</p>\n<p>Now, we both loved Mira, but what did you think of Seth? He was wonderful in my opinion &#8211; at least in the beginning…</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney:</strong> Seth, like many a good romantic hero, is full of surprises. I liked his ambiguity–one of the reasons to keep turning the pages in this very good book is to see if he is truly an ally or not. What did you so like about him?</p>\n<p><strong>Lisa:</strong> He had some great lines, and his mysterious ways kept me turning the pages, TBH. But…well, let’s just say that wonderfulness gets complicated with time and ends with a big twist we won’t spoil here. The ending of this novel leaves things in a very…cliffhangy place. That said, moral grayness is a wonderful part of this novel, and it is a feature and not a bug.</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney:</strong> I so agree with you about the way the book treats good and evil. Greenlaw knows that while her characters all have the capacity to do right and wrong, they, like us all, rarely choose one or the other. I loved the people in this book–they are utterly believable. Seth, Mira, her friends, and those they meet on their journey are wonderfully limned.</p>\n<p><strong>Lisa:</strong> Her ability to paint her characters as real, live human beings is what makes this book so very compelling, to be honest.</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney</strong>: To me, a great book has a trifecta of offerings; the best novels have stellar characters, engrossing plots, and wonderful worldbuilding. We’ve agreed that the characterizations in <strong>Compass and Blade</strong> are excellent. What did you think about the plot?</p>\n<p><strong>Lisa:</strong> The plot is fantastic, even if it’s your typical protagonist-finds-self-while-looking-for-lost-parent journey. It’s powerfully done, quite suspenseful and yes &#8211; leaves room for a sequel (this is set to be a trilogy).</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney:</strong> Well, it is an oft quoted maxim that there are only seven stories humans tell–I am rarely critical of novels simply because they recount stories we’ve read before. What I care about is how well is that tale told and, in <strong>Compass and Blade</strong>, I think it’s done beautifully. The details of this story–Mira’s experiences in and out of the sea, the battles she and her compatriots are drawn into, the politics of the worlds she travels to–these are all unique and made for a page turner of a book.</p>\n<p><strong>Lisa:</strong> Completely true. The world of sailing here is beautifully, written and sculpted thoughtfully. Did it encourage you to think of heading out on a boat yourself?</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney:</strong> I love being on the water but I think I’d like it a lot better if I had Mira’s gifts!</p>\n<p><strong>Lisa:</strong> I can’t blame you, but it made me want to check out the high seas. Familial loyalty is also important here; after all, Mira’s journey is all about rescuing her father. What did you think about the themes of family and family ties binding in this one?</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney:</strong> If I have a complaint about the book, it’s the bloody-mindedness of Mira’s determination to save her father. Parents, in the overwhelming main, never want their kids to sacrifice their lives for them. I wanted Mira to value her life as much as she does her dad’s.</p>\n<p><strong>Lisa:</strong> I actually related to that part of the story. Maybe because my mom’s dead and my father’s very much a part of my life, but I could understand her need to get sacrificial.</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney:</strong> Huh. I think for me, it’s probably an age thing. I can’t imagine the horror I’d feel if one of my kids or my siblings’ kids gave up their life for mine. That said, it certainly makes Mira an admirable character. She’s not pirating for gold for herself–all of her efforts (until the end but no spoilers here!) are motivated by her need to save first her father and second her village.</p>\n<p>I really did enjoy the hell out of this book. It’s marvelously subtle and I couldn’t put it down. It’s an A read for me. How about for you?</p>\n<p><strong>Lisa:</strong> This is a solid A all the way; Mira is a heroine of all time, the plot and worldbuilding are both fantastic, and the supporting characters memorable. I’m very here for the second book in the series.</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney:</strong> Me too! Thanks for chatting with me.</p>\n",
                "text": "This world of sea and storm runs deep with bargains and blood. On the remote isle of Rosevear, Mira, like her mother before her, is a wrecker, one of the seven on the rope who swim out to shipwrecks to plunder them. Mira’s job is to rescue survivors, if there are any. After all, she never feels the cold of the frigid ocean waters and the waves seem to sing to her soul. But the people of Rosevear never admit the that they set the beacons themselves to lure ships into the rocks. When the Council watch lays a trap to put an end to the wrecking, they arrest Mira’s father. Desperate to save him from the noose, Mira strikes a deal with an enigmatic wreck survivor guarding layers of secrets behind his captivating eyes, and sets off to find something her mother has left her, a family secret buried deep in the sea. With just nine days to find what she needs to rescue her father, all Mira knows for certain is The sea gives. The sea takes. And it’s up to her to do what she must to save the ones she loves. Dabney: This is the third first entry in a new YA/NA fantasy trilogy I read in 2023&#8211;the other two were The Fourth Wing and The Hurricane Wars&#8211;and it was the best of a very good bunch. I loved everything about it: the sublime prose and the unexpected character arcs and plot. Greenlaw&#8217;s storytelling relies not on dragons or complicated magic but rather on Mira, her riveting heroine, and those on whom she must rely. Lisa, was it a gem for you too? Lisa: This was my first encounter with this author and I was mightily impressed by it. Mira is a stunner of a character; and she happens to be one of the best of 2024. She’s something special and unique in the field. Dabney: Agreed. The very best leads in magical fiction are those whose magic is a plus not a necessity. I’d have happily read about Mira if she hadn’t an enchanted bone in her body–she’s smart, a bit snarky, determined, loyal, and witty. I loved her. Mira, as we learn in the first pages of the novel, lives in a small, coastal town that relies on the illegal goods they get from being wreckers. She has a preternatural ability to stay in the water and the villagers use her to swim out to the wrecked ships and bring back treasures. She is both ambivalent and determined about her work–she is a marvelously pragmatic woman. When the wrecking goes terribly wrong and her father is imprisoned by the draconian British Guard, she sets out on a quest and, oh, I was so there to watch her in all her adventures. Lisa: The piratical worldbuilding here is fantastic; it reminded me of several different real-life subcultures, like people who scavenge wrecks for cash, or pearl divers working in the deep sea to support their villages. It felt very real and lived-in. And Mira’s love of the ocean is gorgeous and well-defined. It’s, in a great way, a definite part of who she is. Now, we both loved Mira, but what did you think of Seth? He was wonderful in my opinion &#8211; at least in the beginning… Dabney: Seth, like many a good romantic hero, is full of surprises. I liked his ambiguity–one of the reasons to keep turning the pages in this very good book is to see if he is truly an ally or not. What did you so like about him? Lisa: He had some great lines, and his mysterious ways kept me turning the pages, TBH. But…well, let’s just say that wonderfulness gets complicated with time and ends with a big twist we won’t spoil here. The ending of this novel leaves things in a very…cliffhangy place. That said, moral grayness is a wonderful part of this novel, and it is a feature and not a bug. Dabney: I so agree with you about the way the book treats good and evil. Greenlaw knows that while her characters all have the capacity to do right and wrong, they, like us all, rarely choose one or the other. I loved the people in this book–they are utterly believable. Seth, Mira, her friends, and those they meet on their journey are wonderfully limned. Lisa: Her ability to paint her characters as real, live human beings is what makes this book so very compelling, to be honest. Dabney: To me, a great book has a trifecta of offerings; the best novels have stellar characters, engrossing plots, and wonderful worldbuilding. We’ve agreed that the characterizations in Compass and Blade are excellent. What did you think about the plot? Lisa: The plot is fantastic, even if it’s your typical protagonist-finds-self-while-looking-for-lost-parent journey. It’s powerfully done, quite suspenseful and yes &#8211; leaves room for a sequel (this is set to be a trilogy). Dabney: Well, it is an oft quoted maxim that there are only seven stories humans tell–I am rarely critical of novels simply because they recount stories we’ve read before. What I care about is how well is that tale told and, in Compass and Blade, I think it’s done beautifully. The details of this story–Mira’s experiences in and out of the sea, the battles she and her compatriots are drawn into, the politics of the worlds she travels to–these are all unique and made for a page turner of a book. Lisa: Completely true. The world of sailing here is beautifully, written and sculpted thoughtfully. Did it encourage you to think of heading out on a boat yourself? Dabney: I love being on the water but I think I’d like it a lot better if I had Mira’s gifts! Lisa: I can’t blame you, but it made me want to check out the high seas. Familial loyalty is also important here; after all, Mira’s journey is all about rescuing her father. What did you think about the themes of family and family ties binding in this one? Dabney: If I have a complaint about the book, it’s the bloody-mindedness of Mira’s determination to save her father. Parents, in the overwhelming main, never want their kids to sacrifice their lives for them. I wanted Mira to value her life as much as she does her dad’s. Lisa: I actually related to that part of the story. Maybe because my mom’s dead and my father’s very much a part of my life, but I could understand her need to get sacrificial. Dabney: Huh. I think for me, it’s probably an age thing. I can’t imagine the horror I’d feel if one of my kids or my siblings’ kids gave up their life for mine. That said, it certainly makes Mira an admirable character. She’s not pirating for gold for herself–all of her efforts (until the end but no spoilers here!) are motivated by her need to save first her father and second her village. I really did enjoy the hell out of this book. It’s marvelously subtle and I couldn’t put it down. It’s an A read for me. How about for you? Lisa: This is a solid A all the way; Mira is a heroine of all time, the plot and worldbuilding are both fantastic, and the supporting characters memorable. I’m very here for the second book in the series. Dabney: Me too! Thanks for chatting with me."

                "html": "<p><strong>The Woman on the Ledge</strong> is a story where, for the first half of the book, you know the narrator is lying&#8211;she tells you so&#8211;but you don&#8217;t know why. It&#8217;s a book that I found gripping until about the 60% mark at which point, having figured out what was going on, I enjoyed but found less than riveting.</p>\n<p>The novel begins with a jolt. At the annual employee Christmas party, our narrator, Tate Kinsella, escapes from her irritating co-workers by heading up to the roof to have a smoke. (Our so she says.) There she encounters Helen, a woman seemingly set on suicide. Tate, by telling Hellen how much her own life sucks, convinces Helen not to jump and the two women leave the party and exchange numbers.</p>\n<p>Less than twenty-four hours later, Tate finds herself in the back of a police car, accused of a murder in which a woman has fallen from that same roof, and which Tate vehemently denies having done. And yet, from the moment she tells the police her story, things don&#8217;t add up. She contradicts herself even more when she tells her lawyer what happened. There&#8217;s lots of evidence that points to Tate and the police&#8211;and, to a certain extent, the reader&#8211;are convinced of her guilt.</p>\n<p>The story then jumps to Maddy, the wife of Tate&#8217;s boss. Maddy has many things she&#8217;s worried about, the greatest of which is the erratic behavior of her 15 year old daughter Emily. As the book progresses, we hear Tate&#8217;s voice, then Maddy&#8217;s, then Tate&#8217;s. We wonder who the hell Helen is and why Tate is lying to everyone. It&#8217;s confusing, interesting, and gripping.</p>\n<p>It turns out that the truth is&#8211;shocker!&#8211;complex, twisty, and dark. One character preys on young girls and there are passages in this book that turned my stomach. This is very much a story about power, gender, abuse, and revenge and, for the most part, it&#8217;s a compelling one.</p>\n<p>That said, the novel didn&#8217;t completely work for me. When I finished it, I still had questions. Maddy&#8217;s behavior didn&#8217;t make sense to me and, even worse, the rationales she gives for several of her actions were ethically iffy. Emily makes choices that I found hard to believe. And though Tate&#8217;s background gives the reader great sympathy for her, I never really warmed to her nor, in the last third of the book, truly understood her.</p>\n<p><strong>The Woman on the Ledge</strong> is an exciting read that offers an exhilarating ascent followed by a more subdued descent. Yet, despite its shifts in momentum and the lingering questions it leaves behind, the novel&#8217;s gripping premise and unexpected twists had a firm hold on my attention until the very end. It&#8217;s not the best mystery I&#8217;ve read recently but it is one those who like psychological thrillers with morally ambivalent leads will enjoy.</p>\n",
                "text": "The Woman on the Ledge is a story where, for the first half of the book, you know the narrator is lying&#8211;she tells you so&#8211;but you don&#8217;t know why. It&#8217;s a book that I found gripping until about the 60% mark at which point, having figured out what was going on, I enjoyed but found less than riveting. The novel begins with a jolt. At the annual employee Christmas party, our narrator, Tate Kinsella, escapes from her irritating co-workers by heading up to the roof to have a smoke. (Our so she says.) There she encounters Helen, a woman seemingly set on suicide. Tate, by telling Hellen how much her own life sucks, convinces Helen not to jump and the two women leave the party and exchange numbers. Less than twenty-four hours later, Tate finds herself in the back of a police car, accused of a murder in which a woman has fallen from that same roof, and which Tate vehemently denies having done. And yet, from the moment she tells the police her story, things don&#8217;t add up. She contradicts herself even more when she tells her lawyer what happened. There&#8217;s lots of evidence that points to Tate and the police&#8211;and, to a certain extent, the reader&#8211;are convinced of her guilt. The story then jumps to Maddy, the wife of Tate&#8217;s boss. Maddy has many things she&#8217;s worried about, the greatest of which is the erratic behavior of her 15 year old daughter Emily. As the book progresses, we hear Tate&#8217;s voice, then Maddy&#8217;s, then Tate&#8217;s. We wonder who the hell Helen is and why Tate is lying to everyone. It&#8217;s confusing, interesting, and gripping. It turns out that the truth is&#8211;shocker!&#8211;complex, twisty, and dark. One character preys on young girls and there are passages in this book that turned my stomach. This is very much a story about power, gender, abuse, and revenge and, for the most part, it&#8217;s a compelling one. That said, the novel didn&#8217;t completely work for me. When I finished it, I still had questions. Maddy&#8217;s behavior didn&#8217;t make sense to me and, even worse, the rationales she gives for several of her actions were ethically iffy. Emily makes choices that I found hard to believe. And though Tate&#8217;s background gives the reader great sympathy for her, I never really warmed to her nor, in the last third of the book, truly understood her. The Woman on the Ledge is an exciting read that offers an exhilarating ascent followed by a more subdued descent. Yet, despite its shifts in momentum and the lingering questions it leaves behind, the novel&#8217;s gripping premise and unexpected twists had a firm hold on my attention until the very end. It&#8217;s not the best mystery I&#8217;ve read recently but it is one those who like psychological thrillers with morally ambivalent leads will enjoy."

With a fair amount of old-school storytelling and plenty of steamy moments, the story revolves around a troubled marriage in need of healing. I read it in an evening and can say it&#8217;s&#8230; fine. Too short and the storyline doesn&#8217;t really make sense but if you&#8217;re looking for throwback romance, Eaton is here for you.</p>\n<p>It does, however, get off to an awful start.</p>\n<p>Three gossipy ladies of the ton are at the dressmaker&#8217;s and, whew, are they cattily portrayed. One is large and loud, the other flat-chested and obsessed with cats. The third has breasts ruined by time and six kids. They&#8217;re unimaginatively named: Lady Harmsworth, Lady Topple, and Lady Farthing. Lady Harmsworth shares the gossip that the reclusive Lady Southwick&#8211;she has not been to town since her wedding eighteen months ago&#8211;has decided to come to town and take a lover. The three women are just so meanly portrayed and I&#8217;m pretty sure the modes of address&#8211;and, really, I don&#8217;t care about this&#8211;are incorrect. But, thankfully, once we leave the three busybodies, the book becomes much better.</p>\n<p>This rumor, of course, quickly reaches Adrian, the Duke of Southerland at his club. His internal response can be summed up by three words: <em>No fucking way</em>.</p>\n<p>Next we meet the very nice Mara who, when we meet her, is gardening at Southwick Castle, the estate her husband dumped her in after a disastrous wedding night. Mara learns of the rumor sweeping London from her sister Kitty who comes to ask her sister &#8220;what the hell?&#8221; Mara explains that she does want to take a lover but in turns out she was thinking lover could mean companion. Her one experience with the marital bed was so dreadful she sure doesn&#8217;t want to do THAT again. No, Mara, is tired of her lonely existence in the country estate and wants <em>companionship. </em>Kitty, wonderfully brash and fearless, tells her she&#8217;s out of her mind. She&#8217;s duchess for god&#8217;s sake and she&#8217;s shy and likes to follow the rules. Cheating, even if she&#8217;s not looking for sex, is out. Mara is undeterred. She thinks&#8211;and the reader doesn&#8217;t blame her&#8211;her husband is a cold, cruel man who doesn&#8217;t give a fig about her. She suspects that he has affairs right and left so why would he care if she did the same.</p>\n<p>She, it turns out, is wrong on both accounts.</p>\n<p>Now, look, you&#8217;ve read this story a million times. Ambrose is DAMAGED from an abusive bad dad childhood. His father taught him, when Ambrose was eight, that caring for anyone is a weakness and DUKES ARE NOT WEAK. Thus, Ambrose has spent his whole life making sure he doesn&#8217;t give a fuck about anyone&#8211;he&#8217;s a big enough jerk to take it a step farther: Cross him and he ruins you. He&#8217;s a man in desperate need of finding his shriveled heart, although having a heart is his worst nightmare. He married Mara because she fit the bill for a duchess and he was sure he&#8217;d never care for her or even, after she conceived his heir, have to see her again. He is emotionally scarred and, though the reader can see why, he is a much bigger dick than most modern historical romance heroes. (I liked this. Sue me.)</p>\n<p>Mara, pre-marriage, was a virgin and she who still doesn&#8217;t understand why the handsome, powerful Duke decided to court and marry her. She and Kitty had an violent father who beat their mother to death. She learned from an early age to fear men. She keeps to herself&#8211;her sister is the beautiful, vivacious one&#8211;and, when she thought about marriage, she just wanted a nice, quiet life with someone who was kind. Instead, she ends up wed to Adrian whom she fell in love with almost immediately because 1) he told her she was pretty and she believed him and 2) the two have <em>we just met sparks</em> that turn into a bonfire the first time they kiss.</p>\n<p>However, despite several passionate embraces before marriage, on their wedding night, Mara just lay there and thought it hurt terribly and Adrian, drunk, stupid, and remarkably clueless and insensitive to the whole virgin thing, botched his part. In the morning&#8211;and you just have to go with it&#8211;he was embarrassed that he&#8217;d done poorly and despite Mara saying&#8211;she really liked all their premarital antics&#8211;she&#8217;d like to try again, he is dismissive, rude, and leaves his marriage. (At one point, before the rumor, he muses to himself that, at some point, he&#8217;ll have to address the whole heir thing but NOT RIGHT NOW BECAUSE THAT WOULD INVOLVE FEELINGS. Not to mention an apology.)</p>\n<p>So, here we have a wallpaper historical, a hero who behaves stupidly for REASONS, and a bride who has decided SHE MATTERS. And, if you&#8217;re fine with that set up&#8211;and I am&#8211;this is a fun, hot read. Even though their behavior&#8211;especially his&#8211;doesn&#8217;t make a ton of sense, Mara and Ambrose are very sexy and sweet together. Mara learns to stand up for herself and Ambrose learns his defence mechanisms are ruinous and that, who knew?!?!, love and hot sex with a person you allow yourself to love are THE BOMB. There are lots of swoony love scenes and a fair amount of angst&#8211;the few hours I spent reading this book were mindless fun and, honestly, I am all for fun.</p>\n<p>I am sure there are some historical inaccuracies that will irk AAR&#8217;s historically detail-oriented readers&#8211;again, NOT ME!&#8211;but for those who miss old-skool heroes and heroines whose passions overwhelm them, <strong>The Duchess Takes a Lover</strong> will work.                 "html": "<p>Romance readers are a varied lot. We love all sorts of genres, leads, heat, and more. One person’s romp is another’s slog. I was in the middle of this book when <a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/book-review/never-blow-a-kiss-by-lindsay-lovise/\">our review of <strong>Never Blow a Kiss</strong> </a>came out. It’s a good review and, for readers that prefer their historical romances to be realistic with plots that don’t rely on unlikely events, it’s on the money.</p>\n<p>But for those of us who don’t give a fig whether the titles are portrayed correctly and who, sometimes, just want to have fun, this book is a good time. It’s not a DIK for me, but I found it to be an excellent way to while away a rainy Sunday.</p>\n<p><strong style=\"font-family: var(--global-body-font-family);\">Never Blow A Kiss</strong><span style=\"font-family: var(--global-body-font-family);\"> is a fun action rom-com. Think </span><a style=\"font-family: var(--global-body-font-family);\" href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=n_-55vkr1Y8\"><strong>Miss Scarlet and The Duke</strong></a><span style=\"font-family: var(--global-body-font-family);\"> crossed with </span><strong style=\"font-family: var(--global-body-font-family);\">Romancing the Stone</strong><span style=\"font-family: var(--global-body-font-family);\">. From the moment Emily impulsively blows Zach a kiss, the story moves rapidly. Our leads, two modern Victorians, fall for each other almost immediately but their path to love has many an obstacle.</span></p>\n<p>Though both were born poor, Zach is now one of the wealthiest men in Britain, thanks to his investment in the nascent railroad industry. (His stake came from gambling winnings.) He&#8217;s also a policeman tasked with finding The Evangelist, a serial killer preying on prostitutes. Emily is his peer. She is, as she says, a lousy governess, a job she initially got by lying about her criminal past. Her skills, though, were markedly improved by a stint of training at Perdita, the most prestigious agency in London. Emily was recruited by the owner of Perdita, a mysterious woman named The Dove, to spy on those she works for in order to catch those in the ton whom the police cannot. (This is book one in a series called, very straightforwardly, <em>The Secret Society of Governess Spies</em>.)</p>\n<p>I was captivated by them both. Zach exudes a very sexy charm and humor, and his banter with Emily is delightful in both written and spoken form. Emily is a forward thinking lead that, contrary to my usual reservations about such women stuffed into historical romance, I found remarkably enjoyable. Her advocacy for the downtrodden stems not from virtue signaling, but from a painful childhood that she ardently wishes to spare others. She&#8217;s smart, honest with herself about her choices, and very sweetly smitten with Zach even though she knows he can never be hers.</p>\n<p>As Emily and Zach fall for each other&#8211;their love scenes, though completely modern, are steamy and funny, my favorite combo&#8211;they also join forces to discover who is killing ladies of the night in Bethnal Green. And while I figured out who the killer was almost immediately&#8211;I am a devoted mystery reader and literary puzzles are my jam&#8211;I enjoyed watching Emily and Zach work&#8211;in between passionate encounters&#8211;to bring the murderer to justice.</p>\n<p>I enjoyed less the fact that Emily has a BIG SECRET, although to be fair it is indeed a BIG SECRET. Again and again, the author tells us that Emily is fretting about Zach&#8211;and the world&#8211;finding out about her BIG SECRET and I got <a href=\"https://www.reddit.com/r/buffy/comments/mrc8yf/bored_now/?rdt=48558\">bored</a>. I&#8217;d have preferred less anxiety and more answers&#8211;this part of the story, along with the appearances of those from her past (all uniformly awful people) is a drag on otherwise zippy storytelling.</p>\n<p>As I said, this is not a book for purists nor is a perfect read. It worked for me. I&#8217;m interested in the series&#8211;the heroine of the next book is a STEM heroine!&#8211;and in seeing what the Dove is really up to. Never Blow A Kiss is a strong B read and one I recommend to those who like their romances to be airy romps. As the kids say YMMV!</p>\n",
                "text": "Romance readers are a varied lot. We love all sorts of genres, leads, heat, and more. One person’s romp is another’s slog. I was in the middle of this book when our review of Never Blow a Kiss came out. It’s a good review and, for readers that prefer their historical romances to be realistic with plots that don’t rely on unlikely events, it’s on the money. But for those of us who don’t give a fig whether the titles are portrayed correctly and who, sometimes, just want to have fun, this book is a good time. It’s not a DIK for me, but I found it to be an excellent way to while away a rainy Sunday. Never Blow A Kiss is a fun action rom-com. Think Miss Scarlet and The Duke crossed with Romancing the Stone. From the moment Emily impulsively blows Zach a kiss, the story moves rapidly. Our leads, two modern Victorians, fall for each other almost immediately but their path to love has many an obstacle. Though both were born poor, Zach is now one of the wealthiest men in Britain, thanks to his investment in the nascent railroad industry. (His stake came from gambling winnings.) He&#8217;s also a policeman tasked with finding The Evangelist, a serial killer preying on prostitutes. Emily is his peer. She is, as she says, a lousy governess, a job she initially got by lying about her criminal past. Her skills, though, were markedly improved by a stint of training at Perdita, the most prestigious agency in London. Emily was recruited by the owner of Perdita, a mysterious woman named The Dove, to spy on those she works for in order to catch those in the ton whom the police cannot. (This is book one in a series called, very straightforwardly, The Secret Society of Governess Spies.) I was captivated by them both. Zach exudes a very sexy charm and humor, and his banter with Emily is delightful in both written and spoken form. Emily is a forward thinking lead that, contrary to my usual reservations about such women stuffed into historical romance, I found remarkably enjoyable. Her advocacy for the downtrodden stems not from virtue signaling, but from a painful childhood that she ardently wishes to spare others. She&#8217;s smart, honest with herself about her choices, and very sweetly smitten with Zach even though she knows he can never be hers. As Emily and Zach fall for each other&#8211;their love scenes, though completely modern, are steamy and funny, my favorite combo&#8211;they also join forces to discover who is killing ladies of the night in Bethnal Green. And while I figured out who the killer was almost immediately&#8211;I am a devoted mystery reader and literary puzzles are my jam&#8211;I enjoyed watching Emily and Zach work&#8211;in between passionate encounters&#8211;to bring the murderer to justice. I enjoyed less the fact that Emily has a BIG SECRET, although to be fair it is indeed a BIG SECRET. Again and again, the author tells us that Emily is fretting about Zach&#8211;and the world&#8211;finding out about her BIG SECRET and I got bored. I&#8217;d have preferred less anxiety and more answers&#8211;this part of the story, along with the appearances of those from her past (all uniformly awful people) is a drag on otherwise zippy storytelling. As I said, this is not a book for purists nor is a perfect read. It worked for me. I&#8217;m interested in the series&#8211;the heroine of the next book is a STEM heroine!&#8211;and in seeing what the Dove is really up to. Never Blow A Kiss is a strong B read and one I recommend to those who like their romances to be airy romps. As the kids say YMMV!"
