                "html": "<p>Recently, while stuck on a plane for too many hours, I decided to reread <strong>Heat</strong>. Back in the day, I loved Smith&#8217;s complex, morally batshit books. Three of her works, <a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/book-review/the-last-hour-of-gann-r-lee-smith/\"><strong>The Last Hour of Gann</strong></a>, <strong>Heat</strong>, and <strong>Land of the Beautiful Dead</strong>, were all DIKs for me and I wondered how I&#8217;d see her work now. Smith is a fearless writer&#8211;her works are violent, gorgeous, and terrifying. She&#8217;s not at all interested in making readers feel good nor does she care to improve us with her prose. She is, first and foremost, a riveting storyteller. It&#8217;s safe to say <strong>Heat</strong> is still a DIK for me and, I suspect, a book that many readers will be appalled by.</p>\n<p>This almost 700 page book intricately weaves together the tales of two alien men entangled with Earth women. Smith skillfully constructs a world where Earth remains has been isolated since its discovery by the Far-Reachers of Jota&#8217;s history. It&#8217;s a planet where slavers and chemists have thrived for generations.</p>\n<p>Kanetus E&#8217;Var, the son of Jota&#8217;s notorious slaver, is about to be sent to Jotan prison for life. (Slavery is illegal on Jota.) He manages to escape and heads for Earth where he can make tons of money by create a powerful drug, Vahst, derived from the human brain. Vahst&#8211;it reads as dopamine&#8211;is generated when humans orgasm. Kane&#8217;s MO is to brutally kill humans after they&#8217;ve come and harvest the serum. He&#8217;s a slaver as well.</p>\n<p>Jotans must have sex when the temperature is high or else they feel tortuorous pain and begin to go mad. Kane has landed on Earth during a heat wave and his need for constant sex is intense. The same is true for the other Jotan on Earth, Tagen Pahnee, an officer of the Jotan Off-World Security Fleet, who is pursuing Kane to bring him to justice. Unlike Kane who has visited Earth before, Tegan has not. Earth is an utter mystery to him and he is far more at its mercy than is Kane.</p>\n<p>Stranded on Earth, far from their homes, Kane and Tegan navigate a perilous environment teeming with humans and unforeseen dangers exacerbated by the intense Heat. This challenging backdrop adds layers of complexity to their quests. Both men need sex and both are determined to get the thing they most seek: Kane, Vahst; Tagen, Kane. And while it&#8217;s true that Kane is flat out evil, by the standards of both his world and ours, and Tagen is good, both men have motivations that make their choices morally murky.</p>\n<p>This is a dark dark book. There is endless rape, murder, mayhem, and fear. The novel delves into dark themes and morally ambiguous situations, creating a gripping narrative that will most definitely challenge some readers&#8217; comfort zones. It challenges mine but I still love it.</p>\n<p>One reason for this is that Smith&#8217;s characters are indelible. Kane and the human lover he finds, Raven, are BAD and yet they and their love story&#8211;it is a love story&#8211;are thoughtfully and believably portrayed. Tagen and his ultimate partner, Daria, are almost as compelling and certainly much easier to root for. For much of the story, the book switches back and forth between Kane&#8217;s and Raven&#8217;s murderous path and Tagen&#8217;s and Daria&#8217;s tentative relationship. Kane and Raven are enjoying the hell out of themselves while Tagen&#8217;s resolute goodness makes him and Daria suffer. It takes many many pages before the good guys get any kind of an upper hand and the body count accrued over that time is high. You can&#8217;t look away from all the violence simply because you&#8217;ll so want to see what happens next.</p>\n<p>It&#8217;s rare I&#8217;d recommend, to romance readers, a book with so much rape, murder, and cruelty. But recommend <strong>Heat</strong> I do. Tagen and Daria get the HEA they deserve&#8211;their ending is very smartly done&#8211;and Raven and Kane, well, you&#8217;ll have to read the book to see what happens to them. If you decide to give this a chance, understand it&#8217;s the opposite of fluffy. But, even with all its darkness, it is one hell of a read.</p>\n",
                "text": "Recently, while stuck on a plane for too many hours, I decided to reread Heat. Back in the day, I loved Smith&#8217;s complex, morally batshit books. Three of her works, The Last Hour of Gann, Heat, and Land of the Beautiful Dead, were all DIKs for me and I wondered how I&#8217;d see her work now. Smith is a fearless writer&#8211;her works are violent, gorgeous, and terrifying. She&#8217;s not at all interested in making readers feel good nor does she care to improve us with her prose. She is, first and foremost, a riveting storyteller. It&#8217;s safe to say Heat is still a DIK for me and, I suspect, a book that many readers will be appalled by. This almost 700 page book intricately weaves together the tales of two alien men entangled with Earth women. Smith skillfully constructs a world where Earth remains has been isolated since its discovery by the Far-Reachers of Jota&#8217;s history. It&#8217;s a planet where slavers and chemists have thrived for generations. Kanetus E&#8217;Var, the son of Jota&#8217;s notorious slaver, is about to be sent to Jotan prison for life. (Slavery is illegal on Jota.) He manages to escape and heads for Earth where he can make tons of money by create a powerful drug, Vahst, derived from the human brain. Vahst&#8211;it reads as dopamine&#8211;is generated when humans orgasm. Kane&#8217;s MO is to brutally kill humans after they&#8217;ve come and harvest the serum. He&#8217;s a slaver as well. Jotans must have sex when the temperature is high or else they feel tortuorous pain and begin to go mad. Kane has landed on Earth during a heat wave and his need for constant sex is intense. The same is true for the other Jotan on Earth, Tagen Pahnee, an officer of the Jotan Off-World Security Fleet, who is pursuing Kane to bring him to justice. Unlike Kane who has visited Earth before, Tegan has not. Earth is an utter mystery to him and he is far more at its mercy than is Kane. Stranded on Earth, far from their homes, Kane and Tegan navigate a perilous environment teeming with humans and unforeseen dangers exacerbated by the intense Heat. This challenging backdrop adds layers of complexity to their quests. Both men need sex and both are determined to get the thing they most seek: Kane, Vahst; Tagen, Kane. And while it&#8217;s true that Kane is flat out evil, by the standards of both his world and ours, and Tagen is good, both men have motivations that make their choices morally murky. This is a dark dark book. There is endless rape, murder, mayhem, and fear. The novel delves into dark themes and morally ambiguous situations, creating a gripping narrative that will most definitely challenge some readers&#8217; comfort zones. It challenges mine but I still love it. One reason for this is that Smith&#8217;s characters are indelible. Kane and the human lover he finds, Raven, are BAD and yet they and their love story&#8211;it is a love story&#8211;are thoughtfully and believably portrayed. Tagen and his ultimate partner, Daria, are almost as compelling and certainly much easier to root for. For much of the story, the book switches back and forth between Kane&#8217;s and Raven&#8217;s murderous path and Tagen&#8217;s and Daria&#8217;s tentative relationship. Kane and Raven are enjoying the hell out of themselves while Tagen&#8217;s resolute goodness makes him and Daria suffer. It takes many many pages before the good guys get any kind of an upper hand and the body count accrued over that time is high. You can&#8217;t look away from all the violence simply because you&#8217;ll so want to see what happens next. It&#8217;s rare I&#8217;d recommend, to romance readers, a book with so much rape, murder, and cruelty. But recommend Heat I do. Tagen and Daria get the HEA they deserve&#8211;their ending is very smartly done&#8211;and Raven and Kane, well, you&#8217;ll have to read the book to see what happens to them. If you decide to give this a chance, understand it&#8217;s the opposite of fluffy. But, even with all its darkness, it is one hell of a read."

                "html": "<p>In Nita Prose&#8217;s <strong>The Maid</strong>, we are given a first-person narrator in Molly—the Maid herself. Molly, a presumably neurodivergent young woman, finds her sole joy in working as a housemaid at the Regency Grand. Following the recent loss of her beloved Gran, Molly navigates a world where understanding others&#8217; responses remains a constant struggle, leaving her largely isolated.</p>\n<p>Despite her solitude, Molly harbors feelings for Rodney, the attractive bartender, and forms an intriguing yet complex connection with Giselle, the trophy wife of the odious Mr. Black, who runs a questionable business empire from the hotel&#8217;s penthouse. When Molly discovers Mr. Black dead in his hotel room, the mystery of his demise unfolds, leaving questions of murder and suspect identities lingering. Could it be Rodney, revealed to the reader as a man not worthy of Molly&#8217;s affection? Or Giselle, who exudes charm yet emits an air of untrustworthiness? Or someone else&#8211;the Regency Grand is teeming with colorful characters, each a potential suspect in this plot.</p>\n<p>As a mystery enthusiast, it was evident to me early on who was behind Mr. Black&#8217;s demise and why, leaving the anticipation for when Molly would uncover the truth as the primary intrigue. However, the revelation of this mystery took an unreasonably extended period, diluting the impact of the narrative.</p>\n<p>Having heard considerable praise for <strong>The Maid</strong>, I held high expectations that unfortunately weren&#8217;t met. While the novel adeptly highlights society&#8217;s dismissive treatment of service workers and individuals with different abilities, the narrative feels disjointed from reality, lacking a grounded connection to plausibility.</p>\n<p>The commendable exploration of societal themes juxtaposes sharply against the narrative&#8217;s struggle to weave a believable plotline. Molly&#8217;s journey and the societal reflections within the novel are significant. Still, the narrative&#8217;s disconnection from credibility and the delayed resolution of the central mystery ultimately compromise the overall storytelling experience.</p>\n<p>In essence, <strong>The Maid</strong> attempts to address substantial societal issues but falters in grounding its mystery in a believable reality, leading to a disparity between the compelling societal dynamics and the narrative&#8217;s tenuous link to a convincing plot. I suspect that many readers will enjoy it but I found it a letdown.</p>\n",
                "text": "In Nita Prose&#8217;s The Maid, we are given a first-person narrator in Molly—the Maid herself. Molly, a presumably neurodivergent young woman, finds her sole joy in working as a housemaid at the Regency Grand. Following the recent loss of her beloved Gran, Molly navigates a world where understanding others&#8217; responses remains a constant struggle, leaving her largely isolated. Despite her solitude, Molly harbors feelings for Rodney, the attractive bartender, and forms an intriguing yet complex connection with Giselle, the trophy wife of the odious Mr. Black, who runs a questionable business empire from the hotel&#8217;s penthouse. When Molly discovers Mr. Black dead in his hotel room, the mystery of his demise unfolds, leaving questions of murder and suspect identities lingering. Or someone else&#8211;the Regency Grand is teeming with colorful characters, each a potential suspect in this plot. However, the revelation of this mystery took an unreasonably extended period, diluting the impact of the narrative.                 "html": "<p>In the realm of storytelling, every now and then, a book emerges wielding a narrator so specific and wildly entertaining that all one wants to do is shut out the world until the very last page is turned. Such is the enchantment of Elston&#8217;s Evie Porter in <strong>First Lie Wins</strong>.</p>\n<p>In Elston’s inaugural foray into adult fiction with <strong>First Lie Wins</strong>, prepare to be thrust into a whirlwind where deception is an art and mysteries coil and unfurl with relentless intensity.</p>\n<p>Evie Porter, our riveting narrator, is a con artist who moves from town to town and identity to identity, all under the orders of her very mysterious boss, Mr. Smith. Currently, she is navigating the murky labyrinth of Lake Forbing, Louisiana. Guided by the slightly horrifying principle <em>the first lie wins</em>, Evie is tasked with unravelling one Ryan Sumner for reasons she doesn&#8217;t actually know. She is succeeding&#8211;she&#8217;s moved in with Ryan and is, behind his back, digging deep into his world. However, and this is NOT the goal, she finds she not only enjoys burning up the sheets with Ryan, she actually likes him. This, she must keep from Mr. Smith and keeping things from Mr. Smith is almost impossible.</p>\n<p>As Evie delves deeper into Ryan&#8217;s world, the narrative unfolds like a pulse-pounding saga. Sharing intimate moments and cozy brunches, her initial resolve begins to buckle under the weight of unexpected emotions. Amidst this turmoil, Ryan&#8217;s mysterious aura—a shadow as obscure as Mr. Smith&#8217;s—adds a layer of complexity to Evie&#8217;s already precarious mission.</p>\n<p>Elston&#8217;s storytelling prowess never falters, maintaining a breakneck pace that keeps readers riveted. With seamless transitions between past and present, Evie’s backstory unfolds, revealing layers of resilience, unwavering dedication, and a chilling commitment to Mr. Smith’s cryptic agenda.</p>\n<p>Just as the reader gets comfortable, a shocking revelation disrupts Evie&#8217;s world—an imposter claiming Lucca Marino’s identity. The ensuing turmoil propels Evie into a labyrinth of uncertainty where every twist and turn intensifies the thrill.</p>\n<p><strong>First Lie Wins</strong> transcends conventional thriller boundaries, echoing themes of trust, authenticity, and the precarious dance between truth and deceit. Evie Porter emerges as a captivating anti-heroine, navigating a world governed by male expectations while subtly challenging traditional norms—a testament to empowerment through shrewdness rather than overt rebellion. She&#8217;s also hilarious. Honestly, I could listen to her all damn day&#8211;her voice is just that good.</p>\n<p>This will unquestionably be one of my absolute favorite reads of 2024. It hits the trifecta with a captivating voice, a gripping plot, and characters that linger. Spending time with Evie was an absolute delight—I found myself rooting for her at every turn. Like all enthralled by this fabulous narrative, I hold out hope that this isn’t the last we see of Ms. Porter or the exceptional work by this talented author.</p>\n",
                "text": "In the realm of storytelling, every now and then, a book emerges wielding a narrator so specific and wildly entertaining that all one wants to do is shut out the world until the very last page is turned. Such is the enchantment of Elston&#8217;s Evie Porter in First Lie Wins. In Elston’s inaugural foray into adult fiction with First Lie Wins, prepare to be thrust into a whirlwind where deception is an art and mysteries coil and unfurl with relentless intensity. Evie Porter, our riveting narrator, is a con artist who moves from town to town and identity to identity, all under the orders of her very mysterious boss, Mr. Smith. Currently, she is navigating the murky labyrinth of Lake Forbing, Louisiana. Guided by the slightly horrifying principle the first lie wins, Evie is tasked with unravelling one Ryan Sumner for reasons she doesn&#8217;t actually know. She is succeeding&#8211;she&#8217;s moved in with Ryan and is, behind his back, digging deep into his world. However, and this is NOT the goal, she finds she not only enjoys burning up the sheets with Ryan, she actually likes him. This, she must keep from Mr. Smith and keeping things from Mr. Smith is almost impossible. As Evie delves deeper into Ryan&#8217;s world, the narrative unfolds like a pulse-pounding saga. Sharing intimate moments and cozy brunches, her initial resolve begins to buckle under the weight of unexpected emotions. Amidst this turmoil, Ryan&#8217;s mysterious aura—a shadow as obscure as Mr. Smith&#8217;s—adds a layer of complexity to Evie&#8217;s already precarious mission. Elston&#8217;s storytelling prowess never falters, maintaining a breakneck pace that keeps readers riveted. With seamless transitions between past and present, Evie’s backstory unfolds, revealing layers of resilience, unwavering dedication, and a chilling commitment to Mr. Smith’s cryptic agenda. Just as the reader gets comfortable, a shocking revelation disrupts Evie&#8217;s world—an imposter claiming Lucca Marino’s identity. The ensuing turmoil propels Evie into a labyrinth of uncertainty where every twist and turn intensifies the thrill. First Lie Wins transcends conventional thriller boundaries, echoing themes of trust, authenticity, and the precarious dance between truth and deceit. Evie Porter emerges as a captivating anti-heroine, navigating a world governed by male expectations while subtly challenging traditional norms—a testament to empowerment through shrewdness rather than overt rebellion. She&#8217;s also hilarious. Honestly, I could listen to her all damn day&#8211;her voice is just that good. This will unquestionably be one of my absolute favorite reads of 2024. It hits the trifecta with a captivating voice, a gripping plot, and characters that linger. Spending time with Evie was an absolute delight—I found myself rooting for her at every turn. Like all enthralled by this fabulous narrative, I hold out hope that this isn’t the last we see of Ms. Porter or the exceptional work by this talented author."

                "html": "<p>Look, I&#8217;m all in for a good time. Who doesn&#8217;t adore a fun holiday romance? But this one, while sporadically amusing and occasionally sizzling, dissipates into the realm of insubstantiality the moment you close its pages. It&#8217;s the kind of read that evaporates from memory almost as swiftly as snowflakes on a warm palm.</p>\n<p>This narrative is as gossamer-thin as they come, offering a concoction of humor here and steaminess there, but lacking the substance to leave an enduring mark. The leads, Amy and Ryder, feel plucked straight from the pages of a formulaic novel, Ryder especially embodies a level of perfection that seems at best unlikely. Frankly, I&#8217;ve yet to encounter such an impeccably idealized man in real life ever. And Amy, well, she&#8217;s is way to mopey for me although I suspect her whining is supposed to read as empowered. And, though she&#8217;s portrayed with sympathy, she&#8217;s pretty damned self-absorbed. Practically perfect in every way Ryder could do a lot better!</p>\n<p>Sure, there are moments of chuckles and some steamy encounters to keep the pages turning. Yet, the overarching tale feels akin to a glittering facade—enticing at first glance but devoid of the depth and resonance one seeks in a memorable romance. Once the final chapter draws to a close, what lingers is a hazy recollection, a fleeting impression of something seen but not truly felt.</p>\n<p>Love stories often toe the line between the extraordinary and the plausible, and <strong>Hate Me Under the Mistletoe</strong> ventures far into the realm of too-good-to-be-true. It&#8217;s a jaunt into a world where romances sparkle with an artificial sheen, and it left this reader yearning for more authenticity.</p>\n<p>In the end, this holiday escapade offers a transient diversion but fails to carve a lasting niche in the hearts of its readers. It&#8217;s a whirlwind of festive cheer and romantic dalliance, charming in its moments, yet ultimately dissipating into the ether of forgetfulness. If you&#8217;re seeking a brief fling with a holiday romance, this might suffice. But for those craving substance and characters that resonate beyond the pages, <strong>Hate Me Under the Mistletoe</strong> will leave you wishing for something more tangible and real.</p>\n<p>(I&#8217;ve not read the other <em><strong>Heller</strong></em> books, but this wafer thin story stands on its own tiny feet. I suspect, if you love those books, you&#8217;ll love this one. I did not.)</p>\n<p>&nbsp;</p>\n",
                "text": "Look, I&#8217;m all in for a good time. Who doesn&#8217;t adore a fun holiday romance? But this one, while sporadically amusing and occasionally sizzling, dissipates into the realm of insubstantiality the moment you close its pages. It&#8217;s the kind of read that evaporates from memory almost as swiftly as snowflakes on a warm palm. This narrative is as gossamer-thin as they come, offering a concoction of humor here and steaminess there, but lacking the substance to leave an enduring mark. The leads, Amy and Ryder, feel plucked straight from the pages of a formulaic novel, Ryder especially embodies a level of perfection that seems at best unlikely. Frankly, I&#8217;ve yet to encounter such an impeccably idealized man in real life ever. And Amy, well, she&#8217;s is way to mopey for me although I suspect her whining is supposed to read as empowered. And, though she&#8217;s portrayed with sympathy, she&#8217;s pretty damned self-absorbed. Practically perfect in every way Ryder could do a lot better! Sure, there are moments of chuckles and some steamy encounters to keep the pages turning. Yet, the overarching tale feels akin to a glittering facade—enticing at first glance but devoid of the depth and resonance one seeks in a memorable romance. Once the final chapter draws to a close, what lingers is a hazy recollection, a fleeting impression of something seen but not truly felt. Love stories often toe the line between the extraordinary and the plausible, and Hate Me Under the Mistletoe ventures far into the realm of too-good-to-be-true. It&#8217;s a jaunt into a world where romances sparkle with an artificial sheen, and it left this reader yearning for more authenticity. In the end, this holiday escapade offers a transient diversion but fails to carve a lasting niche in the hearts of its readers. It&#8217;s a whirlwind of festive cheer and romantic dalliance, charming in its moments, yet ultimately dissipating into the ether of forgetfulness. If you&#8217;re seeking a brief fling with a holiday romance, this might suffice. But for those craving substance and characters that resonate beyond the pages, Hate Me Under the Mistletoe will leave you wishing for something more tangible and real. (I&#8217;ve not read the other Heller books, but this wafer thin story stands on its own tiny feet. I suspect, if you love those books, you&#8217;ll love this one. I did not.) &nbsp;"

                "html": "<p>Ariel Lawhon&#8217;s latest work is my favorite book of 2023. This whopper of a novel delicately peels back the layers of history to reveal the intricate struggles and enduring resilience of women in post Revolutionary War 18th-century America. Through the eyes of Martha Ballard, a local midwife and guardian of the town&#8217;s hidden stories, Lawhon brilliantly illuminates the profound absence of women&#8217;s rights in the burgeoning American legal landscape, all without resorting to heavy-handed messaging.</p>\n<p>Lawhon&#8217;s novel tells the story of a year in real life heroine <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martha_Ballard\">Martha Ballard,</a> a woman whose life story has been told by many. Ballard was a midwife in rural Maine when women were still limited by the laws of <a href=\"https://www.womenshistory.org/articles/coverture-word-you-probably-dont-know-should\">coverture</a>. Ballard&#8217;s role gave her unusual power&#8211;she was able to testify about her patients in court and, unlike the vast majority of her peers, she was literate. Beginning in her 50th year, she began to keep a daily diary. She was a meticulous recorder of facts rather than emotions&#8211;she chronicled almost two decades of births, deaths, and lives.</p>\n<p>In <strong>Frozen River</strong>, Lawhon explores&#8211;based on history&#8211;an actual murder. In the first chapter, a gruesome discovery within the frozen river shakes the tranquility of her town. At the same time, Martha is a witness in a rape trial&#8211;her patient, the victim, has accused one of the town&#8217;s most powerful men. Martha&#8217;s unwavering pursuit for answers drives her to uncover the truth about both crimes&#8211;and as advocate for vulnerable women, she won&#8217;t rest until she unravels the enigmas within.</p>\n<p>The novel, inspired by the authentic diaries of Martha Ballard, provides a captivating glimpse into the mundane existence of a post-Revolutionary American village. It grants readers a rare and detailed view of women&#8217;s lives during the era, a perspective often overlooked by history due to barriers of literacy and the cost of written communication.</p>\n<p>Lawhon&#8217;s narrative, intertwined with a small-town mystery and a diverse cast of characters, is a profound exploration of love, resilience, and the relentless pursuit of justice. Ephraim, Martha&#8217;s unwavering husband, serves as her emotional anchor through the tumultuous storms of life and death. Theirs is a love story for the literal ages and its exploration gives the novel a warmth and joy that balances out the darkness the novel often invokes.</p>\n<p>This meticulously crafted narrative flows seamlessly, akin to the pages of a time-worn diary, offers readers a captivating blend of historical fiction, mystery, and romance. Its austere tone authentically mirrors the harsh winters and lingering Puritanical ideals of the era, immersing readers in a captivating world of bygone days.</p>\n<p>Whether your passion lies in unraveling mysteries, immersing yourself in historical fiction, savoring love stories, or savoring the beauty of masterfully composed prose, this inspiring book offers an riveting reading experience.</p>\n",
                "text": "Ariel Lawhon&#8217;s latest work is my favorite book of 2023. This whopper of a novel delicately peels back the layers of history to reveal the intricate struggles and enduring resilience of women in post Revolutionary War 18th-century America. Through the eyes of Martha Ballard, a local midwife and guardian of the town&#8217;s hidden stories, Lawhon brilliantly illuminates the profound absence of women&#8217;s rights in the burgeoning American legal landscape, all without resorting to heavy-handed messaging. Lawhon&#8217;s novel tells the story of a year in real life heroine Martha Ballard, a woman whose life story has been told by many. Ballard was a midwife in rural Maine when women were still limited by the laws of coverture. Ballard&#8217;s role gave her unusual power&#8211;she was able to testify about her patients in court and, unlike the vast majority of her peers, she was literate. Beginning in her 50th year, she began to keep a daily diary. She was a meticulous recorder of facts rather than emotions&#8211;she chronicled almost two decades of births, deaths, and lives. In Frozen River, Lawhon explores&#8211;based on history&#8211;an actual murder. In the first chapter, a gruesome discovery within the frozen river shakes the tranquility of her town. At the same time, Martha is a witness in a rape trial&#8211;her patient, the victim, has accused one of the town&#8217;s most powerful men. Martha&#8217;s unwavering pursuit for answers drives her to uncover the truth about both crimes&#8211;and as advocate for vulnerable women, she won&#8217;t rest until she unravels the enigmas within. The novel, inspired by the authentic diaries of Martha Ballard, provides a captivating glimpse into the mundane existence of a post-Revolutionary American village. It grants readers a rare and detailed view of women&#8217;s lives during the era, a perspective often overlooked by history due to barriers of literacy and the cost of written communication. Lawhon&#8217;s narrative, intertwined with a small-town mystery and a diverse cast of characters, is a profound exploration of love, resilience, and the relentless pursuit of justice. Ephraim, Martha&#8217;s unwavering husband, serves as her emotional anchor through the tumultuous storms of life and death. Theirs is a love story for the literal ages and its exploration gives the novel a warmth and joy that balances out the darkness the novel often invokes. This meticulously crafted narrative flows seamlessly, akin to the pages of a time-worn diary, offers readers a captivating blend of historical fiction, mystery, and romance. Its austere tone authentically mirrors the harsh winters and lingering Puritanical ideals of the era, immersing readers in a captivating world of bygone days. Whether your passion lies in unraveling mysteries, immersing yourself in historical fiction, savoring love stories, or savoring the beauty of masterfully composed prose, this inspiring book offers an riveting reading experience."

                "html": "<p>The <em><strong>Bailey Brothers</strong></em> series, by the prolific self-published author Kingsley, comes highly recommended by some of our readers. Curious what the fuss was about, I decided to give the series a whirl.</p>\n<p>The series opens with <strong>Protecting Us</strong>, a novella that essentially serves as a long prologue to the first full-length novel, <strong>Fighting for Us</strong>. The lovers here are Grace and Asher, childhood besties who grow up to be each other&#8217;s soul mates. The first 75% of the novella tracks their progress from tree-climbing kids to besotted adults. This part reads like a million other romances I&#8217;ve read&#8211;it&#8217;s clear from the first paragraph that the two are meant to be. Things are perfect until, very suddenly, it all goes terribly wrong.</p>\n<p>Their love story resumes in <strong>Fighting for Us</strong> which takes place seven years later. Asher returns home to their small town of Tilikum, Washington when he is released from prison. (I told you: their lives went off the rails at the end of <strong>Protecting You</strong>.) The two have had no contact since Asher was incarcerated&#8211;he says that is the only way he could have survived&#8211;and Asher is sure that Grace must have moved on. This, of course, is not true&#8211;the two are, after all, soulmates.</p>\n<p>When Asher realizes the woman he loved still loves him he does not embrace her with open arms. Nope, he is, he reasons, too damaged from the long years of violence he lived in jail. And kudos to Kingsley for showing the reader that, yes, Asher is damaged. His time inside has left him paranoid, adrift, rage-filled, and unable to sleep. It&#8217;s believable that he would believe it would be wrong to tie Grace, the person he loves more than life itself, to such a f*cked up man.</p>\n<p>Grace, though, knows that true love means getting through the tough times together and she is determined to get Asher to see that, no matter who he is now, they belong together still. This conflict is believable but, over the course of the book&#8217;s 500 plus pages, becomes repetitive.</p>\n<p>Additionally, these books present overly idealized characters. The other Baileys, Grace, and even the local shopkeepers in the small Cascade Mountains town where the stories are set, don&#8217;t feel believable. I&#8217;m all for stories about those we can admire but almost everyone in these books is too flawless for me. The worst is Gram, Asher&#8217;s grandmother (and, when he&#8217;s out of prison, his landlady). Asher and his four brothers were orphaned when they were young and Gram and her husband raised them. Gram is Native American and is the story&#8217;s literal wise woman&#8211;discomfitingly, her portrayal veers close to caricature.</p>\n<p>The only person who is genuinely flawed is the hero. Asher is an MMA fighter whose violent response to a threat to Grace landed him in prison. He is, throughout both books, without regret for the actions that led to his prison sentence. This makes him morally iffy and I wish that Kingsley had given him more a redemption that involved forgiving himself <em>and</em> those he attacked.</p>\n<p>Despite my reservations about Asher&#8217;s character, I can see why Grace is so dedicated to him. Real love means loving your partner through good times and bad, and Grace, though clearheaded about Asher&#8217;s struggles, comes across as a patient and compassionate woman. I adored her relationship with her best friend, Cara although there is too much foreshadowing about the latter&#8217;s obvious pairing with another Bailey brother.</p>\n<p>If you like dirty talk, there&#8217;s plenty here&#8211;is it just me or is talking about your genitalia in third person somewhat weird? I prefered the banter of the brothers to the bedroom chitchat. Really, the best thing about the series is the brothers and their lovely, often amusing, interactions. I&#8217;m sticking with the series for them and I can completely understand why so many readers have fallen under the Bailey brothers&#8217; spell.</p>\n<p>Both books unnecessarily together top 700 pages. I found myself skimming chapter after chapter&#8211;Kingsley is a good writer but these novels would have benefitted from some serious pruning.</p>\n<p>In the end, I&#8217;d rate the first two Bailey Brothers series a solid C+. While the romances might not be the strongest point, the witty banter between the brothers and the delightful friendship dynamics are clear winners. However, if you&#8217;re looking for a deeper emotional connection in your romance novels, this might not be your ultimate destination. And be prepared for characters who are almost too perfect to be true.</p>\n",
                "text": "The Bailey Brothers series, by the prolific self-published author Kingsley, comes highly recommended by some of our readers. Curious what the fuss was about, I decided to give the series a whirl. The series opens with Protecting Us, a novella that essentially serves as a long prologue to the first full-length novel, Fighting for Us. The lovers here are Grace and Asher, childhood besties who grow up to be each other&#8217;s soul mates. The first 75% of the novella tracks their progress from tree-climbing kids to besotted adults. This part reads like a million other romances I&#8217;ve read&#8211;it&#8217;s clear from the first paragraph that the two are meant to be. Things are perfect until, very suddenly, it all goes terribly wrong. Their love story resumes in Fighting for Us which takes place seven years later. Asher returns home to their small town of Tilikum, Washington when he is released from prison. (I told you: their lives went off the rails at the end of Protecting You.) The two have had no contact since Asher was incarcerated&#8211;he says that is the only way he could have survived&#8211;and Asher is sure that Grace must have moved on. This, of course, is not true&#8211;the two are, after all, soulmates. When Asher realizes the woman he loved still loves him he does not embrace her with open arms. Nope, he is, he reasons, too damaged from the long years of violence he lived in jail. And kudos to Kingsley for showing the reader that, yes, Asher is damaged. His time inside has left him paranoid, adrift, rage-filled, and unable to sleep. It&#8217;s believable that he would believe it would be wrong to tie Grace, the person he loves more than life itself, to such a f*cked up man. Grace, though, knows that true love means getting through the tough times together and she is determined to get Asher to see that, no matter who he is now, they belong together still. This conflict is believable but, over the course of the book&#8217;s 500 plus pages, becomes repetitive. Additionally, these books present overly idealized characters. The other Baileys, Grace, and even the local shopkeepers in the small Cascade Mountains town where the stories are set, don&#8217;t feel believable. I&#8217;m all for stories about those we can admire but almost everyone in these books is too flawless for me. The worst is Gram, Asher&#8217;s grandmother (and, when he&#8217;s out of prison, his landlady). Asher and his four brothers were orphaned when they were young and Gram and her husband raised them. Gram is Native American and is the story&#8217;s literal wise woman&#8211;discomfitingly, her portrayal veers close to caricature. The only person who is genuinely flawed is the hero. Asher is an MMA fighter whose violent response to a threat to Grace landed him in prison. He is, throughout both books, without regret for the actions that led to his prison sentence. This makes him morally iffy and I wish that Kingsley had given him more a redemption that involved forgiving himself and those he attacked. Despite my reservations about Asher&#8217;s character, I can see why Grace is so dedicated to him. Real love means loving your partner through good times and bad, and Grace, though clearheaded about Asher&#8217;s struggles, comes across as a patient and compassionate woman. I adored her relationship with her best friend, Cara although there is too much foreshadowing about the latter&#8217;s obvious pairing with another Bailey brother. If you like dirty talk, there&#8217;s plenty here&#8211;is it just me or is talking about your genitalia in third person somewhat weird? I prefered the banter of the brothers to the bedroom chitchat. Really, the best thing about the series is the brothers and their lovely, often amusing, interactions. I&#8217;m sticking with the series for them and I can completely understand why so many readers have fallen under the Bailey brothers&#8217; spell. Both books unnecessarily together top 700 pages. I found myself skimming chapter after chapter&#8211;Kingsley is a good writer but these novels would have benefitted from some serious pruning. In the end, I&#8217;d rate the first two Bailey Brothers series a solid C+. While the romances might not be the strongest point, the witty banter between the brothers and the delightful friendship dynamics are clear winners. However, if you&#8217;re looking for a deeper emotional connection in your romance novels, this might not be your ultimate destination. And be prepared for characters who are almost too perfect to be true."

                "html": "<p>Cate C. Wells&#8217; latest offering, <strong>Return to Monte Carlo</strong>, attempts to revisit the sizzling romance novels of the 1980s, but instead, sinks into a morass of missed chances, icky sex scenes, and uninspired narrative.</p>\n<p>The story begins, in 1982, with 20-year-old Diane de Noli waiting for her husband, 32-year-old Marco, to show up for their first anniversary dinner. The two met in a whirlwind romance, right out of an old <strong><em>Presents</em></strong> novel if they&#8217;d had sex scenes with graphic violence and many mentions of bodily fluids. Marco, the older, suave Italian billionaire has to have big boobed, blonde virgin Diane the moment she inadvertently cuts his throat during a shave. When he realizes that she LOVES him to f*ck her violently&#8211;this kind of kink is apparently called <a href=\"https://www.cosmopolitan.com/sex-love/a41175223/consensual-non-consent/\"><em>consensual non-consent</em></a>&#8211;he marries her and brings her back to his horrific family where they all live in misery in extraordinary wealth in a fictional&#8211;as in no bearing to reality&#8211;Monte Carlo. Unsurprisingly, his relatives treat Diane like sh*t but Marco, too busy saving his empire, doesn&#8217;t notice.</p>\n<p>When Marco does finally show up for dinner, he&#8217;s accompanied by his secretary, Sienna, whom Diane is sure he&#8217;s banging. So she bolts.</p>\n<p>Five months later, Diane, despite having been on the pill, is pregnant, and living in semi-squalor with two friends. She&#8211;and this took five months&#8211;decides Marco has the right to know he&#8217;s to be a father and calls him. Within 24 hours, he&#8217;s at her door. After a brief discussion and an aggressive banging over the kitchen counter, Diane gets on his private jet and, yes, returns to Monte Carlo. I really wish she hadn&#8217;t.</p>\n<p>Wells&#8217; writing is crisp and clear, but the narrative doesn&#8217;t do it justice. The story tries to spice things up with a kinky twist, but, here it too often reads as just another name for rapey roleplay. Yes, Diane enjoys playing hard to get&#8211;she also likes to beat up Marco but her tiny female fists and feet never leave a mark&#8211; and Marco delights in bondage, using belts, and calling her names. Not one but two of their <del>love</del> lust scenes involve literal sh*t but despite riveting discussions about &#8220;<em>stuff on your thing</em>,&#8221; the two are unable to talk about anything of importance.</p>\n<p>The book&#8217;s brevity, reminiscent of the old Harlequin romances, fails to deliver depth. The plot is thinner than the actual novel and predictably dull.</p>\n<p>Despite being set in 1982, the story fails to evoke a genuine &#8217;80s vibe. <strong>Return to Monte Carlo</strong>, despite the occasional reference to Folgers, pantyhose, and Mr. Coffee, feels firmly tethered to our era so much so that, if the novel hadn&#8217;t stated it was set in 1982, I&#8217;d have placed it this century. (It does lack cell phones so there&#8217;s that.)</p>\n<p>Worse, almost all the characters are wildly unlikable. Diane is a terrible heroine: self-absorbed, immature, and profoundly annoying. It&#8217;s challenging to find any redeeming qualities in her character. Especially egregious is her hatred of Sienna, a smart and ambitious woman with a degrees from the London School of Economics. As for Marco, his baffling behaviors make him an asshat rather than an enigma. He&#8217;s one of the heroes who is supposed to be brilliant professionally, but he&#8217;s so clueless about his wife, his family, and his actions that he just comes across as an entitled jerk. I loathed them both.</p>\n<p><strong>Return to Monte Carlo</strong> feels more like an failed experiment gone wrong than a successful foray into retro romance. Wells&#8217; writing remains her strong suit, but the romance fails in its portrayal of characters and their inability to communicate, its lackluster historical setting, and its eye-roll inducing epilogue. Readers considering this 80s tinged love story should take their cue from one of the eras most visible women, Nancy Reagan: <em><a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lQXgVM30mIY\">Just say no</a>. </em></p>\n<p><!-- /wp:paragraph --></p>\n",

The book&#8217;s brevity, reminiscent of the old Harlequin romances, fails to deliver depth. The plot is thinner than the actual novel and predictably dull. Despite being set in 1982, the story fails to evoke a genuine &#8217;80s vibe. Return to Monte Carlo, despite the occasional reference to Folgers, pantyhose, and Mr. Coffee, feels firmly tethered to our era so much so that, if the novel hadn&#8217;t stated it was set in 1982, I&#8217;d have placed it this century. (It does lack cell phones so there&#8217;s that.) Worse, almost all the characters are wildly unlikable. Diane is a terrible heroine: self-absorbed, immature, and profoundly annoying. It&#8217;s challenging to find any redeeming qualities in her character. Especially egregious is her hatred of Sienna, a smart and ambitious woman with a degrees from the London School of Economics. As for Marco, his baffling behaviors make him an asshat rather than an enigma. He&#8217;s one of the heroes who is supposed to be brilliant professionally, but he&#8217;s so clueless about his wife, his family, and his actions that he just comes across as an entitled jerk. I loathed them both. Return to Monte Carlo feels more like an failed experiment gone wrong than a successful foray into retro romance. Wells&#8217; writing remains her strong suit, but the romance fails in its portrayal of characters and their inability to communicate, its lackluster historical setting, and its eye-roll inducing epilogue. Readers considering this 80s tinged love story should take their cue from one of the eras most visible women, Nancy Reagan: Just say no. "
            }

                "html": "<p>Looking for a light, fun read? Karin Slaughter&#8217;s latest addition to the GBI Special Agent Will Trent and Dr. Sara Linton series is not it. This book, the 11th installment in the renowned <a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/review-tag/will-trent-series/\"><em><strong>Will Trent</strong></em> series</a>, is a harrowing journey into the depths of human depravity. <strong>After That Night</strong> compels us to confront the grim realities of sexual violence, the resilience of survivors, and the unwavering determination of those who seek justice. It&#8217;s a powerful novel but not a pleasant one.</p>\n<p>As anyone who has followed the story of Sara Linton, steadfast medical examiner and the love of Will&#8217;s life, knows, fifteen years ago, Sara was brutally raped. <strong>After That Night</strong> begins with the death of a young woman, Dani Cooper, who manages to reveal the horrific assault she suffered before her demise. Sara is determined to secure justice for Dani, but her resolve is tested when she becomes a central figure in a high-stakes civil trial where her testimony holds the key to justice for the accused rapist, Tommy McAllister. As Sara delves into both cases with Will&#8217;s assistance, she uncovers disturbing connections that are nothing short of horrifying.</p>\n<p>Slaughter skillfully weaves a complex tapestry of characters, each grappling with their own inner demons. Special Agent Will Trent, alongside his partner Faith Mitchell, who battles PTSD, embarks on an undercover mission that takes them deep into Atlanta&#8217;s criminal underworld, transcending the boundaries of law enforcement jurisdiction. Their unwavering dedication to the case shines through as they confront not only the criminal elements but also their formidable boss, Amanda Wagner.</p>\n<p>The story&#8217;s strength lies in its unflinching portrayal of the horrors experienced by survivors of sexual assault. Slaughter doesn&#8217;t spare readers from the raw details of these heinous crimes, compelling us to confront the brutality and misogyny that persist in our society. One conversation between Sara and another rape survivor left me in tears. However, it&#8217;s worth noting that some scenes in the novel are so distressing that they may leave readers wanting to forget them. And so many men in this book are so evil&#8211;after a while, I felt a bit numb from reading about their mayhem and misogyny.</p>\n<p><strong>After That Night</strong> is not an easy read. It exposes how the troubling combination of sexual violence, corrupt law enforcement, and a culture prone to doubting women&#8217;s stories allows predators to act with impunity. <span style=\"font-family: var(--global-body-font-family);\">There are moments of grace in the novel. Will and Sara&#8217;s relationship, as they plan their upcoming wedding, is a beacon of hope. Faith Mitchell&#8217;s ongoing efforts to be a better mother are lovely to read. And, as always, Amanda Wagner&#8217;s commitment to justice <em>and</em> getting her own way is awesome.</span></p>\n<p><strong>After That Night</strong> is a gripping and thought-provoking read, but it&#8217;s not for the faint of heart. While I don&#8217;t regret reading it, I can&#8217;t recommend it without warning readers to brace themselves for its almost overwhelming darkness.</p>\n",
                "text": "Looking for a light, fun read? Karin Slaughter&#8217;s latest addition to the GBI Special Agent Will Trent and Dr. Sara Linton series is not it. This book, the 11th installment in the renowned Will Trent series, is a harrowing journey into the depths of human depravity. After That Night compels us to confront the grim realities of sexual violence, the resilience of survivors, and the unwavering determination of those who seek justice. It&#8217;s a powerful novel but not a pleasant one. As anyone who has followed the story of Sara Linton, steadfast medical examiner and the love of Will&#8217;s life, knows, fifteen years ago, Sara was brutally raped. After That Night begins with the death of a young woman, Dani Cooper, who manages to reveal the horrific assault she suffered before her demise. Sara is determined to secure justice for Dani, but her resolve is tested when she becomes a central figure in a high-stakes civil trial where her testimony holds the key to justice for the accused rapist, Tommy McAllister. As Sara delves into both cases with Will&#8217;s assistance, she uncovers disturbing connections that are nothing short of horrifying. Slaughter skillfully weaves a complex tapestry of characters, each grappling with their own inner demons. Special Agent Will Trent, alongside his partner Faith Mitchell, who battles PTSD, embarks on an undercover mission that takes them deep into Atlanta&#8217;s criminal underworld, transcending the boundaries of law enforcement jurisdiction. Their unwavering dedication to the case shines through as they confront not only the criminal elements but also their formidable boss, Amanda Wagner. The story&#8217;s strength lies in its unflinching portrayal of the horrors experienced by survivors of sexual assault. Slaughter doesn&#8217;t spare readers from the raw details of these heinous crimes, compelling us to confront the brutality and misogyny that persist in our society. One conversation between Sara and another rape survivor left me in tears. However, it&#8217;s worth noting that some scenes in the novel are so distressing that they may leave readers wanting to forget them. And so many men in this book are so evil&#8211;after a while, I felt a bit numb from reading about their mayhem and misogyny. After That Night is not an easy read. It exposes how the troubling combination of sexual violence, corrupt law enforcement, and a culture prone to doubting women&#8217;s stories allows predators to act with impunity. There are moments of grace in the novel. Will and Sara&#8217;s relationship, as they plan their upcoming wedding, is a beacon of hope. Faith Mitchell&#8217;s ongoing efforts to be a better mother are lovely to read. And, as always, Amanda Wagner&#8217;s commitment to justice and getting her own way is awesome. After That Night is a gripping and thought-provoking read, but it&#8217;s not for the faint of heart. While I don&#8217;t regret reading it, I can&#8217;t recommend it without warning readers to brace themselves for its almost overwhelming darkness."

                "html": "<p>Alix Harrow&#8217;s latest offering, <strong>Starling House</strong>, transports readers to the heart of Eden, Kentucky, a town wrestling with the ghosts of its past—racism, environmental decay, and the decline of coal mining. Against this backdrop stands Starling House, a foreboding gothic mansion with a sinister reputation. Harrow&#8217;s narrative deftly weaves together elements of a hero&#8217;s journey (times two), supernatural intrigue, and a deft exploration of love and connection.</p>\n<p>At the center of this narrative is Opal McCoy, a young woman whose life is mired in hardship. Working a dispiriting job at Tractor Supply and sharing a rundown hotel room with her gifted younger brother, Jasper, Opal has long abandoned any dreams of a brighter future for herself. Her determination lies in securing a better life for Jasper, whose brilliance shines as a beacon of hope in their otherwise gloomy existence. Yet, Starling House, a place most in town dare not approach, inexplicably draws Opal in her dreams.</p>\n<p>Arthur Starling, the last surviving member of the enigmatic Starling family, is the guardian of the haunted mansion. His solemn duty is to protect the house and its surroundings from the menacing Beasts of the Underland. Harrow artfully paints Arthur as a man isolated by his responsibilities, doomed to follow in the footsteps of his ancestors who perished in the same quest. When Opal disregards his warnings and breaches the gates of Starling House, their lives become inexorably intertwined.</p>\n<p>The chemistry between Opal and Arthur is palpable, an ever-present undercurrent of attraction, mistrust, and vulnerability. Their relationship, marked by secrecy and heated exchanges, unfurls gradually amidst the backdrop of supernatural threats, corporate greed, and the town&#8217;s painful history.</p>\n<p>However, <strong>Starling House</strong> is more than a love story; it is a captivating tale of self-discovery within the eerie confines of the mansion&#8217;s hidden chambers. As Opal navigates the mysteries and enchantments concealed within Starling House, readers are treated to a richly atmospheric experience that blurs the lines between reality and fantasy.</p>\n<p>Harrow&#8217;s writing is both evocative and lucid, immersing readers in the labyrinthine corridors and mystical incantations of the house. Her narrative doesn&#8217;t shy away from tackling weighty themes, such as environmental degradation, corporate avarice, and the darkness within human nature. As Opal and Arthur confront supernatural threats and the formidable Gravely Power, a corporation that holds the town in its grip, the stakes couldn&#8217;t be higher.</p>\n<p><strong>Starling House</strong> is a genre-defying tapestry—a mesmerizing blend of gothic haunted house tale, intricate puzzle, and a love story that pulses with intensity. Harrow&#8217;s storytelling prowess shines through, and readers will find themselves irresistibly drawn into the enchanting world she has crafted.</p>\n<p>Prepare to be spellbound.</p>\n",
                "text": "Alix Harrow&#8217;s latest offering, Starling House, transports readers to the heart of Eden, Kentucky, a town wrestling with the ghosts of its past—racism, environmental decay, and the decline of coal mining. Against this backdrop stands Starling House, a foreboding gothic mansion with a sinister reputation. Harrow&#8217;s narrative deftly weaves together elements of a hero&#8217;s journey (times two), supernatural intrigue, and a deft exploration of love and connection. At the center of this narrative is Opal McCoy, a young woman whose life is mired in hardship. Working a dispiriting job at Tractor Supply and sharing a rundown hotel room with her gifted younger brother, Jasper, Opal has long abandoned any dreams of a brighter future for herself. Her determination lies in securing a better life for Jasper, whose brilliance shines as a beacon of hope in their otherwise gloomy existence. Yet, Starling House, a place most in town dare not approach, inexplicably draws Opal in her dreams. Arthur Starling, the last surviving member of the enigmatic Starling family, is the guardian of the haunted mansion. His solemn duty is to protect the house and its surroundings from the menacing Beasts of the Underland. Harrow artfully paints Arthur as a man isolated by his responsibilities, doomed to follow in the footsteps of his ancestors who perished in the same quest. When Opal disregards his warnings and breaches the gates of Starling House, their lives become inexorably intertwined. The chemistry between Opal and Arthur is palpable, an ever-present undercurrent of attraction, mistrust, and vulnerability. Their relationship, marked by secrecy and heated exchanges, unfurls gradually amidst the backdrop of supernatural threats, corporate greed, and the town&#8217;s painful history. However, Starling House is more than a love story; it is a captivating tale of self-discovery within the eerie confines of the mansion&#8217;s hidden chambers. As Opal navigates the mysteries and enchantments concealed within Starling House, readers are treated to a richly atmospheric experience that blurs the lines between reality and fantasy. Harrow&#8217;s writing is both evocative and lucid, immersing readers in the labyrinthine corridors and mystical incantations of the house. Her narrative doesn&#8217;t shy away from tackling weighty themes, such as environmental degradation, corporate avarice, and the darkness within human nature. As Opal and Arthur confront supernatural threats and the formidable Gravely Power, a corporation that holds the town in its grip, the stakes couldn&#8217;t be higher. Starling House is a genre-defying tapestry—a mesmerizing blend of gothic haunted house tale, intricate puzzle, and a love story that pulses with intensity. Harrow&#8217;s storytelling prowess shines through, and readers will find themselves irresistibly drawn into the enchanting world she has crafted. Prepare to be spellbound."

            "content": {
                "html": "<p>Set in the crucible of Spring 2020, as the pandemic&#8217;s grip tightened, Ann Patchett&#8217;s <strong>Tom Lake</strong> is a marvel. The narrative takes place over a few weeks on a family farm&#8211;echoes of Chekhov&#8217;s cherry orchard&#8211;in Michigan, where Lara Kenison, her husband, and their three adult daughters labor amidst the lockdown&#8217;s restraint. As the book begins, Lara is telling the story of the summer of her twenty-fourth year, a season she spent acting in summer theater and falling in love with famed actor Peter Duke.</p>\n<p>Like all parental stories about their youth, the tale Lara tells is curated for her children, each of whom brings their own perspectives and life experiences to the story. Emily, the oldest, was terrifyingly obsessed with Duke as a wildly difficult teen. She now is about to marry her childhood love from the farm next door and aspires to uphold the orchard&#8217;s legacy. The youngest, Nell, an actress whom the pandemic has sidelined, yearns for the far-off footlights. Middle child Maisie, in vet school, spends the few hours she spends away from the cherry trees mending creatures and their wounds. Orbiting these four women is Joe, Lara&#8217;s husband, an lovely man who treasures Lara, his daughters, and the farm with equal intensity.</p>\n<p>The time Lara spent in Tom Lake, Michigan where she plays both Emily in Thornton Wilder&#8217;s <em>Our Town</em> and May in Sam Shepard&#8217;s <em>Fool for Love</em>, shapes her life in ways overt&#8211;these her daughters <em>think</em> they already know&#8211;and subtle. One of the many pleasures of this novel are the moments where Lara breaks the wall between the narrator she is as she spins out the past to her daughters and, instead, speaks to the reader. Lara reveals the hidden pages of her past, unraveled with a candor that lays bare the truth of those few months. Through her lens, we peer into the wings of community theater, her voyage from childhood dreams to the slings and arrows of an adult actor&#8217;s reality. Over 318 pages, we see how the loves, losses, disappointments, and insights she experienced that summer created the content and insightful woman she has become.</p>\n<p>Patchett&#8217;s prose is measured, quiet, and powerful. Love and family, ambition and the crossroads they conspire to create, motherhood and the labyrinth of the mind—all are meticulously intertwined. By the end, the reader is rewarded with a quiet harmony, a resolution that unfurls with remarkable grace.</p>\n<p><strong>Tom Lake</strong> gives us a  slow and purposeful unveiling of lives lived within the embrace of both the mundane and the transcendent. Serious topics&#8211;the terror of global warming, the fragile economics of farming, the challenges of parenting&#8211;are tucked into lives full of meaning, even joy. I loved almost every moment of this book, so caught up was I in Lara&#8217;s lives, both as a wild twenty-four year old actress and as a fifty-seven year old woman sure of the choices she&#8217;s made and the life she&#8217;s created.</p>\n<p>At one point, Lara tells her girls,</p>\n<blockquote><p>There is no explaining this simple truth about life: you will forget much of it. The painful things you were certain you’d never be able to let go? Now you’re not entirely sure when they happened, while the thrilling parts, the heart-stopping joys, splintered and scattered and became something else. Memories are then replaced by different joys and larger sorrows, and unbelievably, those things get knocked aside as well.</p></blockquote>\n<p>In this poignant novel, we are fortunate that this is not true. Lara does indeed remember the past and oh what a joy it is to read.</p>\n",
                "text": "Set in the crucible of Spring 2020, as the pandemic&#8217;s grip tightened, Ann Patchett&#8217;s Tom Lake is a marvel. The narrative takes place over a few weeks on a family farm&#8211;echoes of Chekhov&#8217;s cherry orchard&#8211;in Michigan, where Lara Kenison, her husband, and their three adult daughters labor amidst the lockdown&#8217;s restraint. As the book begins, Lara is telling the story of the summer of her twenty-fourth year, a season she spent acting in summer theater and falling in love with famed actor Peter Duke. Like all parental stories about their youth, the tale Lara tells is curated for her children, each of whom brings their own perspectives and life experiences to the story. Emily, the oldest, was terrifyingly obsessed with Duke as a wildly difficult teen. She now is about to marry her childhood love from the farm next door and aspires to uphold the orchard&#8217;s legacy. The youngest, Nell, an actress whom the pandemic has sidelined, yearns for the far-off footlights. Middle child Maisie, in vet school, spends the few hours she spends away from the cherry trees mending creatures and their wounds. Orbiting these four women is Joe, Lara&#8217;s husband, an lovely man who treasures Lara, his daughters, and the farm with equal intensity. The time Lara spent in Tom Lake, Michigan where she plays both Emily in Thornton Wilder&#8217;s Our Town and May in Sam Shepard&#8217;s Fool for Love, shapes her life in ways overt&#8211;these her daughters think they already know&#8211;and subtle. One of the many pleasures of this novel are the moments where Lara breaks the wall between the narrator she is as she spins out the past to her daughters and, instead, speaks to the reader. Lara reveals the hidden pages of her past, unraveled with a candor that lays bare the truth of those few months. Through her lens, we peer into the wings of community theater, her voyage from childhood dreams to the slings and arrows of an adult actor&#8217;s reality. Over 318 pages, we see how the loves, losses, disappointments, and insights she experienced that summer created the content and insightful woman she has become. Patchett&#8217;s prose is measured, quiet, and powerful. Love and family, ambition and the crossroads they conspire to create, motherhood and the labyrinth of the mind—all are meticulously intertwined. By the end, the reader is rewarded with a quiet harmony, a resolution that unfurls with remarkable grace. Tom Lake gives us a  slow and purposeful unveiling of lives lived within the embrace of both the mundane and the transcendent. Serious topics&#8211;the terror of global warming, the fragile economics of farming, the challenges of parenting&#8211;are tucked into lives full of meaning, even joy. I loved almost every moment of this book, so caught up was I in Lara&#8217;s lives, both as a wild twenty-four year old actress and as a fifty-seven year old woman sure of the choices she&#8217;s made and the life she&#8217;s created. At one point, Lara tells her girls, There is no explaining this simple truth about life: you will forget much of it. The painful things you were certain you’d never be able to let go? Now you’re not entirely sure when they happened, while the thrilling parts, the heart-stopping joys, splintered and scattered and became something else. Memories are then replaced by different joys and larger sorrows, and unbelievably, those things get knocked aside as well. In this poignant novel, we are fortunate that this is not true. Lara does indeed remember the past and oh what a joy it is to read."

                "text": "The Rebel King is the second in Maxwell&#8217;s Deviant Kings series and, like the first, it features a fae king with a penchant for wink-wink kink. Its hero, Tiernan Verran, is the current King of the Dark Fae who rule Las Vegas. Like many a second son, Tiernan never planned on being a monarch but due to the events in the better first entry, The Dark King, his older brother resigned, leaving Tiernan stuck with the job. There are many things he dislikes about being King including the crimp it&#8217;s put in his regular hook-ups with Fiona, a half-fae maid who works in the Verran hotel Nightfall. (If you are looking for a thoughtful exploration of power dynamics in a workplace romance, don&#8217;t read this book.) Because, you see, Tiernan has bodyguards and cameras following him at all times and there&#8217;s just no privacy. Except, of course, in the BDSM dungeon, a place Fiona would dearly love to visit but Tiernan refuses to take her to. Why? you ask. Because Tiernan once lost control with a sub there and thus he can no longer trust himself to whip those he bones into orgiastic frenzies. It&#8217;s just so hard to be king. But king Tiernan is and he has a lot on his plate. There&#8217;s Edevane, the evil king of the Day Court who is trying to kill him and destroy the Dark Fae, the super annoying sexy vampire Dmitri “D’yavol” Romanov whom Tiernan needs to help him defeat the Day Court, his Tuesdays with Morrie friendship with Robert, an 80 year old human with whom Tiernan plays chess, not to mention the demands of running his vast and wildly profitable Las Vegan empire. And then, SO STRESSFUL, it turns out that the best way to disarm the bad guys is for Fiona to go undercover as a stripper at a club where fae women keep going missing. I mean, if he wasn&#8217;t such a stud, I can&#8217;t imagine how he&#8217;d cope. He figures it out, though. For starters, he comes to his senses and does indeed take his bae to the dungeon (among other places) where he gives Fiona the sexcapades of her dreams. He whips her, she moans and comes and comes&#8211;no one is hurt in these scenes&#8211;and, over the course of the novel, the two discover&#8230; wait for it&#8230; they are IN LOVE. What you should fret over is how predictable and insubstantial this book is. Little in it will surprise you nor will it make you care about its outcomes. Which, really, is a gift because this is the middle book in the series and it ends on somewhat of a cliffhanger. You may have noticed I&#8217;ve not said much about Fiona. That&#8217;s because she&#8217;s not very interesting. She has a DESTINY&#8211;I&#8217;ve kinda forgotten what it is&#8211;she&#8217;s very nice, she has red hair everywhere&#8211;I&#8217;d add a rugs and drapes joke here but that would be wrong&#8211;and she digs boning then cuddling her man king. Nuff said. I admit I&#8217;m a little salty about this book&#8211;I really enjoyed The Dark King and had high hopes for this one. And it&#8217;s not all bad&#8211;Maxwell writes banter well and she has a lovely, snarky sense of humor. The sex scenes, while not my jam, are hot if somewhat unbelievably consequence-free. Fae romance is having a serious moment and this one isn&#8217;t the worst I&#8217;ve read. It&#8217;s fine, kinda dumb, but fine. You could do worse. Or you could do better and read some Holly Black.
