I haven&#8217;t read <strong>The Reluctant Countess</strong>. If I had, I wouldn&#8217;t have been so bothered that in this book, the hero, Silvester, The Duke of Huntington, is determined to wed a gorgeous woman named Yasmine. Yasmin is <strong>not</strong> the heroine of <strong>this</strong> story&#8211;wallflower Stella is. Thus, the first half of this book in which Silvester schemes and pines for Yasmin were confusing and, given how fabulous Stella is, did not reflect well on said Duke.</p>\n<p>I&#8217;m glad I sallied on for the second half of the book is a gem, just like Stella. (She, by the way, looks nothing like the slim, glasses-free woman on the cover.)</p>\n<p>Stella is twenty, nearing the end of her first season, redheaded, bosomy, wears glasses, and crackingly smart. So, of course, no one in the ton wants to marry her other than the fortune hunters who are attracted to her very large dowry. Stella&#8217;s not really marriage is any great prize anyway. She&#8217;d rather, she tells her stuffy aunt and guardian,<em>“Use my dowry to live in the country. Anywhere with a bookstore nearby.” </em></p>\n<p>There is <strong>one</strong> man she&#8217;d like to, well not necessarily marry&#8211;if she must marry, she plans to marry the most knowledgeable man she can find&#8211;but, ah, lick.</p>\n<blockquote>\n<p class=\"calibre12\">The Duke of Huntington was the most eligible man in England, possessed of a large estate, decent stature, and all his teeth. Ladies’ eyes followed him everywhere.</p>\n<p class=\"calibre12\">But she doubted that other debutantes had explicit daydreams about how they’d like to . . . to lick him. Do breathless, depraved things that Stella couldn’t quite envision.</p>\n<p class=\"calibre12\">Late at night, she spun stories under the sheets, during which he did things that she was certain no other lady had even imagined.</p>\n</blockquote>\n<p>But the Duke, Silvester, is openly courting the most beautiful woman in the ton, Yasmin Régnier.</p>\n<blockquote>\n<p class=\"calibre12\">&#8230; Silvester intended to marry Yasmin. She had charm, hair the color of old ducats, a naughty giggle . . . More than that, he and Yasmin were friends, never mind the fact that he’d love to bed her.</p>\n<p class=\"calibre12\">He felt the pull of her in his bones, deep in his gut.</p>\n<p class=\"calibre12\">Perhaps even in his heart.</p>\n</blockquote>\n<p>Now of course there are <em><strong>reasons</strong></em> he feels this way. His own parents were&#8211;his marvelous mother still is&#8211;so eccentric they were socially shunned. (Not that they cared&#8211;they were too busy inventing better railway steam engines, together!) Silvester is all that is revered in society and Yasmin seems to him&#8211;and his cock&#8211;the perfect wife.</p>\n<p>Yasmin&#8211;in this book&#8211;seems rather shallow, so it doesn&#8217;t surprise the reader that despite lusting after Yasmin and planning their future, Silvester really enjoys matching wits with Stella. And, for the first half of the book, that&#8217;s pretty much all that happens. Stella has the hots for Silvester. Silvester has the hots for Yasmin. And Yasmin clearly has the hots for Giles Renwick, Earl of Lilford whom, I came to realize, she married in the first book. It didn&#8217;t work for me and had James not so excelled at this book&#8217;s banter&#8211;I haven&#8217;t laughed at a James book this much since <strong><a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/book-review/three-weeks-with-lady-x/\">Three Weeks with Lady X</a>&#8211;</strong>-I might have put the novel down.</p>\n<p>Fortunately, Silvester gets his head out of his ass and realizes that not only is Yasmin in love with one of his oldest friends, he, Silvester, is utterly entranced by Stella. But Stella, after over a hundred pages of watching Silvester pursue Yasmin, doesn&#8217;t believe he cares for her. (The title is misleading&#8211;she really does always want <strong>that</strong> Duke&#8211;it&#8217;s just she thinks he&#8217;s not for her.) And honestly, I was sort of with her.</p>\n<p>Stella is a wonderful woman, brilliant, strong-willed, resilient; someone who doesn&#8217;t want to compromise who she is for anyone. In fact, this is one of those books that it&#8217;s a bit hard to buy that no one wanted Stella. She&#8217;s a classic James heroine&#8211;she could be the auburn twin of Mia, the heroine of <a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/book-review/four-nights-with-the-duke/\"><strong>Four Nights With the Duke</strong></a>, whom I adore. She&#8217;s curvy, very funny, and has a heart of gold. (Her true love, for much of the novel, is her rescued kitten Specs who steals every scene she&#8217;s in.) Silvester is damn lucky she waited for him to come to his senses.</p>\n<p>Despite this pitfall, ultimately I very much enjoyed Silvester and Stella&#8217;s story. James masterfully depicts Silvester&#8217;s confusion and frustration and I found myself forgiving him for his earlier idiocy. The tenor of the book is airy, charming, and wonderfully sly. The love scenes are both sweet and very very dirty (for James). This is a book with great affection for its characters, especially its women. Stella&#8217;s aunt and Silvester&#8217;s mother each are given deep backstories of their own and both stories are moving and, in ways that seem believable, empowering.</p>\n<p>There&#8217;s another author&#8217;s note in the book, this time at the end. In it James writes:</p>\n<blockquote>\n<p class=\"calibre11 pcalibre2\">I grew up in a farmhouse full of books, the oldest child of two eccentric, creative parents: my father was a poet and my mother a short story writer. A couple of miles away, down a few dirt roads, was a small Minnesota town . . . where I never fit in. I was too weird, too addicted to reading, too plump. Like Stella, I was no good at disguising who I am. Thankfully, unlike Regency England, no girl is forced to attend the junior prom. I stayed home and catalogued my romances, practicing skills that would make me an English professor—and a romance writer&#8230;.</p>\n<p class=\"calibre12\">It took me a long time to shake my experiences in middle school. Stella was shamed for her freckles, her reading, and her girth. Silvester created a suit of armor to offset his boyhood shame. Luckily, Silvester and Stella find their way together to a different way of being in the world.</p>\n<p class=\"calibre12\">So this book is dedicated to my husband, Alessandro.</p>\n<p class=\"calibre12\">When he fell in love with me, I felt like the most beautiful, intelligent, and desirable woman in the world. Love isn’t about reality, but perception, and I’m so grateful to have spent half my life looking through his eyes.</p>\n</blockquote>\n<p>Sigh&#8230; I found that lovely, just like this book (after I got through the first half!)</p>\n<p>So, yes, read this book. Just read <strong>The Reluctant Countess</strong> first.</p>\n<p>&nbsp;</p>\n",
                "text": "Not That Duke begins with this author&#8217;s note: There’s no need to have read The Reluctant Countess, but if you have, you’ll notice that Part 1 of Not That Duke takes place in the same time frame. This is not true. I haven&#8217;t read The Reluctant Countess. If I had, I wouldn&#8217;t have been so bothered that in this book, the hero, Silvester, The Duke of Huntington, is determined to wed a gorgeous woman named Yasmine. Yasmin is not the heroine of this story&#8211;wallflower Stella is. Thus, the first half of this book in which Silvester schemes and pines for Yasmin were confusing and, given how fabulous Stella is, did not reflect well on said Duke. I&#8217;m glad I sallied on for the second half of the book is a gem, just like Stella. (She, by the way, looks nothing like the slim, glasses-free woman on the cover.) Stella is twenty, nearing the end of her first season, redheaded, bosomy, wears glasses, and crackingly smart. So, of course, no one in the ton wants to marry her other than the fortune hunters who are attracted to her very large dowry. Stella&#8217;s not really marriage is any great prize anyway. She&#8217;d rather, she tells her stuffy aunt and guardian,“Use my dowry to live in the country. Anywhere with a bookstore nearby.”  There is one man she&#8217;d like to, well not necessarily marry&#8211;if she must marry, she plans to marry the most knowledgeable man she can find&#8211;but, ah, lick. The Duke of Huntington was the most eligible man in England, possessed of a large estate, decent stature, and all his teeth. Ladies’ eyes followed him everywhere. But she doubted that other debutantes had explicit daydreams about how they’d like to . . . to lick him. Do breathless, depraved things that Stella couldn’t quite envision. Late at night, she spun stories under the sheets, during which he did things that she was certain no other lady had even imagined. But the Duke, Silvester, is openly courting the most beautiful woman in the ton, Yasmin Régnier. &#8230; Silvester intended to marry Yasmin. She had charm, hair the color of old ducats, a naughty giggle . . . More than that, he and Yasmin were friends, never mind the fact that he’d love to bed her. He felt the pull of her in his bones, deep in his gut. Perhaps even in his heart. Now of course there are reasons he feels this way. His own parents were&#8211;his marvelous mother still is&#8211;so eccentric they were socially shunned. (Not that they cared&#8211;they were too busy inventing better railway steam engines, together!) Silvester is all that is revered in society and Yasmin seems to him&#8211;and his cock&#8211;the perfect wife. Yasmin&#8211;in this book&#8211;seems rather shallow, so it doesn&#8217;t surprise the reader that despite lusting after Yasmin and planning their future, Silvester really enjoys matching wits with Stella. And, for the first half of the book, that&#8217;s pretty much all that happens. Stella has the hots for Silvester. Silvester has the hots for Yasmin. And Yasmin clearly has the hots for Giles Renwick, Earl of Lilford whom, I came to realize, she married in the first book. It didn&#8217;t work for me and had James not so excelled at this book&#8217;s banter&#8211;I haven&#8217;t laughed at a James book this much since Three Weeks with Lady X&#8211;-I might have put the novel down. Fortunately, Silvester gets his head out of his ass and realizes that not only is Yasmin in love with one of his oldest friends, he, Silvester, is utterly entranced by Stella. But Stella, after over a hundred pages of watching Silvester pursue Yasmin, doesn&#8217;t believe he cares for her. (The title is misleading&#8211;she really does always want that Duke&#8211;it&#8217;s just she thinks he&#8217;s not for her.) And honestly, I was sort of with her. Stella is a wonderful woman, brilliant, strong-willed, resilient; someone who doesn&#8217;t want to compromise who she is for anyone. In fact, this is one of those books that it&#8217;s a bit hard to buy that no one wanted Stella. She&#8217;s a classic James heroine&#8211;she could be the auburn twin of Mia, the heroine of Four Nights With the Duke, whom I adore. She&#8217;s curvy, very funny, and has a heart of gold. (Her true love, for much of the novel, is her rescued kitten Specs who steals every scene she&#8217;s in.) Silvester is damn lucky she waited for him to come to his senses. Despite this pitfall, ultimately I very much enjoyed Silvester and Stella&#8217;s story. James masterfully depicts Silvester&#8217;s confusion and frustration and I found myself forgiving him for his earlier idiocy. The tenor of the book is airy, charming, and wonderfully sly. The love scenes are both sweet and very very dirty (for James). This is a book with great affection for its characters, especially its women. Stella&#8217;s aunt and Silvester&#8217;s mother each are given deep backstories of their own and both stories are moving and, in ways that seem believable, empowering. There&#8217;s another author&#8217;s note in the book, this time at the end. In it James writes: I grew up in a farmhouse full of books, the oldest child of two eccentric, creative parents: my father was a poet and my mother a short story writer. A couple of miles away, down a few dirt roads, was a small Minnesota town . . . where I never fit in. I was too weird, too addicted to reading, too plump. Like Stella, I was no good at disguising who I am. Thankfully, unlike Regency England, no girl is forced to attend the junior prom. I stayed home and catalogued my romances, practicing skills that would make me an English professor—and a romance writer&#8230;. It took me a long time to shake my experiences in middle school. Stella was shamed for her freckles, her reading, and her girth. Silvester created a suit of armor to offset his boyhood shame. Luckily, Silvester and Stella find their way together to a different way of being in the world. So this book is dedicated to my husband, Alessandro. When he fell in love with me, I felt like the most beautiful, intelligent, and desirable woman in the world. Love isn’t about reality, but perception, and I’m so grateful to have spent half my life looking through his eyes. Sigh&#8230; I found that lovely, just like this book (after I got through the first half!) So, yes, read this book. Just read The Reluctant Countess first. &nbsp;"

                "html": "<p>Caroline Linden is one of my favorite historical romance novelists. Her <em><strong>Scandalous</strong></em> series is one of my favorites in the genre&#8211;<a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/book-review/love-and-other-scandals-by-caroline-linden/\"><strong>Love and Other Scandals</strong></a> is flat out fabulous&#8211;and I&#8217;ve enjoyed her most recent series, <a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/review-tag/the-wagers-of-sin-series/\"><strong><em>The Wagers of Sin</em></strong></a>. <strong>Fortune Favors the Viscount</strong> is the fourth and final novel and gets a pleaseed DIK from me.</p>\n<p>All four books feature wagers made in the infamous Vega Club and here, it&#8217;s time for its owner, Nick Dashwood, to meet his match. And he does, in the splendid Emilia Greene. When we meet Emilia, it&#8217;s early morning and she is swigging brandy from a flask while staring through a hired hackney&#8217;s grimy windows at the Vega Club. Emilia is not the sort who drinks brandy or takes dangerous hackney rides but needs must and Emilia has a life to save and she needs Nick Dashwood to do so. So, carrying a forged note, she barges in and demands to speak to the proprietor.</p>\n<p>Nick is decidedly uninterested in whatever this young woman wants from him. It&#8217;s time for him to go home and get some sleep and he rarely hears a proposition worth taking. However, what Miss Greene wants from him genuinely shocks him. For, as she explains, due to a preponderance of daughters, the family line of the Sidneys has left him, the son of a sea captain, the next Viscount Sydenham. Emilia wants him to claim the title.</p>\n<p>Nick isn&#8217;t interested. His impression of peers is a low one and he likes his life the way it is. He&#8217;s well aware that the lords who gamble, drink, and gossip in his establishment would not be thrilled to see him in the halls of Westminster. But Emilia is determined. The life of Lucy Sidney, the ten year old daughter of the last Viscount, depends on it. Emilia is Lucy&#8217;s governess and not only are their funds almost gone, the man whom Lucy&#8217;s father appointed to be her guardian is beyond unfit. Emilia believes that if Nick becomes the Viscount, not only will he provide for Lucy financially, he will be able to somehow keep Lucy from the care of an evil man.</p>\n<p>As the title of the series suggests, Nick finds himself agreeing to a wager. The terms? Emilia bets Nick she can prove his claim to the title. Nick agrees although he tells her if she wins, he&#8217;ll require a favor and no, it&#8217;s not that kind. If she loses, Emilia must burn every bit of evidence she&#8217;s put together and Nick will walk away&#8211;he does agree that, in that case, he&#8217;ll settle five thousand pounds on Lucy. Emboldened by first a glass of wine and then one of Nick&#8217;s best brandy, Emilia wagers&#8230; and wins.</p>\n<p>Emilia is the best. Like Nick, she also lives on the edges of the ton&#8211;she walked away from a betrothal her iffy father arranged for her to one of his friends and has since established herself as a successful governess. She adores Lucy, charms all she meets, wishes she had prettier dresses, and knows and values herself. Since her horrible engagement, she&#8217;s stayed away from men, but, from the moment she sees Nick, he calls to her. And why not? He too is the bomb. Even better, he is just as dizzied by her as she is by him. It&#8217;s lovely to read a book where both leads fall fast and treat each other with respect. Their interactions are always charged&#8211;you can just <em>feel</em> the pull between them&#8211;and both, at all times, act with grace. Theirs is a scrumptious romance.</p>\n<p>The supporting characters are strong as well. Lucy&#8217;s past is one of trauma&#8211;her father was utter garbage&#8211;and her fears are stark and heart-breaking. Nick&#8217;s sister, Charlotte, is a vibrant fifteen year old and it&#8217;s fun to watch Nick, terrified he&#8217;ll muck it up, try to shepherd Charlotte to womanhood. Nick&#8217;s employees add humor to the narrative and the villain well deserves his ultimate fate.</p>\n<p>Does Nick take the title? Will Lucy find a secure home? I suspect you know the answers to these questions. And that&#8217;s fine. Because <strong>Fortune Favors the Viscount</strong> is a traditional love story, a very very good love story. So, if you&#8217;re looking for a smart, sexy historical romance, look no further. Fortune favors the reader in Linden&#8217;s latest, excellent read.</p>\n",

                "html": "<p><strong>Rebel at Heart</strong> is my first Zoe York book&#8211;I can see why other AAR reviewers have so enjoyed her work. Very sexy, nicely funny, and with leads you&#8217;d like to hang out with, this book is a smokin&#8217; good time.</p>\n<p>Josh Kincaid is minding his own damn business when, due to a social media moment that has very little to actually do with him, someone comments &#8220;<em>He&#8217;s married to the Fischer Racing heiress, you know.</em>&#8221; Josh couldn&#8217;t give a sh*t about TikTok but this comment throws him. Hardly anyone knows that, three years ago, for two glorious weeks, he was indeed married to Monica Fischer but that marriage was annulled and he&#8217;s never spoken to her again.</p>\n<p>Said TikTok gossip has also found its way to the gossip papers where it catches the eye of Monica&#8217;s best friend who alerts Monica. Monica is at first pissed&#8211;as an heiress she loathes being in news&#8211;but then, as she thinks about it, she&#8217;s baffled. That marriage was annulled so why can reporters find any records of it being extant?</p>\n<p>Less than one week later, Monica&#8217;s on a private plane heading to Pine Harbour, the tiny Canadian town where Josh and his brothers&#8211;all of whom have had their own love stories in this series&#8211;all live. Her plan: tell Josh she&#8217;s sorry about the annulment or lack thereof, explain why she left him three years ago, &#8220;make it right&#8221; between them, and then head off to Italy for her best friend&#8217;s wedding.</p>\n<p>This, however, is not what happens.</p>\n<p>You see, three years ago, Monica, 21, was determined to prove herself in the world of racing so that one day she could take over her family&#8217;s car racing empire. At one of her father&#8217;s California garages, she sees Josh, an ambitious 30-year-old mechanic&#8211;he dreams of running his own high-end car refurbishment garage. She asks him to teach her about racing, and after they flirt for a while, even as Josh knows it&#8217;s a <em>very bad idea</em> to do anything with the big boss&#8217;s daughter, that night he takes her for a very fast ride. The evening ends on an overlook under the stars and before you can say <em>start your engines</em>, the two are exchanging life changing orgasms in the back of Josh&#8217;s &#8217;69 Gran Torino.</p>\n<p>Their insta-sex turns into insta-love which culminates in a spontaneous Vegas wedding just two weeks after their first tryst. But Monica suddenly requests an annulment, leaving their both their hearts in shambles. Why did she do this? Josh bets it&#8217;s just because she was a spoiled rich girl. The reader is sure her evil father is to blame but whatever the reason, it&#8217;s left Josh a wreck.</p>\n<p>Thus, when Monica ventures to Pine Harbour, Josh tells her to get lost. And she tries to but there&#8217;s a snow storm, a non-life threatening car accident, and the next thing you know the two are forced to share Josh&#8217;s small apartment for three days. Guess what happens next?</p>\n<p>Look, this plot may not break new ground, but York makes it bunches of fun to read. The pages practically sizzle with the scorching chemistry between Josh and Monica, both of whom are impossible not to cheer for. And once Josh&#8217;s family&#8211;they&#8217;re all pretty great&#8211;decide to get involved, the book becomes funny as well as smokin&#8217; hot.</p>\n<p><strong>Rebel at Heart</strong> is thoroughly entertaining and hits all the right notes. Josh and Monica both have to find their way to both romantic and professional happiness and they do so in ways that feel appropriate to the plot. The ending is satisfying (although there&#8217;s an auction I could have done without) and lets Josh and Monica each wield the power they have earned. I very much enjoyed my time in Pine Harbour and look forward to reading other Kincaid love stories! (Here&#8217;s hoping there&#8217;s at least a novella about Bianca, Monica&#8217;s mom, and the time she came to Pine Harbour&#8230;..)</p>\n",
                "text": "Rebel at Heart is my first Zoe York book&#8211;I can see why other AAR reviewers have so enjoyed her work. Very sexy, nicely funny, and with leads you&#8217;d like to hang out with, this book is a smokin&#8217; good time. Monica is at first pissed&#8211;as an heiress she loathes being in news&#8211;but then, as she thinks about it, she&#8217;s baffled. That marriage was annulled so why can reporters find any records of it being extant? Less than one week later, Monica&#8217;s on a private plane heading to Pine Harbour, the tiny Canadian town where Josh and his brothers&#8211;all of whom have had their own love stories in this series&#8211;all live. Her plan: tell Josh she&#8217;s sorry about the annulment or lack thereof, explain why she left him three years ago, &#8220;make it right&#8221; between them, and then head off to Italy for her best friend&#8217;s wedding. I very much enjoyed my time in Pine Harbour and look forward to reading other Kincaid love stories!                 "html": "<p>In <strong>Good As Gold</strong>, Sarina Bowen gives us another couple in her <strong><em>True North</em></strong>&#8216;s small town Vermont.</p>\n<p>Matteo Rossi and Lelia Giltmaker have loved each other since they were teens but because they have the communication skills of emotionally stunted fourteen-year-olds, they&#8217;ve never told each other how they feel. They are now thirty-five and thirty-six. So naturally they decide the best way to interact is to try and make a baby together while still never confessing their unrequited love. Um&#8230; nope.</p>\n<p>The novel cuts back and forth between their teenage years and the present. In the past, Lelia, Matteo, and Rory all hung out, snowboarded, and were, we are supposed to believe, inseparable. From the get go, it&#8217;s clear Matteo and Lelia have feelings for each other and that Rory is an ass. Despite that, in the present, Matteo has been AWOL for the past fifteen years&#8211;I&#8217;m still not clear why he never came home to see his family&#8211;and Lelia and Rory just recently got divorced because of the whole Rory is an ass thing.</p>\n<p>Matteo, however, has finally returned to town for the wedding of one of his many siblings. But, though he&#8217;s built a very successful heli-ski business in Aspen, Matteo feels he&#8217;s a mess because he didn&#8217;t manage to prevent his best friend and business partner, Sean, from dying in a snowboarding accident the previous year. So, even though he&#8217;s STILL in love with Lelia and perhaps hasn&#8217;t had a girlfriend ever due to his pining (his romantic past is never discussed), he still can&#8217;t tell her how he feels because&#8230; I wasn&#8217;t really sure. When he was younger, his excuse was he needed to make the big bucks so he could &#8220;<em>become the kind of guy who can afford gold jewelry for the golden girl. That’s when he’ll be able to tell her how he feels. But not until then.</em>&#8221; Now, I guess it&#8217;s because he isn&#8217;t a god and thus able to prevent those he loves from dying. (Sean, however, still shows up in Matteo&#8217;s dreams and gives him helpful pithy advice like <em>go home</em> and <em>make dinner reservations for my daughter&#8217;s birthday because Aspen gets really booked up in tourist season</em>.)</p>\n<p>For her part, Lelia has always had the hots for Matteo, but he left town and so she married Rory, whom she knew was an ass. Her excuse? &#8220;<em>I think I’d fed off his need. He made me feel powerful—like my opinion mattered. Maybe that’s why I put up with him for twelve wasted years</em>.&#8221; Among other things, staying married to Rotten Rory deprived her of her best baby-making years so now she&#8217;s looking at the eye-poppingly expensive path of medical artificial insemination.</p>\n<p>It only takes a week or so and some serious booze for Lelia to suggest to Matteo that he be her baby daddy. So, after making sure no one expects anything more from him than a clean bill of health and a willingness to do the deed&#8211;he&#8217;s not good enough to be a real dad&#8211;he agrees. This means they only bone one night a month&#8211;<a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=k4mGrNGuJTM\">every sperm is sacred</a>. Sex between them is&#8211;shocker!&#8211;the best they&#8217;ve ever had and they just love hanging out together. But though Matteo ends up staying the summer working at his brother&#8217;s wildly successful bar and at Lelia&#8217;s dad&#8217;s wildly successful beer truck and, in their heads, they fall hard for one another, they remain mum on how they truly feel.</p>\n<p>Because the two are unable to grasp the most basic concept of honest communication, their actions and decisions end up feeling contrived and implausible. The emotional stakes never truly resonate, and the story feels superficial. Which is a shame because Bowen can be a terrific writer.</p>\n<p>I&#8217;ve enjoyed books in this series&#8211;my favorite is <a href=\"https://amzn.to/3CczbRR\"><strong>Steadfast</strong></a>&#8211;and in the<em><strong> Ivy Years</strong></em>, and in her <a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/book-review/brooklynaire-by-sarina-bowen/\"><strong><em>Brooklyn</em></strong></a> series. Here, there are flashes of her brilliance. In particular, she writes families remarkably well. Matteo and his siblings, Lelia and her brother and dad, and especially the parenting of Zara, the heroine of <a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/book-review/bountiful-by-sarina-bowen/\"><strong>Bountiful</strong></a>, all are written with humor and wisdom. When Zara casually says to Lelia, who&#8217;s come in to get coffee from Zara&#8217;s wildly successful coffee shop, &#8220;<em>You want a sassy four-year-old, too?&#8221; she says, tapping on the register screen. &#8220;Cute but argues with everything I say. Fifty percent off today.&#8221;, </em>it made me laugh and nod my head. The sparkle Bowen&#8217;s wit lends the book, however, is not enough to save the frustrating plot.</p>\n<p>Furthermore, at a key point in the novel, Lelia makes an unforgivable choice that Bowen glosses right over. Had I been Matteo, I&#8217;d have been angry and hurt but he&#8217;s super chill because he&#8217;s crazy about her&#8211;a fact he STILL hasn&#8217;t told her.</p>\n<div class=\"su-spoiler su-spoiler-style-fancy su-spoiler-icon-plus su-spoiler-closed\" data-scroll-offset=\"0\" data-anchor-in-url=\"no\"><div class=\"su-spoiler-title\" tabindex=\"0\" role=\"button\"><span class=\"su-spoiler-icon\"></span>Spoiler</div><div class=\"su-spoiler-content su-u-clearfix su-u-trim\">Lelia does, after several months, get pregnant. At this point, Matteo has returned to Aspen and SHE DOESN&#8217;T TELL HIM. Her excuse? She googled the stats on miscarriage rates for pregnancies at thirty-five. </div></div>\n<p>Bowen does, however, give readers a sumptuous epilogue. I loved the conclusion of this book so hard&#8211;it&#8217;s everything a romance reader could want in a finale. I give it a ten out of ten.</p>\n<p>So, is <strong>Good As Gold</strong> worth reading? Sure, as long as you don&#8217;t mind thirty-five-year-olds acting like idiots for far too long. The sex is hot, the humor is smart, and it ends well. There are worse ways to spend a few hours of your life than laughing at the Rossi family texts, fanning yourself as Matteo and Lelia have a grand time trying to make a zygote, and finishing a book where the final chapter sings. I couldn&#8217;t decide between a C+ and a B- but I went with the latter. Those who like Bowen&#8217;s writing will love this book and so will those who aren&#8217;t as irked by adults acting like adolescents as I am.</p>\n",
                "text": "In Good As Gold, Sarina Bowen gives us another couple in her True North&#8216;s small town Vermont. Matteo Rossi and Lelia Giltmaker have loved each other since they were teens but because they have the communication skills of emotionally stunted fourteen-year-olds, they&#8217;ve never told each other how they feel. They are now thirty-five and thirty-six. So naturally they decide the best way to interact is to try and make a baby together while still never confessing their unrequited love. Um&#8230; nope. The novel cuts back and forth between their teenage years and the present. In the past, Lelia, Matteo, and Rory all hung out, snowboarded, and were, we are supposed to believe, inseparable. From the get go, it&#8217;s clear Matteo and Lelia have feelings for each other and that Rory is an ass. Despite that, in the present, Matteo has been AWOL for the past fifteen years&#8211;I&#8217;m still not clear why he never came home to see his family&#8211;and Lelia and Rory just recently got divorced because of the whole Rory is an ass thing. Matteo, however, has finally returned to town for the wedding of one of his many siblings. But, though he&#8217;s built a very successful heli-ski business in Aspen, Matteo feels he&#8217;s a mess because he didn&#8217;t manage to prevent his best friend and business partner, Sean, from dying in a snowboarding accident the previous year. So, even though he&#8217;s STILL in love with Lelia and perhaps hasn&#8217;t had a girlfriend ever due to his pining (his romantic past is never discussed), he still can&#8217;t tell her how he feels because&#8230; I wasn&#8217;t really sure. When he was younger, his excuse was he needed to make the big bucks so he could &#8220;become the kind of guy who can afford gold jewelry for the golden girl. That’s when he’ll be able to tell her how he feels. But not until then.&#8221; Now, I guess it&#8217;s because he isn&#8217;t a god and thus able to prevent those he loves from dying. (Sean, however, still shows up in Matteo&#8217;s dreams and gives him helpful pithy advice like go home and make dinner reservations for my daughter&#8217;s birthday because Aspen gets really booked up in tourist season.) For her part, Lelia has always had the hots for Matteo, but he left town and so she married Rory, whom she knew was an ass. Her excuse? &#8220;I think I’d fed off his need. He made me feel powerful—like my opinion mattered. Maybe that’s why I put up with him for twelve wasted years.&#8221; Among other things, staying married to Rotten Rory deprived her of her best baby-making years so now she&#8217;s looking at the eye-poppingly expensive path of medical artificial insemination. It only takes a week or so and some serious booze for Lelia to suggest to Matteo that he be her baby daddy. So, after making sure no one expects anything more from him than a clean bill of health and a willingness to do the deed&#8211;he&#8217;s not good enough to be a real dad&#8211;he agrees. This means they only bone one night a month&#8211;every sperm is sacred. Sex between them is&#8211;shocker!&#8211;the best they&#8217;ve ever had and they just love hanging out together. But though Matteo ends up staying the summer working at his brother&#8217;s wildly successful bar and at Lelia&#8217;s dad&#8217;s wildly successful beer truck and, in their heads, they fall hard for one another, they remain mum on how they truly feel. Because the two are unable to grasp the most basic concept of honest communication, their actions and decisions end up feeling contrived and implausible. The emotional stakes never truly resonate, and the story feels superficial. Which is a shame because Bowen can be a terrific writer. I&#8217;ve enjoyed books in this series&#8211;my favorite is Steadfast&#8211;and in the Ivy Years, and in her Brooklyn series. Here, there are flashes of her brilliance. In particular, she writes families remarkably well. Matteo and his siblings, Lelia and her brother and dad, and especially the parenting of Zara, the heroine of Bountiful, all are written with humor and wisdom. When Zara casually says to Lelia, who&#8217;s come in to get coffee from Zara&#8217;s wildly successful coffee shop, &#8220;You want a sassy four-year-old, too?&#8221; she says, tapping on the register screen. &#8220;Cute but argues with everything I say. Fifty percent off today.&#8221;, it made me laugh and nod my head. The sparkle Bowen&#8217;s wit lends the book, however, is not enough to save the frustrating plot. Furthermore, at a key point in the novel, Lelia makes an unforgivable choice that Bowen glosses right over. Had I been Matteo, I&#8217;d have been angry and hurt but he&#8217;s super chill because he&#8217;s crazy about her&#8211;a fact he STILL hasn&#8217;t told her. SpoilerLelia does, after several months, get pregnant. At this point, Matteo has returned to Aspen and SHE DOESN&#8217;T TELL HIM. Her excuse? She googled the stats on miscarriage rates for pregnancies at thirty-five. Bowen does, however, give readers a sumptuous epilogue. I loved the conclusion of this book so hard&#8211;it&#8217;s everything a romance reader could want in a finale. I give it a ten out of ten. So, is Good As Gold worth reading? Sure, as long as you don&#8217;t mind thirty-five-year-olds acting like idiots for far too long. The sex is hot, the humor is smart, and it ends well. There are worse ways to spend a few hours of your life than laughing at the Rossi family texts, fanning yourself as Matteo and Lelia have a grand time trying to make a zygote, and finishing a book where the final chapter sings. I couldn&#8217;t decide between a C+ and a B- but I went with the latter. Those who like Bowen&#8217;s writing will love this book and so will those who aren&#8217;t as irked by adults acting like adolescents as I am."

                "html": "<p>In the author&#8217;s note of her debut novel, <strong>Forever Your Rogue</strong>, Erin Langston writes:</p>\n<blockquote><p>I had been halfheartedly researching an entirely different plot for <strong>Forever Your Rogue</strong> when I stumbled upon a piece of legal scholarship that completely ignited my story. The case, De Manneville v. De Manneville (1804), involved a mother seeking custody of her still-nursing infant daughter, who had been taken from her by her estranged husband. I remember looking down at my own still-nursing infant daughter and feeling sick when I learned that the court supported the father’s claim to sole custody of the baby. As a woman, Mrs. De Manneville had no legal rights to her child.</p>\n<p>The only thing I know about Mrs. De Manneville is that her husband took away her baby, and even though she knew it was likely to be a nonstarter, she still pursued legal action. Ultimately, she failed. As did the vast majority of mothers who sought custody of their children in the early 1800s. What struck me most about these stories wasn’t the consistent court ruling that fathers have absolute authority; after all, there were stringent laws and expectations around a woman’s legal standing in this period. What struck me most was that they tried anyway.</p>\n<p>Cora’s story was my way of giving all of those women their own happy endings. My novel was born from their trying.</p></blockquote>\n<p>Readers&#8211;Cora&#8217;s story is simply marvelous. I&#8217;ve not read a historical romance published in the past few years I loved as much as I do <strong>Forever Your Rogue</strong>. Smart, sexy, and powerfully grounded in history, written in clean, clear prose&#8211;this book is the definition of a Desert Island Keeper. (DIK)</p>\n<p>Lord Dane, Cora&#8217;s perfectly awful husband, has been dead almost a year, a fact Cora is deeply grateful for. Dane was the sort who didn&#8217;t bother to record their daughter Tess&#8217; birth in his family tree and who viewed Cora and their children Tess and Leo, as uninteresting items he owned. His death&#8211;he crashed his curricle en route to see his latest mistress&#8211;should have enabled Cora and her children to live in peace. But Dane, ever the controlling asshat, designated his awful sister&#8217;s husband as the children&#8217;s legal guardian.</p>\n<p>As Cora&#8217;s brother, Gavin Sinclair explains,</p>\n<blockquote><p>“Because of the laws of coverture, Lord Dane was the only person on earth with legal rights to my sister’s children. He could designate, upon his death, any guardian for them he wished.”</p>\n<p>&#8230; “A guardianship customarily is handled thusly.” Sinclair was now really warming up to his task. “A mother is often named the guardian of nurture—that means she can see to the daily care and wellbeing of her child. The father’s will may also name a testamentary guardian, who oversees the child’s personal finances and makes legal decisions, including matters of education and marriage. Both the guardian of nurture and the testamentary guardian have claim to the child’s physical custody.”</p>\n<p>&#8230; “Cora is, indeed, Tess and Leo’s guardian of nurture,” Sinclair continued matter-of-factly. “It’s why she can remain at Aldworth Park as long as Leo is in her physical custody. Now, if Dane’s will had been typical, I would have been named the testamentary guardian. I’m Cora’s closest brother, and I can’t inherit from Leo.” He smiled sadly at his sister. “Though in truth, I would have very little to do. Cora is an exceptional mother.”</p>\n<p>&#8230; “Dane, of course, did not select Gavin.” Cora’s voice was brittle. “Instead, he named his brother-in-law—his sister Edith’s husband—as my children’s legal guardian. I can’t imagine why, except to slight me. He always found it distasteful, how I doted on the babies.”</p>\n<p>&#8230; “We believe the Carletons intend to exert their power as testamentary guardians to eventually force Cora out entirely. If they ever manage to be named sole guardians, they would have custody not only of the children but Leo’s estate as well. And time is of the essence. They have decided to visit Aldworth Park this summer. Ostensibly, it’s to spend time with the children, but in reality—”</p>\n<p>“They want to catch me out,” Cora seethed. “They’re coming to check up on me, to prove I’m a poor choice to raise the children.”</p></blockquote>\n<p>In order to forestall her in-laws from taking her children, Cora and Gavin have come up with a plan. Cora will become engaged and she and her fake fiance will host the Carltons and present to them the facade of a perfect family while Gavin petitions the Court of Chancery to revoke the Carletons’ rights. Cora has no intention of actually remarrying&#8211;she just needs time and a man willing to help her with her scheme.</p>\n<p>Fortunately for Cora, she &#8216;s acquainted with an ideal (her choices in 1819 were limited) candidate, Nathaniel Travers, whose sister, Tabby, is Cora&#8217;s best friend. Nate <strong>owes</strong> Cora. Five years earlier, Nate&#8217;s poor judgement, not for the first time, caught up with him. Cora, for reasons she doesn&#8217;t like to look too closely at, saved him and, in exchange, Nate promised her a favor. <em>Anything</em>, he&#8217;d said.</p>\n<p>For his part, Nate is aghast when he hears Cora&#8217;s request. You see, Nate, the heir to the Earl of Fordham, is a genuine scapegrace. Yes, he is his brother&#8217;s heir, but, damnit, Nate&#8217;s not going to let that responsibility get in the way of a life of wine, women, and wagers. Unfortunately Raymond, his brother, has cut off his funds. Cora&#8217;s proposal comes with money and is only for a few weeks so, against his better judgement, Nate says yes.</p>\n<p>I loved everything about this tale. Nate and Cora are a wonderful match and watching them realize that is a joy. Tess and Leo are the sort of children one longs for in romance novels but rarely get&#8211;they&#8217;re believable and add both humor and pathos to the book. The secondary characters, especially Nate&#8217;s valet Barnes and Cora&#8217;s brother Gavin, are so vivid I hope for them both to get their own stories. Nate&#8217;s relationship with his brother, the Earl, is moving and brims with complex love. The humor never misses a mark.</p>\n<p>But what makes this historical romance exceptional is its history. I&#8217;ll just say, while reading, I gave thanks for being born in the 20th century&#8211;Langston&#8217;s deep dive into the laws of coverture, women&#8217;s rights, and parental law is meticulous. Cora&#8217;s happy ending seems impossible and yet Langston makes it believable without sacrificing accuracy.</p>\n<p><strong>Forever Your Rogue</strong> is not just the best historical romance I&#8217;ve read this year, it&#8217;s the best romance. It gets a flat out A from me. Thank you, Ms. Langston!</p>\n",
                "text": "In the author&#8217;s note of her debut novel, Forever Your Rogue, Erin Langston writes: I had been halfheartedly researching an entirely different plot for Forever Your Rogue when I stumbled upon a piece of legal scholarship that completely ignited my story. The case, De Manneville v. De Manneville (1804), involved a mother seeking custody of her still-nursing infant daughter, who had been taken from her by her estranged husband. I remember looking down at my own still-nursing infant daughter and feeling sick when I learned that the court supported the father’s claim to sole custody of the baby. As a woman, Mrs. De Manneville had no legal rights to her child. The only thing I know about Mrs. De Manneville is that her husband took away her baby, and even though she knew it was likely to be a nonstarter, she still pursued legal action. Ultimately, she failed. As did the vast majority of mothers who sought custody of their children in the early 1800s. What struck me most about these stories wasn’t the consistent court ruling that fathers have absolute authority; after all, there were stringent laws and expectations around a woman’s legal standing in this period. What struck me most was that they tried anyway. Cora’s story was my way of giving all of those women their own happy endings. My novel was born from their trying. Readers&#8211;Cora&#8217;s story is simply marvelous. I&#8217;ve not read a historical romance published in the past few years I loved as much as I do Forever Your Rogue. Smart, sexy, and powerfully grounded in history, written in clean, clear prose&#8211;this book is the definition of a Desert Island Keeper. (DIK) Lord Dane, Cora&#8217;s perfectly awful husband, has been dead almost a year, a fact Cora is deeply grateful for. Dane was the sort who didn&#8217;t bother to record their daughter Tess&#8217; birth in his family tree and who viewed Cora and their children Tess and Leo, as uninteresting items he owned. His death&#8211;he crashed his curricle en route to see his latest mistress&#8211;should have enabled Cora and her children to live in peace. But Dane, ever the controlling asshat, designated his awful sister&#8217;s husband as the children&#8217;s legal guardian. As Cora&#8217;s brother, Gavin Sinclair explains, “Because of the laws of coverture, Lord Dane was the only person on earth with legal rights to my sister’s children. He could designate, upon his death, any guardian for them he wished.” &#8230; “A guardianship customarily is handled thusly.” Sinclair was now really warming up to his task. “A mother is often named the guardian of nurture—that means she can see to the daily care and wellbeing of her child. The father’s will may also name a testamentary guardian, who oversees the child’s personal finances and makes legal decisions, including matters of education and marriage. Both the guardian of nurture and the testamentary guardian have claim to the child’s physical custody.” &#8230; “Cora is, indeed, Tess and Leo’s guardian of nurture,” Sinclair continued matter-of-factly. “It’s why she can remain at Aldworth Park as long as Leo is in her physical custody. Now, if Dane’s will had been typical, I would have been named the testamentary guardian. I’m Cora’s closest brother, and I can’t inherit from Leo.” He smiled sadly at his sister. “Though in truth, I would have very little to do. Cora is an exceptional mother.” &#8230; “Dane, of course, did not select Gavin.” Cora’s voice was brittle. “Instead, he named his brother-in-law—his sister Edith’s husband—as my children’s legal guardian. I can’t imagine why, except to slight me. He always found it distasteful, how I doted on the babies.” &#8230; “We believe the Carletons intend to exert their power as testamentary guardians to eventually force Cora out entirely. If they ever manage to be named sole guardians, they would have custody not only of the children but Leo’s estate as well. And time is of the essence. They have decided to visit Aldworth Park this summer. Ostensibly, it’s to spend time with the children, but in reality—” “They want to catch me out,” Cora seethed. “They’re coming to check up on me, to prove I’m a poor choice to raise the children.” In order to forestall her in-laws from taking her children, Cora and Gavin have come up with a plan. Cora will become engaged and she and her fake fiance will host the Carltons and present to them the facade of a perfect family while Gavin petitions the Court of Chancery to revoke the Carletons’ rights. Cora has no intention of actually remarrying&#8211;she just needs time and a man willing to help her with her scheme. Fortunately for Cora, she &#8216;s acquainted with an ideal (her choices in 1819 were limited) candidate, Nathaniel Travers, whose sister, Tabby, is Cora&#8217;s best friend. Nate owes Cora. Five years earlier, Nate&#8217;s poor judgement, not for the first time, caught up with him. Cora, for reasons she doesn&#8217;t like to look too closely at, saved him and, in exchange, Nate promised her a favor. Anything, he&#8217;d said. For his part, Nate is aghast when he hears Cora&#8217;s request. You see, Nate, the heir to the Earl of Fordham, is a genuine scapegrace. Yes, he is his brother&#8217;s heir, but, damnit, Nate&#8217;s not going to let that responsibility get in the way of a life of wine, women, and wagers. Unfortunately Raymond, his brother, has cut off his funds. Cora&#8217;s proposal comes with money and is only for a few weeks so, against his better judgement, Nate says yes. I loved everything about this tale. Nate and Cora are a wonderful match and watching them realize that is a joy. Tess and Leo are the sort of children one longs for in romance novels but rarely get&#8211;they&#8217;re believable and add both humor and pathos to the book. The secondary characters, especially Nate&#8217;s valet Barnes and Cora&#8217;s brother Gavin, are so vivid I hope for them both to get their own stories. Nate&#8217;s relationship with his brother, the Earl, is moving and brims with complex love. The humor never misses a mark. But what makes this historical romance exceptional is its history. I&#8217;ll just say, while reading, I gave thanks for being born in the 20th century&#8211;Langston&#8217;s deep dive into the laws of coverture, women&#8217;s rights, and parental law is meticulous. Cora&#8217;s happy ending seems impossible and yet Langston makes it believable without sacrificing accuracy. Forever Your Rogue is not just the best historical romance I&#8217;ve read this year, it&#8217;s the best romance. It gets a flat out A from me. Thank you, Ms. Langston!"

            "content": {
                "html": "<p>Toward the end of Kate Morton’s magnificent new novel, <strong>Homecoming</strong>, she writes:</p>\n<blockquote><p>Reading shapes a person. The landscape of books is more real, in some ways, than the one outside the window.</p></blockquote>\n<p>In this absorbing dual timeline story, the landscape Morton creates is tangible, immersive, and transportive. Much of the novel takes place in the weeks around the Christmas of 1959 in the fictional Southern Australian town of Tambilla—and as I read, I was <strong>there</strong>. I could see the lush foliage, hear the screech of the cockatoos, and experience the loves and losses of those whose stories Morton tells.</p>\n<p>If you’ve read my now second favorite story by Morton, <a href=\"https://amzn.to/41FVBFq\"><strong>The Forgotten Garden</strong></a>, the structure of this novel will feel somewhat familiar. There is a tragedy in the past—in this case the 1959 deaths of a young mother and her children—the truth of which has never really been known. In the present—2018—Jess, a journalist living in London, comes back to Sydney because her beloved grandmother, Nora, has fallen down the stairs and is now hospitalized. Nora, mysteriously, was trying to get to the attic—her housekeeper says Nora had been distressed the last few weeks. Jess wants to know why and therein begins the tale.</p>\n<p>This is a layered novel with many characters and plotlines all of which Morton writes effortlessly. In present day, Jess, on the cusp of 40, feels as though her professional and personal life has been a let-down. She was essentially raised by her imperious, loving, and rather controlling grandmother&#8211;Jess’s own mother, Polly, lives in Brisbane and rarely speaks to her mother or her daughter. All three, it will turn out, have a copy of Daniel Miller’s <strong>As If They Were Asleep</strong>—a (fictionalized) book whose chapters tell the story of the Turner Family Tragedy of Christmas Eve, 1959. These embedded chapters along with the sections actually set in the past, teem with the people of Tambilla whose families along with that of the Turners are shaped by long held secrets and bone deep love.</p>\n<p>I had a few quibbles&#8211;all around the present-day storyline&#8211;but I forgot them as soon as I turned the page. Morton doesn&#8217;t give a resolution to all the issues Jess faces&#8211;this actually gives the story a verisimilitude lesser fiction often lacks. Additionally, one of the big reveals of the book is not, I believe, intended to be a surprise. The connection between Jess, Nora, and Polly to Isabel Turner and her family is easy to make out early on in the book. But how that outcome occurred and, even more compellingly, <strong>why</strong> are things I didn’t see until the final chapters. The enigma at the heart of the novel is complex, heartbreaking, and will satisfy even the most critical mystery reader.</p>\n<p>Morton limns the way humans hide truths from both themselves and others. With gorgeous prose, she slowly cracks open how, for better and for worse, families, especially mothers, love. This is a book tinged with sadness and yet, when I turned the last page, I felt elated. The hours I spent in the landscape meticulously portrayed in <strong>Homecoming</strong> were a gift. Readers of historical fiction will treasure this book.</p>\n",
                "text": "Toward the end of Kate Morton’s magnificent new novel, Homecoming, she writes: Reading shapes a person. The landscape of books is more real, in some ways, than the one outside the window. In this absorbing dual timeline story, the landscape Morton creates is tangible, immersive, and transportive. Much of the novel takes place in the weeks around the Christmas of 1959 in the fictional Southern Australian town of Tambilla—and as I read, I was there. I could see the lush foliage, hear the screech of the cockatoos, and experience the loves and losses of those whose stories Morton tells. If you’ve read my now second favorite story by Morton, The Forgotten Garden, the structure of this novel will feel somewhat familiar. There is a tragedy in the past—in this case the 1959 deaths of a young mother and her children—the truth of which has never really been known. In the present—2018—Jess, a journalist living in London, comes back to Sydney because her beloved grandmother, Nora, has fallen down the stairs and is now hospitalized. Nora, mysteriously, was trying to get to the attic—her housekeeper says Nora had been distressed the last few weeks. Jess wants to know why and therein begins the tale. This is a layered novel with many characters and plotlines all of which Morton writes effortlessly. In present day, Jess, on the cusp of 40, feels as though her professional and personal life has been a let-down. She was essentially raised by her imperious, loving, and rather controlling grandmother&#8211;Jess’s own mother, Polly, lives in Brisbane and rarely speaks to her mother or her daughter. All three, it will turn out, have a copy of Daniel Miller’s As If They Were Asleep—a (fictionalized) book whose chapters tell the story of the Turner Family Tragedy of Christmas Eve, 1959. These embedded chapters along with the sections actually set in the past, teem with the people of Tambilla whose families along with that of the Turners are shaped by long held secrets and bone deep love. I had a few quibbles&#8211;all around the present-day storyline&#8211;but I forgot them as soon as I turned the page. Morton doesn&#8217;t give a resolution to all the issues Jess faces&#8211;this actually gives the story a verisimilitude lesser fiction often lacks. Additionally, one of the big reveals of the book is not, I believe, intended to be a surprise. The connection between Jess, Nora, and Polly to Isabel Turner and her family is easy to make out early on in the book. But how that outcome occurred and, even more compellingly, why are things I didn’t see until the final chapters. The enigma at the heart of the novel is complex, heartbreaking, and will satisfy even the most critical mystery reader. Morton limns the way humans hide truths from both themselves and others. With gorgeous prose, she slowly cracks open how, for better and for worse, families, especially mothers, love. This is a book tinged with sadness and yet, when I turned the last page, I felt elated. The hours I spent in the landscape meticulously portrayed in Homecoming were a gift. Readers of historical fiction will treasure this book."

                "html": "<p>Serena Bell wraps her her <a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/review-tag/wilder-adventures-series/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"><em><strong>Wilder Adventures</strong></em></a> series with a frenemies to lovers story. This quintet of books, set in the nicest town in Oregon, Rush Creek, features five brothers (<a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/book-review/wilder-for-the-win-by-serena-bell/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">their sole sister got a short story</a>), all tall, gorgeous, and in need of the love of a good woman. Four have found their soulmates, all of whom wish to stay in Rush Creek, and, in Wilder at Last, it&#8217;s the youngest, the panty-melter brother, Easton&#8217;s turn.</p>\n<p>If you&#8217;ve read the series, you&#8217;ve figured out Easton&#8217;s true love is Hanna Hott with whom he&#8217;s grown up. Like Easton, Hannah is the youngest of six&#8211;yes, <a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/Hott-Shot-Steamy-Romantic-Comedy-ebook/dp/B0BNPHCLPN/ref=sr_1_1?crid=1AOLBFOUO3GPC&amp;keywords=hott+shot+serena+bell&amp;qid=1673798047&amp;s=digital-text&amp;sprefix=hott+shot+serena+%2Cdigital-text%2C85&amp;sr=1-1\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">the next set of books will feature the five presumably hot Hott brothers</a>&#8211;but unlike him, she doesn&#8217;t come from a loving family. She works as a trip leader for Wilder Adventures, the company all the Wilders and their partners are connected to, and her girl posse is all Wilder women. Hanna loves the Wilders, loves her job, and loves Rush Creek. In Rush Creek, everyone is loved, supported, and encouraging. It&#8217;s a world where all sexual orientations are valued, all body types are beautiful, and sibling rivalry melts away in the face of regular family dinners. If books were hugs, this one is a giant happy group pile on.</p>\n<p>So, if you need a hug, a comforting, familiar hug, you&#8217;ll enjoy <strong>Wilder at Last</strong>. Here (unlike my favorite Bell, <a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/book-review/sleepover-by-serena-bell-2/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"><strong>Sleepover)</strong></a> the writing is sugar and spice and everything nice. This easy to read love story has quippy banter and steamy sex in tent, progressive values and a prescient dog. For many many readers, that&#8217;s a treat. It&#8217;s hard to hate on happiness and I&#8217;m not even going to try. If you love this sort of thing&#8211;and if you do, you are in good company&#8211;<strong>Wilder at Last</strong> will charm you and leave you smiling.</p>\n",
                "text": "Serena Bell wraps her her Wilder Adventures series with a frenemies to lovers story. This quintet of books, set in the nicest town in Oregon, Rush Creek, features five brothers (their sole sister got a short story), all tall, gorgeous, and in need of the love of a good woman. Four have found their soulmates, all of whom wish to stay in Rush Creek, and, in Wilder at Last, it&#8217;s the youngest, the panty-melter brother, Easton&#8217;s turn. If you&#8217;ve read the series, you&#8217;ve figured out Easton&#8217;s true love is Hanna Hott with whom he&#8217;s grown up. Like Easton, Hannah is the youngest of six&#8211;yes, the next set of books will feature the five presumably hot Hott brothers&#8211;but unlike him, she doesn&#8217;t come from a loving family. (The Wilders are the dream team of families.) Hanna, who lives with her hilariously cranky 85 year old grandfather, is, however, an honorary Wilder. She works as a trip leader for Wilder Adventures, the company all the Wilders and their partners are connected to, and her girl posse is all Wilder women. Hanna loves the Wilders, loves her job, and loves Rush Creek. And she loves pranking Easton just as much as he loves pranking her. As the book opens, Hanna has just covered every inch of Easton Wilder’s work cube with sticky notes. His computer, his keyboard, his desk, the walls of the cube, the front of the desk. I used six different colors, arranged in many patterns, including a smiley face of sticky notes glommed on Easton’s computer screen. It’s basically art. Today is Easton’s birthday, and my sticky-note “gift” is payback for his last birthday “present” to me, which was replacing the contents of my deep bottom file drawer with a terrarium. Stones, little plastic plants, a leopard gecko. Some people might call our pranks mean, but Easton and I, we’ve always been like this. Finding ways to make each other’s lives… more colorful. More interesting. And yeah, sometimes a little more difficult—but in the best possible way. I do a happy jiggle to celebrate my own brilliance. Easton’s gonna love it. Or hate it, which is the same thing when it comes to lifetime frenemies. An astute romance reader recognizes this for what it is: sublimated lust just waiting to be set free. The device Bell uses for this is Hanna&#8217;s having the hots for another man, celebrity chef and YouTube sensation Bear Warden. Wilder Adventures has hired Bear to take their clients on trips based around foraging and preparing food in the wild. The minute Hanna sees Bear, she is struck dumb. Bear Warden on the screen did not prepare me for Bear Warden in the flesh. He’s gorgeous. I mean, not quite as gorgeous as Easton, standing beside him, but ever since Easton started dating mean girls in middle school, I’ve discounted him as a man and thought of him more as a work of art with a sense of humor and bad taste in women. It’s a helpful, ever-present reminder that he’s off limits, even as an object of fantasy. The man next to Easton is probably six-foot-four. Broad as a barn, though not the Wilder-brother molded-from-marble version. Softer, more dad-bodied—if your dad was a grizzly bear. He has reddish-brown hair, a thick and impeccably trimmed coppery beard, full lips, and bright blue eyes. Up close, he’s vivid. Something has happened to my brain. Well, really, to my body. As in, my body—specifically, my vagina—hijacked all the blood from my brain. Which is a big deal, because ever since I moved Easton from the middle-school-crush category to nope, this doesn’t happen to me very often, with men or women. Hanna promptly blackmails Easton&#8211;she overheard him asking Bear for a job, something that is verboten because Wilders must work for Wilder Adventures&#8211;into helping her get Bear into the sack. Hanna&#8217;s not looking for love&#8211;her feckless parents and absentee brothers have left her believing she&#8217;s not worthy&#8211;she just wants to roll around the sheets with dad bod Bear. High jinks ensue, some very funny and some not. The blackmail is kinda yucky. The plot depends on both Easton and Hanna being as clueless as Dionne on the highway. There is no problem that can&#8217;t be solved by compassion, words of wisdom from your peeps, and comfy clothes because the Wilder books eschew angsty conflict or difficult choices. They, like Jill Shalvis&#8217; Lucky Harbor books, are feel good paeans to the best of us served with a side of snark and sexy times. In Rush Creek, everyone is loved, supported, and encouraging. It&#8217;s a world where all sexual orientations are valued, all body types are beautiful, and sibling rivalry melts away in the face of regular family dinners. If books were hugs, this one is a giant happy group pile on. So, if you need a hug, a comforting, familiar hug, you&#8217;ll enjoy Wilder at Last. Here (unlike my favorite Bell, Sleepover) the writing is sugar and spice and everything nice. This easy to read love story has quippy banter and steamy sex in tent, progressive values and a prescient dog. For many many readers, that&#8217;s a treat. It&#8217;s hard to hate on happiness and I&#8217;m not even going to try. If you love this sort of thing&#8211;and if you do, you are in good company&#8211;Wilder at Last will charm you and leave you smiling."

                "html": "<p>I am thrilled to see Julia Bennet again publishing historical romance. Her first two novels, <a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/book-review/the-madness-of-miss-grey-by-julia-bennet/\"><strong>The Madness of Miss Gray</strong></a> and <a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/book-review/the-ruin-of-evangeline-jones-by-julia-bennet/\"><strong>The Ruin of Evangeline Jones</strong></a>, are four star reads for me and, were I awarding points for simply being more <em>interesting</em> than the vast majority of historical romances I&#8217;ve read in the past five years, I&#8217;d rate them even higher. Her latest, <strong>The Worst Woman in London</strong>, is a refreshing, generous tale that tells two love stories as it explores the abhorrent impact on women of divorce law in the Victorian age.</p>\n<p>James Standish first meets Francesca Heller when she is nineteen and he is twenty-six. She is the intended of his best friend, Edward Thorne. James realizes, within minutes, the Thorne marriage is doomed.</p>\n<blockquote>\n<p class=\"block_3\">Miss Heller simply wasn’t the right girl for Thorne. James knew by the way she hid her laughter, by her sadness when Thorne patronized her, and by a dozen other insignificant details. If the ceremony went ahead in three days, it might prove the worst mistake of her life.</p>\n<p class=\"block_3\">If it were any other man, the two might marry, realize their mistake, and make the best of things, but Thorne was a romantic and he’d rhapsodized at length on Miss Heller’s delicacy, her girlish ignorance, and sweet compliance. When he realized she wasn’t the girl of his dreams, his spirits wouldn’t just plummet, but crash. When people tumbled from their pedestals, as they generally did sooner or later, Thorne didn’t hesitate to cut them out of his life. Even his own father.</p>\n<p class=\"block_3\">The girl didn’t understand, not consciously, and Thorne hadn’t a clue.</p>\n<p class=\"block_3\">Perhaps James ought to say something.</p>\n</blockquote>\n<p>James says nothing and Francesca and Edward marry within weeks. The union is, as James foresaw, a disaster.</p>\n<p>Our story then moves forward ten years, the Thornes have lived apart for the past eight&#8211;Edward with his mistresses in London, Francesca in the country. Francesca, much to the horror of society and Edward, is insisting on divorce. She wishes to be truly free of Edward and is unwilling to continue on as they have. Pursuing this end means she&#8217;s lost her standing in society&#8211;even the uncle and aunt who raised her won&#8217;t speak to her&#8211;as well as almost all of her money.</p>\n<p>Edward finds her behavior <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qhXjcZdk5QQ\">inconceivable</a>. He tries to change her mind&#8211;</p>\n<blockquote><p>“You didn’t used to mind doing what&#8217;s expected.” Edward’s voice, quiet with reproach, brought her back to the here and now. The words hung in the air and quashed any triumph she might feel at resisting his tactics. “Are their expectations really so onerous? You don’t want to live with me. We’ll live apart then. They can tolerate that. Surely you can content yourself for your family’s sake. A divorce gains you nothing and causes them, causes all of us, a great deal of unpleasantness.”</p></blockquote>\n<p>&#8211;and when that doesn&#8217;t work, enlists James to make Fran an offer.</p>\n<blockquote><p>“To be precise, I’m willing to offer five thousand pounds per annum to be paid in quarterly installments. She’ll be able to maintain her own establishment, if that&#8217;s what she wishes, and in grand style. She ought to be happy. Any sane woman would be.”</p></blockquote>\n<p>James grudgingly agrees to visit Fran and convey his friend&#8217;s proposal which he, James, thinks is astonishingly generous. James is a man well aware of the value of money. He was raised by his acerbic aunt Miriam whose heir he is. He&#8217;s never worked a day in his life&#8211;men of his class just didn&#8217;t&#8211;and though he doesn&#8217;t love answering to his aunt, he knows better than to threaten his own financial security. But when he goes to Bloomsbury to see her, Fran has no interest in Edward&#8217;s offer. Nothing is worth more to her than her freedom.</p>\n<blockquote><p>James didn’t believe in freedom. She might as well say she wanted a genie to appear and grant her three wishes or the ability to spin straw into gold. It wouldn’t sound more improbable to his ears. Everyone, even the privileged elite, had a role to play and a script to follow.</p></blockquote>\n<p>He leaves her house unsettled. Their conversation makes him feel somehow less for caring about having nice things, for wanting to be a part of high society. James finds himself, over the next days, thinking more than he&#8217;d like about Francesca. She&#8217;s certainly a lot more interesting to him than beautiful, eighteen-year-old Sylvia Randle, the woman Miriam has decided he should consider. The next time James sees Fran, at the opera where Edward is flaunting his diamond bedecked paramour, James asks Fran to come riding with him the next day. That date leads to another which leads to a kiss and suddenly, for the first time in his life, James is in love with the worst woman (for him) in London.</p>\n<p>Though this is a short book&#8211;it comes in at under 300 pages&#8211;<strong>The Worst Woman in London</strong> feels expansive. Ms. Bennet has clearly researched the laws of the time. Women and men were treated very differently in matters of divorce, much to the detriment of the former. Fran meets regularly with her solicitor and those conversations are fascinating. James muses&#8211;and we are privy to his thoughts&#8211;a great deal about work, money, and the roles men are assigned in his aristocratic world.  This is a book whose intellect is obvious and enjoyable&#8211;my favorite kind!</p>\n<p>It is, however, first and foremost a romance novel and, as noted earlier, contains not one but two sets of lovers. The primary romance between James and Fran is sexy and believable. I liked them&#8211;they are admirable, honorable, and ethical leads. James becomes a better man because of his love for Fran and Fran gets the kindness, passion, and love Edward denied her. But&#8211;and this is a bit of a problem&#8211;they weren&#8217;t as compelling to me as the other lovers: Edward and Sylvia.</p>\n<p>Edward is a thorough bounder&#8211;and, in historical romance, I have a weakness for such men. Sylvia is reckless, resentful, and believably immature. Each takes one look at the other and thinks, <em>I want THAT</em>. Their courtship&#8211;it barely qualifies for the term&#8211;is heedless and hot and quite likely to end in ruin. Neither she nor Edward care&#8211;and I loved them for it. I&#8217;d have happily read as much about them as I did about James and Fran&#8211;to be honest, I&#8217;d have been happier to have read <strong>more</strong> about them than James and Fran. I suspect the reason I can&#8217;t is that Ms. Bennet knows that today&#8217;s modern reader is likely to have a hissy fit if a <em>genuine</em> cad, even a somewhat redeemable cad, is the hero. To me, romance is the less for it but that&#8217;s just me.</p>\n<p><strong>The Worst Woman in London</strong> gets a DIK from me. It&#8217;s romantic, feminist, and shimmers with intelligence. Let&#8217;s hope Ms. Bennet keeps writing&#8211;we need more historical romance just like this!</p>\n",
                "text": "I am thrilled to see Julia Bennet again publishing historical romance. Her first two novels, The Madness of Miss Gray and The Ruin of Evangeline Jones, are four star reads for me and, were I awarding points for simply being more interesting than the vast majority of historical romances I&#8217;ve read in the past five years, I&#8217;d rate them even higher. Her latest, The Worst Woman in London, is a refreshing, generous tale that tells two love stories as it explores the abhorrent impact on women of divorce law in the Victorian age. James Standish first meets Francesca Heller when she is nineteen and he is twenty-six. She is the intended of his best friend, Edward Thorne. James realizes, within minutes, the Thorne marriage is doomed. Miss Heller simply wasn’t the right girl for Thorne. James knew by the way she hid her laughter, by her sadness when Thorne patronized her, and by a dozen other insignificant details. If the ceremony went ahead in three days, it might prove the worst mistake of her life. If it were any other man, the two might marry, realize their mistake, and make the best of things, but Thorne was a romantic and he’d rhapsodized at length on Miss Heller’s delicacy, her girlish ignorance, and sweet compliance. When he realized she wasn’t the girl of his dreams, his spirits wouldn’t just plummet, but crash. When people tumbled from their pedestals, as they generally did sooner or later, Thorne didn’t hesitate to cut them out of his life. Even his own father. The girl didn’t understand, not consciously, and Thorne hadn’t a clue. Perhaps James ought to say something. James says nothing and Francesca and Edward marry within weeks. The union is, as James foresaw, a disaster. Our story then moves forward ten years, the Thornes have lived apart for the past eight&#8211;Edward with his mistresses in London, Francesca in the country. Francesca, much to the horror of society and Edward, is insisting on divorce. She wishes to be truly free of Edward and is unwilling to continue on as they have. Pursuing this end means she&#8217;s lost her standing in society&#8211;even the uncle and aunt who raised her won&#8217;t speak to her&#8211;as well as almost all of her money. Edward finds her behavior inconceivable. He tries to change her mind&#8211; “You didn’t used to mind doing what&#8217;s expected.” Edward’s voice, quiet with reproach, brought her back to the here and now. The words hung in the air and quashed any triumph she might feel at resisting his tactics. “Are their expectations really so onerous? You don’t want to live with me. We’ll live apart then. They can tolerate that. Surely you can content yourself for your family’s sake. A divorce gains you nothing and causes them, causes all of us, a great deal of unpleasantness.” &#8211;and when that doesn&#8217;t work, enlists James to make Fran an offer. “To be precise, I’m willing to offer five thousand pounds per annum to be paid in quarterly installments. She’ll be able to maintain her own establishment, if that&#8217;s what she wishes, and in grand style. She ought to be happy. Any sane woman would be.” James grudgingly agrees to visit Fran and convey his friend&#8217;s proposal which he, James, thinks is astonishingly generous. James is a man well aware of the value of money. He was raised by his acerbic aunt Miriam whose heir he is. He&#8217;s never worked a day in his life&#8211;men of his class just didn&#8217;t&#8211;and though he doesn&#8217;t love answering to his aunt, he knows better than to threaten his own financial security. But when he goes to Bloomsbury to see her, Fran has no interest in Edward&#8217;s offer. Nothing is worth more to her than her freedom. James didn’t believe in freedom. She might as well say she wanted a genie to appear and grant her three wishes or the ability to spin straw into gold. It wouldn’t sound more improbable to his ears. Everyone, even the privileged elite, had a role to play and a script to follow. He leaves her house unsettled. Their conversation makes him feel somehow less for caring about having nice things, for wanting to be a part of high society. James finds himself, over the next days, thinking more than he&#8217;d like about Francesca. She&#8217;s certainly a lot more interesting to him than beautiful, eighteen-year-old Sylvia Randle, the woman Miriam has decided he should consider. The next time James sees Fran, at the opera where Edward is flaunting his diamond bedecked paramour, James asks Fran to come riding with him the next day. That date leads to another which leads to a kiss and suddenly, for the first time in his life, James is in love with the worst woman (for him) in London. Though this is a short book&#8211;it comes in at under 300 pages&#8211;The Worst Woman in London feels expansive. Ms. Bennet has clearly researched the laws of the time. Women and men were treated very differently in matters of divorce, much to the detriment of the former. Fran meets regularly with her solicitor and those conversations are fascinating. James muses&#8211;and we are privy to his thoughts&#8211;a great deal about work, money, and the roles men are assigned in his aristocratic world.  This is a book whose intellect is obvious and enjoyable&#8211;my favorite kind! It is, however, first and foremost a romance novel and, as noted earlier, contains not one but two sets of lovers. The primary romance between James and Fran is sexy and believable. I liked them&#8211;they are admirable, honorable, and ethical leads. James becomes a better man because of his love for Fran and Fran gets the kindness, passion, and love Edward denied her. But&#8211;and this is a bit of a problem&#8211;they weren&#8217;t as compelling to me as the other lovers: Edward and Sylvia. Edward is a thorough bounder&#8211;and, in historical romance, I have a weakness for such men. Sylvia is reckless, resentful, and believably immature. Each takes one look at the other and thinks, I want THAT. Their courtship&#8211;it barely qualifies for the term&#8211;is heedless and hot and quite likely to end in ruin. Neither she nor Edward care&#8211;and I loved them for it. I&#8217;d have happily read as much about them as I did about James and Fran&#8211;to be honest, I&#8217;d have been happier to have read more about them than James and Fran. I suspect the reason I can&#8217;t is that Ms. Bennet knows that today&#8217;s modern reader is likely to have a hissy fit if a genuine cad, even a somewhat redeemable cad, is the hero. To me, romance is the less for it but that&#8217;s just me. The Worst Woman in London gets a DIK from me. It&#8217;s romantic, feminist, and shimmers with intelligence. Let&#8217;s hope Ms. Bennet keeps writing&#8211;we need more historical romance just like this!"
            }
