                "html": "<p><em>from <strong>The New York Times</strong> in October 2022:</em></p>\n<div class=\"css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn\">\n<div class=\"css-53u6y8\">\n<p class=\"css-at9mc1 evys1bk0\"><a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2022/10/09/books/colleen-hoover.html?unlocked_article_code=_bTF2FQh1rM7R5lkE1d2uQOA1BcPdPRk30YgjSLlw-Hu5TVNom_cqtCNeIZGv6TxjGTv_8CubyBQ2NJ9XnbWNDu_07ABRloMy8E25UeN1hqNi_g9j_4ZFFZrCdFhY889S849uqqSeYYTJSWqwGwBuxu1kv7ShUhbFqCBwEv7vSy8FwtpwMdJ8Tx2RuuMBZk2WrFs2oLTwR5kA82gyBZajpx3tQzVeoFrA4Lv4ERxYroDufP6zUcLuij5l8m5KAWxxzjncH6cdGcIBNI9lD8wOMXnx9Ee77FycVwTl5breBiCEKhh7VRGoo3KjkICR77IyrYW7TXJ&amp;smid=share-url\">Colleen Hoover has sold more books this year than Dr. Seuss. She’s sold more books than James Patterson and John Grisham — combined.</a></p>\n<p class=\"css-at9mc1 evys1bk0\"><a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2022/10/09/books/colleen-hoover.html?unlocked_article_code=_bTF2FQh1rM7R5lkE1d2uQOA1BcPdPRk30YgjSLlw-Hu5TVNom_cqtCNeIZGv6TxjGTv_8CubyBQ2NJ9XnbWNDu_07ABRloMy8E25UeN1hqNi_g9j_4ZFFZrCdFhY889S849uqqSeYYTJSWqwGwBuxu1kv7ShUhbFqCBwEv7vSy8FwtpwMdJ8Tx2RuuMBZk2WrFs2oLTwR5kA82gyBZajpx3tQzVeoFrA4Lv4ERxYroDufP6zUcLuij5l8m5KAWxxzjncH6cdGcIBNI9lD8wOMXnx9Ee77FycVwTl5breBiCEKhh7VRGoo3KjkICR77IyrYW7TXJ&amp;smid=share-url\">To say she’s currently the best-selling novelist in the United States, to even compare her to other successful authors who have landed several books on the best seller lists, fails to capture the size and loyalty of her audience.</a></p>\n<p class=\"css-at9mc1 evys1bk0\"><a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2022/10/09/books/colleen-hoover.html?unlocked_article_code=_bTF2FQh1rM7R5lkE1d2uQOA1BcPdPRk30YgjSLlw-Hu5TVNom_cqtCNeIZGv6TxjGTv_8CubyBQ2NJ9XnbWNDu_07ABRloMy8E25UeN1hqNi_g9j_4ZFFZrCdFhY889S849uqqSeYYTJSWqwGwBuxu1kv7ShUhbFqCBwEv7vSy8FwtpwMdJ8Tx2RuuMBZk2WrFs2oLTwR5kA82gyBZajpx3tQzVeoFrA4Lv4ERxYroDufP6zUcLuij5l8m5KAWxxzjncH6cdGcIBNI9lD8wOMXnx9Ee77FycVwTl5breBiCEKhh7VRGoo3KjkICR77IyrYW7TXJ&amp;smid=share-url\">She holds six of the top 10 spots on The New York Times’s paperback fiction best-seller list, a stunning number of simultaneous best sellers from a single author. She has sold 8.6 million print books this year alone — more copies than the Bible, according to NPD BookScan.</a></p>\n<hr />\n<p class=\"css-at9mc1 evys1bk0\">We at AAR have never reviewed Colleen Hoover. So, when <strong>Verity</strong> was a <em>Steal and Deal</em> a few weeks ago, I snapped it up.</p>\n<p>The book begins with an act of violence. Our narrator (she is one of two&#8211;the other, the eponymous Verity), Lowen Ashleigh tells us in the book&#8217;s very first line: &#8220;<em>I hear the crack of his skull before the spattering of blood reaches me.</em>&#8221; I gasped, for the first and last time. Lowen, on her way to a meeting with her publisher, has just watched a man step into the street&#8211;he was, of course, on his phone&#8211;and get smashed to bits by a truck.</p>\n<p>This, for Lowen, is a bummer.</p>\n<p>Not because she cares especially about the stranger&#8217;s death but because the white shirt she donned for her meeting is now a red and white shirt and that, she thinks, will not impress the editor she is on her way to meet. Lowen, a self-described introvert, is about to be evicted from her apartment. She&#8217;s broke, unemployed, and down to the last pennies of her last advance from her last poorly selling book. This meeting, whose terms are a mystery to her (her agent and ex-boyfriend set it up), is crucial to her financial survival.</p>\n<p>Fortunately, a man, tall and kind, takes her to a nearby coffee shop where she strips off her shirt&#8211;as he watches&#8211;and, once she&#8217;s cleaned herself up, gives her his own. His name, he tells her, is Jeremy and he and Lowen have a <strong>moment</strong>. But he has a wedding ring on his left hand and Lowen, worried about being late for her meeting, watches him walk away.</p>\n<p>She, however, runs into him almost immediately in the publisher&#8217;s lobby. <del>Not</del> Shockingly, Jeremy is also at this meeting.</p>\n<p>Jeremy is married to wildly successful Verity Crawford, an author of riveting and unsettling murder mysteries. Verity has been in an car accident and, though her condition isn&#8217;t explained, the publisher explains that they&#8217;d like to hire Lowen to write the last three books in Verity&#8217;s best-selling series <strong><em>The Novel Virtues</em></strong>. Despite being about to be evicted, Lowen says she can&#8217;t&#8211;the publicity piece of it just won&#8217;t suit. But, after dismissing everyone else from the room, Jeremy talks her into it with a promise of anonymity and a boatload of money. Plus, he&#8217;s offering housing which means that not only will Lowen have a place to live until her first check comes in, she&#8217;ll be able to spend time immersed in <del>sex fantasies about Jeremy</del> Verity&#8217;s life.</p>\n<p>Thus, in just about the time it would take you to read a synopsis of <a href=\"https://www.britannica.com/topic/Rebecca-novel\"><strong>Rebecca</strong></a>, t<del>he second Mrs. De Winter</del> Lowen arrives at the Crawfords&#8217; rural mansion in Vermont where she&#8217;s to spend a few days going through Verity&#8217;s files and getting a sense of her work. (Lowen has never read her, something she rectifies by listening to an audiobook of the first book on the drive which takes six hours. Lowen finishes the book&#8211;I guess Verity writes very short books&#8211;and deems it <em>really good</em>.) At the house, she finds Jeremy and his five year old son (Jeremy&#8217;s twin daughters both died last year), Crew, the Crawford&#8217;s five year old son, and Verity. The latter is, Jeremey tells Lowen as he takes her to meet his wife who is lying, empty eyed in bed, essentially brain dead. Jeffrey and two nurses take care of her and, thinks Lowen, &#8220;<em>It&#8217;s all so depressing. This house, the tragedies in this family&#8217;s past, the struggles in their present.&#8221; </em></p>\n<p>But this book is a thriller not a cautionary tale about the dangers of not wearing seatbelts. Thus, after meeting Verity, Jeremy takes Lowen to Verity&#8217;s gorgeous office where, once left on her own, Lowen discovers A MANUSCRIPT. This book, entitled <strong>So Be It</strong>, isn&#8217;t part of Verity&#8217;s series. Nope. It&#8217;s an autobiography and once Lowen starts reading it, she is hooked.</p>\n<p>Verity, you see, is EVIL. On the first page of her account of her life with Jeremy&#8211;that is the sole focus of <strong>So Be It</strong>&#8211;she tells the reader that her words will not just be distasteful, they will become part of the reader&#8217;s gut and they will be hurt because of them. This, of course, does not deter Lowen who, over the next two weeks&#8211;she ends up staying longer than she&#8217;d planned because of reasons&#8211;reads Verity&#8217;s words obsessively.</p>\n<p>I couldn&#8217;t tell you why either Lowen or Verity have had success with their books. The chapters in Lowen&#8217;s voice are prosaic, rife with mundane details, and reflect a woman whose curiosity is anxious and credulous. Those in Verity&#8217;s are full of lurid sex scenes that read as if they were written by a 20 year old man with a perpetual hard on and a wish to become the next winner of the <a href=\"https://ew.com/books/2018/12/03/worst-sex-writing-2018-all-men/\">Bad Sex in Fiction award</a>. Neither story is tethered to reality. Every main character in the book is both awful and forgettable, even the five year old. And while Hoover does a fine job relentlessly pushing her story into ever more unbelievable twists, I found <strong>Verity</strong> predictable. Though the book is just 333 pages, it seemed longer, tugged down by its stock prose. It&#8217;s not a total waste of time&#8211;it is suspenseful in parts and there is a ghoulish pleasure to be found in reading just how spectacularly horrendous Verity&#8217;s behavior is.</p>\n<p>What, though, you ask about the much praised ending which a <em><strong>Washington Post</strong> </em>reviewer called <a href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/books/2022/03/14/verity-colleen-hoover-ending/\">the most chilling twist I’ve ever read in a novel</a>. (Despite that, the reviewer didn&#8217;t like the book.) Well, I guess if you&#8217;re wowed by an utterly batshit conclusion that, if you think about it for longer than it takes Lowen to ogle shirtless Jeremy, makes no sense, you&#8217;ll like this book more than did I.</p>\n<p>&nbsp;</p>\n</div>\n</div>\n",
                "text": "from The New York Times in October 2022: Colleen Hoover has sold more books this year than Dr. Seuss. She’s sold more books than James Patterson and John Grisham — combined. To say she’s currently the best-selling novelist in the United States, to even compare her to other successful authors who have landed several books on the best seller lists, fails to capture the size and loyalty of her audience. She holds six of the top 10 spots on The New York Times’s paperback fiction best-seller list, a stunning number of simultaneous best sellers from a single author. She has sold 8.6 million print books this year alone — more copies than the Bible, according to NPD BookScan. We at AAR have never reviewed Colleen Hoover. So, when Verity was a Steal and Deal a few weeks ago, I snapped it up. The book begins with an act of violence. Our narrator (she is one of two&#8211;the other, the eponymous Verity), Lowen Ashleigh tells us in the book&#8217;s very first line: &#8220;I hear the crack of his skull before the spattering of blood reaches me.&#8221; I gasped, for the first and last time. Lowen, on her way to a meeting with her publisher, has just watched a man step into the street&#8211;he was, of course, on his phone&#8211;and get smashed to bits by a truck. This, for Lowen, is a bummer. Not because she cares especially about the stranger&#8217;s death but because the white shirt she donned for her meeting is now a red and white shirt and that, she thinks, will not impress the editor she is on her way to meet. Lowen, a self-described introvert, is about to be evicted from her apartment. She&#8217;s broke, unemployed, and down to the last pennies of her last advance from her last poorly selling book. This meeting, whose terms are a mystery to her (her agent and ex-boyfriend set it up), is crucial to her financial survival. Fortunately, a man, tall and kind, takes her to a nearby coffee shop where she strips off her shirt&#8211;as he watches&#8211;and, once she&#8217;s cleaned herself up, gives her his own. His name, he tells her, is Jeremy and he and Lowen have a moment. But he has a wedding ring on his left hand and Lowen, worried about being late for her meeting, watches him walk away. She, however, runs into him almost immediately in the publisher&#8217;s lobby. Not Shockingly, Jeremy is also at this meeting. Jeremy is married to wildly successful Verity Crawford, an author of riveting and unsettling murder mysteries. Verity has been in an car accident and, though her condition isn&#8217;t explained, the publisher explains that they&#8217;d like to hire Lowen to write the last three books in Verity&#8217;s best-selling series The Novel Virtues. Despite being about to be evicted, Lowen says she can&#8217;t&#8211;the publicity piece of it just won&#8217;t suit. But, after dismissing everyone else from the room, Jeremy talks her into it with a promise of anonymity and a boatload of money. Plus, he&#8217;s offering housing which means that not only will Lowen have a place to live until her first check comes in, she&#8217;ll be able to spend time immersed in sex fantasies about Jeremy Verity&#8217;s life. Thus, in just about the time it would take you to read a synopsis of Rebecca, the second Mrs. De Winter Lowen arrives at the Crawfords&#8217; rural mansion in Vermont where she&#8217;s to spend a few days going through Verity&#8217;s files and getting a sense of her work. (Lowen has never read her, something she rectifies by listening to an audiobook of the first book on the drive which takes six hours. Lowen finishes the book&#8211;I guess Verity writes very short books&#8211;and deems it really good.) At the house, she finds Jeremy and his five year old son (Jeremy&#8217;s twin daughters both died last year), Crew, the Crawford&#8217;s five year old son, and Verity. The latter is, Jeremey tells Lowen as he takes her to meet his wife who is lying, empty eyed in bed, essentially brain dead. Jeffrey and two nurses take care of her and, thinks Lowen, &#8220;It&#8217;s all so depressing. This house, the tragedies in this family&#8217;s past, the struggles in their present.&#8221;  But this book is a thriller not a cautionary tale about the dangers of not wearing seatbelts. Thus, after meeting Verity, Jeremy takes Lowen to Verity&#8217;s gorgeous office where, once left on her own, Lowen discovers A MANUSCRIPT. This book, entitled So Be It, isn&#8217;t part of Verity&#8217;s series. Nope. It&#8217;s an autobiography and once Lowen starts reading it, she is hooked. Verity, you see, is EVIL. On the first page of her account of her life with Jeremy&#8211;that is the sole focus of So Be It&#8211;she tells the reader that her words will not just be distasteful, they will become part of the reader&#8217;s gut and they will be hurt because of them. This, of course, does not deter Lowen who, over the next two weeks&#8211;she ends up staying longer than she&#8217;d planned because of reasons&#8211;reads Verity&#8217;s words obsessively. I couldn&#8217;t tell you why either Lowen or Verity have had success with their books. The chapters in Lowen&#8217;s voice are prosaic, rife with mundane details, and reflect a woman whose curiosity is anxious and credulous. Those in Verity&#8217;s are full of lurid sex scenes that read as if they were written by a 20 year old man with a perpetual hard on and a wish to become the next winner of the Bad Sex in Fiction award. Neither story is tethered to reality. Every main character in the book is both awful and forgettable, even the five year old. And while Hoover does a fine job relentlessly pushing her story into ever more unbelievable twists, I found Verity predictable. Though the book is just 333 pages, it seemed longer, tugged down by its stock prose. It&#8217;s not a total waste of time&#8211;it is suspenseful in parts and there is a ghoulish pleasure to be found in reading just how spectacularly horrendous Verity&#8217;s behavior is. What, though, you ask about the much praised ending which a Washington Post reviewer called the most chilling twist I’ve ever read in a novel. (Despite that, the reviewer didn&#8217;t like the book.) Well, I guess if you&#8217;re wowed by an utterly batshit conclusion that, if you think about it for longer than it takes Lowen to ogle shirtless Jeremy, makes no sense, you&#8217;ll like this book more than did I. &nbsp;"

                "html": "<p><strong>The Dark King</strong>, Gina Maxwell&#8217;s urban fantasy romance, invokes the rockstar <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/music/2022/jan/21/meat-loaf-bat-out-of-hell-singer-dead-at-74\">Meatloaf</a>&#8216;s immortal words: &#8220;<a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=k5hWWe-ts2s\">Two out of three ain&#8217;t bad.</a>&#8221;</p>\n<p>The novel has a delicious love story, satisfying plot, and skimpy world-building. Given that this is fantasy &#8211; in this imaginary world, the Dark Fae rule Las Vegas &#8211; a fictional world with a gossamer thin context is a botheration. That said, if you&#8217;re looking for a fervently libidinous love story with very seductive fairies, you&#8217;ll enjoy<strong> The Dark King</strong>.</p>\n<p>Bryn Meara is thrilled to be in Las Vegas. Who wouldn&#8217;t love a free trip complete with luxury accommodations at the city&#8217;s hottest hotel, Nightfall? I mean, she&#8217;s just lost her job to <em>organizational changes. </em>The hotel is freaking amazing &#8211; she got upgraded to a VIP suite after first being told she didn&#8217;t actually have a reservation &#8211; and she just knows tonight is going to be the best of her life. Once on the casino floor, her conviction proves to be right: Caiden Verran, the owner of the hotel, starts chatting her up at the roulette table. Caiden, along with his two hot as hell brothers, is known as one of the Verran Kings of Vegas, and is <em>the most beautiful person &#8211; man or woman &#8211; </em>Bryn&#8217;s ever seen <em>in her life</em>.</p>\n<p>One thing leads to another and before you can say predictable but fun romance trope, after a night of martinis and inexplicable connection, Bryn and Caiden wake up married. Even worse, from Caiden&#8217;s perspective, they wake up as <em>true mates</em>, an indelible bond that can only occur between pairs with Dark Fae blood. This is VERY BAD because Caiden and all in his line suffer under a curse. If the King of the Night Court, which Caiden is,<em> takes a true queen of fae blood, they will start to weaken and eventually die if their mate is ever &#8220;more than a stone&#8217;s throw&#8221; away from them.</em> For the Dark Fae, this has meant they don&#8217;t marry or bond &#8211; they simply take consorts whom they don&#8217;t love and thus who aren&#8217;t a dire threat to the King&#8217;s very existence.</p>\n<p>It&#8217;s a real pickle and one that infuriates them both. Caiden is sure Bryn has somehow scammed him. How else could he end up mated to a <em>human</em> after a night he can barely remember? Clearly she&#8217;s used some sort of dark magic and cannot be trusted. Bryn thinks Caiden is an utter dick. He won&#8217;t let her leave the hotel and is RUDE. Worst of all, he won&#8217;t have sex with her again and the sex was <em>really</em> <em>really</em> good.</p>\n<p>Whatever will they do?</p>\n<p>Look, you know, more or less, what happens next. They fight, both each other and their all-consuming attraction. They have sex and Bryn learns she likes nipple clamps and butt plugs. (Ms. Maxwell writes sex well and their love scenes have a humor and lightness I enjoyed.) Caiden&#8217;s brothers tease him endlessly about his obsession with his wife while Bryn makes pals with the fae staff who think she&#8217;s THE BEST. Their relationship unfurls amidst court intrigue and fae warfare and it is all a very very good time.</p>\n<p>It is a bummer the world building feels so gauzy. The Fae realm feels slap dashed together as if the author hadn&#8217;t given it a whole lot of thought. This lack of clear context diminishes the threats Caiden faces from his Fae enemies &#8211; it will shock no one to discover that Bryn didn&#8217;t end up in Vegas randomly &#8211; and makes the book good rather than great. But we don&#8217;t always have to read great books and this one is a steamy, sweet romp. It gets a B from me.</p>\n<p>&nbsp;</p>\n",

            "content": {
                "html": "<p>Holly Black&#8217;s marvelous trilogy <a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/book-review/the-cruel-prince-and-the-wicked-king-by-holly-black/\"><em><strong>The Folk of Air</strong></em></a> is so damn good that when I heard she was continuing to explore the world of Elfhame, a kingdom of magical islands, I was thrilled. And cautious. Black&#8217;s novel after the trilogy, <a href=\"https://amzn.to/3Zntpah\"><strong>Book of Night</strong></a>, was a hot mess. Would a return to Elfhame be a return to the greatness that is the story of Jude and Cardan?</p>\n<p>Sadly, no.</p>\n<p><strong>The Stolen Heir</strong> (the first of a duology) is worth reading but those who are looking for sublime will not find it in these 345 pages. Its heroine, Suren (Wren), the true Queen of the Court of Teeth, is less lovable than Jude and this book, the story of a quest she goes on with Jude&#8217;s younger brother Oak, the heir to the Kingdom of Elfhame and to whom Suren was once betrothed, meanders for too long before reaching a dramatic and rather horrifying conclusion.</p>\n<p>Wren is one traumatized blue skinned changeling. Born a faerie, she was raised in the human realm in a loving family until her truly evil parents, Lady Nore and Lord Jarel, kidnapped her. In the almost two years Suren, as she is known in Faerie, lived in the Court of Teeth, she was tortured and profoundly emotionally abused by her parents. At the end of <a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/book-review/queen-of-nothing-by-holly-black/\"><strong>The Queen of Nothing</strong></a>, the final book in the first trilogy, the Kingdom of Teeth is in ruins, Lord Jarel is dead, and Lady Nore has sworn fealty to Suren . Nine years later, Wren is homeless in the human world, wild, isolated and always alone.</p>\n<p>As this book begins, she is being hunted by Bogdana, the storm hag, whom Wren is sure is working for Lady Norel, now back and up to no good in the Court of Teeth. Panicking and trying to escape, Wren is running through the woods when she suddenly runs into Oak.</p>\n<p>Oak, preternaturally gorgeous and charming, offers Wren a deal. He and his knight, Tiernan, will protect Wren if she goes with them to the Court of Teeth. Oak is searching for the heart of Mellith, an object of great power which, were it to fall into Lady Nore&#8217;s hands, would doom the worlds magical and real. Wren is the only person in the kingdom who has any power over Lady Nore whom Wren absolutely loathes and so she agrees and the three set off.</p>\n<p><strong>The Stolen Heir</strong> is, at its somewhat depressing heart, about the wounds of childhood trauma. Wren&#8217;s life has left her fearful and feral. She trusts no one, especially not Oak who, from her perspective, has led a charmed life as loved Elfhame royalty. Oak, who is the heir to the throne until Jude and Cardan start popping out babies, has suffered endless assassination attempts. And while his relationship with his loving sisters is straightforward, that with his adoptive redcap father, Madoc whom Lady Nore is holding captive, is complicated and dangerous. It&#8217;s obvious, perhaps overly so, that Oak and Wren care for one another, even love each other, but their interactions are full of lies and betrayal and a very rational mistrust.</p>\n<p>The novel is told only from Wren&#8217;s perspective&#8211;<a href=\"https://amzn.to/3Zu0Yrq\">the second will be from Oak&#8217;s.</a> As a narrator, Wren is glum. Over and over, she reminds herself, and the reader, that she is damaged, ugly, that Oak only is with her to use her power, and that everything sucks. She&#8217;s not wrong&#8211;this is a dark and fairly humorless book. Oak is a possible source of joy and laughter and yet, through Wren&#8217;s eyes, he comes across as somewhat flimsy. Those who love the first trilogy will compare him to Cardan and find Oak both similar and lacking. Don&#8217;t misunderstand me&#8211;I like Oak and it&#8217;s clear he&#8217;s a complex, morally grounded young man (he&#8217;s 17, Wren is 19). It&#8217;s just that Wren is such a downer for most of the book and her depression colors how accessible Oak is.</p>\n<p>Oak, Wren, and Tiernan slog their way through magical fiefdoms all of which are deadly&#8211;I found myself wanting some nice fairies just to leaven the tale. By the time our trio arrives at the Court of Teeth&#8211;which takes too long&#8211;I was ready for something like happiness. This, dear reader, does not happen. The story ends bleakly although I am sure the duology will not. The final scenes are climactic, even exciting. I am curious to see what happens next&#8211;Wren&#8217;s actions in the last pages were, if not shocking, unsettling both for her and for Oak. Mistrust continues to rule the day even as the longing Wren feels for love simmers inside her.</p>\n<p>Black&#8217;s world building is dense&#8211;and, here, less crisp than in the <strong><em>Folk of Air</em></strong>.  The novel is bedecked with references to magical creatures from all cultures which were fun to learn about. I especially enjoyed the large and inadvertently droll trolls.</p>\n<p>Should you read it? If you&#8217;ve read the first trilogy, absolutely&#8230; with tempered expectations. If you&#8217;ve not, run out and pick up <a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/book-review/the-cruel-prince-and-the-wicked-king-by-holly-black/\"><strong>The Cruel Prince</strong></a>. It, unlike <strong>The Stolen Heir,</strong> is mesmerizing.</p>\n",
                "text": "Holly Black&#8217;s marvelous trilogy The Folk of Air is so damn good that when I heard she was continuing to explore the world of Elfhame, a kingdom of magical islands, I was thrilled. And cautious. Black&#8217;s novel after the trilogy, Book of Night, was a hot mess. Would a return to Elfhame be a return to the greatness that is the story of Jude and Cardan? Sadly, no. The Stolen Heir (the first of a duology) is worth reading but those who are looking for sublime will not find it in these 345 pages. Its heroine, Suren (Wren), the true Queen of the Court of Teeth, is less lovable than Jude and this book, the story of a quest she goes on with Jude&#8217;s younger brother Oak, the heir to the Kingdom of Elfhame and to whom Suren was once betrothed, meanders for too long before reaching a dramatic and rather horrifying conclusion. Wren is one traumatized blue skinned changeling. Born a faerie, she was raised in the human realm in a loving family until her truly evil parents, Lady Nore and Lord Jarel, kidnapped her. In the almost two years Suren, as she is known in Faerie, lived in the Court of Teeth, she was tortured and profoundly emotionally abused by her parents. At the end of The Queen of Nothing, the final book in the first trilogy, the Kingdom of Teeth is in ruins, Lord Jarel is dead, and Lady Nore has sworn fealty to Suren . Nine years later, Wren is homeless in the human world, wild, isolated and always alone. As this book begins, she is being hunted by Bogdana, the storm hag, whom Wren is sure is working for Lady Norel, now back and up to no good in the Court of Teeth. Panicking and trying to escape, Wren is running through the woods when she suddenly runs into Oak. Oak, preternaturally gorgeous and charming, offers Wren a deal. He and his knight, Tiernan, will protect Wren if she goes with them to the Court of Teeth. Oak is searching for the heart of Mellith, an object of great power which, were it to fall into Lady Nore&#8217;s hands, would doom the worlds magical and real. Wren is the only person in the kingdom who has any power over Lady Nore whom Wren absolutely loathes and so she agrees and the three set off. The Stolen Heir is, at its somewhat depressing heart, about the wounds of childhood trauma. Wren&#8217;s life has left her fearful and feral. She trusts no one, especially not Oak who, from her perspective, has led a charmed life as loved Elfhame royalty. Oak, who is the heir to the throne until Jude and Cardan start popping out babies, has suffered endless assassination attempts. And while his relationship with his loving sisters is straightforward, that with his adoptive redcap father, Madoc whom Lady Nore is holding captive, is complicated and dangerous. It&#8217;s obvious, perhaps overly so, that Oak and Wren care for one another, even love each other, but their interactions are full of lies and betrayal and a very rational mistrust. The novel is told only from Wren&#8217;s perspective&#8211;the second will be from Oak&#8217;s. As a narrator, Wren is glum. Over and over, she reminds herself, and the reader, that she is damaged, ugly, that Oak only is with her to use her power, and that everything sucks. She&#8217;s not wrong&#8211;this is a dark and fairly humorless book. Oak is a possible source of joy and laughter and yet, through Wren&#8217;s eyes, he comes across as somewhat flimsy. Those who love the first trilogy will compare him to Cardan and find Oak both similar and lacking. Don&#8217;t misunderstand me&#8211;I like Oak and it&#8217;s clear he&#8217;s a complex, morally grounded young man (he&#8217;s 17, Wren is 19). It&#8217;s just that Wren is such a downer for most of the book and her depression colors how accessible Oak is. Oak, Wren, and Tiernan slog their way through magical fiefdoms all of which are deadly&#8211;I found myself wanting some nice fairies just to leaven the tale. By the time our trio arrives at the Court of Teeth&#8211;which takes too long&#8211;I was ready for something like happiness. This, dear reader, does not happen. The story ends bleakly although I am sure the duology will not. The final scenes are climactic, even exciting. I am curious to see what happens next&#8211;Wren&#8217;s actions in the last pages were, if not shocking, unsettling both for her and for Oak. Mistrust continues to rule the day even as the longing Wren feels for love simmers inside her. Black&#8217;s world building is dense&#8211;and, here, less crisp than in the Folk of Air.  The novel is bedecked with references to magical creatures from all cultures which were fun to learn about. I especially enjoyed the large and inadvertently droll trolls. Should you read it? If you&#8217;ve read the first trilogy, absolutely&#8230; with tempered expectations. If you&#8217;ve not, run out and pick up The Cruel Prince. It, unlike The Stolen Heir, is mesmerizing."
            }

                "html": "<p>Have you read <a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/book-review/ninth-house-by-leigh-bardugo/\"><strong>Ninth House</strong></a>? Because if not&#8211;and you&#8217;re a loon if you haven&#8217;t&#8211;this review is a waste of your time. <strong>Hell Bent</strong> is the second book in Leigh Bardugo&#8217;s <strong><em>Alex Stern</em></strong> series and will likely to confuse those who haven&#8217;t read the first. But for those of you who have&#8230; here goes.</p>\n<p>Our story begins a few months after the literally spellbinding conclusion of <strong>Ninth House</strong> in which Darlington was sent to Hell by a now dead dean. Alex (Galaxy) Stern, now the Virgil of Lethe, the house that monitors the use of magic by Yale&#8217;s famed secret societies, has a lot on her plate. There&#8217;s the usual challenge of trying to pass her classes (her background as a low level drug dealer in L. A. really didn&#8217;t prepare her academically for the Ivy League), her work for Lethe (the ghosts she can see are more aggressive than ever), her very scary ex-boss in L.A. is forcing her to work for him, and, despite being told to drop it, she&#8217;s determined to open a portal to Hell and rescue Darlington, her mentor and possible paramour. To top it off, something is in Black Elm, Darlington&#8217;s large and dark house and that something is freaking Alex out.</p>\n<p>Fortunately, Alex, now in her second year at Yale, has a squad. There&#8217;s Pamela Dawes, the current Oculus at Lethe whose research skills are beyond impressive; Turner, a detective of the New Haven Police Department and liaison between Lethe House and the Chief of Police; Mercy Zhao, Alex&#8217;s roommate; and Tripp Helmuth, third generation Bonesman. All but one are, surprisingly, murderers and Alex will need them all in order to save Darlington and, to a lesser extent, the world.</p>\n<p><strong>Hell Bent</strong> proffers a profusion of riches. As is true in every Bardugo book, the world building is meticulous, dense, and brilliant. Not only is Yale so vividly portrayed it might has well be a character but New Haven, which Alex has to venture into on the orders of Eitan, her old supplier, is crisply manifested as well. The gripping plot is full of clever twists, and the writing is vivid and intelligent, with moments of wit and humor. However, the standout aspect of the book are the well-developed characters, particularly the four murderers, who each have a rich backstory that allows the reader to understand and empathize with them as they navigate the challenges of their journey through hell.</p>\n<p><strong>Hell Bent</strong> isn&#8217;t quite as gripping as <strong>Ninth House, </strong>perhaps because the catchy conceit of the series is no longer new.  And, like <strong>Ninth House</strong>, it ends on a cliffhanger although this one is far more abrupt. I will be eagerly anticipating the next installment&#8211;Bardugo has said she&#8217;d like to write at least five books featuring Alex&#8211;as will, I suspect thousands of others. Read these books, peeps. I promise, you&#8217;ll be transported.                 "html": "<p>In romance novels, the heroine is almost always under thirty. When older women &#8211; those over fifty &#8211; appear in romance, it&#8217;s usually as a secondary character who, if she&#8217;s very beautiful and has either a fortune or a heart of gold, might be lucky enough to have a lover of her own. Romance novels where the lead is over fifty are are as rare as Oscar winning rom coms. <strong>Flirting with the Beast</strong>, by Jane Porter, breaks that mold by featuring lead characters Andi McDermott and Wolf Enders, both of whom are well over fifty <em>and</em> sexy and smart.</p>\n<p>Andi McDermott is a widow at fifty-eight &#8211; her rather controlling husband Kevin died five years ago. Since he died, she&#8217;s found a job she loves and made new, supportive friends but still, <em>something</em> is missing. She&#8217;s lonely &#8211; she and Kevin never had kids although she is a stepmom to Luke, Kevin&#8217;s son whom he had as a teen. As the book begins, Luke has just blown Andi off for an early Christmas dinner Andi put a great deal of effort in preparing. Hurt and uninterested in spending the holidays in the giant house she and Kevin built &#8211; his dream home, not hers &#8211; she decides to head up to his family&#8217;s cabin four hours north on California&#8217;s Lake Arrowhead.</p>\n<p>Andi is a total babe &#8211; her husband was the college stud every girl wanted and since his death she&#8217;s dated several men, all of whom have been more interested in her than she is in them. Her marriage was&#8230; fine. The lack of children was a huge disappointment for Andi but not for Kevin and, over the decades, their passion and connection faded to a partnership rather than a romance. But while Andi didn&#8217;t really love being married to Kevin, she loved being married and would like to find a man with whom she can share her life.</p>\n<p>One man Andi is sure is not for her is Wolf Enders, her only neighbor up at the cabin. Wolf is&#8230; a lot. He&#8217;s big, tattooed, absurdly sexy &#8211; Kevin loathed him &#8211; and every time Andi makes eye contact with him she suddenly feels as though she&#8217;s naked. As soon as she gets to the cabin, she encounters Wolf and it&#8217;s as uncomfortable as ever. She decides to avoid him over her stay but when a major snow storm comes in and all of Lake Arrowhead loses power <em>and </em> Wolf has a generator, Andi begins to see Wolf &#8211; <em>all</em> of Wolf &#8211; very, very differently.</p>\n<p>Wolf &#8211; let me take a moment to fan myself &#8211; is the man of <del>my</del> many a woman&#8217;s dreams. He&#8217;s a decorated ex-Marine who now makes a living designing and drafting homes. He married young and is now, and has been for decades, bitterly divorced from his ex-wife with whom he had three sons. All three followed him into some sort of military service &#8211; his oldest, Stone, was blown to bits by a roadside bomb in Afghanistan.  Wolf cares deeply for his family but he loves his solitary life on the lake &#8211; he&#8217;s a man whose past mistakes have made him believe he&#8217;s a beast at relationships. He enjoys sex &#8211; he <em>loves</em> sex with Andi &#8211; but commitment is a hard pass for him. When it&#8217;s time for Andi to return to her home in San Juan Capistrano, he tells her their holiday tryst is a one and done.</p>\n<p>However, when Wolf&#8217;s ex-wife tells him that Stone&#8217;s young widow Lindsay is a mess and is endangering her three year old son Charlie, Wolf invites his daughter-in-law and grandson to come and live with him in California&#8230; at his house in Andi&#8217;s neighborhood. Andi is shocked to run into Wolf at her favorite coffee shop &#8211; she had no idea he had a home near her &#8211; and despite Wolf&#8217;s determination to stay aloof, he and Andi end up back in bed and in each other lives.</p>\n<p>Oh, how I love this book.</p>\n<p>Andi and Wolf are electric together. Their sex life is hot, inventive, energetic, and integral to their growing feelings for one another. It&#8217;s a gift to read about older lovers whose bouts in the sheets rival that of their much younger peers. They each think the other is gorgeous &#8211; I especially love that though Andi believes she needs to lose the weight she&#8217;s gained since Kevin died, Wolf thinks she&#8217;s sexy as sin just as she is. Their conversations are droll and engaging and illuminate how happy they make one another.</p>\n<p><strong>Flirting with the Beast</strong> deftly explores the complexities of relationships and the growth of love between two emotionally mature characters. Both Wolf and Andi care deeply for Lindsay and Charlie &#8211; the latter is one of the better rendered children I&#8217;ve read in romance &#8211; and that makes their lives together complicated. This is a book about growth, often hard won.  The happy endings in this book feel earned in the best way and I loved watching all the characters find the joy they deserve.</p>\n<p><strong>Flirting with the Beast</strong> is one of the best romances I&#8217;ve read in the past year. I&#8217;d love it even were the protagonists younger, but to have them be my age, well, that makes this book sublime. It&#8217;s a delightful, steamy read that will have you rooting for Andi&#8217;s and Wolf&#8217;s happily ever after. It gets a DIK from me.</p>\n",
                "text": "In romance novels, the heroine is almost always under thirty. When older women &#8211; those over fifty &#8211; appear in romance, it&#8217;s usually as a secondary character who, if she&#8217;s very beautiful and has either a fortune or a heart of gold, might be lucky enough to have a lover of her own. Romance novels where the lead is over fifty are are as rare as Oscar winning rom coms. Flirting with the Beast, by Jane Porter, breaks that mold by featuring lead characters Andi McDermott and Wolf Enders, both of whom are well over fifty and sexy and smart. Andi McDermott is a widow at fifty-eight &#8211; her rather controlling husband Kevin died five years ago. Since he died, she&#8217;s found a job she loves and made new, supportive friends but still, something is missing. She&#8217;s lonely &#8211; she and Kevin never had kids although she is a stepmom to Luke, Kevin&#8217;s son whom he had as a teen. As the book begins, Luke has just blown Andi off for an early Christmas dinner Andi put a great deal of effort in preparing. Hurt and uninterested in spending the holidays in the giant house she and Kevin built &#8211; his dream home, not hers &#8211; she decides to head up to his family&#8217;s cabin four hours north on California&#8217;s Lake Arrowhead. Andi is a total babe &#8211; her husband was the college stud every girl wanted and since his death she&#8217;s dated several men, all of whom have been more interested in her than she is in them. Her marriage was&#8230; fine. The lack of children was a huge disappointment for Andi but not for Kevin and, over the decades, their passion and connection faded to a partnership rather than a romance. But while Andi didn&#8217;t really love being married to Kevin, she loved being married and would like to find a man with whom she can share her life. One man Andi is sure is not for her is Wolf Enders, her only neighbor up at the cabin. Wolf is&#8230; a lot. He&#8217;s big, tattooed, absurdly sexy &#8211; Kevin loathed him &#8211; and every time Andi makes eye contact with him she suddenly feels as though she&#8217;s naked. As soon as she gets to the cabin, she encounters Wolf and it&#8217;s as uncomfortable as ever. She decides to avoid him over her stay but when a major snow storm comes in and all of Lake Arrowhead loses power and  Wolf has a generator, Andi begins to see Wolf &#8211; all of Wolf &#8211; very, very differently. Wolf &#8211; let me take a moment to fan myself &#8211; is the man of my many a woman&#8217;s dreams. He&#8217;s a decorated ex-Marine who now makes a living designing and drafting homes. He married young and is now, and has been for decades, bitterly divorced from his ex-wife with whom he had three sons. All three followed him into some sort of military service &#8211; his oldest, Stone, was blown to bits by a roadside bomb in Afghanistan.  Wolf cares deeply for his family but he loves his solitary life on the lake &#8211; he&#8217;s a man whose past mistakes have made him believe he&#8217;s a beast at relationships. He enjoys sex &#8211; he loves sex with Andi &#8211; but commitment is a hard pass for him. When it&#8217;s time for Andi to return to her home in San Juan Capistrano, he tells her their holiday tryst is a one and done. However, when Wolf&#8217;s ex-wife tells him that Stone&#8217;s young widow Lindsay is a mess and is endangering her three year old son Charlie, Wolf invites his daughter-in-law and grandson to come and live with him in California&#8230; at his house in Andi&#8217;s neighborhood. Andi is shocked to run into Wolf at her favorite coffee shop &#8211; she had no idea he had a home near her &#8211; and despite Wolf&#8217;s determination to stay aloof, he and Andi end up back in bed and in each other lives. Oh, how I love this book. Andi and Wolf are electric together. Their sex life is hot, inventive, energetic, and integral to their growing feelings for one another. It&#8217;s a gift to read about older lovers whose bouts in the sheets rival that of their much younger peers. They each think the other is gorgeous &#8211; I especially love that though Andi believes she needs to lose the weight she&#8217;s gained since Kevin died, Wolf thinks she&#8217;s sexy as sin just as she is. Their conversations are droll and engaging and illuminate how happy they make one another. Flirting with the Beast deftly explores the complexities of relationships and the growth of love between two emotionally mature characters. Both Wolf and Andi care deeply for Lindsay and Charlie &#8211; the latter is one of the better rendered children I&#8217;ve read in romance &#8211; and that makes their lives together complicated. This is a book about growth, often hard won.  The happy endings in this book feel earned in the best way and I loved watching all the characters find the joy they deserve. Flirting with the Beast is one of the best romances I&#8217;ve read in the past year. I&#8217;d love it even were the protagonists younger, but to have them be my age, well, that makes this book sublime. It&#8217;s a delightful, steamy read that will have you rooting for Andi&#8217;s and Wolf&#8217;s happily ever after. It gets a DIK from me."

Here, magic is as real as greed and first love can bind two souls together forever.</p>\n<p>Emery Blackwood and August Salt were born on the island thirty-two years ago. August fled Saoirse fourteen years ago after being accused of murdering Lily Morgan, Emery&#8217;s best friend. Now, August is back and the mystery of what happened that long ago night and the secrets the town has hidden have returned as well.</p>\n<p>Adrienne Young&#8217;s <strong>Spells for Forgetting</strong> is the first adult novel by this best selling YA author. It&#8217;s a book I started at eight pm and read straight through until the wee hours. A story of true love, powerful women, unstable magic, and betrayal&#8211;it held my attention in a way almost no other book has this year.</p>\n<p>Emery Blackwood was born into a family of witches all of whom have lived and died on Saoirse Island. The island is a place alive with literal magic. But <em><span class=\"i\">The Herbarium</span></em> was kept in the shop.</p>\n<p class=\"p\">The heavy, leather-bound book was a kind of diary where the Blackwood women recorded the recipes and herbal studies that had become a kind of textbook. August is on the ferry returning to the island to bury his mother&#8217;s ashes and, he hopes, finally cut ties with his past.</p>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p>To quote Faulkner, &#8220;<em>The past is never dead. It&#8217;s not even past.</em>&#8221; For August, Emery, and the town, August&#8217;s return lays waste to the present and, in doing so, offers Emery and August the possibility of a future they believed they lost the night the island burned.</p>\n<p><strong>Spells for Forgetting</strong> shares its secrets slowly. No one has ever told the truth about what happened fourteen years ago. Every character in the novel&#8211;the story is told from multiple perspectives&#8211;lied to those they loved and those to whom they wished harm. Young does a terrific job of limning the dozen men and women who people this book as well as the intricate relationships between them. For most of the book, I had no idea where the blame for Lily&#8217;s death would land.</p>\n<p>Would it be, as Emery still wonders, on August? And what did Lily&#8217;s death have to do with the orchard, the island&#8217;s crown jewel, now in the town&#8217;s possession, but for generations owned by first the Morgans and then the Salts?</p>\n<p>Young&#8217;s twisty solution is satisfying although readers who believe that evil should be soundly punished may come away somewhat disappointed. The epilogue suggests will be another book although the storylines in this one are resolved.</p>\n<p>As for the seemingly cursed lovers, well, Emery and August&#8217;s story is the best sort of second chance, slow burn romance. They are, in the way of many a magical tale, destined to be together and whether that&#8217;s a tragedy or a gift, well, you&#8217;ll have to read the book to know. <strong>Spells for Forgetting</strong> is one of my favorite books of the year. It&#8217;s a DIK from me.</p>\n",
                "text": "On Saoirse Island, a rain soaked isle in the Pacific Northwest, a murmuration of starlings portends death and the leaves on the trees may burst into color all at once. Here, magic is as real as greed and first love can bind two souls together forever. Emery Blackwood and August Salt were born on the island thirty-two years ago. August fled Saoirse fourteen years ago after being accused of murdering Lily Morgan, Emery&#8217;s best friend. Now, August is back and the mystery of what happened that long ago night and the secrets the town has hidden have returned as well. Adrienne Young&#8217;s Spells for Forgetting is the first adult novel by this best selling YA author. It&#8217;s a book I started at eight pm and read straight through until the wee hours. A story of true love, powerful women, unstable magic, and betrayal&#8211;it held my attention in a way almost no other book has this year. Emery Blackwood was born into a family of witches all of whom have lived and died on Saoirse Island. The island is a place alive with literal magic. Emery runs her family&#8217;s business, Blackwood&#8217;s Tea Shoppe Herbal Tonics &amp; Tea Leaf Readings, where she makes infusions for the tourists who flock to the island for its famous apples and its mystical brews. There were two books that were passed down in the family: The Herbarium and The Blackwood Book of Spells. The book of spells was kept at my grandmother Albertine’s, on the mantle above the fireplace. That would be its home until she departed this life, and then it would be given to me. But The Herbarium was kept in the shop. The heavy, leather-bound book was a kind of diary where the Blackwood women recorded the recipes and herbal studies that had become a kind of textbook. The thick parchment pages were covered in botanical sketches along with handwritten notes that filled the margins. It was used by every herbalist in the family, each one adding their research to it throughout their lifetime&#8230; Emery grew up with August, Lily, and Dutch Boden. But fourteen years ago, the island&#8217;s precious orchard burned, Lily was found dead in the forest, and August and his mother vanished. As the novel opens, Emery, as she does most mornings, is leaving Dutch&#8217;s bed before he wakes and again, as he has for the past six years, asks her to marry him. August is on the ferry returning to the island to bury his mother&#8217;s ashes and, he hopes, finally cut ties with his past. To quote Faulkner, &#8220;The past is never dead. It&#8217;s not even past.&#8221; For August, Emery, and the town, August&#8217;s return lays waste to the present and, in doing so, offers Emery and August the possibility of a future they believed they lost the night the island burned. Spells for Forgetting shares its secrets slowly. No one has ever told the truth about what happened fourteen years ago. Every character in the novel&#8211;the story is told from multiple perspectives&#8211;lied to those they loved and those to whom they wished harm. Young does a terrific job of limning the dozen men and women who people this book as well as the intricate relationships between them. For most of the book, I had no idea where the blame for Lily&#8217;s death would land. Would it be, as Emery still wonders, on August? On Dutch who now runs the orchard August&#8217;s family once owned? On Nixie, her mother&#8217;s last living friend? Or would it be Leoda Morgan, Lily&#8217;s grandmother and the town&#8217;s midwife and political power? What about Jakob, Emery&#8217;s uncle and the town&#8217;s soused sheriff? And what did Lily&#8217;s death have to do with the orchard, the island&#8217;s crown jewel, now in the town&#8217;s possession, but for generations owned by first the Morgans and then the Salts? Young&#8217;s twisty solution is satisfying although readers who believe that evil should be soundly punished may come away somewhat disappointed. The epilogue suggests will be another book although the storylines in this one are resolved. As for the seemingly cursed lovers, well, Emery and August&#8217;s story is the best sort of second chance, slow burn romance. They are, in the way of many a magical tale, destined to be together and whether that&#8217;s a tragedy or a gift, well, you&#8217;ll have to read the book to know. Spells for Forgetting is one of my favorite books of the year. It&#8217;s a DIK from me."

I enjoyed it but didn&#8217;t love it.</p>\n<p>It&#8217;s December in 2020 (this is a Covid free tale) and Madison Simcoe is furious. Yet another asshat at work has groped her which means she&#8217;ll probably need to quit her job. It&#8217;s almost Christmas and New York is cold, impersonal, and, for Madison who has no living family, no real friends, and a shitty married lover, a lonely place. Nothing she can think of will displace her gloomy rage, nothing, that is, but a trip to Macy&#8217;s.</p>\n<p>She arrives at the storied store and encounters a Santa with <em>warm and wise and knowing eyes</em> who, after she gives him twenty bucks, tells her &#8220;<em>Macy&#8217;s will have the answer.</em>&#8221; She&#8217;s shaken&#8211;<em>somehow for the first time in months, in years, she felt loved and cared for</em>. She turns away from him, pushes her way through the heavy doors of the store, and finds herself in what she first thinks is a holiday event&#8211;Macy&#8217;s must be decorated like the 50s! Slowly, over the next hours, however, Madison realizes that somehow, impossibly, she has been thrown back in time, specifically to 1947.</p>\n<p>Not only is she trapped in 1947, she&#8217;s trapped in Macy&#8217;s&#8211;the interior doors are locked to her. Fortunately, she&#8217;s met a tall, blonde, gorgeous, glowering man&#8211;John Larson&#8211;a WWII vet with PTSD who is responsible for much of the design of the store&#8217;s displays. John, for reasons I never really quite bought, lives in Macy&#8217;s and since Madison&#8211;whom John renames Mollie&#8211;has nowhere to go, she and John become uneasy storemates.</p>\n<p>John, a gruff, often rude hero who of course has a heart of gold, doesn&#8217;t know what to do with the crazy woman who has moved into his store. Her story of being from the future is either a lie or a sign of severe mental illness. But, she&#8217;s hot as hell and he lives to protect women from the bad men working at Macy&#8217;s&#8211;there are two and one of them is truly awful&#8211;so he makes Madison his responsibility.</p>\n<p>For her part, once she has settled into her new life&#8211;she works for John, sleeps in the employee lounge, makes a spunky best friend (Rosa), and tries to decide if she likes the late 40s better than the future&#8211;Madison spends most of her time thinking about John. You see Madison, like every Stuart heroine ever, hasn&#8217;t had much luck with men. Yes, she&#8217;s slept with lots&#8211;she is oddly proud of this, oddly because she didn&#8217;t really enjoy the sex&#8211;but (rolls eyes) she&#8217;s never met a man who could love, let alone have an easy orgasm with. John&#8217;s a surly jerk&#8211;or so she tells him and the reader far too many times&#8211;but she wants to kiss him even though, like every Stuart heroine ever, she&#8217;s never liked doing so before. The two have chemistry&#8211;Stuart writes attraction better than most&#8211;but it&#8217;s diffused by their often silly stubbornness.</p>\n<p>Madison is, actually, kind of a brat. John is too good to be true. The time travel piece of the story doesn&#8217;t make much sense. And unlike <a href=\"https://www.newyorker.com/books/page-turner/from-the-mixed-up-files-of-mrs-basil-e-frankweiler-fifty-years-later\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"><strong>From the Mixed Up Files of Mrs. Basil E. </strong><b>Frankweiler</b></a>, the concept of living in a famous place after hours isn&#8217;t sensibly limned. <strong>Return to Christmas</strong> doesn&#8217;t hold a Christmas candle to Stuart&#8217;s best&#8211;<a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/book-review/black-ice-by-anne-stuart/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"><strong>Black Ice</strong></a> or <a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/book-review/reckless-by-anne-stuart/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"><strong>Reckless.</strong></a> Still, it&#8217;s a fun read complete with a zinger of an epilogue. If you&#8217;re a Stuart fan, someone who loves old holiday films, and/or Macy&#8217;s devotee, you&#8217;ll enjoy this book. I know I did.</p>\n<h3 style=\"text-align: center;\"><b>Buy it at: <a href=\"https://amzn.to/3hdJ22G\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Amazon</a></b></h3>\n<h3 style=\"text-align: center;\"><b>Visit our <a href=\"https://amzn.to/2SeEiZg\">Amazon Storefront</a></b></h3>\n",

            "book": {
                "title": "Ninth House",
                "author_first": "Leigh",
                "author_last": "Bardugo",
                "publisher": "Flatiron",
                "isbn": "1250313074",
                "pages": "480",
                "publish_date": "10/2019",
                "grade": "A",
                "sensuality": "Subtle",
                "amazon_url": "https://amzn.to/3Bv4Y0D",
                "amazon_asin": "B07LF64DZ2"

            "content": {
                "html": "<p>The 1800 freshman matriculated at Yale University are likely a storied bunch. Over 35,000 applied to the famed Ivie&#8211;those accepted were likely the rock stars of their high schools with sky-high SATs and absurdly impressive resumes. None of them however have the talent that garners Galaxy &#8220;Alex&#8221; Stern, the protagonist of Leigh Bardugo&#8217;s splendid novel<strong> Ninth House</strong>, entry into New Haven&#8217;s hallowed halls. None of them see ghosts.</p>\n<p>Alex can not only see ghosts&#8211;Greys&#8211;she can interact with them. The Greys made her life a misery, one that she&#8217;d tried escaping by becoming a drug using&#8211;and dealing&#8211;high school dropout. All that changed when Alex, recovering in a hospital bed from an horrific violent incident, woke to see a dean from Yale there to offer her a full ride at the school. The catch? She&#8217;ll use her wraith watching skills to help the Lethe Society, one of Yale&#8217;s famously mysterious secret societies.</p>\n<p>The fictional Lethe is the ninth house and, unlike the other societies in the book, is a product of Bardugo&#8217;s astonishingly inventive imagination. In <strong>Ninth House</strong>, the renowned prestigious and powerful clubs&#8211;Skull and Bones, Manuscript, Aurelian, Scroll and Key, Wolf&#8217;s Head, Book and Snake, St. Elmo&#8217;s, and Berzelius&#8211;each channel, via ritual, a particular brand of magic. Skull and Bones specializes in divination, Scroll and Key in portal magic, Wolf&#8217;s Head in shapeshifting, Manuscript in glamours, Aurelian in logomancy, Book and Snake in necromancy, and St. Elmo&#8217;s in elemental magic. (Berzelius is inept.) Lethe House&#8217;s charter is to oversee these magical machinations.</p>\n<p>Alex and the other two current members of Lethe, golden boy Darlington and socially awkward Dawes, are tasked with ensuring when the other societies use magic, nothing unexpected happens. Alex&#8217;s ability to see Greys&#8211;unheard of even in the magical world&#8211;means, among other things, she can monitor and, in theory, prevent the undead from disrupting the rituals.</p>\n<p>In the book&#8217;s first chapter Alex, running late, arrives in a hidden classroom to watch the quarterly prognostication by Skull and Bones.</p>\n<blockquote><p>All eyes were on the Haruspex, his lean face hidden behind a surgical mask, pale blue robes spattered with blood. His latex-gloved hands moved methodically through the bowels of the—patient?&#8230;</p>\n<p>&#8230;she focused her gaze on some middle distance as the Haruspex called out a series of numbers and letters—stock symbols and share prices for companies traded publicly on the New York Stock Exchange. Later in the night he’d move on to the NASDAQ, Euronext, and the Asian markets. Alex didn’t bother trying to decipher them. The orders to buy, sell, or hold were given in impenetrable Dutch, the language of commerce, the first stock exchange, old New York, and the official language of the Bonesmen. When Skull and Bones was founded, too many students knew Greek and Latin. Their dealings had required something more obscure.</p></blockquote>\n<p>Terrifyingly, the Greys watching the ritual almost derail it and Alex&#8211;and only Alex&#8211;hears a deafening sound of something terrifying knocking from some other world. Afterwards, as she walks home, Alex learns that a townie named Tara has been brutally murdered. Alex thinks there&#8217;s a connection but is told to ignore it&#8211;Tara&#8217;s not a Yalie. The night&#8217;s events launch a ferociously irresistible plot rife with danger, drugs, arcane enchantments, adulation, and betrayal.</p>\n<p>The novel is as gripping a thriller as any I&#8217;ve read. The story moves brilliantly between three timelines all of which we experience through Alex. This is a gift. Alex is an outsider, a So-Cal loser whose sees Yale as both her savior and one fucked up place. Whether she&#8217;s communicating with The Bridegroom, New Haven&#8217;s most famous and allegedly murderous ghost, trying to fit in with her advantaged classmates, or fighting for her life, she holds the reader&#8217;s interest implacably. I could read about the adventures of Galaxy Stern all day long&#8211;thank the gods book two, <strong>Hell Bent</strong>, comes out in January.</p>\n<p>The world she inhabits is vividly limned by Bardugo. Her magic infused New Haven is every bit as intricate and credible as her <a href=\"https://amzn.to/3Saocy1\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Ketterdam</a>. She blends our world with hers, name checking the famous and powerful of alums of the different societies-Jodie Foster from Manuscript, Dr. Spock from Wolf&#8217;s Head, Cole Porter from Scroll and Key, both Bush presidents from Skull and Bones&#8211;so well the reader loses track of which is which. (Bardugo is a Yale graduate and while there was a member of Wolf&#8217;s Head.)</p>\n<p><strong>Ninth House</strong> is an almost flawless read. I read it last year and then again this week. Both times, I resented my time away from its pages. I can&#8217;t recommend it enough.</p>\n<h3 style=\"text-align: center;\"><b>Buy it at: <a href=\"https://amzn.to/3DymRwU\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Amazon</a>, <a href=\"https://amzn.to/3DCVMZO\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Audible</a> or your <a href=\"https://www.indiebound.org/book/9781473227989?aff=allaboutromance\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">local independent retailer</a></b></h3>\n<h3 style=\"text-align: center;\"><b>Visit our <a href=\"https://amzn.to/2SeEiZg\">Amazon Storefront</a></b></h3>\n",
                "text": "The 1800 freshman matriculated at Yale University are likely a storied bunch. Over 35,000 applied to the famed Ivie&#8211;those accepted were likely the rock stars of their high schools with sky-high SATs and absurdly impressive resumes. None of them however have the talent that garners Galaxy &#8220;Alex&#8221; Stern, the protagonist of Leigh Bardugo&#8217;s splendid novel Ninth House, entry into New Haven&#8217;s hallowed halls. None of them see ghosts. Alex can not only see ghosts&#8211;Greys&#8211;she can interact with them. The Greys made her life a misery, one that she&#8217;d tried escaping by becoming a drug using&#8211;and dealing&#8211;high school dropout. All that changed when Alex, recovering in a hospital bed from an horrific violent incident, woke to see a dean from Yale there to offer her a full ride at the school. The catch? She&#8217;ll use her wraith watching skills to help the Lethe Society, one of Yale&#8217;s famously mysterious secret societies. The fictional Lethe is the ninth house and, unlike the other societies in the book, is a product of Bardugo&#8217;s astonishingly inventive imagination. In Ninth House, the renowned prestigious and powerful clubs&#8211;Skull and Bones, Manuscript, Aurelian, Scroll and Key, Wolf&#8217;s Head, Book and Snake, St. Elmo&#8217;s, and Berzelius&#8211;each channel, via ritual, a particular brand of magic. Skull and Bones specializes in divination, Scroll and Key in portal magic, Wolf&#8217;s Head in shapeshifting, Manuscript in glamours, Aurelian in logomancy, Book and Snake in necromancy, and St. Elmo&#8217;s in elemental magic. (Berzelius is inept.) Lethe House&#8217;s charter is to oversee these magical machinations. Alex and the other two current members of Lethe, golden boy Darlington and socially awkward Dawes, are tasked with ensuring when the other societies use magic, nothing unexpected happens. Alex&#8217;s ability to see Greys&#8211;unheard of even in the magical world&#8211;means, among other things, she can monitor and, in theory, prevent the undead from disrupting the rituals. In the book&#8217;s first chapter Alex, running late, arrives in a hidden classroom to watch the quarterly prognostication by Skull and Bones. All eyes were on the Haruspex, his lean face hidden behind a surgical mask, pale blue robes spattered with blood. His latex-gloved hands moved methodically through the bowels of the—patient?&#8230; &#8230;she focused her gaze on some middle distance as the Haruspex called out a series of numbers and letters—stock symbols and share prices for companies traded publicly on the New York Stock Exchange. Later in the night he’d move on to the NASDAQ, Euronext, and the Asian markets. Alex didn’t bother trying to decipher them. The orders to buy, sell, or hold were given in impenetrable Dutch, the language of commerce, the first stock exchange, old New York, and the official language of the Bonesmen. When Skull and Bones was founded, too many students knew Greek and Latin. Their dealings had required something more obscure. Terrifyingly, the Greys watching the ritual almost derail it and Alex&#8211;and only Alex&#8211;hears a deafening sound of something terrifying knocking from some other world. Afterwards, as she walks home, Alex learns that a townie named Tara has been brutally murdered. Alex thinks there&#8217;s a connection but is told to ignore it&#8211;Tara&#8217;s not a Yalie. The night&#8217;s events launch a ferociously irresistible plot rife with danger, drugs, arcane enchantments, adulation, and betrayal. The novel is as gripping a thriller as any I&#8217;ve read. The story moves brilliantly between three timelines all of which we experience through Alex. This is a gift. Alex is an outsider, a So-Cal loser whose sees Yale as both her savior and one fucked up place. Whether she&#8217;s communicating with The Bridegroom, New Haven&#8217;s most famous and allegedly murderous ghost, trying to fit in with her advantaged classmates, or fighting for her life, she holds the reader&#8217;s interest implacably. I could read about the adventures of Galaxy Stern all day long&#8211;thank the gods book two, Hell Bent, comes out in January. The world she inhabits is vividly limned by Bardugo. Her magic infused New Haven is every bit as intricate and credible as her Ketterdam. She blends our world with hers, name checking the famous and powerful of alums of the different societies-Jodie Foster from Manuscript, Dr. Spock from Wolf&#8217;s Head, Cole Porter from Scroll and Key, both Bush presidents from Skull and Bones&#8211;so well the reader loses track of which is which. (Bardugo is a Yale graduate and while there was a member of Wolf&#8217;s Head.) Ninth House is an almost flawless read. I read it last year and then again this week.                 "html": "<p>The first book I read by Karin Slaughter was <a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/book-review/pieces-of-her-by-karin-slaughter/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"><strong>Pieces of Her</strong></a>. Like our reviewer, I couldn&#8217;t put it down and, upon finishing it, I read EVERY SINGLE NOVEL she&#8217;s written. That said, <strong>Pieces of Her</strong> is bonkers and I wasn&#8217;t crazy about Andy, the young woman whose mother&#8217;s past is told in the book. Thus, when I saw that Andy was the lead in Slaughter&#8217;s most recent work, <strong>Girl, Forgotten</strong>, I was somewhat apprehensive.</p>\n<p>I need not have been. Here, Andy is a well-rounded, sane detective whose behavior never veers into batshit crazy or TSTL behavior. Instead, she&#8217;s methodically trying to solve a cold case in the small, insular town she&#8217;s moved to in order to leave behind the trauma of the events in <strong>Pieces of Her</strong>. (<strong>Girl, Forgotten</strong> can be read as a stand alone but you&#8217;ll understand it much better if you&#8217;ve read <strong>Pieces of Her</strong>.)</p>\n<p>Andrea is now a US Marshall and has been assigned to protect a judge, one Esther Vaughn, the subject of violent death threats. Forty years ago, Esther&#8217;s daughter, Emily was brutally attacked and left brain dead. She was kept alive long enough to deliver the child she was carrying and then died. Her murder remains unsolved. The Vaughns still live in Longbill, Delaware as do Emily&#8217;s teenage circle of friends all of whom had reasons to harm Emily.</p>\n<p>This case is also connected to Andrea&#8217;s birth father, the murderous Clayton Morrow, who, after being jailed for thirty years for things he did in <strong>Pieces of Her</strong>, is up for parole in six months. Clayton, born Nicholas Harp, hailed from Longbill and had a connection to Emily back in the day. Andrea is determined to find out what truly happened to Emily, in part because she is trying to determine if Clayton was Emily&#8217;s killer&#8211;Andrea very much does not want Clayton to be free and were he to be charged with more crimes, he&#8217;d remain incarcerated. Furthermore, something is still very wrong in Longbill- including a nearby fava bean farm run by two of Emily&#8217;s old friends whose workers are almost all emaciated, terrified young women.</p>\n<p>This is a dual timeline tale. We see the final months of Emily&#8217;s life in 1982&#8211;and whoa, the early 80s do <strong>not</strong> come off well here. So many cults, drugs, and horribly privileged, sexist and racist males! Still, I enjoyed these chapters&#8211;Emily, though overly naive, is a smart, intrepid young woman and it&#8217;s harrowing to see how the choices she makes sentence her to death. Slaughter is a gifted world builder and, in this past as well as in the present, Longbill is a vibrant and believable community.</p>\n<p>I was less enamored of the storyline in the present. The fava bean farm&#8211;a truly horrible place&#8211;mirrors the contexts of several other Slaughter books. If you&#8217;re looking for yet another Karin Slaughter novel where odious men confine, abuse, and discard innocent young women&#8211;and she has too many&#8211;this one&#8217;s for you. I also just don&#8217;t care about Andrea&#8217;s polemic spouting father, Clayton Morrow. He&#8217;s EVIL. <em>We know.</em> Move on.</p>\n<p>I did, however, appreciate Adrea&#8217;s detective work and her relationship with her partner Leonard &#8216;Catfish&#8217; Bible, an older Marshall whose insights and personal life are routinely amusing. As usual, Slaughter does a superb job of melding her stories and the final chapters are compelling. And though the violence inflicted on women&#8211;a hallmark of Slaughter&#8217;s work&#8211;is present, it&#8217;s less on the page than usual and has less of a torture porn vibe.</p>\n<p>I will continue to read Karin Slaughter&#8211;MORE <a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/review-tag/will-trent-series/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"><em>WILL TRENT</em> BOOKS</a> PLEASE&#8211;and if you&#8217;re a fan of her work, you&#8217;ll like this. Indeed, if you read smart, can&#8217;t put down mysteries, this fits the bill. It&#8217;s not my favorite of the author&#8217;s work&#8211;that&#8217;s a tie between <a href=\"https://amzn.to/3ABMQlg\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"><strong>False Witness</strong></a> and <a href=\"https://amzn.to/3AduBkW\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"><strong>Criminal</strong></a>&#8211;but it&#8217;s a strong book and I recommend it.</p>\n<h3 style=\"text-align: center;\"><b>Buy it at: <a href=\"https://amzn.to/3A3bauV\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Amazon</a>, <a href=\"https://amzn.to/3CcPUWc\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Audible</a> or your <a href=\"https://www.indiebound.org/book/9780062858115?aff=allaboutromance\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">local independent retailer</a></b></h3>\n<h3 style=\"text-align: center;\"><b>Visit our <a href=\"https://amzn.to/2SeEiZg\">Amazon Storefront</a></b></h3>\n",
