                "html": "<p>There was a time when I read lots of category romances&#8230; almost all of which were written by the fabulous <a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/author-books-profile/?afname=Sarah&amp;alname=Mayberry\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Sarah Mayberry</a>, none of which were <em>Harlequin Presents</em>. But I like Caitlin Crews/Megan Crane&#8217;s work and I thought it would be fun to check out what she does with the rules of <em>Presents</em>. They are, according to Harlequin:</p>\n<blockquote><p><strong>Harlequin Presents Key Elements</strong></p>\n<ul>\n<li>A hero who will command and seduce. There&#8217;s nothing in the world his powerful authority and money can&#8217;t buy…except the love of a woman strong enough to tame him!</li>\n<li>A Harlequin Presents heroine isn&#8217;t afraid to stand up to the hero in her own way, whether she&#8217;s at home in his opulent world or not. She can be shy and innocent, feisty and daring or anywhere in between.</li>\n<li>These stories are pure romantic fantasy with glitzy, glamorous, international settings to upstage even the swankiest of red-carpet premieres!</li>\n<li>High sensuality and sky-rocketing sexual tension to quicken your pulse</li>\n<li>Captivating internal emotional conflicts that will sustain the story over the course of 50,000 words.</li>\n<li>Tone should be contemporary but with a strong intensity, delivering an instant hit of powerful emotion</li>\n<li>Give classic themes a fresh 21st century twist &#8211; tease, surprise and delight.</li>\n</ul>\n</blockquote>\n<p>In <strong>Willed to Wed Him</strong>, our hero is Ranieri Furlan, CEO. He&#8217;s fabulously wealthy, gorgeous, arrogant, and supremely self-controlled. As Crews writes, <em>Ranieri looked as if he was the man all James Bonds had tried, and failed, to emulate.</em> He is, of course, Italian, has an impeccable wardrobe and the sexual skills and virility of, well, I don&#8217;t know who because this is a <em>Presents</em> so it&#8217;s definitely outside the scope of my humdrum experience.</p>\n<p>Ranieri, under the terms of Bennett Schuyler, the recently deceased owner of The Schuyler Corporation which Ranieri runs, must marry Annika Schuyler, Bennett&#8217;s daughter, in order to keep his job. The two must be engaged within 24 hours of the reading of the will&#8211;this is when the book begins&#8211;, be living together within one week, and wed within the month. The marriage must last at least one year.</p>\n<p>If they follow the will&#8217;s directions, Annika will be able to keep Schuyler House, the museum that Annika&#8217;s grandparents had built during New York&#8217;s Gilded Age. (Think a lesser <a href=\"https://www.frick.org/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Frick</a>.) Annika runs Schuyler House and can&#8217;t imagine her life without it.</p>\n<p>Annika and Ranieri, after Ranieri has booted all the lawyers out of the lawyers&#8217; swanky Manhattan conference room, agree to obey the letter of the law of the will. They have know each other for years, since Annika was a teenager and Ranieri had finished business school at Harvard. They don&#8217;t get along&#8211;Annika is careless dresser who cares little for what others think and it&#8217;s clear that Ranieri thinks she&#8217;s an embarrassment to her family&#8217;s prestigious name. But, in following her father&#8217;s will, their interests align.</p>\n<p>There&#8217;s a problem, however. Ranieri is sure that New York will never believe a man like him would marry a mess like Annika. So, because it&#8217;s a <em>Presents</em>, he announces that they&#8217;ll tell the world they were both carried away by passion. After leaving the law office and stopping off to pick up a Furlan family heirloom&#8211;<em>a ring with a one of a kind, <a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/deal/pride-and-pleasure-by-sylvia-day-is-1-99/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">sixteen carat Asscher-cut diamond</a></em><a href=\"https://www.brilliance.com/recently-purchased-rings/luxury-custom-16-carat-asscher-cut-diamond-ring\">&#8211;</a>-the two are engaged. For the first couple of weeks, there&#8217;s actually no passion, just parties and corporate events, dress fittings, and Ranieri ultimatums.</p>\n<p>Then, after Annika uses behaving like an idiot in public to try get Ranieri to break the engagement&#8211;at this point she has fulfilled enough of the terms of her father&#8217;s will to be able to hold on to the Museum&#8211;Ranieri is left with no choice but to kiss her passionately. (It&#8217;s a <em>Presents</em>.) Annika&#8211;a (color me shocked I tell you!) virgin&#8211;is remade by this kiss and Ranieri is undone. The two keep kissing right up until their wedding day after which they go on a honeymoon that puts every honeymoon ever to shame. It&#8217;s in Italy, all they do is make love, eat incredible food someone else cooked, admire the countryside, make more love, and talk.</p>\n<p>But into this bliss a conflict must fall and does so when Ranieri&#8217;s absolutely dreadful parents arrive. Their rotten behavior reminds Ranieri that Furlans always destroy those they love so of course he MUST SEND ANNIKA AWAY lest he break her heart.</p>\n<p>You know how this turns out.</p>\n<div class=\"su-spoiler su-spoiler-style-fancy su-spoiler-icon-plus su-spoiler-closed\" data-scroll-offset=\"0\" data-anchor-in-url=\"no\"><div class=\"su-spoiler-title\" tabindex=\"0\" role=\"button\"><span class=\"su-spoiler-icon\"></span>Spoiler</div><div class=\"su-spoiler-content su-u-clearfix su-u-trim\">I was, though, genuinely shocked that, as told in the epilogue, they had seven children. There was no mention of nannies. I guess that&#8217;s a happy ending but still. Seven? </div></div>\n<p>What makes a story like this great is how well this predictable tale is told. And, let me assure you, Caitlin Crews tells this story wonderfully. Ranieri and Annika are vivid characters, each with their own wounds, needs, thoughts, and fears. I was expecting to roll my eyes through their love story. I did not. I thoroughly enjoyed getting to know them and watching them fall in love. Yes, Ranieri&#8217;s an idiot but Crews makes his bad behavior understandable. Prior to Bennett&#8217;s death, Annika and Ranieri didn&#8217;t know each other&#8211;they saw only the externality of the other. As they fall in love, they do so because in seeing the truth in the other, they also become accepting of themselves. This is a feel good story with genuine psychological depth.</p>\n<p><strong>Willed to Wed Him</strong> didn&#8217;t really sell me on <em>Presents</em>. But it reinforced my love for Crews&#8217; work. In some ways, her fabulous dystopian Viking <a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/review-tag/edge-series/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"><strong><em>Edge</em></strong></a> series (written as Megan Crane) couldn&#8217;t be more different than this novel. But whether she&#8217;s writing about absurdly wealthy men in Armani suits who love billionaire heiresses or sex-loving Viking raiders who take their women captive, she tells stories about interesting, believable people in a smart, sexy, unusual way. I enjoyed <strong>Willed to Wed Him</strong>, limos and all.</p>\n<h3 style=\"text-align: center;\"><b>Buy it at: <a href=\"https://amzn.to/3O3SbVY\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Amazon</a> or your <a href=\"https://www.indiebound.org/book/9781335738653?aff=allaboutromance\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">local independent retailer</a></b></h3>\n<h3 style=\"text-align: center;\"><b>Visit our <a href=\"https://amzn.to/2SeEiZg\">Amazon Storefront</a></b></h3>\n",
                "text": "There was a time when I read lots of category romances&#8230; almost all of which were written by the fabulous Sarah Mayberry, none of which were Harlequin Presents. But I like Caitlin Crews/Megan Crane&#8217;s work and I thought it would be fun to check out what she does with the rules of Presents. They are, according to Harlequin: Harlequin Presents Key Elements A hero who will command and seduce. There&#8217;s nothing in the world his powerful authority and money can&#8217;t buy…except the love of a woman strong enough to tame him! A Harlequin Presents heroine isn&#8217;t afraid to stand up to the hero in her own way, whether she&#8217;s at home in his opulent world or not. She can be shy and innocent, feisty and daring or anywhere in between. These stories are pure romantic fantasy with glitzy, glamorous, international settings to upstage even the swankiest of red-carpet premieres! High sensuality and sky-rocketing sexual tension to quicken your pulse Captivating internal emotional conflicts that will sustain the story over the course of 50,000 words. Tone should be contemporary but with a strong intensity, delivering an instant hit of powerful emotion Give classic themes a fresh 21st century twist &#8211; tease, surprise and delight. In Willed to Wed Him, our hero is Ranieri Furlan, CEO. He&#8217;s fabulously wealthy, gorgeous, arrogant, and supremely self-controlled. As Crews writes, Ranieri looked as if he was the man all James Bonds had tried, and failed, to emulate. He is, of course, Italian, has an impeccable wardrobe and the sexual skills and virility of, well, I don&#8217;t know who because this is a Presents so it&#8217;s definitely outside the scope of my humdrum experience. Ranieri, under the terms of Bennett Schuyler, the recently deceased owner of The Schuyler Corporation which Ranieri runs, must marry Annika Schuyler, Bennett&#8217;s daughter, in order to keep his job. The two must be engaged within 24 hours of the reading of the will&#8211;this is when the book begins&#8211;, be living together within one week, and wed within the month. The marriage must last at least one year. If they follow the will&#8217;s directions, Annika will be able to keep Schuyler House, the museum that Annika&#8217;s grandparents had built during New York&#8217;s Gilded Age. (Think a lesser Frick.) Annika runs Schuyler House and can&#8217;t imagine her life without it. Annika and Ranieri, after Ranieri has booted all the lawyers out of the lawyers&#8217; swanky Manhattan conference room, agree to obey the letter of the law of the will. They have know each other for years, since Annika was a teenager and Ranieri had finished business school at Harvard. They don&#8217;t get along&#8211;Annika is careless dresser who cares little for what others think and it&#8217;s clear that Ranieri thinks she&#8217;s an embarrassment to her family&#8217;s prestigious name. But, in following her father&#8217;s will, their interests align. There&#8217;s a problem, however. Ranieri is sure that New York will never believe a man like him would marry a mess like Annika. So, because it&#8217;s a Presents, he announces that they&#8217;ll tell the world they were both carried away by passion. After leaving the law office and stopping off to pick up a Furlan family heirloom&#8211;a ring with a one of a kind, sixteen carat Asscher-cut diamond&#8211;-the two are engaged. For the first couple of weeks, there&#8217;s actually no passion, just parties and corporate events, dress fittings, and Ranieri ultimatums. Then, after Annika uses behaving like an idiot in public to try get Ranieri to break the engagement&#8211;at this point she has fulfilled enough of the terms of her father&#8217;s will to be able to hold on to the Museum&#8211;Ranieri is left with no choice but to kiss her passionately. (It&#8217;s a Presents.) Annika&#8211;a (color me shocked I tell you!) virgin&#8211;is remade by this kiss and Ranieri is undone. The two keep kissing right up until their wedding day after which they go on a honeymoon that puts every honeymoon ever to shame. It&#8217;s in Italy, all they do is make love, eat incredible food someone else cooked, admire the countryside, make more love, and talk. But into this bliss a conflict must fall and does so when Ranieri&#8217;s absolutely dreadful parents arrive. Their rotten behavior reminds Ranieri that Furlans always destroy those they love so of course he MUST SEND ANNIKA AWAY lest he break her heart. You know how this turns out. SpoilerI was, though, genuinely shocked that, as told in the epilogue, they had seven children. There was no mention of nannies. I guess that&#8217;s a happy ending but still. Seven? What makes a story like this great is how well this predictable tale is told. And, let me assure you, Caitlin Crews tells this story wonderfully. Ranieri and Annika are vivid characters, each with their own wounds, needs, thoughts, and fears. I was expecting to roll my eyes through their love story. I did not. I thoroughly enjoyed getting to know them and watching them fall in love. Yes, Ranieri&#8217;s an idiot but Crews makes his bad behavior understandable. Prior to Bennett&#8217;s death, Annika and Ranieri didn&#8217;t know each other&#8211;they saw only the externality of the other. As they fall in love, they do so because in seeing the truth in the other, they also become accepting of themselves. This is a feel good story with genuine psychological depth. Willed to Wed Him didn&#8217;t really sell me on Presents. But it reinforced my love for Crews&#8217; work. In some ways, her fabulous dystopian Viking Edge series (written as Megan Crane) couldn&#8217;t be more different than this novel. But whether she&#8217;s writing about absurdly wealthy men in Armani suits who love billionaire heiresses or sex-loving Viking raiders who take their women captive, she tells stories about interesting, believable people in a smart, sexy, unusual way. I enjoyed Willed to Wed Him, limos and all. Buy it at: Amazon or your local independent retailer Visit our Amazon Storefront"

When Owusu sends the evidence for examination, he learns the bones are connected to a cold case that left three people dead on the kitchen floor in a Chelsea mansion thirty years ago.</i></p>\n<p><em>Rachel Rimmer has also received a shock—news that her husband, Michael, has been found dead in the cellar of his house in France. (It&#8217;s a sequel to <a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/book-review/the-family-upstairs-by-lisa-jewell/\"><strong>The Family Upstairs</strong></a>.) Knowing who most of these characters are and their backstory really makes a difference in how you read the tale. What do you think? Did this work as a standalone?</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><strong>Dabney</strong>: Well… I didn’t realize until I finished it that it was a sequel, of sorts. And I loved it! So I think, if you don’t know better, it works just fine as a standalone. That said, I suspect having read </span><a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/book-review/the-family-upstairs-by-lisa-jewell/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"><b>The Family Upstairs</b></a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> might have made for a richer reading experience. Was that the case for you?</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><strong>Maggie</strong>: Yes.I think otherwise some of the behaviors/events would have seemed odd or downright inexplicable.&nbsp;</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">How would you describe these characters just based on what you learned in this text?&nbsp;</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><strong>Dabney</strong>: It’s true that Lucy, Henry, and Phin were all very mysterious for the first part of the book. But as someone who reads a ton of mysteries, I found that to be normal. My take was that they all had secrets I’d discover as I read which did indeed happen.&nbsp;</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><strong>Maggie</strong>. I think that’s a good take on it, though I would argue that in the first novel, which was more of a psychological thriller/gothic than a mystery, they all had much deeper, darker edges to them. Henry especially seemed less somehow; the Henry of the </span><b>The Family Remains</b><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> appears almost incapable of doing what the Henry of </span><b>The Family Upstairs </b><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">did. I’d also argue that there is no real mystery at the start of the novel for those of us who read that first volume. We know what happened to whom and why.&nbsp;</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">On another note, let’s talk about the characters unique to this tale. I thought Marco was what Henry would have been if it weren’t for Henry’s horrific childhood and I absolutely loved him. Normally, youngsters that savvy drive me crazy but he was great. Rachel is another “newcomer” and I found her tale riveting. She’s so strong, resilient, and positive. A Lucy without all the darkness that has defined that woman’s life. What did you think of them?</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><strong>Dabney</strong>: I really enjoyed Rachel’s story – Jewel makes her actions both sympathetic and understandable. Rachel’s able to overcome her bad choices in a way that Lucy struggles to do. I liked seeing how their stories were different and yet similar. Marco was a great kid – believable and able to help his mom in interesting ways. I loved his friendship with Alf – my age group loves to bemoan how the young use technology. It was fun to see the two boys harness that power for good!</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><strong>Maggie</strong>: In fairness, the struggles that Lucy had to deal with in book one &#8211; which are only alluded to in much of this book &#8211; were far more severe than Rachel’s. I loved that both women had the strength to endure and move on. &nbsp; How would you describe the story (mystery/gothic/suspense/general fiction)&nbsp; and what would you say is the driving factor in it?</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><strong>Dabney</strong>: I would say it’s suspenseful but not intensely so. It’s more an explanation of a stressful time rather than a real time thriller. I liked that about it. Like good mysteries–really like all good fiction – </span><b>The Family Remains </b><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">shows you the why behind people’s actions. Everyone in the book behaved in ways that were true to the characters (IN THIS BOOK) were written. I hate books where people act in ways that make no sense in the context of their stories!</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><strong>Maggie</strong>: I would agree with your depiction of the story as more mystery than thriller. I do struggle with the question of the behaviors being true to the characters because I have that back story from the first novel and they don’t seem quite like the people in that book.&nbsp;</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">One factor that moves this story more towards a whodunit style narrative is the police investigation led by DI Samuel Owosu. I absolutely loved his character and thought he was everything a thorough, dedicated, compassionate officer of the law should be. And I enjoyed watching that investigation unfold knowing what I knew from </span><b>The Family Upstairs </b><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">and wondering if he would truly be able to unpack the complex mess behind Birdie’s murder. What did you think of him and that aspect of the tale?</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><strong>Dabney</strong>: It really sounds as if we read two different books! Plus he has his own sense of honor which makes the choices he makes thoughtful and not necessarily predictable. I had faith he’d figure it out!</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><strong>Maggie:</strong> I’m so excited that Aaron Falk book three comes out in January! It’s interesting that you mention your qualms about going back to read </span><b>The Family Upstairs</b><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> because I’ve wondered whether these are books that can be read backwards and I just don’t know. There was so much I loved about that first volume but knowing what happens may indeed take all the suspense out of it. I would really recommend that readers that have a chance to do so start with the first book.&nbsp;</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Phinn is the impetus for much of our tale &#8211; the search for him is the primary driving factor of this particular story &#8211; but I don’t want to say too much about him because of how impactful that plotline is to this narrative. I knew Phinn, what had happened to him, and why everyone was so freaked out that Henry was going after him. I understood Lucy’s urgency when she chased after her brother. It made Henry creepy. Even by the book’s end, that storyline was my least favorite although I loved the way Marco played into that.&nbsp;</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><strong>Maggie:</strong> The Phinn story is a stalker story, even with the background. Overall, I think those who have read </span><b>The Family Upstairs </b><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">will be happy to read this just to have some additional closure for the characters in that volume. There is a bit of rewriting history here &#8211; Henry especially went from being chilling to simply being a man from a desperate situation &#8211; but the tale is enjoyable and DI Sam and Rachel are both compelling characters who make </span><b>The Family Remains</b><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> well worth a read. I would give this a B+: It’s a solid story with some interesting mystery angles to it. It does, however, lack the dark, eerie edge of the first book.&nbsp;</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><strong>Dabney:</strong> I’d give it a B+/A-.                 "text": "Early one morning on the shore of the Thames, DCI Samuel Owusu is called to the scene of a gruesome discovery. When Owusu sends the evidence for examination, he learns the bones are connected to a cold case that left three people dead on the kitchen floor in a Chelsea mansion thirty years ago. Rachel Rimmer has also received a shock—news that her husband, Michael, has been found dead in the cellar of his house in France. All signs point to an intruder, and the French police need her to come urgently to answer questions about Michael and his past that she very much doesn’t want to answer. As they all race to discover answers to these convoluted mysteries, they will come to find that they’re connected in ways they could have never imagined. Dabney and Maggie are both fans of Lisa Jewell&#8217;s writing and are here to discuss her new book, The Family Remains. Maggie: The back blurb describes The Family Remains as a stand-alone sequel but I have to admit that I didn&#8217;t feel that way. (It&#8217;s a sequel to The Family Upstairs.) Knowing who most of these characters are and their backstory really makes a difference in how you read the tale. What do you think? Did this work as a standalone? Dabney: Well… I didn’t realize until I finished it that it was a sequel, of sorts. And I loved it! So I think, if you don’t know better, it works just fine as a standalone. That said, I suspect having read The Family Upstairs might have made for a richer reading experience. Was that the case for you? Maggie: Yes.I think otherwise some of the behaviors/events would have seemed odd or downright inexplicable.&nbsp; How would you describe these characters just based on what you learned in this text?&nbsp; Dabney: It’s true that Lucy, Henry, and Phin were all very mysterious for the first part of the book. But as someone who reads a ton of mysteries, I found that to be normal. My take was that they all had secrets I’d discover as I read which did indeed happen.&nbsp; Maggie. I think that’s a good take on it, though I would argue that in the first novel, which was more of a psychological thriller/gothic than a mystery, they all had much deeper, darker edges to them. Henry especially seemed less somehow; the Henry of the The Family Remains appears almost incapable of doing what the Henry of The Family Upstairs did. I’d also argue that there is no real mystery at the start of the novel for those of us who read that first volume. We know what happened to whom and why.&nbsp; On another note, let’s talk about the characters unique to this tale. I thought Marco was what Henry would have been if it weren’t for Henry’s horrific childhood and I absolutely loved him. Normally, youngsters that savvy drive me crazy but he was great. Rachel is another “newcomer” and I found her tale riveting. She’s so strong, resilient, and positive. A Lucy without all the darkness that has defined that woman’s life. What did you think of them? Dabney: I really enjoyed Rachel’s story – Jewel makes her actions both sympathetic and understandable. Rachel’s able to overcome her bad choices in a way that Lucy struggles to do. I liked seeing how their stories were different and yet similar. Marco was a great kid – believable and able to help his mom in interesting ways. I loved his friendship with Alf – my age group loves to bemoan how the young use technology. It was fun to see the two boys harness that power for good! Maggie: In fairness, the struggles that Lucy had to deal with in book one &#8211; which are only alluded to in much of this book &#8211; were far more severe than Rachel’s. I loved that both women had the strength to endure and move on. &nbsp; How would you describe the story (mystery/gothic/suspense/general fiction)&nbsp; and what would you say is the driving factor in it? Dabney: I would say it’s suspenseful but not intensely so. It’s more an explanation of a stressful time rather than a real time thriller. I liked that about it. Like good mysteries–really like all good fiction – The Family Remains shows you the why behind people’s actions. Everyone in the book behaved in ways that were true to the characters (IN THIS BOOK) were written. I hate books where people act in ways that make no sense in the context of their stories! Maggie: I would agree with your depiction of the story as more mystery than thriller. I do struggle with the question of the behaviors being true to the characters because I have that back story from the first novel and they don’t seem quite like the people in that book.&nbsp; One factor that moves this story more towards a whodunit style narrative is the police investigation led by DI Samuel Owosu. I absolutely loved his character and thought he was everything a thorough, dedicated, compassionate officer of the law should be. And I enjoyed watching that investigation unfold knowing what I knew from The Family Upstairs and wondering if he would truly be able to unpack the complex mess behind Birdie’s murder. What did you think of him and that aspect of the tale? Dabney: It really sounds as if we read two different books! I’ve thought about going back and reading The Family Upstairs – I’m a Jewel fan and it’s one of the few of hers I’ve not read–but since I know how it turned out, I’m not sure it’s worth it. I like Owosu. He reminds me somewhat of Aaron Falk, the detective in Jane Harper’s compelling mysteries set in Southern Australia–he’s laconic enough to be dryly amusing and smart enough to be fun to follow his investigations. Plus he has his own sense of honor which makes the choices he makes thoughtful and not necessarily predictable. I had faith he’d figure it out! Maggie: I’m so excited that Aaron Falk book three comes out in January! It’s interesting that you mention your qualms about going back to read The Family Upstairs because I’ve wondered whether these are books that can be read backwards and I just don’t know. There was so much I loved about that first volume but knowing what happens may indeed take all the suspense out of it. I would really recommend that readers that have a chance to do so start with the first book.&nbsp; Phinn is the impetus for much of our tale &#8211; the search for him is the primary driving factor of this particular story &#8211; but I don’t want to say too much about him because of how impactful that plotline is to this narrative. I knew Phinn, what had happened to him, and why everyone was so freaked out that Henry was going after him. I understood Lucy’s urgency when she chased after her brother. As a fresh pair of eyes, so to speak, to that dynamic what did you make of that portion of the tale and Lucy and Henry’s actions? Dabney: The Phinn story seemed like a stalker story to me because, I realize, I didn’t have the background. It made Henry creepy. Even by the book’s end, that storyline was my least favorite although I loved the way Marco played into that.&nbsp; Maggie: The Phinn story is a stalker story, even with the background. Overall, I think those who have read The Family Upstairs will be happy to read this just to have some additional closure for the characters in that volume. There is a bit of rewriting history here &#8211; Henry especially went from being chilling to simply being a man from a desperate situation &#8211; but the tale is enjoyable and DI Sam and Rachel are both compelling characters who make The Family Remains well worth a read. I would give this a B+: It’s a solid story with some interesting mystery angles to it. It does, however, lack the dark, eerie edge of the first book.&nbsp; Dabney: I’d give it a B+/A-. I really enjoyed unfurling the plot. I suspect that had I read The Family Upstairs, I’d still have liked it this much but I’d have had a different experience. So I think it’s a win for those who’ve read the first book and those who’ve not. Thanks for chatting with me Maggie. Always a pleasure. Buy it at: Amazon, Audible or your local independent retailer Visit our Amazon Storefront &nbsp;"

                "html": "<p>In the latest from Megan Miranda, <strong>The Last to Vanish</strong>, seven people have vanished in the small North Carolina mountain town of Cutter&#8217;s Pass over the past twenty odd years. What happened to them? And can we trust the narration of Abby Lovett&#8211;the book is in her first-person voice&#8211;about whom we know almost nothing? I can promise you that the first mystery is solved, albeit in a rather rushed manner. As to whether or not the story Abby tells can be believed, well, I&#8217;m not sure.</p>\n<p>Abby is a removed narrator&#8211;I kept wanting to ask her basic questions in order to get a grasp on who she is and how she got that way, but she remains, throughout the book, impenetrable. Having her tell Cutter&#8217;s Pass&#8217; story&#8211;she is still somewhat of an outsider despite having been there for ten years&#8211;was an exercise in (enjoyable) reader frustration. She&#8217;s not an unreliable narrator, she&#8217;s often parsimonious to the point of annoyance.</p>\n<p>Abby, despite her muted tone, desperately wants to know what has happened to the seven lost souls who vanished, all last seen in Cutter&#8217;s Pass. She&#8217;s always wondered but part of trying to fit in in the insular community has meant not asking too many questions. She suspects everyone and no one but her suspicions have never motivated her to push back against the town&#8217;s reticence. However, Trey West, the brother Landon West, the last person to vanish&#8211;two years ago&#8211;has come to stay in the the inn that Abby manages and his arrival pushes Abby into finally doing <em>something</em>.</p>\n<p>All the questions that Abby has suppressed bubble up and she, in fits and starts, finally learns the truth about those who vanished. She does so in the last pages of the book and while the resolution to the mystery is a surprise, it&#8217;s not a very compelling one. The motives of the person or people responsible are slightly touched on. It&#8217;s enough for Abby, and by extension Miranda, to let us know what happened&#8211;the why doesn&#8217;t overmuch interest her.</p>\n<p>Thus, the mystery isn&#8217;t where this book shines. Its joys are found in its faultless rendering of a tiny Southern mountain town. Every year, I spend several weeks in the North Carolina mountains&#8211; I recognize Cutter&#8217;s Pass. It&#8217;s a place where the locals are super friendly to tourists whom they see primarily as income. Everyone knows everyone else&#8217;s business and most minor and even major sins are forgiven and <em>always</em> concealed from outsiders. The police force is small but uncontested&#8211;its rule is law and that&#8217;s how the town likes it. The people of Cutter&#8217;s Pass are a tribe&#8211;racially and religiously fairly monolithic&#8211;and they take great comfort in the way they do things. Outsiders&#8211;tourists, summer people, the wealthy who come to stay in their second homes&#8211;will always be just that. The town&#8217;s history and its denizens, both slowly parsed, are fascinating.</p>\n<p>Thus I can recommend <strong>The Last to Vanish</strong> to those who like character driven stories with a slow growing sense of menace. It&#8217;s not an especially suspenseful book but it is a quietly compelling one. I, like Abby, had to know what happened to all who vanished from Cutter&#8217;s Pass. And though the answer isn&#8217;t much of a jolt, it hews perfectly to Miranda&#8217;s self-contained small town.</p>\n<h3 style=\"text-align: center;\"><b>Buy it at: <a href=\"https://amzn.to/3ojYNW2\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Amazon</a>, <a href=\"https://amzn.to/3aUqtxE\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Audible</a> or <a href=\"https://www.indiebound.org/book/9781982147327?aff=allaboutromance&quot;\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">your local independent retailer</a></b></h3>\n<h3 style=\"text-align: center;\"><b>Visit our <a href=\"https://amzn.to/2SeEiZg\">Amazon Storefront</a></b></h3>\n",
                "text": "In the latest from Megan Miranda, The Last to Vanish, seven people have vanished in the small North Carolina mountain town of Cutter&#8217;s Pass over the past twenty odd years. What happened to them? And can we trust the narration of Abby Lovett&#8211;the book is in her first-person voice&#8211;about whom we know almost nothing? I can promise you that the first mystery is solved, albeit in a rather rushed manner. As to whether or not the story Abby tells can be believed, well, I&#8217;m not sure. Abby is a removed narrator&#8211;I kept wanting to ask her basic questions in order to get a grasp on who she is and how she got that way, but she remains, throughout the book, impenetrable. Having her tell Cutter&#8217;s Pass&#8217; story&#8211;she is still somewhat of an outsider despite having been there for ten years&#8211;was an exercise in (enjoyable) reader frustration. She&#8217;s not an unreliable narrator, she&#8217;s often parsimonious to the point of annoyance. Abby, despite her muted tone, desperately wants to know what has happened to the seven lost souls who vanished, all last seen in Cutter&#8217;s Pass. She&#8217;s always wondered but part of trying to fit in in the insular community has meant not asking too many questions. She suspects everyone and no one but her suspicions have never motivated her to push back against the town&#8217;s reticence. However, Trey West, the brother Landon West, the last person to vanish&#8211;two years ago&#8211;has come to stay in the the inn that Abby manages and his arrival pushes Abby into finally doing something. All the questions that Abby has suppressed bubble up and she, in fits and starts, finally learns the truth about those who vanished. She does so in the last pages of the book and while the resolution to the mystery is a surprise, it&#8217;s not a very compelling one. The motives of the person or people responsible are slightly touched on. It&#8217;s enough for Abby, and by extension Miranda, to let us know what happened&#8211;the why doesn&#8217;t overmuch interest her. Thus, the mystery isn&#8217;t where this book shines. Its joys are found in its faultless rendering of a tiny Southern mountain town. Every year, I spend several weeks in the North Carolina mountains&#8211; I recognize Cutter&#8217;s Pass. It&#8217;s a place where the locals are super friendly to tourists whom they see primarily as income. Everyone knows everyone else&#8217;s business and most minor and even major sins are forgiven and always concealed from outsiders. The police force is small but uncontested&#8211;its rule is law and that&#8217;s how the town likes it. The people of Cutter&#8217;s Pass are a tribe&#8211;racially and religiously fairly monolithic&#8211;and they take great comfort in the way they do things. Outsiders&#8211;tourists, summer people, the wealthy who come to stay in their second homes&#8211;will always be just that. The town&#8217;s history and its denizens, both slowly parsed, are fascinating. Thus I can recommend The Last to Vanish to those who like character driven stories with a slow growing sense of menace. It&#8217;s not an especially suspenseful book but it is a quietly compelling one. I, like Abby, had to know what happened to all who vanished from Cutter&#8217;s Pass. And though the answer isn&#8217;t much of a jolt, it hews perfectly to Miranda&#8217;s self-contained small town.                 "html": "<p><em>Shifter Julia Martel has been spoiled and pampered by all the alpha males around her whose urge to protect her have left her uninformed and vulnerable. Now the Great North Pack has relegated Julia to the care of the wolf at the very bottom of the Pack hierarchy, Arthur Graysson. Julia wants nothing to do with the Pack, except to escape back to her life of luxury and idleness, but the more time she spends with Arthur, the more she learns about the Pack, the dark secrets Arthur carries with him, and the fierceness within herself that could save them all…</em></p>\n<hr />\n<p>Maria Rose and Dabney are here to discuss <strong>Wolf in the Shadows</strong>, the fifth book in the <em><strong>Legend of All Wolves</strong> </em>series.</p>\n<p><b>Maria Rose</b>:  I confess I was really excited when I heard there was going to be a new book in this series! I thought Evie’s book (<a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/book-review/season-of-the-wolf-by-maria-vale/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"><strong>Season of the Wolf</strong></a>) was going to be the last of the set. So I had high expectations for this one and I’m happy to say they’ve been met.  How about you Dabney?</p>\n<p><b>Dabney</b>: I’m glad there were more books in the series and I enjoyed this one. But. I had several significant issues with it that made me like it but not love it.</p>\n<p><b>Maria Rose</b>: Well, now I’m curious! Can you elaborate?</p>\n<p><b>Dabney</b>: I found the way the story was told very disorienting–I’ve read all the books but I still had a hard time figuring out where we were in the Great North Pack storyline. At about the 25% mark, I found my footing but, prior to that, I was a bit lost.</p>\n<p>Julia and Arthur as a couple didn’t wow me in the way the earlier couples have–I wanted Arthur to be a bit less laid back as a wolf in love and Julia was all over the map about what she wanted in a way that made me want better for Arthur.</p>\n<p><b>Maria Rose</b>: This story had similarities for me with a mafia themed romance. Julia is the spoiled Mafia Princess who is really in a prison of mob ‘family’, with the mob boss (her uncle) getting taken out and her ending up a prisoner of the Great North Pack.  But unlike those stories, she doesn’t end up with the Alpha of another family &#8211; she ends up with a beta (or Gamma? Delta? Is there a romance cheat sheet for hero types with Greek letter designations?) The point being that Arthur is at the bottom of the Great North Pack, so far out of Julia’s normal contacts yet the only one who tries to be nice to her (and pays for it, at the beginning of the story). But this also means Julia has to buck up and face some uncomfortable truths, and she really comes into her own as an individual as the story progresses. It’s also been a while for me since I read the previous book and truthfully, plot details often don’t stick with me for long from any story unless it’s one I’ve read multiple times. Thus, I’d also forgotten the end of the previous book and had to figure out what was going on. But it didn’t bother me to do that (it’s an experience I constantly have LOL).</p>\n<p><b>Dabney</b>: It wasn’t just remembering the past–the way the story was told was hard to follow. I’ve read other reviews on GR that had that problem too. I almost feel as though Vale was trying to do something new and it just… didn’t quite work.</p>\n<p><b>Maria Rose</b>: Well then I don’t feel so bad about not remembering! I think once you get past that first part, it does smooth out and as always, the uniqueness of Vale’s worldbuilding, including the more visceral (and probably more accurate) depiction of life in the wolfpack is what makes the series in general stand out in my mind, though perhaps this particular entry a bit less than the others. Are we ready for a grade or do you have any other thoughts?</p>\n<p><b>Dabney</b> I’ll just add that I thought Vale had done a great job in the last book, <a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/book-review/season-of-the-wolf-by-maria-vale/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"><b>Season of the Wolf</b></a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">, and indeed in all the preceding books showing how great a threat humans are to the Great North Pack. The series has been filled with suspense and tragedies, yes, but it&#8217;s also had humor and hope. This book seemed toned down and sadder. The Pack&#8217;s future is grim simply because of how the world is. This book is a more depressing read than the others in the series. </span></p>\n<p><b>Maria Rose</b>: Yes, I can see how one could feel that way. I still enjoyed this entry in the series though, and I’m rating it a B+ (a bit lower than other entries for me, but still a gripping read). How about you?</p>\n<p>Dabney: It&#8217;s a B- for me. I love the series but in some ways, after reading this book, I sort of wish Vale had stopped with <strong>Season of the Wolf</strong>.  <strong>Wolf in the Shadows&#8217;</strong> love story was too hard to follow, the romance too pale, and the overall vibe too sad for me.</p>\n<h3 style=\"text-align: center;\"><b>Buy it at: <a href=\"https://amzn.to/3B4bZpE\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Amazon </a>or <a href=\"https://www.indiebound.org/book/9781728214733?aff=allaboutromance\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">your local independent retailer</a></b></h3>\n<h3 style=\"text-align: center;\"><b>Visit our <a href=\"https://amzn.to/2SeEiZg\">Amazon Storefront</a></b></h3>\n",
                "text": "Shifter Julia Martel has been spoiled and pampered by all the alpha males around her whose urge to protect her have left her uninformed and vulnerable. Now the Great North Pack has relegated Julia to the care of the wolf at the very bottom of the Pack hierarchy, Arthur Graysson. Julia wants nothing to do with the Pack, except to escape back to her life of luxury and idleness, but the more time she spends with Arthur, the more she learns about the Pack, the dark secrets Arthur carries with him, and the fierceness within herself that could save them all… Maria Rose and Dabney are here to discuss Wolf in the Shadows, the fifth book in the Legend of All Wolves series. Maria Rose:  I confess I was really excited when I heard there was going to be a new book in this series! I thought Evie’s book (Season of the Wolf) was going to be the last of the set. So I had high expectations for this one and I’m happy to say they’ve been met.  How about you Dabney? Dabney: I’m glad there were more books in the series and I enjoyed this one. But. I had several significant issues with it that made me like it but not love it. Maria Rose: Well, now I’m curious! Can you elaborate? Dabney: I found the way the story was told very disorienting–I’ve read all the books but I still had a hard time figuring out where we were in the Great North Pack storyline. At about the 25% mark, I found my footing but, prior to that, I was a bit lost. Julia and Arthur as a couple didn’t wow me in the way the earlier couples have–I wanted Arthur to be a bit less laid back as a wolf in love and Julia was all over the map about what she wanted in a way that made me want better for Arthur. Maria Rose: This story had similarities for me with a mafia themed romance. Julia is the spoiled Mafia Princess who is really in a prison of mob ‘family’, with the mob boss (her uncle) getting taken out and her ending up a prisoner of the Great North Pack.  But unlike those stories, she doesn’t end up with the Alpha of another family &#8211; she ends up with a beta (or Gamma? Delta? Is there a romance cheat sheet for hero types with Greek letter designations?) The point being that Arthur is at the bottom of the Great North Pack, so far out of Julia’s normal contacts yet the only one who tries to be nice to her (and pays for it, at the beginning of the story). But this also means Julia has to buck up and face some uncomfortable truths, and she really comes into her own as an individual as the story progresses. It’s also been a while for me since I read the previous book and truthfully, plot details often don’t stick with me for long from any story unless it’s one I’ve read multiple times. Thus, I’d also forgotten the end of the previous book and had to figure out what was going on. But it didn’t bother me to do that (it’s an experience I constantly have LOL). Dabney: It wasn’t just remembering the past–the way the story was told was hard to follow. I’ve read other reviews on GR that had that problem too. I almost feel as though Vale was trying to do something new and it just… didn’t quite work. Maria Rose: Well then I don’t feel so bad about not remembering! I think once you get past that first part, it does smooth out and as always, the uniqueness of Vale’s worldbuilding, including the more visceral (and probably more accurate) depiction of life in the wolfpack is what makes the series in general stand out in my mind, though perhaps this particular entry a bit less than the others. Are we ready for a grade or do you have any other thoughts? Dabney I’ll just add that I thought Vale had done a great job in the last book, Season of the Wolf, and indeed in all the preceding books showing how great a threat humans are to the Great North Pack. The series has been filled with suspense and tragedies, yes, but it&#8217;s also had humor and hope. This book seemed toned down and sadder. The Pack&#8217;s future is grim simply because of how the world is. This book is a more depressing read than the others in the series.  Maria Rose: Yes, I can see how one could feel that way. I still enjoyed this entry in the series though, and I’m rating it a B+ (a bit lower than other entries for me, but still a gripping read). How about you? Dabney: It&#8217;s a B- for me. I love the series but in some ways, after reading this book, I sort of wish Vale had stopped with Season of the Wolf.  Wolf in the Shadows&#8217; love story was too hard to follow, the romance too pale, and the overall vibe too sad for me.                 "html": "<p><strong>A Little Wilder</strong> is Kane Wilder story, he of the famous <a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/review-tag/wilder-adventures-series/\">Wilder</a> family. (This is the fourth full book of the series and, I suspect, given that each book is about a Wilder brother, the penultimate one.) And though I love me some Wilder&#8211;Bell is one of my favorite contemporary romance writers&#8211;in <strong>A Little Wilder</strong>, I found myself getting a bit tired of this increasingly picture perfect family. Over the course of the books, the Wilders&#8211;the five brothers, one sister, their mom, her partner, and&#8211;going into this book&#8211;three significant others AND their families&#8211;have slowly slipped from being loving, funny, and interestingly flawed to verging on a sugar coated fantasy.</p>\n<p>Kane is the sweetest of them all. He&#8217;s gorgeous, kind, other-oriented, funny, talented, incredibly nice to small children and the elderly, a gifted artist whose work highlights the best in his subjects, and, of course, so giving in bed that he never ever lets himself come before his partner. Honestly, all the man is missing is a halo&#8230; and, apparently, a very pregnant baby mama.</p>\n<p>As readers of the last book, <a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/book-review/wilder-with-you-by-serena-bell/\"><strong>Wilder with You</strong></a>, know, Kane has been unable to forget a one night stand he had in Vegas earlier in the year. One night stands are not his norm nor, we are told (and that&#8217;s all because we never saw the actual encounter), is how sexually domineering he was with his hook-up. So when said hook-up, Marigold, shows up&#8211;she&#8217;s been hired by his brother Clark to renovate six Airstream trailers for Wilder Adventures&#8211;Kane is thrilled to see her&#8230; especially since she&#8217;s pregnant and it&#8217;s his. He&#8217;s recently realized that what he truly wants in life is a family of his own and&#8211;whoa&#8211;look what&#8217;s here!</p>\n<p>For her part, Mari isn&#8217;t so sure, at least not at first. The sex with Kane was phenomenal, sure, and her hormones are making her constantly horny, but Mari hasn&#8217;t decided whether or not she&#8217;s keeping Bun, the baby. That said, she&#8217;s excited to renovate the trailers&#8211;she&#8217;s an artist and these look like a very fun job&#8211;and it doesn&#8217;t take much for Kane to convince her&#8211;in the most non-pressuring way possible&#8211;because, saint!&#8211;to spend some time Rush Creek and see what happens.</p>\n<p>I had no doubt&#8211;at any point in this book&#8211;that Kane and Mari would fall in love, stay together, and raise baby Bun. Kane is so perfect and so undemanding and so able to constantly give Mari exactly what she needs in any given situation&#8211;why wouldn&#8217;t Mari stay? Yes, she loves her job and it involves travel. And yes she had a shitty mom who makes her worry she&#8217;ll be a shitty mom. But these fears are clearly solvable&#8211;Kane is perfect so of course he&#8217;ll be the sort of father who supports his partner&#8217;s work and Mari is such a lovely person from the get go that we know she&#8217;ll be a great parent. There&#8217;s no palpable conflict in this book and thus story isn&#8217;t especially interesting.</p>\n<p>That doesn&#8217;t mean the book&#8217;s a failure however. As usual, Bell&#8217;s writing is wry and witty. Her sex scenes are hot&#8211;she does a lovely job of making pregnancy sexy. And I suspect many, wrung out by the news, the weather, the economy, and any number of other stresses, will find the <em>Wilder</em> brand of soothing perfect love comforting. Bell&#8217;s world is one in which everyone is loveable and worthy of love and, really, that&#8217;s wonderful.</p>\n<p>If you love the Wilders and you&#8217;re up for a very sunny read, you&#8217;ll have a great time reading this. But if you&#8217;re looking for depth in your storytelling, I&#8217;m not sure you&#8217;ll find it here.</p>\n",

Kane is so perfect and so undemanding and so able to constantly give Mari exactly what she needs in any given situation&#8211;why wouldn&#8217;t Mari stay? Yes, she loves her job and it involves travel. And yes she had a shitty mom who makes her worry she&#8217;ll be a shitty mom. But these fears are clearly solvable&#8211;Kane is perfect so of course he&#8217;ll be the sort of father who supports his partner&#8217;s work and Mari is such a lovely person from the get go that we know she&#8217;ll be a great parent. There&#8217;s no palpable conflict in this book and thus story isn&#8217;t especially interesting. That doesn&#8217;t mean the book&#8217;s a failure however. As usual, Bell&#8217;s writing is wry and witty. Her sex scenes are hot&#8211;she does a lovely job of making pregnancy sexy. And I suspect many, wrung out by the news, the weather, the economy, and any number of other stresses, will find the Wilder brand of soothing perfect love comforting. Bell&#8217;s world is one in which everyone is loveable and worthy of love and, really, that&#8217;s wonderful. If you love the Wilders and you&#8217;re up for a very sunny read, you&#8217;ll have a great time reading this. But if you&#8217;re looking for depth in your storytelling, I&#8217;m not sure you&#8217;ll find it here."
            }

                "html": "<p>Ten years ago, on June 5th, Gillian Flynn’s <strong>Gone Girl</strong> arrived. It wasn’t Flynn’s first book or even her second—she’d published two unsettling works both of which had sold reasonably well. But <strong>Gone Girl</strong> rocketed to the top of the best-seller list in the summer of 2012—it spent eight weeks at #1 on the NYT hardcover list and by the end of the year had sold over two million copies. In general, <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2012/05/30/books/gone-girl-by-gillian-flynn.html\">critics loved it</a> and readers couldn’t stop talking about it.</p>\n<p>I don&#8217;t love Flynn’s first two books—I find <strong>Sharp Objects</strong> so disturbing that, really, I wish I’d never read it and the lead sin <strong>Dark Places</strong> are too glum for my liking. But I adored <strong>Gone Girl</strong>. I am grateful I read it in the era where spoilers were easy to avoid—I can still remember gaping at the very first paragraph of Part Two. It was a book that as soon as I’d finished reading it, I wanted to do so again and, several weeks later I did. Flynn’s precision with both plot and words riveted me. Everything about the novel, including its morally ambiguous framework, worked for me.</p>\n<p>I read it again last month to see how it would hold up. And, if possible, I thought it even better.</p>\n<p>For those who haven’t read it, <strong>Gone Girl </strong>is the story of Nick and Amy Dunne whose marriage, like many, is full of lies, malice, sex, betrayal, and love. As the book begins, it is the morning of Nick and Amy’s fifth anniversary and Nick comes downstairs to find Amy making pancakes. Amy beams at Nick, calls him handsome, and Nick, full of dread, thinks “OK, go.”</p>\n<p>Within hours, Amy has vanished, the living room is in shambles, and the police—and the reader&#8211;are eyeing Nick with suspicion. After all, the most likely killer of a missing, presumably dead wife is <em>always</em> the husband. Worse, as Nick tells the story, it’s clear he might have murdered Amy. When he met her, she was perfect&#8211;beautiful, charming, and very very rich. Now, however, Amy, though still beautiful, is viciously nasty to Nick (or so he says), and all that money Nick so longed for is missing. After the money vanished, the two moved back to Nick’s small hometown in  Missouri, a place Nick says Amy loathes, and their marriage has become, according to Nick, an emotional hell.</p>\n<p>Nick’s story is in first person but the reader gets Amy’s story via her diary, a work whose first entry she penned seven years ago on the night she met Nick. In her telling, from the moment they met, she adored him. Her prose is full, in the salad days of their story, of effervescent joy. Nick was just <em>the best, coolest, most wonderful man <strong>EVER</strong></em>.</p>\n<p>Both Amy and Nick, when they met, were writers. And though neither of them is paid to do so anymore, in <strong>Gone Girl</strong> they are each determinedly telling their side of the story. The book goes back and forth between Nick narrating what (or so he says) is happening in real-time and Amy narrating what happened in the past (or so she says), in chronological order via her diary. Both narrations are utterly unreliably.</p>\n<p>There are many ways to misdirect a reader. You can leave out facts that had they been shared cast a completely different lens on the story you’re telling. You can emphasize things that in reality were meaningless at the time and now inflate them with portent. You can simply say things that are patently untrue. Amy and Nick each do all of these and more as they work to control the narrative of their love story. Because it is, while not even vaguely a romance, a love story. Amy’s and Nick’s ultimate goal is to show the world the real person the other is and the relationship they’ve wrought is as intimate as any I’ve ever read.</p>\n<p><strong>Gone Girl</strong> offers shock after shock and the plot, while at times borderline bonkers, is believable. This is a book that even on my third reading of it, I couldn’t put down. Even better is Flynn’s prose. In 2022, we all know Amy’s famous <em>Cool Girl</em> rant. It is, if possible, over twenty years even more true in its skewering of a certain kind of horribly common male expectation for women.</p>\n<div class=\"spoiler test-123\"><div class=\"spoiler-title\" role=\"button\" tabindex=\"0\">Spoiler</div><div class=\"spoiler-content\" style=\"display: none;\">Being the Cool Girl means I am a hot, brilliant, funny woman who adores football, poker, dirty jokes, and burping, who plays video games, drinks cheap beer, loves threesomes and anal sex, and jams hot dogs and hamburgers into her mouth like she’s hosting the world’s biggest culinary gang bang while somehow maintaining a size 2, because Cool Girls are above all hot. Hot and understanding. Cool Girls never get angry; they only smile in a chagrined, loving manner and let their men do whatever they want. Go ahead, shit on me, I don’t mind, I’m the Cool Girl.Men actually think this girl exists. Maybe they’re fooled because so many women are willing to pretend to be this girl. For a long time Cool Girl offended me. I used to see men—friends, coworkers, strangers—giddy over these awful pretender women, and I’d want to sit these men down and calmly say: You are not dating a woman, you are dating a woman who has watched too many movies written by socially awkward men who’d like to believe that this kind of woman exists and might kiss them. I’d want to grab the poor guy by his lapels or messenger bag and say: The bitch doesn’t really love chili dogs that much—no one loves chili dogs that much! And the Cool Girls are even more pathetic: They’re not even pretending to be the woman they want to be, they’re pretending to be the woman a man wants them to be. Oh, and if you’re not a Cool Girl, I beg you not to believe that your man doesn’t want the Cool Girl. It may be a slightly different version—maybe he’s a vegetarian, so Cool Girl loves seitan and is great with dogs; or maybe he’s a hipster artist, so Cool Girl is a tattooed, bespectacled nerd who loves comics. There are variations to the window dressing, but believe me, he wants Cool Girl, who is basically the girl who likes every fucking thing he likes and doesn’t ever complain. (How do you know you’re not Cool Girl? Because he says things like: “I like strong women.” If he says that to you, he will at some point fuck someone else. Because “I like strong women” is code for “I hate strong women.”)</div></div>\n<p>One can’t help but agree with Amy’s fury but even as you find yourself nodding your head you remember Amy is not to be trusted—nor, of course, is Nick—and you realize, yet again, you’ve been reading as though their words have some kind of narrative truth when, you realize,  you f*cking know better to believe a word either shares.</p>\n<p>I’ve heard from many that they found the ending unsatisfying, and I get that. We are a world that likes our vengeance and punishment for those who sin. I, though, see the ending as offering both. Amy and Nick get exactly what they deserve. As do we readers who’ve just finished a perfect rendered tale.</p>\n<h3 style=\"text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://amzn.to/3NKBChF\">Get it at Amazon</a></h3>\n",
                "text": "Ten years ago, on June 5th, Gillian Flynn’s Gone Girl arrived. It wasn’t Flynn’s first book or even her second—she’d published two unsettling works both of which had sold reasonably well. But Gone Girl rocketed to the top of the best-seller list in the summer of 2012—it spent eight weeks at #1 on the NYT hardcover list and by the end of the year had sold over two million copies. In general, critics loved it and readers couldn’t stop talking about it. I don&#8217;t love Flynn’s first two books—I find Sharp Objects so disturbing that, really, I wish I’d never read it and the lead sin Dark Places are too glum for my liking. But I adored Gone Girl. I am grateful I read it in the era where spoilers were easy to avoid—I can still remember gaping at the very first paragraph of Part Two. It was a book that as soon as I’d finished reading it, I wanted to do so again and, several weeks later I did. Flynn’s precision with both plot and words riveted me. Everything about the novel, including its morally ambiguous framework, worked for me. I read it again last month to see how it would hold up. And, if possible, I thought it even better. For those who haven’t read it, Gone Girl is the story of Nick and Amy Dunne whose marriage, like many, is full of lies, malice, sex, betrayal, and love. As the book begins, it is the morning of Nick and Amy’s fifth anniversary and Nick comes downstairs to find Amy making pancakes. Amy beams at Nick, calls him handsome, and Nick, full of dread, thinks “OK, go.” Within hours, Amy has vanished, the living room is in shambles, and the police—and the reader&#8211;are eyeing Nick with suspicion. After all, the most likely killer of a missing, presumably dead wife is always the husband. Worse, as Nick tells the story, it’s clear he might have murdered Amy. When he met her, she was perfect&#8211;beautiful, charming, and very very rich. Now, however, Amy, though still beautiful, is viciously nasty to Nick (or so he says), and all that money Nick so longed for is missing. After the money vanished, the two moved back to Nick’s small hometown in  Missouri, a place Nick says Amy loathes, and their marriage has become, according to Nick, an emotional hell. Nick’s story is in first person but the reader gets Amy’s story via her diary, a work whose first entry she penned seven years ago on the night she met Nick. In her telling, from the moment they met, she adored him. Her prose is full, in the salad days of their story, of effervescent joy. Nick was just the best, coolest, most wonderful man EVER. Both Amy and Nick, when they met, were writers. And though neither of them is paid to do so anymore, in Gone Girl they are each determinedly telling their side of the story. The book goes back and forth between Nick narrating what (or so he says) is happening in real-time and Amy narrating what happened in the past (or so she says), in chronological order via her diary. Both narrations are utterly unreliably. There are many ways to misdirect a reader. You can leave out facts that had they been shared cast a completely different lens on the story you’re telling. You can emphasize things that in reality were meaningless at the time and now inflate them with portent. You can simply say things that are patently untrue. Amy and Nick each do all of these and more as they work to control the narrative of their love story. Because it is, while not even vaguely a romance, a love story. Amy’s and Nick’s ultimate goal is to show the world the real person the other is and the relationship they’ve wrought is as intimate as any I’ve ever read. Gone Girl offers shock after shock and the plot, while at times borderline bonkers, is believable. This is a book that even on my third reading of it, I couldn’t put down. Even better is Flynn’s prose. In 2022, we all know Amy’s famous Cool Girl rant. It is, if possible, over twenty years even more true in its skewering of a certain kind of horribly common male expectation for women. Go ahead, shit on me, I don’t mind, I’m the Cool Girl.Men actually think this girl exists. Maybe they’re fooled because so many women are willing to pretend to be this girl.             "book": {
                "title": "The Heir Apparent's Rejected Mate",
                "author_first": "Cate C.",
                "author_last": "Wells",
                "publisher": "Cate C. Wells",
                "isbn": "9798800553260",

                "publish_date": "04/2022",
