            "content": {
                "html": "<p>I&#8217;ve read four of Cate C. Wells books &#8211; this one, its predecessor <span class=\"a-size-extra-large\"><a href=\"https://amzn.to/38xiaq3\"><strong>The Tyrant Alpha&#8217;s Rejected Mate</strong></a>, <a href=\"https://amzn.to/39sBvZy\"><strong>Hitting the Wall</strong></a>, and the second book in that series (</span><span id=\"productTitle\" class=\"a-size-extra-large\"><strong><em>Stonecut County</em></strong>) <a href=\"https://amzn.to/3ws2bBP\"><strong>Against A Wall</strong></a>. I&#8217;ve enjoyed them all &#8211; <strong>The Tyrant Alpha&#8217;s Rejected Mate</strong> is my favorite followed by <strong>Hitting the Wall</strong>. This book isn&#8217;t as strong as either of those but I liked and can recommend it, especially as part of the <strong><em>Five Packs</em></strong> series. </span></p>\n<p><strong>The Heir Apparent&#8217;s Rejected Mate</strong> is the second book in that series which features five different but connected wolf shifter packs. The pack in book one is the Quarry Pack which shuns human contact as much as possible. This book features the Moon Lake Pack, a pack that tries to be as human as possible based on the belief that the best way to survive with humans is to beat them at their own games. I confess to liking the dynamics of the Quarry Pack better than those of the Moon Lake Pack&#8211;the latter is less interesting simply because their motivations and thoughts are, in large part, very similar to our own.</p>\n<p>Every paranormal world has its rules and in that of the Five Packs, the rule is that females choose their mates. Or rather their bodies choose&#8211;a female, when it&#8217;s time for her to go into heat, is suddenly triggered by the presence of her mate. From that moment on, until they mate which, yes, means just what you think it does, she&#8217;s repulsed by all other males and increasingly physically miserable. In both books, nature, the cruel matchmaker she is, pairs a female of very low rank with the leader of the pack who&#8230; promptly rejects her because she&#8217;s of very low rank. But a rule is a rule so, in each book, our star-crossed lovers have to figure out how to be together. Really, what happens is the stupid males too sold on their specialness come to realize the chick who has chosen them is perfect, not just for them but for the fate of the pack.</p>\n<p>Wells&#8217; heroes are, to a man, less interesting than her heroines. The male leads in the books that I&#8217;ve read&#8211;with the exception of Cash, from <strong>Against the Wall</strong>, are the leaders of their community, large and very strong, handsome, and somewhat clueless about what women want. I find them sexy&#8211;what can I say? There&#8217;s no accounting for taste!&#8211;but I&#8217;d much rather be in the heads of the Wells&#8217; females all of who are fascinating. (All the books are narrated in dual voice.)</p>\n<p>Rosie, this book&#8217;s low status lead, is a scavenger. In the Moon Lake Pack, the pack hierarchy is based on wealth and power. And, just like it is in the real world, those with money and power tend to think that those without just don&#8217;t try hard enough. The scavenger class is seen as the welfare class&#8211;they&#8217;re not smart enough or human enough or motivated enough to hold the human jobs the nobs in the pack do and they&#8217;re grudgingly supported with &#8220;donations.&#8221;  Rosie and her friends&#8211;Wells does friend groups beautifully&#8211;spend their time scavenging, hunting for things they can use and trade, and, in general, being there for one another.</p>\n<p>Rosie mostly scavenges for herbs. The pack&#8217;s witch&#8211;they&#8217;re supposed to call her a wise woman but hardly any does&#8211;the fabulous Abertha, chose Rosie as her apprentice when Rosie was a child. Years of combing the woods&#8211;Rosie has developed a grid system&#8211;for ashbalm, <a href=\"https://www.gardeningknowhow.com/ornamental/water-plants/dragons-tongue-plant/how-to-grow-dragons-tongue-plant.htm#:~:text=Hemigraphis%20repanda%2C%20or%20dragon's%20tongue,of%20the%20unusual%20color%20combination.\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">dragon&#8217;s tongue</a>, and <a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/shiver-me-timbers-i-love-our-flag-means-death/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">wolf&#8217;s bane</a> have given her a deep connection to the land the Moon Lake pack occupies. She loves her family and is happy with her life until the day fate completely f*cks her over and pairs her with Cadoc Collins, the Moon Pack&#8217;s eventual leader&#8211;his father is the pack&#8217;s acting regent.</p>\n<p>Cadoc is well-intentioned but patently idiotic about what his pack is really like. When the book begins, he&#8217;s bought into the bullsh*t that the scavengers are lazy morons and that being more human than human is the best thing he can do to take his pack safely into the future. When Rosie claims him &#8211; in the school dining room (they&#8217;re eighteen and nineteen), he&#8217;s sure the right thing to do is send her packing. They&#8217;re too mismatched&#8211;a scavenger and a future alpha&#8211;and it&#8217;s much better that he spend his time meeting with his staff about quarterly projections (the Moon Lake Pack make <strong>a lot</strong> of money) then listening to the bond that now beats in his chest and tells him to be with Rosie asap. His super obnoxious friends &#8211; think the nasty rich kids on every teen TV show ever&#8211;agree and, whenever they see Rosie, they&#8217;re nastier to her and her friends than usual which is really saying something.</p>\n<p>But the bonds of true love &#8211; and profound sexual connection &#8211; must have their way and therein lies the novel. Here, however, it&#8217;s just not very novel. Cadoc is a good guy from the get go and the reader knows it&#8217;s just a matter of time before he claims Rosie and it&#8217;s a bit dull waiting around for him to do so. The parts of the books in his head left me impatient &#8211; come on, dude, follow your heart! Literally.</p>\n<p>Fortunately, more than half the book is in Rosie&#8217;s head. Rosie is not just smart about what matters, she&#8217;s funny and insightful. She&#8217;s well aware that Cadoc doesn&#8217;t understand the true nature on the Moon Lake Pack &#8211; basically bad news for all concerned &#8211; and that if she could just ignore this stupid fated mate thing, her life is worthwhile. She may be younger than Cadoc but he&#8217;s blandly immature, whereas she has a finely honed emotional intelligence that gives her insights gravitas.</p>\n<p>Even the Hamlet like secondary plot which is centered on whether or not Cadoc or his evil uncle will be rule the pack lacks oomph. Cadoc spends a lot of time training &#8211; beating up other shifters who&#8217;ve agreed to be his punching bags &#8211; futilely preparing for a fight he knows he&#8217;ll lose because his uncle, Alban, can flipswitch. Killian, the lead in book one could do this too. They&#8217;re the only two wolves in all the packs (that we know about thus far) who can instantly shift from wolf to man and back. The rest of the wolves all take time to shift which means that a flipswitching shifter could, while a wolf is trying to change to a man, for example, quickly become human and easily knife to death the still shifting wolf. Cadoc cannot do this and thus no matter how strong and agile he becomes, he&#8217;ll never be able to best his uncle in a fight. Cadoc frets about this again and again and again which, over time, gets old.</p>\n<p>When Cadoc and Rosie are together, they&#8217;re cute. Cadoc is deeply protective of Rosie&#8211;a trait all Wells&#8217; men have&#8211;and it&#8217;s fun to watch Rosie not give a sh*t. They have chemistry although not as much as I&#8217;d have liked&#8211;this book could have used more sex scenes because initially, an unshakably need to bone is all that bonds the two. Over time, however, as they learn more about each other, their emotional bond grows believably, making Cadoc a better man and Rosie able to still be true to herself and mated to the alpha heir.</p>\n<p>Wells, in all her books, mines class well. She shows with a gimlet eye how poverty, almost always undeserved, is used against those with little by those with much. All her heroes&#8211;all of whom have money and power compared to their mates&#8211;have to relearn how to see the world with compassion and, even better, in order to earn the love of the person who is perfect for them, must make the larger world a fairer and better place for all. Her books are wonderfully ethically grounded even as they embrace heroes who begin their stories with profound flaws.</p>\n<p>I&#8217;ll keep reading the <strong><em>Five Packs</em></strong> books = while this one isn&#8217;t my favorite, I enjoyed it and I&#8217;m curious to know where she&#8217;s going with the storylines that tie all the packs together. If I were grading the series thus far, I&#8217;d give it strong B+. Hanging out with Wells&#8217; heroines is always a good time and her heroes are sexy. Book three, <strong>The Lone Wolf&#8217;s Rejected Mate</strong>, comes out later this year and, even though it&#8217;s an age-gap romance which is definitely not my thing, I&#8217;m looking forward to it.</p>\n<p>&nbsp;</p>\n<h3 style=\"text-align: center;\"><strong>Buy it at <a href=\"https://amzn.to/37SCUZe\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Amazon </a>or your <a href=\"https://www.indiebound.org/book/9798800553260?aff=allaboutromance\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">local independent retailer</a></strong></h3>\n<h3 style=\"text-align: center;\"><strong>Visit our <a href=\"https://amzn.to/2SeEiZg\">Amazon Storefront</a></strong></h3>\n",
                "text": "I&#8217;ve read four of Cate C. Wells books &#8211; this one, its predecessor The Tyrant Alpha&#8217;s Rejected Mate, Hitting the Wall, and the second book in that series (Stonecut County) Against A Wall. I&#8217;ve enjoyed them all &#8211; The Tyrant Alpha&#8217;s Rejected Mate is my favorite followed by Hitting the Wall. This book isn&#8217;t as strong as either of those but I liked and can recommend it, especially as part of the Five Packs series. The Heir Apparent&#8217;s Rejected Mate is the second book in that series which features five different but connected wolf shifter packs. The pack in book one is the Quarry Pack which shuns human contact as much as possible. This book features the Moon Lake Pack, a pack that tries to be as human as possible based on the belief that the best way to survive with humans is to beat them at their own games. I confess to liking the dynamics of the Quarry Pack better than those of the Moon Lake Pack&#8211;the latter is less interesting simply because their motivations and thoughts are, in large part, very similar to our own. Every paranormal world has its rules and in that of the Five Packs, the rule is that females choose their mates. Or rather their bodies choose&#8211;a female, when it&#8217;s time for her to go into heat, is suddenly triggered by the presence of her mate. From that moment on, until they mate which, yes, means just what you think it does, she&#8217;s repulsed by all other males and increasingly physically miserable. In both books, nature, the cruel matchmaker she is, pairs a female of very low rank with the leader of the pack who&#8230; promptly rejects her because she&#8217;s of very low rank. But a rule is a rule so, in each book, our star-crossed lovers have to figure out how to be together. Really, what happens is the stupid males too sold on their specialness come to realize the chick who has chosen them is perfect, not just for them but for the fate of the pack. Wells&#8217; heroes are, to a man, less interesting than her heroines. The male leads in the books that I&#8217;ve read&#8211;with the exception of Cash, from Against the Wall, are the leaders of their community, large and very strong, handsome, and somewhat clueless about what women want. I find them sexy&#8211;what can I say? There&#8217;s no accounting for taste!&#8211;but I&#8217;d much rather be in the heads of the Wells&#8217; females all of who are fascinating. (All the books are narrated in dual voice.) Rosie, this book&#8217;s low status lead, is a scavenger. In the Moon Lake Pack, the pack hierarchy is based on wealth and power. And, just like it is in the real world, those with money and power tend to think that those without just don&#8217;t try hard enough. The scavenger class is seen as the welfare class&#8211;they&#8217;re not smart enough or human enough or motivated enough to hold the human jobs the nobs in the pack do and they&#8217;re grudgingly supported with &#8220;donations.&#8221;  Rosie and her friends&#8211;Wells does friend groups beautifully&#8211;spend their time scavenging, hunting for things they can use and trade, and, in general, being there for one another. Rosie mostly scavenges for herbs. The pack&#8217;s witch&#8211;they&#8217;re supposed to call her a wise woman but hardly any does&#8211;the fabulous Abertha, chose Rosie as her apprentice when Rosie was a child. Years of combing the woods&#8211;Rosie has developed a grid system&#8211;for ashbalm, dragon&#8217;s tongue, and wolf&#8217;s bane have given her a deep connection to the land the Moon Lake pack occupies. She loves her family and is happy with her life until the day fate completely f*cks her over and pairs her with Cadoc Collins, the Moon Pack&#8217;s eventual leader&#8211;his father is the pack&#8217;s acting regent. Cadoc is well-intentioned but patently idiotic about what his pack is really like. When the book begins, he&#8217;s bought into the bullsh*t that the scavengers are lazy morons and that being more human than human is the best thing he can do to take his pack safely into the future. When Rosie claims him &#8211; in the school dining room (they&#8217;re eighteen and nineteen), he&#8217;s sure the right thing to do is send her packing. They&#8217;re too mismatched&#8211;a scavenger and a future alpha&#8211;and it&#8217;s much better that he spend his time meeting with his staff about quarterly projections (the Moon Lake Pack make a lot of money) then listening to the bond that now beats in his chest and tells him to be with Rosie asap. His super obnoxious friends &#8211; think the nasty rich kids on every teen TV show ever&#8211;agree and, whenever they see Rosie, they&#8217;re nastier to her and her friends than usual which is really saying something. But the bonds of true love &#8211; and profound sexual connection &#8211; must have their way and therein lies the novel. Here, however, it&#8217;s just not very novel. Cadoc is a good guy from the get go and the reader knows it&#8217;s just a matter of time before he claims Rosie and it&#8217;s a bit dull waiting around for him to do so. The parts of the books in his head left me impatient &#8211; come on, dude, follow your heart! Literally. Fortunately, more than half the book is in Rosie&#8217;s head. Rosie is not just smart about what matters, she&#8217;s funny and insightful. She&#8217;s well aware that Cadoc doesn&#8217;t understand the true nature on the Moon Lake Pack &#8211; basically bad news for all concerned &#8211; and that if she could just ignore this stupid fated mate thing, her life is worthwhile. She may be younger than Cadoc but he&#8217;s blandly immature, whereas she has a finely honed emotional intelligence that gives her insights gravitas. Even the Hamlet like secondary plot which is centered on whether or not Cadoc or his evil uncle will be rule the pack lacks oomph. Cadoc spends a lot of time training &#8211; beating up other shifters who&#8217;ve agreed to be his punching bags &#8211; futilely preparing for a fight he knows he&#8217;ll lose because his uncle, Alban, can flipswitch. Killian, the lead in book one could do this too. They&#8217;re the only two wolves in all the packs (that we know about thus far) who can instantly shift from wolf to man and back. The rest of the wolves all take time to shift which means that a flipswitching shifter could, while a wolf is trying to change to a man, for example, quickly become human and easily knife to death the still shifting wolf. Cadoc cannot do this and thus no matter how strong and agile he becomes, he&#8217;ll never be able to best his uncle in a fight. Cadoc frets about this again and again and again which, over time, gets old. When Cadoc and Rosie are together, they&#8217;re cute. Cadoc is deeply protective of Rosie&#8211;a trait all Wells&#8217; men have&#8211;and it&#8217;s fun to watch Rosie not give a sh*t. They have chemistry although not as much as I&#8217;d have liked&#8211;this book could have used more sex scenes because initially, an unshakably need to bone is all that bonds the two. Over time, however, as they learn more about each other, their emotional bond grows believably, making Cadoc a better man and Rosie able to still be true to herself and mated to the alpha heir. Wells, in all her books, mines class well. She shows with a gimlet eye how poverty, almost always undeserved, is used against those with little by those with much. All her heroes&#8211;all of whom have money and power compared to their mates&#8211;have to relearn how to see the world with compassion and, even better, in order to earn the love of the person who is perfect for them, must make the larger world a fairer and better place for all. Her books are wonderfully ethically grounded even as they embrace heroes who begin their stories with profound flaws. I&#8217;ll keep reading the Five Packs books = while this one isn&#8217;t my favorite, I enjoyed it and I&#8217;m curious to know where she&#8217;s going with the storylines that tie all the packs together. If I were grading the series thus far, I&#8217;d give it strong B+. Hanging out with Wells&#8217; heroines is always a good time and her heroes are sexy.                 "text": "there are mild spoilers for the first six books in this review In 2016, I read our review of City of the Lost by Kelley Armstrong, thought, that looks interesting and promptly forgot about it. Three years later, when we reviewed Watcher in the Woods I downloaded the book but didn&#8217;t get to it. Finally, last summer, after readers in the forum mentioned how much they loved the Casey Duncan/Rockton series, I downloaded book one&#8211;City of the Lost&#8212; and was entranced. I read all seven books&#8211;the final book in the series came out in February&#8211;and enjoyed them all individually and as a series. What do I love about the Rockton series? To begin with, everything. Imagine a town, created decades ago in the remote Yukon, where people who need to disappear can. This city, Rockton, is cloaked and essentially invisible&#8211;there&#8217;s no electricity, no computers, phones, or internet, no mail. Rockton only admits people who have a skill the town can use or&#8211;and this is something the reader learns over time&#8211;who have paid a vast sum to the Council, the shadowy remote group who controls the town. Rockton is in large part self-sustaining and civilized, unlike the areas around it which are peopled by other more primitive groups one of which, the hostiles, are terrifying. In book one, City of the Lost, a young woman named Casey Duncan comes to Rockton with her friend Diana. Both are escaping violent pasts. Diana, however, hasn&#8217;t any real skill to bring to town but Casey does. Rockton has just one sherriff, Eric Dalton and he&#8217;s been unable to solve a series of killings that have recently occurred in Rockton. Casey is a homicide detective and is professionally trained, something Eric who was born in Rockton is not. Over the seven books in the series, Armstrong keeps the suspense and the tension coming. I love good long plot arcs and this series has many. Who are the hostiles and why are they so violent? What is the true story behind Dalton&#8217;s childhood? Who is the Council and what are their motives? Is Rockton made up of criminals, victims, or both? Incorporated into these plotlines, in each book, is a specific mystery, several of which I was riveted by and couldn&#8217;t see the denouncements until they arrived upon the page. Armstrong also excels at character. Rockton is a small place and we get to know many characters, none of whom are quite what they seem. I am especially fond of Isabel, the brothel owner, Mathias, the butcher, and Jacob the, well, I&#8217;ll let you learn that on your own. All the books are built upon the relationship between Casey and Dalton which is a romantic suspense reader&#8217;s dream. The final book in the series, The Deepest of Secrets, answers all the questions the series posed. The story about the hostiles is especially well resolved as is the true motives of the Council. It&#8217;s also an interesting story about privacy and our pasts&#8211;Armstrong wants the reader to consider who we are: The person in our worst moments or the person in our everyday actions? What happens, in a small town where secrets are necessary in order for the community to function, when those secrets all spill out? And who would we ally with? Those who&#8217;ve had our back recently or those whose backstories we feel the safest with? If you are looking for a smart, addictive, romantic suspense series, the Rockton novels are for you. While not every book in the series is a DIK, the overall experience the series is superb. I recommend it highly."

                "html": "<p>I read<strong> The Seduction Hypothesis </strong>when it came out and enjoyed it. It was my first quasi BDSM book that sparkled with humor and I did and do love Dryden&#8217;s writing&#8211;she is another writer I sorely miss. Recently it popped up on Steals and Deals and I decided to give it a reread.</p>\n<p>Perhaps the best thing about this story is its hero who is THE BEST. I love a man who makes a stupid mistake and then intelligently makes up for it. In Ben&#8217;s case, he stupidly broke up with his now ex-girlfriend Lindsay because he’d panicked, an act he’s since regretted. The two are both going to BeastCon and Ben decides the trip is the opportunity he needs to rewin Lindsey&#8217;s heart.</p>\n<p>On the way there, Lindsey, a devoted graphic novel fan, is reading a master/sub comic called <em>Balls &#8216;n Chain, </em>a series Ben had kinda sorta made fun of. However, as he watches Linsey read, he realizes that the whole dom/sub thing is a BIG turn on for her. He further realizes that their relationship would work better for Lindsey if he became the sort of Master she loves reading about and, woah, does that idea turn him on.</p>\n<p>Thus, when they arrive at the convention, Ben embarks upon a smart and appropriately dominate seduction of Lindsey. It’s the best campaign to get a girl out of her Slave Leia costume I&#8217;ve read since Jackie Ashenden&#8217;s <strong><a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/book-review/having-her/\">Having Her.</a></strong></p>\n<p><strong>The Seduction Hypothesis</strong> is lovely. It’s funny, emotionally engaging, and the dialog pops. Ben knows he can&#8217;t just come in and boss Lindsey around&#8211;even though she wants SOME bossing around. So, as he morphs into Master Ben, he runs everything he’s doing by Lindsey. This book, written in 2013, does consent well in large part because Ben is such a sweetheart. He not only tells Lindsey what he&#8217;s going to do&#8211;it&#8217;s clear she can always say NO&#8211;but he tells her why he wants them to do it.</p>\n<p>In Dryden&#8217;s hands, discussions about butt plugs, paddles, and any number of other kinks are sexy and sweet. Here&#8217;s Ben talking to Lindsey about how and why he wants to paddle her.</p>\n<blockquote><p>&#8220;I can’t stop thinking about doing all that to you. Not just the spanking, either, a lot more. A lot. If anybody is going to do that stuff to you, I want it to be me. Nobody. Else.”</p>\n<p>She was so accustomed to thinking of him as cute, as harmless. The kind of man who would never hurt a fly. Softly focused, with his sandy hair and indeterminate hazel eyes, vacillating about his career. She’d never seen this version of him until last night’s assertive kiss, this razor-sharp Ben who knew what he wanted and seemed potentially ruthless about getting it.</p>\n<p>But still. “Just because you think that’s what I wanted you to do before?” The music shifted gears, growing louder, and the bass drum throbbed through her bones in a maddening primal beat.</p>\n<p>Ben shook his head and leaned closer, until their lips were almost touching. “No. Because the thought of putting you over my knee and smacking your perfect butt until it looks like my handprint’s tattooed on there makes me so hard I can barely walk. It made me hard before, too, but I was a fucking idiot and thought I had to feel guilty about getting turned on by shit like that. I’m willing to work on my guilt issues if you’re willing to let me take you up to that hotel room right now and violate you eight ways from Sunday.”</p>\n<p>Oh, oh, oh…</p></blockquote>\n<p>I&#8217;m with Lindsey.</p>\n<p>Ben and Lindsey, their friends Ivan and Cami&#8211;the couple from the first book in Ms. Dryden’s <strong><em>The Science of Temptation</em></strong> series, <strong>The Theory of Attraction</strong>– and the world of comic cons are all well rendered and very funny. We see both Lindsey&#8217;s and Ben&#8217;s thoughts and reactions and both are strongly limned and give their characters depth.</p>\n<p>This BDSM love story has lots of smoking sex just as one wants in a winning contemporary romance.  As I always wish it were, the passion the leads share is an integral part of the love they have for one another. I recommend <strong>The Seduction Hypothesis</strong> to anyone who&#8217;s looking for love, laughter, lust, and spreader bars. Just don&#8217;t blame me if, when you&#8217;re done reading it, you&#8217;re super sad Ms. Dryden isn&#8217;t writing enchanting, witty love stories any more.</p>\n<h3 style=\"text-align: center;\"><strong>Buy it at: <a href=\"https://amzn.to/3JtaMsS\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Amazon </a>or <a href=\"https://amzn.to/3IEf2FD\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Audible</a></strong></h3>\n<h3 style=\"text-align: center;\"><strong>Visit our </strong><a href=\"https://amzn.to/2SeEiZg\"><strong>Amazon Storefront</strong></a></h3>\n",
                "text": "I read The Seduction Hypothesis when it came out and enjoyed it. It was my first quasi BDSM book that sparkled with humor and I did and do love Dryden&#8217;s writing&#8211;she is another writer I sorely miss. Recently it popped up on Steals and Deals and I decided to give it a reread. Perhaps the best thing about this story is its hero who is THE BEST. I love a man who makes a stupid mistake and then intelligently makes up for it. In Ben&#8217;s case, he stupidly broke up with his now ex-girlfriend Lindsay because he’d panicked, an act he’s since regretted. The two are both going to BeastCon and Ben decides the trip is the opportunity he needs to rewin Lindsey&#8217;s heart. On the way there, Lindsey, a devoted graphic novel fan, is reading a master/sub comic called Balls &#8216;n Chain, a series Ben had kinda sorta made fun of. Thus, when they arrive at the convention, Ben embarks upon a smart and appropriately dominate seduction of Lindsey. It’s the best campaign to get a girl out of her Slave Leia costume I&#8217;ve read since Jackie Ashenden&#8217;s Having Her. The Seduction Hypothesis is lovely.                 "html": "<p>The heroine of <strong>The Worst Guy</strong> is a plastic surgeon at a teaching hospital with a practice of reconstructive rather than aesthetic cases. My husband is a plastic surgeon who, for the first twenty years of his career was&#8230; at a teaching hospital and whose practice was half reconstructive/half aesthetic cases. I have <em>lived</em> academic plastic surgery. And this book&#8230; well, it gets about half of it right. This made me mildly crazy. But, that&#8217;s just me. Thus, I will&#8211;for this review&#8211;forget everything I know about the real world of plastic surgery and teaching medical surgical departments.</p>\n<p>So&#8230;.</p>\n<p>Sara Shapiro, at thirty-nine, knows her shit. She&#8217;s a plastic surgeon at a busy hospital in Boston. (She, by the way, is the <em>good</em> kind of plastic surgeon&#8211;she doesn&#8217;t do any cosmetic work, only burns and reconstructive work.) As the book begins she is incensed. One of the ER surgeons, the absurdly hot and famously rude Sebastian Stremmel, has STAPLED a patient&#8217;s face. (Staples are used in many cases to close wounds&#8211;they&#8217;re faster than sutures and tend to have a lower complication rate. No surgeon would ever use them to close a facial wound. Whoops! Forget I mentioned it.)</p>\n<p>Sara storms into the ER exam room where Sebastian is doing his charts and, in the confrontation, they manage to destroy the room. This doesn&#8217;t go over well with the hospital&#8217;s Chief of Surgery who&#8211;not going to say a word about the utter absurdity of this&#8211;commands Sara and Sebastian to complete eight hours of conflict resolution therapy. Both Sara and Sebastian are horrified by this. Not because they&#8217;d have to completely upend their surgical schedules but because they fucking do not want to fucking waste their time in such a useless endeavor with someone they can&#8217;t stand to be around.</p>\n<p>It will shock absolutely no one that underneath all of Sara&#8217;s and Sebastian&#8217;s sniping burns a fierce attraction. They&#8217;re both perfectionists.  Sara&#8217;s drive has left her with serious digestive problems and Sebastian uses work to escape emotions. They&#8217;re ambitious, attractive, brilliant, and live in the same brownstone. It&#8217;s kismet or at least very obvious that they make a damn sensible and sexy pair. And by the evening after their second session with the insightful hospital therapist, Sebastian&#8217;s pushed Sara up against the door to her apartment (she&#8217;s on the first floor, he&#8217;s on the third), and the two have embarked on a <em>very</em> hot affair.</p>\n<p>I love Sara and Sebastian&#8211;the book is a dual first person narrative&#8211;and their distinct voices. Canterbary writes how surgeons talk. The two have a friend group&#8211;they all have their own books&#8211;made up of surgeons and their spouses and to a person the MDs and their smart and snarky partners are perfectly limned. I could listen to any of them needle each other all day long.</p>\n<p>Sara grew up as the only daughter of <a href=\"https://www.plasticsurgery.org/documents/News/Statistics/2020/plastic-surgery-statistics-full-report-2020.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">a morally bankrupt plastic surgeon</a>, one who makes bazillion of dollars making women and men look like Barbie and Ken. He sneers at her academic work and uses his (unbelievable) influence over her chair and others in the field to unsettle her&#8211;he wants her to come and join his group of West Coast aesthetic clinics. Sara isn&#8217;t tempted. She&#8217;s a medical rock star; double boarded in both general surgery (I think. It wasn&#8217;t quite clear.) and in plastics&#8211;one of less than 2000 such women in the USA&#8211;a great teacher, and a compassionate caregiver. She works to silence the good girl pleaser in her and to listen to her <em>savage-hearted bitch</em>. She loves her work and her friends. She sure as hell isn&#8217;t interested in getting sucked into a professionally risky and emotionally chaotic relationship with a grump who rarely speaks and whose glare is famous throughout their world.</p>\n<p>There&#8217;s no way, however once Sebastian treats her to the wonders of his body, she can stay away. And why would she? Sebastian is fabulous. He&#8217;s hilarious, inventive, and understands her. He&#8217;s single at forty-two and also loves his job and his friends although he&#8217;d never admit to the latter. He gives Sarah what she needs in bed and lets her push him away as soon as she&#8217;s come even as he knows they could be so much more than just incendiary lovers. He is the BEST.</p>\n<p>As much as I liked Sebastian and Sara as individuals, I struggled a bit with them as a couple. They have the hot sex thing down but they don&#8217;t communicate well with each other and, over the 300 pages it takes from them to go from fuck buddies to an HEA, I grew impatient with their obdurate animosity. Canterbary does a good job of explaining why her lovers find it so hard to connect but she does it again and again. I was ready for better sooner.</p>\n<p>I enjoyed <strong>The Worst Guy</strong>. The writing is deft, funny, and detailed in wonderful ways. Even though I struggled with her depiction of a surgical department, I found the world Canterbury created vivid&#8211;her Boston <strong>is</strong> Boston and each environment she writes is easy to imagine. This is a very sexy book and we all know how down I am for that. I&#8217;ve already begun reading <a href=\"https://amzn.to/3hrqEA2\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"><strong>Preservation</strong></a>, Alex&#8217;s story&#8211;she&#8217;s Sara&#8217;s best friend. It&#8217;s making me smile&#8211;I clearly have a thing for brilliant, profane, funny surgeons. <strong>The Worst Guy</strong> gets a B from me.</p>\n<h3 style=\"text-align: center;\"><strong>Buy it at <a href=\"https://amzn.to/344kgf3\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Amazon</a>, <a href=\"https://amzn.to/3HsjXZ2\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Audible</a> or your <a href=\"https://www.indiebound.org/book/9781946352989?aff=allaboutromance\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">local independent retailer</a></strong></h3>\n<h3 style=\"text-align: center;\"><strong>Visit our </strong><a href=\"https://amzn.to/2SeEiZg\"><strong>Amazon Storefront</strong></a></h3>\n",

            "book": {
                "title": "The Heights",
                "author_first": "Louise",
                "author_last": "Candlish",
                "publisher": "Atria",
                "isbn": "1982174129",
                "pages": "413",
                "publish_date": "03/2022",
                "grade": "B+",
                "sensuality": "N/A",
                "amazon_url": "https://amzn.to/34fUjZS",
                "amazon_asin": "B09842FW9P"
            },
            "content": {
                "html": "<p><i><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">The Heights is a tall, slender apartment building among warehouses in London. Its roof terrace is so discreet, you wouldn’t know it existed if you weren’t standing at the window of the flat directly opposite. But you are. And that’s when you see a man up there—a man you’d recognize anywhere. He may be older now, but it’s definitely him.</span></i></p>\n<p><i><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">But that can’t be because he’s been dead for over two years. You know this for a fact.</span></i></p>\n<p><i><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Because you’re the one who killed him</span></i><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">.</span></p>\n<hr />\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Dabney and Maggie read Louise Candlish&#8217;s </span><b>The Heights</b><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">, then (virtually) got together to discuss the novel and are here to share their thoughts.</span></p>\n<p><b>Maggie:</b><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> Something that I love about the current suspense/thriller/mystery market is that the characters are clever, nuanced and surprising. Almost every novel you pick up has this in common. Candlish is different. Having read her previous work, I know to expect three characters from her  &#8211; one selfish jackass, one naive but earnest damaged individual and one middle-aged man who desperately wants to pretend he&#8217;s in his twenties and sleeps with younger women.  She uses them effectively but they are always present. All three of those stock characters are easily identified in this novel. What is your experience with Candlish and would you agree those characters make an appearance here?</span></p>\n<p><b>Dabney: </b><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">This is my first Candlish and, after what you&#8217;ve said, I&#8217;m grateful for that. None of these characters felt stock to me. In fact, I&#8217;m not sure who would be who in your first two characterizations! I found Ellen, whom I describe as the main character, mesmerizing and unique. Her particular combination of rage, self-awareness, and intelligence was blazingly compelling to me. I&#8217;m guessing you see her as the earnest damaged individual? I&#8217;d argue she is, in her own way, a selfish jackass. But perhaps we are getting ahead of ourselves. What did you think about the plot?</span></p>\n<p><b>Maggie</b><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">: I loved the plot ! It captures a lot of factors about modern family life really well in spite of its deeply atypical premise . Ellen epitomizes the way the modern mom feels &#8211; we are pressured to helicopter parent, to make sure our kids are achieving optimum performance scholastically while also having meaningful after-school activities (music, dance,sports etc.)  and yet we are also expected to give them a great deal of freedom, to know when to stop hovering over them and allow them to spread their wings. It&#8217;s an extremely stressful tightrope to walk on and I empathized a lot with Ellen. She&#8217;s also symbolic of the pressures of co-parenting with an ex, that difficulty of getting them to agree on what is best for the child and carry through with the agreed-upon rules and boundaries. I didn&#8217;t find her selfish at all &#8211; tired, stressed and a devoted mother but not selfish. She also characterizes every mother&#8217;s deepest fear, that everything we do isn&#8217;t enough to keep bad things from happening to our kids or bad people from influencing them. </span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">What did you think of the plot/premise? </span></p>\n<p><b>Dabney:</b><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> I, too, thought it was fabulous. You know, from the beginning, that something terrible happened to Ellen and her family and that she blames someone she thought was dead. Ellen&#8217;s loathing for this man is visceral: </span></p>\n<p><i><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Kieran Watts is the monster who destroyed my life. Whose actions will torment my soul until my dying day, and perhaps even beyond—I wouldn’t put it past him.</span></i></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Ellen thinks he&#8217;s dead because she claims she killed him and yet suddenly, while standing in a client&#8217;s home in London, she sees him, standing on the penthouse deck of the apartment across the street. Ellen&#8217;s hatred for Kieran is visceral and, once she&#8217;s seen him, she is determined to find him and make sure that, this time, he pays for what he did to her. </span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">To say that Ellen is obsessed with Kieran is to miswrite.Since the moment Kieran became friends with her son Lucas, seven years ago, Ellen has been sure that Kieran is, as you wrote, a selfish dangerous jackass whose friendship with Lucas is ruining her son. And, as the book goes back and forth between today and seven years ago, we don&#8217;t really know if Ellen&#8217;s right about Kieran or if Ellen&#8217;s obsession keeps her from seeing Lucas, Kieran, and Lucas&#8217; sister Klara clearly. It&#8217;s mesmerizing.</span></p>\n<p><b>Maggie:</b><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> It is mesmerizing, although I think the last several chapters show us the truth pretty clearly. That is another aspect of the thriller market I love right now  &#8211; pages and pages of uncertainty and then shocking clarity. It&#8217;s seductive and addictive. You mentioned Kieran, a disadvantaged teenage boy who earns a scholarship to a posh academy. He could easily have been a boring, clichéd caricature but seen through Ellen&#8217;s eyes he becomes an almost other-worldly harbinger of evil. How did you feel Candlish handled that aspect of the plot?</span></p>\n<p><b>Dabney:</b><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> Parents do not see their teenage children with clarity and, man, did I think that applied to Ellen. Part of the great fun of the novel is trying to figure out what is and isn&#8217;t true in Ellen&#8217;s narration which, we should add, takes up most but not all of the book. Candlish doesn&#8217;t make it easy to sympathize with Ellen consistently&#8211;her rage has warped her and, at times, makes her what may or may not be crazy. Is Kieran evil? Was he evil in the past but now should be forgiven? Who is the psychopath: myopic, enraged Ellen, Kieran the boy, Kieran the man, or some combination therein? I couldn&#8217;t put the book down because I so needed to know the answer to that question!</span></p>\n<p><b>Maggie:</b><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> This actually touches on two of the triggers I found in the book. One is harm to children/young adults &#8211; if you are sensitive to that, this probably isn&#8217;t the novel for you. The second is a phenomenon I call &#8220;Bitches Be Crazy&#8221; and which has been in existence in the Western world for many centuries. It&#8217;s the premise that strong emotions in women are a sign of unbalance &#8211; we are hysterical, obsessed, manic, unhinged. Most women have probably been told to &#8220;calm down&#8221; at least once in their life because we aren&#8217;t allowed any excess display of emotion. I thought Vic, the middle-aged guy who tries so hard to be &#8220;cool&#8221;, labels Ellen this way a lot, as do her daughter and husband. What did you think of the character of Vic? And did the book have any triggers for you?</span></p>\n<p><b>Dabney:</b><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> I am a trigger-free reader although extreme violence to kids is tough for me to read. So, no to that question!</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">As for Vic, I thought he was portrayed as someone we are supposed to know is a loser&#8211;I still can&#8217;t figure out what his wife sees in him. And, again, Ellen does need to calm the f*ck down. Her rage is ruinous and not just for her. One of the things I found especially unlikable about Ellen is how sure she is that her perceptions are THE RIGHT ones. She wouldn&#8217;t listen to anyone, not even those she loved and she knew loved her.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">I really enjoyed </span><b>The Heights</b><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> tremendously even though I found Ellen, Kieran, and Vic all hard to root for. And I think that says something about how well Candlish writes&#8211;I usually don&#8217;t like books where I don&#8217;t like anyone but in this case, it didn&#8217;t bother me. Did you like the book?</span></p>\n<p><b>Maggie:</b><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> I enjoyed the book but with a caveat. I&#8217;ve heard other readers mention that they struggled to get past the beginning and I agree that this is a book you have to settle into. At the twenty percent mark the author says &#8220;keep reading &#8211; because we&#8217;re almost there&#8221; and I can remember wanting to scream at my Kindle <em>&#8220;Are we??&#8221;</em> because I felt like it was taking  a bit too long to get where we were going. Once we were past the precipitating event, the story picked up and was very much what I expected from today&#8217;s thriller market.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><strong>In terms of grading, I would give it a B+/A-</strong>. The book is fabulous once the story really gets going but it does lag a bit between the gripping beginning and the backstory that returns us to that point. What grade would you give it? </span></p>\n<p><b>Dabney</b><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">: <strong>I too would give it at B+/A-</strong>. And, interestingly, for the exact opposite reason. I thought the weakest part of the book was the resolution and the post-resolution exposition. The first 90% of the book is a DIK read for me, but the end just wasn’t quite what I wanted.</span></p>\n<h3 style=\"text-align: center;\"><strong>Buy it at: <a href=\"https://amzn.to/34fUjZS\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Amazon</a>, <a href=\"https://amzn.to/3rtJKuY\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Audible</a> or your <a href=\"https://www.indiebound.org/book/9781982174125?aff=allaboutromance\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">local independent retailer</a></strong></h3>\n<h3 style=\"text-align: center;\"><strong>Visit our <a href=\"https://amzn.to/2SeEiZg\">Amazon Storefront</a></strong></h3>\n",
                "text": "The Heights is a tall, slender apartment building among warehouses in London. Its roof terrace is so discreet, you wouldn’t know it existed if you weren’t standing at the window of the flat directly opposite. But you are. And that’s when you see a man up there—a man you’d recognize anywhere. He may be older now, but it’s definitely him. But that can’t be because he’s been dead for over two years. You know this for a fact. Because you’re the one who killed him. Dabney and Maggie read Louise Candlish&#8217;s The Heights, then (virtually) got together to discuss the novel and are here to share their thoughts. Maggie: Something that I love about the current suspense/thriller/mystery market is that the characters are clever, nuanced and surprising. Almost every novel you pick up has this in common. Candlish is different. Having read her previous work, I know to expect three characters from her  &#8211; one selfish jackass, one naive but earnest damaged individual and one middle-aged man who desperately wants to pretend he&#8217;s in his twenties and sleeps with younger women.  She uses them effectively but they are always present. All three of those stock characters are easily identified in this novel. What is your experience with Candlish and would you agree those characters make an appearance here? Dabney: This is my first Candlish and, after what you&#8217;ve said, I&#8217;m grateful for that. None of these characters felt stock to me. In fact, I&#8217;m not sure who would be who in your first two characterizations! I found Ellen, whom I describe as the main character, mesmerizing and unique. Her particular combination of rage, self-awareness, and intelligence was blazingly compelling to me. I&#8217;m guessing you see her as the earnest damaged individual? I&#8217;d argue she is, in her own way, a selfish jackass. But perhaps we are getting ahead of ourselves. What did you think about the plot? Maggie: I loved the plot ! It captures a lot of factors about modern family life really well in spite of its deeply atypical premise . Ellen epitomizes the way the modern mom feels &#8211; we are pressured to helicopter parent, to make sure our kids are achieving optimum performance scholastically while also having meaningful after-school activities (music, dance,sports etc.)  and yet we are also expected to give them a great deal of freedom, to know when to stop hovering over them and allow them to spread their wings. It&#8217;s an extremely stressful tightrope to walk on and I empathized a lot with Ellen. She&#8217;s also symbolic of the pressures of co-parenting with an ex, that difficulty of getting them to agree on what is best for the child and carry through with the agreed-upon rules and boundaries. I didn&#8217;t find her selfish at all &#8211; tired, stressed and a devoted mother but not selfish. She also characterizes every mother&#8217;s deepest fear, that everything we do isn&#8217;t enough to keep bad things from happening to our kids or bad people from influencing them.  What did you think of the plot/premise?  Dabney: I, too, thought it was fabulous. You know, from the beginning, that something terrible happened to Ellen and her family and that she blames someone she thought was dead. Ellen&#8217;s loathing for this man is visceral:  Kieran Watts is the monster who destroyed my life. Whose actions will torment my soul until my dying day, and perhaps even beyond—I wouldn’t put it past him. Ellen thinks he&#8217;s dead because she claims she killed him and yet suddenly, while standing in a client&#8217;s home in London, she sees him, standing on the penthouse deck of the apartment across the street. Ellen&#8217;s hatred for Kieran is visceral and, once she&#8217;s seen him, she is determined to find him and make sure that, this time, he pays for what he did to her.  To say that Ellen is obsessed with Kieran is to miswrite.Since the moment Kieran became friends with her son Lucas, seven years ago, Ellen has been sure that Kieran is, as you wrote, a selfish dangerous jackass whose friendship with Lucas is ruining her son. And, as the book goes back and forth between today and seven years ago, we don&#8217;t really know if Ellen&#8217;s right about Kieran or if Ellen&#8217;s obsession keeps her from seeing Lucas, Kieran, and Lucas&#8217; sister Klara clearly. It&#8217;s mesmerizing. Maggie: It is mesmerizing, although I think the last several chapters show us the truth pretty clearly. That is another aspect of the thriller market I love right now  &#8211; pages and pages of uncertainty and then shocking clarity. It&#8217;s seductive and addictive. You mentioned Kieran, a disadvantaged teenage boy who earns a scholarship to a posh academy. He could easily have been a boring, clichéd caricature but seen through Ellen&#8217;s eyes he becomes an almost other-worldly harbinger of evil. How did you feel Candlish handled that aspect of the plot? Dabney: Parents do not see their teenage children with clarity and, man, did I think that applied to Ellen. Part of the great fun of the novel is trying to figure out what is and isn&#8217;t true in Ellen&#8217;s narration which, we should add, takes up most but not all of the book. Candlish doesn&#8217;t make it easy to sympathize with Ellen consistently&#8211;her rage has warped her and, at times, makes her what may or may not be crazy. Is Kieran evil? Was he evil in the past but now should be forgiven? Who is the psychopath: myopic, enraged Ellen, Kieran the boy, Kieran the man, or some combination therein? I couldn&#8217;t put the book down because I so needed to know the answer to that question! Maggie: This actually touches on two of the triggers I found in the book. One is harm to children/young adults &#8211; if you are sensitive to that, this probably isn&#8217;t the novel for you. The second is a phenomenon I call &#8220;Bitches Be Crazy&#8221; and which has been in existence in the Western world for many centuries. It&#8217;s the premise that strong emotions in women are a sign of unbalance &#8211; we are hysterical, obsessed, manic, unhinged. Most women have probably been told to &#8220;calm down&#8221; at least once in their life because we aren&#8217;t allowed any excess display of emotion. I thought Vic, the middle-aged guy who tries so hard to be &#8220;cool&#8221;, labels Ellen this way a lot, as do her daughter and husband. What did you think of the character of Vic? And did the book have any triggers for you? Dabney: I am a trigger-free reader although extreme violence to kids is tough for me to read. So, no to that question! As for Vic, I thought he was portrayed as someone we are supposed to know is a loser&#8211;I still can&#8217;t figure out what his wife sees in him. And, again, Ellen does need to calm the f*ck down. Her rage is ruinous and not just for her. One of the things I found especially unlikable about Ellen is how sure she is that her perceptions are THE RIGHT ones. She wouldn&#8217;t listen to anyone, not even those she loved and she knew loved her. I really enjoyed The Heights tremendously even though I found Ellen, Kieran, and Vic all hard to root for. And I think that says something about how well Candlish writes&#8211;I usually don&#8217;t like books where I don&#8217;t like anyone but in this case, it didn&#8217;t bother me. Did you like the book? Maggie: I enjoyed the book but with a caveat. I&#8217;ve heard other readers mention that they struggled to get past the beginning and I agree that this is a book you have to settle into. At the twenty percent mark the author says &#8220;keep reading &#8211; because we&#8217;re almost there&#8221; and I can remember wanting to scream at my Kindle &#8220;Are we??&#8221; because I felt like it was taking  a bit too long to get where we were going. Once we were past the precipitating event, the story picked up and was very much what I expected from today&#8217;s thriller market. In terms of grading, I would give it a B+/A-. The book is fabulous once the story really gets going but it does lag a bit between the gripping beginning and the backstory that returns us to that point. What grade would you give it?  Dabney: I too would give it at B+/A-. And, interestingly, for the exact opposite reason. I thought the weakest part of the book was the resolution and the post-resolution exposition. The first 90% of the book is a DIK read for me, but the end just wasn’t quite what I wanted.                 "text": "Who knew pretending could be so hot?  Clark: It started as a joke. After all, I’d never pretend to date a woman just to get my mom and sister off my back. I would, however, pretend to date her to get her ex-husband off hers. Now the two of us, the wilderness warrior and the wedding planner, are stuck sharing a very small tent. I had no idea how fast things would heat up in here, or how hard it would be to keep my hands—among other things—to myself. I also didn’t guess how quickly the news of our “relationship” would spread to my big, nosy family. We can’t “break up” yet, because she’s planning my brother’s wedding and I’m his best man. Through venue visits, DIY disasters, and Vegas trips, we’re thrown together, and the chemistry’s off-the-charts. But the kicker is, I feel like she gets me. Maybe that’s what scares me the most. I’m still reeling from the loss of my wife, and she’s still hurting from her ex’s betrayal. There’s no way this can ever be real. But what if I’m starting to hope it is? Maria Rose and Dabney are here to discuss the third book in Serena Bell&#8217;s popular Wilder series, Wilder with You.  Dabney:  I&#8217;ve read all the books in the Wilder series and have enjoyed them. How about you?  Maria Rose: I&#8217;ve read them all too. I have to say I enjoyed this one the best of the three so far, but I think that&#8217;s because I&#8217;m in a better reading frame of mind this year than I was in 2021. I found it difficult to enjoy reading in general at certain points of the year (for pandemic and other reasons) so authors that I normally look forward to reading (such as Serena Bell) didn&#8217;t hold the same luster that they usually do. But I&#8217;m happy to say that my reading mojo is back and as a result, this &#8216;fake relationship turns real&#8217; romance kept me quite entertained. I think I&#8217;m also a sucker for heroes like Clark who show their protective side (without doing it in a alpha-hole way).   Dabney: Interesting. This is actually my least favorite of the three! I enjoyed it&#8211;Bell is one of the best contemporary romance writers around and she&#8217;s always genuinely funny&#8211;but Jessa and Clark&#8217;s fake dating/real f*cking thing made no sense to me. I also think&#8211;and this is a somewhat unfair criticism&#8211;that Clark&#8217;s dedication to his dead wife is uncomfortably close to to Sawyer&#8217;s, the hero of my favorite Bell book Sleepover. I think she did that trope better in Sleepover so this book&#8217;s barrier to love felt wan to me.  Maria Rose:  I&#8217;m terrible at remembering characters from other books so I had to check Goodreads to see if I&#8217;d read Sleepover (I haven&#8217;t) so I don&#8217;t have a comparison with it.  I think the concept of pretending to be in a relationship but having real sex gives the characters the chance to act on their attraction to each other without having to think of what that really means in the long term &#8211; it&#8217;s sex without emotional consequences. And since neither Jessa nor Clark is ready to consider having another committed relationship (Jessa because her marriage has recently broken up and Clark having lost his wife), it&#8217;s an easy way out for them.  Of course, the sex scenes are always fun to read in a Bell book too   Dabney: Agree–Bell does love scenes really well. And don’t get me wrong, I enjoyed this book. It just didn’t wow me. If you think of it as a romantic comedy, I felt the comedy was stellar and the romance was just fine. And while I always like checking in with the other Wilders, there was a bit much of them in this book–I found them almost overwhelming. I also had two other small issues with the book. One was the reveal about Barb seemed to me to be a bit odd–it sort of felt like checking a box than something that was intrinsic to what we know about the character. I also really didn’t, as someone who works in medicine, understand the thing that killed Clark’s wife. It wasn’t well explained and didn’t hold up to scrutiny. I just don’t get why authors don’t do a better job of vetting medical things! Maria Rose: I agree with you about Barb, I didn’t think the clues were really there to come up with that reveal (no spoilers!).  As for Clark’s wife Emma’s death, it made his overreaction to events later with Jessa make more sense but it was a somewhat vague way to remove the character. In the end though, the reasons for her death don’t matter as much as how Clark has dealt with it (or not dealt with it in this case). It was good to see him reach a catharsis and those scenes with him and Emma’s mom made me tearful.  I definitely noticed that this series in general is more lighthearted and funny than her Returning Home series which deals with a lot of trauma (though they are some of my favourites by her).  I was fine with all the family interaction (and as you said there is a lot of it). The Wilders are a big family of siblings and with some of the earlier series characters getting married in this one, I’d expect a lot of interaction with them. It’s given us an interesting heads up into Kane’s book too!  Dabney: I’m hopeful for Kane given that Easton’s love story has been staring us in the face since day one. I hope there’s more to it than just enemies who secretly love each other! Kane’s book looks like a secret baby book– it will be fun to see what Bell does with that trope! I really do love reading about the Wilders – they’re such a loving, funny family. This book isn’t my favorite of the series but it was still a fun, sexy read. What grade would you give it?  Maria Rose:  I’m going with a B+ for this one. I liked all aspects of the book and was really happy to see Clark overcome his grief and realize it was okay to be happy again.  I too am looking forward to seeing what happens with Kane and Easton’s stories! What did you decide on for a grade?  Dabney: This is a B for me. It’s a fun, strong story, just not quite into DIK territory for me. Thanks for chatting with me!                 "html": "<p>Every <del>damn</del> day I search for Steals and Deals for AAR&#8217;s readers. Recently, <strong>Take What You Want</strong> showed up. I remembered loving it years ago so I bought it and read it again. I don&#8217;t read a lot of NA and I think good novellas are few&#8211;<strong>Take What You Want</strong> is both and, yes, I still think it&#8217;s great.</p>\n<p>Ellen Price has had it. Her friends are all off on a tropical spring break&#8211;she couldn&#8217;t afford to go&#8211;and she&#8217;s stuck in town, working at the waitress job she balances with her premed classes. Normally, Ellen is a bit shy, focused on her studies, and rather risk averse. But, tonight, she&#8217;s going to change it up.</p>\n<blockquote><p>For one week—one blessed week—she’d be someone else. With no one around to watch her flail or to remark on her strange behavior, she could do anything, <i>be</i> whoever she pleased. The confident woman who took what she wanted.</p></blockquote>\n<p>So, she walks into a bar, dressed in the sexiest outfit she’s ever donned, picks up a stranger, takes him home, and has the best sex of her life.</p>\n<p>There&#8217;s just one hitch.</p>\n<p>Josh&#8211;and there&#8217;s a reason Ellen doesn&#8217;t know this&#8211;is a fellow pre-med student and not only does he know who Ellen is, he’s had a crush on her for the past three years. When Ellen first comes on strong to Josh, he’s not sure what she’s up to. She’s got to recognize him, right? But, Ellen doesn’t seem to know who he is and when he asks her what she does, she says she’s a waitress and mentions not a word about going to school. Josh, though it makes him squirm, is so thrilled that Ellen wants to  jump his bones that he doesn&#8217;t cop to going to school there either and lets Ellen believe he&#8217;s just in town for the week.</p>\n<p>The two head back to Ellen&#8217;s where Josh makes love to Ellen with every ounce of passion and skill he has. It&#8217;s amazing&#8211;beyond superb&#8211;and Josh is determined not to be a one night stand. Ellen too can&#8217;t believe the sex they had and, even if Josh is only here for a week, she&#8217;d like to see him&#8211;and do him&#8211;again. In lesser hands this big mis might not seem viable but Grey makes it work.</p>\n<p>Josh knows he has less than a week to win Ellen and, at some point, tell her he knows her secret. He knows making her scream in bed is not enough and it&#8217;s sure as hell not all he wants. He wants her to fall for him as he’s fallen for her, to trust him with her life, and to keep their relationship going when they are back in chem class when Spring Break ends.</p>\n<p>Josh is the bomb. Each hour he spends with Ellen, whether it’s in the shower, or on his Harley, or lying next to her on the roof staring at millions of stars, Josh listens to Ellen, trying to understand who she is. He’s that rare thing: an almost perfect guy who doesn’t seem fake, dull, or unbelievable. He’s his physician father’s only child and, for as long as Josh can remember, his dad has pushed him to go to medical school. Josh though doesn’t want to be that kind of doctor. He wants to be the kind who has a PhD in chemistry. Watching him gird himself to come clean to both Ellen and his dad, well, I wish all young men were as clear eyed and as big-hearted as Josh.</p>\n<p>Ellen too is lovely. It’s a joy to watch her trust in her new-found sensuality and discover that her life can give her more, much more, than she’s previously demanded. As she spends time with Josh, she pushes him to take the same chances with his father that she is with him. Their relationship develops quickly but it works because Josh and Ellen are wonderful together.</p>\n<p>The dialogue, indeed all the prose in the book, is sharp and clever. Grey has a pen for voices&#8211;I could hear Josh and Ellen, each distinct, as the two flirted and spoke. The extra little details about their lives&#8211;how Ellen thinks about what she wears, how Josh sees his parents&#8217; strong marriage&#8211;are crystalline. Grey packs a lot in to her pages and the book has a heft many novellas do not.</p>\n<p>I could go on and on. The very frequent sex scenes are lovely and hot. The college town is spot on. The “we fell in love in a week” works here. The writing is crisp and clear. And, oh, the last scene in the book is flat-out fabulous. In it, Ms. Grey takes all the strands of her novel and all the hopes and dreams Josh and Ellen have and creates one of the sweetest endings I’ve read in a romance in a long time.</p>\n<p>I loved <strong>Take What You Want</strong>. It gets an A- from me.</p>\n<h3 style=\"text-align: center\"><strong>Buy it at: <a href=\"https://amzn.to/3IeCOHX\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Amazon</a></strong></h3>\n<h3 style=\"text-align: center\"><strong>Visit our <a href=\"https://amzn.to/2SeEiZg\">Amazon Storefront</a></strong></h3>\n",

                "html": "<p>Joy Delaney, almost 70, has vanished.</p>\n<p>Her husband of fifty years, Stan, and their four kids&#8211;Brooke, Amy, Logan, and Troy&#8211;say they&#8217;ve no idea where&#8217;s she gone. She left no word of where she was headed and her cellphone, purse, and car are all sitting at home. Has she been killed? And if so, did Stan do it? After all, he has scratches on his face and an unhelpful manner. Do his children suspect him? Are they protecting him? What do they know&#8211;because they obviously know something&#8211;that they&#8217;re not telling the police? And how does Savannah, the mysterious young woman who stayed a few weeks with Stan and Joy earlier in the year, figure into it all?</p>\n<p>This is the ostensible plot of the latest headed-for-the-big/small-screen novel by Australia&#8217;s best-selling author Liane Moriarty. But if Joy&#8217;s disappearance is the kernel of the film, the flesh of this story is that of the Delaney family. I couldn&#8217;t get enough of them; each is so fully formed and fallible I could have successfully bought them each a Christmas gift they&#8217;d have loved.*</p>\n<p>The novel lays out the lives of the Delaneys-it goes back and forth in time like all Moriarty&#8217;s books&#8211;in reverent detail. We see Stan and Joy as children&#8211;they were in the very top tier of Aussie tennis players at very young ages&#8211;as young passionate lovers, as exhausted parents, as successful business partners in on of Australia&#8217;s most venerated tennis schools, all the way through to their 50th Valentine&#8217;s Day together&#8211;it&#8217;s the last day anyone heard from Joy. Their kids too are limned through Moriarty&#8217;s crisp, descriptive prose and their secrets and dreams resonate with realism.</p>\n<p>I liked Savannah, the perhaps villainess of the story, less. Like many psychopathic liars, she&#8217;s a blurry protagonist and one I found hard to believe in. That said, the way Savannah understands the Delaneys and uses their best impulses against them is great fun to read mostly because the Delaneys are wonderfully and precisely fascinating.</p>\n<p>As I listened to this story&#8211;Caroline Lee&#8217;s narration is a knock-out&#8211;I wondered at where these six people would land. Did Stan murder Joy? (This is the conviction of the dogged detective on his trail, a long-suffering young woman named Christina Khoury whose determination to see Joy&#8217;s disappearance as a crime is obviously understandable.) Will Amy, the oldest and most offbeat Delaney child, ever get her shit together and see the love right under her eyes? Will Troy decided to let his ex-wife whom he still loves implant the embryos they made when they were still married so that she and her new husband can have a baby? Will Brooke&#8217;s physiotherapy practice succeed better than her marriage? Will Logan win back the heart of Indira or subdue the low-level jealousy he harbors towards his brother&#8217;s successes ? And, most importantly, will Joy, whose love, determination, and sheer verve have ruled her own family for years, get the future she deserves or is she yet another victim of suburban violence?</p>\n<p>You&#8217;ll want to know the answers to these questions badly. And, with the exception of the very last chapter which I am convinced was written with an eye toward the novel&#8217;s inevitable filming, I loved the resolution to these stories. The novel is hopeful and, even better, clear eyed on the necessary compromises one makes for family and for love. <strong>Apples Never Fall</strong> is my favorite of Moriarty&#8217;s work&#8211;read it before it hits the screen.</p>\n<h3 style=\"text-align: center;\"><strong>Buy it at: <a href=\"https://amzn.to/3FUSP5a\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Amazon</a>, <a href=\"https://amzn.to/3sRklMU\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Audible</a> or your <a href=\"https://www.indiebound.org/book/9781250220271?aff=allaboutromance\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">local independent retailer</a></strong></h3>\n<h3 style=\"text-align: center;\"><strong>Visit our <a href=\"https://amzn.to/2SeEiZg\">Amazon Storefront</a></strong></h3>\n<p>*Delaney gift list:</p>\n<p>for <a href=\"https://amzn.to/3zgxbpo\">Joy</a></p>\n<p>for <a href=\"https://amzn.to/3sMJMiV\">Stan</a></p>\n<p>for <a href=\"https://amzn.to/32VoIvr\">Amy</a></p>\n<p>for <a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/Monogrammed-Gifts-Women-Personalized-Engraved/dp/B01HPQ8DXM/ref=sxin_12_pa_sp_search_thematic_sspa?crid=19599BQ8AQZJ8&amp;cv_ct_cx=wine%2Bglass%2Bset&amp;keywords=wine%2Bglass%2Bset&amp;pd_rd_i=B01HPQ9BWO&amp;pd_rd_r=655fac49-2c8f-4ce8-832b-7c56df8f9359&amp;pd_rd_w=WN63k&amp;pd_rd_wg=fOWWB&amp;pf_rd_p=4ad71b32-b810-4124-8735-d02a39478d0c&amp;pf_rd_r=YQW2EB0HGF0BPJ61V99E&amp;qid=1641144885&amp;sprefix=wine%2Bglass%2B%2Caps%2C76&amp;sr=1-1-a73d1c8c-2fd2-4f19-aa41-2df022bcb241-spons&amp;smid=A2GP3964Y64K0P&amp;spLa=ZW5jcnlwdGVkUXVhbGlmaWVyPUE2V0dJRTFMQzdFRjImZW5jcnlwdGVkSWQ9QTAyMTEyNDIxR1EzS0VPTFhZSjlRJmVuY3J5cHRlZEFkSWQ9QTA5NjU1MDkxRVJOTUwyQjkwSTU3JndpZGdldE5hbWU9c3Bfc2VhcmNoX3RoZW1hdGljJmFjdGlvbj1jbGlja1JlZGlyZWN0JmRvTm90TG9nQ2xpY2s9dHJ1ZQ&amp;th=1\">Brooke</a></p>\n<p>for <a href=\"https://amzn.to/3qDFpE9\">Logan</a></p>\n<p>for <a href=\"https://amzn.to/3pMEAtx\">Troy</a></p>\n<p>&nbsp;</p>\n",

                "html": "<p><b>Illumination Night</b> was my favorite book for a decade of my life. It and Josephine Humphrey&#8217;s <a href=\"https://amzn.to/3x0LpJZ\"><b>Dreams of Sleep</b> </a>are two stories I wish I had the talent to have written. I read both before I was married and now, after almost 35 years of marriage, their perspectives on the complexity of a partnered life still resonate.</p>\n<p><b>Illumination Night</b> is the story of Vonny and Andre, their son Simon, Elizabeth the old lady who lives next door, and Jody Elizabeth&#8217;s rebellious granddaughter. There&#8217;s also a giant who hides from the world while tending chickens. All live in Chilmark on Martha&#8217;s Vineyard.</p>\n<p>As the book begins, Vonny and Andre are at a strained time in their marriage. Their son, Simon, is abnormally short for his age and Vonny not only worries about him, she worries about everything, so much so that she becomes unable to leave the house. And though Andre loves Vonny, he&#8217;s unable to understand her now and is increasingly withdrawn, spending much of his time restoring old motorcycles in their garage.</p>\n<p>Elizabeth, at seventy-three, is recovering from having jumped out of her upstairs window&#8211;she momentarily believed she could fly. She needs someone to care for her and takes in her 16 year old granddaughter Jody who is as reckless as wildfire. Elizabeth was never close to her daughter, Jody&#8217;s mother, but she and Jody meet each other&#8217;s needs as Jody finds her way to adulthood and Elizabeth finds her way to the finish of her long life.</p>\n<p>These characters, achingly and accurately rendered, change themselves and each other. Jody, who sometimes babysits Simon, has a disastrous lust for Andre which Vonny fears will destroy her marriage. And yet the two women become friends, united by their feelings for Simon. Simon, who watched Elizabeth jump, is determined to grow taller and, after seeing the boy they call The Giant, begins to understand what it means to grow up in more ways than one. The Giant and Jody, well, their relationship will remake them both.</p>\n<p>Hoffman explores the connections and conflicts in desire and danger, love and death, laughter and tears, fear and contentment. Her empathy for her characters is unparalleled. For years Hoffman has been dismissed as a serious author&#8211;and, yes, I blame the patriarchy&#8211;and that&#8217;s always pissed me off. Over the past four and a half decades, she&#8217;s mined the myriad magic of women&#8217;s lives and loves using language that verges on poetry. I don&#8217;t always love her books but they&#8217;re a damn sight better than the endless NYT best-sellers, too often penned by bitter and depressed men, who seem to believe that love, joy, and kindness themselves are fairy tales. Hoffman knows they&#8217;re not, that every life has the potential for beauty and wonder. I&#8217;ve read most of her books and many are excellent. This one, to me, is one of her very best.</p>\n<h3 style=\"text-align: center\"><strong>Buy it at <a href=\"https://amzn.to/3oJtGmk\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Amazon</a>, <a href=\"https://amzn.to/3CxBkoR\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Audible</a> or your <a href=\"https://www.indiebound.org/book/9780425183267?aff=allaboutromance\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">local independent retailer</a></strong></h3>\n<h3 style=\"text-align: center\"><strong>Visit our <a href=\"https://amzn.to/2SeEiZg\">Amazon Storefront</a></strong></h3>\n<h3 style=\"text-align: center\"></h3>\n",
                "text": "Illumination Night was my favorite book for a decade of my life. It and Josephine Humphrey&#8217;s Dreams of Sleep are two stories I wish I had the talent to have written.
