                "html": "<blockquote><p>A most unexpected client shows up at Charlotte Holmes&#8217;s doorstep: Moriarty himself. Moriarty fears that tragedy has befallen his daughter and wants Charlotte to find out the truth.</p>\n<p>Charlotte and Mrs. Watson travel to a remote community of occult practitioners where Moriarty&#8217;s daughter was last seen, a place full of lies and liars. Meanwhile, Charlotte’s sister Livia tries to make sense of a mysterious message from her beau Mr. Marbleton. And Charlotte’s longtime friend and ally Lord Ingram at last turns his seductive prowess on Charlotte—or is it the other way around?</p>\n<p>But the more secrets Charlotte unravels about Miss Moriarty’s disappearance, the more she wonders why Moriarty has entrusted this delicate matter to her of all people. Is it merely to test Charlotte&#8217;s skills as an investigator, or has the man of shadows trapped her in a nest of vipers?</p></blockquote>\n<p>The game is &#8211; once again &#8211; very much afoot in this sixth installment in Sherry Thomas’ <strong><em>Lady Sherlock </em></strong>series of clever historical mysteries.  As the synopsis indicates, she finally comes face-to-face with her nemesis &#8211; but rather than the expected violent confrontation, ‘Mr. Baxter’ instead wants to engage Holmes’ services to investigate the disappearance of his daughter from a Hermetic (possibly occultist) community in a remote corner of Cornwall.  Of course, Charlotte knows not to take anything at face value, but with no other options available, Charlotte, Lord Ingram and Mrs. Watson head for the Garden of Hermopolis to see what they can find out.  In the meantime, Charlotte’s sister, Livia, is following an intriguing trail of breadcrumbs left by Stephen Marbleton that leads to some very intriguing coded messages which could prove vital in the fight against Moriarty.</p>\n<p>Caz and Dabney are both massive Sherry Thomas fans and have followed the series since day one &#8211; although their opinions over the last couple of books have diverged.  They both read <strong>Miss Moriarty, I Presume?</strong> and are here to share their thoughts about the novel.</p>\n<hr />\n<p><strong>Caz: </strong>Dabney, I know I’ve enjoyed the last couple of <strong><em>Lady Sherlock</em></strong> books a bit more than you have &#8211; but much as it pains me to say it, even <em>I</em> found this one to be a bit of a slog.  None of the books really work as standalones, and that’s especially true of <strong>Miss Moriarty</strong>, which feels like a culmination of all that has gone before.  There are lots of references to events and characters from previous books, but while I was pleased to see all the puzzle pieces being drawn together, I did at times struggle to recall all the whos, whats whens and whys &#8211; and it made for a pretty dense read.</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney: </strong>I want to love this series, I do. And the first two were fabulous and the third quite good but since then, well, I’m losing interest. Each of the last three books has required recalling <em>in detail </em>the preceding books, to the point that without my Kindle’s search feature, I’d have been lost. The plotting is, as you say, dense and the story arcs of the series &#8211; Charlotte and Ash, Moriarty’s true aims, Livia and Mr. Marbleton &#8211; are leisurely. At this point, I’m hoping she’ll speed up these resolutions and move on. The adage <em>all good things must come to an end</em> resonates for a reason.</p>\n<p><strong>Caz: </strong> I agree that there’s been a loss of momentum over the past book or two.  I haven’t found it too much of a problem to be able to recall the plot details I needed to follow each book, but this time around?  Yeah, I was reading things and thinking <em>“I know I should know why this is important…”</em> but couldn’t always remember why, and that was frustrating.  Maybe that’s a failure on my part, but even though I follow a number of mystery series that require some knowledge of what went before, I struggled here.  There were things I liked a lot, but as a whole, I found <strong>Miss Moriarty, I Presume?</strong> to be tough going.  The first half is pretty slow &#8211; actually, the first two-thirds or so is slow &#8211; although fortunately, it did pick up later in the second half and reached a satisfying conclusion.  Although there is clearly more to come.</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney</strong>: I too follow several long-running series and can follow them far better than I can this one. Part of this is that Thomas’ plots have become <span style=\"text-decoration: line-through;\">unbelievably</span>  so intricate that they hinge on tiny details. Worse &#8211; and it pains me to say this &#8211; the clues relevant here, especially those left by Mr. Marbleton, were too far fetched for this reader.</p>\n<p><strong>Caz: </strong> I’d have to agree with that on both counts.  The ‘treasure hunt’ was interesting and very clever, but maybe just a little bit <em>too</em> clever?  I like a complex plot, and that aspect of the books has worked for me so far, but it’s getting too convoluted. One of my biggest issues over the last couple of books is something I touched on in my review of <a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/book-review/murder-on-cold-street-by-sherry-thomas/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"><strong>Murder on Cold Street</strong> </a>&#8211; and you’ve mentioned it, too &#8211; the Moriarty Plot. One of the problems I’m having with the series as a whole is that he’s just so… nebulous, that I can’t work out why Charlotte et al are so scared of him.  In fact, I’ve realised that my view of him &#8211; he’s an evil mastermind who is always Up To No Good &#8211; is based pretty much entirely on the fact that I know he’s the Big Bad in Conan Doyle’s stories.  At least in the BBC version, Andrew Scott’s Moriarty was one of those oddly compelling treading-the-thin-line-between-genius-and-madness types &#8211; but this Moriarty is so hazy that the stakes for our heroes just aren’t very clear.</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney</strong>: And that lack of clear characterization which, I suspect, Thomas has taken from Conan Doyle&#8217;s books &#8211; he only appeared in two of the stories &#8211; makes the way in which everyone else responds to him hard to parse. These books are not adaptations, they’re original tales that borrow from source material <strong>somewhat</strong>. I feel as though we are stuck in some fictional world where, in order to appreciate Thomas’ undeniable genius, we have to both understand Conan Doyle’s characters while making sense of Thomas’. That combination just isn’t working for me.</p>\n<p><strong>Caz:</strong>  It’s been a long time since I read any of the original Holmes stories, but I think you’re right.  And while having a single-note baddie may have worked back when they were written, modern mysteries have moved on and generally tend to flesh them out a lot more.  It seems we’re both having similar issues.  So, what, if anything, did you like about this one?</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney</strong>: Thomas is a gorgeous writer, her descriptions of people and places are grounded and believable. Her characters are interesting and her sly sense of humor is a gift. Ash and Charlotte are lovely together &#8211; I <em>really</em> would like to see far more of them as lovers &#8211; and Charlotte’s compassion for her sisters is boundless. I admire the braininess of these books even as it impedes my pleasure.</p>\n<p><strong>Caz:</strong>  The writing is sublime, and the characterisations are amazing across the board.  I’d also like more of Ash and Charlotte as lovers, but I remind myself that this is historical mystery and not historical romance and tell myself to be happy with what we get!  Ash is delicious though &#8211; I do love those moments when the proper gentleman disappears and rawr!Ash makes an appearance ;)  The epistolary flirting at the beginning is sexy and fun (hah -and then the bag of contraceptives and the, er… *wink*) and even though things aren’t completely settled between them, there’s a real sense that they’re happy with the way things are.  And although I said the first part of the book is slow, I did like the scenes where they’re preparing for the visit by (as they think) Moriarty’s henchman; Sherry Thomas creates some amazing tension and unease there.</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney</strong>: So what’s your grade? I think <strong>mine is a B</strong> simply because Thomas’ work is surpassingly better than most.</p>\n<p><strong>Caz: </strong>Same, and for similar reasons. The final quarter is worth the price of admission, the writing is simply exceptional and I continue to love the characters.  But I am worried the series is becoming (has become?) a bit too complicated for its own good.</p>\n<h3 style=\"text-align: center;\"><strong>Buy it at <a href=\"https://amzn.to/3bosgYn\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Amazon</a>, <a href=\"https://amzn.to/3bnbDfH\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Audible</a> or your <a href=\"https://www.indiebound.org/book/9780593200582?aff=allaboutromance\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">local independent retailer</a></strong></h3>\n<h3 style=\"text-align: center;\"><strong>Visit our <a href=\"https://amzn.to/2SeEiZg\">Amazon Storefront</a></strong></h3>\n",
                "text": "A most unexpected client shows up at Charlotte Holmes&#8217;s doorstep: Moriarty himself. Moriarty fears that tragedy has befallen his daughter and wants Charlotte to find out the truth. Charlotte and Mrs. Watson travel to a remote community of occult practitioners where Moriarty&#8217;s daughter was last seen, a place full of lies and liars. Meanwhile, Charlotte’s sister Livia tries to make sense of a mysterious message from her beau Mr. Marbleton. And Charlotte’s longtime friend and ally Lord Ingram at last turns his seductive prowess on Charlotte—or is it the other way around? But the more secrets Charlotte unravels about Miss Moriarty’s disappearance, the more she wonders why Moriarty has entrusted this delicate matter to her of all people. Is it merely to test Charlotte&#8217;s skills as an investigator, or has the man of shadows trapped her in a nest of vipers? The game is &#8211; once again &#8211; very much afoot in this sixth installment in Sherry Thomas’ Lady Sherlock series of clever historical mysteries.  As the synopsis indicates, she finally comes face-to-face with her nemesis &#8211; but rather than the expected violent confrontation, ‘Mr. Baxter’ instead wants to engage Holmes’ services to investigate the disappearance of his daughter from a Hermetic (possibly occultist) community in a remote corner of Cornwall.  Of course, Charlotte knows not to take anything at face value, but with no other options available, Charlotte, Lord Ingram and Mrs. Watson head for the Garden of Hermopolis to see what they can find out.  In the meantime, Charlotte’s sister, Livia, is following an intriguing trail of breadcrumbs left by Stephen Marbleton that leads to some very intriguing coded messages which could prove vital in the fight against Moriarty. Caz and Dabney are both massive Sherry Thomas fans and have followed the series since day one &#8211; although their opinions over the last couple of books have diverged.  They both read Miss Moriarty, I Presume? and are here to share their thoughts about the novel. Caz: Dabney, I know I’ve enjoyed the last couple of Lady Sherlock books a bit more than you have &#8211; but much as it pains me to say it, even I found this one to be a bit of a slog.  None of the books really work as standalones, and that’s especially true of Miss Moriarty, which feels like a culmination of all that has gone before.  There are lots of references to events and characters from previous books, but while I was pleased to see all the puzzle pieces being drawn together, I did at times struggle to recall all the whos, whats whens and whys &#8211; and it made for a pretty dense read. Dabney: I want to love this series, I do. And the first two were fabulous and the third quite good but since then, well, I’m losing interest. Each of the last three books has required recalling in detail the preceding books, to the point that without my Kindle’s search feature, I’d have been lost. The plotting is, as you say, dense and the story arcs of the series &#8211; Charlotte and Ash, Moriarty’s true aims, Livia and Mr. Marbleton &#8211; are leisurely. At this point, I’m hoping she’ll speed up these resolutions and move on. The adage all good things must come to an end resonates for a reason. Caz:  I agree that there’s been a loss of momentum over the past book or two.  I haven’t found it too much of a problem to be able to recall the plot details I needed to follow each book, but this time around?  Yeah, I was reading things and thinking “I know I should know why this is important…” but couldn’t always remember why, and that was frustrating.  Maybe that’s a failure on my part, but even though I follow a number of mystery series that require some knowledge of what went before, I struggled here.  There were things I liked a lot, but as a whole, I found Miss Moriarty, I Presume? to be tough going.  The first half is pretty slow &#8211; actually, the first two-thirds or so is slow &#8211; although fortunately, it did pick up later in the second half and reached a satisfying conclusion.  Although there is clearly more to come. Dabney: I too follow several long-running series and can follow them far better than I can this one. Part of this is that Thomas’ plots have become unbelievably  so intricate that they hinge on tiny details. Worse &#8211; and it pains me to say this &#8211; the clues relevant here, especially those left by Mr. Marbleton, were too far fetched for this reader. Caz:  I’d have to agree with that on both counts.  The ‘treasure hunt’ was interesting and very clever, but maybe just a little bit too clever?  I like a complex plot, and that aspect of the books has worked for me so far, but it’s getting too convoluted. One of my biggest issues over the last couple of books is something I touched on in my review of Murder on Cold Street &#8211; and you’ve mentioned it, too &#8211; the Moriarty Plot. One of the problems I’m having with the series as a whole is that he’s just so… nebulous, that I can’t work out why Charlotte et al are so scared of him.  In fact, I’ve realised that my view of him &#8211; he’s an evil mastermind who is always Up To No Good &#8211; is based pretty much entirely on the fact that I know he’s the Big Bad in Conan Doyle’s stories.  At least in the BBC version, Andrew Scott’s Moriarty was one of those oddly compelling treading-the-thin-line-between-genius-and-madness types &#8211; but this Moriarty is so hazy that the stakes for our heroes just aren’t very clear. Dabney: And that lack of clear characterization which, I suspect, Thomas has taken from Conan Doyle&#8217;s books &#8211; he only appeared in two of the stories &#8211; makes the way in which everyone else responds to him hard to parse. These books are not adaptations, they’re original tales that borrow from source material somewhat. I feel as though we are stuck in some fictional world where, in order to appreciate Thomas’ undeniable genius, we have to both understand Conan Doyle’s characters while making sense of Thomas’. That combination just isn’t working for me. Caz:  It’s been a long time since I read any of the original Holmes stories, but I think you’re right.  And while having a single-note baddie may have worked back when they were written, modern mysteries have moved on and generally tend to flesh them out a lot more.  It seems we’re both having similar issues.  So, what, if anything, did you like about this one? Dabney: Thomas is a gorgeous writer, her descriptions of people and places are grounded and believable. Her characters are interesting and her sly sense of humor is a gift. Ash and Charlotte are lovely together &#8211; I really would like to see far more of them as lovers &#8211; and Charlotte’s compassion for her sisters is boundless. I admire the braininess of these books even as it impedes my pleasure. Caz:  The writing is sublime, and the characterisations are amazing across the board.  I’d also like more of Ash and Charlotte as lovers, but I remind myself that this is historical mystery and not historical romance and tell myself to be happy with what we get!  Ash is delicious though &#8211; I do love those moments when the proper gentleman disappears and rawr!Ash makes an appearance ;)  The epistolary flirting at the beginning is sexy and fun (hah -and then the bag of contraceptives and the, er… *wink*) and even though things aren’t completely settled between them, there’s a real sense that they’re happy with the way things are.  And although I said the first part of the book is slow, I did like the scenes where they’re preparing for the visit by (as they think) Moriarty’s henchman; Sherry Thomas creates some amazing tension and unease there. Dabney: So what’s your grade? I think mine is a B simply because Thomas’ work is surpassingly better than most. Caz: Same, and for similar reasons. The final quarter is worth the price of admission, the writing is simply exceptional and I continue to love the characters.  But I am worried the series is becoming (has become?) a bit too complicated for its own good.                 "html": "<p><a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/book-review/walk-on-the-wilder-side-wilder-adventures-book-2-by-serena-bell/\">I&#8217;m a fan of Bell&#8217;s <em>Wilder</em> series</a> and had thought there&#8217;d be six books, one for each Wilder sibling. It appears, however, that the story of the lone female Wilder, the already married Amanda, is told in a short story included in the anthology <a href=\"https://amzn.to/3uyqwog\"><strong>Tinsel and Tatas</strong></a>. This collection, a charitable endeavor in support of the<strong><em> Young Survival Coalition</em></strong>, an international organization focusing on women ages 40 and under diagnosed with breast cancer, comes out this week. The anthology has several well-known names in it including Bell&#8217;s and I look forward to reading more of its stories. This review, however, is only for <em>Wilder for the Win</em>.</p>\n<p>What you really want to know is: Is this story worth the 99 cents the anthology costs? The answer: Yes.</p>\n<p>It&#8217;s a challenge to write a contemporary romance about an already married couple. All of the traditional steps that propel much of romance&#8211;first date, first kiss, first sex, first fight&#8211;are in the past. And if the problem the couple faces is too huge, the love story can feel overly heavy. In this story, Amanda and Heath have been married since they were 19, have three adorable kids, and are surrounded by loving family and friends. But, like so many parents, they feel swamped by their kids, their jobs, and their inability to get enough sleep. I have <strong>so</strong> been there&#8211;Bell&#8217;s description of that life is spot on.</p>\n<p>Amanda and Heath love each other and think the other is as hot as a kiln in August. But they haven&#8217;t had sex in <em>three months, two weeks, three days and two hours</em> and neither really understands why. Amanda is determined to get her damn husband back in the sack and has decided today (and tonight) is the perfect time&#8211;the story takes place in a single day during which the Wilder family hosts Rush Creek&#8217;s holiday season Winter Games and Gala. She&#8217;s got not one but two super sexy outfits&#8211;one for the Games and one for the Gala&#8211;and she&#8217;s gone all out with her makeup and her hair. But when she shows up in the kitchen in outfit #1&#8211;a red low cut sweater with reindeer pom-poms aligned with her nipples&#8211;Heath, unloading the dishwasher, barely seems to notice.</p>\n<p>It&#8217;s not, however, that Heath doesn&#8217;t notice&#8211;he sure as shit does&#8211;but he thinks Amanda is so overwhelmed by their life that she doesn&#8217;t want him to make any moves on her. It&#8217;s a classic Big Mis.</p>\n<p>The story is written in alternating first person which works beautifully. Heath is a lovey man who adores his wife and kids and his voice is less strident than Amanda&#8217;s&#8211;he&#8217;s puzzled about their lack of sex but cares first and foremost about supporting his bae. Amanda, the only girl of six, is more frustrated than puzzled. Both, like all in the <em>Wilder</em> world, are very funny and easy to empathize with. I laughed out loud more than once in this 40-ish page story and rooted for the two of them to find their sexual connection again.</p>\n<p>If you like the other <strong><em>Wilder</em></strong> books, this is a must read. It is, it must be said, too short. I wish Bell had written Amanda at least a novella rather than a short story, but given its length, this is satisfying, sweet, sexy read.</p>\n<h3 style=\"text-align: center;\"><strong>Buy it at <a href=\"https://amzn.to/3A1ifdi\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Amazon</a></strong></h3>\n<h3 style=\"text-align: center;\"><strong>Visit our <a href=\"https://amzn.to/2SeEiZg\">Amazon Storefront</a></strong></h3>\n<p>&nbsp;</p>\n",
                "text": "I&#8217;m a fan of Bell&#8217;s Wilder series and had thought there&#8217;d be six books, one for each Wilder sibling. It appears, however, that the story of the lone female Wilder, the already married Amanda, is told in a short story included in the anthology Tinsel and Tatas. This collection, a charitable endeavor in support of the Young Survival Coalition, an international organization focusing on women ages 40 and under diagnosed with breast cancer, comes out this week. The anthology has several well-known names in it including Bell&#8217;s and I look forward to reading more of its stories. This review, however, is only for Wilder for the Win. What you really want to know is: Is this story worth the 99 cents the anthology costs? The answer: Yes. It&#8217;s a challenge to write a contemporary romance about an already married couple. All of the traditional steps that propel much of romance&#8211;first date, first kiss, first sex, first fight&#8211;are in the past. And if the problem the couple faces is too huge, the love story can feel overly heavy. In this story, Amanda and Heath have been married since they were 19, have three adorable kids, and are surrounded by loving family and friends. But, like so many parents, they feel swamped by their kids, their jobs, and their inability to get enough sleep. I have so been there&#8211;Bell&#8217;s description of that life is spot on. You want to know why Ruby Dixon&#8217;s wildly successful series about a group of women who, after being kidnapped from Earth and imprisoned on a spaceship which then crashes, find themselves on an ice planet populated by large blue aliens, mostly male, all of whom are searching for true love, babies, and copious hot sex, have sold bazillions and been analyzed by luminaries such as CNN and countless blogs. I don&#8217;t know. I guess if I read more of the series&#8211;book 22 just came out in February&#8211; I might better understand why readers are obsessed with Dixon&#8217;s books. I mean, I enjoyed Ice Planet Barbarians&#8211;it&#8217;s funny, full of female-centric torrid love scenes, and it was kind of interesting to consider whether or not a symbiotic relationship with a worm can really facilitate finding one&#8217;s soul mate.                 "html": "<p>When it comes to anthologies, it pays to keep your priorities straight. This is how I square it: Entertainment + No Real Problems + Happy Feelings = Satisfaction. So after reading Avon&#8217;s latest anthology and doing some calculations, I can conclude that it works. And the cover is not bad either.</p>\n<hr />\n<p>Sophia Nash&#8217;s contribution, <strong><em>Catch of the Century</em></strong>, doesn&#8217;t feel as polished as it should or could, which is a pity, because there&#8217;s a lot going for it. Victoria Givens, orphanage employee, is escorting three of her charges to an apprenticeship when they get stranded; the Duke of Beaufort (aka Catch of the Century) rescues them. I think Ms. Nash was aiming for screwball comedy, but often the humor comes off as heavy-handed. The author is also too enamored of her Widows Club series and inserts so many of its characters and references that this story suffers, something that, given the page limit, it can&#8217;t afford. However, there are some nice moments in both dialogue and prose, and character development is solid albeit unevenly paced. I&#8217;m going to keep an eye on this author. Sensuality: Warm</p>\n<p>Grade: B-</p>\n<p>If Old School were a sub-genre, Tracy Anne Warren&#8217;s <strong><em>Charmed By Her Smile</em></strong> would qualify since I haven&#8217;t read this plot or come across characters like these in ages. During a house party, 18-year-old young miss asks 32-year-old bored rake to pretend to court her to fob off an unwanted suitor, during which they fall in love. Groan. But it worked. The character portraits aren’t very profound, but the hero and heroine have heaps of chemistry, they get along well, and the unwanted suitor was a believable source of conflict. And it&#8217;s so romantic. Sigh. I haven&#8217;t read Ms. Warren in a while but I&#8217;ll be digging right back in. Sensuality: Warm</p>\n<p>Grade: B+</p>\n<p><em><strong>Devil to Pay</strong></em> takes place in Jeaniene Frost&#8217;s Night Huntress world about which I know nothing, but Ms. Frost wisely minimizes the world-building and focuses on this story. Blake has been possessed by a demon who has turned him into a murderer and he&#8217;s about to throw himself in the path of a subway when he meets vampire Elise. Something about Blake and his predicament galvanizes Elise out of her decades-old aloofness and she helps him exorcise his demon. The development of Blake and Elise&#8217;s feelings is a little uneven, but the story isn&#8217;t bad, the demon is suitably scary. I was intrigued enough with Ms. Frost&#8217;s vampires that I&#8217;ll have to look for more. Sensuality: Subtle</p>\n<p>Grade: B-</p>\n<p>Now on the other hand, Elaine Fox&#8217;s <em><strong>The Duke Who Came to Dinner</strong> </em>is only 60 pages long but the author makes the most of every one. How? She decides to entertain, and entertain most charmingly she does. One cold June morning in Massachusetts, Sam Gregory spies a naked woman pedalling furiously in front of his house. They meet later at the local bar; turns out Gray Gilliam threw caution to the wind (her goal for the summer), went skinny-dipping, and had her clothes stolen by Sam&#8217;s dog. Plus, there is a ghost haunting Gray&#8217;s cottage. It&#8217;s contrived, it&#8217;s cute, and I found it utterly charming in spite of myself. I have a new author to glom. Sensuality: Warm</p>\n<p>Grade: B+</p>\n<p>Cathy Maxwell&#8217;s <em><strong>The Irish Duke</strong></em> is a paltry 50 pages, which includes an epilogue, and boy does it show. Susan Rogers is a marriage advisor to the debutantes of the ton and when she says something that gets twisted out of proportion, it is left to the Irish Duke to reap the fallout. In revenge, the Irish Duke makes a wager about her, which ruins her reputation, but then they realize they love each other, and elope to Scotland. This is where the math comes in: Zero chemistry + Too much telling + Near-invisible characterization = Zero interest. The story is not bad, just deadly dull and fatally unwritten. I could see this as a novella, though. Sensuality: Subtle</p>\n<p>Grade: D+</p>\n",
                "text": "When it comes to anthologies, it pays to keep your priorities straight. This is how I square it: Entertainment + No Real Problems + Happy Feelings = Satisfaction. So after reading Avon&#8217;s latest anthology and doing some calculations, I can conclude that it works. And the cover is not bad either. Sophia Nash&#8217;s contribution, Catch of the Century, doesn&#8217;t feel as polished as it should or could, which is a pity, because there&#8217;s a lot going for it. Victoria Givens, orphanage employee, is escorting three of her charges to an apprenticeship when they get stranded; the Duke of Beaufort (aka Catch of the Century) rescues them. I think Ms. Nash was aiming for screwball comedy, but often the humor comes off as heavy-handed. The author is also too enamored of her Widows Club series and inserts so many of its characters and references that this story suffers, something that, given the page limit, it can&#8217;t afford. However, there are some nice moments in both dialogue and prose, and character development is solid albeit unevenly paced. I&#8217;m going to keep an eye on this author. Sensuality: Warm Grade: B- If Old School were a sub-genre, Tracy Anne Warren&#8217;s Charmed By Her Smile would qualify since I haven&#8217;t read this plot or come across characters like these in ages. During a house party, 18-year-old young miss asks 32-year-old bored rake to pretend to court her to fob off an unwanted suitor, during which they fall in love. Groan. But it worked. The character portraits aren’t very profound, but the hero and heroine have heaps of chemistry, they get along well, and the unwanted suitor was a believable source of conflict. And it&#8217;s so romantic. Sigh. I haven&#8217;t read Ms. Warren in a while but I&#8217;ll be digging right back in. Sensuality: Warm Grade: B+ Devil to Pay takes place in Jeaniene Frost&#8217;s Night Huntress world about which I know nothing, but Ms. Frost wisely minimizes the world-building and focuses on this story. Blake has been possessed by a demon who has turned him into a murderer and he&#8217;s about to throw himself in the path of a subway when he meets vampire Elise. Something about Blake and his predicament galvanizes Elise out of her decades-old aloofness and she helps him exorcise his demon. The development of Blake and Elise&#8217;s feelings is a little uneven, but the story isn&#8217;t bad, the demon is suitably scary. I was intrigued enough with Ms. Frost&#8217;s vampires that I&#8217;ll have to look for more. Sensuality: Subtle Grade: B- Now on the other hand, Elaine Fox&#8217;s The Duke Who Came to Dinner is only 60 pages long but the author makes the most of every one. How? She decides to entertain, and entertain most charmingly she does. One cold June morning in Massachusetts, Sam Gregory spies a naked woman pedalling furiously in front of his house. They meet later at the local bar; turns out Gray Gilliam threw caution to the wind (her goal for the summer), went skinny-dipping, and had her clothes stolen by Sam&#8217;s dog. Plus, there is a ghost haunting Gray&#8217;s cottage. It&#8217;s contrived, it&#8217;s cute, and I found it utterly charming in spite of myself. I have a new author to glom. Sensuality: Warm Grade: B+ Cathy Maxwell&#8217;s The Irish Duke is a paltry 50 pages, which includes an epilogue, and boy does it show. Susan Rogers is a marriage advisor to the debutantes of the ton and when she says something that gets twisted out of proportion, it is left to the Irish Duke to reap the fallout. In revenge, the Irish Duke makes a wager about her, which ruins her reputation, but then they realize they love each other, and elope to Scotland. This is where the math comes in: Zero chemistry + Too much telling + Near-invisible characterization = Zero interest. The story is not bad, just deadly dull and fatally unwritten. I could see this as a novella, though. Sensuality: Subtle Grade: D+"

                "html": "<p><em>Thaddeus Walker Bowman Owens, the backup quarterback for the Chicago Stars, is a team player, talented sideline coach, occasional male underwear model, and a man with a low tolerance for Divas.</em></p>\n<p><em>Olivia Shore, international opera superstar, is a driven diva with a passion for perfection, a craving for justice, too many secrets—and a monumental grudge against the egotistical, lowbrow jock she’s been stuck with.</em></p>\n<p><em>It’s Mozart meets Monday Night Football as the temperamental soprano and stubborn jock embark on a nationwide tour promoting a luxury watch brand. Along the way, the combatants will engage in soul-searching and trash talk, backstage drama and, for sure, a quarterback pass. But they’ll also face trouble as threatening letters, haunting photographs, and a series of dangerous encounters complicate their lives. Is it the work of an overzealous fan or something more sinister?</em></p>\n<p>Susan Elizabeth Phillips has a new book out featuring older leads&#8211;she&#8217;s a world famous opera singer and he&#8217;s a backup quarterback for the Chicago Stars. Dabney and Rachel read it and are here to share their views.</p>\n<hr />\n<p><strong>Dabney</strong>: Those who love Susan Elizabeth Phillips&#8217; <strong><em>Chicago Stars</em> </strong>series but haven&#8217;t been wild about her more recent works will be happy to hear that, while not perfect, <strong>When Stars Collide</strong> is vintage SEP.</p>\n<p><strong>Rachel</strong>: The book definitely did feel like a lot of SEP&#8217;s previous work. The protagonists have an initially antagonistic dynamic that grows over time into something more, an old standby in Phillips&#8217; books.</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney</strong>: I enjoyed it&#8211;it has a lightness that I think I needed not to mention main characters that are older. Did you?</p>\n<p><strong>Rachel</strong>: I really loved the reading experience, the book had a lot of what I love in a romance. I liked the older characters too. The only issue I really had with it was how over the top it got- and that&#8217;s usually fine for SEP&#8217;s books. This time, though, some of the twists fell flat for me. It started to go downhill at about the two-thirds mark in my opinion.</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney</strong>: I kinda agree although I was fine until the 85% mark. As the book careened toward the end, the suspense plot swamped the romance and the, up until that point, lovely character development of our two leads.</p>\n<p><strong>Rachel</strong>: I think it definitely distracted from the characters when the plot got more convoluted. Both leads had great moments, especially when they started to understand each other better and began to communicate. I also thought the supporting characters lived up to SEP&#8217;s previous work, she has such great attention to detail in that way.</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney</strong>: Totes agree about the supporting characters. It&#8217;s such a strong point in her work. I loved Clint, the young foot player who keeps dogging Thad, the main lead, as well as Paisley, the hilarious social media whiz. SEP writes young and old people in ways that seem real&#8211;and she does a great job showing the generational differences with humor. I also really loved the whole opera plot. I had so much empathy for Liv&#8217;s fear that she&#8217;d never truly sing again.</p>\n<p>What did you love?</p>\n<p><strong>Rachel</strong>: I loved the opera plot as well, it&#8217;s always so interesting to read about characters devoted to their art and passionate about their work. I also love when characters are from different worlds but have a lot of common ground. I would say my favorite part of the whole book is Thad&#8217;s development. He goes through so much growth in the book.</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney</strong>: What didn&#8217;t work for you?</p>\n<p><strong>Rachel</strong>: The suspense of it all didn&#8217;t really hold water for me. I usually like SEP&#8217;s damsels in distress, and appreciate how they overcome their adversaries, but the conflict in this book was so byzantine. It seemed needlessly complicated for shock value, to surprise the reader. I don&#8217;t like when plot twists are engineered specifically so you didn&#8217;t see it coming, and feel inorganic to the story. What about you?</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney</strong>: I agree. I loved the relationship between the leads and I really thought the book would have been just fine&#8211;stronger even&#8211;if they&#8217;d just focused on Olivia&#8217;s quest to regain her voice. The whole someone is out to get her thing which morphed into a crazy villainous plot propelled by somewhat obscure motives distracted from the love story.</p>\n<p><strong>Rachel</strong>: Yes, I think the suspense subplot made a good initial hook and might have been just fine if it had been resolved midway through the story. Olivia&#8217;s emotional journey is a lot more interesting, and if that had been more of the focus of the book I would have liked it a lot more.</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney</strong>: So what grade would you give it?</p>\n<p><strong>Rachel</strong>: <strong>I would say it&#8217;s a C from me.</strong> What about you?</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney</strong>: Even with all the unnecessary shenanigans, <strong>I&#8217;d give it a B+.</strong> I enjoyed the characters enough to overlook the nutso goings-on.</p>\n<p><strong>Rachel</strong>: I definitely liked reading about the characters, but it just didn&#8217;t give me enough. I can definitely read a book that is totally bananas and if it&#8217;s written well enough and the characters are compelling, it gets an A from me, like <a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/book-review/match-me-if-you-can-susan-elizabeth-phillips/\"><strong>Match Me If You Can</strong></a>. This one just didn&#8217;t get there for me, unfortunately.</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney</strong>: So, we&#8217;ll call it a B-. Readers, what do you think? SEP gold or brass?</p>\n<h3 style=\"text-align: center\"><strong>Buy it at: <a href=\"https://amzn.to/2SSxUf9\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Amazon</a>, <a href=\"https://amzn.to/3wUU4gd\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Audible</a>, or your <a href=\"https://www.indiebound.org/book/9780062973092?aff=allaboutromance\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">local independent retailer</a></strong></h3>\n<h3 style=\"text-align: center\"><strong>Visit our <a href=\"https://amzn.to/2SeEiZg\">Amazon Storefront</a></strong></h3>\n",
                "text": "Thaddeus Walker Bowman Owens, the backup quarterback for the Chicago Stars, is a team player, talented sideline coach, occasional male underwear model, and a man with a low tolerance for Divas. Olivia Shore, international opera superstar, is a driven diva with a passion for perfection, a craving for justice, too many secrets—and a monumental grudge against the egotistical, lowbrow jock she’s been stuck with. It’s Mozart meets Monday Night Football as the temperamental soprano and stubborn jock embark on a nationwide tour promoting a luxury watch brand. Along the way, the combatants will engage in soul-searching and trash talk, backstage drama and, for sure, a quarterback pass. But they’ll also face trouble as threatening letters, haunting photographs, and a series of dangerous encounters complicate their lives. Is it the work of an overzealous fan or something more sinister? Susan Elizabeth Phillips has a new book out featuring older leads&#8211;she&#8217;s a world famous opera singer and he&#8217;s a backup quarterback for the Chicago Stars. Dabney and Rachel read it and are here to share their views. Dabney: Those who love Susan Elizabeth Phillips&#8217; Chicago Stars series but haven&#8217;t been wild about her more recent works will be happy to hear that, while not perfect, When Stars Collide is vintage SEP. Rachel: The book definitely did feel like a lot of SEP&#8217;s previous work. The protagonists have an initially antagonistic dynamic that grows over time into something more, an old standby in Phillips&#8217; books. Dabney: I enjoyed it&#8211;it has a lightness that I think I needed not to mention main characters that are older. Did you? Rachel: I really loved the reading experience, the book had a lot of what I love in a romance. I liked the older characters too. The only issue I really had with it was how over the top it got- and that&#8217;s usually fine for SEP&#8217;s books. This time, though, some of the twists fell flat for me. It started to go downhill at about the two-thirds mark in my opinion. Dabney: I kinda agree although I was fine until the 85% mark. As the book careened toward the end, the suspense plot swamped the romance and the, up until that point, lovely character development of our two leads. Rachel: I think it definitely distracted from the characters when the plot got more convoluted. Both leads had great moments, especially when they started to understand each other better and began to communicate. I also thought the supporting characters lived up to SEP&#8217;s previous work, she has such great attention to detail in that way. Dabney: Totes agree about the supporting characters. It&#8217;s such a strong point in her work. I loved Clint, the young foot player who keeps dogging Thad, the main lead, as well as Paisley, the hilarious social media whiz. SEP writes young and old people in ways that seem real&#8211;and she does a great job showing the generational differences with humor. I also really loved the whole opera plot. I had so much empathy for Liv&#8217;s fear that she&#8217;d never truly sing again. What did you love? Rachel: I loved the opera plot as well, it&#8217;s always so interesting to read about characters devoted to their art and passionate about their work. I also love when characters are from different worlds but have a lot of common ground. I would say my favorite part of the whole book is Thad&#8217;s development. He goes through so much growth in the book. Dabney: What didn&#8217;t work for you? Rachel: The suspense of it all didn&#8217;t really hold water for me. I usually like SEP&#8217;s damsels in distress, and appreciate how they overcome their adversaries, but the conflict in this book was so byzantine. It seemed needlessly complicated for shock value, to surprise the reader. I don&#8217;t like when plot twists are engineered specifically so you didn&#8217;t see it coming, and feel inorganic to the story. What about you? Dabney: I agree. I loved the relationship between the leads and I really thought the book would have been just fine&#8211;stronger even&#8211;if they&#8217;d just focused on Olivia&#8217;s quest to regain her voice. The whole someone is out to get her thing which morphed into a crazy villainous plot propelled by somewhat obscure motives distracted from the love story. Rachel: Yes, I think the suspense subplot made a good initial hook and might have been just fine if it had been resolved midway through the story. Olivia&#8217;s emotional journey is a lot more interesting, and if that had been more of the focus of the book I would have liked it a lot more. Dabney: So what grade would you give it? Rachel: I would say it&#8217;s a C from me. What about you? Dabney: Even with all the unnecessary shenanigans, I&#8217;d give it a B+. I enjoyed the characters enough to overlook the nutso goings-on. Rachel: I definitely liked reading about the characters, but it just didn&#8217;t give me enough. I can definitely read a book that is totally bananas and if it&#8217;s written well enough and the characters are compelling, it gets an A from me, like Match Me If You Can. This one just didn&#8217;t get there for me, unfortunately. Dabney: So, we&#8217;ll call it a B-. Readers, what do you think? SEP gold or brass?                 "html": "<p><em>No one would guess that beneath Violet Crenshaw&#8217;s ladylike demeanor lies the heart of a rebel. American heiresses looking to secure English lords must be on their best behavior, but Violet has other plans. She intends to flee London and the marriage her parents have arranged to become a published author&#8211;if only the wickedly handsome earl who inspired her most outrageously sinful character didn&#8217;t insist on coming with her.</em></p>\n<p><em>Christian Halston, Earl of Leigh, has a scheme of his own: escort the surprisingly spirited dollar princess north and use every delicious moment in close quarters to convince Violet to marry him. Christian needs an heiress to rebuild his Scottish estate but the more time he spends with Violet, the more he realizes what he really needs is her&#8211;by his side, near his heart, in his bed.</em></p>\n<p><em>Though Christian&#8217;s burning glances offer unholy temptation, Violet has no intention of surrendering herself or her newfound freedom in a permanent deal with the devil. It&#8217;s going to take more than pretty words to prove this fortune hunter&#8217;s love is true&#8230;.</em></p>\n<p>Caz and Dabney both read <strong>The Devil and the Heiress</strong>. Here&#8217;s what they have to say.</p>\n<hr />\n<p><strong>Caz:</strong> Harper St. George’s <strong>The Devil and the Heiress</strong> is book two in her series of novels about <strong><em>Gilded Age Heiresses</em></strong>, wealthy &#8211; or potentially wealthy &#8211; young American women who come to England to search for a titled husband.  Laura Lee Guhrke’s <strong><em>An American Heiress in London</em></strong> has a similar premise as does Maya Rodale’s <strong><em>Keeping Up With the Cavendishes</em></strong>; all feature American heiresses and the Transatlantic culture clash as they struggle to adapt to the rigid conventions of English high society in which, despite their enormous wealth, they are looked down upon because their money is “new” and their breeding questionable.  I haven’t read the previous book (<a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/book-review/the-heiress-gets-a-duke-by-harper-st-george/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"><strong>The Heiress Gets a Duke</strong></a>), which was well received &#8211; our reviewer gave it an A &#8211; but I read this one easily as a standalone so anyone choosing to jump in here won’t find it difficult to do so.  Did you read the first book, Dabney?</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney: </strong>I did. I enjoyed it. I thought the first half was very strong. The second half faltered&#8211;a silly insistence by the heroine and an unnecessary Big Mis&#8211;but I was excited to read this one.</p>\n<p><strong>Caz:</strong> Thankfully, there&#8217;s no Big Mis in <strong>The Devil and the Heiress,</strong> but it does have a hero who is &#8211; at first &#8211; out to win the heroine by underhanded means.  When Christian’s request for Violet’s hand is rejected by her father, and another suitor seems to be favoured, Christian decides he’s going to charm Violet into falling for him.  It’s not an uncommon sort of plotline, so I wasn’t particularly bothered by the fact he was setting out to deliberately deceive her.  Also, the author makes it fairly clear that he’s actually interested in Violet for herself, and isn’t one of those heroes who thinks he’ll marry the cash cow and then leave her in the country while he heads back to town to pick up his rakish lifestyle.  It might not make the deception okay, but it does soften it around the edges a little bit.</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney</strong>: His deception didn’t bother me &#8211; in fact he was my favorite part of the story. Sadly, after Violet seemed so promising in <strong>The Heiress Gets a Duke</strong>, here she was rather blah. What did you think of our leads?</p>\n<p><strong>Caz: </strong> I was rolling my eyes at Violet being yet <em>another</em> secret-author heroine, but her situation as a young woman subject to the dictates of parents who didn’t really care about her or her happiness evoked sympathy.  She wasn’t anything special &#8211; and certainly didn’t seem like the “rebel” of the blurb &#8211; but she wasn’t horrible either.  As for Christian &#8211; he’s much more strongly written but is also another in a long line of devilish/roguish/rakish heroes with reputations sufficient to make one want to clutch one’s pearls in horror the moment he walks into a room… who is in fact nothing of the sort.  I didn’t get why he had such a terrible reputation; there’s no mention of his being a gambler, drunkard or womaniser &#8211; the worst thing about him is that he’s an earl and he’s *gasp!* in trade (because of the club he co-owns &#8211; I should have made a drinking game out of all the “and here’s yet another…” &#8211; because here’s yet another hero who owns a scandalous club).  I liked him, but he was in no way devilish or depraved or whatever he was supposed to be.</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney</strong>: Yeah &#8211; that was a mystery. And, Caz, you know that secret clubs were as rife as rats in VIctorian England….. #not</p>\n<p><strong>Caz: </strong>Hah!  But those Victorians really were a super-repressed bunch! (I did notice the reference to the special “room” at the club ;) )  But in HR right now, almost all the secret clubs are run by noblemen (or heroines who long to be “different”) and that got boring ages ago. That aside though, what of the romance between this not-Devil and his Heiress?</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney:</strong> It was fine but forgettable. As in, I read this over a month ago and now I can’t recall much about it which means nothing in it struck me as worth recalling. In both St. George’s books, I’ve been very distracted by how much I hate the heroines’ parents. As I read this book, I kept wishing Violet would dump them and run away.</p>\n<p><strong>Caz</strong>: Well, I finished it less than two days ago and I&#8217;m having the same problem! The book is well-written and the chemistry between the couple is nicely done, but the romance is very… ordinary.  Perfectly pleasant but unmemorable.  And the ending annoyed me. <div class=\"spoiler test-123\"><div class=\"spoiler-title\" role=\"button\" tabindex=\"0\">Show spoiler</div><div class=\"spoiler-content\" style=\"display: none;\">The separation so Violet could have a good sulk went on for too long and not telling your husband you&#8217;re pregnant (unless for very good reason) is a rotten thing to do.  </div></div>\n<p>I agree about the Crenshaws &#8211; they were horrible. And horribly devoid of nuance.</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney</strong>: Not to digress but honestly, if you are more struck by the terrible behavior of the heroine’s parents rather than with her getting jiggy with the hero, that’s a problem. I did like this book and I’ll definitely read whatever St. George writes next&#8211;I’m very interested in the story of the tragically married friend whom I assume will be the next lead. But I found the first book more engaging than this one. This one is just fine and, well, I always hope for more than that.</p>\n<p><strong>Caz</strong>: Yep &#8211; it&#8217;s always a problem in a romance novel when other characters &#8211; good or bad &#8211; make more of an impression than the principals! I might pick up the next in the series &#8211; I&#8217;m guessing it&#8217;ll be about Helena and Max, and I generally like enemies-to-lovers romances, but I hope it&#8217;s got a bit more oomph! than this one. <strong>I&#8217;m giving it a B-</strong>; basically okay but nothing special.</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney</strong>: That’s my grade too. I do think readers should keep St. George on their radar. We gave <strong>The Heiress Gets A Duke</strong> a DIK &#8211; I’d have given it a B+ &#8211; and I suspect she’s capable of doing very good work.</p>\n<h3 style=\"text-align: center\"><strong>Buy it at: <a href=\"https://amzn.to/3eyi3Lp\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Amazon</a>, Audible, or your <a href=\"https://www.indiebound.org/book/9780593197226?aff=allaboutromance\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">local independent retailer</a></strong></h3>\n<h3 style=\"text-align: center\"><strong>Visit our <a href=\"https://amzn.to/2SeEiZg\">Amazon Storefront</a></strong></h3>\n",
                "text": "No one would guess that beneath Violet Crenshaw&#8217;s ladylike demeanor lies the heart of a rebel. American heiresses looking to secure English lords must be on their best behavior, but Violet has other plans. She intends to flee London and the marriage her parents have arranged to become a published author&#8211;if only the wickedly handsome earl who inspired her most outrageously sinful character didn&#8217;t insist on coming with her. Christian Halston, Earl of Leigh, has a scheme of his own: escort the surprisingly spirited dollar princess north and use every delicious moment in close quarters to convince Violet to marry him. Christian needs an heiress to rebuild his Scottish estate but the more time he spends with Violet, the more he realizes what he really needs is her&#8211;by his side, near his heart, in his bed. Though Christian&#8217;s burning glances offer unholy temptation, Violet has no intention of surrendering herself or her newfound freedom in a permanent deal with the devil. It&#8217;s going to take more than pretty words to prove this fortune hunter&#8217;s love is true&#8230;. Caz and Dabney both read The Devil and the Heiress. Here&#8217;s what they have to say. Caz: Harper St. George’s The Devil and the Heiress is book two in her series of novels about Gilded Age Heiresses, wealthy &#8211; or potentially wealthy &#8211; young American women who come to England to search for a titled husband.  Laura Lee Guhrke’s An American Heiress in London has a similar premise as does Maya Rodale’s Keeping Up With the Cavendishes; all feature American heiresses and the Transatlantic culture clash as they struggle to adapt to the rigid conventions of English high society in which, despite their enormous wealth, they are looked down upon because their money is “new” and their breeding questionable.  I haven’t read the previous book (The Heiress Gets a Duke), which was well received &#8211; our reviewer gave it an A &#8211; but I read this one easily as a standalone so anyone choosing to jump in here won’t find it difficult to do so.  Did you read the first book, Dabney?                 "html": "<p>Last fall, trapped at home and dreaming of flying far away—anywhere!—I picked up <strong>Hostage</strong>. I thoroughly enjoyed Mackintosh’s previous books, especially <a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/book-review/i-see-you-by-clare-mackintosh/\">her first two</a>, and was hopeful this too would be diverting.</p>\n<p>Two days later, having alienated everyone I encountered—I did not want to be disturbed about anything that wasn’t <em>definitively</em> <strong>urgent</strong>—I put down this book, desperate for the rest of the thriller loving world to read it. In short order, I had my husband, my best friend, and my neighbor flipping its pages as fast as they could too.</p>\n<p><strong>Hostage</strong> may make you think twice about flying but, reading while grounded, you’ll be transported.</p>\n<p>As the book begins, Mina, a flight attendant, is headed out on what will be the first nonstop flight from London to Sidney: Twenty hours in the air in a Boeing 777 filled with 353 press, passengers, pilots and other airline staff. Mina has pulled strings to be on this flight, not because it’s a big deal to her but rather as a way to temporarily escape her seemingly broken marriage. Mina loves Adam and their exceedingly precocious daughter Sophia, but she no longer trusts Adam—she’s convinced he was having an affair with their ex-au pair, a young Ukrainian woman who recently cryptically quit working for them.</p>\n<p>Over the first ten chapters, Mackintosh introduces Mina, her family, and her coworkers as well as a terrifyingly matter of fact group of passengers who are on the plane to… you got it… hijack it. They’re eco-terrorists who plan to crash the plane if the airline industry doesn’t agree to significantly cut its carbon footprint. The reader is shown their thinking early on but has no idea who, on the plane, they are.</p>\n<p>Shortly after the plane takes off, Mina is shocked to discover Sophia’s EpiPen in Mina’s flight bag. This makes no sense—Mina knows it is always kept in Sophia’s school backpack because her daughter has severe nut allergy. Mina thinks she must have made a mistake but then, less than 30 minutes later, a passenger suddenly and suspiciously dies and, while Mina is going through his pockets for his ID, she finds a picture of Sophia, clearly taken earlier in the day. Mina is freaking out when things get much worse. The hijackers slip her a note demanding her help in commandeering the plane. If she doesn’t do their bidding, Sophia will die.</p>\n<p>Back in London, Adam and Sophia are also being threatened. Neither they nor Mina have any way to communicate, a situation used to great advantage by the terrorists. As their situations worsen, so does that of all on Flight 70. The chapters switch from narrator to narrator and though this is confusing when the book begins, soon the threads fuse, ensnaring the reader in a delightful web of menace, fear, and frantic curiosity.</p>\n<p>Beginning in her first book, <a href=\"https://amzn.to/3zNLUYD\"><strong>I Let You Go</strong></a>, Mackintosh has gifted readers with twists we didn&#8217;t see coming. Here, she&#8217;s never offered more stunning revelations. This is a book that, to the very end, is full of smartly rendered shockers. I enjoyed each and every one.</p>\n<p>At the end of the novel, Mackintosh has a long and thoughtful note about the airline industry, global warming, and tough choices. It&#8217;s a fascinating take on a complicated conundrum and makes thinking about the issues raised in <strong>Hostage</strong> provoking.</p>\n<p><strong>Hostage</strong>&#8211;along with all those <a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/author-books-profile/?afname=Karin&amp;alname=Slaughter\">Karin Slaughter books</a> AAR convinced me to read&#8211;is the best thriller I&#8217;ve encountered this year. It&#8217;s perfectly paced, genuinely perplexing, and almost impossible to predict. I predict readers everywhere will be held captive to its thrall and will be bereft when the thrill ride that is this book comes to its stunning, jaw-dropping end.</p>\n<p><em>You can read our other review of this title</em> <a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/book-review/hostage-by-clare-mackintosh-2/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">HERE</a>.</p>\n<h3 style=\"text-align: center;\"><strong>Buy it at: <a href=\"https://amzn.to/3isDhMZ\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Amazon</a>, <a href=\"https://amzn.to/3594Kv7\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Audible</a>, or your <a href=\"https://www.indiebound.org/book/9781728245522?aff=allaboutromance\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">local independent retailer</a></strong></h3>\n<h3 style=\"text-align: center;\"><strong>Visit our </strong><a href=\"https://amzn.to/2SeEiZg\"><strong>Amazon Storefront</strong></a></h3>\n",
                "text": "Last fall, trapped at home and dreaming of flying far away—anywhere!—I picked up Hostage. I thoroughly enjoyed Mackintosh’s previous books, especially her first two, and was hopeful this too would be diverting. Two days later, having alienated everyone I encountered—I did not want to be disturbed about anything that wasn’t definitively urgent—I put down this book, desperate for the rest of the thriller loving world to read it. In short order, I had my husband, my best friend, and my neighbor flipping its pages as fast as they could too. Hostage may make you think twice about flying but, reading while grounded, you’ll be transported. As the book begins, Mina, a flight attendant, is headed out on what will be the first nonstop flight from London to Sidney: Twenty hours in the air in a Boeing 777 filled with 353 press, passengers, pilots and other airline staff. Mina has pulled strings to be on this flight, not because it’s a big deal to her but rather as a way to temporarily escape her seemingly broken marriage. Mina loves Adam and their exceedingly precocious daughter Sophia, but she no longer trusts Adam—she’s convinced he was having an affair with their ex-au pair, a young Ukrainian woman who recently cryptically quit working for them. Over the first ten chapters, Mackintosh introduces Mina, her family, and her coworkers as well as a terrifyingly matter of fact group of passengers who are on the plane to… you got it… hijack it. They’re eco-terrorists who plan to crash the plane if the airline industry doesn’t agree to significantly cut its carbon footprint. The reader is shown their thinking early on but has no idea who, on the plane, they are. Shortly after the plane takes off, Mina is shocked to discover Sophia’s EpiPen in Mina’s flight bag. This makes no sense—Mina knows it is always kept in Sophia’s school backpack because her daughter has severe nut allergy. Mina thinks she must have made a mistake but then, less than 30 minutes later, a passenger suddenly and suspiciously dies and, while Mina is going through his pockets for his ID, she finds a picture of Sophia, clearly taken earlier in the day. Mina is freaking out when things get much worse. The hijackers slip her a note demanding her help in commandeering the plane. If she doesn’t do their bidding, Sophia will die. Back in London, Adam and Sophia are also being threatened. Neither they nor Mina have any way to communicate, a situation used to great advantage by the terrorists. As their situations worsen, so does that of all on Flight 70. The chapters switch from narrator to narrator and though this is confusing when the book begins, soon the threads fuse, ensnaring the reader in a delightful web of menace, fear, and frantic curiosity. Beginning in her first book, I Let You Go, Mackintosh has gifted readers with twists we didn&#8217;t see coming. Here, she&#8217;s never offered more stunning revelations. This is a book that, to the very end, is full of smartly rendered shockers. I enjoyed each and every one. At the end of the novel, Mackintosh has a long and thoughtful note about the airline industry, global warming, and tough choices. It&#8217;s a fascinating take on a complicated conundrum and makes thinking about the issues raised in Hostage provoking. Hostage&#8211;along with all those Karin Slaughter books AAR convinced me to read&#8211;is the best thriller I&#8217;ve encountered this year. It&#8217;s perfectly paced, genuinely perplexing, and almost impossible to predict. I predict readers everywhere will be held captive to its thrall and will be bereft when the thrill ride that is this book comes to its stunning, jaw-dropping end.                 "html": "<p>The first book in Serena Bell&#8217;s new <em>Wilder Adventures</em> series is rife with romance tropes. Big city East Coast girl comes to a small town in the Pacific Northwest to work with a family with five brawny, gorgeous brothers (and one married sister) who run a failing outdoor adventure company. All five are single and will, one assumes, in five books, find true love. This book&#8217;s hero was burned by a city girl in the past and will never love again. The marketing savvy heroine hates small towns and trusts no one due to a tragic past. Throw in a severe case of insta-lust, a meet cute involving ducklings, and way too many jokes about the heroine&#8217;s inappropriate footwear&#8211;this is rural Oregon for heaven&#8217;s sake!&#8211;and you have <strong>Make Me Wilder</strong>.</p>\n<p><em>Now Dabney</em>, you say, <em>you say this like it&#8217;s a bad thing!</em></p>\n<p>OK, OK, it&#8217;s not a bad thing. I enjoyed this book. Bell is a terrific witty writer and her characters, despite being tropey types, are interesting and have just enough quirks that they&#8217;re kinda adorable. The sex is hot and the family dynamics&#8211;I especially like the Wilder women&#8211;are well-done and believable. And given that Jill Shalvis, Sarah Morgan, and Kristan Higgins have all moved to women&#8217;s fiction, Bell is a good replacement for those looking for sexy, fun, contemporary romance.</p>\n<p>Our high heeled wearing heroine, Lucy, is temporarily escaping Manhattan after a highly mortifying business meeting at which it became clear to all her colleagues that Lucy had inadvertently slept with her boss&#8217;s fiance. Lucy hightails it to Rush Creek, Oregon where her mom is currently shacked up with a new love. Rush Creek has struggled economically and Barb Wilder, the widowed matriarch of the Wilder clan, has hired Lucy to convince the Wilder brothers that Wilder Adventurers needs a more female&#8211;think bridesmaids parties and connect with your kids outings&#8211;makeover.</p>\n<p>This is not an easy task. The Wilder brothers are all, to a man, disdainful of selling out, compromising their old-school vision of outdoor experiences, and pretty sure Lucy, whom they all agree is smokin&#8217; hot, has nothing professional to offer them. No one feels this more strongly than Gabe, the oldest Wilder brother who is its de facto CEO.</p>\n<p>Unfortunately for Gabe, since he first spotted Lucy&#8211;she was trying to save some stranded ducklings and he, deeply competent in all things in nature, steps in to help&#8211;their chemistry is off the charts. Within an hour of their first encounter, they&#8217;ve met in the lobby of Lucy&#8217;s hotel and are about to head upstairs when Gabe figures out who Lucy is in town to work for. (His mother neglected to mention to her sons that she&#8217;d hired a marketing consultant.) Sex is&#8211;at least at first&#8211;off the table and Gabe and Lucy go from almost torrid trysters to ticked off co-workers.</p>\n<p>Nothing that happens next will surprise anyone who&#8217;s ever read a romance novel. Gabe freaks out everytime any of his brothers flirt with Lucy. Lucy needs a place to stay and ends up in the Wilder guesthouse. Gabe and Lucy&#8211;he has to come because he doesn&#8217;t trust any of his bros to be alone with Lucy&#8211;go on a series of Wilder adventures, each led by a different brother, and Lucy has no idea how to do anything other than ogle Gabe&#8217;s gorgeous bod as he makes fires, builds shelters, hikes up mountains, and casts his rod.</p>\n<p>The reader knows Lucy will come to appreciate the joys found in small town connections, Gabe will see the wisdom in Lucy&#8217;s work advice&#8211;she really is very good at her job&#8211;and the two will, in less than three weeks, realize that love is better than mistrustful solitude.</p>\n<p>Again, that&#8217;s fine. It&#8217;s not startling, but who cares? I didn&#8217;t. And I&#8217;m now invested in the other Wilders and plan to read their stories too. If you like light hearted contemporary romance, grab this book, a glass of your favorite bad for you beverage, and blow off your to do list. You&#8217;ll be glad you did.</p>\n<h3 style=\"text-align: center;\"><strong>Buy it at:</strong>&nbsp;<a href=\"https://amzn.to/2Ss0LHb\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Amazon</a>&nbsp;or <a href=\"https://www.indiebound.org/book/9781953498090?aff=allaboutromance\">Shop your local indie bookstore</a></h3>\n<h3 class=\"fusion-responsive-typography-calculated\" style=\"text-align: center;\" data-fontsize=\"24\" data-lineheight=\"26.4px\"><strong>Visit our&nbsp;<a href=\"http://www.amazon.com/shop/allaboutromance\">Amazon Storefront</a></strong></h3>\n",
                "text": "The first book in Serena Bell&#8217;s new Wilder Adventures series is rife with romance tropes. Big city East Coast girl comes to a small town in the Pacific Northwest to work with a family with five brawny, gorgeous brothers (and one married sister) who run a failing outdoor adventure company. All five are single and will, one assumes, in five books, find true love. This book&#8217;s hero was burned by a city girl in the past and will never love again. The marketing savvy heroine hates small towns and trusts no one due to a tragic past. Throw in a severe case of insta-lust, a meet cute involving ducklings, and way too many jokes about the heroine&#8217;s inappropriate footwear&#8211;this is rural Oregon for heaven&#8217;s sake!&#8211;and you have Make Me Wilder. Now Dabney, you say, you say this like it&#8217;s a bad thing! OK, OK, it&#8217;s not a bad thing. I enjoyed this book. Bell is a terrific witty writer and her characters, despite being tropey types, are interesting and have just enough quirks that they&#8217;re kinda adorable. The sex is hot and the family dynamics&#8211;I especially like the Wilder women&#8211;are well-done and believable. And given that Jill Shalvis, Sarah Morgan, and Kristan Higgins have all moved to women&#8217;s fiction, Bell is a good replacement for those looking for sexy, fun, contemporary romance. Our high heeled wearing heroine, Lucy, is temporarily escaping Manhattan after a highly mortifying business meeting at which it became clear to all her colleagues that Lucy had inadvertently slept with her boss&#8217;s fiance. Lucy hightails it to Rush Creek, Oregon where her mom is currently shacked up with a new love. Rush Creek has struggled economically and Barb Wilder, the widowed matriarch of the Wilder clan, has hired Lucy to convince the Wilder brothers that Wilder Adventurers needs a more female&#8211;think bridesmaids parties and connect with your kids outings&#8211;makeover. This is not an easy task. The Wilder brothers are all, to a man, disdainful of selling out, compromising their old-school vision of outdoor experiences, and pretty sure Lucy, whom they all agree is smokin&#8217; hot, has nothing professional to offer them. No one feels this more strongly than Gabe, the oldest Wilder brother who is its de facto CEO. Unfortunately for Gabe, since he first spotted Lucy&#8211;she was trying to save some stranded ducklings and he, deeply competent in all things in nature, steps in to help&#8211;their chemistry is off the charts. Within an hour of their first encounter, they&#8217;ve met in the lobby of Lucy&#8217;s hotel and are about to head upstairs when Gabe figures out who Lucy is in town to work for. Sex is&#8211;at least at first&#8211;off the table and Gabe and Lucy go from almost torrid trysters to ticked off co-workers. Nothing that happens next will surprise anyone who&#8217;s ever read a romance novel. Gabe freaks out everytime any of his brothers flirt with Lucy. Lucy needs a place to stay and ends up in the Wilder guesthouse. Gabe and Lucy&#8211;he has to come because he doesn&#8217;t trust any of his bros to be alone with Lucy&#8211;go on a series of Wilder adventures, each led by a different brother, and Lucy has no idea how to do anything other than ogle Gabe&#8217;s gorgeous bod as he makes fires, builds shelters, hikes up mountains, and casts his rod. The reader knows Lucy will come to appreciate the joys found in small town connections, Gabe will see the wisdom in Lucy&#8217;s work advice&#8211;she really is very good at her job&#8211;and the two will, in less than three weeks, realize that love is better than mistrustful solitude.                 "html": "<p>Sigh.</p>\n<p>My first (reading) impression of this book was that it was worse than the last Sally Thorne book, <a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/book-review/99-percent-mine-by-sally-thorne/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"><strong>99% Mine</strong></a>, a book I gave a C grade to only because I so liked the best friend that I couldn&#8217;t bring myself to give it a D. Thus, after reading about 25% of <strong>Second First Impressions</strong>, I put it down and decided I&#8217;d come back to it when&#8211;maybe?&#8211;its annoyingly quirky characters and overly twee heroine didn&#8217;t irritate the hell out of me.</p>\n<p>A month or so later, I gave the book another try and&#8230; nope.</p>\n<p>This time, I managed to make it to the 75% mark and then, well, I just quit. The best thing I can say about this book is that it is not for me and I&#8217;m just happy that all those readers who love a painfully sweet, twee heroine with the real world sense of <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TWzezWq7FkA\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Michael Scott</a> to fall in love with a man-child who&#8217;s supposed to be charmingly asinine but is really a dullard finally have a love story they can treasure.</p>\n<p>I didn&#8217;t finish this book&#8211;I&#8217;m about to turn 60 and knowing I have only a quarter or so of life left to me made me feel that time could be better spent <del>doing anything else</del> watching Taylor Swift videos and deciding, definitively, which is her best. (It&#8217;s this <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IdneKLhsWOQ\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">one</a>.)</p>\n<p>Here&#8217;s what I can tell you about it based on the first three quarters. Ruthie, age 25,  lives in a town in someplace that one would be hard pressed to<del> believe in</del> know where it is.  She is the acting office manager of the Providence Retirement Villa whose inhabitants are each so specifically nutty you&#8217;d think the place only admitted extras from <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aO1bYukdvLI\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">a poorly received Wes Anderson film</a>. Ruthie is single, <del>prissy</del> prim, and the sort of person who allows her temp, whom she&#8217;s known all of three weeks, to commandeer her love life. You see, Ruthie&#8217;s experience with men is, with the exception of a disastrous prom date that ended in shame, nominal.</p>\n<p>Thus, when Teddy, the book&#8217;s immature&#8211;think a five year old whose talent for charm is outweighed by his self-absorption, something I forgive in small children but dislike in adults&#8211;hero roars up on his motorcycle, Ruthie is smitten immediately because&#8230; he reminds her of her Teddy Bear.</p>\n<blockquote><p>I actually have a stuffed bear from my childhood called Teddy in my room right now. The two are <del>so cliched</del> perfect for each other. Teddy&#8217;s a bad boy with a heart of gold. Ruthie is a beautiful&#8211;on the inside AND outside of course&#8211;young woman who just doesn&#8217;t know how <del>soppy</del> precious she is. Ruthie needs to be saved and Teddy, for no reason I can fathom, wants to be the man who rescues her from her oh so dull life. Surely, there&#8217;s a decent, if unremarkable, romance there.</p>\n<p>No.</p>\n<p>Thorne, whose first novel <a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/book-review/the-hating-game-by-sally-thorne/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"><strong>The Hating Game</strong></a> is one of the great contemporary romances of the past decade, seems to have lost her sense of humor, passion, pacing, and plot here. Teddy&#8217;s and Ruthie&#8217;s romance is so glacially dull it could work as a soporific for those who struggle to fall asleep. The two, both unappealing stereotypes, have little chemistry and their banter made me wince. Instead of story, there are endless pages of Ruthie ruminating on what should she do with her <del>boring</del> life. Instead of sparkling dialogue, Ruthie and those in her world natter.</p>\n<p>Here&#8217;s Ruthie and Teddy discussing a tortoise.</p>\n<blockquote>\n<p class=\"calibre12\">A golden bonnet tortoise is making its way over to us. This girl is so cute,” he adds to himself.</p>\n<p class=\"calibre12\">I lean sideways and pick up the tortoise. He’s a healthy boy now, big as a paperback, kicking and protesting his midair situation with vigor. I look down at Teddy and try to suppress my smile at his rapt expression. “I’m just going to have a moment here with this tortoise, which might be weird, but who knows when I’ll see him again.”</p>\n<p class=\"calibre12\">“Have your moment.”</p>\n<p class=\"calibre12\">I say to the gimlet-eyed creature, “Number One, when I first picked you up, I didn’t know a thing. But you made me realize that I can still help without being a vet. You gave me hope. You were the one who changed everything for me and I hope we meet again someday. Let me just . . .” I put the tortoise back down on the blanket, take a few photos of him, and then rummage through my bag. Using my headphone cord, I measure across the shell and mark it with a hair clip. “I can record his size in his chart.”</p>\n</blockquote>\n<p>Just kill me now.</p>\n<p>To be fair, I didn&#8217;t finish this book and it&#8217;s possible that the last quarter is so magnificent that the first deeply disappointing 275 pages were worth it.                 "text": "Sigh. My first (reading) impression of this book was that it was worse than the last Sally Thorne book, 99% Mine, a book I gave a C grade to only because I so liked the best friend that I couldn&#8217;t bring myself to give it a D. Thus, after reading about 25% of Second First Impressions, I put it down and decided I&#8217;d come back to it when&#8211;maybe?&#8211;its annoyingly quirky characters and overly twee heroine didn&#8217;t irritate the hell out of me. A month or so later, I gave the book another try and&#8230; nope. This time, I managed to make it to the 75% mark and then, well, I just quit. The best thing I can say about this book is that it is not for me and I&#8217;m just happy that all those readers who love a painfully sweet, twee heroine with the real world sense of Michael Scott to fall in love with a man-child who&#8217;s supposed to be charmingly asinine but is really a dullard finally have a love story they can treasure. I didn&#8217;t finish this book&#8211;I&#8217;m about to turn 60 and knowing I have only a quarter or so of life left to me made me feel that time could be better spent doing anything else watching Taylor Swift videos and deciding, definitively, which is her best. (It&#8217;s this one.) Here&#8217;s what I can tell you about it based on the first three quarters. Ruthie, age 25,  lives in a town in someplace that one would be hard pressed to believe in know where it is.  She is the acting office manager of the Providence Retirement Villa whose inhabitants are each so specifically nutty you&#8217;d think the place only admitted extras from a poorly received Wes Anderson film. Ruthie is single, prissy prim, and the sort of person who allows her temp, whom she&#8217;s known all of three weeks, to commandeer her love life. You see, Ruthie&#8217;s experience with men is, with the exception of a disastrous prom date that ended in shame, nominal. Thus, when Teddy, the book&#8217;s immature&#8211;think a five year old whose talent for charm is outweighed by his self-absorption, something I forgive in small children but dislike in adults&#8211;hero roars up on his motorcycle, Ruthie is smitten immediately because&#8230; he reminds her of her Teddy Bear. I actually have a stuffed bear from my childhood called Teddy in my room right now. They both have a lot of experience sitting on girls’ beds. Bright-eyed, adorable creations made for hugging and finding in your sheets in the morning. The spark in Teddy’s eyes intensifies; he’s biting his lip, holding the laugh in. I brush some hair away from my face; my cheek is hot. What&#8217;s the hold up, you ask? Why can&#8217;t Teddy and Ruthie fall in love and run off and make lots of Build-a-Bears?
