Ruthie needs to be saved and Teddy, for no reason I can fathom, wants to be the man who rescues her from her oh so dull life. Surely, there&#8217;s a decent, if unremarkable, romance there. No. Thorne, whose first novel The Hating Game is one of the great contemporary romances of the past decade, seems to have lost her sense of humor, passion, pacing, and plot here. Teddy&#8217;s and Ruthie&#8217;s romance is so glacially dull it could work as a soporific for those who struggle to fall asleep. The two, both unappealing stereotypes, have little chemistry and their banter made me wince. Instead of story, there are endless pages of Ruthie ruminating on what should she do with her boring life. Instead of sparkling dialogue, Ruthie and those in her world natter. Here&#8217;s Ruthie and Teddy discussing a tortoise. A golden bonnet tortoise is making its way over to us. I see some red on it, then relax when it’s not blood. It’s Sharpie. “Hey. Look. It’s Number One. Teddy, it’s my first tortoise.” He’s smiling up at me from my lap. “You never forget a face? This girl is so cute,” he adds to himself. I lean sideways and pick up the tortoise. He’s a healthy boy now, big as a paperback, kicking and protesting his midair situation with vigor. I look down at Teddy and try to suppress my smile at his rapt expression. “I’m just going to have a moment here with this tortoise, which might be weird, but who knows when I’ll see him again.” “Have your moment.” I say to the gimlet-eyed creature, “Number One, when I first picked you up, I didn’t know a thing. But you made me realize that I can still help without being a vet. You gave me hope. You were the one who changed everything for me and I hope we meet again someday. Let me just . . .” I put the tortoise back down on the blanket, take a few photos of him, and then rummage through my bag. Using my headphone cord, I measure across the shell and mark it with a hair clip. “I can record his size in his chart.” Just kill me now.                 "html": "<p>If you love <a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/book-review/reckless-by-anne-stuart/\"><strong>Reckless</strong></a>, my personal fave of Stuart&#8217;s historical romances, you&#8217;ll like <strong>The Absolutely Positively Worst Man in England, Scotland and Wales</strong>. The latter has all the trappings of the former with not quite the panache or charm.</p>\n<p>In <strong>TAPWMiESaW</strong>, our anti-hero is (Earl) Kit Adderley who, if the reputation he has earned is accurate, is a genuine rotter. He ruins and kills without a care and is shunned by all of society&#8230; except the moronic peers who gamble with and lose to him (he cheats) and the women who simply cannot resist his overpowering beauty and seductiveness. Kit spends his dissolute days bored out of his mind&#8211;he is, of course, brilliant&#8211;and, when roused, doing <em>very bad things</em>.</p>\n<p>Our tale begins with Kit playing cards with the absurdly oafish George Latherby who, when unable to pay his considerable losses, promises Kit the very large dowry of the plain woman he&#8211;George&#8211;is to marry in a few weeks. Kit is unwilling to wait so they hatch a plan to, that very night, kidnap the bride, whisk her off to Scotland, wed and bed her&#8211;Kit thinks he might as well do the latter because George has the pox&#8211;and collect her fortune which Kit, who is loaded, doesn&#8217;t need.</p>\n<p>The caper, however, does not go as planned. The goons they hire for the job kidnap both the bride&#8211;one Bryony Marton&#8211;and her lovely young cousin Cecilia.  The women are tossed into a carriage where Kit and, occasionally, George join them and they jolt off to Gretna Green. It will shock you not that Kit is immediately, ineluctably drawn to Bryony. She has freckles, a gorgeous mouth, is tall, and utterly uncowed by him. For her part, he is the most beautiful man she&#8217;s ever seen and by far the most interesting thing that&#8217;s happened to her since her globe trotting father died and she came to live with Cecilia&#8217;s truly terrible parents.</p>\n<p>As they gallop along, stopping for food and shelter and&#8211;yes!&#8211;bathroom breaks, Bryony and Kit banter, Cecilia natters&#8211;she has an unnecessary romance with a Bow Street runner her parents have sent after her (only her, not Bryony)&#8211;and George competes to be the biggest evil idiot to grace the pages of an historical romance.</p>\n<p>Kit is an enigma&#8211;it&#8217;s hard to know why Bryony falls for him although he has a swooning sexuality that jumps of the page&#8211;and I wish Stuart had shown us more of his evolution to (barely) hero. Bryony is overly self-aware but she&#8217;s amusing and I rooted for her to find her HEA. A few weeks after reading their story, I recall little about them other than I had a good time reading their romance.</p>\n<p>This is a throwback novel&#8211;it hollers OLD SKOOL&#8211;and if you hate that sort of thing, you&#8217;ll hate this book. But if you&#8217;ve missed Stuart&#8217;s badly behaved, bad boy heroes and have got five dollars to spare, this book isn&#8217;t a bad bet.</p>\n<p>&nbsp;</p>\n<p>&nbsp;</p>\n",
                "text": "If you love Reckless, my personal fave of Stuart&#8217;s historical romances, you&#8217;ll like The Absolutely Positively Worst Man in England, Scotland and Wales. The latter has all the trappings of the former with not quite the panache or charm. In TAPWMiESaW, our anti-hero is (Earl) Kit Adderley who, if the reputation he has earned is accurate, is a genuine rotter. He ruins and kills without a care and is shunned by all of society&#8230; except the moronic peers who gamble with and lose to him (he cheats) and the women who simply cannot resist his overpowering beauty and seductiveness. Kit spends his dissolute days bored out of his mind&#8211;he is, of course, brilliant&#8211;and, when roused, doing very bad things. Our tale begins with Kit playing cards with the absurdly oafish George Latherby who, when unable to pay his considerable losses, promises Kit the very large dowry of the plain woman he&#8211;George&#8211;is to marry in a few weeks. Kit is unwilling to wait so they hatch a plan to, that very night, kidnap the bride, whisk her off to Scotland, wed and bed her&#8211;Kit thinks he might as well do the latter because George has the pox&#8211;and collect her fortune which Kit, who is loaded, doesn&#8217;t need. The caper, however, does not go as planned. The goons they hire for the job kidnap both the bride&#8211;one Bryony Marton&#8211;and her lovely young cousin Cecilia.  The women are tossed into a carriage where Kit and, occasionally, George join them and they jolt off to Gretna Green. It will shock you not that Kit is immediately, ineluctably drawn to Bryony. She has freckles, a gorgeous mouth, is tall, and utterly uncowed by him. For her part, he is the most beautiful man she&#8217;s ever seen and by far the most interesting thing that&#8217;s happened to her since her globe trotting father died and she came to live with Cecilia&#8217;s truly terrible parents. As they gallop along, stopping for food and shelter and&#8211;yes!&#8211;bathroom breaks, Bryony and Kit banter, Cecilia natters&#8211;she has an unnecessary romance with a Bow Street runner her parents have sent after her (only her, not Bryony)&#8211;and George competes to be the biggest evil idiot to grace the pages of an historical romance. Kit is an enigma&#8211;it&#8217;s hard to know why Bryony falls for him although he has a swooning sexuality that jumps of the page&#8211;and I wish Stuart had shown us more of his evolution to (barely) hero. Bryony is overly self-aware but she&#8217;s amusing and I rooted for her to find her HEA. A few weeks after reading their story, I recall little about them other than I had a good time reading their romance. This is a throwback novel&#8211;it hollers OLD SKOOL&#8211;and if you hate that sort of thing, you&#8217;ll hate this book. But if you&#8217;ve missed Stuart&#8217;s badly behaved, bad boy heroes and have got five dollars to spare, this book isn&#8217;t a bad bet. &nbsp; &nbsp;"
            }

Nicholas pulled out and ran as though chased by the hounds of hell. Since then, he&#8217;s pretended she doesn&#8217;t exist. Helena, however, wants a real marriage and another go between the marital sheets, so, wearing a wig and the trappings of a lady of the night, she tracks her husband down at his favorite house of carnal delights.</p>\n<p>She finds him watching an adventurous threesome. He&#8217;s coped by masturbating endlessly while fantasizing his virtuous wife but it&#8217;s not enough. He&#8217;d come to the Nunnery thinking he’d find relief bedding a whore, but found, much to his despair, he only wants his Helena.</p>\n<p>However, when a gorgeous woman runs into him&#8211;he&#8217;s watching the sexual gymnastics behind a drapery&#8211;he&#8217;s instantly and overwhelmingly aroused. Helena, afraid he’d be appalled at her bawdy behavior, uses a French accent as she moans.  Once finished, Nicholas drops a fifty-pound note on the table and walks away.</p>\n<p>Needless to say, Nicholas feels like a horrible human being, having fucked a whore not his wife while fantasizing that she was. Helena, however, wants a great deal more of that kind of passion and is determined to win her husband&#8217;s affections.</p>\n<p>It&#8217;s not easy.</p>\n<p>No matter what she does, Nicholas is a jerk. Normally this dynamic would irritate me, but here it works. Nicholas has good reasons for believing he&#8217;s not good enough for his wife. The horrors of his childhood and youth have left him deeply shameful and he simply doesn&#8217;t know how to overcome his self-loathing.</p>\n<p>I liked both Nicholas and Helena. The romance in this book is a good one and if you like dirty talk and adventurous marital sex in your love stories, I suspect you&#8217;ll enjoy this one.</p>\n<p>I wasn&#8217;t as enthralled with the suspense plot that takes up a great deal of the tale. Some unknown villain is threatening to reveal Nicholas&#8217; past. In addition, there are shady goings on at the shipping company Nicholas owns. Neither of these plots wowed me. I&#8217;d much rather have kept reading about Nicholas and Helena.</p>\n<p>That said, this is a fun and seriously steamy read and I am fan of both. <strong>Her Husband&#8217;s Harlot</strong> is a light, steamy, enjoyable read and I recommend it.</p>\n<h3>Get it at <a href=\"https://amzn.to/3ls4bD9\">Amazon</a> or listen to it on <a href=\"https://amzn.to/35ly7vg\">Audible</a></h3>\n",

                "html": "<p>It&#8217;s been a week or so since I finished this book after reading the three that proceed it. I still think about the Great Northern Pack, the society of wolves that feature in Maria Vale&#8217;s uncommon shapeshifter series. (If you&#8217;d like to know more about this world in detail, <a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/wolves-the-wild-and-the-other-an-interview-and-giveaway-with-maria-vale/\">Vale spoke to AAR about it recently</a>.)</p>\n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><em>(This review has spoilers for earlier books in the series.)</em></p>\n<p>In this installation&#8211;there are to be at least two more&#8211;the lovers are Evie Kitwansadottir, the Pack&#8217;s Alpha (leader) and Constantine, a Shifter who&#8217;s the Pack&#8217;s prisoner and sworn enemy. When the series began&#8211;book one is <a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/book-review/the-last-wolf-by-maria-vale/\"><strong>The Last Wolf</strong></a>&#8211;Evie was mated with John, the Pack&#8217;s Alpha. John is murdered at the end of that book by men employed by a minacious group of Shifters. Since then Evie has become the Pack&#8217;s Alpha, given birth to two pups (pregnancies are rare in the Pack), and mourned the loss of her mate while successfully managing the Pack and its diverse demands. With all she has to oversee, she&#8217;s unhappy she&#8217;s suddenly burdened with four prisoners, Shifters from the aforementioned group, three of whom she sees as no threat. But one, a tall, broad shouldered man, he, he is dangerous.</p>\n<p><strong>The Season of the Wolf</strong> is the first book in the series to have two POVs, Evie&#8217;s and Constantine&#8217;s, and that&#8217;s a fine thing. Constantine&#8211;whom we&#8217;ve seen as a killer in earlier books&#8211;is a creature whose history&#8217;s made his life one of almost utter emptiness. As he sees the Pack and Evie, he glimpses a meaningful future, as a wolf and with Evie, and he finds himself yearning for both.</p>\n<p>But the Pack and Evie&#8211;whose Pack of origin was murdered by Shifters&#8211;shun outsiders. They are sure there is no place in their world for Constantine. A credible HEA seems unworkable and it is to Vale&#8217;s great credit that the reader&#8211;and the lovers&#8211;remain hesitant, until the book&#8217;s unerring end, whether or not Constantine will earn the place he hungers to have.</p>\n<p>Vale&#8217;s love story is sensual both in its depiction of the keen desire shared by Evie and Constantine and in the absolute joy the wolves feel for the wild. And though the quandaries they face are somber, this story&#8211;and series&#8211;brims with whimsey and hope.</p>\n<p>If this intrigues you, I strongly recommend beginning with book one and reading the series as a whole. Vale&#8217;s world building and the Pack itself are riveting, singular, and damn worth your time.</p>\n<p>&nbsp;</p>\n<p>&nbsp;</p>\n",
                "text": "It&#8217;s been a week or so since I finished this book after reading the three that proceed it. I still think about the Great Northern Pack, the society of wolves that feature in Maria Vale&#8217;s uncommon shapeshifter series. (If you&#8217;d like to know more about this world in detail, Vale spoke to AAR about it recently.) (This review has spoilers for earlier books in the series.) In this installation&#8211;there are to be at least two more&#8211;the lovers are Evie Kitwansadottir, the Pack&#8217;s Alpha (leader) and Constantine, a Shifter who&#8217;s the Pack&#8217;s prisoner and sworn enemy. When the series began&#8211;book one is The Last Wolf&#8211;Evie was mated with John, the Pack&#8217;s Alpha. John is murdered at the end of that book by men employed by a minacious group of Shifters. Since then Evie has become the Pack&#8217;s Alpha, given birth to two pups (pregnancies are rare in the Pack), and mourned the loss of her mate while successfully managing the Pack and its diverse demands. With all she has to oversee, she&#8217;s unhappy she&#8217;s suddenly burdened with four prisoners, Shifters from the aforementioned group, three of whom she sees as no threat. But one, a tall, broad shouldered man, he, he is dangerous. The Season of the Wolf is the first book in the series to have two POVs, Evie&#8217;s and Constantine&#8217;s, and that&#8217;s a fine thing. Constantine&#8211;whom we&#8217;ve seen as a killer in earlier books&#8211;is a creature whose history&#8217;s made his life one of almost utter emptiness. As he sees the Pack and Evie, he glimpses a meaningful future, as a wolf and with Evie, and he finds himself yearning for both. But the Pack and Evie&#8211;whose Pack of origin was murdered by Shifters&#8211;shun outsiders. They are sure there is no place in their world for Constantine. A credible HEA seems unworkable and it is to Vale&#8217;s great credit that the reader&#8211;and the lovers&#8211;remain hesitant, until the book&#8217;s unerring end, whether or not Constantine will earn the place he hungers to have. Vale&#8217;s love story is sensual both in its depiction of the keen desire shared by Evie and Constantine and in the absolute joy the wolves feel for the wild. And though the quandaries they face are somber, this story&#8211;and series&#8211;brims with whimsey and hope. If this intrigues you, I strongly recommend beginning with book one and reading the series as a whole. Vale&#8217;s world building and the Pack itself are riveting, singular, and damn worth your time. &nbsp; &nbsp;"

                "title": "Dance Away with Me",
                "author_first": "Susan Elizabeth",
                "author_last": "Phillips",
                "publisher": "William Morrow",
                "isbn": "0062973053",
                "pages": "400",
                "publish_date": "06/2020",

                "sensuality": "Warm",
                "amazon_url": "https://amzn.to/3dbMFQ6",
                "amazon_asin": "B07XPD48W2"

            "content": {
                "html": "<p><em><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">When life throws her one setback too many, midwife and young widow Tess Hartsong takes off for Runaway Mountain. In this small town high in the Tennessee mountains, surrounded by nature, she hopes to outrun her heartbreak and find the solace she needs to heal. </span></em></p>\n<p><em><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">But instead of peace and quiet, she encounters an enigmatic artist with a craving for solitude, a fairy-tale sprite with too many secrets, a helpless infant, a passel of curious teens, and a town suspicious of outsiders, especially one as headstrong as Tess. Just as headstrong, is Ian North, a difficult, gifted man with a tortured soul—a man who makes Tess question everything. </span></em></p>\n<p><em><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">In running away to this new life, Tess wonders— Has she lost herself . . . or has she found her future?</span></em></p>\n<hr />\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><strong>Kristen:</strong> So, Dabney. There is A LOT to talk about in this book &#8211; ideas about motherhood, small town relationships, grief, trauma, insiders/outsiders&#8230; where do you want to start? </span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><strong>Dabney:</strong> This book is nuts but not necessarily in a bad way. Or is it just me?</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><strong>Kristen:</strong> I’m not sure I’d say “bad way”, but I didn’t love it. It felt like a fifteen pound story in a five pound bag. There was just </span><i><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">so much</span></i><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> and a lot of it didn’t resonate with me at all, which is why I’m glad to be talking to you about it since we have different life experiences when it comes to motherhood. I, for example, am not one, and so a lot of Tess’ motivations felt foreign to me. </span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><strong>Dabney:</strong> The motherhood thing was interesting and, oddly, parts of it made me very uncomfortable. But let’s start with Tess. She’s an interesting woman but I would not want to be her friend. You?</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><strong>Kristen:</strong> I was legitimately afraid of her a few times! She’s intense, that’s for sure, and I don’t think she’d like </span><i><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">me</span></i><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> very much. She was clearly a product of a lot of trauma (her husband’s death, another tragedy early in the story) and that colors how she interacts with herself and others, but it didn’t make for a character I was eager to spend more time with. I wasn’t quite sure was Ms. Phillips was trying to do with the talk about her body &#8211; I never got a real grip on what Tess actually </span><i><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">looked</span></i><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> like. I’ve never lived in a town as small as Runaway Mountain (which is a very on-the-nose-name here), but we certainly don’t usually see the cruelty of small towns in romance like this. What did you think about her interactions with the town? </span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><strong>Dabney:</strong> Well, all those mean people weren’t really, ultimately, mean. You just had to get to know them. It certainly is a town where not a single person didn’t seem exceedingly unique&#8211;everyone was a CHARACTER.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><strong>Kristen:</strong> Huh. I didn’t see it that way. I saw some of their ‘character’ as being cruel to be cruel, but I can see how that’s not necessarily true. </span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><strong>Dabney:</strong> And, here’s my real problem with this book: I didn’t like hardly ANYONE in it. Not Tess, not Ian, not Bianca, not Tess’s wacky coworkers, no one. Except Wren. Wren I liked because, well, babies.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><strong>Kristen:</strong> Oh, I kinda liked the babysitter. But beyond that? With you. Plus, I have </span><i><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">no</span></i><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> idea why Ian and Tess got together in the end. </span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><strong>Dabney:</strong> I didn’t understand them at all. I guess Ian is the hottest older guy since Idris Elba so maybe that’s why Tess fell so hard for him. But he was so often an ass and did not appear to understand the concept of compromise. And as for why Ian fell for Tess, I thought at first it was because she was so competent. But then she became so cranky that I didn’t get her appeal. And, unlike so many of SEP’s lovers, they had very little chemistry. </span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><strong>Kristen:</strong> I usually *fly* through SEP books, but this was a slog for me because of the lack of chemistry. What also didn’t help is that &#8211; as I mentioned before &#8211; there were a lot of stories and none of them felt settled. We dealt with purity culture and parent’s fears about teenage sex, we dealt with abusive spouses, we dealt with trauma, we dealt with adoption, and on and on. I needed one to make full sense and, to me, none of them did. I really &#8211; and this saddens me &#8211; cannot recommend this book. </span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><strong>Dabney:</strong> I too found this book sloooooow going. And I’ve loved so many of her books. Ultimately, I couldn’t quite understand this book&#8211;the love story is between two people who don’t really fit and the reclamation of the small town was just sort of dull.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">However, the real thing that bothered me was the story of Wren.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><strong>Kristen:</strong> Oh, can you tell me why? Because I really hated the bit with the grandparents &#8211; it made Wren feel like a plot device instead of a person to me &#8211; is that what you mean? </span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><strong>Dabney:</strong>  I think the whole Wren plot is a bit ethically iffy. Without giving away any spoilers&#8211;Tess’s sense of ownership over Wren made me very uncomfortable. Like so uncomfortable that I wondered if SEP had talked to a lawyer before writing the book.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><strong>Kristen:</strong> You know, I wondered the same. I also wondered what research went into post-traumatic stress reactions to both primary secondary trauma… just a lot of questions that weren’t answered in the text. </span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">So, Dabney, what do you say? We advise our readers to give this one a pass? </span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><strong>Dabney:</strong> Well, if you love SEP, you should read this book. It has much of her skill set&#8211;humor, interesting characters, and a bone-deep depth that isn’t always found in contemporary romance. But if you don’t love her, I don’t think this book is going to wow you. </span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">What grade would you give it?</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><strong>Kristen:</strong> For me, <strong>this is a C-</strong>. I was bored and befuddled for most of it, but there were some moments of levity that bumped it up from a D for me. You? </span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><strong>Dabney:</strong> I liked it more than that. It’s true I kept shaking my head as I read but I find her writing to be heads and shoulders above that of so many other romance writers. <strong>I’m going with a B-</strong>.</span></p>\n<p><i><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Well, readers.                 "text": "When life throws her one setback too many, midwife and young widow Tess Hartsong takes off for Runaway Mountain. In this small town high in the Tennessee mountains, surrounded by nature, she hopes to outrun her heartbreak and find the solace she needs to heal.  But instead of peace and quiet, she encounters an enigmatic artist with a craving for solitude, a fairy-tale sprite with too many secrets, a helpless infant, a passel of curious teens, and a town suspicious of outsiders, especially one as headstrong as Tess. Just as headstrong, is Ian North, a difficult, gifted man with a tortured soul—a man who makes Tess question everything.  In running away to this new life, Tess wonders— Has she lost herself . . . or has she found her future? Kristen: So, Dabney. There is A LOT to talk about in this book &#8211; ideas about motherhood, small town relationships, grief, trauma, insiders/outsiders&#8230; where do you want to start?  Dabney: This book is nuts but not necessarily in a bad way. Or is it just me? Kristen: I’m not sure I’d say “bad way”, but I didn’t love it. It felt like a fifteen pound story in a five pound bag. There was just so much and a lot of it didn’t resonate with me at all, which is why I’m glad to be talking to you about it since we have different life experiences when it comes to motherhood. I, for example, am not one, and so a lot of Tess’ motivations felt foreign to me.  Dabney: The motherhood thing was interesting and, oddly, parts of it made me very uncomfortable. But let’s start with Tess. She’s an interesting woman but I would not want to be her friend. You? Kristen: I was legitimately afraid of her a few times! She’s intense, that’s for sure, and I don’t think she’d like me very much. She was clearly a product of a lot of trauma (her husband’s death, another tragedy early in the story) and that colors how she interacts with herself and others, but it didn’t make for a character I was eager to spend more time with. I wasn’t quite sure was Ms. Phillips was trying to do with the talk about her body &#8211; I never got a real grip on what Tess actually looked like. I’ve never lived in a town as small as Runaway Mountain (which is a very on-the-nose-name here), but we certainly don’t usually see the cruelty of small towns in romance like this. What did you think about her interactions with the town?  Dabney: Well, all those mean people weren’t really, ultimately, mean. You just had to get to know them. It certainly is a town where not a single person didn’t seem exceedingly unique&#8211;everyone was a CHARACTER. Kristen: Huh. I didn’t see it that way. I saw some of their ‘character’ as being cruel to be cruel, but I can see how that’s not necessarily true.  Dabney: And, here’s my real problem with this book: I didn’t like hardly ANYONE in it. Not Tess, not Ian, not Bianca, not Tess’s wacky coworkers, no one. Except Wren. Wren I liked because, well, babies. Kristen: Oh, I kinda liked the babysitter. But beyond that? With you. Plus, I have no idea why Ian and Tess got together in the end.  Dabney: I didn’t understand them at all. I guess Ian is the hottest older guy since Idris Elba so maybe that’s why Tess fell so hard for him. But he was so often an ass and did not appear to understand the concept of compromise. And as for why Ian fell for Tess, I thought at first it was because she was so competent. But then she became so cranky that I didn’t get her appeal. And, unlike so many of SEP’s lovers, they had very little chemistry.  Kristen: I usually *fly* through SEP books, but this was a slog for me because of the lack of chemistry. What also didn’t help is that &#8211; as I mentioned before &#8211; there were a lot of stories and none of them felt settled. We dealt with purity culture and parent’s fears about teenage sex, we dealt with abusive spouses, we dealt with trauma, we dealt with adoption, and on and on. I needed one to make full sense and, to me, none of them did. I really &#8211; and this saddens me &#8211; cannot recommend this book.  Dabney: I too found this book sloooooow going. And I’ve loved so many of her books. Ultimately, I couldn’t quite understand this book&#8211;the love story is between two people who don’t really fit and the reclamation of the small town was just sort of dull. However, the real thing that bothered me was the story of Wren. Kristen: Oh, can you tell me why? Because I really hated the bit with the grandparents &#8211; it made Wren feel like a plot device instead of a person to me &#8211; is that what you mean?  Dabney:  I think the whole Wren plot is a bit ethically iffy. Without giving away any spoilers&#8211;Tess’s sense of ownership over Wren made me very uncomfortable. Like so uncomfortable that I wondered if SEP had talked to a lawyer before writing the book. Kristen: You know, I wondered the same. I also wondered what research went into post-traumatic stress reactions to both primary secondary trauma… just a lot of questions that weren’t answered in the text.  So, Dabney, what do you say? We advise our readers to give this one a pass?  Dabney: Well, if you love SEP, you should read this book. It has much of her skill set&#8211;humor, interesting characters, and a bone-deep depth that isn’t always found in contemporary romance. But if you don’t love her, I don’t think this book is going to wow you.  What grade would you give it? Kristen: For me, this is a C-. I was bored and befuddled for most of it, but there were some moments of levity that bumped it up from a D for me. You?  Dabney: I liked it more than that. It’s true I kept shaking my head as I read but I find her writing to be heads and shoulders above that of so many other romance writers. I’m going with a B-. Well, readers.                 "html": "<div>Shannon: <a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/book-review/phoenix-unbound-by-grace-draven/\"><strong>Phoenix Unbound</strong></a>, the prequel to <strong>Dragon Unleashed</strong> was my first experience with Grace Draven’s writing, and I was beyond impressed by the novel. This, the second book in the series, is set in the same world, but has little noticeable carry-over from the first book. I think readers could easily start with <strong>Dragon Unleashed</strong> without feeling overly confused. What do you think?</div>\n<div></div>\n<div>Dabney: Completely agree. If you&#8217;d read <strong>Phoenix Unbound</strong>, you&#8217;d have a deeper understanding of some of the references but, as a story, <strong>Dragon Unleashed</strong> works just fine as a stand alone novel.</div>\n<div></div>\n<div>Shannon: And what an epic novel I found it to be! Draven&#8217;s world building is completely immersive and her characters practically leapt off the page for me. There&#8217;s so much depth in what she&#8217;s created here, and in some ways, I feel like we&#8217;ve barely scratched the surface of this world and these people, and yet, at the same time, Helani and Malachus feel like old and familiar friends. It&#8217;s an unusual dichotomy, but one I often look for when reading fantasy romance. What were your overall impressions of <strong>Dragon Unleashed</strong>?</div>\n<div></div>\n<div>Dabney: I thoroughly enjoyed reading it&#8230; but not quite as much as I did Phoenix Unbound. But given that I <em>adored</em> <strong>Phoenix Unbound</strong>, that&#8217;s not much of a criticism.</div>\n<div></div>\n<div>This is a quieter story and the leads felt much much older and, in ways I really liked, wiser. Helani and Malachus are both deliberative about the choices they make and I enjoyed watching them slowly figure out a way towards not only their own HEA but building a better world for all. Helani&#8217;s powers aren&#8217;t superpower showy and I liked that. Both of them have almost a meditative quality to the way they interact with the world. <strong>Dragon Unleashed</strong> unfurls slowly but I very much enjoyed the journey.</div>\n<div></div>\n<div>Shannon: Those are great points. I suppose some readers might find the pacing a bit too slow for them, but I really enjoyed watching the story unfold in a way that didn&#8217;t feel like too much action crammed into one book.</div>\n<div></div>\n<div>Shannon: Since you brought up Helani and her magical abilities, I&#8217;d like to touch on her character a bit more. She&#8217;s kind and compassionate, but she&#8217;s also strong and resourceful. At first, I worried she&#8217;d feel too good to be true, but the author made sure to give her some struggles that made her feel relatable. I loved her relationship with her mother as well as her willingness to openly care for those around her. What did you think of Helani as a person?</div>\n<div></div>\n<div>Dabney: She is <i>very</i> self-sacrificing BUT she is true to herself and, by the story&#8217;s end, I believed in her choices. If you like novels where strong women figure out how to be their true selves and save the world, you&#8217;ll love this effort by Draven.</div>\n<div></div>\n<div>Shannon: Absolutely! Helani&#8217;s inner journey is the backbone of this tale.</div>\n<div></div>\n<div>Shannon: Moving on to Malachus now, dragons aren&#8217;t always my favorite mythological creatures to read about, but I ended up enjoying getting to know Malachus and the way dragon mythology is handled in this world. He could be a little self-righteous at times, but I loved his ability to learn from his mistakes rather than simply stagnating. He had a kind spirit that really spoke to me in certain parts of the book. He won&#8217;t be everyone&#8217;s ideal hero, but I found him quite intriguing. What about you?</div>\n<div></div>\n<div>Dabney: And see I dig dragons! I loved the dragon mythology and Malachus&#8217; history. His self-righteousness seemed so valid to me&#8211;he has no choice but to be single minded about his goals. It was lovely to see that for all his strength, pain, and focus on his outcomes, he isn&#8217;t an annoying alpha. His embrace of Helani and his commitment to supporting her was lovely.</div>\n<div></div>\n<div>Shannon: The one  facet of Malachus&#8217; story that didn&#8217;t quite work for me had to do with the mother bond. It took me quite a while to really understand the connection between the actual bond and the artefact that housed it. Was there anything you found difficult to relate to or understand?</div>\n<div></div>\n<div>Dabney: I found the implementation of Helani&#8217;s magic a bit hard to follow. One thing I loved about <strong>Phoenix Unbound</strong> was how visceral the magic wielded by Gilene was. Here, the magic is harder to parse.</div>\n<div></div>\n<div>Shannon: As far as a final grade, I&#8217;d give this an A-. It was close to perfect, but a bit more description of the magic system would have been helpful. What is your final grade?</div>\n<div></div>\n<div>Dabney: This is closer to a B for me.                 "text": "Shannon: Phoenix Unbound, the prequel to Dragon Unleashed was my first experience with Grace Draven’s writing, and I was beyond impressed by the novel. This, the second book in the series, is set in the same world, but has little noticeable carry-over from the first book. I think readers could easily start with Dragon Unleashed without feeling overly confused. What do you think? Dabney: Completely agree. If you&#8217;d read Phoenix Unbound, you&#8217;d have a deeper understanding of some of the references but, as a story, Dragon Unleashed works just fine as a stand alone novel. Shannon: And what an epic novel I found it to be! Draven&#8217;s world building is completely immersive and her characters practically leapt off the page for me. There&#8217;s so much depth in what she&#8217;s created here, and in some ways, I feel like we&#8217;ve barely scratched the surface of this world and these people, and yet, at the same time, Helani and Malachus feel like old and familiar friends. It&#8217;s an unusual dichotomy, but one I often look for when reading fantasy romance. What were your overall impressions of Dragon Unleashed? Dabney: I thoroughly enjoyed reading it&#8230; but not quite as much as I did Phoenix Unbound. But given that I adored Phoenix Unbound, that&#8217;s not much of a criticism. This is a quieter story and the leads felt much much older and, in ways I really liked, wiser. Helani and Malachus are both deliberative about the choices they make and I enjoyed watching them slowly figure out a way towards not only their own HEA but building a better world for all. Helani&#8217;s powers aren&#8217;t superpower showy and I liked that. Both of them have almost a meditative quality to the way they interact with the world. Dragon Unleashed unfurls slowly but I very much enjoyed the journey. Shannon: Those are great points. Shannon: Since you brought up Helani and her magical abilities, I&#8217;d like to touch on her character a bit more. She&#8217;s kind and compassionate, but she&#8217;s also strong and resourceful. At first, I worried she&#8217;d feel too good to be true, but the author made sure to give her some struggles that made her feel relatable. If you like novels where strong women figure out how to be their true selves and save the world, you&#8217;ll love this effort by Draven. Shannon: Absolutely! It took me quite a while to really understand the connection between the actual bond and the artefact that housed it. For all Draven&#8217;s attention to detail in other aspects of the novel, this particular part lacked clarity. Was there anything you found difficult to relate to or understand? Dabney: I found the implementation of Helani&#8217;s magic a bit hard to follow. I think both the mother bond magic and her earth magic are harder to comprehend how they actually work than I&#8217;d have liked. One thing I loved about Phoenix Unbound was how visceral the magic wielded by Gilene was. Here, the magic is harder to parse. Shannon: As far as a final grade, I&#8217;d give this an A-. It was close to perfect, but a bit more description of the magic system would have been helpful. What is your final grade? Dabney: This is closer to a B for me.                 "html": "<p><em>Everything has a price&#8230;</em></p>\n<p><em>Railway magnate Tom Severin is wealthy and powerful enough to satisfy any desire as soon as it arises. Anything—or anyone—is his for the asking. It should be simple to find the perfect wife—and from his first glimpse of Lady Cassandra Ravenel, he’s determined to have her. But the beautiful and quick-witted Cassandra is equally determined to marry for love—the one thing he can’t give.</em></p>\n<p><em>Everything except her&#8230;</em></p>\n<p><em>Severin is the most compelling and attractive man Cassandra has ever met, even if his heart is frozen. But she has no interest in living in the fast-paced world of a ruthless man who always plays to win.</em></p>\n<p><em>When a newfound enemy nearly destroys Cassandra’s reputation, Severin seizes the opportunity he’s been waiting for. As always, he gets what he wants—or does he? There’s one lesson Tom Severin has yet to learn from his new bride:</em></p>\n<p><em>Never underestimate a Ravenel.</em></p>\n<p><em>The chase for Cassandra’s hand may be over. But the chase for her heart has only just begun…</em></p>\n<p>Dabney Grinnan, Evelyn North and Em Wittmann read the final chapter in Lisa Kleypas&#8217; <strong><em>Ravenel</em></strong> series.  Here&#8217;s what they have to say about the novel.</p>\n<hr />\n<p><strong>Em:</strong> From the opening scene to the closing chapter, <strong>Chasing Cassandra</strong> never worked. I didn’t like the completely bizarre stranger insta-lust that set our principal characters in each other&#8217;s path (and shouldn’t they have already been in each others circles?), and I kept waiting&#8230; and waiting&#8230; and waiting for someone to ACTUALLY OR FIGURATIVELY chase Cassandra. But no one ever did! Certainly not Tom Severin, who essentially decided he wanted Cassandra and then tried to talk himself out of it almost immediately. Because he liked her too much? The entire story felt like one big elaborate farce &#8211; they liked each other and wanted to be together so why not give it a try? &#8211; and I never got to know either of the principal characters enough to know if I liked them as individuals or a couple. This is a full length book that could have been two chapters.</p>\n<p>What did you two think?</p>\n<p><strong>Evelyn:</strong> I liked it more than you. I enjoyed getting to know how Tom Severin worked &#8211; he’s been an interesting supporting character for awhile and I was happy to get more of him. I agree that you had to buy into his instant feelings for Cassandra for the book to work, and there were scenes that I liked &#8211; such as the discussions of their &#8216;marriage contract&#8217;, the scenes with Tom and his friends, and the boiler scene. I’d say I enjoyed the first two-thirds of the book but then it went a little off kilter. I kept imagining the Marquis coming back to undermine Severin &#8211; and where did Lady Berwick go? The ending was a little too contrived for me, too. It wasn’t close to my favorite Kleypas but I enjoyed most of it.</p>\n<p>Dabney, did this one work for you?</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney:</strong> *struggles to recall anything &#8211; anything! &#8211; about <strong>Chasing Cassandra*</strong></p>\n<p>Not really. It wasn’t bad &#8211; no glaring plot holes or character leaps &#8211; nor was it interesting. It’s a somewhat similar story to Kleypas’ <a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/book-review/tempt-me-at-twilight-by-lisa-kleypas/\"><strong>Tempt Me at Twilight</strong></a> (a book I like much more than this) but in this retelling, the instalust and the lack of any real barrier to true love made for a very slow read.</p>\n<p><strong>Evelyn:</strong> Yes, the barrier was &#8216;I can’t love you because I don’t want the emotion of love in my life, if it even exists&#8217; &#8211; which is a tough sell for me. But I bought it &#8211; it was just what I expected Severin to be like. He’s definitely a hero who has shut down his vulnerable, feeling side. What did you guys think of Severin as a hero?</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney:</strong> Despite having read the earlier books in this series, Severin hadn’t really registered for me. Thus I had no expectations of who he would be as a hero. I must say, I’m sort of over these Kleypas heroes that are THE defining men of their time. Professionally, Severin seemed like a capitalist superhero and while I love learning about how new technologies shaped the Victorian era, I rolled my eyes at all that Severin did. And I truly do not like the &#8216;I can’t love because it’s too dangerous&#8217; trope in romance. I am grateful that it wasn’t combined with &#8216;She’s too good for me&#8217;, another trope I rarely enjoy!</p>\n<p><strong>Em:</strong> I’m not going to heap onto the anti-Severin sentiments; I’ll simply say I agree, I didn’t know him well enough to like or hate him, and I didn’t understand his character motivations. At all. That said, Cassandra didn’t really work for me either. She’s seemingly bright and lovely, so why do only creeps like her? And if her family is so AMAZING AND AWESOME AND SURROUNDED BY AMAZING AND AWESOME people, where are the actual contenders for her heart? I thought she was naive in the extreme, and aside from her beauty and perfect manners &#8211; with homeless boys (ahem) and hard headed males &#8211; she’s kind of blah. Frankly, several weeks out from reading this story I’m also struggling to remember her in any significant way. Did you like her?</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney:</strong> Well, here’s one thing I thought was odd. Cassandra is supposed to be so gorgeous that men turn to gibbering idiots when she walks by and yet Kleypas never describes her. I don’t know what she looks like nor do I know how Severin sees her. I felt as though the book wanted it both ways: Cassandra’s beauty is the draw for Severin, at least initially, but that beauty isn’t dwelt on at all. It just was weird. As for liking her, sure, what’s not to like? But that’s not my kind of heroine. I like my leads to have depth and I just didn’t feel that here.</p>\n<p><strong>Em:</strong> Ladies, what I really want to talk about is the ridiculous deus ex machina after Cassandra finds herself in a spot of trouble. She’s nearly ruined&#8230; and then. Well, I won’t give it away but COME ON. Her ruination was clunky, the true villain has a blink and you’ll miss it appearance, and then it’s rainbows and unicorns in the very next chapter. What is the point??!!</p>\n<p><strong>Evelyn:</strong> I think that’s the place in the book where it started losing steam for me. I honestly thought the villains must be coming back at some point but…</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney:</strong> Yep. The plot in this book takes such a backseat to the characters. And that would have worked for me if the characters had more oomph. But I just found myself flipping through the pages.</p>\n<p><strong>Evelyn:</strong> I did like Severin. And his comments on the classics he read were hilarious. He and Cassandra are not going to be remembered as a great romantic couple but I think fans of the <em><strong>Ravenels</strong></em> will root for them. For me, the quality of the book varied &#8211; like I said, the first parts pulled me in, but the last parts left me scratching my head a little. Did you two enjoy any parts of the story?</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney:</strong> I loved the book plot; for me it was the strongest part of the story. And I enjoyed learning about trains, and how society’s needs for housing and transportation were changing so rapidly at that time.</p>\n<p><strong>Em:</strong> Agreed; the book discussions are a highlight. I also enjoyed the brief cameos of past Ravenel couples. But this couple? Well, I wish Cassandra’s possible ruination had been a bigger part of the story and that the villains were better developed. I’m reading another historical romance now, and the ruin of the heroine is central to her entire storyline from start to finish. It’s so much better finessed, and served as a means to develop and define the heroine. This story starts with two strangers falling in lust, and ends with them declaring it love. I couldn’t make the jump and I think readers are going to struggle with it too.</p>\n<p><strong>Evelyn:</strong> So it sounds like fans of the Ravenel series will enjoy seeing cameos of past characters but this story won’t wow them. Is that a decent summary?</p>\n<p><strong>Em:</strong> Yep. <strong>I&#8217;m giving it a C-</strong>.</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney:</strong> If you’re looking for a romance with a zinger of a plot and complex characters, this probably isn’t the novel for you. But, if you’re a Kleypas fan and love the Ravenels and friends, you’ll enjoy this book. <strong>It gets a C from me</strong>.</p>\n<p><strong>Evelyn:</strong> I think that’s a fair summary. I am a Kleypas fan and I do love the Ravenels so, even though it had some weak points, <strong>it’s a B- from me</strong>.</p>\n<h3><strong>Buy it at: <a href=\"https://amzn.to/3242X8m\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Amazon</a> or shop at your <a href=\"https://www.indiebound.org/book/9780062371942?aff=allaboutromance\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">local independent bookstore</a></strong></h3>\n<h3 style=\"text-align: center;\"><strong>Visit our <a href=\"https://amzn.to/2SeEiZg\">Amazon Storefront</a> </strong></h3>\n",
                "text": "Everything has a price&#8230; Railway magnate Tom Severin is wealthy and powerful enough to satisfy any desire as soon as it arises. Anything—or anyone—is his for the asking. It should be simple to find the perfect wife—and from his first glimpse of Lady Cassandra Ravenel, he’s determined to have her. But the beautiful and quick-witted Cassandra is equally determined to marry for love—the one thing he can’t give. Everything except her&#8230; Severin is the most compelling and attractive man Cassandra has ever met, even if his heart is frozen. But she has no interest in living in the fast-paced world of a ruthless man who always plays to win. When a newfound enemy nearly destroys Cassandra’s reputation, Severin seizes the opportunity he’s been waiting for. As always, he gets what he wants—or does he? There’s one lesson Tom Severin has yet to learn from his new bride: Never underestimate a Ravenel. The chase for Cassandra’s hand may be over. But the chase for her heart has only just begun… Dabney Grinnan, Evelyn North and Em Wittmann read the final chapter in Lisa Kleypas&#8217; Ravenel series.  Here&#8217;s what they have to say about the novel. Em: From the opening scene to the closing chapter, Chasing Cassandra never worked. I didn’t like the completely bizarre stranger insta-lust that set our principal characters in each other&#8217;s path (and shouldn’t they have already been in each others circles?), and I kept waiting&#8230; and waiting&#8230; and waiting for someone to ACTUALLY OR FIGURATIVELY chase Cassandra. But no one ever did! Certainly not Tom Severin, who essentially decided he wanted Cassandra and then tried to talk himself out of it almost immediately. Because he liked her too much? The entire story felt like one big elaborate farce &#8211; they liked each other and wanted to be together so why not give it a try? &#8211; and I never got to know either of the principal characters enough to know if I liked them as individuals or a couple. This is a full length book that could have been two chapters. What did you two think? Evelyn: I liked it more than you. I enjoyed getting to know how Tom Severin worked &#8211; he’s been an interesting supporting character for awhile and I was happy to get more of him. I agree that you had to buy into his instant feelings for Cassandra for the book to work, and there were scenes that I liked &#8211; such as the discussions of their &#8216;marriage contract&#8217;, the scenes with Tom and his friends, and the boiler scene. I’d say I enjoyed the first two-thirds of the book but then it went a little off kilter. I kept imagining the Marquis coming back to undermine Severin &#8211; and where did Lady Berwick go? The ending was a little too contrived for me, too. It wasn’t close to my favorite Kleypas but I enjoyed most of it. Dabney, did this one work for you? Dabney: *struggles to recall anything &#8211; anything! &#8211; about Chasing Cassandra* Not really. It wasn’t bad &#8211; no glaring plot holes or character leaps &#8211; nor was it interesting. It’s a somewhat similar story to Kleypas’ Tempt Me at Twilight (a book I like much more than this) but in this retelling, the instalust and the lack of any real barrier to true love made for a very slow read. Evelyn: Yes, the barrier was &#8216;I can’t love you because I don’t want the emotion of love in my life, if it even exists&#8217; &#8211; which is a tough sell for me. But I bought it &#8211; it was just what I expected Severin to be like. He’s definitely a hero who has shut down his vulnerable, feeling side. What did you guys think of Severin as a hero? Dabney: Despite having read the earlier books in this series, Severin hadn’t really registered for me. Thus I had no expectations of who he would be as a hero. I must say, I’m sort of over these Kleypas heroes that are THE defining men of their time. Professionally, Severin seemed like a capitalist superhero and while I love learning about how new technologies shaped the Victorian era, I rolled my eyes at all that Severin did. And I truly do not like the &#8216;I can’t love because it’s too dangerous&#8217; trope in romance. I am grateful that it wasn’t combined with &#8216;She’s too good for me&#8217;, another trope I rarely enjoy! Em: I’m not going to heap onto the anti-Severin sentiments; I’ll simply say I agree, I didn’t know him well enough to like or hate him, and I didn’t understand his character motivations. At all. That said, Cassandra didn’t really work for me either. She’s seemingly bright and lovely, so why do only creeps like her? And if her family is so AMAZING AND AWESOME AND SURROUNDED BY AMAZING AND AWESOME people, where are the actual contenders for her heart? I thought she was naive in the extreme, and aside from her beauty and perfect manners &#8211; with homeless boys (ahem) and hard headed males &#8211; she’s kind of blah. Frankly, several weeks out from reading this story I’m also struggling to remember her in any significant way. Did you like her? Dabney: Well, here’s one thing I thought was odd. Cassandra is supposed to be so gorgeous that men turn to gibbering idiots when she walks by and yet Kleypas never describes her. I don’t know what she looks like nor do I know how Severin sees her. I felt as though the book wanted it both ways: Cassandra’s beauty is the draw for Severin, at least initially, but that beauty isn’t dwelt on at all. It just was weird. As for liking her, sure, what’s not to like? But that’s not my kind of heroine. I like my leads to have depth and I just didn’t feel that here. Em: Ladies, what I really want to talk about is the ridiculous deus ex machina after Cassandra finds herself in a spot of trouble. She’s nearly ruined&#8230; and then. Well, I won’t give it away but COME ON. Her ruination was clunky, the true villain has a blink and you’ll miss it appearance, and then it’s rainbows and unicorns in the very next chapter. What is the point??!! Evelyn: I think that’s the place in the book where it started losing steam for me. I honestly thought the villains must be coming back at some point but… Dabney: Yep. The plot in this book takes such a backseat to the characters. And that would have worked for me if the characters had more oomph. But I just found myself flipping through the pages. Evelyn: I did like Severin. And his comments on the classics he read were hilarious. He and Cassandra are not going to be remembered as a great romantic couple but I think fans of the Ravenels will root for them. For me, the quality of the book varied &#8211; like I said, the first parts pulled me in, but the last parts left me scratching my head a little. Did you two enjoy any parts of the story? Dabney: I loved the book plot; for me it was the strongest part of the story. And I enjoyed learning about trains, and how society’s needs for housing and transportation were changing so rapidly at that time. Em: Agreed; the book discussions are a highlight. I also enjoyed the brief cameos of past Ravenel couples. But this couple? Well, I wish Cassandra’s possible ruination had been a bigger part of the story and that the villains were better developed. I’m reading another historical romance now, and the ruin of the heroine is central to her entire storyline from start to finish. It’s so much better finessed, and served as a means to develop and define the heroine. This story starts with two strangers falling in lust, and ends with them declaring it love. I couldn’t make the jump and I think readers are going to struggle with it too. Evelyn: So it sounds like fans of the Ravenel series will enjoy seeing cameos of past characters but this story won’t wow them. Is that a decent summary? Em: Yep. I&#8217;m giving it a C-. Dabney: If you’re looking for a romance with a zinger of a plot and complex characters, this probably isn’t the novel for you. But, if you’re a Kleypas fan and love the Ravenels and friends, you’ll enjoy this book. It gets a C from me. Evelyn: I think that’s a fair summary.                 "html": "<p><em>In a Philadelphia neighborhood rocked by the opioid crisis, two once-inseparable sisters find themselves at odds. One, Kacey, lives on the streets in the vise of addiction. The other, Mickey, walks those same blocks on her police beat. They don&#8217;t speak anymore, but Mickey never stops worrying about her sibling.</em></p>\n<p><em>Then Kacey disappears, suddenly, at the same time that a mysterious string of murders begins in Mickey&#8217;s district, and Mickey becomes dangerously obsessed with finding the culprit&#8211;and her sister&#8211;before it&#8217;s too late.</em></p>\n<p><em>Alternating its present-day mystery with the story of the sisters&#8217; childhood and adolescence, Long Bright River is at once heart-pounding and heart-wrenching: a gripping suspense novel that is also a moving story of sisters, addiction, and the formidable ties that persist between place, family, and fate.</em></p>\n<hr />\n<p><strong>Shannon</strong>: This is the first book I’ve read by Liz Moore, but after finishing <strong>Long Bright River</strong>, I put a few of her other novels on hold. Have you read anything else she’s written?</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney</strong>: I have not. But, whoa, after this book, I&#8217;d like to. I found this book to be riveting and I know you did too. What struck you the most?</p>\n<p><strong>Shannon</strong>: One of the most important themes of the novel is sisterhood. The relationship between Mickey and Kacey is incredibly nuanced, and in many ways, it’s what propels the story forward. I was invested in both women almost from the beginning of the story, due in large part to the remarkable way the author allowed readers to know them both so well. How did Moore’s depiction of this relationship work for you?</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney</strong>: It&#8217;s interesting to see the world through the eyes of just one person in the story. In this case, since we only get Mickey&#8217;s view&#8211;it&#8217;s a first person narration&#8211;our view of the sisters is her view. Sometimes first person narratives are too limited for me but in this case the way Moore tells the story switching between <em>Then</em> and <em>Now</em> lets us see how profoundly Kacey and Mickey are connected. Their relationship is heartbreaking, believable, and complicated in the way that sibling relationships inherently are.</p>\n<p><strong>Shannon</strong>: You make a good point here, and so, I’d like to talk a bit more about Mickey. She grew up in the shadow of addiction. It obviously had a profound effect on her, and I loved the way the author used the flashbacks to younger Mickey to illustrate the changes she went through as she aged. I found her an easy character to have empathy for, even if I didn’t always agree with her choices. How did Mickey work for you?</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney</strong>: I like unreliable narrators and Mickey is that. Every adult in her childhood let her down in part to addiction but also because&#8211;and I&#8217;m thinking of her grandmother Gee here&#8211;they simply aren&#8217;t capable of compassionate, good caretaking. Mickey&#8217;s ability to understand people is, as a result of her borderline abusive childhood, flawed. She makes mistake after mistake about the people in her life&#8211;and perhaps nowhere is that more true than with Kacey. She alienates people unnecessarily and compromises herself at work. She takes shortcuts that are hard to accept although Moore does a stellar job of showing the reader why. Mickey isn&#8217;t a character I admire but, even with all her flaws, Moore made me understand and respect her.</p>\n<p><strong>Shannon</strong>: Gee was a hard character for me to feel good about. She treated Mickey and Kacey horribly and didn’t seem to be aware of the harm she’d done. In her mind, meeting their physical needs counted as caring for them. I was relieved to see Mickey taking a different tack with her own child, even if her parenting decisions weren’t always the wisest. Moore excels at helping us see all sides of complex issues, and that’s one of the things I liked best about this book. What stands out for you?</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney</strong>:<strong> Long Bright River</strong> makes the world we see in the headlines&#8211;the thousand people who overdose every week, the families destroyed by addiction&#8211;palpable. So, in a way, what stands out for me is the world-building. But the book is more than a grim urban <a href=\"https://amzn.to/2RwqZW5\"><strong>Hillbilly Elegy</strong></a>. Moore&#8217;s characters are layered&#8211;both tragic and heroic&#8211;and, despite their contradictions, worth rooting for.</p>\n<p><strong>Shannon</strong>: I completely agree with you. By creating characters we can empathize with, Moore helps us realize that real people are affected by addiction every day.</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney</strong>: Yes. And despite it being a grim world, there&#8217;s humor in Moore&#8217;s writing. It is a nerve-wracking read but it didn&#8217;t make me sad by the story&#8217;s end.</p>\n<p><strong>Shannon</strong>: Getting back to the novel’s narrative structure for a moment, what did you think of the flashbacks? There’s a part of me that would have liked to see some of those scenes through Kacey’s eyes. I wondered what she was thinking and feeling, especially as she spiraled deeper into addiction. I wasn’t necessarily displeased by the author’s choice to filter everything through Mickey, but I did have questions about Kacey’s perspective.</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney</strong>: I very much liked the structure of the story. I&#8217;ve read this book twice and am now convinced that the greatness of this book lies in more than its depiction of a city hollowed out by drugs. Mickey&#8217;s voice and the way she tells the story, what she gets right and what she gets wrong, is brilliant. If we&#8217;d heard Kacey&#8217;s or anyone else&#8217;s voice, I think it would have been a lesser book.</p>\n<p><strong>Shannon</strong>: I can definitely see that. So, I hate saying this since it’s only January, but I can easily see this book being one of my favorite reads of 2020. I gave it 5 stars on GoodReads and I<strong>’m giving it an A</strong> here at AAR. It’s hard-hitting in the very best way, and I loved every minute I spent with these characters. What is your final grade?</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney</strong>: <strong>It&#8217;s an A- for me</strong>. I wasn&#8217;t wowed by the identity of the murderer and I struggled, at times, with how utterly inept Mickey can be, but the book is a fabulous read despite those limitations.</p>\n<h3>Buy it at <a href=\"https://amzn.to/2O1oDvZ\">Amazon</a> or <a href=\"https://www.indiebound.org/book/9780525540670?aff=allaboutromance\">Shop your local indie bookstore</a></h3>\n",
                "text": "In a Philadelphia neighborhood rocked by the opioid crisis, two once-inseparable sisters find themselves at odds. One, Kacey, lives on the streets in the vise of addiction. The other, Mickey, walks those same blocks on her police beat. They don&#8217;t speak anymore, but Mickey never stops worrying about her sibling. Then Kacey disappears, suddenly, at the same time that a mysterious string of murders begins in Mickey&#8217;s district, and Mickey becomes dangerously obsessed with finding the culprit&#8211;and her sister&#8211;before it&#8217;s too late. Alternating its present-day mystery with the story of the sisters&#8217; childhood and adolescence, Long Bright River is at once heart-pounding and heart-wrenching: a gripping suspense novel that is also a moving story of sisters, addiction, and the formidable ties that persist between place, family, and fate. Shannon: This is the first book I’ve read by Liz Moore, but after finishing Long Bright River, I put a few of her other novels on hold. Have you read anything else she’s written? Dabney: I have not. But, whoa, after this book, I&#8217;d like to. I found this book to be riveting and I know you did too. What struck you the most? Shannon: One of the most important themes of the novel is sisterhood. The relationship between Mickey and Kacey is incredibly nuanced, and in many ways, it’s what propels the story forward. I was invested in both women almost from the beginning of the story, due in large part to the remarkable way the author allowed readers to know them both so well. How did Moore’s depiction of this relationship work for you? Dabney: It&#8217;s interesting to see the world through the eyes of just one person in the story. In this case, since we only get Mickey&#8217;s view&#8211;it&#8217;s a first person narration&#8211;our view of the sisters is her view. Sometimes first person narratives are too limited for me but in this case the way Moore tells the story switching between Then and Now lets us see how profoundly Kacey and Mickey are connected. Their relationship is heartbreaking, believable, and complicated in the way that sibling relationships inherently are. Shannon: You make a good point here, and so, I’d like to talk a bit more about Mickey. She grew up in the shadow of addiction. It obviously had a profound effect on her, and I loved the way the author used the flashbacks to younger Mickey to illustrate the changes she went through as she aged. I found her an easy character to have empathy for, even if I didn’t always agree with her choices. How did Mickey work for you? Dabney: I like unreliable narrators and Mickey is that. Every adult in her childhood let her down in part to addiction but also because&#8211;and I&#8217;m thinking of her grandmother Gee here&#8211;they simply aren&#8217;t capable of compassionate, good caretaking. Mickey&#8217;s ability to understand people is, as a result of her borderline abusive childhood, flawed. She makes mistake after mistake about the people in her life&#8211;and perhaps nowhere is that more true than with Kacey. She alienates people unnecessarily and compromises herself at work. She takes shortcuts that are hard to accept although Moore does a stellar job of showing the reader why. Mickey isn&#8217;t a character I admire but, even with all her flaws, Moore made me understand and respect her. Shannon: Gee was a hard character for me to feel good about. She treated Mickey and Kacey horribly and didn’t seem to be aware of the harm she’d done. In her mind, meeting their physical needs counted as caring for them. I was relieved to see Mickey taking a different tack with her own child, even if her parenting decisions weren’t always the wisest. Moore excels at helping us see all sides of complex issues, and that’s one of the things I liked best about this book. What stands out for you? Dabney: Long Bright River makes the world we see in the headlines&#8211;the thousand people who overdose every week, the families destroyed by addiction&#8211;palpable. So, in a way, what stands out for me is the world-building. But the book is more than a grim urban Hillbilly Elegy. Moore&#8217;s characters are layered&#8211;both tragic and heroic&#8211;and, despite their contradictions, worth rooting for. Shannon: I completely agree with you. By creating characters we can empathize with, Moore helps us realize that real people are affected by addiction every day. Dabney: Yes. And despite it being a grim world, there&#8217;s humor in Moore&#8217;s writing. It is a nerve-wracking read but it didn&#8217;t make me sad by the story&#8217;s end. Shannon: Getting back to the novel’s narrative structure for a moment, what did you think of the flashbacks? There’s a part of me that would have liked to see some of those scenes through Kacey’s eyes. I wondered what she was thinking and feeling, especially as she spiraled deeper into addiction. I wasn’t necessarily displeased by the author’s choice to filter everything through Mickey, but I did have questions about Kacey’s perspective. Dabney: I very much liked the structure of the story. I&#8217;ve read this book twice and am now convinced that the greatness of this book lies in more than its depiction of a city hollowed out by drugs. Mickey&#8217;s voice and the way she tells the story, what she gets right and what she gets wrong, is brilliant. If we&#8217;d heard Kacey&#8217;s or anyone else&#8217;s voice, I think it would have been a lesser book. Shannon: I can definitely see that. So, I hate saying this since it’s only January, but I can easily see this book being one of my favorite reads of 2020. I gave it 5 stars on GoodReads and I’m giving it an A here at AAR. It’s hard-hitting in the very best way, and I loved every minute I spent with these characters. What is your final grade? Dabney: It&#8217;s an A- for me. I wasn&#8217;t wowed by the identity of the murderer and I struggled, at times, with how utterly inept Mickey can be, but the book is a fabulous read despite those limitations.                 "html": "<p>I love our end of the year lists in part because, later, I can look back and see what we loved. In 2014, Meljean Brook&#8217;s novella <strong>Frozen</strong> made <a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/dabneys-best-of-2014-list/\">my #Bestof2014 list</a>. (2014 produced several books on it I still adore: <a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/book-review/three-weeks-with-lady-x/\"><strong>Three Weeks with Lady X</strong></a>, <a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/book-review/rogue-spy-2/\"><strong>Rogue Spy</strong></a>, <a href=\"https://amzn.to/2Qyxy8Q\"><strong>No More Mr. Nice Guy</strong></a>, <a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/book-review/having-her/\"><strong>Having Her</strong></a>, <a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/book-review/off-the-edge-by-carolyn-crane/\"><strong>Off the Edge</strong></a>, and <a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/book-review/the-suffragette-scandal-by-courtney-milan/\"><strong>The Suffragette Scandal</strong></a>.) I&#8217;d not reread <em>Frozen</em>, but after reading Brook&#8217;s latest &#8211; <a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/book-review/a-heart-of-blood-and-ashes-by-milla-vane/\"><strong>A Heart of Blood and Ashes</strong></a> &#8211; I decided to see if the novella was a strong as I&#8217;d recalled.  While the book isn&#8217;t quite a DIK, it is indeed an engrossing and sexy read.</p>\n<p>It&#8217;s a week before Christmas and Olivia Martin, a kickass civil engineer who works for Gullbrandr Engineering, is pulling up to Erik Gullbrandr&#8217;s house &#8211; which is more of a defensive fortress &#8211; to drop off some papers for him to sign. Erik is the son of the CEO of the company and his dad specifically asked Olivia to run this errand. Olivia and Erik have a history&#8211;from the moment they met they had CHEMISTRY but after exchanging a life-changing kiss, Erik made it clear he wanted nothing to do with Olivia. They are currently uneasy colleagues &#8211; Erik&#8217;s always so chilly to Olivia and she doesn&#8217;t really get why &#8211; and Olivia is fairly steamed about having to run this irritating errand and subjecting herself to rejection yet again.</p>\n<p>When she arrives, after hiking for a quarter of a mile in two feet deep snow, Erik is horrified to see her. He demands she leaves immediately and escorts her to her car to insure that she does. However, when they arrive at her Jeep they are aghast to see someone &#8211; something &#8211; has ripped it to shreds. As they make a run back to the house, Olivia is even more shocked to realize that Erik isn&#8217;t entirely human &#8211; he is a frost giant and the creatures that destroyed Olivia&#8217;s ride are Hounds determined to destroy him. But this isn&#8217;t the worst news Erik has for Olivia: He&#8217;s cursed &#8211; all the men in his family are &#8211; and, in two days, when the winter solstice arrives, he&#8217;ll attack Olivia.</p>\n<blockquote><p>I’ll come through stone to get you. I will, Olivia. The curse doesn’t let me kill myself to stop it, so you have to. I thought that if I was away from you, if I didn’t know where you were, it would be all right. But I can feel you, like there’s a chain pulling me toward you, and it’s getting stronger. If you leave now, I’ll track you down. There’s nowhere to run. And when I find you, I’ll force— I’ll…” His voice faltered before hardening again. “I’ll hurt you, Olivia.</p></blockquote>\n<p>He assures her the curse is unbreakable&#8211;it&#8217;s existed for millenia.</p>\n<blockquote><p>“This curse on my family will break during Ragnarök, when Odin’s son Víðarr destroys Loki’s son, Fenrir the Wolf.”</p></blockquote>\n<p>(I <em>adore</em> Norse mythology so this backstory rings all my bells.)</p>\n<p>I have to say, if I had to be trapped in a fortress with a mostly human frost giant who can barely keep his hands off me as we try to outwit Norse-inspired hell hounds, as long as said frost giant was Erik, I&#8217;d be so down. Erik is honorable, smart, sexy, and, despite being in a terrifying fight for his and Olivia&#8217;s lives, has a wicked sense of humor. He&#8217;s a gem.</p>\n<p>I liked Olivia as well. She&#8217;s always been profoundly drawn to Erik and now that she&#8217;s figured out what the problem between them is &#8211; not her, at least not in the way she thought &#8211; she&#8217;s damn determined she and Erik will survive the next few days.</p>\n<p>The world building that Brook/Vane is deservedly famous for is in short shrift here &#8211; it&#8217;s a novella &#8211; but the relationship between the leads has depth and shape enough to overcome the lack of deeply defined context. I don&#8217;t love the last ten percent of the book &#8211; it&#8217;s what keeps the novella from being a DIK &#8211; but found the conclusion very satisfying.</p>\n<p>Ultimately <strong>Frozen</strong> is a book I couldn&#8217;t put down, even on my second read.                 "text": "I love our end of the year lists in part because, later, I can look back and see what we loved. In 2014, Meljean Brook&#8217;s novella Frozen made my #Bestof2014 list. (2014 produced several books on it I still adore: Three Weeks with Lady X, Rogue Spy, No More Mr. Nice Guy, Having Her, Off the Edge, and The Suffragette Scandal.) I&#8217;d not reread Frozen, but after reading Brook&#8217;s latest &#8211; A Heart of Blood and Ashes &#8211; I decided to see if the novella was a strong as I&#8217;d recalled.  While the book isn&#8217;t quite a DIK, it is indeed an engrossing and sexy read. It&#8217;s a week before Christmas and Olivia Martin, a kickass civil engineer who works for Gullbrandr Engineering, is pulling up to Erik Gullbrandr&#8217;s house &#8211; which is more of a defensive fortress &#8211; to drop off some papers for him to sign. Erik is the son of the CEO of the company and his dad specifically asked Olivia to run this errand. Olivia and Erik have a history&#8211;from the moment they met they had CHEMISTRY but after exchanging a life-changing kiss, Erik made it clear he wanted nothing to do with Olivia. They are currently uneasy colleagues &#8211; Erik&#8217;s always so chilly to Olivia and she doesn&#8217;t really get why &#8211; and Olivia is fairly steamed about having to run this irritating errand and subjecting herself to rejection yet again. When she arrives, after hiking for a quarter of a mile in two feet deep snow, Erik is horrified to see her. He demands she leaves immediately and escorts her to her car to insure that she does. However, when they arrive at her Jeep they are aghast to see someone &#8211; something &#8211; has ripped it to shreds. As they make a run back to the house, Olivia is even more shocked to realize that Erik isn&#8217;t entirely human &#8211; he is a frost giant and the creatures that destroyed Olivia&#8217;s ride are Hounds determined to destroy him. But this isn&#8217;t the worst news Erik has for Olivia: He&#8217;s cursed &#8211; all the men in his family are &#8211; and, in two days, when the winter solstice arrives, he&#8217;ll attack Olivia. I’ll come through stone to get you. I will, Olivia. The curse doesn’t let me kill myself to stop it, so you have to. I thought that if I was away from you, if I didn’t know where you were, it would be all right. But I can feel you, like there’s a chain pulling me toward you, and it’s getting stronger. If you leave now, I’ll track you down. There’s nowhere to run. And when I find you, I’ll force— I’ll…” His voice faltered before hardening again. “I’ll hurt you, Olivia. He assures her the curse is unbreakable&#8211;it&#8217;s existed for millenia. “This curse on my family will break during Ragnarök, when Odin’s son Víðarr destroys Loki’s son, Fenrir the Wolf.” (I adore Norse mythology so this backstory rings all my bells.) I have to say, if I had to be trapped in a fortress with a mostly human frost giant who can barely keep his hands off me as we try to outwit Norse-inspired hell hounds, as long as said frost giant was Erik, I&#8217;d be so down. Erik is honorable, smart, sexy, and, despite being in a terrifying fight for his and Olivia&#8217;s lives, has a wicked sense of humor. He&#8217;s a gem. I liked Olivia as well. She&#8217;s always been profoundly drawn to Erik and now that she&#8217;s figured out what the problem between them is &#8211; not her, at least not in the way she thought &#8211; she&#8217;s damn determined she and Erik will survive the next few days. The world building that Brook/Vane is deservedly famous for is in short shrift here &#8211; it&#8217;s a novella &#8211; but the relationship between the leads has depth and shape enough to overcome the lack of deeply defined context. I don&#8217;t love the last ten percent of the book &#8211; it&#8217;s what keeps the novella from being a DIK &#8211; but found the conclusion very satisfying. Ultimately Frozen is a book I couldn&#8217;t put down, even on my second read. If you like sexy PRN, I suggest you give it a whirl.
