                "html": "<p><strong>Uncommon Passion</strong> is one of my very favorite romances. I’ve read it again and again—it’s my favorite of Calhoun’s books and has been since it was first published in 2013. It’s a virgin/rake story and, like the best of that trope, is a testament to the redemptive power of love.</p>\n<p>Rachel Hill, age 25,&nbsp;has recently escaped the Elysian Fields Community of God, an isolated religious community in rural Texas where she grew up. Rachel left Elysian Fields because, as she says,</p>\n<blockquote><p>They needed me to be someone I am not. They expected me to surrender all choice and control in my life to God, and if God’s direction wasn’t clear, my pastor or my father would explain it to me.</p></blockquote>\n<p>One choice Rachel&#8217;s never made is to touch or be touched by a man. In Elysian Fields, all sexual contact is saved for marriage and Rachel, who stayed stubbornly unwed, is a virgin in every sense of the word. Rachel’s ready to change that and, one night, while working at a&nbsp;charity bachelor auction,&nbsp;Rachel decides she&#8217;s ready to get rid of her virginity (and a large swath of her savings) by bidding Ben Harris, a sexy SWAT officer up for auction. Ben looks to Rachel like the perfect man for the job.</p>\n<blockquote><p>Perfect, because she’d just bet two thousand dollars that he had no interest in a relationship, no sense that sex was something special reserved for the marriage bed, no inclination to call again.</p></blockquote>\n<p>Ben doesn&#8217;t give a fuck. Not about anything but his job and his brother. He sure as shit doesn&#8217;t give a damn about the women he screws. But when he wakes up the morning after bedding Rachel, he&#8217;s first shocked and then furious to see blood on his cock. He tracks Rachel down and asks her what the hell she thought she was doing. She tells him her virginity was hers to lose and, anyway, she didn&#8217;t think he would <em>know</em>&nbsp;or&nbsp;<em>care</em>. Ben, angry and intrigued, tells her he wants&nbsp;<em>another shot,&nbsp;</em>that he&#8217;s got what she&nbsp;<em>needs.&nbsp;</em></p>\n<blockquote><p>“You don’t know what I need,” she said as she glanced toward the barn&#8230;.</p>\n<p>“I remember,” he said without lowering his voice, “how you were shaking under me at the end. Look me in the eye and tell me you don’t need more.”</p>\n<p>She went still again, stiller than he thought possible&#8230;.</p>\n<p>“I want an explanation. You want to do it again. Longer. Slower. Hotter. This time we’ll both get what we want.”</p></blockquote>\n<p>Ben, who has slept with so many women he can&#8217;t remember their faces let alone their names, finds making love with Rachel disorienting. For him, sex is a means to keep emotion at bay. Fucking Rachel is terrifyingly different.</p>\n<p>Rachel uses sex the way she uses everything: as an implement for self-discovery. As Ben watches Rachel push herself to experience all she was denied at Elysian Fields, Ben starts to see himself differently. Rachel lives life authentically and Ben, whose self-imposed limits are destroying him, finds himself longing for what Rachel demands for herself.</p>\n<p>It&#8217;s profoundly satisfying to watch Rachel evolve. Every experience Rachel has, whether it&#8217;s watching the way the Texas A&amp;M boys working at the farm for the summer play poker or taking in the expressions of amateur poets at open-mike night at her favorite bookstore in Galveston, Rachel uses it to build on what she&#8217;s previously seen and felt. Rachel doesn&#8217;t need rescuing&#8211;she&#8217;s compently and curiously creating a life with meaning.</p>\n<p>It&#8217;s Ben who needs saving. His reckless bravado hides a complex, angry man. He&#8217;s estranged from his family and has spent years punishing himself and his father. The man he is in the beginning of the novel is sexy to Rachel&#8211;and to the reader&#8211;because of his confident diffidence. But the Ben the novel slowly reveals, the man Ben begins to understand he can be, <strong>that</strong> man, a Ben loves and lets himself be loved, is spellbinding.</p>\n<p>Ms. Calhoun&#8217;s writing thrills. Every scene feels necessary to the storytelling; her descriptions broaden the novel&#8217;s emotional scope. The sex scenes are lush, erotic, and singular. The pacing layers the narrative; the ending holds a sense of sweet inevitability. If you’ve not read Calhoun or if you’re just searching for a love story with verve and heft, check out <strong>Uncommon Passion</strong>. It’s superb.</p>\n",
                "text": "Uncommon Passion is one of my very favorite romances. I’ve read it again and again—it’s my favorite of Calhoun’s books and has been since it was first published in 2013. It’s a virgin/rake story and, like the best of that trope, is a testament to the redemptive power of love. Rachel Hill, age 25,&nbsp;has recently escaped the Elysian Fields Community of God, an isolated religious community in rural Texas where she grew up. Rachel left Elysian Fields because, as she says, They needed me to be someone I am not. They expected me to surrender all choice and control in my life to God, and if God’s direction wasn’t clear, my pastor or my father would explain it to me. One choice Rachel&#8217;s never made is to touch or be touched by a man. In Elysian Fields, all sexual contact is saved for marriage and Rachel, who stayed stubbornly unwed, is a virgin in every sense of the word. Rachel’s ready to change that and, one night, while working at a&nbsp;charity bachelor auction,&nbsp;Rachel decides she&#8217;s ready to get rid of her virginity (and a large swath of her savings) by bidding Ben Harris, a sexy SWAT officer up for auction. Ben looks to Rachel like the perfect man for the job. Perfect, because she’d just bet two thousand dollars that he had no interest in a relationship, no sense that sex was something special reserved for the marriage bed, no inclination to call again. Ben doesn&#8217;t give a fuck. Not about anything but his job and his brother. He sure as shit doesn&#8217;t give a damn about the women he screws. But when he wakes up the morning after bedding Rachel, he&#8217;s first shocked and then furious to see blood on his cock. He tracks Rachel down and asks her what the hell she thought she was doing. She tells him her virginity was hers to lose and, anyway, she didn&#8217;t think he would know&nbsp;or&nbsp;care. Ben, angry and intrigued, tells her he wants&nbsp;another shot,&nbsp;that he&#8217;s got what she&nbsp;needs.&nbsp; “You don’t know what I need,” she said as she glanced toward the barn&#8230;. “I remember,” he said without lowering his voice, “how you were shaking under me at the end. Look me in the eye and tell me you don’t need more.” She went still again, stiller than he thought possible&#8230;. “I want an explanation. You want to do it again. Longer. Slower. Hotter. This time we’ll both get what we want.” Ben, who has slept with so many women he can&#8217;t remember their faces let alone their names, finds making love with Rachel disorienting. For him, sex is a means to keep emotion at bay. Fucking Rachel is terrifyingly different. Rachel uses sex the way she uses everything: as an implement for self-discovery. As Ben watches Rachel push herself to experience all she was denied at Elysian Fields, Ben starts to see himself differently. Rachel lives life authentically and Ben, whose self-imposed limits are destroying him, finds himself longing for what Rachel demands for herself. It&#8217;s profoundly satisfying to watch Rachel evolve. Every experience Rachel has, whether it&#8217;s watching the way the Texas A&amp;M boys working at the farm for the summer play poker or taking in the expressions of amateur poets at open-mike night at her favorite bookstore in Galveston, Rachel uses it to build on what she&#8217;s previously seen and felt. Rachel doesn&#8217;t need rescuing&#8211;she&#8217;s compently and curiously creating a life with meaning. It&#8217;s Ben who needs saving. His reckless bravado hides a complex, angry man. He&#8217;s estranged from his family and has spent years punishing himself and his father. The man he is in the beginning of the novel is sexy to Rachel&#8211;and to the reader&#8211;because of his confident diffidence. But the Ben the novel slowly reveals, the man Ben begins to understand he can be, that man, a Ben loves and lets himself be loved, is spellbinding. Ms. Calhoun&#8217;s writing thrills. Every scene feels necessary to the storytelling; her descriptions broaden the novel&#8217;s emotional scope. The sex scenes are lush, erotic, and singular. The pacing layers the narrative; the ending holds a sense of sweet inevitability. If you’ve not read Calhoun or if you’re just searching for a love story with verve and heft, check out Uncommon Passion. It’s superb."

                "html": "<p style=\"text-align: center\"><em>This review contains spoilers for the first two books in <strong>The Folk of Air</strong> series.</em></p>\n<p>At the end of <a href=\"https://amzn.to/2OwSlIE\"><strong>The Wicked King</strong></a>, the second book in Black&#8217;s marvelous <span class=\"a-size-extra-large\"><a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/book-review/the-cruel-prince-and-the-wicked-king-by-holly-black/\"><em>The Folk of the Air</em> </a>series, Cardan, the King of Faerie, banishes Jude to the mortal world decreeing:<br />\n</span></p>\n<blockquote><p>“I exile Jude Duarte to the mortal world. Until and unless she is pardoned by the crown, let her not step one foot in Faerie or forfeit her life.”</p></blockquote>\n<p>This does not go over well.</p>\n<p>As the final book in the trilogy, <strong>The Queen of Nothing</strong>, begins Jude is infuriated, embarrassed, and bored. Living in Maine with her sister Vivi and her brother Oak, she spends her days watching brainless TV and her nights doing odd jobs for fairies. She misses Faerieland desperately. She longs to return, to best Cardan, to seize the throne, to somehow get back who she was there, a self she simply isn&#8217;t in the mortal world.</p>\n<p>Thus when her treacherous twin Taryn arrives at her door requesting that Jude temporarily swap places with her&#8211;Taryn has, astonishingly, murdered her utter prick of a husband, Cardan&#8217;s childhood friend Locke, and wants Jude, who cannot be glamoured to tell the truth, to pretend to be her during Taryn&#8217;s inquest&#8211;Jude agrees. And though the plan is that Jude will only go to Faerieland for a day or two, the moment Jude returns to Court, she&#8217;s again enmeshed in the fight for the throne, a seat that belongs now not only to Cardan but, unbeknownst to all, to her. <span id=\"ebooksProductTitle\" class=\"a-size-extra-large\"> </span></p>\n<p><em><a href=\"https://amzn.to/35qIATl\"><img loading=\"lazy\" decoding=\"async\" class=\"wp-image-91017 size-medium alignright\" src=\"https://allaboutromance.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/1-24-300x245.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"300\" height=\"245\" srcset=\"https://allaboutromance.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/1-24-300x245.jpg 300w, https://allaboutromance.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/1-24-150x123.jpg 150w, https://allaboutromance.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/1-24-200x163.jpg 200w, https://allaboutromance.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/1-24.jpg 367w\" sizes=\"auto, (max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /></a>The Folk of Air </em>is exquisite enchantment&#8211;gorgeous, absorbing, lavish with magic, love, and conflict. The books build on one another beautifully, each deepening the complex narrative and illuminating the dispositions and motivations of the characters. The principals here, varied and satisfyingly authentic, are among the believable I&#8217;ve encountered in fantasy. One of the many joys of <strong>The Queen of Nothing</strong> is seeing the conclusion of the stories of Madoc (Jude&#8217;s adoptive father who wants the throne for his own), Taryn, Vivi, the Ghost, the Bomb, and the Roach (fellow spies from The Court of Shadows where Jude once served) and a legion of others. (I don&#8217;t recommend this book as a standalone.)</p>\n<p>At its marrow, though, the series is Cardan&#8217;s and Jude&#8217;s story and I&#8217;m hard pressed to think of a pair I&#8217;ve liked more. In <a href=\"https://amzn.to/34fWwzt\"><strong>The Cruel Prince</strong></a>, Cardan and Jude begin as enemies, he a hateful brutal prince whom Jude hates more than anyone else in the Court. Over the next thousand pages, the two form a snarled partnership that, by the series&#8217; end, empowers not only themselves but all of Faerieland. Theirs is love-hate story for the ages and one I suspect I&#8217;ll read and recommend again and again.</p>\n<h3 style=\"text-align: center\">Buy it at <a href=\"https://amzn.to/34fWwzt\">Amazon</a>/<a href=\"https://books.apple.com/us/book/the-queen-of-nothing/id1456158022?mt=11&amp;app=itunes&amp;at=1010lmPQ\">Apple Books</a>/<a href=\"http://www.anrdoezrs.net/links/8039827/type/dlg/fragment/%2F/https://www.barnesandnoble.com/w/the-queen-of-nothing-holly-black/1130884109?ean=9780316310406\">Barnes and Noble</a>/<a href=\"https://click.linksynergy.com/deeplink?id=b95pXvP*dp4&amp;mid=37217&amp;murl=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.kobo.com%2Fus%2Fen%2Febook%2Fthe-queen-of-nothing\">Kobo</a></h3>\n<h3 style=\"text-align: center\">or <a href=\"https://www.indiebound.org/book/9780316310420?aff=allaboutromance\">Shop your local indie bookstore</a></h3>\n",
                "text": "This review contains spoilers for the first two books in The Folk of Air series. At the end of The Wicked King, the second book in Black&#8217;s marvelous The Folk of the Air series, Cardan, the King of Faerie, banishes Jude to the mortal world decreeing: “I exile Jude Duarte to the mortal world. Until and unless she is pardoned by the crown, let her not step one foot in Faerie or forfeit her life.” This does not go over well. As the final book in the trilogy, The Queen of Nothing, begins Jude is infuriated, embarrassed, and bored. Living in Maine with her sister Vivi and her brother Oak, she spends her days watching brainless TV and her nights doing odd jobs for fairies. She misses Faerieland desperately. She longs to return, to best Cardan, to seize the throne, to somehow get back who she was there, a self she simply isn&#8217;t in the mortal world. Thus when her treacherous twin Taryn arrives at her door requesting that Jude temporarily swap places with her&#8211;Taryn has, astonishingly, murdered her utter prick of a husband, Cardan&#8217;s childhood friend Locke, and wants Jude, who cannot be glamoured to tell the truth, to pretend to be her during Taryn&#8217;s inquest&#8211;Jude agrees. And though the plan is that Jude will only go to Faerieland for a day or two, the moment Jude returns to Court, she&#8217;s again enmeshed in the fight for the throne, a seat that belongs now not only to Cardan but, unbeknownst to all, to her.   The Folk of Air is exquisite enchantment&#8211;gorgeous, absorbing, lavish with magic, love, and conflict. The books build on one another beautifully, each deepening the complex narrative and illuminating the dispositions and motivations of the characters. The principals here, varied and satisfyingly authentic, are among the believable I&#8217;ve encountered in fantasy. One of the many joys of The Queen of Nothing is seeing the conclusion of the stories of Madoc (Jude&#8217;s adoptive father who wants the throne for his own), Taryn, Vivi, the Ghost, the Bomb, and the Roach (fellow spies from The Court of Shadows where Jude once served) and a legion of others. (I don&#8217;t recommend this book as a standalone.) At its marrow, though, the series is Cardan&#8217;s and Jude&#8217;s story and I&#8217;m hard pressed to think of a pair I&#8217;ve liked more. In The Cruel Prince, Cardan and Jude begin as enemies, he a hateful brutal prince whom Jude hates more than anyone else in the Court. Over the next thousand pages, the two form a snarled partnership that, by the series&#8217; end, empowers not only themselves but all of Faerieland. Theirs is love-hate story for the ages and one I suspect I&#8217;ll read and recommend again and again. Buy it at Amazon/Apple Books/Barnes and Noble/Kobo or Shop your local indie bookstore"

                "html": "<p>I&#8217;ve not read much Nalini Singh &#8211; just her <strong><a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/book-review/rock-hard/\"><em>Rock Kiss</em></a></strong> series &#8211; so, if you&#8217;re a lover of her paranormals, I can&#8217;t tell you whether this book is on par with those. I do, however, read scads of mystery and romantic suspense and, if you&#8217;re a lover of those genres, you&#8217;ll enjoy Singh&#8217;s first foray into the field, <strong>The Madness of Sunshine</strong>.</p>\n<p>Anahera Rawiri fled the tiny, remote West Coast New Zealand town of Golden Cove eight years ago when she was 21. Now, reeling from the death of her famous London husband and the discovery of his perfidy, she&#8217;s come home. Golden Cove, however, is no peaceful haven but rather a place stalked by death and riven by secrets.</p>\n<p>Fifteen years ago, three young women, tourist hikers, vanished and their deaths were never solved. Now, Miriama, the young beauty of the town, has disappeared and Anahera, like many who have grown up in here, suspects the crimes are linked. So does Will Gallagher, Golden Cove&#8217;s new and only detective, a man with a past as dark as the one Anahera ran from when she left. Together, as they try desperately to find Miriama, they exhume secrets some will kill to keep hidden.</p>\n<p>Singh pulls out all the tropes here: a moody heroine, a man with a clouded past, a hamlet hiding horrors, a heretofore unknown serial killer and, overall, does these oft stock mores deftly. Golden Cove&#8217;s residents are each written with nuance as are the complex relationships they share. Sex, power, money, and violence shape all in the town and with each successive chapter Singh erodes the veneers almost everyone in Golden Cove wears.</p>\n<p>I tore through this book. The mystery is compelling and Singh&#8217;s prose is evocative and precise. I felt the pelting rains, the crash of the sea, the all encompassing hold of the bush. Anahera and Will are both separately and together absorbing protagonists and although their romance is but a small part of this book, it&#8217;s a satisfying affair. The rest of the cast is diverse and distinct and the ways in which their pasts stamp the present is adroitly done.</p>\n<p>One thing didn&#8217;t wow&#8211;thus the A- rather than an A. By the end of the book, it felt as though every man in the book other than Will was beyond fatally flawed. When the villain(s) were revealed, so many of the male characters had enough of a dark side that I began to wonder if there was something in the water in Golden Cove that turned men <em>evil</em>. This meant I wasn&#8217;t super startled by the bad guy(s)&#8217;s identity.</p>\n<p>But my awareness of who did it came late enough in the book that I still was buoyed by the story until almost the very end. And I really did find the story &#8211; until the last few chapters &#8211; so riveting that I was irritated when anyone interrupted me while I was reading it. If you&#8217;re looking for an atmospheric, beautifully written suspense novel with a soupcon of romance I highly recommend this book.</p>\n<h3><strong>Buy it at: <a href=\"https://amzn.to/2qpdfBF\">Amazon</a>/<a href=\"https://books.apple.com/us/book/a-madness-of-sunshine/id1455777427?mt=11&amp;app=itunes&amp;at=1010lmPQ\">Apple Books</a>/<a href=\"http://www.anrdoezrs.net/links/8039827/type/dlg/fragment/%2F/https://www.barnesandnoble.com/w/a-madness-of-sunshine-nalini-singh/1130866888?ean=9780593099087\">Barnes and Noble</a>/<a href=\"https://click.linksynergy.com/deeplink?id=b95pXvP*dp4&amp;mid=37217&amp;murl=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.kobo.com%2Fus%2Fen%2Febook%2Fa-madness-of-sunshine\">Kobo</a></strong></h3>\n<h3 style=\"text-align: center;\"><strong>Visit our <a href=\"https://amzn.to/2SeEiZg\">Amazon Storefront</a></strong></h3>\n",

                "html": "<p><a href=\"https://amzn.to/2pRvQFZ\"><strong>The Cruel Prince</strong></a> and <a href=\"https://amzn.to/2BO8m7j\"><strong>The Wicked King</strong></a> are the first two books in a fantasy series by Holly Black. I advise you to quit reading this review and, instead, find a way to get your hands on both books.</p>\n<p>Still here? OK. That&#8217;s on you.</p>\n<p>Prior to reading these cracktastic books, I&#8217;d read one other Black book&#8211;<a href=\"https://amzn.to/33SiK9S\"><strong>The Darkest Part of the Forest</strong></a>&#8211;and had liked it but hadn&#8217;t been inspired to pick up another. (So many books, way too little time.) But then Bec McMaster began raving about <strong>The Cruel Prince</strong> on Facebook so, when it was recently an AAR Steal and Deal, I bought it. I began reading it on a plane and, let me tell you, the nation has never flashed by so quickly.</p>\n<p>Why? Well, to begin with: Jude. Jude is Black&#8217;s protagonist and, for all but the prologue of each book, their narrator. She is splendid. She&#8217;s everything I want in a character&#8211;complex, thoughtful, flawed, smart, and compelling. As the first book begins, Jude is verging on adulthood in the world of Faerie where, unlike anyone else, she and her twin sister Taryn are human AND members of the High Court&#8211;their adoptive father Madoc is the the General to the High King and has raised them as though they were his daughters in truth. Jude and Taryn have lived in Faerie for just over ten years and are profoundly aware that being a human in Faerie is no easy thing. The fey see humans as less than and, for Jude and her sister, that&#8217;s meant a decade of danger and daily humiliations.</p>\n<p>Jude&#8211;an utter bad ass&#8211;dreams of becoming a knight so she will have her own&#8211;and not Madoc&#8217;s&#8211;power and will thus be accepted as a permanent member of the Court. Her sister Taryn seeks another path to inclusion: marriage to a fairy of the High Court. The paths the women pursue will, over the course of the series, put them at risk and at odds. Though they&#8217;ve been lived the same lives in many ways, they don&#8217;t see the fey the same nor do the wish to wield power in the same way. Taryn is curiously subtle, more interested in kisses than in politics. Jude is ambitious&#8211;in no small part due to watching Madoc scheme. Thus when the current High King announces his retirement and his heirs&#8211;only a child of old Mab&#8217;s blood may rule&#8211;strive for the throne, Jude sees an opportunity for herself to ally well. And therein begins a story of violence, politics, love, fear, and magic.</p>\n<p>That&#8217;s all I&#8217;ll say about the plot. I want you to have the joy of reading just as I did. #nospoilers</p>\n<p>This isn&#8217;t a romance &#8211; I am still rooting for an HEA by the end of the series &#8211; although there is Cardan, the youngest of all the High King&#8217;s sons, inhumanly beautiful and routinely, horribly cruel. His relationship with Jude is perplexing and deeply dangerous to Jude&#8230; and perhaps to himself. Cardan and Jude are determined to protect what they want for themselves and for the kingdom and the ways they do so are keenly informed by complicated, compromised ethics.</p>\n<p>The Faerie of <em>The Folk of Air</em>, as the fairies of the High Court are called, is traditional and not. It&#8217;s a world where Vivienne, Jude&#8217;s older half-fairy sister, is in love with a mortal girl, fairies have alliances with humans and fairies of either sex, and weeds can be made into flying steeds. There are no cell-phones or TVs or fish sticks or bras. The magic the fairies have gives them the ability to do almost anything and yet they cannot lie and simple wards can rob them of their power. Jude, human by nature and fairy by nurture, uses her knowledge of both and maneuvers her way to&#8230; well, that would be telling.</p>\n<p>I don&#8217;t think I&#8217;ve conveyed well enough the skill with which Black tells her tale. Readers looking for supple storytelling set in a singular world will be thrilled with <em>The Folk of Air</em>.  The third book in the series, <a href=\"https://amzn.to/2BBovgc\"><strong>The Queen of Nothing</strong></a>, comes out on November 19th and I will be reading it immediately. You should too.</p>\n<h3>Buy it at <a href=\"https://amzn.to/341Izoh\">Amazon</a>/<a href=\"https://books.apple.com/us/book/the-cruel-prince/id1225110611?mt=11&amp;app=itunes&amp;at=1010lmPQ\">Apple Books</a>/<a href=\"http://www.anrdoezrs.net/links/8039827/type/dlg/https://www.barnesandnoble.com/s/folk%20of%20the%20air%20series/_/N-8qa\">Barnes and Noble</a>/<a href=\"https://click.linksynergy.com/deeplink?id=b95pXvP*dp4&amp;mid=37217&amp;murl=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.kobo.com%2Fus%2Fen%2Faudiobook%2Fthe-cruel-prince-2\">Kobo</a></h3>\n",

                "html": "<p style=\"padding-left: 40px;\"><em>Emma London never thought she had anything in common with her grandmother Genevieve London. The regal old woman came from wealthy and bluest-blood New England stock, but that didn&#8217;t protect her from life&#8217;s cruelest blows: the disappearance of Genevieve&#8217;s young son, followed by the premature death of her husband. But Genevieve rose from those ashes of grief and built a fashion empire that was respected the world over, even when it meant neglecting her other son.</em></p>\n<p style=\"padding-left: 40px;\"><em>When Emma&#8217;s own mother died, her father abandoned her on his mother&#8217;s doorstep. Genevieve took Emma in and reluctantly raised her&#8211;until Emma got pregnant her senior year of high school. Genevieve kicked her out with nothing but the clothes on her back&#8230;but Emma took with her the most important London possession: the strength not just to survive but to thrive. And indeed, Emma has built a wonderful life for herself and her teenage daughter, Riley.</em></p>\n<p style=\"padding-left: 40px;\"><em>So what is Emma to do when Genevieve does the one thing Emma never expected of her and, after not speaking to her for nearly two decades, calls and asks for help?</em></p>\n<p>Kristen Donnelly, Shannon Dyer and Dabney Grinnan read Kristan Higgins&#8217; latest novel, <strong>Life and Other Inconveniences, </strong>and are here to share their thoughts about it.</p>\n<hr style=\"padding-left: 40px;\" />\n<p><strong>Dabney</strong>: This book broke my heart. In a good way.</p>\n<p><strong>Shannon</strong>: It broke mine too. Genevieve and Emma are damaged in very different ways, and the author did such a great job making me cheer them on, even when I didn’t like things they were doing.</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney</strong>: Yep. Higgins is wonderful at creating complex women whose flaws don&#8217;t make you cringe.</p>\n<p><strong>Shannon</strong>: Genevieve was hard for me to warm up to initially. She treated Emma horribly, and I couldn’t understand what would cause her to behave that way. Fortunately, learning a bit about her back story helped turn her into a relatable character. Did either of you have a similar experience with her?</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney</strong>: I couldn&#8217;t stand Genevieve for much of the book. BUT. I really enjoyed her as a character. This is one of Higgins&#8217; great skills&#8211;she can write characters whom you don&#8217;t like, aren&#8217;t rooting for, and still can&#8217;t wait to see what they do next.</p>\n<p><strong>Kristen</strong>: Oh, I never found her relatable, to be honest, but I could understand her by the end. If she wasn&#8217;t who she was, Emma wouldn&#8217;t be herself, after all and I did love Emma. While I have a great relationship with my mother, I have several friends who are more in the Genevieve and Emma camp and I could see so much of them in Emma.</p>\n<p><strong>Shannon</strong>: It’s funny that you say that, Kristen. My relationship with my own mother contains hints of these characters, and I’m wondering if having been raised by someone who reminds me a bit of Genevieve made her easier for me to relate to.</p>\n<p><strong>Kristen</strong>: Oh, fascinating!</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney</strong>: Ha. I think I&#8217;m far more Genevieve than my own mom who is the loveliest person I know.</p>\n<p><strong>Kristen</strong>: I have come to adore the way Higgins writes mothers and daughters like Emma and Riley, however, and so I want to talk about Riley for a minute. I was impressed with how she was able to separate her relationship with her grandmother from her mother&#8217;s relationship with Genevieve. Did you all feel the same?</p>\n<p><strong>Shannon</strong>: One of my favorite things about this author’s writing is her ability to bring complex family dynamics to life on the page. The relationship between Emma and Riley is the perfect example of this. It would have been so easy for Riley to view Genevieve the way Emma did, and I loved her for not doing that. She forged a unique relationship with her, one that didn’t hinge on anyone but the two of them.</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney</strong>: Absolutely. I come from a large close family and one of the rules&#8211;which, granted, is hard to follow&#8211;is that we all strive to have individual relationships with each other and not allow the dynamics of one relationship to overly influence another. Higgins does that in almost all her books&#8211;one character can have a vastly different relationship with a family member than someone else in the family does. Her sense of community doesn&#8217;t require that everyone see each other in the same way.</p>\n<p><strong>Kristen</strong>: Yeah, I come from a small family and we still struggle with triangulation, so I can imagine the more folks there are, the harder it is.</p>\n<p>I loved this thing from top to bottom, if I&#8217;m honest, and I just found the whole thing a world I could dive into and spend time in with glee. Was there anything that didn&#8217;t work for y&#8217;all?</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney</strong>: Well, there is one thing. Higgins&#8217; women&#8217;s fiction is less romantic and sexual than her romances. In this book this makes the primary romance less grounded than I&#8217;d have wished. I could have used more love scenes between Emma and Miller in part because I think it would have made that relationship even more believable. Plus I like sex scenes ;).</p>\n<p><strong>Shannon</strong>: There definitely wasn’t a lot of sex, but I didn’t mind that. I loved the focus on the female relationships, and the bit of romance woven into the story was kind of an added bonus.</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney</strong>: I can see that. I wish it had been more than a bit. I love her romances and the love story in this book left me wanting more of it. But, I&#8217;m also always up for powerful female relationships and this book offers those in spades.</p>\n<p><strong>Shannon</strong>: At its core, this book feels like a parenting story. We’re shown a wide array of parenting styles, some more palatable than others. Emma shines in this arena, while Genevieve kind of flounders, especially when it comes to her son Clarke. As the two of you read this, did it feel like a parent-centered story, or did you pick out another central theme?</p>\n<p><strong>Kristen</strong>: That&#8217;s an interesting question, Shannon. I think I saw it broader than that, like it&#8217;s more about family and connections that are both given and forged. Dabney, what do you think?</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney</strong>: It&#8217;s a story about how the relationship between parents, children, and grandchildren are profoundly interdependent and what it takes to created and keep family. Higgins shines at showing how the most important aspect of familying is love&#8211;and this book is really about that.</p>\n<p><strong>Shannon</strong>: I love how you put that, Dabney. In more ways than one, love is a trademark of Higgins&#8217; work. She pays homage to it in all its many forms, and I&#8217;m constantly in awe of the way she brings so many different kinds of love to life on the page.</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney</strong>: Yes. Whenever I read a Higgins book, I am reminded of how capacious the human heart is and how lucky we are that is so.</p>\n<p>As far as grades go, <strong>this was a B+ read</strong> for me. I enjoyed it and it left me being glad to be alive&#8211;no small feat in 2019. What about you two?</p>\n<p><strong>Shannon</strong>: I think I’m going to go just above you, Dabney, and <strong>give it an A-</strong>. It was pretty close to perfect, definitely something I’m happy to recommend to fans of Ms. Higgins’ previous books as well as to those who might be new to her writing.</p>\n<p><strong>Kristen</strong>: I<strong>t&#8217;s an A- for me too</strong>.</p>\n<h3>Buy it at <a href=\"https://amzn.to/2OjsaXy\">Amazon</a>/<a href=\"https://books.apple.com/us/book/life-and-other-inconveniences/id1441910195?mt=11&amp;app=itunes&amp;at=1010lmPQ\">Apple Books</a>/<a href=\"http://www.anrdoezrs.net/links/8039827/type/dlg/fragment/%2F/https://www.barnesandnoble.com/w/life-and-other-inconveniences-kristan-higgins/1129853074?ean=9780451489432\">Barnes and Noble</a>/<a href=\"https://click.linksynergy.com/deeplink?id=b95pXvP*dp4&amp;mid=37217&amp;murl=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.kobo.com%2Fus%2Fen%2Febook%2Flife-and-other-inconveniences\">Kobo</a></h3>\n",
                "text": "Emma London never thought she had anything in common with her grandmother Genevieve London. The regal old woman came from wealthy and bluest-blood New England stock, but that didn&#8217;t protect her from life&#8217;s cruelest blows: the disappearance of Genevieve&#8217;s young son, followed by the premature death of her husband. But Genevieve rose from those ashes of grief and built a fashion empire that was respected the world over, even when it meant neglecting her other son. When Emma&#8217;s own mother died, her father abandoned her on his mother&#8217;s doorstep. Genevieve took Emma in and reluctantly raised her&#8211;until Emma got pregnant her senior year of high school. Genevieve kicked her out with nothing but the clothes on her back&#8230;but Emma took with her the most important London possession: the strength not just to survive but to thrive. And indeed, Emma has built a wonderful life for herself and her teenage daughter, Riley. So what is Emma to do when Genevieve does the one thing Emma never expected of her and, after not speaking to her for nearly two decades, calls and asks for help? Kristen Donnelly, Shannon Dyer and Dabney Grinnan read Kristan Higgins&#8217; latest novel, Life and Other Inconveniences, and are here to share their thoughts about it. Dabney: This book broke my heart. In a good way. Shannon: It broke mine too. Genevieve and Emma are damaged in very different ways, and the author did such a great job making me cheer them on, even when I didn’t like things they were doing. Dabney: Yep. Higgins is wonderful at creating complex women whose flaws don&#8217;t make you cringe. Shannon: Genevieve was hard for me to warm up to initially. She treated Emma horribly, and I couldn’t understand what would cause her to behave that way. Fortunately, learning a bit about her back story helped turn her into a relatable character. Did either of you have a similar experience with her? Dabney: I couldn&#8217;t stand Genevieve for much of the book. BUT. I really enjoyed her as a character. This is one of Higgins&#8217; great skills&#8211;she can write characters whom you don&#8217;t like, aren&#8217;t rooting for, and still can&#8217;t wait to see what they do next. Kristen: Oh, I never found her relatable, to be honest, but I could understand her by the end. If she wasn&#8217;t who she was, Emma wouldn&#8217;t be herself, after all and I did love Emma. While I have a great relationship with my mother, I have several friends who are more in the Genevieve and Emma camp and I could see so much of them in Emma. Shannon: It’s funny that you say that, Kristen. My relationship with my own mother contains hints of these characters, and I’m wondering if having been raised by someone who reminds me a bit of Genevieve made her easier for me to relate to. Kristen: Oh, fascinating! Dabney: Ha. I think I&#8217;m far more Genevieve than my own mom who is the loveliest person I know. Kristen: I have come to adore the way Higgins writes mothers and daughters like Emma and Riley, however, and so I want to talk about Riley for a minute. I was impressed with how she was able to separate her relationship with her grandmother from her mother&#8217;s relationship with Genevieve. Did you all feel the same? Shannon: One of my favorite things about this author’s writing is her ability to bring complex family dynamics to life on the page. The relationship between Emma and Riley is the perfect example of this. It would have been so easy for Riley to view Genevieve the way Emma did, and I loved her for not doing that. She forged a unique relationship with her, one that didn’t hinge on anyone but the two of them. Dabney: Absolutely. I come from a large close family and one of the rules&#8211;which, granted, is hard to follow&#8211;is that we all strive to have individual relationships with each other and not allow the dynamics of one relationship to overly influence another. Higgins does that in almost all her books&#8211;one character can have a vastly different relationship with a family member than someone else in the family does. Her sense of community doesn&#8217;t require that everyone see each other in the same way. Kristen: Yeah, I come from a small family and we still struggle with triangulation, so I can imagine the more folks there are, the harder it is. I loved this thing from top to bottom, if I&#8217;m honest, and I just found the whole thing a world I could dive into and spend time in with glee. Was there anything that didn&#8217;t work for y&#8217;all? Dabney: Well, there is one thing. Higgins&#8217; women&#8217;s fiction is less romantic and sexual than her romances. In this book this makes the primary romance less grounded than I&#8217;d have wished. I could have used more love scenes between Emma and Miller in part because I think it would have made that relationship even more believable. Plus I like sex scenes ;). Shannon: There definitely wasn’t a lot of sex, but I didn’t mind that. I loved the focus on the female relationships, and the bit of romance woven into the story was kind of an added bonus. Dabney: I can see that. I wish it had been more than a bit. I love her romances and the love story in this book left me wanting more of it. But, I&#8217;m also always up for powerful female relationships and this book offers those in spades. Shannon: At its core, this book feels like a parenting story. We’re shown a wide array of parenting styles, some more palatable than others. Emma shines in this arena, while Genevieve kind of flounders, especially when it comes to her son Clarke. As the two of you read this, did it feel like a parent-centered story, or did you pick out another central theme? Kristen: That&#8217;s an interesting question, Shannon. I think I saw it broader than that, like it&#8217;s more about family and connections that are both given and forged. Dabney, what do you think? Dabney: It&#8217;s a story about how the relationship between parents, children, and grandchildren are profoundly interdependent and what it takes to created and keep family. Higgins shines at showing how the most important aspect of familying is love&#8211;and this book is really about that. Shannon: I love how you put that, Dabney. In more ways than one, love is a trademark of Higgins&#8217; work. She pays homage to it in all its many forms, and I&#8217;m constantly in awe of the way she brings so many different kinds of love to life on the page. Dabney: Yes. Whenever I read a Higgins book, I am reminded of how capacious the human heart is and how lucky we are that is so. As far as grades go, this was a B+ read for me. I enjoyed it and it left me being glad to be alive&#8211;no small feat in 2019. What about you two? Shannon: I think I’m going to go just above you, Dabney, and give it an A-. It was pretty close to perfect, definitely something I’m happy to recommend to fans of Ms. Higgins’ previous books as well as to those who might be new to her writing. Kristen: It&#8217;s an A- for me too. Buy it at Amazon/Apple Books/Barnes and Noble/Kobo"

                "html": "<p><img loading=\"lazy\" decoding=\"async\" style=\"border: none !important; margin: 0px !important;\" src=\"https://ir-na.amazon-adsystem.com/e/ir?t=wilck-20&amp;language=en_US&amp;l=li3&amp;o=1&amp;a=B07J4WHC78\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" border=\"0\" /><i><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Cassie Hanwell was born for emergencies. As one of the only female firefighters in her Texas firehouse, she&#8217;s seen her fair share of them, and she&#8217;s excellent at dealing with other people&#8217;s tragedies. But when her estranged and ailing mother asks her to uproot her life and move to Boston, it&#8217;s an emergency of a kind Cassie never anticipated.</span></i></p>\n<p><i><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">The tough, old-school Boston firehouse is as different from Cassie&#8217;s old job as it could possibly be. Hazing, a lack of funding, and poor facilities mean that the firemen aren&#8217;t exactly thrilled to have a &#8220;lady&#8221; on the crew, even one as competent and smart as Cassie. Except for the handsome rookie, who doesn&#8217;t seem to mind having Cassie around. But she can&#8217;t think about that. Because she doesn&#8217;t fall in love. And because of the advice her old captain gave her: don&#8217;t date firefighters. Cassie can feel her resolve slipping&#8230;but will she jeopardize her place in a career where she&#8217;s worked so hard to be taken seriously?</span></i></p>\n<hr />\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><strong>Kristen</strong>: Dabney, I didn’t really know what to expect going into this book, besides there was some serious buzz about it. I’ve never read anything by Ms. Center before, but I’m always game for a story of “woman in a man’s world” and Kate Meader and Shannon Stacey have certainly helped me fall for firehouse stories! All that said, I was not quite prepared for the gravity of this book. </span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><strong>Dabney</strong>: Maybe it’s a trend. I just read a contemporary romance that was so gravely dark I could barely get through it. This book, even with its serious issues, I was able to read without recoiling from the prose. </span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">I’m going to assume that there were several threads in this book you found grave. Is that right?</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><strong>Kristen</strong>: Great assumption. “Grave” might be a little… I think what I found was a lot of real. The story felt like it could leap off the page at any moment because these things all happen. Grave implies to me that there’s a bit of gothic darkness for the sake of it and that’s not the feeling I got here. Instead, it’s a story about the life that happens when you’re making other plans. </span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">What did you think of this one, overall? </span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><strong>Dabney</strong>: I very much enjoyed it. I love&#8211;love!&#8211;how the characters are all grounded in reality. I especially love that the flawed men, Cassie’s co-workers, are sexist, upon occasion loutish, and routinely stellar human beings. I am not a fan of man-bashing or one note characterizations and there is little of that here.</span><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><br />\n</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">I also was thrilled to see the characters solving their problems with real world solutions. The love stories here&#8211;and there are many encompassing the panoply of love&#8211;are built by people taking small steps, stopping and listening, really listening, to those around them, and by asking, awkwardly and often poorly, for help.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><strong>Kristen</strong>: Hear, hear! I co-sign all of that. When we got the initial description of her new chief, I got nervous. I am exhausted by one dimensional misogynists in fiction and was so grateful to see how Ms. Center crafted the dudes of the firehouse. They are sexist, and ageist, and all sorts of other things that people frequently are, but they are also humans. There are pieces of them that are open to change &#8211; which we see evidence of &#8211; and others that are calcified. Even when a line of dialogue rankled me, I knew it was because that man would say that and not because he was a plot device being used to make a point. </span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">I also adored &#8211; wait, let me emphasize that more &#8211; ADORED Cassie’s interior journey. The growth that she opens herself up to, the meditations on forgiveness, how she handles conflict throughout the story… man, I want to take her out for dinner and give her a big hug. </span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><strong>Dabney</strong>: Honestly, the true love story in this is that between Cassie and her mom. I can not tell you how much this story moved me. Just thinking about it now makes my heart squeeze. Everything about that relationship is so lovely and powerful. And again, Cassie, her mom (and her dad) all made huge mistakes in the past, moves that pushed them apart and deeply hurt them. The way those relationships are portrayed and how those wounds are healed is utterly and beautifully believable. </span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><strong>Kristen</strong>: I wondered if your mother heart would just explode over that, because my daughter one did. My mother is also a reader, so as soon as I finished this I pre-ordered it for her because I want to talk to her about it! </span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">So, for me, <strong>this is an A</strong>. I recommend it unabashedly for anyone who loves fiction, who believes humans have the capacity to change, and who could use some time in someone else’s life. It’ll be a strong contender for my top ten list for sure. </span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><strong>Dabney</strong>: We haven’t talked about it much but I assure romance readers that the romance in this is a good one. Cassie and “the rookie” are a fab couple&#8211;they are believable as firefighters, friends, lovers, and co-workers. I don’t want to say too much about the path they forge but it’s a good one full of heat and humor. Which reminds me, this book is funny in all the best ways.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><strong>This is an A for me too</strong>. Readers who love Kristan Higgins-esque fiction will love this as will, I bet, readers everywhere.</span></p>\n<h3>Buy it at <a href=\"https://amzn.to/2WYpwZ8\">Amazon</a>/<a href=\"https://books.apple.com/us/book/things-you-save-in-a-fire/id1438429876?mt=11&amp;app=itunes&amp;at=1010lmPQ\">Apple Books</a>/<a href=\"http://www.anrdoezrs.net/links/8039827/type/dlg/fragment/%2F/https://www.barnesandnoble.com/w/things-you-save-in-a-fire-katherine-center/1129285265?ean=9781466847712\">Barnes and Noble</a>/<a href=\"https://click.linksynergy.com/deeplink?id=b95pXvP*dp4&amp;mid=37217&amp;murl=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.kobo.com%2Fus%2Fen%2Febook%2Fthings-you-save-in-a-fire\">Kobo</a></h3>\n",
                "text": "Cassie Hanwell was born for emergencies. As one of the only female firefighters in her Texas firehouse, she&#8217;s seen her fair share of them, and she&#8217;s excellent at dealing with other people&#8217;s tragedies. But when her estranged and ailing mother asks her to uproot her life and move to Boston, it&#8217;s an emergency of a kind Cassie never anticipated. The tough, old-school Boston firehouse is as different from Cassie&#8217;s old job as it could possibly be. Hazing, a lack of funding, and poor facilities mean that the firemen aren&#8217;t exactly thrilled to have a &#8220;lady&#8221; on the crew, even one as competent and smart as Cassie. Except for the handsome rookie, who doesn&#8217;t seem to mind having Cassie around. But she can&#8217;t think about that. Because she doesn&#8217;t fall in love. And because of the advice her old captain gave her: don&#8217;t date firefighters. Cassie can feel her resolve slipping&#8230;but will she jeopardize her place in a career where she&#8217;s worked so hard to be taken seriously? Kristen: Dabney, I didn’t really know what to expect going into this book, besides there was some serious buzz about it. I’ve never read anything by Ms. Center before, but I’m always game for a story of “woman in a man’s world” and Kate Meader and Shannon Stacey have certainly helped me fall for firehouse stories! All that said, I was not quite prepared for the gravity of this book. Dabney: Maybe it’s a trend. I just read a contemporary romance that was so gravely dark I could barely get through it. This book, even with its serious issues, I was able to read without recoiling from the prose. I’m going to assume that there were several threads in this book you found grave. Is that right? Kristen: Great assumption. “Grave” might be a little… I think what I found was a lot of real. The story felt like it could leap off the page at any moment because these things all happen. Grave implies to me that there’s a bit of gothic darkness for the sake of it and that’s not the feeling I got here. Instead, it’s a story about the life that happens when you’re making other plans. What did you think of this one, overall? Dabney: I very much enjoyed it. I love&#8211;love!&#8211;how the characters are all grounded in reality. I especially love that the flawed men, Cassie’s co-workers, are sexist, upon occasion loutish, and routinely stellar human beings. I am not a fan of man-bashing or one note characterizations and there is little of that here. I also was thrilled to see the characters solving their problems with real world solutions. The love stories here&#8211;and there are many encompassing the panoply of love&#8211;are built by people taking small steps, stopping and listening, really listening, to those around them, and by asking, awkwardly and often poorly, for help. Kristen: Hear, hear! I co-sign all of that. When we got the initial description of her new chief, I got nervous. I am exhausted by one dimensional misogynists in fiction and was so grateful to see how Ms. Center crafted the dudes of the firehouse. They are sexist, and ageist, and all sorts of other things that people frequently are, but they are also humans. There are pieces of them that are open to change &#8211; which we see evidence of &#8211; and others that are calcified. Even when a line of dialogue rankled me, I knew it was because that man would say that and not because he was a plot device being used to make a point. I also adored &#8211; wait, let me emphasize that more &#8211; ADORED Cassie’s interior journey. The growth that she opens herself up to, the meditations on forgiveness, how she handles conflict throughout the story… man, I want to take her out for dinner and give her a big hug. Dabney: Honestly, the true love story in this is that between Cassie and her mom. I can not tell you how much this story moved me. Just thinking about it now makes my heart squeeze. Everything about that relationship is so lovely and powerful. And again, Cassie, her mom (and her dad) all made huge mistakes in the past, moves that pushed them apart and deeply hurt them. The way those relationships are portrayed and how those wounds are healed is utterly and beautifully believable. Kristen: I wondered if your mother heart would just explode over that, because my daughter one did. My mother is also a reader, so as soon as I finished this I pre-ordered it for her because I want to talk to her about it! So, for me, this is an A. I recommend it unabashedly for anyone who loves fiction, who believes humans have the capacity to change, and who could use some time in someone else’s life. It’ll be a strong contender for my top ten list for sure. Dabney: We haven’t talked about it much but I assure romance readers that the romance in this is a good one. Cassie and “the rookie” are a fab couple&#8211;they are believable as firefighters, friends, lovers, and co-workers. I don’t want to say too much about the path they forge but it’s a good one full of heat and humor. Which reminds me, this book is funny in all the best ways. This is an A for me too. Readers who love Kristan Higgins-esque fiction will love this as will, I bet, readers everywhere. Buy it at Amazon/Apple Books/Barnes and Noble/Kobo"
            }

                "html": "<p><em>Although beautiful young widow Phoebe, Lady Clare, has never met West Ravenel, she knows one thing for certain: he&#8217;s a mean, rotten bully. Back in boarding school, he made her late husband&#8217;s life a misery, and she&#8217;ll never forgive him for it. But when Phoebe attends a family wedding, she encounters a dashing and impossibly charming stranger who sends a fire-and-ice jolt of attraction through her. And then he introduces himself&#8230;as none other than West Ravenel.</em></p>\n<p><em>West is a man with a tarnished past. No apologies, no excuses. However, from the moment he meets Phoebe, West is consumed by irresistible desire&#8230;not to mention the bitter awareness that a woman like her is far out of his reach. What West doesn&#8217;t bargain on is that Phoebe is no straitlaced aristocratic lady. She&#8217;s the daughter of a strong-willed wallflower who long ago eloped with Sebastian, Lord St. Vincent—the most devilishly wicked rake in England.</em></p>\n<p><em>Before long, Phoebe sets out to seduce the man who has awakened her fiery nature and shown her unimaginable pleasure. Will their overwhelming passion be enough to overcome the obstacles of the past?</em></p>\n<p><em>Only the devil&#8217;s daughter knows&#8230;</em></p>\n<hr />\n<p><strong>Dabney</strong>: The latest book by Kleypas is populated by characters from many of her prior historical romances. The heroine, Phoebe is Sebastian&#8217;s (<a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/book-review/devil-in-winter-by-lisa-kleypas/\"><strong>A Devil in Winter)</strong></a> daughter and the hero, Wes, is a Ravenel. So, ladies, what did you think?</p>\n<p><strong>Kristen</strong>: This book really worked for me. When I read that Phoebe was a widow with two small children I was concerned that the kids would be treacly plot devices, but instead I found the way Phoebe&#8217;s identity as &#8220;mother&#8221; grounded her to be really well executed. Now, I say that as not-a-mom, so maybe it&#8217;s more an outside-looking-in thing, but I could see why she was the way she was and the decisions she was making based on the legacy of her boys. But before I get into too much of that, Em! You mentioned offline that you loved West and I&#8217;d love to hear why he specifically worked for you.</p>\n<p><strong>Em</strong>: I also loved it. But I feel like I should confess something first. I know AAR readers love the <a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/review-tag/the-wallflowers-series/\"><em>Wallflowers</em> series</a>, and <strong>Devil in Winter</strong> particularly. I barely remember it! I love Kleypas so I probably liked it&#8230;but really, it doesn’t stand out in my memory (and actually, I liked <a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/book-review/it-happened-one-autumn-by-lisa-kleypas/\"><strong>It Happened One Autumn</strong></a> best!), and consequently, I haven’t read the newer <a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/review-tag/the-ravenels-series/\"><em>Ravenels</em> series</a> with quite the same sense of nostalgia and fondness and expectations many of our readers/reviewers have. Perhaps that’s why I’ve enjoyed each and every one of them more than the last.</p>\n<p>Although there is a villain in this story &#8211; and a saintly dead husband, there’s very little angst. And I liked that! These two meet and it’s on. Phoebe is a widow still in love with her husband, but stoic in her sadness&#8230;And she’s a wonderful mom who cares about and adores her children. She’s self aware and keeps her emotions closely in check &#8211; except when she’s with her large family. Then we get to see her fun side&#8230;and it’s lovely. West is the best kind of reformed rake &#8211; he’s knows he was an asshole but he’s finally got his shit together and he’s finally allowing that side of himself to run the show. Their chemistry together is wonderful and every time they’re on the page together I caught myself smiling and rooting for them. I loved that the obstacles to their relationship are manageable and fixable, and that the villain of the piece doesn’t overwhelm the story or their path to happily ever after. Sigh. I loved it and them.</p>\n<p>West is my favorite kind of hero. He’s well on the path to redemption but falling in love proves to be the hardest hurdle to jump. Phoebe already has her act together &#8211; she could have anyone, but wants West. And that scares him! I love that he can’t resist her, delights in shocking her, and that his quiet goodness is clear to everyone around him. Phoebe is the peace of the puzzle he’s missing &#8211; and he knows it. I thought he was an awesome match for her and vice versa.</p>\n<p>Dabney, did you like this story? We haven’t heard from you?!</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney</strong>: *winces* I did not. I didn’t hate it but it just didn’t do much for me. Perhaps my biggest complaint is that it really wasn’t clear to me why Phoebe and West fell for each other so quickly. The majority of the novel takes place over just a few days and, while I’m not averse to insta-lust stories, insta-love stories don’t work for me unless an author has clearly shown why these two people have so suddenly recharted their lives and hearts. I didn’t get that here.</p>\n<p><strong>Kristen</strong>: Hm, that’s fascinating, but I can completely see that. For me, the pivotal bit was that there was a three month gap between some of the action and one can do a lot of inner work in three months. If the feelings were lust before that gap, I can see how that gap solidified this recharting. However, if that’s not something you believe, that gap is gonna do nothing.</p>\n<p><strong>Em</strong>: I decided early on that I hated Phoebe’s dead husband &#8211; and that made me dislike her too! But she absolutely grew on me (and I made peace with her first marriage), and I loved her decision to claim West and to enjoy him while she had him. Friends: The shaving scene is particularly excellent. What did you all think of her?</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney</strong>: I will confess, at the beginning of the book, I couldn’t understand Phoebe at all. She’s the product of one of the greatest love stories in all of Romancelandia (<strong>The Devil in Winter</strong>) and yet she married someone who was, it seemed, her best friend. It’s as if Aretha Franklin and Al Green had a child who thought singing was OK. So, that threw me off. Once I, sorta, got over that, I thought she was OK. I liked how she thought about her kids and I liked that she worked her way to letting herself enjoy West. But she never really gelled for me. When I finished the book, I couldn’t remember much about her at all.</p>\n<p><strong>Kristen</strong>: So I loved her beginning to end. I have a lot of time for characters who do “the right thing” out of love, rather than engaging with love themselves and that’s what I think Phoebe did. I can see how her parents’ love story was so spectacular, so singular that her brain rejected it as a possibility for her. Why shoot for the once-in-a-generation story when she could be just fine with someone who loved her? Why take that risk?</p>\n<p>That’s actually why I think I love her and Wes so much. He was a huge risk for her and once she took it, she unearthed a part of herself she had ignored. Perhaps I’m projecting too much on her, but that’s exactly how I read her.</p>\n<p><strong>Em</strong>: Re: the villain of this story. The ending felt tacked on to me and the whole situation in the club almost ruined the story (although I liked the aftermath). I had a hard time believing that Phoebe or her husband would have trusted this moron with the estate &#8211; let alone promised he would one day be master of all&#8230;That storyline felt underdeveloped and slightly ridiculous &#8211; even Phoebe knew he was trash even before all was revealed. I wish Ms. Kleypas had spent a bit more with Phoebe before she traveled to the wedding; her day to day on the estate without Henry was unclear before and after she meets West. What did you think of our villain? And Henry for that matter?</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney</strong>: Neither man had much to recommend himself. And that fact made Phoebe less too. In a way, this is a “magical wang/man” story&#8211;it takes West to make Phoebe realize how to live in the world as she needs to. That’s not one of my favorite things.</p>\n<p><strong>Em</strong>: I felt like they saved each other! She needed a man like West &#8211; he’s sorted his rakish/irresponsible/reprehensible ways and settled into the man he wants to be &#8211; and that combination (playful and naughty/responsible and kind) unlocks her adventurous/wild and slightly wicked side. But he&#8217;s also &#8211; much to my delight &#8211; attracted to her mind and intelligence and her love for her boys and Henry. West needed a woman to consolidate all the redemptive qualities he’s worked on over the past few years, and Phoebe is the perfect woman for him. I thought they were very much equal to each other and their partnership was the key to unlocking the person they’re each meant to be.</p>\n<p>The villain, Edward, was just meh and so was the totally unnecessary mother-in-law. I didn’t care about either of these troublemakers, although I wish the penultimate scene wherein the villain, West and Sebastian face off together was more exciting and drawn out. It was seriously underwhelming.</p>\n<p><strong>Kristen</strong>: Em, I’m with you on the saving each other. We were supposed to think the conflict that was between them was external, but I read it as much more internal. Because, yeah, the external barrier to the HEA was weaksauce.</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney</strong>: Kleypas took a lot of heat&#8211;which she responded to by revising her book&#8211;over cultural appropriation in her last book, <a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/book-review/hello-stranger-by-lisa-kleypas/\"><strong>Hello, Stranger</strong></a>. This book hasn’t a whiff of controversy to it. But what it does have is a serious celebration of how masculine/virile/manly West is, especially in comparison to Phoebe’s dead husband and to her estate manager and suitor Edward. And I’m normally all over alpha heroes but, here, it felt almost heavy handed. I guess I wanted to have my cake and eat it too: I wanted Phoebe to save herself and have her end up with a man who could sweep her off her feet.</p>\n<p><strong>Kristen</strong>: Right, that makes sense. I had figured that since Phoebe’s dad was Sebastian, her suitor would have to be physically daunting to match the mental daunting that Sebastian provides to get her attention, so I was kind of prepared for that. I also didn’t think that West read as a alpha beyond his body so it worked for me.</p>\n<p>I read this week that no two people read the same book, and that is totally the case here because I think she did save herself and get swept off her feet!</p>\n<p><strong>Em</strong>: Same! I also did not read West as an alpha at all. Different strokes for different folks and all that.</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney</strong>: You guys are right&#8211;West isn&#8217;t really an alpha in behavior (much). It&#8217;s more the way he&#8217;s repeatedly described.</p>\n<p>My favorite person and the one who stole every scene he is in is Sebastian, Phoebe’s famed father. Did you guys feel that way too?</p>\n<p><strong>Em</strong>: This is where I think my ambivalence about the first series manifests itself most. I did think he stole his scenes (and I loved the bath scene with Evie). But don’t you think he’s a bit too pretty perfect? Perfect duke, dad, husband, guest, wise sage, savior, grandpa? In this case, I can swallow the insta-lust a lot easier than the perfection. He’s great &#8211; I get it. No one else gets to be a superman?</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney</strong>: He’s Sebastian&#8211;he’s so indelible that I can’t see him any other way. He was such a scoundrel when young. I think Kleypas wrote him to be consistent with who he’s been historically. But if your dad is hotter than your suitor, it’s a problem.</p>\n<p><strong>Kristen</strong>: Another case where we all get to experience art the way we want, I can’t quite understand how Sebastian didn’t imprint himself on your reading soul, Em! His assholery was all confined to previous books and I’m okay with his superman status now, tbh. I was delighted by every single appearance of the infamous St. Vincent and it made me miss Evie and the rest of the Wallflowers something fierce.</p>\n<p>This book just flat out worked for me in some ways I can’t quite put my finger on. My mother and I are both huge fans of Ms. Kleypas and I have already giddily informed her that she’ll love this installment too.</p>\n<p>Ladies, are we comfortable landing at a B+ for a communal grade? Any final thoughts?</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney</strong>: I can live with that. Maybe I was just cranky. It&#8217;s rare I see a book so differently than you two do. I’ve gotten so much joy from Kleypas’ writing over the years and if you guys think this one works, I want our readers to check it out!</p>\n<p><strong>Em</strong>: Yes on the B+! I think Kleypas fans will be well pleased with this duo, and eager for more!</p>\n<h3 data-fontsize=\"17\" data-lineheight=\"23\"><strong>Buy it at: <a href=\"https://amzn.to/2MexWGQ\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Amazon</a>/<a href=\"https://geo.itunes.apple.com/us/book/devils-daughter/id1344937359?mt=11&amp;at=1010lmPQ\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Apple Books</a>/<a href=\"http://www.anrdoezrs.net/links/8039827/type/dlg/fragment/%2F/https://www.barnesandnoble.com/w/devils-daughter-lisa-kleypas/1129241246?ean=9780062371928\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Barnes &amp; Noble</a>/<a href=\"https://click.linksynergy.com/link?id=b95pXvP*dp4&amp;offerid=635768.515919780062908858&amp;type=2&amp;murl=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.kobo.com%2Fus%2Fen%2Faudiobook%2Fdevil-s-daughter-10\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Kobo</a></strong></h3>\n",
                "text": "Although beautiful young widow Phoebe, Lady Clare, has never met West Ravenel, she knows one thing for certain: he&#8217;s a mean, rotten bully. Back in boarding school, he made her late husband&#8217;s life a misery, and she&#8217;ll never forgive him for it. But when Phoebe attends a family wedding, she encounters a dashing and impossibly charming stranger who sends a fire-and-ice jolt of attraction through her. And then he introduces himself&#8230;as none other than West Ravenel. West is a man with a tarnished past. No apologies, no excuses. However, from the moment he meets Phoebe, West is consumed by irresistible desire&#8230;not to mention the bitter awareness that a woman like her is far out of his reach. What West doesn&#8217;t bargain on is that Phoebe is no straitlaced aristocratic lady. She&#8217;s the daughter of a strong-willed wallflower who long ago eloped with Sebastian, Lord St. Vincent—the most devilishly wicked rake in England. Before long, Phoebe sets out to seduce the man who has awakened her fiery nature and shown her unimaginable pleasure. Will their overwhelming passion be enough to overcome the obstacles of the past? Only the devil&#8217;s daughter knows&#8230; Dabney: The latest book by Kleypas is populated by characters from many of her prior historical romances. The heroine, Phoebe is Sebastian&#8217;s (A Devil in Winter) daughter and the hero, Wes, is a Ravenel. So, ladies, what did you think? Kristen: This book really worked for me. When I read that Phoebe was a widow with two small children I was concerned that the kids would be treacly plot devices, but instead I found the way Phoebe&#8217;s identity as &#8220;mother&#8221; grounded her to be really well executed. Now, I say that as not-a-mom, so maybe it&#8217;s more an outside-looking-in thing, but I could see why she was the way she was and the decisions she was making based on the legacy of her boys. But before I get into too much of that, Em! You mentioned offline that you loved West and I&#8217;d love to hear why he specifically worked for you. Em: I also loved it. But I feel like I should confess something first. I know AAR readers love the Wallflowers series, and Devil in Winter particularly. I barely remember it! I love Kleypas so I probably liked it&#8230;but really, it doesn’t stand out in my memory (and actually, I liked It Happened One Autumn best!), and consequently, I haven’t read the newer Ravenels series with quite the same sense of nostalgia and fondness and expectations many of our readers/reviewers have. Perhaps that’s why I’ve enjoyed each and every one of them more than the last. Although there is a villain in this story &#8211; and a saintly dead husband, there’s very little angst. And I liked that! These two meet and it’s on. Phoebe is a widow still in love with her husband, but stoic in her sadness&#8230;And she’s a wonderful mom who cares about and adores her children. She’s self aware and keeps her emotions closely in check &#8211; except when she’s with her large family. Then we get to see her fun side&#8230;and it’s lovely. West is the best kind of reformed rake &#8211; he’s knows he was an asshole but he’s finally got his shit together and he’s finally allowing that side of himself to run the show. Their chemistry together is wonderful and every time they’re on the page together I caught myself smiling and rooting for them. I loved that the obstacles to their relationship are manageable and fixable, and that the villain of the piece doesn’t overwhelm the story or their path to happily ever after. Sigh. I loved it and them. West is my favorite kind of hero. He’s well on the path to redemption but falling in love proves to be the hardest hurdle to jump. Phoebe already has her act together &#8211; she could have anyone, but wants West. And that scares him! I love that he can’t resist her, delights in shocking her, and that his quiet goodness is clear to everyone around him. Phoebe is the peace of the puzzle he’s missing &#8211; and he knows it. I thought he was an awesome match for her and vice versa. Dabney, did you like this story? We haven’t heard from you?! Dabney: *winces* I did not. I didn’t hate it but it just didn’t do much for me. Perhaps my biggest complaint is that it really wasn’t clear to me why Phoebe and West fell for each other so quickly. The majority of the novel takes place over just a few days and, while I’m not averse to insta-lust stories, insta-love stories don’t work for me unless an author has clearly shown why these two people have so suddenly recharted their lives and hearts. I didn’t get that here. Kristen: Hm, that’s fascinating, but I can completely see that. For me, the pivotal bit was that there was a three month gap between some of the action and one can do a lot of inner work in three months. If the feelings were lust before that gap, I can see how that gap solidified this recharting. However, if that’s not something you believe, that gap is gonna do nothing. Em: I decided early on that I hated Phoebe’s dead husband &#8211; and that made me dislike her too! But she absolutely grew on me (and I made peace with her first marriage), and I loved her decision to claim West and to enjoy him while she had him. Friends: The shaving scene is particularly excellent. What did you all think of her? Dabney: I will confess, at the beginning of the book, I couldn’t understand Phoebe at all. She’s the product of one of the greatest love stories in all of Romancelandia (The Devil in Winter) and yet she married someone who was, it seemed, her best friend. It’s as if Aretha Franklin and Al Green had a child who thought singing was OK. So, that threw me off. Once I, sorta, got over that, I thought she was OK. I liked how she thought about her kids and I liked that she worked her way to letting herself enjoy West. But she never really gelled for me. When I finished the book, I couldn’t remember much about her at all. Kristen: So I loved her beginning to end. I have a lot of time for characters who do “the right thing” out of love, rather than engaging with love themselves and that’s what I think Phoebe did. I can see how her parents’ love story was so spectacular, so singular that her brain rejected it as a possibility for her. Why shoot for the once-in-a-generation story when she could be just fine with someone who loved her? Why take that risk? That’s actually why I think I love her and Wes so much. He was a huge risk for her and once she took it, she unearthed a part of herself she had ignored. Perhaps I’m projecting too much on her, but that’s exactly how I read her. Em: Re: the villain of this story. The ending felt tacked on to me and the whole situation in the club almost ruined the story (although I liked the aftermath). I had a hard time believing that Phoebe or her husband would have trusted this moron with the estate &#8211; let alone promised he would one day be master of all&#8230;That storyline felt underdeveloped and slightly ridiculous &#8211; even Phoebe knew he was trash even before all was revealed. I wish Ms. Kleypas had spent a bit more with Phoebe before she traveled to the wedding; her day to day on the estate without Henry was unclear before and after she meets West. What did you think of our villain? And Henry for that matter? Dabney: Neither man had much to recommend himself. And that fact made Phoebe less too. In a way, this is a “magical wang/man” story&#8211;it takes West to make Phoebe realize how to live in the world as she needs to. That’s not one of my favorite things. Em: I felt like they saved each other! She needed a man like West &#8211; he’s sorted his rakish/irresponsible/reprehensible ways and settled into the man he wants to be &#8211; and that combination (playful and naughty/responsible and kind) unlocks her adventurous/wild and slightly wicked side. But he&#8217;s also &#8211; much to my delight &#8211; attracted to her mind and intelligence and her love for her boys and Henry. West needed a woman to consolidate all the redemptive qualities he’s worked on over the past few years, and Phoebe is the perfect woman for him. I thought they were very much equal to each other and their partnership was the key to unlocking the person they’re each meant to be. The villain, Edward, was just meh and so was the totally unnecessary mother-in-law. I didn’t care about either of these troublemakers, although I wish the penultimate scene wherein the villain, West and Sebastian face off together was more exciting and drawn out. It was seriously underwhelming. Kristen: Em, I’m with you on the saving each other. We were supposed to think the conflict that was between them was external, but I read it as much more internal. Because, yeah, the external barrier to the HEA was weaksauce. Dabney: Kleypas took a lot of heat&#8211;which she responded to by revising her book&#8211;over cultural appropriation in her last book, Hello, Stranger. This book hasn’t a whiff of controversy to it. But what it does have is a serious celebration of how masculine/virile/manly West is, especially in comparison to Phoebe’s dead husband and to her estate manager and suitor Edward. And I’m normally all over alpha heroes but, here, it felt almost heavy handed. I guess I wanted to have my cake and eat it too: I wanted Phoebe to save herself and have her end up with a man who could sweep her off her feet. Kristen: Right, that makes sense. I had figured that since Phoebe’s dad was Sebastian, her suitor would have to be physically daunting to match the mental daunting that Sebastian provides to get her attention, so I was kind of prepared for that. I also didn’t think that West read as a alpha beyond his body so it worked for me. I read this week that no two people read the same book, and that is totally the case here because I think she did save herself and get swept off her feet! Em: Same! I also did not read West as an alpha at all. Different strokes for different folks and all that. Dabney: You guys are right&#8211;West isn&#8217;t really an alpha in behavior (much). It&#8217;s more the way he&#8217;s repeatedly described. My favorite person and the one who stole every scene he is in is Sebastian, Phoebe’s famed father. Did you guys feel that way too? Em: This is where I think my ambivalence about the first series manifests itself most. I did think he stole his scenes (and I loved the bath scene with Evie). But don’t you think he’s a bit too pretty perfect? Perfect duke, dad, husband, guest, wise sage, savior, grandpa? In this case, I can swallow the insta-lust a lot easier than the perfection. He’s great &#8211; I get it. No one else gets to be a superman? Dabney: He’s Sebastian&#8211;he’s so indelible that I can’t see him any other way. He was such a scoundrel when young. I think Kleypas wrote him to be consistent with who he’s been historically. But if your dad is hotter than your suitor, it’s a problem. Kristen: Another case where we all get to experience art the way we want, I can’t quite understand how Sebastian didn’t imprint himself on your reading soul, Em! His assholery was all confined to previous books and I’m okay with his superman status now, tbh. I was delighted by every single appearance of the infamous St. Vincent and it made me miss Evie and the rest of the Wallflowers something fierce. This book just flat out worked for me in some ways I can’t quite put my finger on. My mother and I are both huge fans of Ms. Kleypas and I have already giddily informed her that she’ll love this installment too. Ladies, are we comfortable landing at a B+ for a communal grade? Any final thoughts? Dabney: I can live with that. Maybe I was just cranky. It&#8217;s rare I see a book so differently than you two do. I’ve gotten so much joy from Kleypas’ writing over the years and if you guys think this one works, I want our readers to check it out! Em: Yes on the B+! I think Kleypas fans will be well pleased with this duo, and eager for more! Buy it at: Amazon/Apple Books/Barnes &amp; Noble/Kobo"
            }
