                "html": "<p><a href=\"https://amzn.to/2G3ajzS\">Darcy Barrett has undertaken a global survey of men. She’s travelled the world, and can categorically say that no one measures up to Tom Valeska, whose only flaw is that Darcy’s twin brother Jamie saw him first and claimed him forever as his best friend. Despite Darcy’s best efforts, Tom’s off limits and loyal to her brother, 99%. That’s the problem with finding her dream man at age eight and peaking in her photography career at age twenty—ever since, she’s had to learn to settle for good enough.</a></p>\n<p><a href=\"https://amzn.to/2G3ajzS\">When Darcy and Jamie inherit a tumble-down cottage from their grandmother, they’re left with strict instructions to bring it back to its former glory and sell the property. Darcy plans to be in an aisle seat halfway across the ocean as soon as the renovations start, but before she can cut and run, she finds a familiar face on her porch: house-flipper extraordinaire Tom’s arrived, he’s bearing power tools, and he’s single for the first time in almost a decade.</a></p>\n<p><a href=\"https://amzn.to/2G3ajzS\">Suddenly Darcy’s considering sticking around to make sure her twin doesn’t ruin the cottage’s inherent magic with his penchant for grey and chrome. She’s definitely not staying because of her new business partner’s tight t-shirts, or that perfect face that&#8217;s inspiring her to pick up her camera again. Soon sparks are flying—and it’s not the faulty wiring. It turns out one percent of Tom’s heart might not be enough for Darcy anymore. This time around, she’s switching things up. She’s going to make Tom Valeska 99 percent hers.</a></p>\n<hr />\n<p><strong>Dabney:</strong> There aren&#8217;t a lot of books as anticipated as this one and I think, for me, that was a bit of a problem.</p>\n<p><strong>Kristen:</strong> Yeah, I had a hard time managing my expectations on this one. I had NONE for <a href=\"https://amzn.to/2B0Og9F\"><strong>The Hating Game</strong></a>, of course, so I sometimes wonder if that made me love it more. So yes, Dabney, I agree.</p>\n<p><strong>Haley:</strong> I tried to tell myself going in that this wouldn&#8217;t be <strong>The Hating Game</strong>, so there was no way I would like it as much. <strong>THG</strong> was one of those oddball books that comes along really rarely for me and makes me fall madly in love. The chances of that happening twice were impossible. I just wanted <strong><span class=\"m_-7656361340798270406gmail-m_7593695302416859043gmail-il\">99</span> Percent Mine</strong> to sound like Sally Thorne and, I think it did.</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney:</strong> And perhaps that&#8217;s part of why I didn&#8217;t love it. At all.</p>\n<p><strong>Kristen:</strong> Haley, did it sounding like Sally Thorne mean you liked it? Because I completely agree it felt like her voice, but man, I did not like this book. The dialogue I found witty and creative in <strong>THG</strong> felt labored here and I could not stand the protagonists &#8211; any of them!</p>\n<p><strong>Haley:</strong> It actually did. I think I must have liked it more than y&#8217;all did because, while it was no <strong>THG</strong>, I enjoyed most of <strong><span class=\"m_-7656361340798270406gmail-m_7593695302416859043gmail-il\">99 Percent </span>Mine</strong>. It had its flaws, for sure, but I enjoyed the central love story. What was it that you didn&#8217;t like about Tom and Darcy?</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney:</strong> Um. Pretty much everything. I didn&#8217;t like them especially as individuals, in large part because they didn&#8217;t make any sense to me. I didn&#8217;t like their relationship which, again, I didn&#8217;t really understand. I found them both to be unnecessarily self-destructive &#8211; Darcy borders on selfish as well &#8211; and I didn&#8217;t think either of them were ready, even by the end of the book, to truly love another.</p>\n<p><strong>Caroline:</strong> I accept that Darcy was self-destructive, but that&#8217;s part of what I found interesting about reading her story. I was interviewing an author about a different flawed heroine, and she made a comment about how literature conditions us to grapple with understanding and loving troubled male characters but our women typically need to be likeable and unchallenging. Since I&#8217;ve been guilty of that, it really stuck with me.</p>\n<p><strong>Haley:</strong> I&#8217;d have to agree, Caroline. I think she did have a self destructive urge, but it didn&#8217;t make me hate her. I can&#8217;t remember how old she and her twin are, but I had a streak in my early twenties where dating jerks, drinking, and acting selfish seemed like great ideas. Now, I will say, one of my bigger hang ups was the twin. The over protective, pushy brother trope almost never works for me. Especially as a device to keep the two love interests apart.</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney:</strong> There are heroines who are self-destructive, bitchy, cranky, and bossy that I&#8217;ve loved. Darcy is not one of them. Her self-destructiveness seemed so self-absorbed which made her a tough love story heroine. I never believed she&#8217;d really love Tom as he deserved to be loved.</p>\n<p><strong>Caroline:</strong> That&#8217;s interesting, because the one thing I believed was that she completely and utterly loved Tom!</p>\n<p>The thing that worked least for me was the pacing of the beginning of the book. The opening scene, which began with Darcy tending bar and narrated the next day or so continuously, including Tom&#8217;s arrival, dragged, especially because the author had to keep coming up with ways to avoid Tom telling Darcy what we all knew about his fiancée, Megan. If those chapters had been split over more time (a phone call with Tom, his arrival and tour, his moving in a week later, etc.), I think it would have been more effective. It seems like a small complaint, but those pages are practically the first third of the book, and it was a big issue for me getting into a reading rhythm.</p>\n<p><strong>Kristen:</strong> Man, I love how subjective art is. We all saw different things in such a fascinating way. Caroline, I&#8217;m glad you pointed out the rhythm issues in the beginning because I think that is one of my key issues: I never fell into a reading rhythm with this. Besides my feelings towards the characters &#8211; which are mostly in line with Dabney&#8217;s &#8211; I just kept feeling unsettled during the reading experience.</p>\n<p>Overall, this book was just a miss for me. I found Darcy unappealing, her relationship with her twin to be symbiotic instead of productive, and Tom to be a bit of a meh all around. I&#8217;m still struggling to sort a grade, though, because while it didn&#8217;t work for me at all I can see how it would work for others. I&#8217;ve landed on a C for that reason.</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney:</strong> I read it less than a month ago and when I think about what I like about it, the only thing that really comes to mind is Darcy&#8217;s utterly fabulous best friend Truly. (I have taken to calling myself plush-sized every chance I get.) She and Darcy were lovely together. The novel sparkled every time Truly showed up and that made me even more aware of how the rest of the book did not. And, by the way, I have boy/girl twins who are in their twenties. Darcy and her brother Jamie were just weird &#8211; I kept trying to imagine people behaving as they did and I just couldn&#8217;t.For me, this book is a C as well.</p>\n<p><strong>Haley:</strong> I think I liked it more than the rest of you, though I agree the twins came off weird. I&#8217;m not a fan of the overprotective brother trope at all. I agree with Caroline that the pacing at the start of the book threw me off, and it took me a bit to get into. Once I did, I enjoyed the dynamic between Tom and Darcy. I really believed she adored him, but thought she had messed up too many times and lost her chance. I also, surprisingly, enjoyed the house renovation element, which I didn&#8217;t expect to (although I totally wanted her to keep the house).</p>\n<p>I would say it was a B- for me. Probably not a book I&#8217;ll go back and reread, but I enjoyed it at the time.</p>\n<p><strong>Caroline: </strong>I think I&#8217;m a B. The challenging nature of the heroine makes this book something I&#8217;d read when I&#8217;m in the mood for women&#8217;s fiction rather than romance. I liked that the characters all had depth &#8211; the villainous brother isn&#8217;t (Villainous), the perfect man isn&#8217;t (perfect), and the disaster of a heroine isn&#8217;t (a disaster). We didn&#8217;t discuss Darcy&#8217;s heart condition much, but I would be interested to hear what people with a health condition think about how the author depicts its impact on Darcy&#8217;s behavior and self-image. I think that&#8217;s a big part of the reason my grade is so much higher &#8211; this book made me think about issues from health to sibling rivalry to unfair expectations of relationship partners. I&#8217;d rather have something complex but a bit messy (like Darcy!) than something with fewer flaws that feels bland.</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney:</strong> I know our readers won&#8217;t all agree with us. And I&#8217;m hopeful that Thorne has more great books in her. Second novels are often the most difficult to do well&#8211;there&#8217;s a reason we all know the term sophomore slump. AAR readers&#8211;have you read <strong><span class=\"m_-7656361340798270406gmail-m_7593695302416859043gmail-il\">99 Percent</span> Mine</strong>? And if so, what did you think?</p>\n<h3><strong>Buy it at: <a href=\"https://amzn.to/2SiiBYa\">Amazon</a>/<a href=\"https://geo.itunes.apple.com/us/book/99-percent-mine/id1286643466?mt=11&amp;at=1010lmPQ\">Apple Books</a>/<a href=\"http://www.anrdoezrs.net/links/8039827/type/dlg/fragment/%2F/https:/www.barnesandnoble.com/w/99-percent-mine-sally-thorne/1127754906?ean=9780062439628\">Barnes &amp; Noble</a>/<a href=\"https://click.linksynergy.com/link?id=b95pXvP*dp4&amp;offerid=635768.515919780062682161&amp;type=2&amp;murl=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.kobo.com%2Fus%2Fen%2Faudiobook%2F99-percent-mine-1\">Kobo</a></strong></h3>\n<h3 style=\"text-align: center;\"><strong>Visit our <a href=\"https://amzn.to/2SeEiZg\">Amazon Storefront</a></strong></h3>\n",
                "text": "Darcy Barrett has undertaken a global survey of men. She’s travelled the world, and can categorically say that no one measures up to Tom Valeska, whose only flaw is that Darcy’s twin brother Jamie saw him first and claimed him forever as his best friend. Despite Darcy’s best efforts, Tom’s off limits and loyal to her brother, 99%. That’s the problem with finding her dream man at age eight and peaking in her photography career at age twenty—ever since, she’s had to learn to settle for good enough. When Darcy and Jamie inherit a tumble-down cottage from their grandmother, they’re left with strict instructions to bring it back to its former glory and sell the property. Darcy plans to be in an aisle seat halfway across the ocean as soon as the renovations start, but before she can cut and run, she finds a familiar face on her porch: house-flipper extraordinaire Tom’s arrived, he’s bearing power tools, and he’s single for the first time in almost a decade. Suddenly Darcy’s considering sticking around to make sure her twin doesn’t ruin the cottage’s inherent magic with his penchant for grey and chrome. She’s definitely not staying because of her new business partner’s tight t-shirts, or that perfect face that&#8217;s inspiring her to pick up her camera again. Soon sparks are flying—and it’s not the faulty wiring. It turns out one percent of Tom’s heart might not be enough for Darcy anymore. This time around, she’s switching things up. She’s going to make Tom Valeska 99 percent hers. Dabney: There aren&#8217;t a lot of books as anticipated as this one and I think, for me, that was a bit of a problem. Kristen: Yeah, I had a hard time managing my expectations on this one. I had NONE for The Hating Game, of course, so I sometimes wonder if that made me love it more. So yes, Dabney, I agree. Haley: I tried to tell myself going in that this wouldn&#8217;t be The Hating Game, so there was no way I would like it as much. THG was one of those oddball books that comes along really rarely for me and makes me fall madly in love. The chances of that happening twice were impossible. I just wanted 99 Percent Mine to sound like Sally Thorne and, I think it did. Dabney: And perhaps that&#8217;s part of why I didn&#8217;t love it. At all. Kristen: Haley, did it sounding like Sally Thorne mean you liked it? Because I completely agree it felt like her voice, but man, I did not like this book. The dialogue I found witty and creative in THG felt labored here and I could not stand the protagonists &#8211; any of them! Haley: It actually did. I think I must have liked it more than y&#8217;all did because, while it was no THG, I enjoyed most of 99 Percent Mine. It had its flaws, for sure, but I enjoyed the central love story. What was it that you didn&#8217;t like about Tom and Darcy? Dabney: Um. Pretty much everything. I didn&#8217;t like them especially as individuals, in large part because they didn&#8217;t make any sense to me. I didn&#8217;t like their relationship which, again, I didn&#8217;t really understand. I found them both to be unnecessarily self-destructive &#8211; Darcy borders on selfish as well &#8211; and I didn&#8217;t think either of them were ready, even by the end of the book, to truly love another. Caroline: I accept that Darcy was self-destructive, but that&#8217;s part of what I found interesting about reading her story. I was interviewing an author about a different flawed heroine, and she made a comment about how literature conditions us to grapple with understanding and loving troubled male characters but our women typically need to be likeable and unchallenging. Since I&#8217;ve been guilty of that, it really stuck with me. Haley: I&#8217;d have to agree, Caroline. I think she did have a self destructive urge, but it didn&#8217;t make me hate her. I can&#8217;t remember how old she and her twin are, but I had a streak in my early twenties where dating jerks, drinking, and acting selfish seemed like great ideas. Now, I will say, one of my bigger hang ups was the twin. The over protective, pushy brother trope almost never works for me. Especially as a device to keep the two love interests apart. Dabney: There are heroines who are self-destructive, bitchy, cranky, and bossy that I&#8217;ve loved. Darcy is not one of them. Her self-destructiveness seemed so self-absorbed which made her a tough love story heroine. I never believed she&#8217;d really love Tom as he deserved to be loved. Caroline: That&#8217;s interesting, because the one thing I believed was that she completely and utterly loved Tom! The thing that worked least for me was the pacing of the beginning of the book. The opening scene, which began with Darcy tending bar and narrated the next day or so continuously, including Tom&#8217;s arrival, dragged, especially because the author had to keep coming up with ways to avoid Tom telling Darcy what we all knew about his fiancée, Megan. If those chapters had been split over more time (a phone call with Tom, his arrival and tour, his moving in a week later, etc.), I think it would have been more effective. It seems like a small complaint, but those pages are practically the first third of the book, and it was a big issue for me getting into a reading rhythm. Kristen: Man, I love how subjective art is. We all saw different things in such a fascinating way. Caroline, I&#8217;m glad you pointed out the rhythm issues in the beginning because I think that is one of my key issues: I never fell into a reading rhythm with this. Besides my feelings towards the characters &#8211; which are mostly in line with Dabney&#8217;s &#8211; I just kept feeling unsettled during the reading experience. Overall, this book was just a miss for me. I found Darcy unappealing, her relationship with her twin to be symbiotic instead of productive, and Tom to be a bit of a meh all around. I&#8217;m still struggling to sort a grade, though, because while it didn&#8217;t work for me at all I can see how it would work for others. I&#8217;ve landed on a C for that reason. Dabney: I read it less than a month ago and when I think about what I like about it, the only thing that really comes to mind is Darcy&#8217;s utterly fabulous best friend Truly. (I have taken to calling myself plush-sized every chance I get.) She and Darcy were lovely together. The novel sparkled every time Truly showed up and that made me even more aware of how the rest of the book did not. And, by the way, I have boy/girl twins who are in their twenties. Darcy and her brother Jamie were just weird &#8211; I kept trying to imagine people behaving as they did and I just couldn&#8217;t.For me, this book is a C as well. Haley: I think I liked it more than the rest of you, though I agree the twins came off weird. I&#8217;m not a fan of the overprotective brother trope at all. I agree with Caroline that the pacing at the start of the book threw me off, and it took me a bit to get into. Once I did, I enjoyed the dynamic between Tom and Darcy. I really believed she adored him, but thought she had messed up too many times and lost her chance. I also, surprisingly, enjoyed the house renovation element, which I didn&#8217;t expect to (although I totally wanted her to keep the house). I would say it was a B- for me. Probably not a book I&#8217;ll go back and reread, but I enjoyed it at the time. Caroline: I think I&#8217;m a B. The challenging nature of the heroine makes this book something I&#8217;d read when I&#8217;m in the mood for women&#8217;s fiction rather than romance. I liked that the characters all had depth &#8211; the villainous brother isn&#8217;t (Villainous), the perfect man isn&#8217;t (perfect), and the disaster of a heroine isn&#8217;t (a disaster). We didn&#8217;t discuss Darcy&#8217;s heart condition much, but I would be interested to hear what people with a health condition think about how the author depicts its impact on Darcy&#8217;s behavior and self-image. I think that&#8217;s a big part of the reason my grade is so much higher &#8211; this book made me think about issues from health to sibling rivalry to unfair expectations of relationship partners. I&#8217;d rather have something complex but a bit messy (like Darcy!) than something with fewer flaws that feels bland. Dabney: I know our readers won&#8217;t all agree with us. And I&#8217;m hopeful that Thorne has more great books in her. Second novels are often the most difficult to do well&#8211;there&#8217;s a reason we all know the term sophomore slump. AAR readers&#8211;have you read 99 Percent Mine? And if so, what did you think? Buy it at: Amazon/Apple Books/Barnes &amp; Noble/Kobo Visit our Amazon Storefront"

                "html": "<p><a href=\"https://amzn.to/2T6PMhA\">Delilah Swanpoole, Countess of Derring, learns the hard way that her husband, “Dear Dull Derring,” is a lot more interesting—and perfidious—dead than alive. It’s a devil of an inheritance, but in the grand ruins of the one building Derring left her, are the seeds of her liberation. And she vows <em>never</em> again to place herself at the mercy of a man.</a></p>\n<p><a href=\"https://amzn.to/2T6PMhA\">But battle-hardened Captain Tristan Hardy is nothing if not merciless. When the charismatic naval hero tracks a notorious smuggler to a London boarding house known as the Rogue’s Palace, seducing the beautiful, blue-blooded proprietress to get his man seems like a small sacrifice.</a></p>\n<p><a href=\"https://amzn.to/2T6PMhA\">They both believe love is a myth. But a desire beyond reason threatens to destroy the armor around their hearts. Now a shattering decision looms: Will Tristan betray his own code of honor…or choose a love that might be the truest thing he’s ever known?</a></p>\n<hr />\n<p><strong>Dabney</strong>: SHE&#8217;S BACK! And, man am I happy about that. Don&#8217;t get me wrong&#8211;I enjoyed all of Long&#8217;s <a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/review-tag/hellcat-canyon-series/\"><em>Hellcat Canyon</em> </a>books. But. There&#8217;s no writer of historical romance I love more than I love JAL and her <em><a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/review-tag/pennyroyal-green-series/\">Pennyroyal Green series</a></em>. So I was over the moon when I heard she was returning to HR. And what a return!</p>\n<p><strong>Kristen</strong>: Yes! Since I&#8217;m a bit of a late joiner to Romancelandia, I read all of the <em>Pennyroyal</em> series as part of Ms. Long&#8217;s back catalogue. When I heard she was releasing a new historical series, I was thrilled to be getting in on the ground floor, as it were. I eagerly read this tale in one greedy sitting and adored it pretty much top to bottom.</p>\n<p>Well, now that I&#8217;ve tipped my hand&#8230; ladies, what say you?</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney</strong>: I too love this book. So many things about it are my jam&#8211;the wonderfully witty banter, the smouldering tension between the leads, the developed and integral cast of characters. And the writing is as good as any in Long&#8217;s catalog.</p>\n<p><strong>Alexandra</strong>: I couldn&#8217;t agree more. I&#8217;ve always enjoyed Long&#8217;s writing, but this book has to be one of my favorites. I particularly liked the character of Delilah, Lady Derring. She comes across as innocent and naive in the beginning, but then surprised me with her wit and, well, daring.</p>\n<p><strong>Kristen</strong>: In my professional life, I spend a lot of time with women who own businesses and many who started ones because they had no other choice, much like Delilah. There is such an air of &#8220;right, let&#8217;s get on with it&#8221; about this book that I found gorgeously authentic to the women I work alongside and gave me such a deep affection for the character. Delilah could have easily wallowed in her circumstances, emotionally anyway, and instead took a deep breath and made it work.</p>\n<p>How did you ladies react to the initial reveal of Derring&#8217;s mistress?</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney</strong>: I thought it was a win. And I love how her character, Angelique, evolved over the course of the book. (Slight spoiler ahead!) For me, as lovely as the relationship between Delilah and Tristan is, the relationship between Delilah and Angelique is every bit as wondrous. I was trying to think if Long has ever written such a strong female friendship in any of her other historicals. I adore these two.</p>\n<p><strong>Alexandra</strong>: I loved that element too&#8211;it some ways, this book felt like Women&#8217;s Fiction wrapped in a Historical Romance. At the core there was a focus on Delilah discovering her own strength as she confronts her husband&#8217;s mistress and starts her own business. I also particularly liked that those elements stood apart from Delilah&#8217;s relationship with Tristan. Although he&#8217;s supportive, her accomplishments are due to her own hard work, not Tristan riding in to save her.</p>\n<p>We&#8217;ve talked a lot about what we loved in this book. Was there anything you ladies had problems with?</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney</strong>: The romance is a bit of a slower burn than I usually like but the banter between Delilah and Tristan is so brilliant that bothered me less than it might have.</p>\n<p><strong>Kristen</strong>: I can find niggly things for sure &#8211; a few lines of dialogue that felt clunky and I&#8217;m with Dabney that it took longer to move than I prefer, but honestly? Nothing that deterred from my unadulterated love for this thing. It ticked every box I wanted it to and gave me such a happy book feeling. I was craving a good friendship story more than I even knew, and this delivered.</p>\n<p>Also. More Angelique ASAP please and thank you. This one is a A+ from me &#8211; I think that&#8217;s the third one I&#8217;ve ever given out.</p>\n<p><strong>Alexandra</strong>: I&#8217;m right there with you Kristen, it easily earned an A in my book. There was nothing major that I found to dislike, and I actually enjoyed the slow burn aspect of the romance. It felt right to me, as it allowed time for Delilah to find her footing after her husband&#8217;s death and realize her own internal strength. By the time she officially begins an affair with Tristan, she&#8217;s doing so as an independent woman seeking companionship, not a damsel in distress seeking a knight in shining armor. For me, that was one of the elements that made this not just a good book, but a great one.</p>\n<p><strong>Dabney</strong>: I&#8217;m going with an A too. (I&#8217;ve never given ANY book an A+.) Not only is this a delight to read, it sets up a context, just as she did with the town of Pennyroyal Green, I love and can&#8217;t wait to read more of.  Here&#8217;s hoping Angelique&#8217;s story comes out soon!</p>\n<h3><strong>Buy it at: <a href=\"https://amzn.to/2T6PMhA\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Amazon</a>/<a href=\"https://geo.itunes.apple.com/us/book/lady-derring-takes-a-lover/id1336074185?mt=11&amp;at=1010lmPQ\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Apple Books</a>/<a href=\"http://www.anrdoezrs.net/links/8039827/type/dlg/fragment/%2F/https://www.barnesandnoble.com/w/lady-derring-takes-a-lover-julie-anne-long/1128796063?ean=9780062867476\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Barnes &amp; Noble</a>/<a href=\"https://click.linksynergy.com/link?id=b95pXvP*dp4&amp;offerid=635768.100059780062867476&amp;type=2&amp;murl=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.kobo.com%2Fus%2Fen%2Febook%2Flady-derring-takes-a-lover\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Kobo</a></strong></h3>\n<h3 style=\"text-align: center\"><strong>Visit our </strong><a href=\"https://amzn.to/2SeEiZg\"><strong>Amazon Storefront</strong></a></h3>\n<p>&nbsp;</p>\n<p>&nbsp;</p>\n",

                "html": "<p>When Julie Anne Long wrapped up her much adored <em><a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/review-tag/pennyroyal-green-series/\">Pennyroyal Green</a></em> series with <a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/book-review/the-legend-of-lyon-redmond-by-julie-anne-long/\"><strong>The Legend of Lyon Redmond</strong></a>, she did a rather odd thing. The final pages of the book&#8211;a DIK for us&#8211;leapt forward in time to an epilogue set in the year that book was published (2015). Readers suddenly found themselves reading about a young woman named Isabel Redmond, an American, who&#8217;d come to Pennyroyal Green to find out more about her recently discovered family.</p>\n<p>As the epilogue begins, Isabel is standing underneath an ancient oak, taking in all that is modern Pennyroyal Green, when, startled by a motorcycle, her cell phone shoots out of her hands and lands directly in the path of the man driving said cycle. He, an exceptionally attractive GP named Malcolm Coburn, stops his bike, returns her phone, and, over the next 30 or so pages, chats with Isabel about Pennyroyal Green&#8217;s famous forbearers. The fates of Olivia, Lyon, Elise, Lavay, Jonathan, Miles, Cynthia, Colin, Madeline, and many of the other characters from the series are quickly covered as Isabel and Malcolm share stories.</p>\n<p>I liked but didn&#8217;t love the epilogue and was intrigued by Malcolm and Isabel. I&#8217;d heard Long was going to begin writing contemporary romance and I hoped their story would be next. It wasn&#8217;t. Instead, Long wrote about the Northern California community of <a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/review-tag/hellcat-canyon-series/\"><em>Hellcat Canyon</em></a>, a world with nary a Redmond or an Eversea.</p>\n<p>Now, however, before she returns to historical romance&#8211;<a href=\"https://amzn.to/2RJzqLw\"><strong>Lady Derring Takes a Lover</strong></a> comes out in February of next year&#8211;Long has written Malcolm and Isabel&#8217;s story. The 145 page novella begins exactly&#8211;and I do mean <em>exactly</em>&#8211;where <strong>The Legend of Lyon Redmond</strong> ends.</p>\n<p>Isabel, a woman of 30, was raised in a series of foster homes and didn&#8217;t discover her Redmond-ness until just a few months ago. Now, not only is she a Redmond, she&#8217;s in possession of two of the Redmond family heirlooms: Olivia Eversea Redmond&#8217;s diary and Lyon&#8217;s gold pocket-watch. Isabel has read and re-read Olivia&#8217;s diary&#8211;and it so speaks to her that she&#8217;s rented a flat in Pennyroyal Green for the next three months.</p>\n<p>Malcolm, on the other hand, grew up in Pennyroyal Green, and is now one of two overworked physicians tending to the town&#8217;s citizens which still include Duggans, Everseas, Falconbridges, Hawthornes, and O&#8217;Flahterys. (Everyone still drinks at the Pig &amp; Thistle and the vicar is still &#8220;dishy&#8221;.) He&#8217;s a lovely man, dedicated to his work and to his town, and, prior to meeting Isabel, would have said he was content with his life. But Isabel</p>\n<blockquote><p>&#8230;tipped his world ever so slightly on its axis. Just enough to dislodge any certainty he’d felt about his satisfaction with his existence prior to meeting her.</p></blockquote>\n<p>Isabel is equally taken with Malcolm and when, on her first night in her new place cuts her finger badly enough to need stitches, it feels like kismet. These two, <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NpWAlvWNZj0\">to steal a phrase from Jerry Maguire</a>, complete each other.</p>\n<p>This isn&#8217;t one of those love stories where there are lots of barriers keeping our lovers apart. Isabel and Malcolm fall fast and hard for each other. Like many of Long&#8217;s contemporary characters, both adore obscure music and one of the book&#8217;s greatest joys is a plot about a band called Heliotrope whose biggest song is called <em>Your Kiss Broke Time</em> and whose lead singer Sir Clive Dunkirk&#8211;think a knighted Pete Townshend&#8211;is distantly related to Isabel. Malcolm and Isabel spend just as much time talking as they do having the best sex of their lives and Long writes both with her trademark skillful wit and charm.</p>\n<p>The cast of characters around them is wonderful and, despite the brevity of the book, fully realized. I especially liked Declan Duggan, a musician with an outsized talent and personality, as well as Poppy Allgood, Isabel&#8217;s wonderfully self-satisfied neighbor.</p>\n<p>What keeps this from being a DIK for me? It&#8217;s, ironically, the reason for the story. Long makes a rather heavy-handed case that Olivia and Lyon&#8217;s story is integral to Malcolm and Isabel&#8217;s and that just didn&#8217;t do much for me. Perhaps it&#8217;s because I found the story of our modern lovers to be delightful on its own. I loved this last (?) look at Pennyroyal Green and I think most readers will too.</p>\n<h3><strong>Buy it at <a href=\"https://amzn.to/2CHvfMg\">Amazon</a>/Apple Books/<a href=\"http://www.anrdoezrs.net/links/8039827/type/dlg/https://www.barnesandnoble.com/w/malcolm-isabel-julie-anne-long/1129618664?ean=2940161654545\">Barnes and Noble</a>/<a href=\"https://click.linksynergy.com/fs-bin/click?id=b95pXvP*dp4&amp;subid=0&amp;offerid=551651.1&amp;type=10&amp;tmpid=9309&amp;RD_PARM1=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.kobo.com%2Fus%2Fen%2Fsearch%3FQuery%3Dmalcolm%2B%2526%2Bisabel\">Kobo</a></strong></h3>\n<p>&nbsp;</p>\n",
                "text": "When Julie Anne Long wrapped up her much adored Pennyroyal Green series with The Legend of Lyon Redmond, she did a rather odd thing. The final pages of the book&#8211;a DIK for us&#8211;leapt forward in time to an epilogue set in the year that book was published (2015). Readers suddenly found themselves reading about a young woman named Isabel Redmond, an American, who&#8217;d come to Pennyroyal Green to find out more about her recently discovered family. As the epilogue begins, Isabel is standing underneath an ancient oak, taking in all that is modern Pennyroyal Green, when, startled by a motorcycle, her cell phone shoots out of her hands and lands directly in the path of the man driving said cycle. He, an exceptionally attractive GP named Malcolm Coburn, stops his bike, returns her phone, and, over the next 30 or so pages, chats with Isabel about Pennyroyal Green&#8217;s famous forbearers. The fates of Olivia, Lyon, Elise, Lavay, Jonathan, Miles, Cynthia, Colin, Madeline, and many of the other characters from the series are quickly covered as Isabel and Malcolm share stories. I liked but didn&#8217;t love the epilogue and was intrigued by Malcolm and Isabel. I&#8217;d heard Long was going to begin writing contemporary romance and I hoped their story would be next. It wasn&#8217;t. Instead, Long wrote about the Northern California community of Hellcat Canyon, a world with nary a Redmond or an Eversea. Now, however, before she returns to historical romance&#8211;Lady Derring Takes a Lover comes out in February of next year&#8211;Long has written Malcolm and Isabel&#8217;s story. The 145 page novella begins exactly&#8211;and I do mean exactly&#8211;where The Legend of Lyon Redmond ends. Isabel, a woman of 30, was raised in a series of foster homes and didn&#8217;t discover her Redmond-ness until just a few months ago. Now, not only is she a Redmond, she&#8217;s in possession of two of the Redmond family heirlooms: Olivia Eversea Redmond&#8217;s diary and Lyon&#8217;s gold pocket-watch. Isabel has read and re-read Olivia&#8217;s diary&#8211;and it so speaks to her that she&#8217;s rented a flat in Pennyroyal Green for the next three months. Malcolm, on the other hand, grew up in Pennyroyal Green, and is now one of two overworked physicians tending to the town&#8217;s citizens which still include Duggans, Everseas, Falconbridges, Hawthornes, and O&#8217;Flahterys. (Everyone still drinks at the Pig &amp; Thistle and the vicar is still &#8220;dishy&#8221;.) He&#8217;s a lovely man, dedicated to his work and to his town, and, prior to meeting Isabel, would have said he was content with his life. But Isabel &#8230;tipped his world ever so slightly on its axis. Just enough to dislodge any certainty he’d felt about his satisfaction with his existence prior to meeting her. Isabel is equally taken with Malcolm and when, on her first night in her new place cuts her finger badly enough to need stitches, it feels like kismet. These two, to steal a phrase from Jerry Maguire, complete each other. This isn&#8217;t one of those love stories where there are lots of barriers keeping our lovers apart. Isabel and Malcolm fall fast and hard for each other. Like many of Long&#8217;s contemporary characters, both adore obscure music and one of the book&#8217;s greatest joys is a plot about a band called Heliotrope whose biggest song is called Your Kiss Broke Time and whose lead singer Sir Clive Dunkirk&#8211;think a knighted Pete Townshend&#8211;is distantly related to Isabel. Malcolm and Isabel spend just as much time talking as they do having the best sex of their lives and Long writes both with her trademark skillful wit and charm. The cast of characters around them is wonderful and, despite the brevity of the book, fully realized. I especially liked Declan Duggan, a musician with an outsized talent and personality, as well as Poppy Allgood, Isabel&#8217;s wonderfully self-satisfied neighbor. What keeps this from being a DIK for me? It&#8217;s, ironically, the reason for the story. Long makes a rather heavy-handed case that Olivia and Lyon&#8217;s story is integral to Malcolm and Isabel&#8217;s and that just didn&#8217;t do much for me. Perhaps it&#8217;s because I found the story of our modern lovers to be delightful on its own. I loved this last (?) look at Pennyroyal Green and I think most readers will too.                 "html": "<p>Jill Sorenson’s<strong> <a href=\"https://amzn.to/1WrYUJ2\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Against the Wall</a> </strong>might be my favorite of Ms. Sorenson’s books. Many of her most memorable characters are genuinely hampered by their life choices, often to the point that there really isn’t a scott-free HEA in their future. This is definitely true for Eric Hernandez, the hero of <strong>Against the Wall</strong>. Eric first appeared in Sorenson’s 2011 <a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/book-review/the-edge-of-night/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><strong>The Edge of Night</strong></a> and, at the end of that book, went to jail for crimes he did indeed commit.</p>\n<p>In <strong>Against the Wall</strong>, Eric has now served his time and is trying to build a new life. He is, however, still in love with Meghan–also from <strong>The Edge of Night</strong>–who is, as she was five years ago, out of his reach.</p>\n<p>Sorenson writes characters who struggle to survive. The barriers Eric faces as an ex-con of color are palpably real. Eric is poor <em>and</em> Hispanic, and the choices he is forced to make are often heartbreaking. Furthermore, the mistakes he&#8217;s made are ones 21st century America is unlikely to forgive. Sorenson&#8217;s deft plotting, however, gives us hope that maybe, just maybe, Eric can become the man he is determined to be.</p>\n<p>Meghan, who is white and middle-class, is also a believable character. Like many a college student, she isn’t sure what she wants from life or from herself. Meghan too makes mistakes but her class and color make hers easier for her to recover from. Eric and Meghan are the sort of lovers you desperately want to have an HEA and, for much of this tautly written book, that outcome seems impossible.</p>\n<p>I love everything about this book. It&#8217;s gritty, sexy&#8211;like, really really hot&#8211;, and, in places, oh so sad. Sorenson’s prose crackles with life–this book transports you to its context. Eric and Meghan aren’t able to keep their hands off or their hearts closed to each other but their path is a fraught one. This is a book that once you start reading, you&#8217;ll keep reading. It&#8217;s just so good. I recommend it without reservation.</p>\n<h3><strong>Buy it at <a href=\"https://amzn.to/2Or5gLD\">Amazon</a>/<a href=\"https://geo.itunes.apple.com/us/book/against-the-wall/id1037738837?mt=11&amp;at=1010lmPQ\">iBooks</a>/<a href=\"http://www.anrdoezrs.net/links/8039827/type/dlg/https://www.barnesandnoble.com/w/against-the-wall-jill-sorenson/1122404518?ean=9781101965139\">Barnes and Noble</a>/<a href=\"https://click.linksynergy.com/fs-bin/click?id=b95pXvP*dp4&amp;subid=0&amp;offerid=551651.1&amp;type=10&amp;tmpid=9310&amp;RD_PARM1=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.kobo.com%2Fus%2Fen%2Febook%2Fagainst-the-wall-14\">Kobo</a></strong></h3>\n",
                "text": "Jill Sorenson’s Against the Wall might be my favorite of Ms. Sorenson’s books. Many of her most memorable characters are genuinely hampered by their life choices, often to the point that there really isn’t a scott-free HEA in their future. This is definitely true for Eric Hernandez, the hero of Against the Wall. Eric first appeared in Sorenson’s 2011 The Edge of Night and, at the end of that book, went to jail for crimes he did indeed commit. In Against the Wall, Eric has now served his time and is trying to build a new life.                 "html": "<p><b>Shameless</b> is the fourth in Ms. Stuart’s <b><i>The House of Rohan</i> </b>series&#8211;<a href=\"https://amzn.to/2IdOy2U\"><strong>Heartless</strong></a> comes out this week&#8211;and, while it’s not as stellar as the first two in the series, <a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/book-review/ruthless/\"><b>Ruthless</b></a> and <a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/book-review/reckless-3/\"><b>Reckless</b></a> (my personal favorite), it’as good as the third, <b>Breathless</b>. And, because it’s by Anne Stuart, it’s a damn fun read.</p>\n<p>The hero of <b>Shameless</b>, Benedick Rohan, is the brother of the heroine (Miranda) of the last Rohan tale. In <b>Breathless</b>, Benedick was last seen married to a woman he loved with one son and another child on the way. In <b>Shameless</b>, somewhat confusingly, Benedick has now lost two wives to childbirth and has no children. (No explanation is given for what happened to his first son.) In <b>Shameless</b>, Benedick is a rake who no longer believes in love although he, like all in the men in the <b><i>Rohan </i></b>series, is a big fan of sexual congress in all its varied forms.</p>\n<p>As the story begins, Benedick has come to London to do two things: find a biddable, boring bride and get laid. The first task is a necessary chore—he’s an eldest son and must have an heir. The second task he plans to accomplish with the help of one of London’s most talented fellatrices, Violet Highstreet. Benedick sends Vi a note asking her to come and attend to him. Violet dashes to his side, sinks to her knees and… suddenly, the door to Viscount Rohan’s salon flies open, admitting a strident woman he’s never seen before. The “virago” sternly tells Violet to “get up” and stop degrading herself! Violet protests she likes degrading herself in this particular fashion. The woman at the door, Lady Charity Carstairs, in a long-suffering voice, reminds Violet she has chosen to leave behind  her livelihood of salacious acts and instead reside in Carstairs House, a home for fallen women. Violet rather ungraciously opts for housing over whoring and, much to Benedick’s sorrow, leaves his house with the all no-play and all no-fun Lady Charity.</p>\n<p>The widowed Lady Charity Carstairs, at age 29, is a genuine prude. Her marriage to a much older man did nothing to convince her of the pull of passion and, as a widow, she’s had one brief, pitiable affair that left her sure men have nothing to offer. She’s confident, or so she tells herself, she’s content improving the lives of the gaggle of fallen women she saves from the streets.  So, despite thinking Benedick Rohan might be the best looking man she’s ever seen, she wants nothing to do with him until one of her “girls” is brutally beaten.</p>\n<p>Charity is sure the girl was so abused by the nefarious group of upper-class debauchees who form the Heavenly Host. The Host has figured in each of the Rohan books and, though the group has always been unsettling and seriously off-putting, they’ve never been truly criminal and violent until now. Under their new mysterious leader, not only has the Host begun viciously beating unwilling young women, rumor has it they plan to sacrifice a virgin on the next full moon.</p>\n<p>Charity asks Benedick for his help destroying the Heavenly Host, a group his family founded years ago. Initially, Benedick, who has nothing to do with the group, doesn’t care the Host have become so dissolute. Then Charity informs him his younger brother Brandon, a post-war wreck of a man, is involved with the group’s horrific plans. Worried for his opium addicted brother—and drawn to Charity&#8211;, Benedick agrees to work with her to destroy the Host.</p>\n<p>I wasn’t crazy about the suspense plot in <b>Shameless</b>. It was clear to me who the mysterious head of the Host was and I had a hard time buying Benedick’s brother Brandon doing anything truly evil.  I was also bored with the Heavenly Host. They have been in every <b><i>Rohan </i></b>novel and, at this point, they’re rather like garish wallpaper—you see them but other than making you cringe, they don’t have much impact on things that matter. Additionally, I was saddened there wasn’t Ms. Stuart’s trademark <b><i>Rohan</i> </b>secondary romance in this novel. While it’s clear there’s something between Brandon and Emma, Charity’s best friend and former madam extraordinaire, nothing of real interest passes between them in this book. I hoped for more for Brandon and Emma in this tale.</p>\n<p>But the primary love story, I loved. Charity has only had unsatisfactory sex and has never experienced romantic love. Benedick has had a superb sex life and has truly loved—he adored his first wife. Charity holds her heart apart because she doesn’t know what she’s missing; Benedick, his because he’s terrified of the pain that comes with loving and losing. As the two move into each other’s arms and emotions, they both slowly learn the value of risking one’s heart. Ms. Stuart always writes well about the way passion can bind. In <b>Shameless</b>, she writes not only about the power of sex but of the joy of companionship, and of the pleasure in finding that special someone you most enjoy sharing your day—and life—with. In this book, she writes convincingly of falling sweetly as well as passionately in love. It’s a treat to see Ms. Stuart, who does dark romance so well, write with great verve and skill about a lighter kind of love.</p>\n<p>&nbsp;</p>\n<h3><strong>Buy it at <a href=\"https://amzn.to/2KhVXuy\">Amazon</a>/<a href=\"https://geo.itunes.apple.com/us/book/shameless/id445590291?mt=11&amp;at=1010lmPQ\">iBooks</a>/<a href=\"http://www.anrdoezrs.net/links/8039827/type/dlg/https://www.barnesandnoble.com/w/shameless-anne-stuart/1101103462?ean=9781459207622\">Barnes and Noble</a>/<a href=\"https://click.linksynergy.com/fs-bin/click?id=b95pXvP*dp4&amp;subid=0&amp;offerid=551651.1&amp;type=10&amp;tmpid=9310&amp;RD_PARM1=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.kobo.com%2Fus%2Fen%2Febook%2Fshameless-3\">Kobo</a></strong></h3>\n",

                "html": "<p>I&#8217;m not sure why I decided to re-read <strong>Unforgiven</strong>. I&#8217;d read it years ago and thought it was good but not great. This go-round, it impressed the hell out of me. It resonated in a way contemporary romance rarely does with me.</p>\n<p>Adam Collins and Marissa Brooks grew up in the small town of Walker’s Ford, South Dakota. It&#8217;s a place where people drive pickup trucks, live in the same houses they grew up in, and where it feels almost impossible to become anyone other than who you once were. Calhoun&#8217;s rural America is more than credible&#8211;people worry about paying the bills, drink crappy coffee in worn booths, and rely on the library to show them worlds other than their own.</p>\n<p>When Adam and Marissa were seventeen they were in crazy, wildly in love. Though they never had actual sex, they spent every moment they could in each others&#8217; arms. When they thought about the future, Adam dreamed about exploring the world on his beloved motorcycle and Marissa longed to buy and restore her family&#8217;s ancestral home, Brookhaven.</p>\n<p>Adam destroyed one of those dreams one horrible night and the next day, he left town and joined the Marines. Twelve years later, he returns to Walker’s Ford, having left the Corps. On the night he returns, he walks into Brookhaven, now almost fully restored and owned by Marissa, to attend the engagement party of Adam’s best friend, Keith who is marrying Delaney, a woman Adam was engaged to for years and whom he broke up with eight months ago for reasons that no one really knows.</p>\n<p>Adam&#8217;s attention, however, isn&#8217;t on the celebrating couple, it&#8217;s on Marissa and, within an hour, the two are having the sex Adam denied them in high school. Within days, they are lovers.</p>\n<p>Marissa lets Adam into her body but she&#8217;s determined not to let him back into her heart. Though Adam says he&#8217;s back in South Dakota to stay&#8211;he plans to study architecture at a nearby university&#8211;she doesn&#8217;t believe he won&#8217;t again leave her and Walker&#8217;s Ford. And, she might be right. Adam keeps his emotions on lock-down and, despite the the heat that burns between them&#8211;and whoa does it burn&#8211;, he&#8217;s still so damaged by what happened seventeen years ago.</p>\n<p>Adam and Marissa are tethered to the past in heartrending ways and their story is absorbing. Change is difficult for both of them and it&#8217;s hard to watch them so limit their lives. Neither believes they deserve joy or love let alone a coupled happy ending. The small steps they take occur organically&#8211;there are no big misunderstandings here&#8211;and work beautifully to oh so slowly allow them to shed the pains of their past.</p>\n<p>Calhoun is one of the very best writers of love scenes and this book is on fire in that regard. If you&#8217;re looking for a story where consent, sex, and emotion are fused fabulously, look no further. The erotic prose in <strong>Unforgiven</strong>, like that in <a href=\"https://amzn.to/2JFbkNd\"><strong>Uncommon Passion</strong></a>, my favorite of her books, is arousing and emotional.</p>\n<p>I loved <strong>Unforgiven</strong> this read. It&#8217;s moving and beautifully written. Its people and places feel real. Adam&#8217;s and Marissa&#8217;s story has heft in all the best ways. It&#8217;s a DIK for me on the second time around.</p>\n<h3>Buy it at Amazon/<a href=\"https://geo.itunes.apple.com/us/book/unforgiven/id565677460?mt=11&amp;at=1010lmPQ\">iBooks</a>/<a href=\"http://www.anrdoezrs.net/links/8039827/type/dlg/https://www.barnesandnoble.com/w/unforgiven-anne-calhoun/1112826106?ean=9781101609545\">Barnes and Noble</a>/<a href=\"https://click.linksynergy.com/fs-bin/click?id=b95pXvP*dp4&amp;subid=0&amp;offerid=551651.1&amp;type=10&amp;tmpid=9310&amp;RD_PARM1=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.kobo.com%2Fus%2Fen%2Febook%2Funforgiven-6\">Kobo</a></h3>\n<p>&nbsp;</p>\n",
                "text": "I&#8217;m not sure why I decided to re-read Unforgiven. I&#8217;d read it years ago and thought it was good but not great. This go-round, it impressed the hell out of me.                 "html": "<p>I don’t read many category romances—I like longer stories. Sarah Mayberry’s, however, are the outstanding exception to that rule. I’ve read twenty of her novels. <strong>Suddenly You</strong> is my favorite. It’s funny, sexy, feminist, and wonderfully real.</p>\n<p>Harry is a nice guy who likes to take it all easy. He’s got a cool car, a decent job, good mates, and answers to no one but himself. And he likes it that way… until one night he sees his best friend’s ex-girlfriend Pippa stranded on the side of the road with her broken down car.</p>\n<p>Pippa doesn’t think much of Harry—he’s a pal of Steve&#8217;s, her loser ex. Steve and Pippa broke up when Pippa got pregnant and Steve insisted she get an abortion. Since then, Steve has been nothing but awful to Pippa and baby Alice. His refusal to support his child has meant Pippa and Alice teeter on the edge of poverty. She lets Harry give her a ride home and sends him on his way.</p>\n<p>Harry drives by Pippa’s broken-down car for several days and can’t figure out why she hasn’t had it towed. Finally, he stops by her ramshackle house and asks her. She tells him she doesn’t have the money—Steve won&#8217;t give her child support and she’s just barely paying her bills.</p>\n<p>Harry decides to fix Pippa’s car himself, even as he’s not sure why he’s doing so. He also tries to get Steve to support Alice and is upset when Steve says no. As far as Steve’s concerned, once Pippa decided to have Alice, the baby became Pippa’s sole responsibility. Harry finds himself seeking out Pippa, fixing up her house—she makes him dinner as payment&#8211;and slowly the two become more than just friends.</p>\n<p>Everything about this book works. Baby Alice isn’t a prop—she’s as difficult and as adorable as any normal baby and that’s just enough to make Pippa’s life as a single mom tough. Harry’s a gem and, even as he falls for Pippa, he doesn’t give up on Steve. The secondary characters, especially Harry’s parents, are winning and intrinsic to the story. The prose is hilarious—the wood filler scene alone is worth the price of the book. And the sex scenes are steamy and sweet.</p>\n<p>Perhaps best of all is that Mayberry’s characters exist in the same world as the rest of us. They worry about money and are grounded in the lives they live. By the time Pippa and Harry find, slowly, their way to true love—the kind that changes everything—we believe they’ll grow old together, laughing, loving, and living. Their HEA resonates.</p>\n<p>If you’ve not read Mayberry, I recommend this as a stellar place to start. <strong>Suddenly You</strong> is lovely.</p>\n<h3 style=\"text-align: left;\"><strong>Buy it at <a href=\"https://amzn.to/2K2FFpQ\">Amazon</a>/<a href=\"https://geo.itunes.apple.com/us/book/suddenly-you/id806453740?mt=11&amp;at=1010lmPQ\">Apple Books</a>/<a href=\"http://www.anrdoezrs.net/links/8039827/type/dlg/https://www.barnesandnoble.com/w/suddenly-you-sarah-mayberry/1110917308?ean=9781460334270\">Barnes and Noble</a>/<a href=\"https://click.linksynergy.com/fs-bin/click?id=b95pXvP*dp4&amp;subid=0&amp;offerid=551651.1&amp;type=10&amp;tmpid=9310&amp;RD_PARM1=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.kobo.com%2Fus%2Fen%2Febook%2Fsuddenly-you-4\">Kobo</a></strong></h3>\n",

                "html": "<blockquote><p>But for the first time, I feel the power of praying words alongside someone else, the power of praying words so familiar and ancient they come from some hitherto unknown part of my mind. The part of my mind that isn’t consumed with accounting and finance, the part that isn’t even rational or entirely civilized. It’s a part of me so deep, so elemental, I can’t even name it. But it responds to the old words like trees to wind, rustling awake, stretching roots deep, deep down. The words don’t care about my feelings, about my petty sulks and mortal frustrations. The words are there anyway, just as the humanness inside me is there anyway, and for one clear, shimmering moment, I understand.</p>\n<p>I understand how you can convict God of terrible crimes and then go to evening prayer.</p>\n<p>I understand that hate was never, ever the opposite of belief. I understand that belief isn’t a coat to be put on and worn in all kinds of weather, even the blistering sun.</p>\n<p>Belief is this. Praying when you don’t feel like it, when you don’t know who or what is listening; it’s doing the actions with the trust that something about it matters. That something about it makes you more human, a better human, a human able to love and trust and hope in a world where those things are hard.</p></blockquote>\n<p><em>from <strong>Sinner</strong> by Sierra Simone</em></p>\n<p>There’s also butt sex.</p>\n<p><strong>Sinner</strong> is somewhat of a miracle. It&#8217;s a book in which a profound commitment to understanding faith AND a plethora of scorching sex scenes are each well-written and intrinsic to the story. It&#8217;s an erotic romance that makes you think, hard, about spiritual, ethical, and metaphysical questions.</p>\n<p><strong>Sinner</strong> is the third book in Simone&#8217;s <em>Priest</em> series&#8211;I haven&#8217;t read the first two&#8211;and functions as a stand-alone. It&#8217;s the tale of thirty-six year old millionaire libertine Sean Bell and 21 year old virgin Zenobia Iverson. (The two reminded me, incongruously, of a modern day <a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/book-review/devil-in-winter-by-lisa-kleypas/\">Sebastian and Evie.</a>) Zenny is the young sister of Sean&#8217;s oldest friend and is beyond forbidden to Sean for any number of reasons, several of which I agree with. (I believe strongly in the half your age plus seven for romantic pairings.*)</p>\n<p>When the novel begins, Zenny and Sean meet hot at a party. He doesn&#8217;t recognize her. (She, however, knows exactly who he is.) They flirt, Sean talks some <em>serious</em> sex smack, and they begin to kiss but are interrupted&#8211;Sean has to race to the hospital where his mother, a terminal cancer patient, has been taken to the ER. The two part and Sean&#8211;he narrates the book&#8211;thinks he&#8217;ll never again see &#8220;Mary.&#8221;</p>\n<p>This is, of course, not the case. The next day, Sean&#8217;s boss sends him to finesse kicking a bunch of nuns out of the shelter they run&#8211;Sean is a deal closer extraordinaire&#8211;and, wouldn&#8217;t you know it, Mary turns out to be Zenny <strong>and</strong> a postulant there. She also turns out to want Sean to show her all she&#8217;ll be missing when, in a month, she marries the church and foreswears sex and men forever. And she does mean all.</p>\n<p>This is not a story line that calls to me in any way. And yet&#8230;.</p>\n<p>I like this book a lot. Simone is at ease in both the smutty and the spiritual&#8211;even better, she sees the connection between the two. As Sean&#8217;s brother Tyler tells him:</p>\n<blockquote><p>To be fully human is to be fully sexual, and while that doesn’t mean having sex or even sexual desire, it does mean being fully in your body. It means recognizing that there’s nothing any less holy about your body than there is about your soul, that as long as your body is treated with consent and respect and affection— and that you treat the bodies of others in the same way— there’s nothing inherently sinful about your flesh.</p></blockquote>\n<p>Faith, and what it means to live a life guided by it, is the heart of this story. Zenny and Sean go through all the expected stages of a contemporary romance as they find their way to their HEA. The reader is rarely surprised by their story but, whoa, the discussions they have as they work their way there are intricate and enthralling. Sean, with Zenny&#8217;s help, learns to understand God, death, and love in profound, life-affirming ways.</p>\n<p>There are flaws&#8211;yes. There&#8217;s a reveal about a secondary character that was as surprising as an anvil. Zenny is too young for Sean. The first person narration feels, at times, limiting.</p>\n<p>But, damn, if you&#8217;re looking for a book that successfully combines sex and (the path to) salvation, read this book. Sean, Zenny, their families&#8211;I &lt;3 Sean&#8217;s mom so hard&#8211;and their discussions have stayed with me long after I finished <strong>Sinner</strong>. It&#8217;s almost glorious.</p>\n<p><em>*The half+7 rule states that couples under the age of 45 should preferentially pick partners who are no less than half their age plus seven years. Once over 45, the seven number should slowly rise.</em></p>\n<h3><strong>Buy it at <a href=\"https://amzn.to/2Hbctv9\">Amazon</a>/<a href=\"https://geo.itunes.apple.com/us/book/sinner/id1339867054?mt=11&amp;at=1010lmPQ\">Apple Books</a>/<a href=\"http://www.anrdoezrs.net/links/8039827/type/dlg/https://www.barnesandnoble.com/w/sinner-sierra-simone/1127883891?ean=2940158957109\">Barnes and Noble</a>/<a href=\"https://click.linksynergy.com/fs-bin/click?id=b95pXvP*dp4&amp;subid=0&amp;offerid=551651.1&amp;type=10&amp;tmpid=9310&amp;RD_PARM1=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.kobo.com%2Fus%2Fen%2Febook%2Fsinner-37\">Kobo</a></strong></h3>\n<p>&nbsp;</p>\n",
                "text": "But for the first time, I feel the power of praying words alongside someone else, the power of praying words so familiar and ancient they come from some hitherto unknown part of my mind. The part of my mind that isn’t consumed with accounting and finance, the part that isn’t even rational or entirely civilized. It’s a part of me so deep, so elemental, I can’t even name it. That something about it makes you more human, a better human, a human able to love and trust and hope in a world where those things are hard. from Sinner by Sierra Simone There’s also butt sex. Sinner is somewhat of a miracle. It&#8217;s a book in which a profound commitment to understanding faith AND a plethora of scorching sex scenes are each well-written and intrinsic to the story. It&#8217;s an erotic romance that makes you think, hard, about spiritual, ethical, and metaphysical questions. This is not a story line that calls to me in any way. And yet&#8230;. I like this book a lot. As Sean&#8217;s brother Tyler tells him: To be fully human is to be fully sexual, and while that doesn’t mean having sex or even sexual desire, it does mean being fully in your body. It means recognizing that there’s nothing any less holy about your body than there is about your soul, that as long as your body is treated with consent and respect and affection— and that you treat the bodies of others in the same way— there’s nothing inherently sinful about your flesh. Faith, and what it means to live a life guided by it, is the heart of this story. Zenny and Sean go through all the expected stages of a contemporary romance as they find their way to their HEA. The reader is rarely surprised by their story but, whoa, the discussions they have as they work their way there are intricate and enthralling.                 "title": "What I Did for a Duke",
                "author_first": "Julie Anne",
                "author_last": "Long",
                "publisher": "Avon",

            "content": {
                "html": "<p style=\"text-align: left;\">Genevieve Eversea, of Pennyroyal Green, has been in love with Lord Harry Osborne for three years. Harry is all that Genevieve wants in a man — he’s funny, handsome, shares her knowledge and love of Italian art, and makes her smile every time she sees him. She is certain they make the perfect couple and that he’s just waiting for the right moment to ask her to be his bride. So it comes as a horrible, heartbreaking shock when he tells her he intends to propose to <b><i>her best friend Millicent</i></b> at an upcoming Everseas’ house party.</p>\n<p>Alexander Moncrieffe, the sixth Duke of Falconbridge, is, at forty, a chilly, ruthless, formidable man. He’s rumored to have poisoned his first wife and is known for never <em>ever</em> losing. Alex is a man most fear and avoid, although his title and wealth allow him to go wherever he chooses. He has chosen to come to the aforementioned house party where he intends to debauch Genevieve whom he’s never met. Earlier in the month, he caught her scapegrace brother Ian naked in bed with Alex’s now ex-fiancée. Alex has never let <b><i>anyone</i></b> cheat or wrong him without exacting revenge and, to him, the seduction of Ian’s innocent sister is fair retribution for Ian’s transgression.</p>\n<p>Neither Genevieve nor Alex is what they first seem. The ton believes Genevieve is a shy, quiet girl who is fond of art and calmer than her wild siblings &#8211; her suitors (and Harry) always present her with bouquets of pale and delicate flowers. In truth, Genevieve is complicated, passionate and extraordinarily clever. She chafes at the perception society — and her family — have of her. Her control over herself is thoughtful rather than guarded. She’s very witty and her insights into others — especially Alex — are dead on. She’s the sort of heroine one longs to actually know. Alex <b><i>is</i></b> a cold and often cruel man —it’s clear he deserves his terrifying reputation. He is also fiercely intelligent and very lonely. Even as he works to “compromise, ruin and abandon” Genevieve, he begins to care for her. His callous demeanor softens and, surprising even himself, he comes to value Genevieve’s wellbeing more than his own. Together they are lovely — full of intelligence, passion, and humor.</p>\n<p>Ms. Long is a first-rate writer and her use of language is superb. Her descriptive powers are formidable; she has a knack for imagery and dialogue. She’s also very funny. I loved this scene where Alex and Genevieve first chat on a walk to see the Eversea folly:</p>\n<blockquote><p>“What are your pleasures and pursuits, Lord Moncrieffe?” Miss Eversea asked too brightly, when the silence had gone on for more than was strictly comfortable or polite…. “Well, I’m partial to whores….” “Whor… whores…?”</p>\n<p>She choked out the word as if she’d just inhaled it like bad cigar smoke. He widened his own eyes with alarm, recoiling slightly. “I…I beg your pardon — Horses. Honestly, Miss Eversea,” he stammered. “I do wonder what you think of me if that’s what you heard.” He shook his head ruefully. “Horses. Those hooved beasts a man can race, wager upon, plow a field with, harness to a phaeton and drive at deliciously reckless speeds.”</p>\n<p>She stared at him now as he walked…. “And one cannot do any of that with whores?” she asked softly….</p>\n<p>His heart picked up a beat or two. “It’s a frustrating truism,” he allowed resignedly, “but it’s a rare whore who’ll consent to be harnessed to a plow.”</p></blockquote>\n<p>As Alex and Genevieve move from witty wordplay to passionate foreplay, the relationship between them shifts and what began as a story about a young maiden and an older rake becomes something much more nuanced. At the end of the novel, when Alex takes a risk that would have been unthinkable for him prior to falling in love with Genevieve, her reaction and the story’s denouement are beautifully and satisfyingly done.</p>\n<p>I’ve enjoyed all the Pennyroyal Green books, and <b>What I Did for a Duke</b> is my favorite thus far. Ms. Long’s novel, the fifth in the series, deftly continues the tale of two captivating families &#8211; the Everseas and the Redmonds -and intriguingly deepens the mysteries wending through the books. Now, I am <b><i>really</i></b> wondering what happened between Lyon Redmond and Olivia Eversea and why the relationship between the Eversea parents — Jacob and Isolde — is so strained. I want to know what the slave trade means to the finances of both families and who Colin Eversea’s father actually is. This book provides clues to these (and other) questions and gives just enough information to make one long for the next book.</p>\n<p>I can’t wait to read next Pennyroyal Green book — and I really hope it is Olivia’s and Lyon’s tale!</p>\n<h3>Buy it on <a href=\"http://amzn.to/29HMJcs\">Amazon</a>/<a href=\"https://geo.itunes.apple.com/us/book/what-i-did-for-a-duke/id400622054?mt=11&amp;at=1010lmPQ\">iBooks</a>/<a href=\"http://www.anrdoezrs.net/links/8039827/type/dlg/http://www.barnesandnoble.com/w/what-i-did-for-a-duke-julie-anne-long/1102006654?ean=9780062065803\">Barnes &amp; Noble</a>/<a href=\"http://click.linksynergy.com/fs-bin/click?id=b95pXvP*dp4&amp;subid=&amp;offerid=361251.1&amp;type=10&amp;tmpid=9310&amp;RD_PARM1=https%3A%2F%2Fstore.kobobooks.com%2Fen-us%2Febook%2Fwhat-i-did-for-a-duke-pennyroyal-green-series\">Kobo</a></h3>\n",
                "text": "Genevieve Eversea, of Pennyroyal Green, has been in love with Lord Harry Osborne for three years. Harry is all that Genevieve wants in a man — he’s funny, handsome, shares her knowledge and love of Italian art, and makes her smile every time she sees him. She is certain they make the perfect couple and that he’s just waiting for the right moment to ask her to be his bride. So it comes as a horrible, heartbreaking shock when he tells her he intends to propose to her best friend Millicent at an upcoming Everseas’ house party. Alexander Moncrieffe, the sixth Duke of Falconbridge, is, at forty, a chilly, ruthless, formidable man. He’s rumored to have poisoned his first wife and is known for never ever losing. Alex is a man most fear and avoid, although his title and wealth allow him to go wherever he chooses. He has chosen to come to the aforementioned house party where he intends to debauch Genevieve whom he’s never met. Earlier in the month, he caught her scapegrace brother Ian naked in bed with Alex’s now ex-fiancée. Alex has never let anyone cheat or wrong him without exacting revenge and, to him, the seduction of Ian’s innocent sister is fair retribution for Ian’s transgression. Neither Genevieve nor Alex is what they first seem. The ton believes Genevieve is a shy, quiet girl who is fond of art and calmer than her wild siblings &#8211; her suitors (and Harry) always present her with bouquets of pale and delicate flowers. In truth, Genevieve is complicated, passionate and extraordinarily clever. She chafes at the perception society — and her family — have of her. Her control over herself is thoughtful rather than guarded. She’s very witty and her insights into others — especially Alex — are dead on. She’s the sort of heroine one longs to actually know. Alex is a cold and often cruel man —it’s clear he deserves his terrifying reputation. He is also fiercely intelligent and very lonely. Even as he works to “compromise, ruin and abandon” Genevieve, he begins to care for her. His callous demeanor softens and, surprising even himself, he comes to value Genevieve’s wellbeing more than his own. Together they are lovely — full of intelligence, passion, and humor. Ms. Long is a first-rate writer and her use of language is superb. Her descriptive powers are formidable; she has a knack for imagery and dialogue. She’s also very funny. I loved this scene where Alex and Genevieve first chat on a walk to see the Eversea folly: “What are your pleasures and pursuits, Lord Moncrieffe?” Miss Eversea asked too brightly, when the silence had gone on for more than was strictly comfortable or polite…. “Well, I’m partial to whores….” “Whor… whores…?” She choked out the word as if she’d just inhaled it like bad cigar smoke. He widened his own eyes with alarm, recoiling slightly. “I…I beg your pardon — Horses. Honestly, Miss Eversea,” he stammered. “I do wonder what you think of me if that’s what you heard.” He shook his head ruefully. “Horses. Those hooved beasts a man can race, wager upon, plow a field with, harness to a phaeton and drive at deliciously reckless speeds.” She stared at him now as he walked…. “And one cannot do any of that with whores?” she asked softly…. His heart picked up a beat or two. “It’s a frustrating truism,” he allowed resignedly, “but it’s a rare whore who’ll consent to be harnessed to a plow.” As Alex and Genevieve move from witty wordplay to passionate foreplay, the relationship between them shifts and what began as a story about a young maiden and an older rake becomes something much more nuanced. At the end of the novel, when Alex takes a risk that would have been unthinkable for him prior to falling in love with Genevieve, her reaction and the story’s denouement are beautifully and satisfyingly done. I’ve enjoyed all the Pennyroyal Green books, and What I Did for a Duke is my favorite thus far. Ms. Long’s novel, the fifth in the series, deftly continues the tale of two captivating families &#8211; the Everseas and the Redmonds -and intriguingly deepens the mysteries wending through the books. Now, I am really wondering what happened between Lyon Redmond and Olivia Eversea and why the relationship between the Eversea parents — Jacob and Isolde — is so strained. I want to know what the slave trade means to the finances of both families and who Colin Eversea’s father actually is. This book provides clues to these (and other) questions and gives just enough information to make one long for the next book. I can’t wait to read next Pennyroyal Green book — and I really hope it is Olivia’s and Lyon’s tale! Buy it on Amazon/iBooks/Barnes &amp; Noble/Kobo"

                "html": "<p>Jane Harper had been a journalist for a decade<a href=\"http://www.canberratimes.com.au/entertainment/jane-harper-follows-the-dry-with-sequel-force-of-nature-20170913-gygwz5.html\"> when she decided she wanted to write fiction</a>. So, she did what many of us do when we want to learn a new skill: She took an online course. It must have been a hell of a course because her debut novel<a href=\"http://amzn.to/2H1TPX5\"> <strong>The Dry</strong></a>&#8211;which she wrote in 12 weeks&#8211;became an award-winning, NYT best-seller, and has been optioned by Reese Witherspoon.</p>\n<p>Have you read <strong>The Dry</strong>? No? It&#8217;s good, really good. It made <a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/best-2017-dabneys-list/\">my top ten list for 2017</a> and those I&#8217;ve given it to have been unable to put it down.</p>\n<p><a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/Dry-Novel-Jane-Harper-ebook/dp/B01BSN15F6/ref=as_li_ss_il?_encoding=UTF8&amp;psc=1&amp;refRID=3QBDD7FHPP2KK6YMW2C8&amp;linkCode=li3&amp;tag=allaboutromance&amp;linkId=1244c60866c8fa7de155cbf45866c071\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img decoding=\"async\" class=\"alignright\" src=\"//ws-na.amazon-adsystem.com/widgets/q?_encoding=UTF8&amp;ASIN=B01BSN15F6&amp;Format=_SL250_&amp;ID=AsinImage&amp;MarketPlace=US&amp;ServiceVersion=20070822&amp;WS=1&amp;tag=allaboutromance\" border=\"0\" /></a><img loading=\"lazy\" decoding=\"async\" style=\"border: none !important;margin: 0px !important\" src=\"https://ir-na.amazon-adsystem.com/e/ir?t=allaboutromance&amp;l=li3&amp;o=1&amp;a=B01BSN15F6\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" border=\"0\" /><strong>The Dry</strong> introduced (Australian) Federal Agent Aaron Falk. In that book, Falk returned to his hometown of Kiewarra&#8211;for the first time in 25 years&#8211; a town a five-hour drive from Melbourne, for the funeral of his best friend. Kiewarra is in the third year of a once-in-a-lifetime drought that&#8217;s destroying this rural farming community. Harper makes you feel the dust, the dryness, and the fear and anger the unrelenting sun stokes every day.</p>\n<p>In <strong>Force of Nature</strong>, that sense of place is again meticulously rendered. Here, it&#8217;s the Australian bush. Two teams from the accounting firm BaileyTennants, one all women and one all male, supervisors and staff, head out for a three-day team-building retreat in the mountains a few hours east of Melbourne. When they return, the women hours past schedule, one employee, Alice Russell, is missing.</p>\n<p>Aaron and his partner Carmen are called in from Melbourne&#8211;Alice called Aaron early the morning she was reported missing. Alice, you see, is the key to a money-laundering case the Feds are building against the Baileys. Jill and Daniel Bailey were both on the retreat.</p>\n<p>The book alternates between the present investigation and the days of the retreat. The five women comprise an uneasy group: Jill, Alice and Lauren who, decades ago, went to school together, and Bree and Beth, twin sisters one of whom is remarkably unreliable. Each was selected for the retreat and not one wants to be there. Hours after leaving the lodge&#8211;base camp&#8211;the women begin to bicker and, within a day, they&#8217;re lost.</p>\n<p>The second-best part of this compulsively readable book is the hour by hour recap of the three days the women wander through the mountains. The narration is omniscient so we see the perspectives of all five and, as they muse on the hell they&#8217;re in now, they share pieces of the past that may or may not be why Alice is gone.</p>\n<p>The best part of <strong>Force of Nature</strong>, as it was in <strong>The Dry</strong>, is the setting. You feel every drip from the oppressive trees, flinch at the sharp rocks that trip the hikers, and shiver at the animal sounds heard in the pitch night. Again and again, the women try and get a signal on Alice&#8217;s phone&#8211;which, of course, she wasn&#8217;t supposed to bring&#8211;and every time it fails. Here, nature is implacable and, until the final pages, you won&#8217;t be able to decide if it&#8217;s the bush or Alice&#8217;s many enemies who posed to her the greatest threat.</p>\n<p>I didn&#8217;t love the resolution of what happened to Alice and the last few chapters of the book are rushed. <strong>Force of Nature</strong> isn&#8217;t the powerhouse <strong>The Dry</strong> is. But it&#8217;s not a disappointment, either. Falk is a laconic, compelling sleuth. Watching him try to parse those women, all of whom have secrets, makes for excellent entertainment. I&#8217;m already waiting for book three.</p>\n<h3><strong>Buy it at <a href=\"http://amzn.to/2BO0tkc\">Amazon</a>/<a href=\"https://geo.itunes.apple.com/us/book/force-of-nature/id1297328419?mt=11&amp;at=1010lmPQ\">iBooks</a>/<a href=\"http://www.anrdoezrs.net/links/8039827/type/dlg/fragment/%2F/https://www.barnesandnoble.com/w/force-of-nature-jane-harper/1125686768?ean=9781250105646\">Barnes and Noble</a>/<a href=\"https://click.linksynergy.com/fs-bin/click?id=b95pXvP*dp4&amp;subid=0&amp;offerid=551651.1&amp;type=10&amp;tmpid=9310&amp;RD_PARM1=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.kobo.com%2Fus%2Fen%2Febook%2Fforce-of-nature-33\">Kobo</a></strong></h3>\n",
                "text": "Jane Harper had been a journalist for a decade when she decided she wanted to write fiction. So, she did what many of us do when we want to learn a new skill: She took an online course. It must have been a hell of a course because her debut novel The Dry&#8211;which she wrote in 12 weeks&#8211;became an award-winning, NYT best-seller, and has been optioned by Reese Witherspoon. Have you read The Dry? No? It&#8217;s good, really good. It made my top ten list for 2017 and those I&#8217;ve given it to have been unable to put it down. The Dry introduced (Australian) Federal Agent Aaron Falk. In that book, Falk returned to his hometown of Kiewarra&#8211;for the first time in 25 years&#8211; a town a five-hour drive from Melbourne, for the funeral of his best friend. Kiewarra is in the third year of a once-in-a-lifetime drought that&#8217;s destroying this rural farming community. Harper makes you feel the dust, the dryness, and the fear and anger the unrelenting sun stokes every day. In Force of Nature, that sense of place is again meticulously rendered. Here, it&#8217;s the Australian bush. Two teams from the accounting firm BaileyTennants, one all women and one all male, supervisors and staff, head out for a three-day team-building retreat in the mountains a few hours east of Melbourne. When they return, the women hours past schedule, one employee, Alice Russell, is missing. Aaron and his partner Carmen are called in from Melbourne&#8211;Alice called Aaron early the morning she was reported missing. Alice, you see, is the key to a money-laundering case the Feds are building against the Baileys. Jill and Daniel Bailey were both on the retreat. The book alternates between the present investigation and the days of the retreat. The five women comprise an uneasy group: Jill, Alice and Lauren who, decades ago, went to school together, and Bree and Beth, twin sisters one of whom is remarkably unreliable. Each was selected for the retreat and not one wants to be there. Hours after leaving the lodge&#8211;base camp&#8211;the women begin to bicker and, within a day, they&#8217;re lost. The second-best part of this compulsively readable book is the hour by hour recap of the three days the women wander through the mountains. The narration is omniscient so we see the perspectives of all five and, as they muse on the hell they&#8217;re in now, they share pieces of the past that may or may not be why Alice is gone. The best part of Force of Nature, as it was in The Dry, is the setting. You feel every drip from the oppressive trees, flinch at the sharp rocks that trip the hikers, and shiver at the animal sounds heard in the pitch night. Again and again, the women try and get a signal on Alice&#8217;s phone&#8211;which, of course, she wasn&#8217;t supposed to bring&#8211;and every time it fails. Here, nature is implacable and, until the final pages, you won&#8217;t be able to decide if it&#8217;s the bush or Alice&#8217;s many enemies who posed to her the greatest threat. I didn&#8217;t love the resolution of what happened to Alice and the last few chapters of the book are rushed. Force of Nature isn&#8217;t the powerhouse The Dry is. But it&#8217;s not a disappointment, either. Falk is a laconic, compelling sleuth. Watching him try to parse those women, all of whom have secrets, makes for excellent entertainment. I&#8217;m already waiting for book three. Buy it at Amazon/iBooks/Barnes and Noble/Kobo"
