                "html": "<p>There are books I read once and there are books I read again and again. <b>Having Her</b> is one of the latter. I read it for the first time two months ago and, since then, have read it again&#8230; and again. It&#8217;s sexy, unexpected, romantic, smart, and, in places, achingly sad. The novel meets my criteria for a superb erotic romance: the sex shared by the characters is integral to the plot and both are wonderfully done.</p>\n<p>Kara Sinclair is twenty-five and not afraid to stand out in a crowd. She wears brightly colored contact lenses, dyes her long hair colors never found in nature, favors biker boots, unusual outfits, and facial piercings. She owns a manga/Internet cafe, has been living on her own since she was seventeen, and is a bit of a hot head. She&#8217;s also a virgin, a state she&#8217;d like to change. But every time she tries, she ends up running away. There&#8217;s something about sex that makes her feel awkward and insecure. She believes if she could just get laid, sex would become easy for her.</p>\n<p>As the book begins, she&#8217;s resorted to picking up a strange guy at a bar and going home with him. But, the minute it is time to get naked, she runs&#8230; and finds herself stranded in an iffy neighborhood at eleven o&#8217;clock at night. She calls her best friend Ellie Fox to ask for a ride but it&#8217;s not Ellie who answers the phone. It&#8217;s Ellie&#8217;s older brother Vincent who is &#8220;a complete control-freak, arrogant, and the most patronizing bastard she’d ever had the misfortune to come across.&#8221; He is also &#8220;possibly the most beautiful man she’d ever met.&#8221;</p>\n<p>It&#8217;s true that Vincent is a control freak. He&#8217;s had to be. His mother is a schizophrenic who, when violent, wants to kill his sister, and his father abandoned their family when Vince was young. Vincent is the one who has always had to be in charge. In his early thirties, he owns a successful construction business. For years, every choice he&#8217;s made has been predicated at making sure his sister, mother, and business are safe. He&#8217;s never applied to architecture school&#8211;his childhood dream&#8211; and has never had time for a relationship. He can&#8217;t remember ever doing anything that was just for himself.</p>\n<p>Vince picks up Kara and is shocked to hear she&#8217;s a virgin and appalled to hear she&#8217;s planning to give herself to a stranger. He tells her she can do better, in fact, she damn well better do better. She says, unless he wants to be the one, he can damn well stop telling her what to do. At first Vince says he&#8217;s not interested but after a few days of Kara sending him provocative texts of the guys she&#8217;s considering, he makes her an offer.</p>\n<blockquote><p>You know what I’m offering, baby girl. You want to lose your virginity? Then it needs to be with someone who’ll keep you safe. With someone who knows what they’re doing and who’ll make it good for you. Who won’t take advantage of you.</p></blockquote>\n<p>Vince doesn&#8217;t just make it good for Kara. He makes it extraordinary not only for Kara but for himself. He does so by setting up rules that are perfect for them both.</p>\n<blockquote><p>“You don’t have to do anything,” Vin went on, still quiet, still in charge. “All you have to do is follow my orders. Because you’re here for my pleasure and my pleasure alone. Do you understand?”</p>\n<p>His pleasure alone? Shit. She should be protesting, shouldn’t she? Telling him where to stick his sexist bullshit? Yet the words stuck in her throat.</p>\n<p><strong><i>Because this is what you want. This is exactly what you want.</i></strong></p>\n<p>Kara struggled to take a breath. Yeah, God, it was what she’d fantasized about. Someone telling her what to do. Taking away the burden of her inexperience so she didn’t have to worry about it. And even more important than that, he was giving her a role to play. A mask to wear. Some extra armor to protect herself in a situation where she felt unprotected. A way to feel less vulnerable.</p>\n<p>She didn’t have to be Kara, the freaky-ass chick with the weird hair who dressed funny. The girl nobody, not even her family, wanted. She could just be a slave girl.</p>\n<p>Vin’s slave girl.</p></blockquote>\n<p>Kara and Vin enter into a sexual relationship that is twisted, complex, and powerful. Theirs isn&#8217;t a typical dom/sub liaison. There&#8217;s no violence, and, when Kara needs it, Vin gives her control. When they are not having sex, they are equals, each pushing the other to ask more from life. Their path is hard and both find it almost impossible to not be limited by their troubled pasts. Their HEA made me cry.</p>\n<p>I loved their story and, if you like demanding erotic romance, you will too.</p>\n<p>&nbsp;</p>\n<p><strong>Buy it at <a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0756M9HDG/ref=as_li_qf_sp_asin_il_tl?ie=UTF8&amp;tag=allaboutromance&amp;camp=1789&amp;creative=9325&amp;linkCode=as2&amp;creativeASIN=B0756M9HDG&amp;linkId=dc1b2667d46a63f5e8681daf4e9499dc\">A</a>/<a href=\"https://geo.itunes.apple.com/us/book/having-her/id1276020798?mt=11&amp;at=1010lmPQ\">iB</a>/<a href=\"http://www.anrdoezrs.net/links/8039827/type/dlg/https://www.barnesandnoble.com/w/having-her-jackie-ashenden/1117228892?ean=2940154895498\">BN</a>/<a href=\"https://click.linksynergy.com/fs-bin/click?id=b95pXvP*dp4&amp;subid=0&amp;offerid=361251.1&amp;type=10&amp;tmpid=9310&amp;RD_PARM1=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.kobo.com%2Fus%2Fen%2Febook%2Fhaving-her-1\">K</a></strong></p>\n",
                "text": "There are books I read once and there are books I read again and again. Having Her is one of the latter. I read it for the first time two months ago and, since then, have read it again&#8230; and again. It&#8217;s sexy, unexpected, romantic, smart, and, in places, achingly sad. The novel meets my criteria for a superb erotic romance: the sex shared by the characters is integral to the plot and both are wonderfully done. Kara Sinclair is twenty-five and not afraid to stand out in a crowd. She wears brightly colored contact lenses, dyes her long hair colors never found in nature, favors biker boots, unusual outfits, and facial piercings. She owns a manga/Internet cafe, has been living on her own since she was seventeen, and is a bit of a hot head. She&#8217;s also a virgin, a state she&#8217;d like to change. But every time she tries, she ends up running away. There&#8217;s something about sex that makes her feel awkward and insecure. She believes if she could just get laid, sex would become easy for her. As the book begins, she&#8217;s resorted to picking up a strange guy at a bar and going home with him. But, the minute it is time to get naked, she runs&#8230; and finds herself stranded in an iffy neighborhood at eleven o&#8217;clock at night. She calls her best friend Ellie Fox to ask for a ride but it&#8217;s not Ellie who answers the phone. It&#8217;s Ellie&#8217;s older brother Vincent who is &#8220;a complete control-freak, arrogant, and the most patronizing bastard she’d ever had the misfortune to come across.&#8221; He is also &#8220;possibly the most beautiful man she’d ever met.&#8221; It&#8217;s true that Vincent is a control freak. He&#8217;s had to be. His mother is a schizophrenic who, when violent, wants to kill his sister, and his father abandoned their family when Vince was young. Vincent is the one who has always had to be in charge. In his early thirties, he owns a successful construction business. For years, every choice he&#8217;s made has been predicated at making sure his sister, mother, and business are safe. He&#8217;s never applied to architecture school&#8211;his childhood dream&#8211; and has never had time for a relationship. He can&#8217;t remember ever doing anything that was just for himself. Vince picks up Kara and is shocked to hear she&#8217;s a virgin and appalled to hear she&#8217;s planning to give herself to a stranger. He tells her she can do better, in fact, she damn well better do better. She says, unless he wants to be the one, he can damn well stop telling her what to do. At first Vince says he&#8217;s not interested but after a few days of Kara sending him provocative texts of the guys she&#8217;s considering, he makes her an offer. You know what I’m offering, baby girl. You want to lose your virginity? Then it needs to be with someone who’ll keep you safe. With someone who knows what they’re doing and who’ll make it good for you. Who won’t take advantage of you. Vince doesn&#8217;t just make it good for Kara. He makes it extraordinary not only for Kara but for himself. He does so by setting up rules that are perfect for them both. “You don’t have to do anything,” Vin went on, still quiet, still in charge. “All you have to do is follow my orders. Because you’re here for my pleasure and my pleasure alone. Do you understand?” His pleasure alone? Shit. She should be protesting, shouldn’t she? Telling him where to stick his sexist bullshit? Yet the words stuck in her throat. Because this is what you want. This is exactly what you want. Kara struggled to take a breath. Yeah, God, it was what she’d fantasized about. Someone telling her what to do. Taking away the burden of her inexperience so she didn’t have to worry about it. And even more important than that, he was giving her a role to play. A mask to wear. Some extra armor to protect herself in a situation where she felt unprotected. A way to feel less vulnerable. She didn’t have to be Kara, the freaky-ass chick with the weird hair who dressed funny. The girl nobody, not even her family, wanted. She could just be a slave girl. Vin’s slave girl. Kara and Vin enter into a sexual relationship that is twisted, complex, and powerful. Theirs isn&#8217;t a typical dom/sub liaison. There&#8217;s no violence, and, when Kara needs it, Vin gives her control. When they are not having sex, they are equals, each pushing the other to ask more from life. Their path is hard and both find it almost impossible to not be limited by their troubled pasts. Their HEA made me cry. I loved their story and, if you like demanding erotic romance, you will too. &nbsp; Buy it at A/iB/BN/K"
            }

                "html": "<p>I loved this book when I first read it in 2012. I picked it up again for <a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/activist-heroines/\">our blog on Activist Heroines</a> and fell hard all over again. This is the story of Lulu Davies, a pilot for the English Air Transport Auxiliary, the only organization that allowed women to fly planes in WWII. She falls in love with American medic Joe Weber whom she meets when he’s the medic sent to save her after she makes a crash landing.</p>\n<p>Lulu and Joe and their WWII context are brilliantly rendered by Ms. Lofty for whom this book was a true labor of love. <strong>His Very Own Girl</strong> is a my favorite wartime romance. Joe and Lulu meet in January of 1944 and in June, Joe heads to Normandy as part of the D-Day invasion. Lulu stays in Britain, flying planes and pushing to be allowed in the combat zones. Joe survives in part by staying focused on the life he wants when the war ends, a life with Lulu. Lulu takes on increasingly dangerous missions and writes Joe letters she’s worried he’ll never get. Their romance is so real–it’s rather like reading a movie. This is a love story that showcases genuine heroes; Joe and Lulu are willing to give up their lives if it means defeating Hitler and his armies.</p>\n<p>Will Lulu fly combat planes? Will she and Joe find a future together? What happened to the women who were given so much responsibility in WWII only to see it whisked away when the men came back from war? Ms. Lofty answers all these questions deftly. <strong>His Very Own Girl</strong> is a DIK in every way.</p>\n",

Lulu and Joe and their WWII context are brilliantly rendered by Ms. Lofty for whom this book was a true labor of love. His Very Own Girl is a my favorite wartime romance.             "content": {
                "html": "<p>Stephen King once said that publishers disliked novellas because they &#8220;they were too long to be short and too short to be really long.&#8221; And it&#8217;s not just publishers, is it? Read through reviews of novella after novella here at AAR and you&#8217;ll read of similar dissatisfactions. I can think of no one who does them consistently brilliantly&#8230; no one but Courtney Milan.</p>\n<p>Ms. Milan&#8217;s novellas are, as a rule, superb. <a href=\"http://amzn.to/2hQpQYF\"><strong>This Wicked Gift</strong></a>, <a href=\"http://amzn.to/2hHgqeF\"><strong>The Governess Affair</strong></a>, and <strong><a href=\"http://amzn.to/2hHpEb0\">A Kiss for Midwinter</a> </strong>are<strong> </strong>all small(ish) prose wonders, each presenting a fully-fledged story in less than 125 pages.</p>\n<p>But my favorite novella by Ms. Milan is the first I read, <strong>Unlocked</strong>. This story is, tangentially, a part of the <em>Turner</em> series which I also love. The heroine of this story, Lady Elaine Warren, is a friend to Margaret, the steel-spined heroine of the first book in the series, <a href=\"http://amzn.to/2gTYzof\"><strong>Unveiled</strong></a>. Elaine, when the reader meets her, is ruined. Not by a seducing rake or a plummeting fortune, but by that most constant of devastations: bullying.</p>\n<p>Ten years ago, when Elaine first came out, she laughed and society&#8211;and in particular a darling gent of the ton, Evan Carlton, the Earl of Westfeld&#8211;shuddered. Elaine&#8217;s laugh was a bray, an embarrassment, and an easy target for those looking to make their mark. Evan, then young and callow, made her a joke&#8211;<em>Lady Equine</em>&#8211;and, really, that was it for Elaine.</p>\n<p>Now, Evan has returned to London, a very different man than when he left, and he sees, with terrible clarity, the woman she&#8217;s become:</p>\n<blockquote><p>She made herself easy to overlook. Her arms were drawn tightly about her waist, as if she could squeeze herself into insignificance. Her gown, a pink so anemic it might have been white, left her muted in the crowd of bright colors. Even the pale color of her hair, twisted into an indifferent chignon, seemed to declare her inconsequential. It was only his own memory that made her stand out.</p></blockquote>\n<p>For Elaine, Evan&#8217;s return is terrifying.</p>\n<blockquote><p>She had fallen into a nightmare: the kind where she entered a ballroom wearing nothing but her drawers. She’d had that dream before. Soon, everyone would start laughing at her. And when they turned to her en masse, the people who pointed and mocked all wore the same face: a thousand incarnations of Evan Carlton—now the Earl of Westfeld.</p></blockquote>\n<p>In the years since Evan left to&#8211;literally&#8211;climb mountains, Elaine has, much to her satisfaction, survived. She and her equally maligned mother&#8211;Lady Stockhurst is an astronomer whose fearsome intelligence make her the target of ridicule&#8211;continue to go to balls and to teas at which Elaine thinks every moment, every day, &#8220;<em>You cannot break me. You cannot hurt me. You cannot even make me notice you.</em>&#8221;</p>\n<p>Over the next 150 pages&#8211;the story is 181 pages long&#8211;Evan and Elaine remake their story both for themselves and for the ton. Ms. Milan takes no shortcuts here. Evan knows he wronged Elaine grievously and yet, we the readers, privy to his thoughts, long for Elaine to see him as the man he has now is. And yet there is no way for Elaine to do so without first processing the anger and the pain his cruelty caused her. Elaine, like the very best of heroines, has learned to value herself. Evan must earn her trust, her respect, and, if the reader is very very lucky, her love.</p>\n<p>The story of Elaine and Evan is riveting enough on its own. Ms. Milan adds to it the redemption of Lady Stockhurst&#8217;s reputation as well. The way in which Elaine and her mother are made whole in the eyes of those who have demeaned them for over a decade is so glorious&#8230; really, it&#8217;s just sublime.</p>\n<p>So, if you have an hour or two and want to immerse yourself in a fiction that inspires, moves, and persuasively entertains, pick up <strong>Unlocked</strong>. It&#8217;s a rarity: a wallop of a tale neither too long nor too short. It&#8217;s a gift.</p>\n<p>&nbsp;</p>\n",
                "text": "Stephen King once said that publishers disliked novellas because they &#8220;they were too long to be short and too short to be really long.&#8221; And it&#8217;s not just publishers, is it? Read through reviews of novella after novella here at AAR and you&#8217;ll read of similar dissatisfactions. I can think of no one who does them consistently brilliantly&#8230; no one but Courtney Milan. Ms. Milan&#8217;s novellas are, as a rule, superb. This Wicked Gift, The Governess Affair, and A Kiss for Midwinter are all small(ish) prose wonders, each presenting a fully-fledged story in less than 125 pages. But my favorite novella by Ms. Milan is the first I read, Unlocked. This story is, tangentially, a part of the Turner series which I also love. The heroine of this story, Lady Elaine Warren, is a friend to Margaret, the steel-spined heroine of the first book in the series, Unveiled. Elaine, when the reader meets her, is ruined. Not by a seducing rake or a plummeting fortune, but by that most constant of devastations: bullying. Ten years ago, when Elaine first came out, she laughed and society&#8211;and in particular a darling gent of the ton, Evan Carlton, the Earl of Westfeld&#8211;shuddered. Elaine&#8217;s laugh was a bray, an embarrassment, and an easy target for those looking to make their mark. Evan, then young and callow, made her a joke&#8211;Lady Equine&#8211;and, really, that was it for Elaine. Now, Evan has returned to London, a very different man than when he left, and he sees, with terrible clarity, the woman she&#8217;s become: She made herself easy to overlook. Her arms were drawn tightly about her waist, as if she could squeeze herself into insignificance. Her gown, a pink so anemic it might have been white, left her muted in the crowd of bright colors. Even the pale color of her hair, twisted into an indifferent chignon, seemed to declare her inconsequential. It was only his own memory that made her stand out. For Elaine, Evan&#8217;s return is terrifying. She had fallen into a nightmare: the kind where she entered a ballroom wearing nothing but her drawers. She’d had that dream before. Soon, everyone would start laughing at her. And when they turned to her en masse, the people who pointed and mocked all wore the same face: a thousand incarnations of Evan Carlton—now the Earl of Westfeld. In the years since Evan left to&#8211;literally&#8211;climb mountains, Elaine has, much to her satisfaction, survived. She and her equally maligned mother&#8211;Lady Stockhurst is an astronomer whose fearsome intelligence make her the target of ridicule&#8211;continue to go to balls and to teas at which Elaine thinks every moment, every day, &#8220;You cannot break me. You cannot hurt me. You cannot even make me notice you.&#8221; Over the next 150 pages&#8211;the story is 181 pages long&#8211;Evan and Elaine remake their story both for themselves and for the ton. Ms. Milan takes no shortcuts here. Evan knows he wronged Elaine grievously and yet, we the readers, privy to his thoughts, long for Elaine to see him as the man he has now is. And yet there is no way for Elaine to do so without first processing the anger and the pain his cruelty caused her. Elaine, like the very best of heroines, has learned to value herself. Evan must earn her trust, her respect, and, if the reader is very very lucky, her love. The story of Elaine and Evan is riveting enough on its own. Ms. Milan adds to it the redemption of Lady Stockhurst&#8217;s reputation as well. The way in which Elaine and her mother are made whole in the eyes of those who have demeaned them for over a decade is so glorious&#8230; really, it&#8217;s just sublime. So, if you have an hour or two and want to immerse yourself in a fiction that inspires, moves, and persuasively entertains, pick up Unlocked. It&#8217;s a rarity: a wallop of a tale neither too long nor too short. It&#8217;s a gift. &nbsp;"

I&#8217;ve liked the other two books in the series despite my normal &#8220;eh&#8221; response to most New Adult. I&#8217;ve liked the hero, Zach, in the other books and love the &#8220;virgin hero&#8221; trope.</p>\n<p>But, it was not to be. For starters, the premise of this book didn&#8217;t work for me. The heroine, Lark (she&#8217;s the best friend of May for those who&#8217;ve read the books), comes to the farm to recover from being kidnapped for ransom while working for a non-profit in Guatemala. She&#8217;s now back, struggling with PTSD, and trying to make peace with what happened there.</p>\n<p>But although the book is written in alternating first person, I couldn&#8217;t quite apprehend Lark. (And the way her kidnapping experience played out didn&#8217;t seem viable.) She stayed stuck in the pages for me. I didn&#8217;t know her and I found her hard to care about.</p>\n<p>I, however, loved Zach. His voice rings true and authentic and his life, as he tells it, is engaging and unusual. I even bought his falling in love at first sight with Lark. He is a wonderful man and it was lovely to watch him discover sex and intimacy.</p>\n<p>I am also a bit over the wondrousness of Shipley Farm and those who live there.  This book relies heavily on a reader caring about all who are a part of that community and, three books in, they are starting to seem flat to me&#8211;they aren&#8217;t evolving in interesting ways.</p>\n<p>Lastly, a very tricky relationship issue between Lark and another member of the community (not Zach) is resolved absurdly easily. Having this happen made the Shipley crowd seem even less like flawed, complex real people.</p>\n<p>The sex is great however! And the humor sparkles.</p>\n",
                "text": "I wanted to love this book. I&#8217;ve liked the other two books in the series despite my normal &#8220;eh&#8221; response to most New Adult. I&#8217;ve liked the hero, Zach, in the other books and love the &#8220;virgin hero&#8221; trope. But, it was not to be. For starters, the premise of this book didn&#8217;t work for me. The heroine, Lark (she&#8217;s the best friend of May for those who&#8217;ve read the books), comes to the farm to recover from being kidnapped for ransom while working for a non-profit in Guatemala. She&#8217;s now back, struggling with PTSD, and trying to make peace with what happened there. But although the book is written in alternating first person, I couldn&#8217;t quite apprehend Lark. (And the way her kidnapping experience played out didn&#8217;t seem viable.) She stayed stuck in the pages for me. I didn&#8217;t know her and I found her hard to care about. I, however, loved Zach. His voice rings true and authentic and his life, as he tells it, is engaging and unusual. I even bought his falling in love at first sight with Lark. He is a wonderful man and it was lovely to watch him discover sex and intimacy. I am also a bit over the wondrousness of Shipley Farm and those who live there.  This book relies heavily on a reader caring about all who are a part of that community and, three books in, they are starting to seem flat to me&#8211;they aren&#8217;t evolving in interesting ways. Lastly, a very tricky relationship issue between Lark and another member of the community (not Zach) is resolved absurdly easily. Having this happen made the Shipley crowd seem even less like flawed, complex real people. The sex is great however! And the humor sparkles."

            "content": {
                "html": "<p><a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/Woods-Dublin-Murder-Squad-Book-ebook/dp/B000U913EI/ref=as_li_ss_il?s=books&amp;ie=UTF8&amp;qid=1474505643&amp;sr=1-1&amp;refinements=p_82:B001H6IGWU,p_n_feature_browse-bin:618073011&amp;linkCode=li2&amp;tag=allaboutromance&amp;linkId=945669d95b26953553e9873564ce5263\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img decoding=\"async\" class=\"alignright\" src=\"//ws-na.amazon-adsystem.com/widgets/q?_encoding=UTF8&amp;ASIN=B000U913EI&amp;Format=_SL160_&amp;ID=AsinImage&amp;MarketPlace=US&amp;ServiceVersion=20070822&amp;WS=1&amp;tag=allaboutromance\" border=\"0\" /></a><img loading=\"lazy\" decoding=\"async\" style=\"border: none !important; margin: 0px !important;\" src=\"https://ir-na.amazon-adsystem.com/e/ir?t=allaboutromance&amp;l=li2&amp;o=1&amp;a=B000U913EI\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" border=\"0\" />In early summer of 2007, I picked up a mystery at the Regulator Bookshop. The cover was mildly menacing, black letters embellished with sharp pointed green branches spelled out Tana French <a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/Woods-Dublin-Murder-Squad-Book-ebook/dp/B000U913EI/ref=la_B001H6IGWU_1_1?s=books&amp;ie=UTF8&amp;qid=1474505643&amp;sr=1-1&amp;refinements=p_82%3AB001H6IGWU%2Cp_n_feature_browse-bin%3A618073011\"><strong>In the Woods</strong></a>. From the first lines of the book&#8217;s first chapter&#8211;<em>What I warn you to remember is that I am a detective. Our relationship with the truth is fundamental but cracked, refracting confusedly like fragmented glass</em>.&#8211;to its last I was entranced, unwilling to do anything but read.</p>\n<p><img loading=\"lazy\" decoding=\"async\" style=\"border: none !important; margin: 0px !important;\" src=\"https://ir-na.amazon-adsystem.com/e/ir?t=allaboutromance&amp;l=li2&amp;o=1&amp;a=B003NX764O\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" border=\"0\" />Since then, Ms. French has written six books&#8211;the <em><a href=\"http://amzn.to/2dioG2W\">Dublin Murder Squad</a></em> series&#8211;all with first person narrators, all loosely connected. My favorite of the set is <strong><a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B003NX764O/ref=series_dp_rw_ca_3\">Faithful Place.</a> </strong>My second is her latest, the intricate and satisfying <a href=\"http://amzn.to/2jNunYU\"><strong>The Trespasser</strong></a>, narrated by Detective Antoinette Conway.<img loading=\"lazy\" decoding=\"async\" style=\"border: none !important; margin: 0px !important;\" src=\"https://ir-na.amazon-adsystem.com/e/ir?t=allaboutromance&amp;l=li1&amp;o=1&amp;a=B003NX764O\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" border=\"0\" /></p>\n<p>Ms. French&#8217;s books are always about a murder but they&#8217;re never just that. Each is also about a particular time and place, always in Ireland, and explores the lives of those in the Murder Squad. As her detectives slowly piece together the story of the crime, they reveal the pith of their own lives. Neither is straightforward and no one comes out unscathed.<a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B003NX764O/ref=as_li_ss_il?ie=UTF8&amp;linkCode=li2&amp;tag=allaboutromance&amp;linkId=4e0ff4c29a7850c2e1649d6e80582596\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img decoding=\"async\" class=\"alignright\" src=\"//ws-na.amazon-adsystem.com/widgets/q?_encoding=UTF8&amp;ASIN=B003NX764O&amp;Format=_SL160_&amp;ID=AsinImage&amp;MarketPlace=US&amp;ServiceVersion=20070822&amp;WS=1&amp;tag=allaboutromance\" border=\"0\" /></a><img loading=\"lazy\" decoding=\"async\" style=\"border: none !important; margin: 0px !important;\" src=\"https://ir-na.amazon-adsystem.com/e/ir?t=allaboutromance&amp;l=li2&amp;o=1&amp;a=B003NX764O\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" border=\"0\" /><br />\nThe murder in this book is of a young woman, Aislinn Murray. Detective Antoinette Conway and her partner Stephen Moran get the case early one frozen Dublin dawn. The two head to the Stoneybatter, a neighborhood on the north side of the city where they find the victim.</p>\n<blockquote><p>She’s on her back, knock-kneed, like someone threw her there. One arm is by her side; the other is up over her head, bent at an awkward angle. She’s maybe five seven, skinny, wearing spike heels, plenty of fake tan, a tight-fitting cobalt-blue dress and a chunky fake-gold necklace. Her face is covered by blond hair, straightened and sprayed so ferociously that even murder hasn’t managed to mess it up. She looks like Dead Barbie.</p></blockquote>\n<p>Aislinn was clearly awaiting a date and when Conway and Moran find she&#8217;s got a bloke, they think he&#8217;s the likely killer. They bring him in and Antoinette questions him along with Breslin, one of the Murder Squad&#8217;s senior detectives.</p>\n<blockquote><p><span class=\"calibre7\"><span class=\"bq\">E</span></span><span class=\"bf\">veryone has an interview shtick. One guy on the squad does a beautiful line in Father Confessor, piling on the guilt and waving absolution like a doggy treat; another one does Narky Headmaster, staring over his glasses and snapping out questions. I do Warrior Woman, ready to rush out with her guns blazing and avenge all your wrongs, if you’ll just tell her what they are, and her flipside Stroppy Man-Hating Bitch when we want to piss off a rapist or a Neanderthal; I also do Cool Girl, who’s one of the lads and stands her round and has a laugh, who guys can talk to when they wouldn’t feel comfortable talking to another fella. Steve does Nice Boy Next Door and variations. With women, Breslin does Gallant Gentleman, taking their coats and bending his head to listen to every word; with guys he does Chief Jock, your best pal </span><span class=\"bf\">but you better stay on his good side or he’ll flush your head down the jacks. We size up the target and wheel out the one that we think has the best chance.</span></p>\n<p class=\"f\"><span class=\"q\">Rory doesn’t need Warrior Woman, at least as far as we know, and Stroppy Man-Hating Bitch would probably scare him under the table, but Cool Girl should relax him a notch or two. It sounds like he’d get on great with Nice Boy Next Door, but that’s out for now. I just hope Chief Jock doesn’t intimidate him enough, or piss me off enough, to send this whole thing off the rails.</span></p>\n</blockquote>\n<p class=\"f\">Antoinette loathes Rory, but then, Antoinette loathes most people. Her father, who abandoned her when she was young, was dark skinned and between Antoinette&#8217;s slightly foreign appearance and her  smart mouth, she&#8217;s always been hassled. Her Murder colleagues&#8211;she&#8217;s the only female&#8211;have made her life hell since her first month there two years ago and, at this point in her life, she&#8217;s almost always ready to blow. The only person she&#8217;s somewhat at ease with is Moran&#8211;he&#8217;s easy going and balances out her anger. Theirs isn&#8217;t a romance but it is a pairing which, in Ms. French&#8217;s books, usually ends in ruins.</p>\n<p class=\"f\">As the two delve into Aislinn&#8217;s life&#8211;and it&#8217;s worth noting that like Antoinette, Aislinn&#8217;s father vanished when she was ten&#8211;they are under pressure from Breslin and from their boss, Superintendent O&#8217;Kelly, to arrest Rory and wrap up the case. This pressure makes Antoinette wary but neither Antoinette nor the reader can be sure her doubts are viable or whether they&#8217;re the product of her resentments toward the department. And, as she and Moran, wend their way past obstacles, paperwork, disinformation, and lies to find who killed Aislinn, the things they discover about the case, the Squad and themselves become ever more threatening.</p>\n<p class=\"f\"><strong>The </strong><b>Trespasser</b>, like <strong>In the Woods</strong>, is a book I devoured. The prose is vivid and assured and Ms. French&#8217;s pacing and plotting expertly done. Her characters are among the realest I&#8217;ve read and oh how I hope to encounter all of them&#8211;Moran, Conway, Breslin, O&#8217;Kelly and the rest of the Murder Squad&#8211;again. The book is marred only by the portrayal of Aislinn&#8211;she lacks the tangibility the rest of Ms. French&#8217;s characters exude.</p>\n<p class=\"f\">Ms. French usually publishes a book every two years. Right now, that seems an interminable wait.</p>\n",
                "text": "In early summer of 2007, I picked up a mystery at the Regulator Bookshop. The cover was mildly menacing, black letters embellished with sharp pointed green branches spelled out Tana French In the Woods. From the first lines of the book&#8217;s first chapter&#8211;What I warn you to remember is that I am a detective. Our relationship with the truth is fundamental but cracked, refracting confusedly like fragmented glass.&#8211;to its last I was entranced, unwilling to do anything but read. Since then, Ms. French has written six books&#8211;the Dublin Murder Squad series&#8211;all with first person narrators, all loosely connected. My favorite of the set is Faithful Place. My second is her latest, the intricate and satisfying The Trespasser, narrated by Detective Antoinette Conway. Ms. French&#8217;s books are always about a murder but they&#8217;re never just that. Each is also about a particular time and place, always in Ireland, and explores the lives of those in the Murder Squad. As her detectives slowly piece together the story of the crime, they reveal the pith of their own lives. Neither is straightforward and no one comes out unscathed. The murder in this book is of a young woman, Aislinn Murray. Detective Antoinette Conway and her partner Stephen Moran get the case early one frozen Dublin dawn. The two head to the Stoneybatter, a neighborhood on the north side of the city where they find the victim. She’s on her back, knock-kneed, like someone threw her there. One arm is by her side; the other is up over her head, bent at an awkward angle. She’s maybe five seven, skinny, wearing spike heels, plenty of fake tan, a tight-fitting cobalt-blue dress and a chunky fake-gold necklace. Her face is covered by blond hair, straightened and sprayed so ferociously that even murder hasn’t managed to mess it up. She looks like Dead Barbie. Aislinn was clearly awaiting a date and when Conway and Moran find she&#8217;s got a bloke, they think he&#8217;s the likely killer. They bring him in and Antoinette questions him along with Breslin, one of the Murder Squad&#8217;s senior detectives. Everyone has an interview shtick. One guy on the squad does a beautiful line in Father Confessor, piling on the guilt and waving absolution like a doggy treat; another one does Narky Headmaster, staring over his glasses and snapping out questions. I do Warrior Woman, ready to rush out with her guns blazing and avenge all your wrongs, if you’ll just tell her what they are, and her flipside Stroppy Man-Hating Bitch when we want to piss off a rapist or a Neanderthal; I also do Cool Girl, who’s one of the lads and stands her round and has a laugh, who guys can talk to when they wouldn’t feel comfortable talking to another fella. Steve does Nice Boy Next Door and variations. With women, Breslin does Gallant Gentleman, taking their coats and bending his head to listen to every word; with guys he does Chief Jock, your best pal but you better stay on his good side or he’ll flush your head down the jacks. We size up the target and wheel out the one that we think has the best chance. Rory doesn’t need Warrior Woman, at least as far as we know, and Stroppy Man-Hating Bitch would probably scare him under the table, but Cool Girl should relax him a notch or two. It sounds like he’d get on great with Nice Boy Next Door, but that’s out for now. I just hope Chief Jock doesn’t intimidate him enough, or piss me off enough, to send this whole thing off the rails. Antoinette loathes Rory, but then, Antoinette loathes most people. Her father, who abandoned her when she was young, was dark skinned and between Antoinette&#8217;s slightly foreign appearance and her  smart mouth, she&#8217;s always been hassled. Her Murder colleagues&#8211;she&#8217;s the only female&#8211;have made her life hell since her first month there two years ago and, at this point in her life, she&#8217;s almost always ready to blow. The only person she&#8217;s somewhat at ease with is Moran&#8211;he&#8217;s easy going and balances out her anger. Theirs isn&#8217;t a romance but it is a pairing which, in Ms. French&#8217;s books, usually ends in ruins. As the two delve into Aislinn&#8217;s life&#8211;and it&#8217;s worth noting that like Antoinette, Aislinn&#8217;s father vanished when she was ten&#8211;they are under pressure from Breslin and from their boss, Superintendent O&#8217;Kelly, to arrest Rory and wrap up the case. This pressure makes Antoinette wary but neither Antoinette nor the reader can be sure her doubts are viable or whether they&#8217;re the product of her resentments toward the department. And, as she and Moran, wend their way past obstacles, paperwork, disinformation, and lies to find who killed Aislinn, the things they discover about the case, the Squad and themselves become ever more threatening. The Trespasser, like In the Woods, is a book I devoured. The prose is vivid and assured and Ms. French&#8217;s pacing and plotting expertly done. Her characters are among the realest I&#8217;ve read and oh how I hope to encounter all of them&#8211;Moran, Conway, Breslin, O&#8217;Kelly and the rest of the Murder Squad&#8211;again. The book is marred only by the portrayal of Aislinn&#8211;she lacks the tangibility the rest of Ms. French&#8217;s characters exude. Ms. French usually publishes a book every two years. Right now, that seems an interminable wait."
            }

                "html": "<p>Jennifer Egan’s a storied writer. She won the Pulitzer and the National Book Critics Circle Award in 2011 for <strong>Welcome to the Goon Squad</strong>. Her writings appear regularly in the <em>New York Times</em>.&nbsp;I’ve enjoyed all of Ms. Egan’s books but my favorite is her first <a href=\"http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/0307387526?ie=UTF8&amp;camp=1789&amp;creativeASIN=0307387526&amp;linkCode=xm2&amp;tag=allaboutromance\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"><strong>The Invisible Circus</strong></a>. I recommended it my 18 year old niece this summer and, after she returned it–she loved it–I read it again.</p>\n<p>The book is set in 1978. Phoebe O’Connor has just graduated from high school and is set to attend Berkeley in the fall. Phoebe’s life is&nbsp;to her, however, of little interest. Since her charismatic, troubled older sister Faith committed suicide when Phoebe was ten, Phoebe’s been&nbsp;frozen, unable to move into her future and obsessed with her sister’s past.</p>\n<p>A chance meeting in Golden Gate Park with one of the hippies in Faith’s&nbsp;group of wild and alluring friends sends Phoebe on a trip to Europe where she hopes to understand&nbsp;who her sister (Faith was eight years older) was and why she took her life. As is true for most coming of age journeys, the self Phoebe comes to know&nbsp;is her own.</p>\n<p>Ms. Egan prose immerses you in Phoebe, in her thoughts and her emotions. Phoebe travels the places her sister did in the months before her death and the each locale is vividly described, tinctured by Phoebe’s slow understanding of who she is.&nbsp;Halfway through the book, in Munich, Phoebe finds her sister’s old boyfriend, Wolf.&nbsp;<strong>The Invisible Circus</strong> isn’t a love story, but Phoebe’s and Wolf’s relationship is mesmerizing to read.</p>\n<p>Readers who expect the modern storytelling Ms. Egan utilized to great effect in <strong>The Keep</strong> and in <strong>Welcome to the Goon Squad</strong> will not find that here. Phoebe tells&nbsp;(though the book is not a first person narrative) her story straightforwardly. <strong>The Invisible Circus</strong> is an elegant novel about love and loss. It remains one of my favorite books.</p>\n",
                "text": "Jennifer Egan’s a storied writer. She won the Pulitzer and the National Book Critics Circle Award in 2011 for Welcome to the Goon Squad. Her writings appear regularly in the New York Times.&nbsp;I’ve enjoyed all of Ms. Egan’s books but my favorite is her first The Invisible Circus. I recommended it my 18 year old niece this summer and, after she returned it–she loved it–I read it again. The book is set in 1978. Phoebe O’Connor has just graduated from high school and is set to attend Berkeley in the fall. Phoebe’s life is&nbsp;to her, however, of little interest. Since her charismatic, troubled older sister Faith committed suicide when Phoebe was ten, Phoebe’s been&nbsp;frozen, unable to move into her future and obsessed with her sister’s past. A chance meeting in Golden Gate Park with one of the hippies in Faith’s&nbsp;group of wild and alluring friends sends Phoebe on a trip to Europe where she hopes to understand&nbsp;who her sister (Faith was eight years older) was and why she took her life. As is true for most coming of age journeys, the self Phoebe comes to know&nbsp;is her own. Ms. Egan prose immerses you in Phoebe, in her thoughts and her emotions. Phoebe travels the places her sister did in the months before her death and the each locale is vividly described, tinctured by Phoebe’s slow understanding of who she is.&nbsp;Halfway through the book, in Munich, Phoebe finds her sister’s old boyfriend, Wolf.&nbsp;The Invisible Circus isn’t a love story, but Phoebe’s and Wolf’s relationship is mesmerizing to read. Readers who expect the modern storytelling Ms. Egan utilized to great effect in The Keep and in Welcome to the Goon Squad will not find that here. Phoebe tells&nbsp;(though the book is not a first person narrative) her story straightforwardly. The Invisible Circus is an elegant novel about love and loss. It remains one of my favorite books."

            "content": {
                "html": "<p><b>Marrying Winterborne</b> the second book in Lisa Kleypas&#8217;s dearly anticipated <b><i>Ravenels</i></b> series, begins with Lady Helen Ravenel calling on Rhys Winterborne, a man to whom she was briefly engaged. As almost anyone who read the first book, <a href=\"http://amzn.to/1Wofa10\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><b>A Cold Hearted Rake</b></a>, will tell you, Rhys and his passion for Helen utterly upstaged that story&#8217;s lovers and left historical romance readers longing for more.</p>\n<p>And more, wonderfully more, readers do indeed get. <b>Marrying Winterborne</b> is as engrossing a story as any of Ms. Kleypas&#8217;s earlier works&#8211;my favorite is <a href=\"http://amzn.to/1UgL3VP\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><b>It Happened One Autumn</b></a>&#8211;and, in it, her writing is as good as it&#8217;s ever been.</p>\n<p>The plot is, on the surface, a familiar one. Helen and Rhys, she an aristocrat and he a self-made magnate, are compromised&#8211;deliciously&#8211;and agree, again, to wed. Despite a sharing a desperate attraction for one another, their relationship is challenged by internal and external obstacles. Sounds conventional, right? It&#8217;s not.</p>\n<p>For starters, Helen and Rhys <i>decide</i> to have Rhys compromise Helen so that their marriage will be a fait accompli and they both <i>thoroughly</i> enjoy Helen&#8217;s ruination. Rhys has burned for Helen since she nursed him back from a train accident in <b>A Cold Hearted Rake</b>. In that book, it seemed his passion was too overwhelming for Helen. This, however, isn&#8217;t the case. Helen is every bit as drawn to Rhys. She knows little of men but when Rhys kisses her, she knows that, that, is what she wants.</p>\n<blockquote><p><i>She had never imagined that a man would kiss her as if he were trying to breathe her in, as if kisses were words meant for poems, or honey to be gathered with his tongue.</i></p></blockquote>\n<p>Helen realizes being Rhys&#8217;s wife will challenge her in ways she can&#8217;t fathom&#8211;he runs an department store empire and his background is wildly different than hers&#8211;but that unknown future is exciting and full of possibilities. In that, it&#8217;s appealingly different from the life she thought she&#8217;d have, one in which she&#8217;d</p>\n<blockquote><p><i>meet an eligible man her family would approve of. A member of the landed gentry, bland and reserved, with a very tall forehead. He would expect her to make his wishes her own.</i></p></blockquote>\n<p>Rhys isn&#8217;t that man. He&#8217;s from a working class Welsh family, a self-made man and a fearsome competitor, someone who breaks more rules than he follows. He values his fortune with the fervor of one raised terribly poor and, other than Helen, he&#8217;s never needed anyone. But he <i>needs</i> Helen. As he tells her in one of the book&#8217;s many romantic passages, when he is with her, he is, for the first time, complete.</p>\n<p>Helen and Rhys are smashing together&#8211;there isn&#8217;t a scene they share that doesn&#8217;t serve their love story. Each word and touch they exchange is <i>making love, </i>creating an abiding and encompassing relationship. Their love scenes are aren&#8217;t just erotic, they&#8217;re intimate. The two cherish everything&#8211;body, heart,and mind&#8211;about each other. Their Happily Ever After seems inevitable not because of the demands of the genre but because they belong with one another.</p>\n<p>Ms. Kleypas creates a vivid context for her lovers. Rhys&#8217;s department store, Winterborne&#8217;s, is intricately displayed. Ms. Kleypas shows us not just the comforts of the age&#8211;all of which Rhys sells&#8211;but its squalid, impoverished scourges&#8211;the tenements, the orphanages, the sewage strewn streets. She renders Rhys a businessman with a social reformer&#8217;s standards and Helen an aristocrat with the same. Rhys is a pragmatic man for whom the success of his business is enhanced by his progressive commercial choices. He hires women when they are the best people for the job. He cares about the health and well-being of his workers, in large part, because doing so makes them more productive. He&#8217;s a man of his times, not ours, who stands up to modern scrutiny.</p>\n<p>Rhys&#8217;s world is that of Winterborne&#8217;s; Helen&#8217;s is her family. The Ravenels are a intriguing bunch, especially her twin younger sisters, Cassandra and Pandora&#8211;the latter of whom will be matched with Gabriel, Sebastian&#8217;s and Evie&#8217;s (from <a href=\"http://amzn.to/1qP7nvp\"><strong>A Devil in Winter</strong></a>) son in the next book, <a href=\"http://amzn.to/1XCENu3\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><strong>A Devil in Spring</strong></a>.</p>\n<p>This book abounds with strong female characters. I especially enjoyed Dr. Garrett Gibson, a supremely confident physician Rhys employs, and Lady Berwick, the Ravenels&#8217; chaperone, whose insistence on deportment belies her determination for the young women she mentors to thrive in the male run Regency world.</p>\n<p>After I finished <b>A Cold Hearted Rake</b>, I went back and reread some of Ms. Kleypas&#8217;s earlier Avon historicals. After I finished <b>Marrying Winterborne</b>, I went back to page one and began reading the book again. It&#8217;s damn near perfect. Its flaws seem small compared to all that is great within it. There are a few times where Rhys seemed unbelievably rigid in his assessment of others. The major obstacle to Helen and Rhys&#8217;s happiness is one that, to a modern eye, seems somewhat overblown. Honestly, none of this bothered me.</p>\n<p><b>Marrying Winterborne</b> has everything I could want in a romance: Appealing leads, great secondary characters I can&#8217;t wait to see more of, a convincing love story, wonderfully torrid scenes, elegant prose, and a wry sense of mirth. It gets an A from me.</p>\n",
                "text": "Marrying Winterborne the second book in Lisa Kleypas&#8217;s dearly anticipated Ravenels series, begins with Lady Helen Ravenel calling on Rhys Winterborne, a man to whom she was briefly engaged. As almost anyone who read the first book, A Cold Hearted Rake, will tell you, Rhys and his passion for Helen utterly upstaged that story&#8217;s lovers and left historical romance readers longing for more. And more, wonderfully more, readers do indeed get. Marrying Winterborne is as engrossing a story as any of Ms. Kleypas&#8217;s earlier works&#8211;my favorite is It Happened One Autumn&#8211;and, in it, her writing is as good as it&#8217;s ever been. The plot is, on the surface, a familiar one. Helen and Rhys, she an aristocrat and he a self-made magnate, are compromised&#8211;deliciously&#8211;and agree, again, to wed. Despite a sharing a desperate attraction for one another, their relationship is challenged by internal and external obstacles. Sounds conventional, right? It&#8217;s not. For starters, Helen and Rhys decide to have Rhys compromise Helen so that their marriage will be a fait accompli and they both thoroughly enjoy Helen&#8217;s ruination. Rhys has burned for Helen since she nursed him back from a train accident in A Cold Hearted Rake. In that book, it seemed his passion was too overwhelming for Helen. This, however, isn&#8217;t the case. Helen is every bit as drawn to Rhys. She knows little of men but when Rhys kisses her, she knows that, that, is what she wants. She had never imagined that a man would kiss her as if he were trying to breathe her in, as if kisses were words meant for poems, or honey to be gathered with his tongue. Helen realizes being Rhys&#8217;s wife will challenge her in ways she can&#8217;t fathom&#8211;he runs an department store empire and his background is wildly different than hers&#8211;but that unknown future is exciting and full of possibilities. In that, it&#8217;s appealingly different from the life she thought she&#8217;d have, one in which she&#8217;d meet an eligible man her family would approve of. A member of the landed gentry, bland and reserved, with a very tall forehead. He would expect her to make his wishes her own. Rhys isn&#8217;t that man. He&#8217;s from a working class Welsh family, a self-made man and a fearsome competitor, someone who breaks more rules than he follows. He values his fortune with the fervor of one raised terribly poor and, other than Helen, he&#8217;s never needed anyone. But he needs Helen. As he tells her in one of the book&#8217;s many romantic passages, when he is with her, he is, for the first time, complete. Helen and Rhys are smashing together&#8211;there isn&#8217;t a scene they share that doesn&#8217;t serve their love story. Each word and touch they exchange is making love, creating an abiding and encompassing relationship. Their love scenes are aren&#8217;t just erotic, they&#8217;re intimate. The two cherish everything&#8211;body, heart,and mind&#8211;about each other. Their Happily Ever After seems inevitable not because of the demands of the genre but because they belong with one another. Ms. Kleypas creates a vivid context for her lovers. Rhys&#8217;s department store, Winterborne&#8217;s, is intricately displayed. Ms. Kleypas shows us not just the comforts of the age&#8211;all of which Rhys sells&#8211;but its squalid, impoverished scourges&#8211;the tenements, the orphanages, the sewage strewn streets. She renders Rhys a businessman with a social reformer&#8217;s standards and Helen an aristocrat with the same. Rhys is a pragmatic man for whom the success of his business is enhanced by his progressive commercial choices. He hires women when they are the best people for the job. He cares about the health and well-being of his workers, in large part, because doing so makes them more productive. He&#8217;s a man of his times, not ours, who stands up to modern scrutiny. Rhys&#8217;s world is that of Winterborne&#8217;s; Helen&#8217;s is her family. The Ravenels are a intriguing bunch, especially her twin younger sisters, Cassandra and Pandora&#8211;the latter of whom will be matched with Gabriel, Sebastian&#8217;s and Evie&#8217;s (from A Devil in Winter) son in the next book, A Devil in Spring. This book abounds with strong female characters. I especially enjoyed Dr. Garrett Gibson, a supremely confident physician Rhys employs, and Lady Berwick, the Ravenels&#8217; chaperone, whose insistence on deportment belies her determination for the young women she mentors to thrive in the male run Regency world. After I finished A Cold Hearted Rake, I went back and reread some of Ms. Kleypas&#8217;s earlier Avon historicals. After I finished Marrying Winterborne, I went back to page one and began reading the book again. It&#8217;s damn near perfect. Its flaws seem small compared to all that is great within it. There are a few times where Rhys seemed unbelievably rigid in his assessment of others. The major obstacle to Helen and Rhys&#8217;s happiness is one that, to a modern eye, seems somewhat overblown. Honestly, none of this bothered me. Marrying Winterborne has everything I could want in a romance: Appealing leads, great secondary characters I can&#8217;t wait to see more of, a convincing love story, wonderfully torrid scenes, elegant prose, and a wry sense of mirth. It gets an A from me."

            "content": {
                "html": "<p><em>When does something begin and end? The ripples from a stone cast into a pond, do they start with the smoothness of the pebble that first attracts the eye, the impulse to feel it against your palm, to make it skip over water&#8230; do they end with the last tiny lap of a wave on the distant shore&#8230;</em></p>\n<p>These are the opening words of <b>The Slow Burn of Silence</b> by Loreth Anne White. Their obliqueness and the craft in the question made me want to read on. I&#8217;m glad I did. From beginning to almost end, <b>Slow Burn of Silence</b> had me flipping the pages, absorbed, wondering what would happen next.</p>\n<p>Rachel Salonen has just lost her sister and brother-in-law to a terrible fire. She has been granted the guardianship of their only child, her niece Quinn. While at the lawyer&#8217;s office to go over the details, Rachel is stunned to learn Quinn&#8217;s birth parents are Jeb Cullen, the love of Rachel&#8217;s life, and Amy Findlay, the woman he was accused of kidnapping, assaulting, and raping nine years ago. Jeb has spent those nine years in prison, put there in part by the testimony of Rachel and others. Amy never really recovered from the violence done to her and, finally, recently committed suicide.</p>\n<p>Rachel is beyond stunned when the lawyer tells her, for the past five years, her sister Sophia has been working with the University of British Columbia’s Innocence Project to get Jeb freed. Jeb has always sworn he is innocent of the crimes against Amy and her still missing friend Merilee. Rachel has never believed him and has never forgiven him for not being the young man she she thought he was when they were in love. Rachel asks the lawyer if Jeb knows Quinn was adopted by her sister; he tells her Jeb was never told where his daughter was placed.</p>\n<p>Six months later, Rachel and Quinn have moved to Snowy River, the small mountain town Rachel grew up in, and into her family&#8217;s old home. It&#8217;s not been easy on either of them. Rachel is running the small town newspaper her father left her last year and trying to raise a clearly distant and angry eight year old girl. Rachel&#8217;s exhausted, sad, and stressed and then, something happens that terrifies her. Her sister&#8217;s work with the Innocence Project has paid off and Jeb Cullen has been released from prison.</p>\n<p>When someone matching Jeb&#8217;s description is seen talking to Quinn on the playground, Rachel is sure he&#8217;s come to do her harm. She heads immediately to the police station and shares her fear with her old friend Adam LeFleur, the Deputy Chief Constable.</p>\n<p><i>“What if he does come back?” I say softly. “Can we stop him from being here?” </i></p>\n<p>“Cullen’s conviction was overturned. He’s as free as the next guy to go wherever he pleases. Law enforcement has no control over his movements. But there is also no reason for him to come back here.”</p>\n<p>“What about that land his mother left him, on the Wolf River?”</p>\n<p>“It’s derelict. There’s nothing there for him. He’d be insane to even try to make something work here. He’s not welcome in Snowy Creek, Rachel, and he knows it. What he did to those girls—people here will crucify him for it if he returns. There’s still so much residual anger, hell knows what might happen if he sets foot in this town. I’m not sure I could control it.”</p>\n<p>“What if it’s revenge he wants? For us testifying? You know, like that felon who comes after his lawyer in that old movie Cape Fear.”</p>\n<p>Adam hesitates. “You’re thinking he might go after your niece to get at you, is that what this is about? You think he’ll come after our children, just to mess with our heads?”</p>\n<p>I bite my lip. Deep down, even now, in spite of what I’ve been led to believe about Jeb, in spite of all the evidence presented in court, in spite of my own fears, in spite of today, I can’t fully accept he’s capable. When it comes to Jeb, I can’t think clearly.</p>\n<p>Adam is wrong about Jeb, however. Jeb has two very good reasons to return to Snowy River. The first is to clear his name and find the real criminals behind the crimes he took the fall for. The second is to see Quinn who, thanks to Sophia, he knows is his.</p>\n<p><b>The Slow Burn of Silence</b> is written from several different perspectives but the two given the largest voice are those of Jeb and Rachel. They are reliable narrators and thus, from the moment Jeb appears back in Snowy Creek, ready to dig up the past and find the truth someone there has hidden for the past nine years, the reader believes him.</p>\n<p>Rachel, initially does not. She loved him deeply as a young girl and believed he loved her. On the night Amy and Merilee went missing, Rachel and Jeb argued. Jeb consoled himself by having sex with Amy. When Amy showed up, days later, beaten, pregnant, and with no memory of what had happened to her, Rachel believed the worst of Jeb. In the years that have passed, she&#8217;s wondered not if he was guilty but how could she have so misjudged him.</p>\n<p>Jeb, though, is determined to clear his name and prove to Rachel, the world, and the little girl who has his eyes that he is the man Rachel thought he was. And, when he is brutally attacked by three men in the masks, Rachel takes him in, despite her fear, and slowly, oh so slowly, begins to see him as he is and has always been: a man worthy of her love.</p>\n<p><b>The Slow Burn of Silence</b> is an excellent read on many levels. The book is a gripping mystery. Ms. White fills her books with a host of richly developed characters, all of whom have secrets. The varying voices are well done&#8211;I especially liked the nuanced portrayal of the women married to the men who had condemned Jeb nine years ago. These are wives who love their husbands and children and who protect their families in ways that are poignant and sympathetic. The mystery loses a bit of its hold in the last third of the book when it becomes obvious who really behaved monstrously nine years ago but, though the mystery ebbs, the suspense continues to build. Rachel, Jeb, Quinn and others in Snowy Creek are in genuine danger and Ms. White spins out the tension until the last chapter.</p>\n<p><b>The Slow Burn of Silence</b> is also a damn good romance. Rachel and Jeb are hot together, but, the past they share is difficult for them&#8211;especially Rachel&#8211;to move past. Their relationship is made more complicated by Quinn who instinctively trusts Jeb without knowing who he is. It&#8217;s easy for Rachel, once she believes in Jeb&#8217;s innocence, to fear Quinn being taken away by her father. For his part, Jeb treads carefully with Quinn, knowing that if his plan fails, he&#8217;ll do her no favors by claiming her as his own.</p>\n<p>It&#8217;s hard to write stand alone romantic suspense where both the romance and the suspense make my pulse pound. <b>The Slow Burn of Silence</b> is such a book.</p>\n<p>I&#8217;ve read all of Ms. White&#8217;s recent romantic suspense and enjoyed them. This one, though, is still my favorite.</p>\n",
                "text": "When does something begin and end? The ripples from a stone cast into a pond, do they start with the smoothness of the pebble that first attracts the eye, the impulse to feel it against your palm, to make it skip over water&#8230; do they end with the last tiny lap of a wave on the distant shore&#8230; These are the opening words of The Slow Burn of Silence by Loreth Anne White. Their obliqueness and the craft in the question made me want to read on. I&#8217;m glad I did. From beginning to almost end, Slow Burn of Silence had me flipping the pages, absorbed, wondering what would happen next. Rachel Salonen has just lost her sister and brother-in-law to a terrible fire. She has been granted the guardianship of their only child, her niece Quinn. While at the lawyer&#8217;s office to go over the details, Rachel is stunned to learn Quinn&#8217;s birth parents are Jeb Cullen, the love of Rachel&#8217;s life, and Amy Findlay, the woman he was accused of kidnapping, assaulting, and raping nine years ago. Jeb has spent those nine years in prison, put there in part by the testimony of Rachel and others. Amy never really recovered from the violence done to her and, finally, recently committed suicide. Rachel is beyond stunned when the lawyer tells her, for the past five years, her sister Sophia has been working with the University of British Columbia’s Innocence Project to get Jeb freed. Jeb has always sworn he is innocent of the crimes against Amy and her still missing friend Merilee. Rachel has never believed him and has never forgiven him for not being the young man she she thought he was when they were in love. Rachel asks the lawyer if Jeb knows Quinn was adopted by her sister; he tells her Jeb was never told where his daughter was placed. Six months later, Rachel and Quinn have moved to Snowy River, the small mountain town Rachel grew up in, and into her family&#8217;s old home. It&#8217;s not been easy on either of them. Rachel is running the small town newspaper her father left her last year and trying to raise a clearly distant and angry eight year old girl. Rachel&#8217;s exhausted, sad, and stressed and then, something happens that terrifies her. Her sister&#8217;s work with the Innocence Project has paid off and Jeb Cullen has been released from prison. When someone matching Jeb&#8217;s description is seen talking to Quinn on the playground, Rachel is sure he&#8217;s come to do her harm. She heads immediately to the police station and shares her fear with her old friend Adam LeFleur, the Deputy Chief Constable. “What if he does come back?” I say softly. “Can we stop him from being here?” “Cullen’s conviction was overturned. He’s as free as the next guy to go wherever he pleases. Law enforcement has no control over his movements. But there is also no reason for him to come back here.” “What about that land his mother left him, on the Wolf River?” “It’s derelict. There’s nothing there for him. He’d be insane to even try to make something work here. He’s not welcome in Snowy Creek, Rachel, and he knows it. What he did to those girls—people here will crucify him for it if he returns. There’s still so much residual anger, hell knows what might happen if he sets foot in this town. I’m not sure I could control it.” “What if it’s revenge he wants? For us testifying? You know, like that felon who comes after his lawyer in that old movie Cape Fear.” Adam hesitates. “You’re thinking he might go after your niece to get at you, is that what this is about? You think he’ll come after our children, just to mess with our heads?” I bite my lip. Deep down, even now, in spite of what I’ve been led to believe about Jeb, in spite of all the evidence presented in court, in spite of my own fears, in spite of today, I can’t fully accept he’s capable. When it comes to Jeb, I can’t think clearly. Adam is wrong about Jeb, however. Jeb has two very good reasons to return to Snowy River. The first is to clear his name and find the real criminals behind the crimes he took the fall for. The second is to see Quinn who, thanks to Sophia, he knows is his. The Slow Burn of Silence is written from several different perspectives but the two given the largest voice are those of Jeb and Rachel. They are reliable narrators and thus, from the moment Jeb appears back in Snowy Creek, ready to dig up the past and find the truth someone there has hidden for the past nine years, the reader believes him. Rachel, initially does not. She loved him deeply as a young girl and believed he loved her. On the night Amy and Merilee went missing, Rachel and Jeb argued. Jeb consoled himself by having sex with Amy. When Amy showed up, days later, beaten, pregnant, and with no memory of what had happened to her, Rachel believed the worst of Jeb. In the years that have passed, she&#8217;s wondered not if he was guilty but how could she have so misjudged him. Jeb, though, is determined to clear his name and prove to Rachel, the world, and the little girl who has his eyes that he is the man Rachel thought he was. And, when he is brutally attacked by three men in the masks, Rachel takes him in, despite her fear, and slowly, oh so slowly, begins to see him as he is and has always been: a man worthy of her love. The Slow Burn of Silence is an excellent read on many levels. The book is a gripping mystery. Ms. White fills her books with a host of richly developed characters, all of whom have secrets. The varying voices are well done&#8211;I especially liked the nuanced portrayal of the women married to the men who had condemned Jeb nine years ago. These are wives who love their husbands and children and who protect their families in ways that are poignant and sympathetic. The mystery loses a bit of its hold in the last third of the book when it becomes obvious who really behaved monstrously nine years ago but, though the mystery ebbs, the suspense continues to build. Rachel, Jeb, Quinn and others in Snowy Creek are in genuine danger and Ms. White spins out the tension until the last chapter. The Slow Burn of Silence is also a damn good romance. Rachel and Jeb are hot together, but, the past they share is difficult for them&#8211;especially Rachel&#8211;to move past. Their relationship is made more complicated by Quinn who instinctively trusts Jeb without knowing who he is. It&#8217;s easy for Rachel, once she believes in Jeb&#8217;s innocence, to fear Quinn being taken away by her father. For his part, Jeb treads carefully with Quinn, knowing that if his plan fails, he&#8217;ll do her no favors by claiming her as his own. It&#8217;s hard to write stand alone romantic suspense where both the romance and the suspense make my pulse pound. The Slow Burn of Silence is such a book. I&#8217;ve read all of Ms. White&#8217;s recent romantic suspense and enjoyed them. This one, though, is still my favorite."
            }

                "html": "<p>I began the book the evening I downloaded it and stayed up until after one, unable to put it down until I got to its end. Yes. I read <b>Edge of Obsession</b> obsessively and I enjoyed the hell out of it.</p>\n<p>The book begins with a précis of the world as is now is.</p>\n<blockquote><p><i>A hundred years ago, or so the stories went, the great Storms came over the course of a few tumultuous decades and kicked the world’s ass. Cities fell. Seas rose. People died.</i></p></blockquote>\n<p>A lot of people.</p>\n<p>It’s dystopia as written by Buffy which means I, of course, loved it.</p>\n<p>In this world, life sucks for pretty much everyone except for the superrich–who don’t figure in this book–and the raiders.</p>\n<blockquote><p><i>Harsh times bred hard men. And the hardest of these by far were the bands of raiders—groups of men who laughed in the face of what governments remained and chose to live free instead. These men took over the new, remote eastern islands that remained when the storms passed, in what was left of the Appalachian mountain range in the northeast. They swore fealty only to their chosen clans and the kings who won their thrones with strength and maintained them with cunning. They prized their brotherhoods above all else, carved their oaths into their skin and made their vows in blood and battle.</i></p>\n<p>&#8230; Years passed, and in the darkness, the raiders became the monsters of their new world. Scary stories whispered around the fire, when the cold nights drew near. Dangerous men who came in the night in their terrible ships and took what they wanted, whenever they wanted.</p></blockquote>\n<p>Tyr is the war chief of his Viking-like raider clan. He and a raiding party are on the Mainland when someone shoots at them. This surprises them because only morons use guns–the bullets are waterlogged and the ancient machines malfunction more than they work. The raiders track the shooter to a compound filled with Mainlanders. (The Mainlanders are most of what’s left of the country’s population.) In the compound is Helena, a smart-mouthed woman who not only stands up to Tyr but subjects him to well-constructed, very sarcastic insults. Tyr is beyond startled. In his experience, compliant women (this is what Mainstream women are called due to the sex-limiting religion/social construct they follow) either are terrified of raiders or they beg to be taken so they may become camp girls (the raiders are known for their very sex-positive culture.)</p>\n<p>Helena has her reasons for challenging the raider. She’s desperate to get out of the compound. She’s being hunted by Krajic–a Very Bad Man–and she has a secret mission she must complete. She pushes Tyr to the point that he has no choice but to take her captive. It doesn’t take much. Tyr and Helena have a molten chemistry–over the top, crazy, and insanely hot. He has to have her.</p>\n<p>Helena and Tyr travel back to the raiders’ home where Helena realizes everything she’s ever learned about these barbarians is a lie. Yes, they do have all kinds of sex all over the place all the time – this is in stark contrast to the mainland culture where sex occurs only in tepid winter marriages (they last just the winter) and is done only with the goal of procreation – and the raiders are swaggeringly arrogant. But the culture they’ve created is far better, and far more just, than any Helena has ever seen.</p>\n<p>It’s not just the lure of the raider world that&#8217;s keeping Helena from trying to escape and continue on her mission. There’s the phenomenal sex life she has with Tyr which is inventive, playful, expansive, and addicting. Unfortunately for Helena, Tyr and his king, the wonderfully rendered Wulf, suspect that Helena may be a spy. The man chasing Helena is the man who butchered Tyr’s brother and if there’s even a chance that Helena is in cahoots with Krajic, Tyr himself will have to execute her.</p>\n<p>Tyr and Helena are a wonderful couple. They’re snarky, smart, funny, and very smutty. <b>Edge of Obsession</b> begins as a Viking takes a captive romance but quickly becomes a story of two equals. Helena is trying to do something no one else in her world is trying to do and never does she give up on that goal. She’s a powerhouse and Tyr never tries to make her anything less.</p>\n<p>It’s the rare post-apocalyptic Viking erotic romance that has intricate, complex, thoughtful world-building. Ms. Crane’s done a fabulous job here–she gives just enough information about the past for her future to make sense but keeps the focus on the here and now. Her world and its inhabitants are fascinating. I’ll read the rest of the series just to see how she spins out the clearly coming conflict between the kings of the West and their wealthy corrupt bishops and the raiders and – maybe? – the downtrodden Mainlanders.</p>\n<p>At the end of the book, I felt it wobbled. In the novel’s final confrontation, Tyr is more violent than smart and I had a hard time believing the raiders would have made some of the choices they did. Additionally, the writing, especially that describing Helena’s and Tyr’s thoughts about their relationship, was overdone.</p>\n<p>These concerns, however, didn’t keep me from enjoying the book. I’ve already started on the next in the <b><i>Edge</i></b> series, <b>Edge of Temptation</b>. I’m hooked and I’m happy. And a little bit flushed….</p>\n<h3><strong>Buy it at <a href=\"http://amzn.to/2wBdNS6\">Amazon</a>/<a href=\"https://geo.itunes.apple.com/us/book/edge-of-obsession/id1050610001?mt=11&amp;at=1010lmPQ\">iBooks</a>/<a href=\"http://www.anrdoezrs.net/links/8039827/type/dlg/http://www.barnesandnoble.com/w/edge-of-obsession-megan-crane/1122822816?ean=9781466885325\">Barnes &amp; Noble</a>/<a href=\"http://click.linksynergy.com/fs-bin/click?id=b95pXvP*dp4&amp;subid=&amp;offerid=361251.1&amp;type=10&amp;tmpid=9310&amp;RD_PARM1=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.kobo.com%2Fus%2Fen%2Febook%2Fedge-of-obsession\">Kobo</a></strong></h3>\n",

Helena is trying to do something no one else in her world is trying to do and never does she give up on that goal. She’s a powerhouse and Tyr never tries to make her anything less. It’s the rare post-apocalyptic Viking erotic romance that has intricate, complex, thoughtful world-building. Ms. Crane’s done a fabulous job here–she gives just enough information about the past for her future to make sense but keeps the focus on the here and now. Her world and its inhabitants are fascinating. I’ll read the rest of the series just to see how she spins out the clearly coming conflict between the kings of the West and their wealthy corrupt bishops and the raiders and – maybe? – the downtrodden Mainlanders. At the end of the book, I felt it wobbled. In the novel’s final confrontation, Tyr is more violent than smart and I had a hard time believing the raiders would have made some of the choices they did. Additionally, the writing, especially that describing Helena’s and Tyr’s thoughts about their relationship, was overdone. These concerns, however, didn’t keep me from enjoying the book. I’ve already started on the next in the Edge series, Edge of Temptation. I’m hooked and I’m happy. And a little bit flushed…. Buy it at Amazon/iBooks/Barnes &amp; Noble/Kobo"
