Never having read Smith before I had no idea that I was in for a marathon of nonstop reading while my home went to hell all around me. Having more experience with Smith’s books, was it what you were expecting? Did you like it? Dabney: I did. And as for what I was expecting, I’d have to say that one of the cool things about Ms. Smith’s work is that each book is wildly different. They all are sci-fi erotica/romance, but the plot and characters in each are distinctly different. In Heat, another book by Ms. Smith I like, the setting is Earth, there are just two aliens, and there are two compelling love stories. Heat is gripping because it’s a thriller, with one alien working against the clock to stop the other. That sense of urgency is missing in The Last Hour of Gann but the latter is just as interesting. Wendy: This book was certainly different from any of the other romances I’ve read. Inter-species love has been explored before, of course, but never so successfully and somehow realistically, in my opinion. That the main characters were different species seemed not as much a means of titillating readers as it was a natural progression of a fantastic, sexy, romance. Dabney: I have to say, other than Heat, I’ve don&#8217;t think I&#8217;ve read another alien/human love story. I read hardly any paranormal romance. What intrigues me about the world Ms. Lee creates in is the way she uses an alien culture as a measure of our own. The world of Gann is one in which men have all the power, sex is either a means of violence or a means of procreation, and religious mandates are the law. As I read the novel, I kept comparing and contrasting the planet of Gann&#8211;Ms. Smith’s world-building is so detailed and believable&#8211;to our own. It’s a book that made me think. Wendy: She does hold a mirror up to our world! It also incorporates environmental issues, religious beliefs, societal pressures, and other heavy topics such as the result of inter-global war. And yes, it made me think, and keep thinking. I couldn’t decide if it was a cautionary tale or some sort of funny, erotic, pseudo-inspirational (just writing that makes me grin). There are so many things I want to talk about! What aspect of the book affected you the most deeply? Dabney: One of the most perplexing things of living in modern society is trying to judge – and boy is that a loaded word – the culture and customs of others. In The Last Hour of Gann, the mores of that planet allow for behaviors that, were they on Earth, would be morally abhorrent. The most striking example of this is the sex Meoraq is allowed/expected to have with the women in each city he comes to as a high priest. The women have no say in this. They literally bend over and are taken by Meoraq after he wins the battles that serve as trials on Gann. In our culture we would call that rape. But Gann is not Earth and Meoraq is not, in the context of his world, a villain. In that context, his behavior is exemplary. In The Last Hour of Gann, that planet’s past actions were so destructive that the civilization that sprung up in their wake is a rigid and unforgiving one. It’s a culture I’d loathe to live in. And yet clearly the ruinous choices those on Gann made long ago are echoed in choices we are making today. I have to admit I’ve rarely read erotic romance that made me think so hard about the sociology of civilizations. Wendy: Yes, I kept comparing Gann’s history to our current civilization and to the world that Amber left behind, our future. It all seemed so bleak. So what kind of genius does Smith have that in the midst of all the misadventure and strife she also demonstrated a great sense of humor? Meoraq made me laugh so many times. The way he would pray for patience, and ask his god why he couldn’t be a dick without his god catching him at it was just priceless. Did you also find him funny? Amber was amusing too, and I felt that the fact they both shared a dry sense of humor and the ability to laugh at their troubles added a wonderful flavor to their romance. Dabney: Yes. This book has it all: rollicking humor, hot sex, grave danger, weighty ideas, and characters that are believable and sympathetic. Meoraq is a great hero; even as he is a warrior and a lizard-man of decisive action he is constantly thinking, questioning himself and his religion, and challenging himself to do the right thing. Furthermore he is funny. His relationship with Amber was wonderful in part because he, the alien, enables her to be the fabulous person she is. When we first meet Amber, she’s strong but lacking in empathy. On Earth, the society she lived in was so hellish that all she could do was get out of there. On Gann, despite the horrific things she and the other humans experience, Amber becomes every bit as heroic as Meoraq. I loved them as a couple. Wendy: Oh absolutely! They’re the best couple of 2013 for me. I thought at first that the sex-with-an-alien thing would be off-putting, but in that regard their species became unimportant and it was all about the chemistry, which they had by the truckload. That portion of the book where Meoraq and Amber were in the wilderness alone was just wonderful, wasn’t it? But then, how did you feel about the violence and treachery and rape that followed? I normally skim through all that stuff because it feels gratuitous most of the time, but here it felt like a natural progression of events &#8211; necessary for the ending to work. Dabney: I wasn’t bothered by all the mayhem in the plot. I did hit the 92% mark, thought the story was ready to come to its natural conclusion, and was taken aback at how much more plot there was in the last 8% of the book! The book&#8217;s end worked although it did leave me with a few unanswered questions. I think that was deliberate of Ms. Lee. She’s an author who is refreshingly uninterested in easily meeting reader expectations. Wendy: Mayhem &#8211; perfect word choice! I had the same reaction you did to all the huge events toward the end, and I thrilled to the book&#8217;s conclusion. Speaking of questions, I had one that I&#8217;ve been unable to answer. Did the human&#8217;s arrival on Gann precipitate what happened in the last couple of pages or would it have occurred anyway? Also, was there anything you didn&#8217;t like about it? I had a real problem with Amber&#8217;s willingness to forgive people who didn&#8217;t deserve forgiveness, and her sharing what little she had with people who expressed no gratitude. Why was she like that? Because of how much her selflessness bothered me I&#8217;d give The Last Hour of Gann an A- instead of the A+ it might have earned otherwise. Dabney: Well, Meoraq would never have gone on his pilgrimage had he not seen the pillar of fire created by the crash of the humans’ spaceship. I also think Amber had to be with him in order for him to discover what he did. Meoraq believes in destiny. Amber does not. I think it’s up to the reader to decide whether the fate of Gann was destined. I too struggled with Amber’s self-destructive behavior vis-à-vis her fellow humans. I understand that because they are the only humans on Gann Amber feels she must protect them. But I regularly wanted to yell at her to take care of herself. The other thing that didn’t quite work for me was the ease with which the aliens and the humans were able to communicate verbally. Had they not been able to do so the story would not have worked. However the facility with which they did so struck me as unlikely. Wendy: The ease with which they communicated bothered me a little as well. Not as much as Amber’s needing to grow a pair when it came to her shipmates, but sometimes Meoraq would say a word and I’d stop to think “now where could he have picked that up?” Regardless, I still think this is one of the best books of the year. Dabney: The Last Hour of Gann is proof that for a book to stand out it doesn’t have to be perfect. It just has to be something that grabs you, intrigues you, and compels you to say to all your friends, “You’ve got to read this book!” I too woud give it an A-. This was great fun, Wendy. Thanks for chatting with me! Get it at Amazon"
            }

                "html": "<p>Gertrude Stein famously wrote &#8220;<i>a rose is a rose is a rose.</i>&#8221; The plot in Ms. Neville&#8217;s latest in her <a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/review-tag/the-wild-quartet/\"><i><b>The Wild Quartet</b></i> </a>series, <b>The Ruin of a Rogue</b>, may be summed up as: A rogue is kinda a rogue is a non-rogue. I&#8217;ve never been wowed by the poetry of Ms. Stein and I&#8217;m wasn&#8217;t wowed by <b>The Ruin of a Rogue</b>.</p>\n<p>Marcus Lithgow is known as a knavish rogue who makes and loses his living gambling. He&#8217;s currently alarmingly broke and in need of funds. He&#8217;s previously met Anne Brotherton, &#8220;the wealthiest woman in Great Britain,&#8221; and decides to set his sights on her. He&#8217;ll try to ruin her. He wins if she must wed him &#8211; he&#8217;d control her fortune &#8211; and he wins if her notoriously stern guardian pays him to leave her alone. He&#8217;ll flatter the rather unremarkable Miss Brotherton, persuade her to let him lead her astray, and put his losing streak to an end.</p>\n<p>Anne is in need of being swept off her feet. She is beleaguered by suitors who are &#8220;<i>attracted by her rolling acres, magnificent mansions, and thousands upon thousands of pounds in the funds</i>&#8221; and who haven&#8217;t the slightest interest in <b><i>her</i></b>. Nor do they share her passion for Roman antiquities. They, and the rest of the ton, blanch when she shares her deepest desire is to archaeologically discover an ancient Roman villa buried somewhere in England.</p>\n<p>Marcus has done his homework so when he first encounters her, at a meeting he has carefully arranged, he speaks to her of his travels to Rome and his knowledge of ancient statuary. The second time he meets her, again at his contrivance, he woos her with talk of books of ancient times. The third time, he sweetly kisses her and then tells her he&#8217;s a cad for doing so when he knows he&#8217;s unworthy of her. Anne is smitten&#8230;until she overhears Marcus talking with her neighbor, the Duke of Denford, with whom Marcus attended Oxford. Julian asks Marcus how he is doing in his pursuit of Anne and her money.</p>\n<blockquote><p>“Spoiled heiresses need careful handling,” he said. “I believe I progress with the amiable Miss Brotherton. The poor girl is beginning to trust me. Two steps forward and one back. You know how the game is played. I kiss her, and apologize for the liberty. Next time I shall declare myself unable to resist her. It won’t be long until she’s begging for my attentions. As long as her guardian stays away for a few more weeks I’m confident I can bring home the prize.”</p></blockquote>\n<p>Anne is first crushed and then furious. She&#8217;ll teach him to call her a spoiled heiress!</p>\n<p>Thus begins Anne&#8217;s torment of Marcus. She makes him spend money on her, asks him for absurd favors, and, whenever she is with him, behaves like an excessively entitled harridan. Marcus begins to dread her company and is thrilled to learn he has inherited his uncle&#8217;s estate, Hinton Manor, a run down place Marcus hopes to be able to sell for enough coin to refill his very empty pockets. He bids her adieu and hopes he&#8217;s seen the last of the bothersome Miss Brotherton.</p>\n<p>Anne, though, has heard Marcus&#8217;s new found land is a perfect place for excavation; his uncle discovered two Roman villas on the property. She concocts a scheme with a friend and then hastens to Hinton Manor where she plans to harass Marcus into allowing her to explore his land. Displeased to see her, Marcus tells her she&#8217;s not taking a single shovel to his property. She pleads and he, thinking it&#8217;s vastly amusing, says she can do so only if she agrees to come to his house every morning and spend a couple hours as his housemaid. (He hasn&#8217;t any help because the villagers think the Manor is haunted and refuse to work there.) At first she flounces away in indignation but, after thinking about how very much she wants to dig for a villa, she tells him she&#8217;ll do it.</p>\n<p>The expected happens. As the two spend time together, Anne drops her total brat act and Marcus reveals himself to be an admirable stand up guy.</p>\n<p>All of this is written is lovely, detailed prose &#8211; perhaps too much prose &#8211; but nothing about it pulled me in. I found Anne very difficult to like and even a bit dull. Marcus is a bore as a rake and though he became more complex as he struggled to save Hinton Manor and his moral center, he remained at a remove for me. I couldn&#8217;t get invested in whether or not amateur archaeologist Anne found remnants of Rome. I liked watching Marcus care for his tenants, but there was nothing new or striking in the way he did so. I did believe Anne and Marcus could love one another but I didn&#8217;t care.</p>\n<p>The most interesting thing in <b>The Ruin of a Rogue</b> is the relationship between Julian, the Duke of Denford, and Anne&#8217;s married friend Cynthia, Lady Windermere. Cynthia&#8217;s husband Damian has abandoned her for reasons unknown and it&#8217;s unclear why Julian, who appears to consider Damian a friend, would be pursuing her. Ms. Neville does an excellent job of stoking interest in that story.</p>\n<p><b>The Ruin of a Rogue</b> gets a C+. It&#8217;s well-written, but too ponderous and unexciting for me.</p>\n",
                "text": "Gertrude Stein famously wrote &#8220;a rose is a rose is a rose.&#8221; The plot in Ms. Neville&#8217;s latest in her The Wild Quartet series, The Ruin of a Rogue, may be summed up as: A rogue is kinda a rogue is a non-rogue. I&#8217;ve never been wowed by the poetry of Ms. Stein and I&#8217;m wasn&#8217;t wowed by The Ruin of a Rogue. Marcus Lithgow is known as a knavish rogue who makes and loses his living gambling. He&#8217;s currently alarmingly broke and in need of funds. He&#8217;s previously met Anne Brotherton, &#8220;the wealthiest woman in Great Britain,&#8221; and decides to set his sights on her. He&#8217;ll try to ruin her. He wins if she must wed him &#8211; he&#8217;d control her fortune &#8211; and he wins if her notoriously stern guardian pays him to leave her alone. He&#8217;ll flatter the rather unremarkable Miss Brotherton, persuade her to let him lead her astray, and put his losing streak to an end. Anne is in need of being swept off her feet. She is beleaguered by suitors who are &#8220;attracted by her rolling acres, magnificent mansions, and thousands upon thousands of pounds in the funds&#8221; and who haven&#8217;t the slightest interest in her. Nor do they share her passion for Roman antiquities. They, and the rest of the ton, blanch when she shares her deepest desire is to archaeologically discover an ancient Roman villa buried somewhere in England. Marcus has done his homework so when he first encounters her, at a meeting he has carefully arranged, he speaks to her of his travels to Rome and his knowledge of ancient statuary. The second time he meets her, again at his contrivance, he woos her with talk of books of ancient times. The third time, he sweetly kisses her and then tells her he&#8217;s a cad for doing so when he knows he&#8217;s unworthy of her. Anne is smitten&#8230;until she overhears Marcus talking with her neighbor, the Duke of Denford, with whom Marcus attended Oxford. Julian asks Marcus how he is doing in his pursuit of Anne and her money. “Spoiled heiresses need careful handling,” he said. “I believe I progress with the amiable Miss Brotherton. The poor girl is beginning to trust me. Two steps forward and one back. You know how the game is played. I kiss her, and apologize for the liberty. Next time I shall declare myself unable to resist her. It won’t be long until she’s begging for my attentions. As long as her guardian stays away for a few more weeks I’m confident I can bring home the prize.” Anne is first crushed and then furious. She&#8217;ll teach him to call her a spoiled heiress! Thus begins Anne&#8217;s torment of Marcus. She makes him spend money on her, asks him for absurd favors, and, whenever she is with him, behaves like an excessively entitled harridan. Marcus begins to dread her company and is thrilled to learn he has inherited his uncle&#8217;s estate, Hinton Manor, a run down place Marcus hopes to be able to sell for enough coin to refill his very empty pockets. He bids her adieu and hopes he&#8217;s seen the last of the bothersome Miss Brotherton. Anne, though, has heard Marcus&#8217;s new found land is a perfect place for excavation; his uncle discovered two Roman villas on the property. She concocts a scheme with a friend and then hastens to Hinton Manor where she plans to harass Marcus into allowing her to explore his land. Displeased to see her, Marcus tells her she&#8217;s not taking a single shovel to his property. She pleads and he, thinking it&#8217;s vastly amusing, says she can do so only if she agrees to come to his house every morning and spend a couple hours as his housemaid. (He hasn&#8217;t any help because the villagers think the Manor is haunted and refuse to work there.) At first she flounces away in indignation but, after thinking about how very much she wants to dig for a villa, she tells him she&#8217;ll do it. The expected happens. As the two spend time together, Anne drops her total brat act and Marcus reveals himself to be an admirable stand up guy. All of this is written is lovely, detailed prose &#8211; perhaps too much prose &#8211; but nothing about it pulled me in. I found Anne very difficult to like and even a bit dull. Marcus is a bore as a rake and though he became more complex as he struggled to save Hinton Manor and his moral center, he remained at a remove for me. I couldn&#8217;t get invested in whether or not amateur archaeologist Anne found remnants of Rome. I liked watching Marcus care for his tenants, but there was nothing new or striking in the way he did so. I did believe Anne and Marcus could love one another but I didn&#8217;t care. The most interesting thing in The Ruin of a Rogue is the relationship between Julian, the Duke of Denford, and Anne&#8217;s married friend Cynthia, Lady Windermere. Cynthia&#8217;s husband Damian has abandoned her for reasons unknown and it&#8217;s unclear why Julian, who appears to consider Damian a friend, would be pursuing her. Ms. Neville does an excellent job of stoking interest in that story. The Ruin of a Rogue gets a C+. It&#8217;s well-written, but too ponderous and unexciting for me."

            "book": {
                "title": "Glitterland",
                "author_first": "Alexis",
                "author_last": "Hall",
                "publisher": "Riptide",
                "isbn": "1626490252",
                "pages": "248",
                "publish_date": "09/2013",
                "grade": "A-",
                "sensuality": "Hot",
                "amazon_url": "https://amzn.to/3l0EcI5",
                "amazon_asin": "B09XGPSQ9K"

            "content": {
                "html": "<p>It would be easy label Alexis Hall&#8217;s debut novel <b>Glitterland</b> as <a href=\"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Literary_fiction\">literary fiction</a> masquerading as romance. The language he uses &#8211; his metaphors are often show stoppingly gorgeous &#8211; and his narrator, a bipolar depressive &#8211; beg to be read by those who dismiss genre fiction as lowly. The next time someone sniffs derisively at romance novels, rather than roll my eyes and pray for patience, I plan to say, &#8220;Ah, I see you haven&#8217;t read <b>Glitterland</b>. Try it. I think you&#8217;ll be impressed.&#8221; (This is clearly a better response than calling someone a judgmental prat.)</p>\n<p><b>Glitterland</b> <b><i>is</i></b> a romance, complete with compelling leads, steamy love scenes, and a hard-won Happy For Now ending. I liked it tremendously. It&#8217;s one of the best books I&#8217;ve read this summer and, I think, the best debut novel of the year thus far.</p>\n<p>The narrator of <b>Glitterland</b> is Ash Winters and he is not a nice man. Ash is seriously mentally ill and is recovering from a fairly recent psychotic breakdown. He is also an intellectual from Britain&#8217;s upper class (he&#8217;s a Cambridge grad), a successful writer, wealthy enough to never worry about money, and a snob. He mocks everyone including himself and when he sees Darian dancing at a gay bar in Essex (Ash, who never leaves his apartment if he doesn&#8217;t have to, is there for a friend&#8217;s stag party he was unable to avoid), he labels him as a risible rube.</p>\n<blockquote><p>He was a ridiculous creature. A vulgar, glittering pirate of a man, all jewellery and fake tan, gold glinting in his ears, on his fingers and round his wrists. His dark hair gleamed with product and had been painstakingly teased into a quiff that defied taste, reason, and gravity.</p></blockquote>\n<p>Much to his dismay, Ash is attracted to this ludicrous person. Two things amaze Ash about the want he feels. Ash is &#8220;a muted thing&#8221; and hasn&#8217;t felt much of anything since he was discharged. And to feel lust for something &#8211; for Ash doesn&#8217;t see Darian as anything more than an object of desire &#8211; so definitely of the masses is, to Ash, humiliating. To be fair, Ash defines almost everything he does as self-destructive.</p>\n<p>Darian sees Ash watching him, grins up at him, and pulls himself up to the balcony Ash is standing on like &#8220;<i>the world&#8217;s most ill-suited Romeo.</i>&#8221;</p>\n<blockquote><p>“I gotta say, babes,” he said in a nasal Essex whine, “you’re giving me sutcha bedroom look.”<br />\nI stared down into his face, so close to mine. <i>Babes</i>? And, dear God, that accent.<br />\n“Well,” I heard myself say, “play your cards right and I might consent to do more than look.”<br />\n“Omigod, you talk like the Queen.”<br />\nI blinked. “Pardon?”<br />\n“Are you in parliament?”<br />\nI had the feeling I’d lost control of the conversation.<br />\n“What? No. I’m a writer.”<br />\n“Omigod, really?” He sounded both impressed and bewildered, as if I’d said I went fishing on the moon.</p></blockquote>\n<p>This interchange, where Darian sees Ash as an educated enticing man, and Ash sees Darian as an Essex idiot, is repeated again and again in the book.</p>\n<p>Ash does go home that night with Darian for a furtive one-night stand, and afterward as Darian &#8211; whose name Ash didn&#8217;t bother to remember &#8211; sleeps, Ash runs out of the house in a panic, already feeling shame and despair. He calls his closest friend Niall, who &#8211; yet again &#8211; comes to rescue Ash, and Ash, once back in his apartment, hopes to never see his hook-up again.</p>\n<p>Darian, however, has other plans. He shows up at a book signing for Ash&#8217;s latest book, a best selling crime novel called <b>Through a Glass Darkly</b> (its hero is named Rik Glass) and asks Ash to dedicate the book &#8220;<i>To the geeza what I slept wif and then done a runner on in the middle of the night, making ’im feel like a right slapper’?</i>” Ash chooses instead to sign it &#8220;<i>To a bloke I fucked</i>.&#8221; Darian points out that Ash isn&#8217;t a very nice person and Ash tells him he&#8217;s right and then invites Darian up to his flat for a round of sex. One round turns into several and the two spend several days together during which Ash feels something akin to happiness. The feeling terrifies him. For Ash, happiness has often led to the sort of mania that leads to a harrowing crash. And yet when Darian, who is pursuing a career as a male model, asks Ash to come see him in the Essex Fashion Week Show, Ash demurs. Darian leaves making it clear that if Ash wants to see him again, he&#8217;d best come to the show in Essex.</p>\n<p>It&#8217;s clear though Ash has the education, the money, and the career, his life veers close to the stuff of nightmares. Ash is mentally ill. He&#8217;s attempted suicide in the past, has destroyed almost every relationship he has, and struggles every day, with the help of a set of pills designed to keep him safe, to not sink into desolation. For him,</p>\n<blockquote><p>Depression simply is. It has no beginning and no end, no boundaries and no world outside itself. It is the first, the last, the only, the alpha and the omega. Memories of better times die upon its desolate shores. Voices drown in its seas. The mind becomes its own prisoner.</p></blockquote>\n<p>Life is different for Darian. He&#8217;s an essentially, determinedly happy guy who sees life though a serotonin-filled gaze. He likes himself, has good friends, a caring grandmother, and finds joy with ease. If there is a flaw in <b>Glitterland</b>, it&#8217;s in the effortlessness of Darian&#8217;s emotional life. Darian is almost too good to read true and his easy acceptance of Ash&#8217;s very real problems treads on the facile. <b>Glitterland</b>, though, is not a happily ever after story where Darian&#8217;s care for Ash cures Ash. By the novel&#8217;s end, Ash and Darian have found a place where, together, they&#8217;re going to try to make a go at a love. It&#8217;s an almost happy for now ending and, in acknowledging their relationship&#8217;s limitations, Mr. Hall gives them &#8211; and the reader &#8211; something that feels real and true.</p>\n<p>I would be remiss if I didn&#8217;t praise Mr. Hall&#8217;s prose. As rendered through Ash&#8217;s narration, Mr. Hall writes beautifully, movingly, and with wry humor. Ash&#8217;s describes his suicide attempt where he slashed his arms as, &#8220;<i>old lunacy&#8230;. I thought there were lost words trapped in my skin and I was releasing them back into the world. Like a flock of phoenix.</i>” His university years were &#8220;<i>A blur of gold and green, the scent of old books, the slide of a stranger’s body against mine.</i>&#8221; The night sky &#8220;<i>was a bruised swirl of blue and indigo, the air sharp-edged with salt</i>.&#8221; Mr. Halls&#8217;s words are unrushed, his sentences given the space to unfurl and steal a reader&#8217;s heart. In short, it rocks.</p>\n<p><b>Glitterland</b> held my attention from the first scene to the last. It gets a slightly awed A- from me.</p>\n",
                "text": "It would be easy label Alexis Hall&#8217;s debut novel Glitterland as literary fiction masquerading as romance. The language he uses &#8211; his metaphors are often show stoppingly gorgeous &#8211; and his narrator, a bipolar depressive &#8211; beg to be read by those who dismiss genre fiction as lowly. The next time someone sniffs derisively at romance novels, rather than roll my eyes and pray for patience, I plan to say, &#8220;Ah, I see you haven&#8217;t read Glitterland. Try it. I think you&#8217;ll be impressed.&#8221; (This is clearly a better response than calling someone a judgmental prat.) Glitterland is a romance, complete with compelling leads, steamy love scenes, and a hard-won Happy For Now ending. I liked it tremendously. It&#8217;s one of the best books I&#8217;ve read this summer and, I think, the best debut novel of the year thus far. The narrator of Glitterland is Ash Winters and he is not a nice man. Ash is seriously mentally ill and is recovering from a fairly recent psychotic breakdown. He is also an intellectual from Britain&#8217;s upper class (he&#8217;s a Cambridge grad), a successful writer, wealthy enough to never worry about money, and a snob. He mocks everyone including himself and when he sees Darian dancing at a gay bar in Essex (Ash, who never leaves his apartment if he doesn&#8217;t have to, is there for a friend&#8217;s stag party he was unable to avoid), he labels him as a risible rube. He was a ridiculous creature. A vulgar, glittering pirate of a man, all jewellery and fake tan, gold glinting in his ears, on his fingers and round his wrists. His dark hair gleamed with product and had been painstakingly teased into a quiff that defied taste, reason, and gravity. Much to his dismay, Ash is attracted to this ludicrous person. Two things amaze Ash about the want he feels. Ash is &#8220;a muted thing&#8221; and hasn&#8217;t felt much of anything since he was discharged. And to feel lust for something &#8211; for Ash doesn&#8217;t see Darian as anything more than an object of desire &#8211; so definitely of the masses is, to Ash, humiliating. To be fair, Ash defines almost everything he does as self-destructive. Darian sees Ash watching him, grins up at him, and pulls himself up to the balcony Ash is standing on like &#8220;the world&#8217;s most ill-suited Romeo.&#8221; “I gotta say, babes,” he said in a nasal Essex whine, “you’re giving me sutcha bedroom look.” I stared down into his face, so close to mine. Babes? And, dear God, that accent. “Well,” I heard myself say, “play your cards right and I might consent to do more than look.” “Omigod, you talk like the Queen.” I blinked. “Pardon?” “Are you in parliament?” I had the feeling I’d lost control of the conversation. “What? No. I’m a writer.” “Omigod, really?” He sounded both impressed and bewildered, as if I’d said I went fishing on the moon. This interchange, where Darian sees Ash as an educated enticing man, and Ash sees Darian as an Essex idiot, is repeated again and again in the book. Ash does go home that night with Darian for a furtive one-night stand, and afterward as Darian &#8211; whose name Ash didn&#8217;t bother to remember &#8211; sleeps, Ash runs out of the house in a panic, already feeling shame and despair. He calls his closest friend Niall, who &#8211; yet again &#8211; comes to rescue Ash, and Ash, once back in his apartment, hopes to never see his hook-up again. Darian, however, has other plans. He shows up at a book signing for Ash&#8217;s latest book, a best selling crime novel called Through a Glass Darkly (its hero is named Rik Glass) and asks Ash to dedicate the book &#8220;To the geeza what I slept wif and then done a runner on in the middle of the night, making ’im feel like a right slapper’?” Ash chooses instead to sign it &#8220;To a bloke I fucked.&#8221; Darian points out that Ash isn&#8217;t a very nice person and Ash tells him he&#8217;s right and then invites Darian up to his flat for a round of sex. One round turns into several and the two spend several days together during which Ash feels something akin to happiness. The feeling terrifies him. For Ash, happiness has often led to the sort of mania that leads to a harrowing crash. And yet when Darian, who is pursuing a career as a male model, asks Ash to come see him in the Essex Fashion Week Show, Ash demurs. Darian leaves making it clear that if Ash wants to see him again, he&#8217;d best come to the show in Essex. It&#8217;s clear though Ash has the education, the money, and the career, his life veers close to the stuff of nightmares. Ash is mentally ill. He&#8217;s attempted suicide in the past, has destroyed almost every relationship he has, and struggles every day, with the help of a set of pills designed to keep him safe, to not sink into desolation. For him, Depression simply is. It has no beginning and no end, no boundaries and no world outside itself. It is the first, the last, the only, the alpha and the omega. Memories of better times die upon its desolate shores. Voices drown in its seas. The mind becomes its own prisoner. Life is different for Darian. He&#8217;s an essentially, determinedly happy guy who sees life though a serotonin-filled gaze. He likes himself, has good friends, a caring grandmother, and finds joy with ease. If there is a flaw in Glitterland, it&#8217;s in the effortlessness of Darian&#8217;s emotional life. Darian is almost too good to read true and his easy acceptance of Ash&#8217;s very real problems treads on the facile. Glitterland, though, is not a happily ever after story where Darian&#8217;s care for Ash cures Ash. By the novel&#8217;s end, Ash and Darian have found a place where, together, they&#8217;re going to try to make a go at a love. It&#8217;s an almost happy for now ending and, in acknowledging their relationship&#8217;s limitations, Mr. Hall gives them &#8211; and the reader &#8211; something that feels real and true. I would be remiss if I didn&#8217;t praise Mr. Hall&#8217;s prose. As rendered through Ash&#8217;s narration, Mr. Hall writes beautifully, movingly, and with wry humor. Ash&#8217;s describes his suicide attempt where he slashed his arms as, &#8220;old lunacy&#8230;. I thought there were lost words trapped in my skin and I was releasing them back into the world. Like a flock of phoenix.” His university years were &#8220;A blur of gold and green, the scent of old books, the slide of a stranger’s body against mine.&#8221; The night sky &#8220;was a bruised swirl of blue and indigo, the air sharp-edged with salt.&#8221; Mr. Halls&#8217;s words are unrushed, his sentences given the space to unfurl and steal a reader&#8217;s heart. In short, it rocks. Glitterland held my attention from the first scene to the last. It gets a slightly awed A- from me."
            }

                "html": "<p>Caroline Linden&#8217;s <b>Love and Other Scandals</b> is the best historical romance I&#8217;ve read this summer. Joan Bennet, the spinster heroine, has a sharper tongue and a sharper mind. The louche hero, Tristan Burke, is witty and wicked. Together, they are an engaging couple whose path to true love is sweet, believable, interesting, and sexy. Plus, there&#8217;s a balloon ride!</p>\n<p>Joan and Tristan first meet when Joan is eight and Tristan twelve. Tristan is up from Eton for the holiday with Joan&#8217;s brother Douglas. Joan is asleep in her room when Tristan bursts into her room, shirtless and carrying a single red rose. The second time they meet, it&#8217;s at Tristan&#8217;s uncle&#8217;s funeral. Tristan, now Lord Burke, is a tall moody man who has already began to garner a reputation as a rake. When Joan approaches him and tells him she&#8217;s sorry for his loss, he kvetches to her about the way his relatives and society gossip about him. She asks him why, as an independent man, he cares.</p>\n<blockquote><p>His mouth twisted. “You don’t understand.”</p>\n<p>Joan heaved a sigh. “No, of course I don’t. I could never possibly understand what it’s like to be a gentleman with my own fortune, able to do as I please with no one to say me nay. Heaven preserve me from such unbearable oppression.”</p>\n<p>He looked at her, perhaps really paying attention to her for the first time. “You’re quite impertinent.”</p>\n<p>She beamed at him, instead of smacking him across the face as her hand itched to do. “Thank you.”</p>\n<p>Tristan Burke stared at her, and then he laughed. His deep green eyes lit up and a wide grin creased his face, sharpening a dimple in his cheek. He looked full of joy in that moment, and Joan’s smile faded away as she stared at him.</p>\n<p>“I’ll remember you, Joan Bennet,” he said. “I like an impertinent girl.”</p></blockquote>\n<p>The third time Joan meets Tristan, she&#8217;s 24. Tristan is staying with her dissolute (but essentially kind) brother Douglas in the latter&#8217;s town home while Tristan repairs his own. Joan&#8217;s mother has decided that Douglas simply must attend the Malcom Ball the next night so that he may dance with &#8211; and, if Mrs. Bennet has anything to do with it, marry &#8211; a nice young lady named Felicity. Joan knows Douglas would rather be kicked in the face by his horse than go to a marriage mart ball and so, being the lovely sweet sister she is, Joan volunteers to go to her brother&#8217;s and relay her mother&#8217;s command. (She&#8217;s especially gleeful about the prospect of waking him up from a hangover.)</p>\n<p>Joan, who is unescorted because she is only supposed to call upon her brother, arrives at his house right after breakfast and bangs on the door. She&#8217;s startled when a shirtless man yanks it open. She realizes it&#8217;s Tristan, needles him about his rude behavior, shoves past him, and waltzes up the steps to her brother&#8217;s room. There she throws open his curtains, makes as much noise as she possibly can, and happily badgers her brother. Just as she&#8217;s tormenting Douglas by deliberately prattling on at him about what color gown she might wear to the Malcom ball, Tristan appears in the doorway, wrapped in a deep green dressing gown and says, &#8220;<i>Gold. You should wear gold.</i>&#8221;</p>\n<p>Tristan, who is a connoisseur of women, is right. Joan should wear gold. He in fact thinks she should wear anything but the current girlish fashions she wears. Joan is tall, voluptuous and handsome. The clothes, hats, and hairstyles she stuffs herself into don&#8217;t suit her at all. Joan dimly realizes this but can&#8217;t figure out what would show her charms to best advantage. Tristan&#8217;s comment makes her self-conscious and she speaks tartly to him and then returns to making her brother&#8217;s morning worse by forcing him to sign a note addressed to their mother in which Douglas promises to attend the ball. Note in hand, Joan sweeps out of Douglas&#8217;s home and heads to the place she truly wants to go: a bookstore on Bond Street where a copy of the naughty pamphlet &#8220;<b>50 Ways to Sin</b>&#8221; can be bought. (I decided to squelch my irritation at this <i>50 Shades</i> intrusion. There&#8217;s nothing else in the story that smacks of <i>50 Shades</i> &#8211; I think it must have been a poorly chosen marketing ploy.)</p>\n<p>Begged by Douglas to follow Joan and take back his note, Tristan surprises Joan in the bookstore. Joan refuses to give him the missive and Tristan irritates her further by pointing out the striped pink gown she&#8217;s wearing makes her easy to track from blocks away. Joan, indignant, leaves him and the pamphlet she&#8217;d come to collect. Tristan, collects the wrapped package (he doesn&#8217;t know what it is) and decides to attend the Malcom ball so that he may return it to her.</p>\n<p>From then on, the two begin a very unconventional courtship. Tristan has no intention of marrying anyone, especially not his best friend&#8217;s sister who is both a virgin and, as he calls her, a Fury. Tristan, despite enjoying matching wits with Joan, feels she&#8217;s the sort of girl he should stay far far away from. However, when the elder Bennets abruptly leave town due to Mrs. Bennet&#8217;s declining health and Douglas is dispatched by his father to the country to check on work being done their country estate, Douglas asks Tristan if he&#8217;ll occasionally check up on Joan and make sure she&#8217;s not too lonely. Tristan knows this is a bad idea, but, unable to say no to Douglas, agrees he will escort Joan around town. Joan&#8217;s wild aunt is acting as Joan&#8217;s chaperone and, between the freedom Aunt Evangeline gives her and the mischief Tristan talks her into, Joan finds herself having the time of her life.</p>\n<p>Ms. Linden rarely hits a false note in <b>Love and Other Scandals</b>. The sweetly battled war of wits and wiles between Tristan and Joan reminds me of the best of Julia Quinn. The secondary characters &#8211; especially Joan&#8217;s two best friends &#8211; are fleshed out and add to the story. I especially liked all the information Ms. Linden gives about the new technologies in residential building of the time. Tristan is building a new house and, as he tells Joan all about its innovations, the reader learns many an interesting tidbit.</p>\n<p>I like my love stories to have heat in them and, here too, Ms. Linden does not disappoint. Joan and Tristan have great chemistry together (and apart, when thinking about each other). I&#8217;ve read far too many historical romances where the virginal heroine is putty in the hands of the accomplished rake. (Yawn.) Joan &#8211; in part because of her pamphlet reading and her chats with her friends &#8211; is informed about sex but doesn&#8217;t understand desire. Tristan knows all about sex but nothing about love. Together, the two discover passionate love as equals and &#8211; which I loved &#8211; with humor.</p>\n<p>I firmly recommend <b>Love and Other Scandals</b>. The novel, with its blend of ardor and amusement, gets an A- from me.</p>\n<h3>Buy it at <a href=\"https://amzn.to/2XpwKpd\">Amazon</a>/<a href=\"https://geo.itunes.apple.com/us/book/love-and-other-scandals/id569225860?mt=11&amp;at=1010lmPQ\">Apple Books</a>/<a href=\"http://www.anrdoezrs.net/links/8039827/type/dlg/http://www.barnesandnoble.com/w/love-and-other-scandals-caroline-linden/1113200700?ean=9780062244888\">Barnes and Noble</a>/<a href=\"http://click.linksynergy.com/fs-bin/click?id=b95pXvP*dp4&amp;subid=&amp;offerid=361251.1&amp;type=10&amp;tmpid=9310&amp;RD_PARM1=https%3A%2F%2Fstore.kobobooks.com%2Fen-us%2Febook%2Flove-and-other-scandals\">Kobo</a></h3>\n",
                "text": "Caroline Linden&#8217;s Love and Other Scandals is the best historical romance I&#8217;ve read this summer. Joan Bennet, the spinster heroine, has a sharper tongue and a sharper mind. The louche hero, Tristan Burke, is witty and wicked. Together, they are an engaging couple whose path to true love is sweet, believable, interesting, and sexy. Plus, there&#8217;s a balloon ride! Joan and Tristan first meet when Joan is eight and Tristan twelve. Tristan is up from Eton for the holiday with Joan&#8217;s brother Douglas. Joan is asleep in her room when Tristan bursts into her room, shirtless and carrying a single red rose. The second time they meet, it&#8217;s at Tristan&#8217;s uncle&#8217;s funeral. Tristan, now Lord Burke, is a tall moody man who has already began to garner a reputation as a rake. When Joan approaches him and tells him she&#8217;s sorry for his loss, he kvetches to her about the way his relatives and society gossip about him. She asks him why, as an independent man, he cares. His mouth twisted. “You don’t understand.” Joan heaved a sigh. “No, of course I don’t. I could never possibly understand what it’s like to be a gentleman with my own fortune, able to do as I please with no one to say me nay. Heaven preserve me from such unbearable oppression.” He looked at her, perhaps really paying attention to her for the first time. “You’re quite impertinent.” She beamed at him, instead of smacking him across the face as her hand itched to do. “Thank you.” Tristan Burke stared at her, and then he laughed. His deep green eyes lit up and a wide grin creased his face, sharpening a dimple in his cheek. He looked full of joy in that moment, and Joan’s smile faded away as she stared at him. “I’ll remember you, Joan Bennet,” he said. “I like an impertinent girl.” The third time Joan meets Tristan, she&#8217;s 24. Tristan is staying with her dissolute (but essentially kind) brother Douglas in the latter&#8217;s town home while Tristan repairs his own. Joan&#8217;s mother has decided that Douglas simply must attend the Malcom Ball the next night so that he may dance with &#8211; and, if Mrs. Bennet has anything to do with it, marry &#8211; a nice young lady named Felicity. Joan knows Douglas would rather be kicked in the face by his horse than go to a marriage mart ball and so, being the lovely sweet sister she is, Joan volunteers to go to her brother&#8217;s and relay her mother&#8217;s command. (She&#8217;s especially gleeful about the prospect of waking him up from a hangover.) Joan, who is unescorted because she is only supposed to call upon her brother, arrives at his house right after breakfast and bangs on the door. She&#8217;s startled when a shirtless man yanks it open. She realizes it&#8217;s Tristan, needles him about his rude behavior, shoves past him, and waltzes up the steps to her brother&#8217;s room. There she throws open his curtains, makes as much noise as she possibly can, and happily badgers her brother. Just as she&#8217;s tormenting Douglas by deliberately prattling on at him about what color gown she might wear to the Malcom ball, Tristan appears in the doorway, wrapped in a deep green dressing gown and says, &#8220;Gold. You should wear gold.&#8221; Tristan, who is a connoisseur of women, is right. Joan should wear gold. He in fact thinks she should wear anything but the current girlish fashions she wears. Joan is tall, voluptuous and handsome. The clothes, hats, and hairstyles she stuffs herself into don&#8217;t suit her at all. Joan dimly realizes this but can&#8217;t figure out what would show her charms to best advantage. Tristan&#8217;s comment makes her self-conscious and she speaks tartly to him and then returns to making her brother&#8217;s morning worse by forcing him to sign a note addressed to their mother in which Douglas promises to attend the ball. Note in hand, Joan sweeps out of Douglas&#8217;s home and heads to the place she truly wants to go: a bookstore on Bond Street where a copy of the naughty pamphlet &#8220;50 Ways to Sin&#8221; can be bought. (I decided to squelch my irritation at this 50 Shades intrusion. There&#8217;s nothing else in the story that smacks of 50 Shades &#8211; I think it must have been a poorly chosen marketing ploy.) Begged by Douglas to follow Joan and take back his note, Tristan surprises Joan in the bookstore. Joan refuses to give him the missive and Tristan irritates her further by pointing out the striped pink gown she&#8217;s wearing makes her easy to track from blocks away. Joan, indignant, leaves him and the pamphlet she&#8217;d come to collect. Tristan, collects the wrapped package (he doesn&#8217;t know what it is) and decides to attend the Malcom ball so that he may return it to her. From then on, the two begin a very unconventional courtship. Tristan has no intention of marrying anyone, especially not his best friend&#8217;s sister who is both a virgin and, as he calls her, a Fury. Tristan, despite enjoying matching wits with Joan, feels she&#8217;s the sort of girl he should stay far far away from. However, when the elder Bennets abruptly leave town due to Mrs. Bennet&#8217;s declining health and Douglas is dispatched by his father to the country to check on work being done their country estate, Douglas asks Tristan if he&#8217;ll occasionally check up on Joan and make sure she&#8217;s not too lonely. Tristan knows this is a bad idea, but, unable to say no to Douglas, agrees he will escort Joan around town. Joan&#8217;s wild aunt is acting as Joan&#8217;s chaperone and, between the freedom Aunt Evangeline gives her and the mischief Tristan talks her into, Joan finds herself having the time of her life. Ms. Linden rarely hits a false note in Love and Other Scandals. The sweetly battled war of wits and wiles between Tristan and Joan reminds me of the best of Julia Quinn. The secondary characters &#8211; especially Joan&#8217;s two best friends &#8211; are fleshed out and add to the story. I especially liked all the information Ms. Linden gives about the new technologies in residential building of the time. Tristan is building a new house and, as he tells Joan all about its innovations, the reader learns many an interesting tidbit. I like my love stories to have heat in them and, here too, Ms. Linden does not disappoint. Joan and Tristan have great chemistry together (and apart, when thinking about each other). I&#8217;ve read far too many historical romances where the virginal heroine is putty in the hands of the accomplished rake. (Yawn.) Joan &#8211; in part because of her pamphlet reading and her chats with her friends &#8211; is informed about sex but doesn&#8217;t understand desire. Tristan knows all about sex but nothing about love. Together, the two discover passionate love as equals and &#8211; which I loved &#8211; with humor. I firmly recommend Love and Other Scandals. The novel, with its blend of ardor and amusement, gets an A- from me. Buy it at Amazon/Apple Books/Barnes and Noble/Kobo"

                "html": "<p><b>It Happened One Midnight</b> is the eighth book in Ms. Long&#8217;s <i><b>Pennyroyal Green</b></i> series. The hero is Jonathan Redmond, the youngest of the Redmonds.This fact alone made me consider downgrading this book. I and the rest of Ms. Long&#8217;s fans have been impatiently waiting since <b>I Kissed an Earl</b> (#5) to learn what Lyon is doing and when Olivia will find out the truth about her father&#8217;s involvement in the slave trade. Sadly, there is so little information in this book about the Eversea/Redmond storyline <b>It Happened One Midnight</b> could be read as a stand-alone book.</p>\n<p><b>It Happened One Midnight</b> takes place nine months after the end of <b>I Kissed an Earl</b>. As it begins, Jonathan Redmond encounters Thomasina de Ballesteros (she goes by Tommy) standing outside the window of the Duke of Greyfolk&#8217;s London home gazing fixedly at the elderly Duke inside. Jonathan is leaving the Duke&#8217;s after dinner there; he wrangled an invitation to try to convince the Duke to invest in a color printing press Jonathan is an owner of. Jonathan has no idea why Tommy, the current toast of the demimonde, is loitering in the dark. He and Tommy had met earlier in the day at a salon Tommy hosts for the eccentric, elderly Countess Mirabeau and had taken each other&#8217;s measure. Both are exceptionally gorgeous and charming. On the surface, both are clichés. Jonathan is an aristocratic rake; Tommy, a poor beauty who plans to trade her body for wealth and security. Beneath the selves they show to society, however, their characters are more complex.</p>\n<p>Jonathan and Tommy verbally spar in the moonlight. At the end of their conversation, they part, aware that while neither is an appropriate romantic partner for the other, they like each other and might, perhaps, be able to be friends.</p>\n<p>The next day, Jonathan returns to the Redmond home in Pennyroyal Green. He comes to visit his very pregnant sister Violet, and having failed to enlist the financial support of Greyfolk, to ask his father, Isaiah, for financial backing for his new business. Isaiah, however, makes it clear to Jonathan that he, Isaiah, hasn&#8217;t a whit of faith in Jonathan&#8217;s ability to do anything but look good and get in trouble.</p>\n<p>Jonathan is shocked his father thinks so little of him. He&#8217;s then genuinely infuriated when his father tells him Jonathan has six months to marry a woman Isaiah approves of or Jonathan will be completely cut off financially. This exchange between father and son is reminiscent of Isaiah&#8217;s similar threat to Jonathan&#8217;s older brother Miles (the hero of <b>Like No Other Lover</b>) which Miles flouted by marrying a woman very much like Tommy.</p>\n<p>It&#8217;s clear to the reader that, like Miles, Jonathan isn&#8217;t going to let his father dictate the woman he&#8217;ll marry. And, given that Tommy is the heroine of the book, it&#8217;s also clear this book shares a theme that permeates many of the <b><i>Pennyroyal Green</i></b> books. In all but two of the eight books, a man is paired with a woman society deems unacceptable as his bride. Ms. Long writes about class distinctions well, yet reading this story again &#8211; told better in <b>How the Marquess Was Won</b> &#8211; makes <b>It Happened One Midnight</b> feel somewhat stale.</p>\n<p>Tommy is an inappropriate woman for Jonathan. She&#8217;s the illegitimate and unrecognized daughter of a Duke (guess which one?) and his long dead mistress. Her mother died when she was a child, and prior to the intervention of Countess Mirabeau, Tommy fared poorly on the London streets. She&#8217;s clever, manipulative, and ambitious. She longs for a family of her own and to feel owned by a family as well. She flirts with what seems like every unmarried aristocrat in London, but gives herself to none of them, as she is holding out for marriage. She&#8217;s also a do-gooder of dangerous proportions: She steals/rescues abused child servants and finds a safe place for them to develop a trade. This aspect of her personality makes her admirable almost to the point of perfection. She&#8217;s the Clark Kent of scandalous salons: A seemingly shallow temptress in the evening and a reckless savior of the weak at midnight.</p>\n<p>Tommy pulls Jonathan into her midnight missions and he, in turn, uses money she gives him (garnered by pawning a necklace of perfect pearls from an admirer) to fund the first runs of his new color printing press. A suggestion from Tommy about what the printing press could print and make a mint off of gives Jonathan a brilliant idea that earns him financial independence and his father&#8217;s fury.</p>\n<p>The plot is an odd meld of commerce, danger, adorable tots, explosive kisses, and self-determination. Ms. Long pulls it off although the most compelling story is not of that era&#8217;s abused impoverished young but rather of Jonathan&#8217;s strategic toppling of his father&#8217;s limiting demands. Isaiah Redmond has long been cruising for a comeuppance and it&#8217;s satisfying to see his youngest son deliver it to him.</p>\n<p>I liked Jonathan more than Tommy in part because Jonathan is deftly and deeply portrayed. Readers of the series have gotten to know him and his troubled family over many pages and he is a compelling and confident hero. Tommy is much hazier. Whole parts of her are missing (her sexual and relational past, her relationship with her mother, how she acquired her many skills, just to name a few). And unlike, Jonathan, she doesn&#8217;t have to give up anything to fuse her future with his.</p>\n<p>I did enjoy the interactions between the two. Ms. Long excels at writing witty repartee and deliciously effective love scenes. One of the pleasant aspects of <b>It Happened One Midnight</b> is that Tommy and Jonathan like each other long before they begin exploring the lust they feel. I worried, once they became lovers, that Jonathan conflated lust and love, but by the (sigh) epilogue, he and Tommy have the stuff that dreams are made of: True, lasting, passionate love.</p>\n<p>I count Ms. Long as one of my favorite writers. Two of her <b><i>Pennyroyal </i></b>books (#4 and #5) are among my top ten favorite historical romances. <b>It Happened One Midnight</b> is not one of Ms. Long&#8217;s best books, but nor is it a bad one. It&#8217;s good, not great.</p>\n<p>Did I like it less because I&#8217;m running out of patience with the <b><i>Pennyroyal</i></b> series? I don&#8217;t think so. There are things in this book besides its lack of Olivia/Lyon that didn&#8217;t work for me. After reading it twice, I decided to give it a B. I am, however, steeling myself for book nine. It&#8217;s not about Olivia and Lyon either. It&#8217;s Ian Eversea&#8217;s story (last seen being terrorized by the fabulous Duke of Falconbridge, the hero of <b>What I Did for a Duke</b>) and is due out next March. <b><i>Pennyroyal Green</i></b> fans will line up in droves to read it and, yes, I&#8217;ll be right there with them.</p>\n",
                "text": "It Happened One Midnight is the eighth book in Ms. Long&#8217;s Pennyroyal Green series. The hero is Jonathan Redmond, the youngest of the Redmonds.This fact alone made me consider downgrading this book. I and the rest of Ms. Long&#8217;s fans have been impatiently waiting since I Kissed an Earl (#5) to learn what Lyon is doing and when Olivia will find out the truth about her father&#8217;s involvement in the slave trade. Sadly, there is so little information in this book about the Eversea/Redmond storyline It Happened One Midnight could be read as a stand-alone book. It Happened One Midnight takes place nine months after the end of I Kissed an Earl. As it begins, Jonathan Redmond encounters Thomasina de Ballesteros (she goes by Tommy) standing outside the window of the Duke of Greyfolk&#8217;s London home gazing fixedly at the elderly Duke inside. Jonathan is leaving the Duke&#8217;s after dinner there; he wrangled an invitation to try to convince the Duke to invest in a color printing press Jonathan is an owner of. Jonathan has no idea why Tommy, the current toast of the demimonde, is loitering in the dark. He and Tommy had met earlier in the day at a salon Tommy hosts for the eccentric, elderly Countess Mirabeau and had taken each other&#8217;s measure. Both are exceptionally gorgeous and charming. On the surface, both are clichés. Jonathan is an aristocratic rake; Tommy, a poor beauty who plans to trade her body for wealth and security. Beneath the selves they show to society, however, their characters are more complex. Jonathan and Tommy verbally spar in the moonlight. At the end of their conversation, they part, aware that while neither is an appropriate romantic partner for the other, they like each other and might, perhaps, be able to be friends. The next day, Jonathan returns to the Redmond home in Pennyroyal Green. He comes to visit his very pregnant sister Violet, and having failed to enlist the financial support of Greyfolk, to ask his father, Isaiah, for financial backing for his new business. Isaiah, however, makes it clear to Jonathan that he, Isaiah, hasn&#8217;t a whit of faith in Jonathan&#8217;s ability to do anything but look good and get in trouble. Jonathan is shocked his father thinks so little of him. He&#8217;s then genuinely infuriated when his father tells him Jonathan has six months to marry a woman Isaiah approves of or Jonathan will be completely cut off financially. This exchange between father and son is reminiscent of Isaiah&#8217;s similar threat to Jonathan&#8217;s older brother Miles (the hero of Like No Other Lover) which Miles flouted by marrying a woman very much like Tommy. It&#8217;s clear to the reader that, like Miles, Jonathan isn&#8217;t going to let his father dictate the woman he&#8217;ll marry. And, given that Tommy is the heroine of the book, it&#8217;s also clear this book shares a theme that permeates many of the Pennyroyal Green books. In all but two of the eight books, a man is paired with a woman society deems unacceptable as his bride. Ms. Long writes about class distinctions well, yet reading this story again &#8211; told better in How the Marquess Was Won &#8211; makes It Happened One Midnight feel somewhat stale. Tommy is an inappropriate woman for Jonathan. She&#8217;s the illegitimate and unrecognized daughter of a Duke (guess which one?) and his long dead mistress. Her mother died when she was a child, and prior to the intervention of Countess Mirabeau, Tommy fared poorly on the London streets. She&#8217;s clever, manipulative, and ambitious. She longs for a family of her own and to feel owned by a family as well. She flirts with what seems like every unmarried aristocrat in London, but gives herself to none of them, as she is holding out for marriage. She&#8217;s also a do-gooder of dangerous proportions: She steals/rescues abused child servants and finds a safe place for them to develop a trade. This aspect of her personality makes her admirable almost to the point of perfection. She&#8217;s the Clark Kent of scandalous salons: A seemingly shallow temptress in the evening and a reckless savior of the weak at midnight. Tommy pulls Jonathan into her midnight missions and he, in turn, uses money she gives him (garnered by pawning a necklace of perfect pearls from an admirer) to fund the first runs of his new color printing press. A suggestion from Tommy about what the printing press could print and make a mint off of gives Jonathan a brilliant idea that earns him financial independence and his father&#8217;s fury. The plot is an odd meld of commerce, danger, adorable tots, explosive kisses, and self-determination. Ms. Long pulls it off although the most compelling story is not of that era&#8217;s abused impoverished young but rather of Jonathan&#8217;s strategic toppling of his father&#8217;s limiting demands. Isaiah Redmond has long been cruising for a comeuppance and it&#8217;s satisfying to see his youngest son deliver it to him. I liked Jonathan more than Tommy in part because Jonathan is deftly and deeply portrayed. Readers of the series have gotten to know him and his troubled family over many pages and he is a compelling and confident hero. Tommy is much hazier. Whole parts of her are missing (her sexual and relational past, her relationship with her mother, how she acquired her many skills, just to name a few). And unlike, Jonathan, she doesn&#8217;t have to give up anything to fuse her future with his. I did enjoy the interactions between the two. Ms. Long excels at writing witty repartee and deliciously effective love scenes. One of the pleasant aspects of It Happened One Midnight is that Tommy and Jonathan like each other long before they begin exploring the lust they feel. I worried, once they became lovers, that Jonathan conflated lust and love, but by the (sigh) epilogue, he and Tommy have the stuff that dreams are made of: True, lasting, passionate love. I count Ms. Long as one of my favorite writers. Two of her Pennyroyal books (#4 and #5) are among my top ten favorite historical romances. It Happened One Midnight is not one of Ms. Long&#8217;s best books, but nor is it a bad one. It&#8217;s good, not great. Did I like it less because I&#8217;m running out of patience with the Pennyroyal series? I don&#8217;t think so. There are things in this book besides its lack of Olivia/Lyon that didn&#8217;t work for me. After reading it twice, I decided to give it a B. I am, however, steeling myself for book nine. It&#8217;s not about Olivia and Lyon either. It&#8217;s Ian Eversea&#8217;s story (last seen being terrorized by the fabulous Duke of Falconbridge, the hero of What I Did for a Duke) and is due out next March. Pennyroyal Green fans will line up in droves to read it and, yes, I&#8217;ll be right there with them."

                "html": "<p>I am a fan of Ruthie Knox&#8217;s works. Her books are filled with characters it&#8217;s easy to care for, zingy conversations, smoking love scenes, and realistic relational conundrums. Thus I am not a whit surprised I like her latest, <b>Flirting with Disaster</b>, the third book in her <i>Camelot</i> series. This consistently entertaining series features the Clark siblings; <b>Flirting with Disaster</b> tells the tale of the youngest, Katie.</p>\n<p>Katie is back in Camelot, Ohio after her husband and high school sweetheart Levi dumped her and cleaned out their bank account. In an effort to pull her out of the dumps, her big brother Caleb (the hero of the previous book, <a href=\"https://allaboutromance.com/book-review/along-came-trouble-ruthie-knox/\"><b>Along Came Trouble</b>)</a> hires her to manage his new company Camelot Security. The job does pull Katie out of her post-Levi slump but running the office is just a step toward her new and improved future. Katie&#8217;s current goal is for Caleb to promote her to agent. Caleb, however, is on the over-protective side and has little interest putting Katie in any situation where she faces any danger.</p>\n<p>Fortunately for Katie, Judah Pratt, a famous rocker who hires Camelot Security to deal with a series of mysterious threats, takes one look at Katie and announces he&#8217;ll only hire the firm if Katie is on the job. Caleb agrees but insists Katie work with his other employee, Sean Owens. This pairing poses a problem for Katie because Sean refuses to speak to her. &#8220;<i>Not at all, not ever, not under any circumstances.&#8221;</i> Katie hasn&#8217;t a clue why she gets the silent treatment from Sean and the whole thing makes her crazy.</p>\n<p>Katie makes Sean crazy. How to interview Judah Pratt with Katie as a sidekick and manage not to stutter?</p>\n<p>He’d have to improvise.</p>\n<p>He took his phone out of his pocket and tapped out a text message. Shall we go in?</p>\n<p>Katie’s phone chirped. She checked out the screen. “Very funny.”</p>\n<p>She stomped across the gravel lot toward the building’s entrance, leaving him to trail along behind her, trying to keep his eyes off her ass.</p></blockquote>\n<p>When they walk in the club, Judah isn&#8217;t there. Sean, who came to Camelot to settle his mother&#8217;s estate, is trying to mangage his real life in California, come to terms with his unresolved feelings about his dead mother, and solve Judah&#8217;s case. Katie is striving to move past being the enabler she was with Levi, figure out what she wants to do with her life, and navigate her relationships with her family. As all this is going on, Katie and Sean are falling for each other, even as Sean plans, when Judah&#8217;s case is over, to return home to California. Ms. Knox manages to keep all these plots clear and, even better, she weaves them together so that each storyline strengthens the others.</p>\n<p><b>Flirting with Disaster</b> is, at heart, a love story and it&#8217;s one that Ms. Knox makes sweet and sexy. In its epilogue, <b>Flirting with Disaster</b> offers easy answers to pretty much everything and in doing so lessens the power of the struggles portrayed in the book. This is a book where everyone lives <b><i>too</i></b> happily ever after. Still, that&#8217;s a small flaw in an overall good book. I remain a fan.</p>\n",
                "text": "I am a fan of Ruthie Knox&#8217;s works. Her books are filled with characters it&#8217;s easy to care for, zingy conversations, smoking love scenes, and realistic relational conundrums. Thus I am not a whit surprised I like her latest, Flirting with Disaster, the third book in her Camelot series. This consistently entertaining series features the Clark siblings; Flirting with Disaster tells the tale of the youngest, Katie. Katie is back in Camelot, Ohio after her husband and high school sweetheart Levi dumped her and cleaned out their bank account. In an effort to pull her out of the dumps, her big brother Caleb (the hero of the previous book, Along Came Trouble) hires her to manage his new company Camelot Security. The job does pull Katie out of her post-Levi slump but running the office is just a step toward her new and improved future. Katie&#8217;s current goal is for Caleb to promote her to agent. Caleb, however, is on the over-protective side and has little interest putting Katie in any situation where she faces any danger. Fortunately for Katie, Judah Pratt, a famous rocker who hires Camelot Security to deal with a series of mysterious threats, takes one look at Katie and announces he&#8217;ll only hire the firm if Katie is on the job. Caleb agrees but insists Katie work with his other employee, Sean Owens. This pairing poses a problem for Katie because Sean refuses to speak to her. &#8220;Not at all, not ever, not under any circumstances.&#8221; Katie hasn&#8217;t a clue why she gets the silent treatment from Sean and the whole thing makes her crazy. Katie makes Sean crazy. Not only is she his high-school crush and the star of many of his fantasies, she triggers the stuttering problem that plagued him for years which he, until he encounters all-grown-up Katie, has generally overcome. Thus both of them are wound rather tightly as they head off to Louisville, where Judah is performing. When they arrive at the dive at which Judah asked they all meet, Katie demands to know how she and Sean are going to work together. “Seriously, can you at least write me notes? Send me emails? I don’t see how this is going to work otherwise.” She had a point. He didn’t see how it was going to work, either. How to interview Judah Pratt with Katie as a sidekick and manage not to stutter? He’d have to improvise. He took his phone out of his pocket and tapped out a text message. Shall we go in? Katie’s phone chirped. She checked out the screen. “Very funny.” She stomped across the gravel lot toward the building’s entrance, leaving him to trail along behind her, trying to keep his eyes off her ass. When they walk in the club, Judah isn&#8217;t there. In fact, once in Louisville, they find it difficult to get Judah to talk to them. He&#8217;s not at the club and he&#8217;s booked them into a hotel far from his. Sean, determined to solve this case, books himself and Katie into the swanky hotel where Judah is staying, a hotel in which the only available room is the Atrium Suite. This It Happened One Night set-up has been done a thousand times but Ms. Knox makes it seem fresh and hilarious. Sean&#8217;s not the only one with lust in his heart. Before they&#8217;ve even managed to eat the food Katie&#8217;s ordered up for dinner, Katie&#8217;s realizes she&#8217;s warm for Sean&#8217;s form. Their lust-o-rama is complicated by not only Sean&#8217;s inability to talk to Katie but by Judah&#8217;s apparent lust for Katie as well. That evening, when Katie and Sean meet up with Judah, tensions are high. Judah refuses to tell Sean and Katie anything about the threats &#8211; this both mystifies and pisses off Sean. Judah does agree, however, to talk with just Katie, after the show, in his hotel room. This makes Sean so irate he does the only thing he can think of to warn off Judah and draw in Katie: He kisses her. This was what he’d wanted to tell her earlier in the room. This. Her energy moved into him where they touched, thighs and mouths and his palm on her bare skin, the other wrapped around the nape of her neck. The pleasure of smelling her, touching her, unhitched something essential he kept reined in, and he felt the sudden rush of it, the terrible freedom of losing control— And that made him stop. &#8230;When he pulled away, she made a sound, a sort of helpless squeak that said she wanted to continue, and hearing it called up a desperate ache in his chest that he immediately locked down. Appalling, what she did to him. He wanted her. Right here, right now, with that black dress bunched up around her thighs. He wanted her anywhere, everywhere, any way he could get her. Despite the kiss, Katie goes to Judah&#8217;s room where she realizes Judah&#8217;s just pretending to be interested in her. When she asks what he&#8217;s up to, he tells her tells her he has no idea, that he just knows she&#8217;s supposed to be there, to help him in some way. This book has a lot going on it. Judah has a complicated life and, as he and Katie become friends, the two work to sort out the many issues in Judah&#8217;s life. Sean, who came to Camelot to settle his mother&#8217;s estate, is trying to mangage his real life in California, come to terms with his unresolved feelings about his dead mother, and solve Judah&#8217;s case. Katie is striving to move past being the enabler she was with Levi, figure out what she wants to do with her life, and navigate her relationships with her family. As all this is going on, Katie and Sean are falling for each other, even as Sean plans, when Judah&#8217;s case is over, to return home to California. Ms. Knox manages to keep all these plots clear and, even better, she weaves them together so that each storyline strengthens the others. Flirting with Disaster is, at heart, a love story and it&#8217;s one that Ms. Knox makes sweet and sexy. The scenes between Sean and Katie are filled with wit and want. Here, Sean is asking Katie about the romance novels she loves to read. “What do you read those books for?” “Same reason anyone does, I guess.” “Are they your ffantasies?” “Some of them,” she said. “Not all.” His hands on the steering wheel drew her eyes. He had such big hands. His nails were blunt and short and unpretty. Rough hands. Hands that had gathered her close and held her in place when he took that kiss. “Have you ever been with a man who d-did those things to you?” His voice had turned husky and dark. “Talked dirty to you? Spanked you? Tied you up and sspent hours figuring out how many ways he could make you c-come with his tongue?” “No.” She put as much scorn into the word as she could manage. As if scorn could protect her from the way he was turning her on. Or prevent him from knowing he was doing it. It was no use. Sean turned to look at her, and he smiled the wickedest smile she’d ever seen. A smile that said he knew exactly what he was doing, and he’d known all along. “Sounds like the guys you’ve been with have been reading all the wrong books.” My only complaint about the book is its rushed and rather formulaic ending. In its epilogue, Flirting with Disaster offers easy answers to pretty much everything and in doing so lessens the power of the struggles portrayed in the book. This is a book where everyone lives too happily ever after. Still, that&#8217;s a small flaw in an overall good book. I remain a fan."

            "content": {
                "html": "<p>The last Susan Sey book I read, <b>Money Shot</b> (2011) was set on a remote island in Lake Superior and had deadly money laundering villain, pagan ceremonies, and a smokin&#8217; ex Navy SEAL for a hero. This book, <b>Taste for Trouble</b>, is set in the suburbs of DC, has a scheming Martha Stewart wannabe, and a professional soccer playing sorta hot Southern gentleman for a hero. I loved <b>Money Shot</b>; I like <b>Taste for Trouble</b>.</p>\n<p><b>Taste for Trouble</b> opens with the familiar scene of a perfectionist female getting left at the altar by her &#8220;I&#8217;ve fallen in love with your assistant&#8221; fiance. The dumpee is Belinda West, a driven woman who is the second in command on &#8220;Kate Every Day,&#8221; a popular syndicated daytime TV show. Belinda is upset about her jilting, but not because she loves her jilter. He is just a good friend who, until he fell for another woman, had agreed with Belinda that <i>“Love is nothing more than an excuse to be fickle, impulsive and selfish. People shouldn’t build a lunch date around it, let alone a marriage.&#8221;</i> Belinda is, however, dismayed that the entire world, as well as Kate of &#8220;Kate Every Day&#8221;, has just watched Belinda&#8217;s non-wedding on national TV. Kate, who is poised to pick her successor &#8211; Belinda was sure it would be her &#8211; tells Belinda she&#8217;s clearly not up to &#8220;Kate Every Day&#8221; standards and fires her.</p>\n<p>Belinda and Kate&#8217;s agent, a truly lovely man named Bob Beck, tells Belinda she can win her job back if she takes agrees to a (ludicrous) scheme Bob and Kate have cooked up. Another of Bob&#8217;s clients, the man-child soccer star James Blake, is in need of a manners nanny. James is in danger of being kicked off the DC Statesmen because, as Bob says, &#8220;He drinks, he fights, and if he’s ever had a date he didn’t pick up in a strip club I’ve never met her.” Bob proposes that Belinda spend the four weeks supervising James and his two brothers, Will and Drew. When Belinda asks for clarification, Bob explains.</p>\n<blockquote><p>“It means that each week for the next four weeks, Kate will assign you a new social grace to teach our boy. At the end of each week, she’ll evaluate his performance and yours. Brutally. You pass and you get your job back in time for the <i>Kate Every Day</i> Christmas Special.”</p></blockquote>\n<p>Belinda, who has spent the last twelve years of her life, dreaming of living a &#8220;Kate Every Day&#8221; life, agrees.</p>\n<p>The premise of this novel didn&#8217;t do a thing for me. It seems forced, silly, and unbelievable. I doubted Ms. Sey, though her <i>Money</i> books are excellently plotted, could make this work. I was wrong. Though the premise never became any less unlikely, the characters in <i>Taste for Trouble</i> sell the story. Belinda and James, as well as a host of well-developed secondary characters, are interesting, well-written, and emotionally engaging.</p>\n<p>One of the truly striking things about this book is how profoundly it both shows and tells the reader that family is everything. James, Will, and Drew are a unit because that&#8217;s who they are. As James explains to Belinda, the only child of a self-absorbed soul-wrecker of a mother, the Blakes have a code.</p>\n<blockquote><p>&#8220;&#8230;we know what’s important. We know that family is precious, that love is rare, that fate is unkind. We learned those lessons the hard way, and it taught us how to protect what we love against anybody and anything that threatens it.”</p></blockquote>\n<p>What&#8217;s interesting is that Ms. Sey doesn&#8217;t make the filial bonds the Blake boys share easy ones. In fact, my favorite part of the book is how bitter and angry Will (my favorite character as well), James&#8217;s older brother, is about the ties that bind him to his brothers. Will is one unhappy man. He&#8217;s a borderline alcoholic with a compulsive need to lash out and destroy. He is furious at the ease with which James gets everything: success, money, women, friends, and love. He tears down Drew&#8217;s simple joy in everyday life every chance he gets. He hates who he is but he can&#8217;t stop himself from being so self-destructive. Yet it clear he loves his brothers deeply and their love for him exists whether or not he&#8217;s an utter ass. The next book is Will&#8217;s story and I can&#8217;t wait to read it.</p>\n<p>Though their parents are dead, the Blakes are a clan (they even have a family crest). Their bonded life exists in sharp contrast to Belinda&#8217;s (and her boss Kate&#8217;s) very isolated one. This difference in life experience shapes how differently Belinda and James see their attraction to each other. Belinda fights it because not only is love a messy business, James is her job. Belinda has made her life work by living by a series of rules and one of those is that it is unprofessional to get involved with client. This distinction means nothing to James. He begins falling for Belinda from the moment he meets her. Soon, he cares deeply for her and, for James, that connection is all that matters. Their relationship is winning without being sappy, sexy without being overheated.</p>\n<p>At times, this book felt like a Desert Island Keeper to me. In other places, it felt like an inchoate mess. But even when a plot-line didn&#8217;t work or a character behaved incomprehensibly, I wanted to keep reading. This is a read that, in places, made my heart hurt. I cried at the end, the kind of tears that make you want to find those you love and hold them in your arms. I connected with the Blakes and Belinda, with Kate &#8211; poor, bitchy Kate &#8211; and Bob, and with Audrey (Will&#8217;s love interest) and her little girl. I wanted all of these characters to find happiness. Not all do and that too makes this a stronger book than its plot would suggest. I&#8217;m glad I read it. I&#8217;ll be waiting eagerly for <b>Talent for Trouble</b>, the next tale in the trilogy.</p>\n<h3>Buy it on <a href=\"https://amzn.to/2CZLTFG\">Amazon</a>/<a href=\"https://geo.itunes.apple.com/us/book/taste-for-trouble/id1231811891?mt=11&amp;at=1010lmPQ\">Apple Books</a>/<a href=\"http://www.anrdoezrs.net/links/8039827/type/dlg/https://www.barnesandnoble.com/w/taste-for-trouble-susan-sey/1126480395?ean=2940157198527\">Barnes &amp; Noble</a>/<a href=\"https://click.linksynergy.com/deeplink?id=b95pXvP*dp4&amp;mid=37217&amp;murl=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.kobo.com%2Fus%2Fen%2Febook%2Ftaste-for-trouble\">Kobo</a></h3>\n",
